You may copy it, give it away or\r\n'b're-use it under the terms of the Project Gutenberg License included\r\n'b'with this eBook or online at www.gutenberg.org\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Title: The Mysterious Island\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Author: Jules Verne\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Posting Date: August 24, 2008 [EBook #1268]\r\n'b'Release Date: April, 1998\r\n'b'Last Updated: October 13, 2016\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Language: English\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Character set encoding: UTF-8\r\n'b'\r\n'b'*** START OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK THE MYSTERIOUS ISLAND ***\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Produced by Anthony Matonak, and Trevor Carlson\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'THE MYSTERIOUS ISLAND\r\n'b'\r\n'b'by Jules Verne\r\n'b'\r\n'b'1874\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'PART 1--DROPPED FROM THE CLOUDS\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 1\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre we rising again?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNo. On the contrary.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAre we descending?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' \xe2\x80\x9cWorse than that, captain! we are falling!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cFor Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake heave out\r\n'b'the ballast!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThere! the last sack is empty!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cDoes the balloon rise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' \xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI hear a noise like the dashing of waves. The sea is below the\r\n'b'car! It cannot be more than 500 feet from us!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cOverboard with every\r\n'b'weight! ... everything!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Such were the loud and startling words which resounded through the air,\r\n'b'above the vast watery desert of the Pacific, about four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the\r\n'b'evening of the 23rd of March, 1865.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Few can possibly have forgotten the terrible storm from the northeast,\r\n'b'in the middle of the equinox of that year. The tempest raged without\r\n'b'intermission from the 18th to the 26th of March. Its ravages were\r\n'b'terrible in America, Europe, and Asia, covering a distance of eighteen\r\n'b'hundred miles, and extending obliquely to the equator from the\r\n'b'thirty-fifth north parallel to the fortieth south parallel. Towns were\r\n'b'overthrown, forests uprooted, coasts devastated by the mountains of\r\n'b'water which were precipitated on them, vessels cast on the shore, which\r\n'b'the published accounts numbered by hundreds, whole districts leveled\r\n'b'by waterspouts which destroyed everything they passed over, several\r\n'b'thousand people crushed on land or drowned at sea; such were the traces\r\n'b'of its fury, left by this devastating tempest. It surpassed in disasters\r\n'b'those which so frightfully ravaged Havana and Guadalupe, one on the 25th\r\n'b'of October, 1810, the other on the 26th of July, 1825.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But while so many catastrophes were taking place on land and at sea, a\r\n'b'drama not less exciting was being enacted in the agitated air.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, a balloon, as a ball might be carried on the summit of a\r\n'b'waterspout, had been taken into the circling movement of a column of\r\n'b'air and had traversed space at the rate of ninety miles an hour, turning\r\n'b'round and round as if seized by some aerial maelstrom.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Beneath the lower point of the balloon swung a car, containing five\r\n'b'passengers, scarcely visible in the midst of the thick vapor mingled\r\n'b'with spray which hung over the surface of the ocean.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Whence, it may be asked, had come that plaything of the tempest? From\r\n'b'what part of the world did it rise? It surely could not have started\r\n'b'during the storm. But the storm had raged five days already, and the\r\n'b'first symptoms were manifested on the 18th. It cannot be doubted that\r\n'b'the balloon came from a great distance, for it could not have traveled\r\n'b'less than two thousand miles in twenty-four hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At any rate the passengers, destitute of all marks for their guidance,\r\n'b'could not have possessed the means of reckoning the route traversed\r\n'b'since their departure. It was a remarkable fact that, although in the\r\n'b'very midst of the furious tempest, they did not suffer from it. They\r\n'b'were thrown about and whirled round and round without feeling the\r\n'b'rotation in the slightest degree, or being sensible that they were\r\n'b'removed from a horizontal position.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their eyes could not pierce through the thick mist which had gathered\r\n'b'beneath the car. Dark vapor was all around them. Such was the density\r\n'b'of the atmosphere that they could not be certain whether it was day or\r\n'b'night. No reflection of light, no sound from inhabited land, no roaring\r\n'b'of the ocean could have reached them, through the obscurity, while\r\n'b'suspended in those elevated zones. Their rapid descent alone had\r\n'b'informed them of the dangers which they ran from the waves. However,\r\n'b'the balloon, lightened of heavy articles, such as ammunition, arms, and\r\n'b'provisions, had risen into the higher layers of the atmosphere, to a\r\n'b'height of 4,500 feet. The voyagers, after having discovered that the sea\r\n'b'extended beneath them, and thinking the dangers above less dreadful than\r\n'b'those below, did not hesitate to throw overboard even their most useful\r\n'b'articles, while they endeavored to lose no more of that fluid, the life\r\n'b'of their enterprise, which sustained them above the abyss.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night passed in the midst of alarms which would have been death to\r\n'b'less energetic souls. Again the day appeared and with it the tempest\r\n'b'began to moderate. From the beginning of that day, the 24th of March,\r\n'b'it showed symptoms of abating. At dawn, some of the lighter clouds had\r\n'b'risen into the more lofty regions of the air. In a few hours the wind\r\n'b'had changed from a hurricane to a fresh breeze, that is to say, the rate\r\n'b'of the transit of the atmospheric layers was diminished by half. It\r\n'b'was still what sailors call \xe2\x80\x9ca close-reefed topsail breeze,\xe2\x80\x9d but the\r\n'b'commotion in the elements had none the less considerably diminished.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the lower region of the air was sensibly\r\n'b'clearer. The atmosphere threw off that chilly dampness which is felt\r\n'b'after the passage of a great meteor. The storm did not seem to have gone\r\n'b'farther to the west. It appeared to have exhausted itself. Could it have\r\n'b'passed away in electric sheets, as is sometimes the case with regard to\r\n'b'the typhoons of the Indian Ocean?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But at the same time, it was also evident that the balloon was again\r\n'b'slowly descending with a regular movement. It appeared as if it were,\r\n'b'little by little, collapsing, and that its case was lengthening and\r\n'b'extending, passing from a spherical to an oval form. Towards midday the\r\n'b'balloon was hovering above the sea at a height of only 2,000 feet. It\r\n'b'contained 50,000 cubic feet of gas, and, thanks to its capacity, it\r\n'b'could maintain itself a long time in the air, although it should reach a\r\n'b'great altitude or might be thrown into a horizontal position.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Perceiving their danger, the passengers cast away the last articles\r\n'b'which still weighed down the car, the few provisions they had kept,\r\n'b'everything, even to their pocket-knives, and one of them, having hoisted\r\n'b'himself on to the circles which united the cords of the net, tried to\r\n'b'secure more firmly the lower point of the balloon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was, however, evident to the voyagers that the gas was failing, and\r\n'b'that the balloon could no longer be sustained in the higher regions.\r\n'b'They must infallibly perish!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was not a continent, nor even an island, visible beneath them.\r\n'b'The watery expanse did not present a single speck of land, not a solid\r\n'b'surface upon which their anchor could hold.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the open sea, whose waves were still dashing with tremendous\r\n'b'violence! It was the ocean, without any visible limits, even for those\r\n'b'whose gaze, from their commanding position, extended over a radius of\r\n'b'forty miles. The vast liquid plain, lashed without mercy by the storm,\r\n'b'appeared as if covered with herds of furious chargers, whose white and\r\n'b'disheveled crests were streaming in the wind. No land was in sight, not\r\n'b'a solitary ship could be seen. It was necessary at any cost to arrest\r\n'b'their downward course, and to prevent the balloon from being engulfed in\r\n'b'the waves. The voyagers directed all their energies to this urgent work.\r\n'b'But, notwithstanding their efforts, the balloon still fell, and at the\r\n'b'same time shifted with the greatest rapidity, following the direction of\r\n'b'the wind, that is to say, from the northeast to the southwest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Frightful indeed was the situation of these unfortunate men. They were\r\n'b'evidently no longer masters of the machine. All their attempts were\r\n'b'useless. The case of the balloon collapsed more and more. The gas\r\n'b'escaped without any possibility of retaining it. Their descent was\r\n'b'visibly accelerated, and soon after midday the car hung within 600 feet\r\n'b'of the ocean.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was impossible to prevent the escape of gas, which rushed through a\r\n'b'large rent in the silk. By lightening the car of all the articles which\r\n'b'it contained, the passengers had been able to prolong their suspension\r\n'b'in the air for a few hours. But the inevitable catastrophe could only\r\n'b'be retarded, and if land did not appear before night, voyagers, car, and\r\n'b'balloon must to a certainty vanish beneath the waves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They now resorted to the only remaining expedient. They were truly\r\n'b'dauntless men, who knew how to look death in the face. Not a single\r\n'b'murmur escaped from their lips. They were determined to struggle to the\r\n'b'last minute, to do anything to retard their fall. The car was only a\r\n'b'sort of willow basket, unable to float, and there was not the slightest\r\n'b'possibility of maintaining it on the surface of the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two more hours passed and the balloon was scarcely 400 feet above the\r\n'b'water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment a loud voice, the voice of a man whose heart was\r\n'b'inaccessible to fear, was heard. To this voice responded others not\r\n'b'less determined. \xe2\x80\x9cIs everything thrown out?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNo, here are still 2,000\r\n'b'dollars in gold.\xe2\x80\x9d A heavy bag immediately plunged into the sea. \xe2\x80\x9cDoes\r\n'b'the balloon rise?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cA little, but it will not be long before it falls\r\n'b'again.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWhat still remains to be thrown out?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYes! the\r\n'b'car!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cLet us catch hold of the net, and into the sea with the car.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was, in fact, the last and only mode of lightening the balloon.\r\n'b'The ropes which held the car were cut, and the balloon, after its fall,\r\n'b'mounted 2,000 feet. The five voyagers had hoisted themselves into the\r\n'b'net, and clung to the meshes, gazing at the abyss.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The delicate sensibility of balloons is well known. It is sufficient to\r\n'b'throw out the lightest article to produce a difference in its vertical\r\n'b'position. The apparatus in the air is like a balance of mathematical\r\n'b'precision. It can be thus easily understood that when it is lightened of\r\n'b'any considerable weight its movement will be impetuous and sudden. So\r\n'b'it happened on this occasion. But after being suspended for an instant\r\n'b'aloft, the balloon began to redescend, the gas escaping by the rent\r\n'b'which it was impossible to repair.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The men had done all that men could do. No human efforts could save them\r\n'b'now.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They must trust to the mercy of Him who rules the elements.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At four o\xe2\x80\x99clock the balloon was only 500 feet above the surface of the\r\n'b'water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A loud barking was heard. A dog accompanied the voyagers, and was held\r\n'b'pressed close to his master in the meshes of the net.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop has seen something,\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of the men. Then immediately a loud\r\n'b'voice shouted,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLand! land!\xe2\x80\x9d The balloon, which the wind still drove towards the\r\n'b'southwest, had since daybreak gone a considerable distance, which might\r\n'b'be reckoned by hundreds of miles, and a tolerably high land had, in\r\n'b'fact, appeared in that direction. But this land was still thirty miles\r\n'b'off. It would not take less than an hour to get to it, and then there\r\n'b'was the chance of falling to leeward.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An hour! Might not the balloon before that be emptied of all the fluid\r\n'b'it yet retained?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Such was the terrible question! The voyagers could distinctly see that\r\n'b'solid spot which they must reach at any cost. They were ignorant of what\r\n'b'it was, whether an island or a continent, for they did not know to what\r\n'b'part of the world the hurricane had driven them. But they must reach\r\n'b'this land, whether inhabited or desolate, whether hospitable or not.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was evident that the balloon could no longer support itself! Several\r\n'b'times already had the crests of the enormous billows licked the bottom\r\n'b'of the net, making it still heavier, and the balloon only half rose,\r\n'b'like a bird with a wounded wing. Half an hour later the land was not\r\n'b'more than a mile off, but the balloon, exhausted, flabby, hanging in\r\n'b'great folds, had gas in its upper part alone. The voyagers, clinging to\r\n'b'the net, were still too heavy for it, and soon, half plunged into the\r\n'b'sea, they were beaten by the furious waves. The balloon-case bulged out\r\n'b'again, and the wind, taking it, drove it along like a vessel. Might it\r\n'b'not possibly thus reach the land?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But, when only two fathoms off, terrible cries resounded from four pairs\r\n'b'of lungs at once. The balloon, which had appeared as if it would never\r\n'b'again rise, suddenly made an unexpected bound, after having been struck\r\n'b'by a tremendous sea. As if it had been at that instant relieved of a new\r\n'b'part of its weight, it mounted to a height of 1,500 feet, and here it\r\n'b'met a current of wind, which instead of taking it directly to the coast,\r\n'b'carried it in a nearly parallel direction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last, two minutes later, it reproached obliquely, and finally fell on\r\n'b'a sandy beach, out of the reach of the waves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The voyagers, aiding each other, managed to disengage themselves from\r\n'b'the meshes of the net. The balloon, relieved of their weight, was taken\r\n'b'by the wind, and like a wounded bird which revives for an instant,\r\n'b'disappeared into space.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the car had contained five passengers, with a dog, and the balloon\r\n'b'only left four on the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The missing person had evidently been swept off by the sea, which had\r\n'b'just struck the net, and it was owing to this circumstance that the\r\n'b'lightened balloon rose the last time, and then soon after reached the\r\n'b'land. Scarcely had the four castaways set foot on firm ground, than they\r\n'b'all, thinking of the absent one, simultaneously exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he\r\n'b'will try to swim to land! Let us save him! let us save him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 2\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Those whom the hurricane had just thrown on this coast were neither\r\n'b'aeronauts by profession nor amateurs. They were prisoners of war whose\r\n'b'boldness had induced them to escape in this extraordinary manner.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A hundred times they had almost perished! A hundred times had they\r\n'b'almost fallen from their torn balloon into the depths of the ocean. But\r\n'b'Heaven had reserved them for a strange destiny, and after having, on the\r\n'b'20th of March, escaped from Richmond, besieged by the troops of General\r\n'b'Ulysses Grant, they found themselves seven thousand miles from the\r\n'b'capital of Virginia, which was the principal stronghold of the South,\r\n'b'during the terrible War of Secession. Their aerial voyage had lasted\r\n'b'five days.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The curious circumstances which led to the escape of the prisoners were\r\n'b'as follows:\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That same year, in the month of February, 1865, in one of the coups\r\n'b'de main by which General Grant attempted, though in vain, to possess\r\n'b'himself of Richmond, several of his officers fell into the power of the\r\n'b'enemy and were detained in the town. One of the most distinguished was\r\n'b'Captain Cyrus Harding. He was a native of Massachusetts, a first-class\r\n'b'engineer, to whom the government had confided, during the war, the\r\n'b'direction of the railways, which were so important at that time. A\r\n'b'true Northerner, thin, bony, lean, about forty-five years of age; his\r\n'b'close-cut hair and his beard, of which he only kept a thick mustache,\r\n'b'were already getting gray. He had one-of those finely-developed heads\r\n'b'which appear made to be struck on a medal, piercing eyes, a serious\r\n'b'mouth, the physiognomy of a clever man of the military school. He was\r\n'b'one of those engineers who began by handling the hammer and pickaxe,\r\n'b'like generals who first act as common soldiers. Besides mental power, he\r\n'b'also possessed great manual dexterity. His muscles exhibited remarkable\r\n'b'proofs of tenacity. A man of action as well as a man of thought, all he\r\n'b'did was without effort to one of his vigorous and sanguine temperament.\r\n'b'Learned, clear-headed, and practical, he fulfilled in all\r\n'b'emergencies those three conditions which united ought to insure human\r\n'b'success--activity of mind and body, impetuous wishes, and powerful will.\r\n'b'He might have taken for his motto that of William of Orange in the 17th\r\n'b'century: \xe2\x80\x9cI can undertake and persevere even without hope of success.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' Cyrus Harding was courage personified. He had been in all the battles of\r\n'b'that war. After having begun as a volunteer at Illinois, under Ulysses\r\n'b'Grant, he fought at Paducah, Belmont, Pittsburg Landing, at the siege of\r\n'b'Corinth, Port Gibson, Black River, Chattanooga, the Wilderness, on the\r\n'b'Potomac, everywhere and valiantly, a soldier worthy of the general who\r\n'b'said, \xe2\x80\x9cI never count my dead!\xe2\x80\x9d And hundreds of times Captain Harding had\r\n'b'almost been among those who were not counted by the terrible Grant; but\r\n'b'in these combats where he never spared himself, fortune favored him till\r\n'b'the moment when he was wounded and taken prisoner on the field of battle\r\n'b'near Richmond. At the same time and on the same day another important\r\n'b'personage fell into the hands of the Southerners. This was no other than\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, a reporter for the New York Herald, who had been ordered\r\n'b'to follow the changes of the war in the midst of the Northern armies.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett was one of that race of indomitable English or American\r\n'b'chroniclers, like Stanley and others, who stop at nothing to obtain\r\n'b'exact information, and transmit it to their journal in the shortest\r\n'b'possible time. The newspapers of the Union, such as the New York Herald,\r\n'b'are genuine powers, and their reporters are men to be reckoned with.\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett ranked among the first of those reporters: a man of great\r\n'b'merit, energetic, prompt and ready for anything, full of ideas, having\r\n'b'traveled over the whole world, soldier and artist, enthusiastic in\r\n'b'council, resolute in action, caring neither for trouble, fatigue, nor\r\n'b'danger, when in pursuit of information, for himself first, and then for\r\n'b'his journal, a perfect treasury of knowledge on all sorts of curious\r\n'b'subjects, of the unpublished, of the unknown, and of the impossible. He\r\n'b'was one of those intrepid observers who write under fire, \xe2\x80\x9creporting\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' among bullets, and to whom every danger is welcome.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He also had been in all the battles, in the first rank, revolver in one\r\n'b'hand, note-book in the other; grape-shot never made his pencil tremble.\r\n'b'He did not fatigue the wires with incessant telegrams, like those who\r\n'b'speak when they have nothing to say, but each of his notes, short,\r\n'b'decisive, and clear, threw light on some important point. Besides, he\r\n'b'was not wanting in humor. It was he who, after the affair of the Black\r\n'b'River, determined at any cost to keep his place at the wicket of the\r\n'b'telegraph office, and after having announced to his journal the result\r\n'b'of the battle, telegraphed for two hours the first chapters of the\r\n'b'Bible. It cost the New York Herald two thousand dollars, but the New\r\n'b'York Herald published the first intelligence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett was tall. He was rather more than forty years of age.\r\n'b'Light whiskers bordering on red surrounded his face. His eye was steady,\r\n'b'lively, rapid in its changes. It was the eye of a man accustomed to take\r\n'b'in at a glance all the details of a scene. Well built, he was inured to\r\n'b'all climates, like a bar of steel hardened in cold water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For ten years Gideon Spilett had been the reporter of the New York\r\n'b'Herald, which he enriched by his letters and drawings, for he was as\r\n'b'skilful in the use of the pencil as of the pen. When he was captured,\r\n'b'he was in the act of making a description and sketch of the battle. The\r\n'b'last words in his note-book were these: \xe2\x80\x9cA Southern rifleman has just\r\n'b'taken aim at me, but--\xe2\x80\x9d The Southerner notwithstanding missed Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, who, with his usual fortune, came out of this affair without a\r\n'b'scratch.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett, who did not know each other except\r\n'b'by reputation, had both been carried to Richmond. The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'wounds rapidly healed, and it was during his convalescence that he made\r\n'b'acquaintance with the reporter. The two men then learned to appreciate\r\n'b'each other. Soon their common aim had but one object, that of escaping,\r\n'b'rejoining Grant\xe2\x80\x99s army, and fighting together in the ranks of the\r\n'b'Federals.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The two Americans had from the first determined to seize every chance;\r\n'b'but although they were allowed to wander at liberty in the town,\r\n'b'Richmond was so strictly guarded, that escape appeared impossible. In\r\n'b'the meanwhile Captain Harding was rejoined by a servant who was devoted\r\n'b'to him in life and in death. This intrepid fellow was a Negro born on\r\n'b'the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s estate, of a slave father and mother, but to whom Cyrus,\r\n'b'who was an Abolitionist from conviction and heart, had long since given\r\n'b'his freedom. The once slave, though free, would not leave his master. He\r\n'b'would have died for him. He was a man of about thirty, vigorous, active,\r\n'b'clever, intelligent, gentle, and calm, sometimes naive, always merry,\r\n'b'obliging, and honest. His name was Nebuchadnezzar, but he only answered\r\n'b'to the familiar abbreviation of Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When Neb heard that his master had been made prisoner, he left\r\n'b'Massachusetts without hesitating an instant, arrived before Richmond,\r\n'b'and by dint of stratagem and shrewdness, after having risked his life\r\n'b'twenty times over, managed to penetrate into the besieged town. The\r\n'b'pleasure of Harding on seeing his servant, and the joy of Neb at finding\r\n'b'his master, can scarcely be described.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But though Neb had been able to make his way into Richmond, it was quite\r\n'b'another thing to get out again, for the Northern prisoners were very\r\n'b'strictly watched. Some extraordinary opportunity was needed to make the\r\n'b'attempt with any chance of success, and this opportunity not only did\r\n'b'not present itself, but was very difficult to find.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile Grant continued his energetic operations. The victory of\r\n'b'Petersburg had been very dearly bought. His forces, united to those of\r\n'b'Butler, had as yet been unsuccessful before Richmond, and nothing gave\r\n'b'the prisoners any hope of a speedy deliverance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter, to whom his tedious captivity did not offer a single\r\n'b'incident worthy of note, could stand it no longer. His usually active\r\n'b'mind was occupied with one sole thought--how he might get out of\r\n'b'Richmond at any cost. Several times had he even made the attempt,\r\n'b'but was stopped by some insurmountable obstacle. However, the siege\r\n'b'continued; and if the prisoners were anxious to escape and join Grant\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'army, certain of the besieged were no less anxious to join the Southern\r\n'b'forces. Among them was one Jonathan Forster, a determined Southerner.\r\n'b'The truth was, that if the prisoners of the Secessionists could not\r\n'b'leave the town, neither could the Secessionists themselves while the\r\n'b'Northern army invested it. The Governor of Richmond for a long time had\r\n'b'been unable to communicate with General Lee, and he very much wished to\r\n'b'make known to him the situation of the town, so as to hasten the march\r\n'b'of the army to their relief. Thus Jonathan Forster accordingly conceived\r\n'b'the idea of rising in a balloon, so as to pass over the besieging lines,\r\n'b'and in that way reach the Secessionist camp.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The Governor authorized the attempt. A balloon was manufactured and\r\n'b'placed at the disposal of Forster, who was to be accompanied by five\r\n'b'other persons. They were furnished with arms in case they might have\r\n'b'to defend themselves when they alighted, and provisions in the event of\r\n'b'their aerial voyage being prolonged.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The departure of the balloon was fixed for the 18th of March. It should\r\n'b'be effected during the night, with a northwest wind of moderate force,\r\n'b'and the aeronauts calculated that they would reach General Lee\xe2\x80\x99s camp in\r\n'b'a few hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But this northwest wind was not a simple breeze. From the 18th it was\r\n'b'evident that it was changing to a hurricane. The tempest soon became\r\n'b'such that Forster\xe2\x80\x99s departure was deferred, for it was impossible to\r\n'b'risk the balloon and those whom it carried in the midst of the furious\r\n'b'elements.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The balloon, inflated on the great square of Richmond, was ready to\r\n'b'depart on the first abatement of the wind, and, as may be supposed, the\r\n'b'impatience among the besieged to see the storm moderate was very great.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The 18th, the 19th of March passed without any alteration in the\r\n'b'weather. There was even great difficulty in keeping the balloon fastened\r\n'b'to the ground, as the squalls dashed it furiously about.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night of the 19th passed, but the next morning the storm blew with\r\n'b'redoubled force. The departure of the balloon was impossible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On that day the engineer, Cyrus Harding, was accosted in one of the\r\n'b'streets of Richmond by a person whom he did not in the least know. This\r\n'b'was a sailor named Pencroft, a man of about thirty-five or forty years\r\n'b'of age, strongly built, very sunburnt, and possessed of a pair of\r\n'b'bright sparkling eyes and a remarkably good physiognomy. Pencroft was an\r\n'b'American from the North, who had sailed all the ocean over, and who had\r\n'b'gone through every possible and almost impossible adventure that a being\r\n'b'with two feet and no wings would encounter. It is needless to say that\r\n'b'he was a bold, dashing fellow, ready to dare anything and was astonished\r\n'b'at nothing. Pencroft at the beginning of the year had gone to Richmond\r\n'b'on business, with a young boy of fifteen from New Jersey, son of a\r\n'b'former captain, an orphan, whom he loved as if he had been his\r\n'b'own child. Not having been able to leave the town before the first\r\n'b'operations of the siege, he found himself shut up, to his great disgust;\r\n'b'but, not accustomed to succumb to difficulties, he resolved to escape by\r\n'b'some means or other. He knew the engineer-officer by reputation; he knew\r\n'b'with what impatience that determined man chafed under his restraint. On\r\n'b'this day he did not, therefore, hesitate to accost him, saying, without\r\n'b'circumlocution, \xe2\x80\x9cHave you had enough of Richmond, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer looked fixedly at the man who spoke, and who added, in a\r\n'b'low voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding, will you try to escape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer quickly, and it was evident that this\r\n'b'question was uttered without consideration, for he had not yet examined\r\n'b'the stranger who addressed him. But after having with a penetrating\r\n'b'eye observed the open face of the sailor, he was convinced that he had\r\n'b'before him an honest man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked briefly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft made himself known.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand in what way do you propose to escape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy that lazy balloon which is left there doing nothing, and which looks\r\n'b'to me as if it was waiting on purpose for us--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no necessity for the sailor to finish his sentence. The\r\n'b'engineer understood him at once. He seized Pencroft by the arm, and\r\n'b'dragged him to his house. There the sailor developed his project, which\r\n'b'was indeed extremely simple. They risked nothing but their lives in its\r\n'b'execution. The hurricane was in all its violence, it is true, but so\r\n'b'clever and daring an engineer as Cyrus Harding knew perfectly well how\r\n'b'to manage a balloon. Had he himself been as well acquainted with the art\r\n'b'of sailing in the air as he was with the navigation of a ship, Pencroft\r\n'b'would not have hesitated to set out, of course taking his young friend\r\n'b'Herbert with him; for, accustomed to brave the fiercest tempests of the\r\n'b'ocean, he was not to be hindered on account of the hurricane.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Harding had listened to the sailor without saying a word,\r\n'b'but his eyes shone with satisfaction. Here was the long-sought-for\r\n'b'opportunity--he was not a man to let it pass. The plan was feasible,\r\n'b'though, it must be confessed, dangerous in the extreme. In the night,\r\n'b'in spite of their guards, they might approach the balloon, slip into the\r\n'b'car, and then cut the cords which held it. There was no doubt that they\r\n'b'might be killed, but on the other hand they might succeed, and without\r\n'b'this storm!--Without this storm the balloon would have started already\r\n'b'and the looked-for opportunity would not have then presented itself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not alone!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding at last.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHow many people do you wish to bring with you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTwo; my friend Spilett, and my servant Neb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be three,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cand with Herbert and me five.\r\n'b'But the balloon will hold six--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be enough, we will go,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding in a firm voice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x9d included Spilett, for the reporter, as his friend well knew,\r\n'b'was not a man to draw back, and when the project was communicated to him\r\n'b'he approved of it unreservedly. What astonished him was, that so simple\r\n'b'an idea had not occurred to him before. As to Neb, he followed his\r\n'b'master wherever his master wished to go.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis evening, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will all meet out there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis evening, at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Captain Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cand Heaven\r\n'b'grant that the storm does not abate before our departure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft took leave of the two friends, and returned to his lodging,\r\n'b'where young Herbert Brown had remained. The courageous boy knew of the\r\n'b'sailor\xe2\x80\x99s plan, and it was not without anxiety that he awaited the result\r\n'b'of the proposal being made to the engineer. Thus five determined\r\n'b'persons were about to abandon themselves to the mercy of the tempestuous\r\n'b'elements!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No! the storm did not abate, and neither Jonathan Forster nor his\r\n'b'companions dreamed of confronting it in that frail car.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It would be a terrible journey. The engineer only feared one thing; it\r\n'b'was that the balloon, held to the ground and dashed about by the\r\n'b'wind, would be torn into shreds. For several hours he roamed round the\r\n'b'nearly-deserted square, surveying the apparatus. Pencroft did the same\r\n'b'on his side, his hands in his pockets, yawning now and then like a man\r\n'b'who did not know how to kill the time, but really dreading, like\r\n'b'his friend, either the escape or destruction of the balloon. Evening\r\n'b'arrived. The night was dark in the extreme. Thick mists passed like\r\n'b'clouds close to the ground. Rain fell mingled with snow, it was very\r\n'b'cold. A mist hung over Richmond. It seemed as if the violent storm had\r\n'b'produced a truce between the besiegers and the besieged, and that the\r\n'b'cannon were silenced by the louder detonations of the storm. The streets\r\n'b'of the town were deserted. It had not even appeared necessary in that\r\n'b'horrible weather to place a guard in the square, in the midst of which\r\n'b'plunged the balloon. Everything favored the departure of the prisoners,\r\n'b'but what might possibly be the termination of the hazardous voyage they\r\n'b'contemplated in the midst of the furious elements?--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDirty weather!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, fixing his hat firmly on his head\r\n'b'with a blow of his fist; \xe2\x80\x9cbut pshaw, we shall succeed all the same!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At half-past nine, Harding and his companions glided from different\r\n'b'directions into the square, which the gas-lamps, extinguished by the\r\n'b'wind, had left in total obscurity. Even the enormous balloon, almost\r\n'b'beaten to the ground, could not be seen. Independently of the sacks of\r\n'b'ballast, to which the cords of the net were fastened, the car was\r\n'b'held by a strong cable passed through a ring in the pavement. The five\r\n'b'prisoners met by the car. They had not been perceived, and such was the\r\n'b'darkness that they could not even see each other.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Without speaking a word, Harding, Spilett, Neb, and Herbert took their\r\n'b'places in the car, while Pencroft by the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s order detached\r\n'b'successively the bags of ballast. It was the work of a few minutes only,\r\n'b'and the sailor rejoined his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The balloon was then only held by the cable, and the engineer had\r\n'b'nothing to do but to give the word.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment a dog sprang with a bound into the car. It was Top,\r\n'b'a favorite of the engineer. The faithful creature, having broken his\r\n'b'chain, had followed his master. He, however, fearing that its additional\r\n'b'weight might impede their ascent, wished to send away the animal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne more will make but little difference, poor beast!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed\r\n'b'Pencroft, heaving out two bags of sand, and as he spoke letting go the\r\n'b'cable; the balloon ascending in an oblique direction, disappeared, after\r\n'b'having dashed the car against two chimneys, which it threw down as it\r\n'b'swept by them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, indeed, the full rage of the hurricane was exhibited to the\r\n'b'voyagers. During the night the engineer could not dream of descending,\r\n'b'and when day broke, even a glimpse of the earth below was intercepted by\r\n'b'fog.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Five days had passed when a partial clearing allowed them to see the\r\n'b'wide extending ocean beneath their feet, now lashed into the maddest\r\n'b'fury by the gale.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Our readers will recollect what befell these five daring individuals\r\n'b'who set out on their hazardous expedition in the balloon on the 20th of\r\n'b'March. Five days afterwards four of them were thrown on a desert coast,\r\n'b'seven thousand miles from their country! But one of their number was\r\n'b'missing, the man who was to be their guide, their leading spirit, the\r\n'b'engineer, Captain Harding! The instant they had recovered their feet,\r\n'b'they all hurried to the beach in the hopes of rendering him assistance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 3\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, the meshes of the net having given way, had been carried\r\n'b'off by a wave. His dog also had disappeared. The faithful animal\r\n'b'had voluntarily leaped out to help his master. \xe2\x80\x9cForward,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\n'b'reporter; and all four, Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft, and Neb, forgetting\r\n'b'their fatigue, began their search. Poor Neb shed bitter tears, giving\r\n'b'way to despair at the thought of having lost the only being he loved on\r\n'b'earth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Only two minutes had passed from the time when Cyrus Harding disappeared\r\n'b'to the moment when his companions set foot on the ground. They had hopes\r\n'b'therefore of arriving in time to save him. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us look for him! let us\r\n'b'look for him!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand we will find him too!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiving, I trust!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStill living!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCan he swim?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cand besides, Top is there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor, observing the heavy surf on the shore, shook his head.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer had disappeared to the north of the shore, and nearly half\r\n'b'a mile from the place where the castaways had landed. The nearest point\r\n'b'of the beach he could reach was thus fully that distance off.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was then nearly six o\xe2\x80\x99clock. A thick fog made the night very dark.\r\n'b'The castaways proceeded toward the north of the land on which chance had\r\n'b'thrown them, an unknown region, the geographical situation of which they\r\n'b'could not even guess. They were walking upon a sandy soil, mingled with\r\n'b'stones, which appeared destitute of any sort of vegetation. The ground,\r\n'b'very unequal and rough, was in some places perfectly riddled with holes,\r\n'b'making walking extremely painful. From these holes escaped every minute\r\n'b'great birds of clumsy flight, which flew in all directions. Others, more\r\n'b'active, rose in flocks and passed in clouds over their heads. The sailor\r\n'b'thought he recognized gulls and cormorants, whose shrill cries rose\r\n'b'above the roaring of the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From time to time the castaways stopped and shouted, then listened for\r\n'b'some response from the ocean, for they thought that if the engineer had\r\n'b'landed, and they had been near to the place, they would have heard the\r\n'b'barking of the dog Top, even should Harding himself have been unable to\r\n'b'give any sign of existence. They stopped to listen, but no sound arose\r\n'b'above the roaring of the waves and the dashing of the surf. The little\r\n'b'band then continued their march forward, searching into every hollow of\r\n'b'the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After walking for twenty minutes, the four castaways were suddenly\r\n'b'brought to a standstill by the sight of foaming billows close to\r\n'b'their feet. The solid ground ended here. They found themselves at the\r\n'b'extremity of a sharp point on which the sea broke furiously.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a promontory,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cwe must retrace our steps,\r\n'b'holding towards the right, and we shall thus gain the mainland.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut if he is there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, pointing to the ocean, whose waves shone\r\n'b'of a snowy white in the darkness. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, let us call again,\xe2\x80\x9d and all\r\n'b'uniting their voices, they gave a vigorous shout, but there came no\r\n'b'reply. They waited for a lull, then began again; still no reply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The castaways accordingly returned, following the opposite side of the\r\n'b'promontory, over a soil equally sandy and rugged. However, Pencroft\r\n'b'observed that the shore was more equal, that the ground rose, and he\r\n'b'declared that it was joined by a long slope to a hill, whose massive\r\n'b'front he thought that he could see looming indistinctly through the\r\n'b'mist. The birds were less numerous on this part of the shore; the sea\r\n'b'was also less tumultuous, and they observed that the agitation of the\r\n'b'waves was diminished. The noise of the surf was scarcely heard. This\r\n'b'side of the promontory evidently formed a semicircular bay, which the\r\n'b'sharp point sheltered from the breakers of the open sea. But to follow\r\n'b'this direction was to go south, exactly opposite to that part of the\r\n'b'coast where Harding might have landed. After a walk of a mile and a\r\n'b'half, the shore presented no curve which would permit them to return to\r\n'b'the north. This promontory, of which they had turned the point, must\r\n'b'be attached to the mainland. The castaways, although their strength\r\n'b'was nearly exhausted, still marched courageously forward, hoping every\r\n'b'moment to meet with a sudden angle which would set them in the first\r\n'b'direction. What was their disappointment, when, after trudging nearly\r\n'b'two miles, having reached an elevated point composed of slippery rocks,\r\n'b'they found themselves again stopped by the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are on an islet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand we have surveyed it from one\r\n'b'extremity to the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor was right; they had been thrown, not on a continent, not\r\n'b'even on an island, but on an islet which was not more than two miles in\r\n'b'length, with even a less breadth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Was this barren spot the desolate refuge of sea-birds, strewn with\r\n'b'stones and destitute of vegetation, attached to a more important\r\n'b'archipelago? It was impossible to say. When the voyagers from their car\r\n'b'saw the land through the mist, they had not been able to reconnoiter\r\n'b'it sufficiently. However, Pencroft, accustomed with his sailor eyes\r\n'b'to piece through the gloom, was almost certain that he could clearly\r\n'b'distinguish in the west confused masses which indicated an elevated\r\n'b'coast. But they could not in the dark determine whether it was a single\r\n'b'island, or connected with others. They could not leave it either, as the\r\n'b'sea surrounded them; they must therefore put off till the next day their\r\n'b'search for the engineer, from whom, alas! not a single cry had reached\r\n'b'them to show that he was still in existence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe silence of our friend proves nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps\r\n'b'he has fainted or is wounded, and unable to reply directly, so we will\r\n'b'not despair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter then proposed to light a fire on a point of the islet,\r\n'b'which would serve as a signal to the engineer. But they searched in vain\r\n'b'for wood or dry brambles; nothing but sand and stones were to be found.\r\n'b'The grief of Neb and his companions, who were all strongly attached to\r\n'b'the intrepid Harding, can be better pictured than described. It was too\r\n'b'evident that they were powerless to help him. They must wait with what\r\n'b'patience they could for daylight. Either the engineer had been able to\r\n'b'save himself, and had already found a refuge on some point of the coast,\r\n'b'or he was lost for ever! The long and painful hours passed by. The cold\r\n'b'was intense. The castaways suffered cruelly, but they scarcely perceived\r\n'b'it. They did not even think of taking a minute\xe2\x80\x99s rest. Forgetting\r\n'b'everything but their chief, hoping or wishing to hope on, they continued\r\n'b'to walk up and down on this sterile spot, always returning to its\r\n'b'northern point, where they could approach nearest to the scene of the\r\n'b'catastrophe. They listened, they called, and then uniting their voices,\r\n'b'they endeavored to raise even a louder shout than before, which would\r\n'b'be transmitted to a great distance. The wind had now fallen almost to\r\n'b'a calm, and the noise of the sea began also to subside. One of Neb\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'shouts even appeared to produce an echo. Herbert directed Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'attention to it, adding, \xe2\x80\x9cThat proves that there is a coast to the west,\r\n'b'at no great distance.\xe2\x80\x9d The sailor nodded; besides, his eyes could not\r\n'b'deceive him. If he had discovered land, however indistinct it might\r\n'b'appear, land was sure to be there. But that distant echo was the only\r\n'b'response produced by Neb\xe2\x80\x99s shouts, while a heavy gloom hung over all the\r\n'b'part east of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, the sky was clearing little by little. Towards midnight the\r\n'b'stars shone out, and if the engineer had been there with his companions\r\n'b'he would have remarked that these stars did not belong to the Northern\r\n'b'Hemisphere. The Polar Star was not visible, the constellations were not\r\n'b'those which they had been accustomed to see in the United States; the\r\n'b'Southern Cross glittered brightly in the sky.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night passed away. Towards five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning of the 25th\r\n'b'of March, the sky began to lighten; the horizon still remained dark,\r\n'b'but with daybreak a thick mist rose from the sea, so that the eye could\r\n'b'scarcely penetrate beyond twenty feet or so from where they stood. At\r\n'b'length the fog gradually unrolled itself in great heavily moving waves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was unfortunate, however, that the castaways could distinguish\r\n'b'nothing around them. While the gaze of the reporter and Neb were cast\r\n'b'upon the ocean, the sailor and Herbert looked eagerly for the coast\r\n'b'in the west. But not a speck of land was visible. \xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\n'b'Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthough I do not see the land, I feel it... it is there...\r\n'b'there... as sure as the fact that we are no longer at Richmond.\xe2\x80\x9d But the\r\n'b'fog was not long in rising. It was only a fine-weather mist. A hot\r\n'b'sun soon penetrated to the surface of the island. About half-past\r\n'b'six, three-quarters of an hour after sunrise, the mist became more\r\n'b'transparent. It grew thicker above, but cleared away below. Soon the\r\n'b'isle appeared as if it had descended from a cloud, then the sea showed\r\n'b'itself around them, spreading far away towards the east, but bounded on\r\n'b'the west by an abrupt and precipitous coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Yes! the land was there. Their safety was at least provisionally\r\n'b'insured. The islet and the coast were separated by a channel about half\r\n'b'a mile in breadth, through which rushed an extremely rapid current.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, one of the castaways, following the impulse of his heart,\r\n'b'immediately threw himself into the current, without consulting his\r\n'b'companions, without saying a single word. It was Neb. He was in haste\r\n'b'to be on the other side, and to climb towards the north. It had been\r\n'b'impossible to hold him back. Pencroft called him in vain. The reporter\r\n'b'prepared to follow him, but Pencroft stopped him. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you want to cross\r\n'b'the channel?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cAll right!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\n'b'seaman; \xe2\x80\x9cwait a bit; Neb is well able to carry help to his master. If we\r\n'b'venture into the channel, we risk being carried into the open sea by\r\n'b'the current, which is running very strong; but, if I\xe2\x80\x99m not wrong, it is\r\n'b'ebbing. See, the tide is going down over the sand. Let us have patience,\r\n'b'and at low water it is possible we may find a fordable passage.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\n'b'are right,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will not separate more than we can\r\n'b'help.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this time Neb was struggling vigorously against the current. He\r\n'b'was crossing in an oblique direction. His black shoulders could be seen\r\n'b'emerging at each stroke. He was carried down very quickly, but he also\r\n'b'made way towards the shore. It took more than half an hour to cross from\r\n'b'the islet to the land, and he reached the shore several hundred feet\r\n'b'from the place which was opposite to the point from which he had\r\n'b'started.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Landing at the foot of a high wall of granite, he shook himself\r\n'b'vigorously; and then, setting off running, soon disappeared behind\r\n'b'a rocky point, which projected to nearly the height of the northern\r\n'b'extremity of the islet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb\xe2\x80\x99s companions had watched his daring attempt with painful anxiety,\r\n'b'and when he was out of sight, they fixed their attention on the land\r\n'b'where their hope of safety lay, while eating some shell-fish with which\r\n'b'the sand was strewn. It was a wretched repast, but still it was better\r\n'b'than nothing. The opposite coast formed one vast bay, terminating on the\r\n'b'south by a very sharp point, which was destitute of all vegetation,\r\n'b'and was of a very wild aspect. This point abutted on the shore in a\r\n'b'grotesque outline of high granite rocks. Towards the north, on the\r\n'b'contrary, the bay widened, and a more rounded coast appeared, trending\r\n'b'from the southwest to the northeast, and terminating in a slender cape.\r\n'b'The distance between these two extremities, which made the bow of the\r\n'b'bay, was about eight miles. Half a mile from the shore rose the islet,\r\n'b'which somewhat resembled the carcass of a gigantic whale. Its extreme\r\n'b'breadth was not more than a quarter of a mile.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Opposite the islet, the beach consisted first of sand, covered with\r\n'b'black stones, which were now appearing little by little above the\r\n'b'retreating tide. The second level was separated by a perpendicular\r\n'b'granite cliff, terminated at the top by an unequal edge at a height of\r\n'b'at least 300 feet. It continued thus for a length of three miles, ending\r\n'b'suddenly on the right with a precipice which looked as if cut by the\r\n'b'hand of man. On the left, above the promontory, this irregular and\r\n'b'jagged cliff descended by a long slope of conglomerated rocks till it\r\n'b'mingled with the ground of the southern point. On the upper plateau of\r\n'b'the coast not a tree appeared. It was a flat tableland like that above\r\n'b'Cape Town at the Cape of Good Hope, but of reduced proportions; at least\r\n'b'so it appeared seen from the islet. However, verdure was not wanting to\r\n'b'the right beyond the precipice. They could easily distinguish a confused\r\n'b'mass of great trees, which extended beyond the limits of their view.\r\n'b'This verdure relieved the eye, so long wearied by the continued ranges\r\n'b'of granite. Lastly, beyond and above the plateau, in a northwesterly\r\n'b'direction and at a distance of at least seven miles, glittered a white\r\n'b'summit which reflected the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays. It was that of a lofty mountain,\r\n'b'capped with snow.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The question could not at present be decided whether this land formed\r\n'b'an island, or whether it belonged to a continent. But on beholding\r\n'b'the convulsed masses heaped up on the left, no geologist would have\r\n'b'hesitated to give them a volcanic origin, for they were unquestionably\r\n'b'the work of subterranean convulsions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Herbert attentively examined this land, on\r\n'b'which they might perhaps have to live many long years; on which indeed\r\n'b'they might even die, should it be out of the usual track of vessels, as\r\n'b'was likely to be the case.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you say, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is some good and some bad, as in everything,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see. But now the ebb is evidently making. In three hours we\r\n'b'will attempt the passage, and once on the other side, we will try to get\r\n'b'out of this scrape, and I hope may find the captain.\xe2\x80\x9d Pencroft was not\r\n'b'wrong in his anticipations. Three hours later at low tide, the greater\r\n'b'part of the sand forming the bed of the channel was uncovered. Between\r\n'b'the islet and the coast there only remained a narrow channel which would\r\n'b'no doubt be easy to cross.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Gideon Spilett and his companions stripped themselves\r\n'b'of their clothes, which they placed in bundles on their heads, and\r\n'b'then ventured into the water, which was not more than five feet deep.\r\n'b'Herbert, for whom it was too deep, swam like a fish, and got through\r\n'b'capitally. All three arrived without difficulty on the opposite shore.\r\n'b'Quickly drying themselves in the sun, they put on their clothes, which\r\n'b'they had preserved from contact with the water, and sat down to take\r\n'b'counsel together what to do next.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 4\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All at once the reporter sprang up, and telling the sailor that he would\r\n'b'rejoin them at that same place, he climbed the cliff in the direction\r\n'b'which the Negro Neb had taken a few hours before. Anxiety hastened\r\n'b'his steps, for he longed to obtain news of his friend, and he soon\r\n'b'disappeared round an angle of the cliff. Herbert wished to accompany\r\n'b'him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStop here, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have to prepare an encampment,\r\n'b'and to try and find rather better grub than these shell-fish. Our\r\n'b'friends will want something when they come back. There is work for\r\n'b'everybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cthat will do. We must set about it\r\n'b'regularly. We are tired, cold, and hungry; therefore we must have\r\n'b'shelter, fire, and food. There is wood in the forest, and eggs in nests;\r\n'b'we have only to find a house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cI will look for a cave among the rocks,\r\n'b'and I shall be sure to discover some hole into which we can creep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cgo on, my boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They both walked to the foot of the enormous wall over the beach, far\r\n'b'from which the tide had now retreated; but instead of going towards the\r\n'b'north, they went southward. Pencroft had remarked, several hundred feet\r\n'b'from the place at which they landed, a narrow cutting, out of which\r\n'b'he thought a river or stream might issue. Now, on the one hand it was\r\n'b'important to settle themselves in the neighborhood of a good stream\r\n'b'of water, and on the other it was possible that the current had thrown\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding on the shore there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cliff, as has been said, rose to a height of three hundred feet, but\r\n'b'the mass was unbroken throughout, and even at its base, scarcely washed\r\n'b'by the sea, it did not offer the smallest fissure which would serve as\r\n'b'a dwelling. It was a perpendicular wall of very hard granite, which even\r\n'b'the waves had not worn away. Towards the summit fluttered myriads of\r\n'b'sea-fowl, and especially those of the web-footed species with long,\r\n'b'flat, pointed beaks--a clamorous tribe, bold in the presence of man,\r\n'b'who probably for the first time thus invaded their domains. Pencroft\r\n'b'recognized the skua and other gulls among them, the voracious little\r\n'b'sea-mew, which in great numbers nestled in the crevices of the granite.\r\n'b'A shot fired among this swarm would have killed a great number, but to\r\n'b'fire a shot a gun was needed, and neither Pencroft nor Herbert had one;\r\n'b'besides this, gulls and sea-mews are scarcely eatable, and even their\r\n'b'eggs have a detestable taste. However, Herbert, who had gone forward\r\n'b'a little more to the left, soon came upon rocks covered with sea-weed,\r\n'b'which, some hours later, would be hidden by the high tide. On these\r\n'b'rocks, in the midst of slippery wrack, abounded bivalve shell-fish, not\r\n'b'to be despised by starving people. Herbert called Pencroft, who ran up\r\n'b'hastily.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere are mussels!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cthese will do instead of eggs!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey are not mussels,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, who was attentively examining\r\n'b'the molluscs attached to the rocks; \xe2\x80\x9cthey are lithodomes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre they good to eat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen let us eat some lithodomes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor could rely upon Herbert; the young boy was well up in natural\r\n'b'history, and always had had quite a passion for the science. His father\r\n'b'had encouraged him in it, by letting him attend the lectures of the best\r\n'b'professors in Boston, who were very fond of the intelligent, industrious\r\n'b'lad. And his turn for natural history was, more than once in the course\r\n'b'of time, of great use, and he was not mistaken in this instance. These\r\n'b'lithodomes were oblong shells, suspended in clusters and adhering\r\n'b'very tightly to the rocks. They belong to that species of molluscous\r\n'b'perforators which excavate holes in the hardest stone; their shell is\r\n'b'rounded at both ends, a feature which is not remarked in the common\r\n'b'mussel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Herbert made a good meal of the lithodomes, which were\r\n'b'then half opened to the sun. They ate them as oysters, and as they had\r\n'b'a strong peppery taste, they were palatable without condiments of any\r\n'b'sort.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their hunger was thus appeased for the time, but not their thirst, which\r\n'b'increased after eating these naturally-spiced molluscs. They had then to\r\n'b'find fresh water, and it was not likely that it would be wanting in such\r\n'b'a capriciously uneven region. Pencroft and Herbert, after having taken\r\n'b'the precaution of collecting an ample supply of lithodomes, with which\r\n'b'they filled their pockets and handkerchiefs, regained the foot of the\r\n'b'cliff.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two hundred paces farther they arrived at the cutting, through which, as\r\n'b'Pencroft had guessed, ran a stream of water, whether fresh or not was to\r\n'b'be ascertained. At this place the wall appeared to have been separated\r\n'b'by some violent subterranean force. At its base was hollowed out a\r\n'b'little creek, the farthest part of which formed a tolerably sharp angle.\r\n'b'The watercourse at that part measured one hundred feet in breadth, and\r\n'b'its two banks on each side were scarcely twenty feet high. The river\r\n'b'became strong almost directly between the two walls of granite, which\r\n'b'began to sink above the mouth; it then suddenly turned and disappeared\r\n'b'beneath a wood of stunted trees half a mile off.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere is the water, and yonder is the wood we require!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Herbert, now we only want the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The water of the river was limpid. The sailor ascertained that at this\r\n'b'time--that is to say, at low tide, when the rising floods did not reach\r\n'b'it--it was sweet. This important point established, Herbert looked for\r\n'b'some cavity which would serve them as a retreat, but in vain; everywhere\r\n'b'the wall appeared smooth, plain, and perpendicular.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, at the mouth of the watercourse and above the reach of the high\r\n'b'tide, the convulsions of nature had formed, not a grotto, but a pile\r\n'b'of enormous rocks, such as are often met with in granite countries and\r\n'b'which bear the name of \xe2\x80\x9cChimneys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Herbert penetrated quite far in among the rocks, by sandy\r\n'b'passages in which light was not wanting, for it entered through the\r\n'b'openings which were left between the blocks, of which some were only\r\n'b'sustained by a miracle of equilibrium; but with the light came also\r\n'b'air--a regular corridor-gale--and with the wind the sharp cold from the\r\n'b'exterior. However, the sailor thought that by stopping-up some of\r\n'b'the openings with a mixture of stones and sand, the Chimneys could be\r\n'b'rendered habitable. Their geometrical plan represented the typographical\r\n'b'sign \xe2\x80\x9c&,\xe2\x80\x9d which signifies \xe2\x80\x9cet cetera\xe2\x80\x9d abridged, but by isolating the\r\n'b'upper mouth of the sign, through which the south and west winds blew so\r\n'b'strongly, they could succeed in making the lower part of use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s our work,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand if we ever see Captain Harding\r\n'b'again, he will know how to make something of this labyrinth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see him again, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand when he returns\r\n'b'he must find a tolerable dwelling here. It will be so, if we can make a\r\n'b'fireplace in the left passage and keep an opening for the smoke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo we can, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand these Chimneys will serve\r\n'b'our turn. Let us set to work, but first come and get a store of fuel. I\r\n'b'think some branches will be very useful in stopping up these openings,\r\n'b'through which the wind shrieks like so many fiends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and Pencroft left the Chimneys, and, turning the angle, they\r\n'b'began to climb the left bank of the river. The current here was quite\r\n'b'rapid, and drifted down some dead wood. The rising tide--and it could\r\n'b'already be perceived--must drive it back with force to a considerable\r\n'b'distance. The sailor then thought that they could utilize this ebb and\r\n'b'flow for the transport of heavy objects.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After having walked for a quarter of an hour, the sailor and the boy\r\n'b'arrived at the angle which the river made in turning towards the left.\r\n'b'From this point its course was pursued through a forest of magnificent\r\n'b'trees. These trees still retained their verdure, notwithstanding the\r\n'b'advanced season, for they belonged to the family of \xe2\x80\x9cconiferae,\xe2\x80\x9d which\r\n'b'is spread over all the regions of the globe, from northern climates to\r\n'b'the tropics. The young naturalist recognized especially the \xe2\x80\x9cdeedara,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' which are very numerous in the Himalayan zone, and which spread around\r\n'b'them a most agreeable odor. Between these beautiful trees sprang up\r\n'b'clusters of firs, whose opaque open parasol boughs spread wide around.\r\n'b'Among the long grass, Pencroft felt that his feet were crushing dry\r\n'b'branches which crackled like fireworks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cif I don\xe2\x80\x99t know the name of these\r\n'b'trees, at any rate I reckon that we may call them \xe2\x80\x98burning wood,\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\n'b'just now that\xe2\x80\x99s the chief thing we want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us get a supply,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, who immediately set to work.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The collection was easily made. It was not even necessary to lop the\r\n'b'trees, for enormous quantities of dead wood were lying at their feet;\r\n'b'but if fuel was not wanting, the means of transporting it was not yet\r\n'b'found. The wood, being very dry, would burn rapidly; it was therefore\r\n'b'necessary to carry to the Chimneys a considerable quantity, and the\r\n'b'loads of two men would not be sufficient. Herbert remarked this.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthere must be some way of carrying\r\n'b'this wood; there is always a way of doing everything. If we had a cart\r\n'b'or a boat, it would be easy enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut we have the river,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cthe river will be to us like a road which\r\n'b'carries of itself, and rafts have not been invented for nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOnly,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cat this moment our road is going the wrong\r\n'b'way, for the tide is rising!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall be all right if we wait till it ebbs,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cand then we will trust it to carry our fuel to the Chimneys. Let us get\r\n'b'the raft ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor, followed by Herbert, directed his steps towards the river.\r\n'b'They both carried, each in proportion to his strength, a load of wood\r\n'b'bound in fagots. They found on the bank also a great quantity of dead\r\n'b'branches in the midst of grass, among which the foot of man had probably\r\n'b'never before trod. Pencroft began directly to make his raft. In a kind\r\n'b'of little bay, created by a point of the shore which broke the current,\r\n'b'the sailor and the lad placed some good-sized pieces of wood, which\r\n'b'they had fastened together with dry creepers. A raft was thus formed, on\r\n'b'which they stacked all they had collected, sufficient, indeed, to have\r\n'b'loaded at least twenty men. In an hour the work was finished, and the\r\n'b'raft moored to the bank, awaited the turning of the tide.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There were still several hours to be occupied, and with one consent\r\n'b'Pencroft and Herbert resolved to gain the upper plateau, so as to have a\r\n'b'more extended view of the surrounding country.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Exactly two hundred feet behind the angle formed by the river, the wall,\r\n'b'terminated by a fall of rocks, died away in a gentle slope to the edge\r\n'b'of the forest. It was a natural staircase. Herbert and the sailor began\r\n'b'their ascent; thanks to the vigor of their muscles they reached the\r\n'b'summit in a few minutes; and proceeded to the point above the mouth of\r\n'b'the river.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On attaining it, their first look was cast upon the ocean which not long\r\n'b'before they had traversed in such a terrible condition. They observed,\r\n'b'with emotion, all that part to the north of the coast on which the\r\n'b'catastrophe had taken place. It was there that Cyrus Harding had\r\n'b'disappeared. They looked to see if some portion of their balloon, to\r\n'b'which a man might possibly cling, yet existed. Nothing! The sea was but\r\n'b'one vast watery desert. As to the coast, it was solitary also. Neither\r\n'b'the reporter nor Neb could be anywhere seen. But it was possible that at\r\n'b'this time they were both too far away to be perceived.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSomething tells me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat a man as energetic as Captain\r\n'b'Harding would not let himself be drowned like other people. He must have\r\n'b'reached some point of the shore; don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor shook his head sadly. He little expected ever to see Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding again; but wishing to leave some hope to Herbert: \xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless,\r\n'b'doubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cour engineer is a man who would get out of a\r\n'b'scrape to which any one else would yield.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meantime he examined the coast with great attention. Stretched\r\n'b'out below them was the sandy shore, bounded on the right of the river\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'mouth by lines of breakers. The rocks which were visible appeared like\r\n'b'amphibious monsters reposing in the surf. Beyond the reef, the sea\r\n'b'sparkled beneath the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays. To the south a sharp point closed the\r\n'b'horizon, and it could not be seen if the land was prolonged in that\r\n'b'direction, or if it ran southeast and southwest, which would have made\r\n'b'this coast a very long peninsula. At the northern extremity of the bay\r\n'b'the outline of the shore was continued to a great distance in a wider\r\n'b'curve. There the shore was low, flat, without cliffs, and with great\r\n'b'banks of sand, which the tide left uncovered. Pencroft and Herbert then\r\n'b'returned towards the west. Their attention was first arrested by the\r\n'b'snow-topped mountain which rose at a distance of six or seven miles.\r\n'b'From its first declivities to within two miles of the coast were spread\r\n'b'vast masses of wood, relieved by large green patches, caused by the\r\n'b'presence of evergreen trees. Then, from the edge of this forest to the\r\n'b'shore extended a plain, scattered irregularly with groups of trees. Here\r\n'b'and there on the left sparkled through glades the waters of the little\r\n'b'river; they could trace its winding course back towards the spurs of the\r\n'b'mountain, among which it seemed to spring. At the point where the sailor\r\n'b'had left his raft of wood, it began to run between the two high granite\r\n'b'walls; but if on the left bank the wall remained clear and abrupt, on\r\n'b'the right bank, on the contrary, it sank gradually, the massive sides\r\n'b'changed to isolated rocks, the rocks to stones, the stones to shingle\r\n'b'running to the extremity of the point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre we on an island?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate, it seems to be big enough,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the lad.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAn island, ever so big, is an island all the same!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But this important question could not yet be answered. A more perfect\r\n'b'survey had to be made to settle the point. As to the land itself, island\r\n'b'or continent, it appeared fertile, agreeable in its aspect, and varied\r\n'b'in its productions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is satisfactory,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cand in our misfortune, we\r\n'b'must thank Providence for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGod be praised!\xe2\x80\x9d responded Herbert, whose pious heart was full of\r\n'b'gratitude to the Author of all things.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Herbert examined for some time the country on which\r\n'b'they had been cast; but it was difficult to guess after so hasty an\r\n'b'inspection what the future had in store for them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They then returned, following the southern crest of the granite\r\n'b'platform, bordered by a long fringe of jagged rocks, of the most\r\n'b'whimsical shapes. Some hundreds of birds lived there nestled in the\r\n'b'holes of the stone; Herbert, jumping over the rocks, startled a whole\r\n'b'flock of these winged creatures.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cthose are not gulls nor sea-mews!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are they then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, one would say they were pigeons!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJust so, but these are wild or rock pigeons. I recognize them by\r\n'b'the double band of black on the wing, by the white tail, and by their\r\n'b'slate-colored plumage. But if the rock-pigeon is good to eat, its eggs\r\n'b'must be excellent, and we will soon see how many they may have left in\r\n'b'their nests!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will not give them time to hatch, unless it is in the shape of an\r\n'b'omelet!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft merrily.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what will you make your omelet in?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9cin your hat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not quite conjuror enough for that;\r\n'b'we must come down to eggs in the shell, my boy, and I will undertake to\r\n'b'despatch the hardest!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Herbert attentively examined the cavities in the granite,\r\n'b'and they really found eggs in some of the hollows. A few dozen being\r\n'b'collected, were packed in the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s handkerchief, and as the time\r\n'b'when the tide would be full was approaching, Pencroft and Herbert began\r\n'b'to redescend towards the watercourse. When they arrived there, it was\r\n'b'an hour after midday. The tide had already turned. They must now avail\r\n'b'themselves of the ebb to take the wood to the mouth. Pencroft did not\r\n'b'intend to let the raft go away in the current without guidance, neither\r\n'b'did he mean to embark on it himself to steer it. But a sailor is never\r\n'b'at a loss when there is a question of cables or ropes, and Pencroft\r\n'b'rapidly twisted a cord, a few fathoms long, made of dry creepers. This\r\n'b'vegetable cable was fastened to the after-part of the raft, and the\r\n'b'sailor held it in his hand while Herbert, pushing off the raft with\r\n'b'a long pole, kept it in the current. This succeeded capitally. The\r\n'b'enormous load of wood drifted down the current. The bank was very\r\n'b'equal; there was no fear that the raft would run aground, and before\r\n'b'two o\xe2\x80\x99clock they arrived at the river\xe2\x80\x99s mouth, a few paces from the\r\n'b'Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 5\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s first care, after unloading the raft, was to render the cave\r\n'b'habitable by stopping up all the holes which made it draughty. Sand,\r\n'b'stones, twisted branches, wet clay, closed up the galleries open to the\r\n'b'south winds. One narrow and winding opening at the side was kept, to\r\n'b'lead out the smoke and to make the fire draw. The cave was thus divided\r\n'b'into three or four rooms, if such dark dens with which a donkey would\r\n'b'scarcely have been contented deserved the name. But they were dry, and\r\n'b'there was space to stand upright, at least in the principal room, which\r\n'b'occupied the center. The floor was covered with fine sand, and taking\r\n'b'all in all they were well pleased with it for want of a better.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, while he and Pencroft were working, \xe2\x80\x9cour\r\n'b'companions have found a superior place to ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery likely,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the seaman; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, as we don\xe2\x80\x99t know, we must work\r\n'b'all the same. Better to have two strings to one\xe2\x80\x99s bow than no string at\r\n'b'all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9chow jolly it will be if they were to find\r\n'b'Captain Harding and were to bring him back with them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat was a man of the right sort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWas!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you despair of ever seeing him again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGod forbid!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. Their work was soon done, and Pencroft\r\n'b'declared himself very well satisfied.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cour friends can come back when they like. They will\r\n'b'find a good enough shelter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They now had only to make a fireplace and to prepare the supper--an easy\r\n'b'task. Large flat stones were placed on the ground at the opening of the\r\n'b'narrow passage which had been kept. This, if the smoke did not take\r\n'b'the heat out with it, would be enough to maintain an equal temperature\r\n'b'inside. Their wood was stowed away in one of the rooms, and the sailor\r\n'b'laid in the fireplace some logs and brushwood. The seaman was busy with\r\n'b'this, when Herbert asked him if he had any matches.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand I may say happily, for without\r\n'b'matches or tinder we should be in a fix.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStill we might get fire as the savages do,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cby\r\n'b'rubbing two bits of dry stick one against the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll right; try, my boy, and let\xe2\x80\x99s see if you can do anything besides\r\n'b'exercising your arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it\xe2\x80\x99s a very simple proceeding, and much used in the islands of\r\n'b'the Pacific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t deny it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the savages must know how to\r\n'b'do it or employ a peculiar wood, for more than once I have tried to\r\n'b'get fire in that way, but I could never manage it. I must say I prefer\r\n'b'matches. By the bye, where are my matches?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft searched in his waistcoat for the box, which was always there,\r\n'b'for he was a confirmed smoker. He could not find it; he rummaged the\r\n'b'pockets of his trousers, but, to his horror, he could nowhere discover\r\n'b'the box.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s a go!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, looking at Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cThe box must have\r\n'b'fallen out of my pocket and got lost! Surely, Herbert, you must have\r\n'b'something--a tinder-box--anything that can possibly make fire!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor rushed out, followed by the boy. On the sand, among the\r\n'b'rocks, near the river\xe2\x80\x99s bank, they both searched carefully, but in vain.\r\n'b'The box was of copper, and therefore would have been easily seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cdidn\xe2\x80\x99t you throw it out of the car?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI knew better than that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cbut such a small article\r\n'b'could easily disappear in the tumbling about we have gone through. I\r\n'b'would rather even have lost my pipe! Confound the box! Where can it be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook here, the tide is going down,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9clet\xe2\x80\x99s run to the\r\n'b'place where we landed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was scarcely probable that they would find the box, which the waves\r\n'b'had rolled about among the pebbles, at high tide, but it was as well\r\n'b'to try. Herbert and Pencroft walked rapidly to the point where they had\r\n'b'landed the day before, about two hundred feet from the cave.
