They hunted\r\n'b'there, among the shingle, in the clefts of the rocks, but found nothing.\r\n'b'If the box had fallen at this place it must have been swept away by the\r\n'b'waves. As the sea went down, they searched every little crevice with\r\n'b'no result. It was a grave loss in their circumstances, and for the\r\n'b'time irreparable. Pencroft could not hide his vexation; he looked very\r\n'b'anxious, but said not a word. Herbert tried to console him by observing,\r\n'b'that if they had found the matches, they would, very likely, have been\r\n'b'wetted by the sea and useless.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cthey were in a copper box which shut\r\n'b'very tightly; and now what are we to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall certainly find some way of making a fire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding or Mr. Spilett will not be without them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cbut in the meantime we are without fire, and\r\n'b'our companions will find but a sorry repast on their return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think it possible that they have no\r\n'b'tinder or matches?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI doubt it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, shaking his head, \xe2\x80\x9cfor neither Neb nor\r\n'b'Captain Harding smoke, and I believe that Mr. Spilett would rather keep\r\n'b'his note-book than his match-box.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert did not reply. The loss of the box was certainly to be\r\n'b'regretted, but the boy was still sure of procuring fire in some way or\r\n'b'other. Pencroft, more experienced, did not think so, although he was not\r\n'b'a man to trouble himself about a small or great grievance. At any rate,\r\n'b'there was only one thing to be done--to await the return of Neb and the\r\n'b'reporter; but they must give up the feast of hard eggs which they had\r\n'b'meant to prepare, and a meal of raw flesh was not an agreeable prospect\r\n'b'either for themselves or for the others.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Before returning to the cave, the sailor and Herbert, in the event of\r\n'b'fire being positively unattainable, collected some more shell-fish, and\r\n'b'then silently retraced their steps to their dwelling.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, his eyes fixed on the ground, still looked for his box. He\r\n'b'even climbed up the left bank of the river from its mouth to the angle\r\n'b'where the raft had been moored. He returned to the plateau, went over it\r\n'b'in every direction, searched among the high grass on the border of the\r\n'b'forest, all in vain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was five in the evening when he and Herbert re-entered the cave.\r\n'b'It is useless to say that the darkest corners of the passages were\r\n'b'ransacked before they were obliged to give it up in despair. Towards\r\n'b'six o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when the sun was disappearing behind the high lands of the\r\n'b'west, Herbert, who was walking up and down on the strand, signalized the\r\n'b'return of Neb and Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were returning alone!... The boy\xe2\x80\x99s heart sank; the sailor had not\r\n'b'been deceived in his forebodings; the engineer, Cyrus Harding, had not\r\n'b'been found!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter, on his arrival, sat down on a rock, without saying\r\n'b'anything. Exhausted with fatigue, dying of hunger, he had not strength\r\n'b'to utter a word.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Neb, his red eyes showed how he had cried, and the tears which he\r\n'b'could not restrain told too clearly that he had lost all hope.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter recounted all that they had done in their attempt to\r\n'b'recover Cyrus Harding. He and Neb had surveyed the coast for a distance\r\n'b'of eight miles and consequently much beyond the place where the balloon\r\n'b'had fallen the last time but one, a fall which was followed by the\r\n'b'disappearance of the engineer and the dog Top. The shore was solitary;\r\n'b'not a vestige of a mark. Not even a pebble recently displaced; not a\r\n'b'trace on the sand; not a human footstep on all that part of the beach.\r\n'b'It was clear that that portion of the shore had never been visited by\r\n'b'a human being. The sea was as deserted as the land, and it was there,\r\n'b'a few hundred feet from the coast, that the engineer must have found a\r\n'b'tomb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As Spilett ended his account, Neb jumped up, exclaiming in a voice which\r\n'b'showed how hope struggled within him, \xe2\x80\x9cNo! he is not dead! he can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\n'b'dead! It might happen to any one else, but never to him! He could get\r\n'b'out of anything!\xe2\x80\x9d Then his strength forsaking him, \xe2\x80\x9cOh! I can do no\r\n'b'more!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNeb,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, running to him, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will find him! God will give\r\n'b'him back to us! But in the meantime you are hungry, and you must eat\r\n'b'something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So saying, he offered the poor Negro a few handfuls of shell-fish, which\r\n'b'was indeed wretched and insufficient food. Neb had not eaten anything\r\n'b'for several hours, but he refused them. He could not, would not live\r\n'b'without his master.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Gideon Spilett, he devoured the shell-fish, then he laid himself\r\n'b'down on the sand, at the foot of a rock. He was very weak, but calm.\r\n'b'Herbert went up to him, and taking his hand, \xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\r\n'b'have found a shelter which will be better than lying here. Night is\r\n'b'advancing. Come and rest! To-morrow we will search farther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter got up, and guided by the boy went towards the cave. On\r\n'b'the way, Pencroft asked him in the most natural tone, if by chance he\r\n'b'happened to have a match or two.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter stopped, felt in his pockets, but finding nothing said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n'b'had some, but I must have thrown them away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The seaman then put the same question to Neb and received the same\r\n'b'answer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cConfound it!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter heard him and seizing his arm, \xe2\x80\x9cHave you no matches?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\n'b'asked.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot one, and no fire in consequence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cif my master was here, he would know what to do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The four castaways remained motionless, looking uneasily at each other.\r\n'b'Herbert was the first to break the silence by saying, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Spilett,\r\n'b'you are a smoker and always have matches about you; perhaps you haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n'b'looked well, try again, a single match will be enough!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter hunted again in the pockets of his trousers, waistcoat, and\r\n'b'great-coat, and at last to Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s great joy, no less to his extreme\r\n'b'surprise, he felt a tiny piece of wood entangled in the lining of his\r\n'b'waistcoat. He seized it with his fingers through the stuff, but he could\r\n'b'not get it out. If this was a match and a single one, it was of great\r\n'b'importance not to rub off the phosphorus.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWill you let me try?\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy, and very cleverly, without breaking\r\n'b'it, he managed to draw out the wretched yet precious little bit of wood\r\n'b'which was of such great importance to these poor men. It was unused.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cit is as good as having a whole cargo!\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\n'b'took the match, and, followed by his companions, entered the cave.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This small piece of wood, of which so many in an inhabited country are\r\n'b'wasted with indifference and are of no value, must here be used with the\r\n'b'greatest caution.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor first made sure that it was quite dry; that done, \xe2\x80\x9cWe must\r\n'b'have some paper,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Spilett, after some hesitation tearing a leaf out of his\r\n'b'note-book.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft took the piece of paper which the reporter held out to him, and\r\n'b'knelt down before the fireplace. Some handfuls of grass, leaves, and dry\r\n'b'moss were placed under the fagots and disposed in such a way that the\r\n'b'air could easily circulate, and the dry wood would rapidly catch fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft then twisted the piece of paper into the shape of a cone, as\r\n'b'smokers do in a high wind, and poked it in among the moss. Taking a\r\n'b'small, rough stone, he wiped it carefully, and with a beating heart,\r\n'b'holding his breath, he gently rubbed the match. The first attempt did\r\n'b'not produce any effect. Pencroft had not struck hard enough, fearing to\r\n'b'rub off the phosphorus.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I can\xe2\x80\x99t do it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cmy hand trembles, the match has missed\r\n'b'fire; I cannot, I will not!\xe2\x80\x9d and rising, he told Herbert to take his\r\n'b'place.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Certainly the boy had never in all his life been so nervous. Prometheus\r\n'b'going to steal the fire from heaven could not have been more anxious. He\r\n'b'did not hesitate, however, but struck the match directly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A little spluttering was heard and a tiny blue flame sprang up, making\r\n'b'a choking smoke. Herbert quickly turned the match so as to augment the\r\n'b'flame, and then slipped it into the paper cone, which in a few seconds\r\n'b'too caught fire, and then the moss.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A minute later the dry wood crackled and a cheerful flame, assisted\r\n'b'by the vigorous blowing of the sailor, sprang up in the midst of the\r\n'b'darkness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt last!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, getting up; \xe2\x80\x9cI was never so nervous before in\r\n'b'all my life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The flat stones made a capital fireplace. The smoke went quite easily\r\n'b'out at the narrow passage, the chimney drew, and an agreeable warmth was\r\n'b'not long in being felt.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They must now take great care not to let the fire go out, and always to\r\n'b'keep some embers alight. It only needed care and attention, as they had\r\n'b'plenty of wood and could renew their store at any time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s first thought was to use the fire by preparing a more\r\n'b'nourishing supper than a dish of shell-fish. Two dozen eggs were\r\n'b'brought by Herbert. The reporter leaning up in a corner, watched these\r\n'b'preparations without saying anything. A threefold thought weighed on his\r\n'b'mind. Was Cyrus still alive? If he was alive, where was he? If he had\r\n'b'survived from his fall, how was it that he had not found some means of\r\n'b'making known his existence? As to Neb, he was roaming about the shore.\r\n'b'He was like a body without a soul.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft knew fifty ways of cooking eggs, but this time he had no\r\n'b'choice, and was obliged to content himself with roasting them under\r\n'b'the hot cinders. In a few minutes the cooking was done, and the seaman\r\n'b'invited the reporter to take his share of the supper. Such was the\r\n'b'first repast of the castaways on this unknown coast. The hard eggs\r\n'b'were excellent, and as eggs contain everything indispensable to man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'nourishment, these poor people thought themselves well off, and were\r\n'b'much strengthened by them. Oh! if only one of them had not been missing\r\n'b'at this meal! If the five prisoners who escaped from Richmond had been\r\n'b'all there, under the piled-up rocks, before this clear, crackling fire\r\n'b'on the dry sand, what thanksgiving must they have rendered to Heaven!\r\n'b'But the most ingenious, the most learned, he who was their unquestioned\r\n'b'chief, Cyrus Harding, was, alas! missing, and his body had not even\r\n'b'obtained a burial-place.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus passed the 25th of March. Night had come on. Outside could be heard\r\n'b'the howling of the wind and the monotonous sound of the surf breaking\r\n'b'on the shore. The waves rolled the shingle backwards and forwards with a\r\n'b'deafening noise.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter retired into a dark corner after having shortly noted down\r\n'b'the occurrences of the day; the first appearance of this new land, the\r\n'b'loss of their leader, the exploration of the coast, the incident of the\r\n'b'matches, etc.; and then overcome by fatigue, he managed to forget his\r\n'b'sorrows in sleep. Herbert went to sleep directly. As to the sailor, he\r\n'b'passed the night with one eye on the fire, on which he did not\r\n'b'spare fuel. But one of the castaways did not sleep in the cave. The\r\n'b'inconsolable, despairing Neb, notwithstanding all that his companions\r\n'b'could say to induce him to take some rest, wandered all night long on\r\n'b'the shore calling on his master.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 6\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The inventory of the articles possessed by these castaways from the\r\n'b'clouds, thrown upon a coast which appeared to be uninhabited, was soon\r\n'b'made out. They had nothing, save the clothes which they were wearing at\r\n'b'the time of the catastrophe. We must mention, however, a note-book and\r\n'b'a watch which Gideon Spilett had kept, doubtless by inadvertence, not a\r\n'b'weapon, not a tool, not even a pocket-knife; for while in the car they\r\n'b'had thrown out everything to lighten the balloon. The imaginary heroes\r\n'b'of Daniel Defoe or of Wyss, as well as Selkirk and Raynal shipwrecked\r\n'b'on Juan Fernandez and on the archipelago of the Aucklands, were never in\r\n'b'such absolute destitution. Either they had abundant resources from their\r\n'b'stranded vessels, in grain, cattle, tools, ammunition, or else some\r\n'b'things were thrown up on the coast which supplied them with all the\r\n'b'first necessities of life. But here, not any instrument whatever, not a\r\n'b'utensil. From nothing they must supply themselves with everything.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And yet, if Cyrus Harding had been with them, if the engineer could\r\n'b'have brought his practical science, his inventive mind to bear on their\r\n'b'situation, perhaps all hope would not have been lost. Alas! they must\r\n'b'hope no longer again to see Cyrus Harding. The castaways could expect\r\n'b'nothing but from themselves and from that Providence which never\r\n'b'abandons those whose faith is sincere.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But ought they to establish themselves on this part of the coast,\r\n'b'without trying to know to what continent it belonged, if it was\r\n'b'inhabited, or if they were on the shore of a desert island?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was an important question, and should be solved with the shortest\r\n'b'possible delay. From its answer they would know what measures to take.\r\n'b'However, according to Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s advice, it appeared best to wait a few\r\n'b'days before commencing an exploration. They must, in fact, prepare some\r\n'b'provisions and procure more strengthening food than eggs and molluscs.\r\n'b'The explorers, before undertaking new fatigues, must first of all\r\n'b'recruit their strength.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The Chimneys offered a retreat sufficient for the present. The fire was\r\n'b'lighted, and it was easy to preserve some embers. There were plenty of\r\n'b'shell-fish and eggs among the rocks and on the beach. It would be easy\r\n'b'to kill a few of the pigeons which were flying by hundreds about the\r\n'b'summit of the plateau, either with sticks or stones. Perhaps the trees\r\n'b'of the neighboring forest would supply them with eatable fruit. Lastly,\r\n'b'the sweet water was there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was accordingly settled that for a few days they would remain at the\r\n'b'Chimneys so as to prepare themselves for an expedition, either along\r\n'b'the shore or into the interior of the country. This plan suited Neb\r\n'b'particularly. As obstinate in his ideas as in his presentiments, he\r\n'b'was in no haste to abandon this part of the coast, the scene of the\r\n'b'catastrophe. He did not, he would not believe in the loss of Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding. No, it did not seem to him possible that such a man had ended\r\n'b'in this vulgar fashion, carried away by a wave, drowned in the floods, a\r\n'b'few hundred feet from a shore. As long as the waves had not cast up the\r\n'b'body of the engineer, as long as he, Neb, had not seen with his eyes,\r\n'b'touched with his hands the corpse of his master, he would not believe\r\n'b'in his death! And this idea rooted itself deeper than ever in his\r\n'b'determined heart. An illusion perhaps, but still an illusion to be\r\n'b'respected, and one which the sailor did not wish to destroy. As for him,\r\n'b'he hoped no longer, but there was no use in arguing with Neb. He was\r\n'b'like the dog who will not leave the place where his master is buried,\r\n'b'and his grief was such that most probably he would not survive him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This same morning, the 26th of March, at daybreak, Neb had set out on\r\n'b'the shore in a northerly direction, and he had returned to the spot\r\n'b'where the sea, no doubt, had closed over the unfortunate Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That day\xe2\x80\x99s breakfast was composed solely of pigeon\xe2\x80\x99s eggs and\r\n'b'lithodomes. Herbert had found some salt deposited by evaporation in the\r\n'b'hollows of the rocks, and this mineral was very welcome.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The repast ended, Pencroft asked the reporter if he wished to accompany\r\n'b'Herbert and himself to the forest, where they were going to try to\r\n'b'hunt. But on consideration, it was thought necessary that someone should\r\n'b'remain to keep in the fire, and to be at hand in the highly improbable\r\n'b'event of Neb requiring aid. The reporter accordingly remained behind.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo the chase, Herbert,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cWe shall find ammunition\r\n'b'on our way, and cut our weapons in the forest.\xe2\x80\x9d But at the moment of\r\n'b'starting, Herbert observed, that since they had no tinder, it would\r\n'b'perhaps be prudent to replace it by another substance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBurnt linen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the boy. \xe2\x80\x9cThat could in case of need serve for\r\n'b'tinder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor thought it very sensible advice. Only it had the\r\n'b'inconvenience of necessitating the sacrifice of a piece of handkerchief.\r\n'b'Notwithstanding, the thing was well worth while trying, and a part of\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s large checked handkerchief was soon reduced to the state of\r\n'b'a half-burnt rag. This inflammable material was placed in the central\r\n'b'chamber at the bottom of a little cavity in the rock, sheltered from all\r\n'b'wind and damp.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning. The weather was threatening and the\r\n'b'breeze blew from the southeast. Herbert and Pencroft turned the angle of\r\n'b'the Chimneys, not without having cast a look at the smoke which, just at\r\n'b'that place, curled round a point of rock: they ascended the left bank of\r\n'b'the river.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at the forest, Pencroft broke from the first tree two stout\r\n'b'branches which he transformed into clubs, the ends of which Herbert\r\n'b'rubbed smooth on a rock. Oh! what would they not have given for a knife!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The two hunters now advanced among the long grass, following the bank.\r\n'b'From the turning which directed its course to the southwest, the river\r\n'b'narrowed gradually and the channel lay between high banks, over\r\n'b'which the trees formed a double arch. Pencroft, lest they should lose\r\n'b'themselves, resolved to follow the course of the stream, which would\r\n'b'always lead them back to the point from which they started. But the bank\r\n'b'was not without some obstacles: here, the flexible branches of the trees\r\n'b'bent level with the current; there, creepers and thorns which they had\r\n'b'to break down with their sticks. Herbert often glided among the\r\n'b'broken stumps with the agility of a young cat, and disappeared in the\r\n'b'underwood. But Pencroft called him back directly, begging him not to\r\n'b'wander away. Meanwhile, the sailor attentively observed the disposition\r\n'b'and nature of the surrounding country. On the left bank, the ground,\r\n'b'which was flat and marshy, rose imperceptibly towards the interior. It\r\n'b'looked there like a network of liquid threads which doubtless reached\r\n'b'the river by some underground drain. Sometimes a stream ran through the\r\n'b'underwood, which they crossed without difficulty. The opposite shore\r\n'b'appeared to be more uneven, and the valley of which the river occupied\r\n'b'the bottom was more clearly visible. The hill, covered with trees\r\n'b'disposed in terraces, intercepted the view. On the right bank walking\r\n'b'would have been difficult, for the declivities fell suddenly, and the\r\n'b'trees bending over the water were only sustained by the strength of\r\n'b'their roots.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is needless to add that this forest, as well as the coast already\r\n'b'surveyed, was destitute of any sign of human life. Pencroft only saw\r\n'b'traces of quadrupeds, fresh footprints of animals, of which he could not\r\n'b'recognize the species. In all probability, and such was also Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'opinion, some had been left by formidable wild beasts which doubtless\r\n'b'would give them some trouble; but nowhere did they observe the mark of\r\n'b'an axe on the trees, nor the ashes of a fire, nor the impression of a\r\n'b'human foot. On this they might probably congratulate themselves, for on\r\n'b'any land in the middle of the Pacific the presence of man was perhaps\r\n'b'more to be feared than desired. Herbert and Pencroft speaking little,\r\n'b'for the difficulties of the way were great, advanced very slowly, and\r\n'b'after walking for an hour they had scarcely gone more than a mile.\r\n'b'As yet the hunt had not been successful. However, some birds sang\r\n'b'and fluttered in the foliage, and appeared very timid, as if man had\r\n'b'inspired them with an instinctive fear. Among others, Herbert described,\r\n'b'in a marshy part of the forest, a bird with a long pointed beak, closely\r\n'b'resembling the king-fisher, but its plumage was not fine, though of a\r\n'b'metallic brilliancy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat must be a jacamar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, trying to get nearer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis will be a good opportunity to taste jacamar,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cif that fellow is in a humor to be roasted!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Just then, a stone cleverly thrown by the boy, struck the creature on\r\n'b'the wing, but the blow did not disable it, and the jacamar ran off and\r\n'b'disappeared in an instant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHow clumsy I am!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, my boy!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cThe blow was well aimed; many a\r\n'b'one would have missed it altogether! Come, don\xe2\x80\x99t be vexed with yourself.\r\n'b'We shall catch it another day!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As the hunters advanced, the trees were found to be more scattered, many\r\n'b'being magnificent, but none bore eatable fruit. Pencroft searched in\r\n'b'vain for some of those precious palm-trees which are employed in so many\r\n'b'ways in domestic life, and which have been found as far as the fortieth\r\n'b'parallel in the Northern Hemisphere, and to the thirty-fifth only in\r\n'b'the Southern Hemisphere. But this forest was only composed of coniferae,\r\n'b'such as deodaras, already recognized by Herbert, and Douglas pine,\r\n'b'similar to those which grow on the northwest coast of America, and\r\n'b'splendid firs, measuring a hundred and fifty feet in height.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment a flock of birds, of a small size and pretty plumage,\r\n'b'with long glancing tails, dispersed themselves among the branches\r\n'b'strewing their feathers, which covered the ground as with fine down.\r\n'b'Herbert picked up a few of these feathers, and after having examined\r\n'b'them,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThese are couroucous,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI should prefer a moor-cock or guinea-fowl,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cstill,\r\n'b'if they are good to eat--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey are good to eat, and also their flesh is very delicate,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\n'b'Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, if I don\xe2\x80\x99t mistake, it is easy to approach and kill\r\n'b'them with a stick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor and the lad, creeping among the grass, arrived at the foot\r\n'b'of a tree, whose lower branches were covered with little birds. The\r\n'b'couroucous were waiting the passage of insects which served for their\r\n'b'nourishment. Their feathery feet could be seen clasping the slender\r\n'b'twigs which supported them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The hunters then rose, and using their sticks like scythes, they mowed\r\n'b'down whole rows of these couroucous, who never thought of flying away,\r\n'b'and stupidly allowed themselves to be knocked off. A hundred were\r\n'b'already heaped on the ground, before the others made up their minds to\r\n'b'fly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9chere is game, which is quite within the reach of\r\n'b'hunters like us. We have only to put out our hands and take it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor having strung the couroucous like larks on flexible twigs,\r\n'b'they then continued their exploration. The stream here made a bend\r\n'b'towards the south, but this detour was probably not prolonged for the\r\n'b'river must have its source in the mountain, and be supplied by the\r\n'b'melting of the snow which covered the sides of the central cone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The particular object of their expedition was, as has been said, to\r\n'b'procure the greatest possible quantity of game for the inhabitants of\r\n'b'the Chimneys. It must be acknowledged that as yet this object had not\r\n'b'been attained. So the sailor actively pursued his researches, though he\r\n'b'exclaimed, when some animal which he had not even time to recognize\r\n'b'fled into the long grass, \xe2\x80\x9cIf only we had had the dog Top!\xe2\x80\x9d But Top had\r\n'b'disappeared at the same time as his master, and had probably perished\r\n'b'with him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards three o\xe2\x80\x99clock new flocks of birds were seen through certain\r\n'b'trees, at whose aromatic berries they were pecking, those of the\r\n'b'juniper-tree among others. Suddenly a loud trumpet call resounded\r\n'b'through the forest. This strange and sonorous cry was produced by a game\r\n'b'bird called grouse in the United States. They soon saw several couples,\r\n'b'whose plumage was rich chestnut-brown mottled with dark brown, and tail\r\n'b'of the same color. Herbert recognized the males by the two wing-like\r\n'b'appendages raised on the neck. Pencroft determined to get hold of at\r\n'b'least one of these gallinaceae, which were as large as a fowl, and whose\r\n'b'flesh is better than that of a pullet. But it was difficult, for they\r\n'b'would not allow themselves to be approached. After several fruitless\r\n'b'attempts, which resulted in nothing but scaring the grouse, the sailor\r\n'b'said to the lad,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly, since we can\xe2\x80\x99t kill them on the wing, we must try to take\r\n'b'them with a line.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLike a fish?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, much surprised at the proposal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLike a fish,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor quite seriously. Pencroft had found\r\n'b'among the grass half a dozen grouse nests, each having three or four\r\n'b'eggs. He took great care not to touch these nests, to which their\r\n'b'proprietors would not fail to return. It was around these that he\r\n'b'meant to stretch his lines, not snares, but real fishing-lines. He took\r\n'b'Herbert to some distance from the nests, and there prepared his singular\r\n'b'apparatus with all the care which a disciple of Izaak Walton would\r\n'b'have used. Herbert watched the work with great interest, though rather\r\n'b'doubting its success. The lines were made of fine creepers, fastened\r\n'b'one to the other, of the length of fifteen or twenty feet. Thick, strong\r\n'b'thorns, the points bent back (which were supplied from a dwarf acacia\r\n'b'bush) were fastened to the ends of the creepers, by way of hooks. Large\r\n'b'red worms, which were crawling on the ground, furnished bait.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This done, Pencroft, passing among the grass and concealing himself\r\n'b'skillfully, placed the end of his lines armed with hooks near the grouse\r\n'b'nests; then he returned, took the other ends and hid with Herbert behind\r\n'b'a large tree. There they both waited patiently; though, it must be\r\n'b'said, that Herbert did not reckon much on the success of the inventive\r\n'b'Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A whole half-hour passed, but then, as the sailor had surmised, several\r\n'b'couple of grouse returned to their nests. They walked along, pecking the\r\n'b'ground, and not suspecting in any way the presence of the hunters,\r\n'b'who, besides, had taken care to place themselves to leeward of the\r\n'b'gallinaceae.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The lad felt at this moment highly interested. He held his breath, and\r\n'b'Pencroft, his eyes staring, his mouth open, his lips advanced, as if\r\n'b'about to taste a piece of grouse, scarcely breathed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, the birds walked about the hooks, without taking any notice\r\n'b'of them. Pencroft then gave little tugs which moved the bait as if the\r\n'b'worms had been still alive.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor undoubtedly felt much greater anxiety than does the\r\n'b'fisherman, for he does not see his prey coming through the water. The\r\n'b'jerks attracted the attention of the gallinaceae, and they attacked the\r\n'b'hooks with their beaks. Three voracious grouse swallowed at the same\r\n'b'moment bait and hook. Suddenly with a smart jerk, Pencroft \xe2\x80\x9cstruck\xe2\x80\x9d his\r\n'b'line, and a flapping of wings showed that the birds were taken.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, rushing towards the game, of which he made himself\r\n'b'master in an instant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert clapped his hands. It was the first time that he had ever seen\r\n'b'birds taken with a line, but the sailor modestly confessed that it was\r\n'b'not his first attempt, and that besides he could not claim the merit of\r\n'b'invention.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd at any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, \xe2\x80\x9csituated as we are, we must hope to hit\r\n'b'upon many other contrivances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The grouse were fastened by their claws, and Pencroft, delighted at not\r\n'b'having to appear before their companions with empty hands, and observing\r\n'b'that the day had begun to decline, judged it best to return to their\r\n'b'dwelling.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The direction was indicated by the river, whose course they had only\r\n'b'to follow, and, towards six o\xe2\x80\x99clock, tired enough with their excursion,\r\n'b'Herbert and Pencroft arrived at the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 7\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett was standing motionless on the shore, his arms crossed,\r\n'b'gazing over the sea, the horizon of which was lost towards the east in\r\n'b'a thick black cloud which was spreading rapidly towards the zenith.\r\n'b'The wind was already strong, and increased with the decline of day.\r\n'b'The whole sky was of a threatening aspect, and the first symptoms of a\r\n'b'violent storm were clearly visible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert entered the Chimneys, and Pencroft went towards the reporter.\r\n'b'The latter, deeply absorbed, did not see him approach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are going to have a dirty night, Mr. Spilett!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor:\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPetrels delight in wind and rain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter, turning at the moment, saw Pencroft, and his first words\r\n'b'were,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt what distance from the coast would you say the car was, when the\r\n'b'waves carried off our companion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor had not expected this question. He reflected an instant and\r\n'b'replied,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTwo cables lengths at the most.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is a cable\xe2\x80\x99s length?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout a hundred and twenty fathoms, or six hundred feet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cCyrus Harding must have disappeared twelve\r\n'b'hundred feet at the most from the shore?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd his dog also?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAlso.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat astonishes me,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile admitting that our\r\n'b'companion has perished, is that Top has also met his death, and that\r\n'b'neither the body of the dog nor of his master has been cast on the\r\n'b'shore!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not astonishing, with such a heavy sea,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, it is possible that currents have carried them farther down\r\n'b'the coast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, it is your opinion that our friend has perished in the waves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' again asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is my opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy own opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwith due deference to your\r\n'b'experience, Pencroft, is that in the double fact of the absolute\r\n'b'disappearance of Cyrus and Top, living or dead, there is something\r\n'b'unaccountable and unlikely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could think like you, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft;\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cunhappily, my mind is made up on this point.\xe2\x80\x9d Having said this, the\r\n'b'sailor returned to the Chimneys. A good fire crackled on the hearth.\r\n'b'Herbert had just thrown on an armful of dry wood, and the flame cast a\r\n'b'bright light into the darkest parts of the passage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft immediately began to prepare the dinner. It appeared best to\r\n'b'introduce something solid into the bill of fare, for all needed to get\r\n'b'up their strength. The strings of couroucous were kept for the next day,\r\n'b'but they plucked a couple of grouse, which were soon spitted on a stick,\r\n'b'and roasting before a blazing fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At seven in the evening Neb had not returned. The prolonged absence of\r\n'b'the Negro made Pencroft very uneasy. It was to be feared that he had met\r\n'b'with an accident on this unknown land, or that the unhappy fellow had\r\n'b'been driven to some act of despair. But Herbert drew very different\r\n'b'conclusions from this absence. According to him, Neb\xe2\x80\x99s delay was caused\r\n'b'by some new circumstances which had induced him to prolong his search.\r\n'b'Also, everything new must be to the advantage of Cyrus Harding. Why had\r\n'b'Neb not returned unless hope still detained him? Perhaps he had found\r\n'b'some mark, a footstep, a trace which had put him in the right path.\r\n'b'Perhaps he was at this moment on a certain track. Perhaps even he was\r\n'b'near his master.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus the lad reasoned. Thus he spoke. His companions let him talk. The\r\n'b'reporter alone approved with a gesture. But what Pencroft thought most\r\n'b'probable was, that Neb had pushed his researches on the shore farther\r\n'b'than the day before, and that he had not as yet had time to return.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, however, agitated by vague presentiments, several times\r\n'b'manifested an intention to go to meet Neb. But Pencroft assured him\r\n'b'that that would be a useless course, that in the darkness and deplorable\r\n'b'weather he could not find any traces of Neb, and that it would be much\r\n'b'better to wait. If Neb had not made his appearance by the next day,\r\n'b'Pencroft would not hesitate to join him in his search.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett approved of the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s opinion that it was best not to\r\n'b'divide, and Herbert was obliged to give up his project; but two large\r\n'b'tears fell from his eyes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter could not refrain from embracing the generous boy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Bad weather now set in. A furious gale from the southeast passed over\r\n'b'the coast. The sea roared as it beat over the reef. Heavy rain was\r\n'b'dashed by the storm into particles like dust. Ragged masses of vapor\r\n'b'drove along the beach, on which the tormented shingles sounded as if\r\n'b'poured out in cart-loads, while the sand raised by the wind added as\r\n'b'it were mineral dust to that which was liquid, and rendered the united\r\n'b'attack insupportable. Between the river\xe2\x80\x99s mouth and the end of the\r\n'b'cliff, eddies of wind whirled and gusts from this maelstrom lashed the\r\n'b'water which ran through the narrow valley. The smoke from the fireplace\r\n'b'was also driven back through the opening, filling the passages and\r\n'b'rendering them uninhabitable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Therefore, as the grouse were cooked, Pencroft let the fire die away,\r\n'b'and only preserved a few embers buried under the ashes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock Neb had not appeared, but there was no doubt that the\r\n'b'frightful weather alone hindered his return, and that he must have\r\n'b'taken refuge in some cave, to await the end of the storm or at least the\r\n'b'return of day. As to going to meet him, or attempting to find him, it\r\n'b'was impossible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The game constituted the only dish at supper; the meat was excellent,\r\n'b'and Pencroft and Herbert, whose long excursion had rendered them very\r\n'b'hungry, devoured it with infinite satisfaction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their meal concluded, each retired to the corner in which he had rested\r\n'b'the preceding night, and Herbert was not long in going to sleep near the\r\n'b'sailor, who had stretched himself beside the fireplace.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Outside, as the night advanced, the tempest also increased in strength,\r\n'b'until it was equal to that which had carried the prisoners from Richmond\r\n'b'to this land in the Pacific. The tempests which are frequent during the\r\n'b'seasons of the equinox, and which are so prolific in catastrophes, are\r\n'b'above all terrible over this immense ocean, which opposes no obstacle to\r\n'b'their fury. No description can give an idea of the terrific violence of\r\n'b'the gale as it beat upon the unprotected coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Happily the pile of rocks which formed the Chimneys was solid. It was\r\n'b'composed of enormous blocks of granite, a few of which, insecurely\r\n'b'balanced, seemed to tremble on their foundations, and Pencroft could\r\n'b'feel rapid quiverings under his head as it rested on the rock. But he\r\n'b'repeated to himself, and rightly, that there was nothing to fear, and\r\n'b'that their retreat would not give way. However he heard the noise of\r\n'b'stones torn from the summit of the plateau by the wind, falling down on\r\n'b'to the beach. A few even rolled on to the upper part of the Chimneys,\r\n'b'or flew off in fragments when they were projected perpendicularly. Twice\r\n'b'the sailor rose and intrenched himself at the opening of the passage, so\r\n'b'as to take a look in safety at the outside. But there was nothing to be\r\n'b'feared from these showers, which were not considerable, and he returned\r\n'b'to his couch before the fireplace, where the embers glowed beneath the\r\n'b'ashes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Notwithstanding the fury of the hurricane, the uproar of the tempest,\r\n'b'the thunder, and the tumult, Herbert slept profoundly. Sleep at last\r\n'b'took possession of Pencroft, whom a seafaring life had habituated to\r\n'b'anything. Gideon Spilett alone was kept awake by anxiety. He reproached\r\n'b'himself with not having accompanied Neb. It was evident that he had not\r\n'b'abandoned all hope. The presentiments which had troubled Herbert did not\r\n'b'cease to agitate him also. His thoughts were concentrated on Neb. Why\r\n'b'had Neb not returned? He tossed about on his sandy couch, scarcely\r\n'b'giving a thought to the struggle of the elements. Now and then, his\r\n'b'eyes, heavy with fatigue, closed for an instant, but some sudden thought\r\n'b'reopened them almost immediately.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile the night advanced, and it was perhaps two hours from morning,\r\n'b'when Pencroft, then sound asleep, was vigorously shaken.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, rousing himself, and collecting his ideas\r\n'b'with the promptitude usual to seamen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter was leaning over him, and saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cListen, Pencroft, listen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor strained his ears, but could hear no noise beyond those\r\n'b'caused by the storm.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the wind,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, listening again, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought I heard--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe barking of a dog!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA dog!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, springing up.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes--barking--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not possible!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd besides, how, in the\r\n'b'roaring of the storm--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStop--listen--\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft listened more attentively, and really thought he heard, during\r\n'b'a lull, distant barking.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, pressing the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes--yes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Top! It is Top!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, who had just awoke; and all three\r\n'b'rushed towards the opening of the Chimneys. They had great difficulty in\r\n'b'getting out. The wind drove them back. But at last they succeeded, and\r\n'b'could only remain standing by leaning against the rocks. They looked\r\n'b'about, but could not speak. The darkness was intense. The sea, the sky,\r\n'b'the land were all mingled in one black mass. Not a speck of light was\r\n'b'visible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter and his companions remained thus for a few minutes,\r\n'b'overwhelmed by the wind, drenched by the rain, blinded by the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, in a pause of the tumult, they again heard the barking, which they\r\n'b'found must be at some distance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It could only be Top! But was he alone or accompanied? He was most\r\n'b'probably alone, for, if Neb had been with him, he would have made\r\n'b'his way more directly towards the Chimneys. The sailor squeezed the\r\n'b'reporter\xe2\x80\x99s hand, for he could not make himself heard, in a way which\r\n'b'signified \xe2\x80\x9cWait!\xe2\x80\x9d then he reentered the passage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An instant after he issued with a lighted fagot, which he threw into the\r\n'b'darkness, whistling shrilly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It appeared as if this signal had been waited for; the barking\r\n'b'immediately came nearer, and soon a dog bounded into the passage.\r\n'b'Pencroft, Herbert, and Spilett entered after him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An armful of dry wood was thrown on the embers. The passage was lighted\r\n'b'up with a bright flame.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Top!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was indeed Top, a magnificent Anglo-Norman, who derived from these\r\n'b'two races crossed the swiftness of foot and the acuteness of smell which\r\n'b'are the preeminent qualities of coursing dogs. It was the dog of the\r\n'b'engineer, Cyrus Harding. But he was alone! Neither Neb nor his master\r\n'b'accompanied him!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'How was it that his instinct had guided him straight to the Chimneys,\r\n'b'which he did not know? It appeared inexplicable, above all, in the\r\n'b'midst of this black night and in such a tempest! But what was still more\r\n'b'inexplicable was, that Top was neither tired, nor exhausted, nor even\r\n'b'soiled with mud or sand!--Herbert had drawn him towards him, and was\r\n'b'patting his head, the dog rubbing his neck against the lad\xe2\x80\x99s hands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf the dog is found, the master will be found also!\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGod grant it!\xe2\x80\x9d responded Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us set off! Top will guide us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft did not make any objection. He felt that Top\xe2\x80\x99s arrival\r\n'b'contradicted his conjectures. \xe2\x80\x9cCome along then!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft carefully covered the embers on the hearth. He placed a few\r\n'b'pieces of wood among them, so as to keep in the fire until their return.\r\n'b'Then, preceded by the dog, who seemed to invite them by short barks to\r\n'b'come with him, and followed by the reporter and the boy, he dashed out,\r\n'b'after having put up in his handkerchief the remains of the supper.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The storm was then in all its violence, and perhaps at its height. Not a\r\n'b'single ray of light from the moon pierced through the clouds. To follow\r\n'b'a straight course was difficult. It was best to rely on Top\xe2\x80\x99s instinct.\r\n'b'They did so. The reporter and Herbert walked behind the dog, and the\r\n'b'sailor brought up the rear. It was impossible to exchange a word. The\r\n'b'rain was not very heavy, but the wind was terrific.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, one circumstance favored the seaman and his two companions. The\r\n'b'wind being southeast, consequently blew on their backs. The clouds of\r\n'b'sand, which otherwise would have been insupportable, from being received\r\n'b'behind, did not in consequence impede their progress. In short, they\r\n'b'sometimes went faster than they liked, and had some difficulty in\r\n'b'keeping their feet; but hope gave them strength, for it was not at\r\n'b'random that they made their way along the shore. They had no doubt that\r\n'b'Neb had found his master, and that he had sent them the faithful dog.\r\n'b'But was the engineer living, or had Neb only sent for his companions\r\n'b'that they might render the last duties to the corpse of the unfortunate\r\n'b'Harding?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After having passed the precipice, Herbert, the reporter, and Pencroft\r\n'b'prudently stepped aside to stop and take breath. The turn of the rocks\r\n'b'sheltered them from the wind, and they could breathe after this walk or\r\n'b'rather run of a quarter of an hour.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They could now hear and reply to each other, and the lad having\r\n'b'pronounced the name of Cyrus Harding, Top gave a few short barks, as\r\n'b'much as to say that his master was saved.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSaved, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9csaved, Top?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the dog barked in reply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They once more set out. The tide began to rise, and urged by the wind it\r\n'b'threatened to be unusually high, as it was a spring tide. Great billows\r\n'b'thundered against the reef with such violence that they probably passed\r\n'b'entirely over the islet, then quite invisible. The mole no longer\r\n'b'protected the coast, which was directly exposed to the attacks of the\r\n'b'open sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As soon as the sailor and his companions left the precipice, the wind\r\n'b'struck them again with renewed fury. Though bent under the gale they\r\n'b'walked very quickly, following Top, who did not hesitate as to what\r\n'b'direction to take.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They ascended towards the north, having on their left an interminable\r\n'b'extent of billows, which broke with a deafening noise, and on their\r\n'b'right a dark country, the aspect of which it was impossible to guess.\r\n'b'But they felt that it was comparatively flat, for the wind passed\r\n'b'completely over them, without being driven back as it was when it came\r\n'b'in contact with the cliff.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, they reckoned that they had cleared\r\n'b'about five miles. The clouds were slightly raised, and the wind, though\r\n'b'less damp, was very sharp and cold. Insufficiently protected by their\r\n'b'clothing, Pencroft, Herbert and Spilett suffered cruelly, but not\r\n'b'a complaint escaped their lips. They were determined to follow Top,\r\n'b'wherever the intelligent animal wished to lead them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards five o\xe2\x80\x99clock day began to break. At the zenith, where the fog\r\n'b'was less thick, gray shades bordered the clouds; under an opaque belt, a\r\n'b'luminous line clearly traced the horizon. The crests of the billows were\r\n'b'tipped with a wild light, and the foam regained its whiteness. At the\r\n'b'same time on the left the hilly parts of the coast could be seen, though\r\n'b'very indistinctly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At six o\xe2\x80\x99clock day had broken. The clouds rapidly lifted. The seaman and\r\n'b'his companions were then about six miles from the Chimneys. They were\r\n'b'following a very flat shore bounded by a reef of rocks, whose heads\r\n'b'scarcely emerged from the sea, for they were in deep water. On the left,\r\n'b'the country appeared to be one vast extent of sandy downs, bristling\r\n'b'with thistles. There was no cliff, and the shore offered no resistance\r\n'b'to the ocean but a chain of irregular hillocks. Here and there grew two\r\n'b'or three trees, inclined towards the west, their branches projecting in\r\n'b'that direction. Quite behind, in the southwest, extended the border of\r\n'b'the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment, Top became very excited. He ran forward, then returned,\r\n'b'and seemed to entreat them to hasten their steps. The dog then left the\r\n'b'beach, and guided by his wonderful instinct, without showing the least\r\n'b'hesitation, went straight in among the downs. They followed him. The\r\n'b'country appeared an absolute desert. Not a living creature was to be\r\n'b'seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The downs, the extent of which was large, were composed of hillocks\r\n'b'and even of hills, very irregularly distributed. They resembled a\r\n'b'Switzerland modeled in sand, and only an amazing instinct could have\r\n'b'possibly recognized the way.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Five minutes after having left the beach, the reporter and his two\r\n'b'companions arrived at a sort of excavation, hollowed out at the back of\r\n'b'a high mound. There Top stopped, and gave a loud, clear bark. Spilett,\r\n'b'Herbert, and Pencroft dashed into the cave.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb was there, kneeling beside a body extended on a bed of grass.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The body was that of the engineer, Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 8\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb did not move. Pencroft only uttered one word.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiving?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb did not reply. Spilett and the sailor turned pale. Herbert clasped\r\n'b'his hands, and remained motionless. The poor Negro, absorbed in his\r\n'b'grief, evidently had neither seen his companions nor heard the sailor\r\n'b'speak.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter knelt down beside the motionless body, and placed his ear\r\n'b'to the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s chest, having first torn open his clothes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A minute--an age!--passed, during which he endeavored to catch the\r\n'b'faintest throb of the heart.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb had raised himself a little and gazed without seeing. Despair had\r\n'b'completely changed his countenance. He could scarcely be recognized,\r\n'b'exhausted with fatigue, broken with grief. He believed his master was\r\n'b'dead.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett at last rose, after a long and attentive examination.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe lives!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft knelt in his turn beside the engineer, he also heard a\r\n'b'throbbing, and even felt a slight breath on his cheek.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert at a word from the reporter ran out to look for water. He found,\r\n'b'a hundred feet off, a limpid stream, which seemed to have been greatly\r\n'b'increased by the rains, and which filtered through the sand; but nothing\r\n'b'in which to put the water, not even a shell among the downs. The lad was\r\n'b'obliged to content himself with dipping his handkerchief in the stream,\r\n'b'and with it hastened back to the grotto.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Happily the wet handkerchief was enough for Gideon Spilett, who only\r\n'b'wished to wet the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s lips. The cold water produced an almost\r\n'b'immediate effect. His chest heaved and he seemed to try to speak.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will save him!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At these words hope revived in Neb\xe2\x80\x99s heart. He undressed his master\r\n'b'to see if he was wounded, but not so much as a bruise was to be found,\r\n'b'either on the head, body, or limbs, which was surprising, as he must\r\n'b'have been dashed against the rocks; even the hands were uninjured, and\r\n'b'it was difficult to explain how the engineer showed no traces of the\r\n'b'efforts which he must have made to get out of reach of the breakers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the explanation would come later. When Cyrus was able to speak he\r\n'b'would say what had happened. For the present the question was, how to\r\n'b'recall him to life, and it appeared likely that rubbing would bring this\r\n'b'about; so they set to work with the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s jersey.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, revived by this rude shampooing, moved his arm slightly\r\n'b'and began to breathe more regularly. He was sinking from exhaustion,\r\n'b'and certainly, had not the reporter and his companions arrived, it would\r\n'b'have been all over with Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou thought your master was dead, didn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the seaman to Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! quite dead!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cand if Top had not found you, and\r\n'b'brought you here, I should have buried my master, and then have lain\r\n'b'down on his grave to die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It had indeed been a narrow escape for Cyrus Harding!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb then recounted what had happened. The day before, after having\r\n'b'left the Chimneys at daybreak, he had ascended the coast in a northerly\r\n'b'direction, and had reached that part of the shore which he had already\r\n'b'visited.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There, without any hope he acknowledged, Neb had searched the beach,\r\n'b'among the rocks, on the sand, for the smallest trace to guide him. He\r\n'b'examined particularly that part of the beach which was not covered by\r\n'b'the high tide, for near the sea the water would have obliterated all\r\n'b'marks. Neb did not expect to find his master living. It was for a corpse\r\n'b'that he searched, a corpse which he wished to bury with his own hands!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He sought long in vain. This desert coast appeared never to have been\r\n'b'visited by a human creature. The shells, those which the sea had not\r\n'b'reached, and which might be met with by millions above high-water mark,\r\n'b'were untouched. Not a shell was broken.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb then resolved to walk along the beach for some miles. It was\r\n'b'possible that the waves had carried the body to quite a distant point.\r\n'b'When a corpse floats a little distance from a low shore, it rarely\r\n'b'happens that the tide does not throw it up, sooner or later. This Neb\r\n'b'knew, and he wished to see his master again for the last time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI went along the coast for another two miles, carefully examining\r\n'b'the beach, both at high and low water, and I had despaired of finding\r\n'b'anything, when yesterday, above five in the evening, I saw footprints on\r\n'b'the sand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFootprints?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDid these footprints begin at the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, \xe2\x80\x9conly above high-water mark, for the others must have\r\n'b'been washed out by the tide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI went half crazy when I saw these footprints. They were very clear\r\n'b'and went towards the downs. I followed them for a quarter of a mile,\r\n'b'running, but taking care not to destroy them. Five minutes after, as\r\n'b'it was getting dark, I heard the barking of a dog. It was Top, and Top\r\n'b'brought me here, to my master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb ended his account by saying what had been his grief at finding the\r\n'b'inanimate body, in which he vainly sought for the least sign of life.\r\n'b'Now that he had found him dead he longed for him to be alive. All his\r\n'b'efforts were useless! Nothing remained to be done but to render the last\r\n'b'duties to the one whom he had loved so much! Neb then thought of his\r\n'b'companions. They, no doubt, would wish to see the unfortunate man again.\r\n'b'Top was there. Could he not rely on the sagacity of the faithful animal?\r\n'b'Neb several times pronounced the name of the reporter, the one among his\r\n'b'companions whom Top knew best.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then he pointed to the south, and the dog bounded off in the direction\r\n'b'indicated to him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'We have heard how, guided by an instinct which might be looked upon\r\n'b'almost as supernatural, Top had found them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb\xe2\x80\x99s companions had listened with great attention to this account.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was unaccountable to them how Cyrus Harding, after the efforts which\r\n'b'he must have made to escape from the waves by crossing the rocks, had\r\n'b'not received even a scratch. And what could not be explained either was\r\n'b'how the engineer had managed to get to this cave in the downs, more than\r\n'b'a mile from the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cit was not you who brought your master to\r\n'b'this place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it was not I,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Negro.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very clear that the captain came here by himself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is clear in reality,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is not credible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The explanation of this fact could only be produced from the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'own lips, and they must wait for that till speech returned. Rubbing had\r\n'b're-established the circulation of the blood. Cyrus Harding moved his arm\r\n'b'again, then his head, and a few incomprehensible words escaped him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb, who was bending over him, spoke, but the engineer did not appear\r\n'b'to hear, and his eyes remained closed. Life was only exhibited in him by\r\n'b'movement, his senses had not as yet been restored.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft much regretted not having either fire, or the means of\r\n'b'procuring it, for he had, unfortunately, forgotten to bring the burnt\r\n'b'linen, which would easily have ignited from the sparks produced by\r\n'b'striking together two flints. As to the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s pockets, they were\r\n'b'entirely empty, except that of his waistcoat, which contained his watch.\r\n'b'It was necessary to carry Harding to the Chimneys, and that as soon as\r\n'b'possible. This was the opinion of all.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, the care which was lavished on the engineer brought him back\r\n'b'to consciousness sooner than they could have expected. The water with\r\n'b'which they wetted his lips revived him gradually. Pencroft also thought\r\n'b'of mixing with the water some moisture from the titra\xe2\x80\x99s flesh which\r\n'b'he had brought. Herbert ran to the beach and returned with two large\r\n'b'bivalve shells. The sailor concocted something which he introduced\r\n'b'between the lips of the engineer, who eagerly drinking it opened his\r\n'b'eyes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb and the reporter were leaning over him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy master! my master!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer heard him. He recognized Neb and Spilett, then his other\r\n'b'two companions, and his hand slightly pressed theirs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few words again escaped him, which showed what thoughts were, even\r\n'b'then, troubling his brain. This time he was understood. Undoubtedly they\r\n'b'were the same words he had before attempted to utter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIsland or continent?\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBother the continent,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft hastily; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is time enough\r\n'b'to see about that, captain! we don\xe2\x80\x99t care for anything, provided you are\r\n'b'living.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer nodded faintly, and then appeared to sleep.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They respected this sleep, and the reporter began immediately to make\r\n'b'arrangements for transporting Harding to a more comfortable place. Neb,\r\n'b'Herbert, and Pencroft left the cave and directed their steps towards\r\n'b'a high mound crowned with a few distorted trees. On the way the sailor\r\n'b'could not help repeating,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIsland or continent! To think of that, when at one\xe2\x80\x99s last gasp! What a\r\n'b'man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at the summit of the mound, Pencroft and his two companions\r\n'b'set to work, with no other tools than their hands, to despoil of its\r\n'b'principal branches a rather sickly tree, a sort of marine fir; with\r\n'b'these branches they made a litter, on which, covered with grass and\r\n'b'leaves, they could carry the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This occupied them nearly forty minutes, and it was ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock when\r\n'b'they returned to Cyrus Harding whom Spilett had not left.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer was just awaking from the sleep, or rather from the\r\n'b'drowsiness, in which they had found him. The color was returning to his\r\n'b'cheeks, which till now had been as pale as death. He raised himself a\r\n'b'little, looked around him, and appeared to ask where he was.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCan you listen to me without fatigue, Cyrus?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s my opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Captain Harding will be\r\n'b'able to listen to you still better, if he will have some more grouse\r\n'b'jelly,--for we have grouse, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, presenting him with a\r\n'b'little of this jelly, to which he this time added some of the flesh.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding ate a little of the grouse, and the rest was divided\r\n'b'among his companions, who found it but a meager breakfast, for they were\r\n'b'suffering extremely from hunger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is plenty of food at the Chimneys, for\r\n'b'you must know, captain, that down there, in the south, we have a house,\r\n'b'with rooms, beds, and fireplace, and in the pantry, several dozen of\r\n'b'birds, which our Herbert calls couroucous. Your litter is ready, and as\r\n'b'soon as you feel strong enough we will carry you home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cwait another hour or two,\r\n'b'and then we will set out. And now speak, Spilett.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter then told him all that had occurred. He recounted all the\r\n'b'events with which Cyrus was unacquainted, the last fall of the balloon,\r\n'b'the landing on this unknown land, which appeared a desert (whatever it\r\n'b'was, whether island or continent), the discovery of the Chimneys,\r\n'b'the search for him, not forgetting of course Neb\xe2\x80\x99s devotion, the\r\n'b'intelligence exhibited by the faithful Top, as well as many other\r\n'b'matters.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding, in a still feeble voice, \xe2\x80\x9cyou did not, then, pick\r\n'b'me up on the beach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you not bring me to this cave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt what distance is this cave from the sea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout a mile,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cand if you are astonished, captain,\r\n'b'we are not less surprised ourselves at seeing you in this place!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, who was recovering gradually, and who took\r\n'b'great interest in these details, \xe2\x80\x9cindeed it is very singular!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9ccan you tell us what happened after you were\r\n'b'carried off by the sea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding considered. He knew very little. The wave had torn him\r\n'b'from the balloon net. He sank at first several fathoms. On returning\r\n'b'to the surface, in the half light, he felt a living creature struggling\r\n'b'near him. It was Top, who had sprung to his help. He saw nothing of the\r\n'b'balloon, which, lightened both of his weight and that of the dog, had\r\n'b'darted away like an arrow.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There he was, in the midst of the angry sea, at a distance which could\r\n'b'not be less than half a mile from the shore. He attempted to struggle\r\n'b'against the billows by swimming vigorously. Top held him up by his\r\n'b'clothes; but a strong current seized him and drove him towards the\r\n'b'north, and after half an hour of exertion, he sank, dragging Top\r\n'b'with him into the depths. From that moment to the moment in which he\r\n'b'recovered to find himself in the arms of his friends he remembered\r\n'b'nothing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must have been thrown on to the\r\n'b'beach, and you must have had strength to walk here, since Neb found your\r\n'b'footmarks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes... of course,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, thoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x9cand you found\r\n'b'no traces of human beings on this coast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot a trace,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, if by chance you had met\r\n'b'with some deliverer there, just in the nick of time, why should he have\r\n'b'abandoned you after having saved you from the waves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, my dear Spilett. Tell me, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d added the engineer,\r\n'b'turning to his servant, \xe2\x80\x9cit was not you who... you can\xe2\x80\x99t have had a\r\n'b'moment of unconsciousness... during which no, that\xe2\x80\x99s absurd.... Do any\r\n'b'of the footsteps still remain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, master,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb; \xe2\x80\x9chere, at the entrance, at the back of\r\n'b'the mound, in a place sheltered from the rain and wind. The storm has\r\n'b'destroyed the others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you take my shoe and see if it\r\n'b'fits exactly to the footprints?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor did as the engineer requested. While he and Herbert, guided\r\n'b'by Neb, went to the place where the footprints were to be found, Cyrus\r\n'b'remarked to the reporter,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a most extraordinary thing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly inexplicable!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut do not dwell upon it just now, my dear Spilett, we will talk about\r\n'b'it by-and-by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A moment after the others entered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no doubt about it. The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s shoe fitted exactly to the\r\n'b'footmarks. It was therefore Cyrus Harding who had left them on the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI must have experienced this unconsciousness which I\r\n'b'attributed to Neb. I must have walked like a somnambulist, without any\r\n'b'knowledge of my steps, and Top must have guided me here, after having\r\n'b'dragged me from the waves... Come, Top! Come, old dog!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The magnificent animal bounded barking to his master, and caresses were\r\n'b'lavished on him. It was agreed that there was no other way of accounting\r\n'b'for the rescue of Cyrus Harding, and that Top deserved all the honor of\r\n'b'the affair.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Pencroft having asked the engineer if they could\r\n'b'now remove him, Harding, instead of replying, and by an effort which\r\n'b'exhibited the most energetic will, got up. But he was obliged to lean on\r\n'b'the sailor, or he would have fallen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell done!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cbring the captain\xe2\x80\x99s litter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The litter was brought; the transverse branches had been covered with\r\n'b'leaves and long grass. Harding was laid on it, and Pencroft, having\r\n'b'taken his place at one end and Neb at the other, they started towards\r\n'b'the coast. There was a distance of eight miles to be accomplished; but,\r\n'b'as they could not go fast, and it would perhaps be necessary to stop\r\n'b'frequently, they reckoned that it would take at least six hours to reach\r\n'b'the Chimneys. The wind was still strong, but fortunately it did not\r\n'b'rain. Although lying down, the engineer, leaning on his elbow, observed\r\n'b'the coast, particularly inland. He did not speak, but he gazed; and, no\r\n'b'doubt, the appearance of the country, with its inequalities of ground,\r\n'b'its forests, its various productions, were impressed on his mind.\r\n'b'However, after traveling for two hours, fatigue overcame him, and he\r\n'b'slept.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At half-past five the little band arrived at the precipice, and a short\r\n'b'time after at the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They stopped, and the litter was placed on the sand; Cyrus Harding was\r\n'b'sleeping profoundly, and did not awake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, to his extreme surprise, found that the terrible storm had\r\n'b'quite altered the aspect of the place. Important changes had occurred;\r\n'b'great blocks of stone lay on the beach, which was also covered with a\r\n'b'thick carpet of sea-weed, algae, and wrack. Evidently the sea, passing\r\n'b'over the islet, had been carried right up to the foot of the enormous\r\n'b'curtain of granite. The soil in front of the cave had been torn away\r\n'b'by the violence of the waves. A horrid presentiment flashed across\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s mind. He rushed into the passage, but returned almost\r\n'b'immediately, and stood motionless, staring at his companions.... The\r\n'b'fire was out; the drowned cinders were nothing but mud; the burnt\r\n'b'linen, which was to have served as tinder, had disappeared! The sea had\r\n'b'penetrated to the end of the passages, and everything was overthrown and\r\n'b'destroyed in the interior of the Chimneys!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 9\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few words, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Neb were made acquainted\r\n'b'with what had happened. This accident, which appeared so very serious\r\n'b'to Pencroft, produced different effects on the companions of the honest\r\n'b'sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb, in his delight at having found his master, did not listen, or\r\n'b'rather, did not care to trouble himself with what Pencroft was saying.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert shared in some degree the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s feelings.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the reporter, he simply replied,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, Pencroft, it\xe2\x80\x99s perfectly indifferent to me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, I repeat, that we haven\xe2\x80\x99t any fire!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPooh!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNor any means of relighting it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut I say, Mr. Spilett--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t Cyrus here?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs not our engineer alive? He will soon find some way of making fire\r\n'b'for us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWith what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWith nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What had Pencroft to say? He could say nothing, for, in the bottom of\r\n'b'his heart he shared the confidence which his companions had in Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding. The engineer was to them a microcosm, a compound of every\r\n'b'science, a possessor of all human knowledge. It was better to be with\r\n'b'Cyrus in a desert island, than without him in the most flourishing town\r\n'b'in the United States. With him they could want nothing; with him they\r\n'b'would never despair. If these brave men had been told that a volcanic\r\n'b'eruption would destroy the land, that this land would be engulfed in the\r\n'b'depths of the Pacific, they would have imperturbably replied,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCyrus is here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While in the palanquin, however, the engineer had again relapsed into\r\n'b'unconsciousness, which the jolting to which he had been subjected during\r\n'b'his journey had brought on, so that they could not now appeal to his\r\n'b'ingenuity. The supper must necessarily be very meager. In fact, all the\r\n'b'grouse flesh had been consumed, and there no longer existed any means of\r\n'b'cooking more game. Besides, the couroucous which had been reserved had\r\n'b'disappeared. They must consider what was to be done.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'First of all, Cyrus Harding was carried into the central passage. There\r\n'b'they managed to arrange for him a couch of sea-weed which still remained\r\n'b'almost dry. The deep sleep which had overpowered him would no doubt be\r\n'b'more beneficial to him than any nourishment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Night had closed in, and the temperature, which had modified when the\r\n'b'wind shifted to the northwest, again became extremely cold. Also, the\r\n'b'sea having destroyed the partitions which Pencroft had put up in certain\r\n'b'places in the passages, the Chimneys, on account of the draughts, had\r\n'b'become scarcely habitable. The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s condition would, therefore,\r\n'b'have been bad enough, if his companions had not carefully covered him\r\n'b'with their coats and waistcoats.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Supper, this evening, was of course composed of the inevitable\r\n'b'lithodomes, of which Herbert and Neb picked up a plentiful supply on the\r\n'b'beach. However, to these molluscs, the lad added some edible sea-weed,\r\n'b'which he gathered on high rocks, whose sides were only washed by the sea\r\n'b'at the time of high tides. This sea-weed, which belongs to the order\r\n'b'of Fucacae, of the genus Sargassum, produces, when dry, a gelatinous\r\n'b'matter, rich and nutritious. The reporter and his companions, after\r\n'b'having eaten a quantity of lithodomes, sucked the sargassum, of which\r\n'b'the taste was very tolerable. It is used in parts of the East very\r\n'b'considerably by the natives. \xe2\x80\x9cNever mind!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthe captain\r\n'b'will help us soon.\xe2\x80\x9d Meanwhile the cold became very severe, and unhappily\r\n'b'they had no means of defending themselves from it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor, extremely vexed, tried in all sorts of ways to procure fire.\r\n'b'Neb helped him in this work. He found some dry moss, and by striking\r\n'b'together two pebbles he obtained some sparks, but the moss, not being\r\n'b'inflammable enough, did not take fire, for the sparks were really only\r\n'b'incandescent, and not at all of the same consistency as those which\r\n'b'are emitted from flint when struck in the same manner. The experiment,\r\n'b'therefore, did not succeed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, although he had no confidence in the proceeding, then tried\r\n'b'rubbing two pieces of dry wood together, as savages do. Certainly, the\r\n'b'movement which he and Neb exhibited, if it had been transformed into\r\n'b'heat, according to the new theory, would have been enough to heat the\r\n'b'boiler of a steamer! It came to nothing. The bits of wood became hot, to\r\n'b'be sure, but much less so than the operators themselves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After working an hour, Pencroft, who was in a complete state of\r\n'b'perspiration, threw down the pieces of wood in disgust.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI can never be made to believe that savages light their fires in this\r\n'b'way, let them say what they will,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cI could sooner light\r\n'b'my arms by rubbing them against each other!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor was wrong to despise the proceeding. Savages often kindle\r\n'b'wood by means of rapid rubbing. But every sort of wood does not answer\r\n'b'for the purpose, and besides, there is \xe2\x80\x9cthe knack,\xe2\x80\x9d following the usual\r\n'b'expression, and it is probable that Pencroft had not \xe2\x80\x9cthe knack.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s ill humor did not last long. Herbert had taken the bits of\r\n'b'wood which he had turned down, and was exerting himself to rub them.\r\n'b'The hardy sailor could not restrain a burst of laughter on seeing the\r\n'b'efforts of the lad to succeed where he had failed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRub, my boy, rub!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am rubbing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to do\r\n'b'anything else but warm myself instead of shivering, and soon I shall be\r\n'b'as hot as you are, my good Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This soon happened. However, they were obliged to give up, for this\r\n'b'night at least, the attempt to procure fire. Gideon Spilett repeated,\r\n'b'for the twentieth time, that Cyrus Harding would not have been troubled\r\n'b'for so small a difficulty. And, in the meantime, he stretched himself in\r\n'b'one of the passages on his bed of sand.
