Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft did\r\n'b'the same, while Top slept at his master\xe2\x80\x99s feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Next day, the 28th of March, when the engineer awoke, about eight in the\r\n'b'morning, he saw his companions around him watching his sleep, and, as on\r\n'b'the day before, his first words were:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIsland or continent?\xe2\x80\x9d This was his uppermost thought.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwe don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about it, captain!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know yet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut we shall know,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you have guided us into\r\n'b'the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think I am able to try it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, who, without much\r\n'b'effort, rose and stood upright.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s capital!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI feel dreadfully weak,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me something to eat, my\r\n'b'friends, and it will soon go off. You have fire, haven\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This question was not immediately replied to. But, in a few seconds--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! we have no fire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cor rather, captain, we have it\r\n'b'no longer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor recounted all that had passed the day before. He amused\r\n'b'the engineer by the history of the single match, then his abortive\r\n'b'attempt to procure fire in the savages\xe2\x80\x99 way.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall consider,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand if we do not find some\r\n'b'substance similar to tinder--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we will make matches.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cChemicals?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cChemicals!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not more difficult than that,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the reporter, striking the\r\n'b'sailor on the shoulder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The latter did not think it so simple, but he did not protest. All went\r\n'b'out. The weather had become very fine. The sun was rising from the sea\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'horizon, and touched with golden spangles the prismatic rugosities of\r\n'b'the huge precipice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Having thrown a rapid glance around him, the engineer seated himself on\r\n'b'a block of stone. Herbert offered him a few handfuls of shell-fish and\r\n'b'sargassum, saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is all that we have, Captain Harding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cit will do--for this morning at\r\n'b'least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He ate the wretched food with appetite, and washed it down with a little\r\n'b'fresh water, drawn from the river in an immense shell.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His companions looked at him without speaking. Then, feeling somewhat\r\n'b'refreshed, Cyrus Harding crossed his arms, and said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo, my friends, you do not know yet whether fate has thrown us on an\r\n'b'island, or on a continent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the boy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall know to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9ctill then, there is\r\n'b'nothing to be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFire,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, who, also, had a fixed idea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will make it, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhile you were carrying me yesterday, did I not see in the west a\r\n'b'mountain which commands the country?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9ca mountain which must be rather high--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will climb to the summit to-morrow,\r\n'b'and then we shall see if this land is an island or a continent. Till\r\n'b'then, I repeat, there is nothing to be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, fire!\xe2\x80\x9d said the obstinate sailor again.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut he will make us a fire!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9conly have a\r\n'b'little patience, Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The seaman looked at Spilett in a way which seemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cIf it\r\n'b'depended upon you to do it, we wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t taste roast meat very soon\xe2\x80\x9d; but\r\n'b'he was silent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile Captain Harding had made no reply. He appeared to be very\r\n'b'little troubled by the question of fire. For a few minutes he remained\r\n'b'absorbed in thought; then again speaking,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cour situation is, perhaps, deplorable; but, at\r\n'b'any rate, it is very plain. Either we are on a continent, and then, at\r\n'b'the expense of greater or less fatigue, we shall reach some inhabited\r\n'b'place, or we are on an island. In the latter case, if the island is\r\n'b'inhabited, we will try to get out of the scrape with the help of its\r\n'b'inhabitants; if it is desert, we will try to get out of the scrape by\r\n'b'ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, nothing could be plainer,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, whether it is an island or a continent,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cwhereabouts do you think, Cyrus, this storm has thrown us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot say exactly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I presume it is\r\n'b'some land in the Pacific. In fact, when we left Richmond, the wind was\r\n'b'blowing from the northeast, and its very violence greatly proves that\r\n'b'it could not have varied. If the direction has been maintained from\r\n'b'the northeast to the southwest, we have traversed the States of North\r\n'b'Carolina, of South Carolina, of Georgia, the Gulf of Mexico, Mexico,\r\n'b'itself, in its narrow part, then a part of the Pacific Ocean. I cannot\r\n'b'estimate the distance traversed by the balloon at less than six to seven\r\n'b'thousand miles, and, even supposing that the wind had varied half a\r\n'b'quarter, it must have brought us either to the archipelago of Mendava,\r\n'b'either on the Pomotous, or even, if it had a greater strength than I\r\n'b'suppose, to the land of New Zealand. If the last hypothesis is correct,\r\n'b'it will be easy enough to get home again. English or Maoris, we shall\r\n'b'always find some one to whom we can speak. If, on the contrary, this is\r\n'b'the coast of a desert island in some tiny archipelago, perhaps we shall\r\n'b'be able to reconnoiter it from the summit of that peak which overlooks\r\n'b'the country, and then we shall see how best to establish ourselves here\r\n'b'as if we are never to go away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cYou say \xe2\x80\x98Never,\xe2\x80\x99 my dear Cyrus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBetter to put things at the worst at first,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\n'b'reserve the best for a surprise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell said,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is to be hoped, too, that this\r\n'b'island, if it be one, is not situated just out of the course of ships;\r\n'b'that would be really unlucky!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall not know what we have to rely on until we have first made the\r\n'b'ascent of the mountain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut to-morrow, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cshall you be in a state to\r\n'b'bear the fatigue of the ascent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cprovided you and Pencroft, my boy,\r\n'b'show yourselves quick and clever hunters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9csince you are speaking of game, if on my\r\n'b'return, I was as certain of roasting it as I am of bringing it back--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBring it back all the same, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was then agreed that the engineer and the reporter were to pass the\r\n'b'day at the Chimneys, so as to examine the shore and the upper plateau.\r\n'b'Neb, Herbert, and the sailor were to return to the forest, renew their\r\n'b'store of wood, and lay violent hands on every creature, feathered or\r\n'b'hairy, which might come within their reach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They set out accordingly about ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, Herbert\r\n'b'confident, Neb joyous, Pencroft murmuring aside,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf, on my return, I find a fire at the house, I shall believe that\r\n'b'the thunder itself came to light it.\xe2\x80\x9d All three climbed the bank; and\r\n'b'arrived at the angle made by the river, the sailor, stopping, said to\r\n'b'his two companions,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShall we begin by being hunters or wood-men?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHunters,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is Top already in quest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will hunt, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand afterwards we can come back\r\n'b'and collect our wood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This agreed to, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft, after having torn three\r\n'b'sticks from the trunk of a young fir, followed Top, who was bounding\r\n'b'about among the long grass.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This time, the hunters, instead of following the course of the river,\r\n'b'plunged straight into the heart of the forest. There were still the\r\n'b'same trees, belonging, for the most part, to the pine family. In\r\n'b'certain places, less crowded, growing in clumps, these pines exhibited\r\n'b'considerable dimensions, and appeared to indicate, by their development,\r\n'b'that the country was situated in a higher latitude than the engineer had\r\n'b'supposed. Glades, bristling with stumps worn away by time, were covered\r\n'b'with dry wood, which formed an inexhaustible store of fuel. Then,\r\n'b'the glade passed, the underwood thickened again, and became almost\r\n'b'impenetrable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was difficult enough to find the way among the groups of trees,\r\n'b'without any beaten track. So the sailor from time to time broke off\r\n'b'branches which might be easily recognized. But, perhaps, he was wrong\r\n'b'not to follow the watercourse, as he and Herbert had done on their first\r\n'b'excursion, for after walking an hour not a creature had shown itself.\r\n'b'Top, running under the branches, only roused birds which could not be\r\n'b'approached. Even the couroucous were invisible, and it was probable that\r\n'b'the sailor would be obliged to return to the marshy part of the forest,\r\n'b'in which he had so happily performed his grouse fishing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, in a slightly sarcastic tone, \xe2\x80\x9cif this is\r\n'b'all the game which you promised to bring back to my master, it won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n'b'need a large fire to roast it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave patience,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cit isn\xe2\x80\x99t the game which will be\r\n'b'wanting on our return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not confidence in Captain Harding?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe that he will make fire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI shall believe it when the wood is blazing in the fireplace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt will blaze, since my master has said so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, the sun had not reached the highest point in its course above\r\n'b'the horizon. The exploration, therefore, continued, and was usefully\r\n'b'marked by a discovery which Herbert made of a tree whose fruit was\r\n'b'edible. This was the stone-pine, which produces an excellent almond,\r\n'b'very much esteemed in the temperate regions of America and Europe. These\r\n'b'almonds were in a perfect state of maturity, and Herbert described them\r\n'b'to his companions, who feasted on them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9csea-weed by way of bread, raw mussels for meat,\r\n'b'and almonds for dessert, that\xe2\x80\x99s certainly a good dinner for those who\r\n'b'have not a single match in their pocket!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe mustn\xe2\x80\x99t complain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not complaining, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9conly I repeat, that\r\n'b'meat is a little too much economized in this sort of meal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop has found something!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, who ran towards a thicket, in the\r\n'b'midst of which the dog had disappeared, barking. With Top\xe2\x80\x99s barking were\r\n'b'mingled curious gruntings.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor and Herbert had followed Neb. If there was game there this\r\n'b'was not the time to discuss how it was to be cooked, but rather, how\r\n'b'they were to get hold of it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The hunters had scarcely entered the bushes when they saw Top engaged\r\n'b'in a struggle with an animal which he was holding by the ear. This\r\n'b'quadruped was a sort of pig nearly two feet and a half long, of a\r\n'b'blackish brown color, lighter below, having hard scanty hair; its toes,\r\n'b'then strongly fixed in the ground, seemed to be united by a membrane.\r\n'b'Herbert recognized in this animal the capybara, that is to say, one of\r\n'b'the largest members of the rodent order.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, the capybara did not struggle against the dog. It stupidly\r\n'b'rolled its eyes, deeply buried in a thick bed of fat. Perhaps it saw men\r\n'b'for the first time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, Neb having tightened his grasp on his stick, was just going to\r\n'b'fell the pig, when the latter, tearing itself from Top\xe2\x80\x99s teeth, by which\r\n'b'it was only held by the tip of its ear, uttered a vigorous grunt, rushed\r\n'b'upon Herbert, almost overthrew him, and disappeared in the wood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe rascal!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All three directly darted after Top, but at the moment when they joined\r\n'b'him the animal had disappeared under the waters of a large pond shaded\r\n'b'by venerable pines.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft stopped, motionless. Top plunged into the\r\n'b'water, but the capybara, hidden at the bottom of the pond, did not\r\n'b'appear.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy, \xe2\x80\x9cfor he will soon come to the surface to\r\n'b'breathe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t he drown?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9csince he has webbed feet, and is almost an\r\n'b'amphibious animal. But watch him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top remained in the water. Pencroft and his two companions went to\r\n'b'different parts of the bank, so as to cut off the retreat of the\r\n'b'capybara, which the dog was looking for beneath the water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert was not mistaken. In a few minutes the animal appeared on the\r\n'b'surface of the water. Top was upon it in a bound, and kept it from\r\n'b'plunging again. An instant later the capybara, dragged to the bank, was\r\n'b'killed by a blow from Neb\xe2\x80\x99s stick.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, who was always ready with this cry of triumph.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGive me but a good fire, and this pig shall be gnawed to the bones!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft hoisted the capybara on his shoulders, and judging by the\r\n'b'height of the sun that it was about two o\xe2\x80\x99clock, he gave the signal to\r\n'b'return.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top\xe2\x80\x99s instinct was useful to the hunters, who, thanks to the intelligent\r\n'b'animal, were enabled to discover the road by which they had come. Half\r\n'b'an hour later they arrived at the river.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft soon made a raft of wood, as he had done before, though if\r\n'b'there was no fire it would be a useless task, and the raft following the\r\n'b'current, they returned towards the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the sailor had not gone fifty paces when he stopped, and again\r\n'b'uttering a tremendous hurrah, pointed towards the angle of the cliff,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHerbert! Neb! Look!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Smoke was escaping and curling up among the rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 10\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few minutes the three hunters were before a crackling fire. The\r\n'b'captain and the reporter were there. Pencroft looked from one to the\r\n'b'other, his capybara in his hand, without saying a word.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, yes, my brave fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFire, real fire, which will roast this splendid pig perfectly, and we\r\n'b'will have a feast presently!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut who lighted it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe sun!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett was quite right in his reply. It was the sun which\r\n'b'had furnished the heat which so astonished Pencroft. The sailor could\r\n'b'scarcely believe his eyes, and he was so amazed that he did not think of\r\n'b'questioning the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHad you a burning-glass, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert of Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I made one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And he showed the apparatus which served for a burning-glass. It was\r\n'b'simply two glasses which he had taken from his own and the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'watches. Having filled them with water and rendered their edges adhesive\r\n'b'by means of a little clay, he thus fabricated a regular burning-glass,\r\n'b'which, concentrating the solar rays on some very dry moss, soon caused\r\n'b'it to blaze.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor considered the apparatus; then he gazed at the engineer\r\n'b'without saying a word, only a look plainly expressed his opinion that if\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding was not a magician, he was certainly no ordinary man. At\r\n'b'last speech returned to him, and he cried,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNote that, Mr. Spilett, note that down on your paper!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is noted,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, Neb helping him, the seaman arranged the spit, and the capybara,\r\n'b'properly cleaned, was soon roasting like a suckling-pig before a clear,\r\n'b'crackling fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The Chimneys had again become more habitable, not only because the\r\n'b'passages were warmed by the fire, but because the partitions of wood and\r\n'b'mud had been re-established.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was evident that the engineer and his companions had employed their\r\n'b'day well. Cyrus Harding had almost entirely recovered his strength, and\r\n'b'had proved it by climbing to the upper plateau. From this point his eye,\r\n'b'accustomed to estimate heights and distances, was fixed for a long time\r\n'b'on the cone, the summit of which he wished to reach the next day. The\r\n'b'mountain, situated about six miles to the northwest, appeared to him to\r\n'b'measure 3,500 feet above the level of the sea. Consequently the gaze of\r\n'b'an observer posted on its summit would extend over a radius of at least\r\n'b'fifty miles. Therefore it was probable that Harding could easily solve\r\n'b'the question of \xe2\x80\x9cisland or continent,\xe2\x80\x9d to which he attached so much\r\n'b'importance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They supped capitally. The flesh of the capybara was declared excellent.\r\n'b'The sargassum and the almonds of the stone-pine completed the repast,\r\n'b'during which the engineer spoke little. He was preoccupied with projects\r\n'b'for the next day.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Once or twice Pencroft gave forth some ideas upon what it would be best\r\n'b'to do; but Cyrus Harding, who was evidently of a methodical mind, only\r\n'b'shook his head without uttering a word.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall know what we have to depend upon,\r\n'b'and we will act accordingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The meal ended, fresh armfuls of wood were thrown on the fire, and\r\n'b'the inhabitants of the Chimneys, including the faithful Top, were soon\r\n'b'buried in a deep sleep.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No incident disturbed this peaceful night, and the next day, the 29th\r\n'b'of March, fresh and active they awoke, ready to undertake the excursion\r\n'b'which must determine their fate.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All was ready for the start. The remains of the capybara would be enough\r\n'b'to sustain Harding and his companions for at least twenty-four hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Besides, they hoped to find more food on the way. As the glasses had\r\n'b'been returned to the watches of the engineer and reporter, Pencroft\r\n'b'burned a little linen to serve as tinder. As to flint, that would not be\r\n'b'wanting in these regions of Plutonic origin. It was half-past seven in\r\n'b'the morning when the explorers, armed with sticks, left the Chimneys.\r\n'b'Following Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s advice, it appeared best to take the road already\r\n'b'traversed through the forest, and to return by another route. It was\r\n'b'also the most direct way to reach the mountain. They turned the south\r\n'b'angle and followed the left bank of the river, which was abandoned at\r\n'b'the point where it formed an elbow towards the southwest. The path,\r\n'b'already trodden under the evergreen trees, was found, and at nine\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock Cyrus Harding and his companions had reached the western border\r\n'b'of the forest. The ground, till then, very little undulated, boggy at\r\n'b'first, dry and sandy afterwards, had a gentle slope, which ascended from\r\n'b'the shore towards the interior of the country. A few very timid animals\r\n'b'were seen under the forest-trees. Top quickly started them, but his\r\n'b'master soon called him back, for the time had not come to commence\r\n'b'hunting; that would be attended to later. The engineer was not a man who\r\n'b'would allow himself to be diverted from his fixed idea. It might even\r\n'b'have been said that he did not observe the country at all, either in\r\n'b'its configuration or in its natural productions, his great aim being\r\n'b'to climb the mountain before him, and therefore straight towards it he\r\n'b'went. At ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock a halt of a few minutes was made. On leaving\r\n'b'the forest, the mountain system of the country appeared before the\r\n'b'explorers. The mountain was composed of two cones; the first, truncated\r\n'b'at a height of about two thousand five hundred feet, was sustained by\r\n'b'buttresses, which appeared to branch out like the talons of an immense\r\n'b'claw set on the ground. Between these were narrow valleys, bristling\r\n'b'with trees, the last clumps of which rose to the top of the lowest cone.\r\n'b'There appeared to be less vegetation on that side of the mountain which\r\n'b'was exposed to the northeast, and deep fissures could be seen which, no\r\n'b'doubt, were watercourses.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the first cone rested a second, slightly rounded, and placed a little\r\n'b'on one side, like a great round hat cocked over the ear. A Scotchman\r\n'b'would have said, \xe2\x80\x9cHis bonnet was a thocht ajee.\xe2\x80\x9d It appeared formed of\r\n'b'bare earth, here and there pierced by reddish rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They wished to reach the second cone, and proceeding along the ridge of\r\n'b'the spurs seemed to be the best way by which to gain it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are on volcanic ground,\xe2\x80\x9d Cyrus Harding had said, and his companions\r\n'b'following him began to ascend by degrees on the back of a spur, which,\r\n'b'by a winding and consequently more accessible path, joined the first\r\n'b'plateau.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The ground had evidently been convulsed by subterranean force. Here and\r\n'b'there stray blocks, numerous debris of basalt and pumice-stone, were met\r\n'b'with. In isolated groups rose fir-trees, which, some hundred feet\r\n'b'lower, at the bottom of the narrow gorges, formed massive shades almost\r\n'b'impenetrable to the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the first part of the ascent, Herbert remarked on the footprints\r\n'b'which indicated the recent passage of large animals.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps these beasts will not let us pass by willingly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, who had already hunted the tiger in\r\n'b'India, and the lion in Africa, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall soon learn how successfully to\r\n'b'encounter them. But in the meantime we must be upon our guard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They ascended but slowly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The distance, increased by detours and obstacles which could not be\r\n'b'surmounted directly, was long. Sometimes, too, the ground suddenly fell,\r\n'b'and they found themselves on the edge of a deep chasm which they had to\r\n'b'go round. Thus, in retracing their steps so as to find some practicable\r\n'b'path, much time was employed and fatigue undergone for nothing. At\r\n'b'twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when the small band of adventurers halted for breakfast\r\n'b'at the foot of a large group of firs, near a little stream which fell in\r\n'b'cascades, they found themselves still half way from the first plateau,\r\n'b'which most probably they would not reach till nightfall. From this\r\n'b'point the view of the sea was much extended, but on the right the high\r\n'b'promontory prevented their seeing whether there was land beyond it. On\r\n'b'the left, the sight extended several miles to the north; but, on the\r\n'b'northwest, at the point occupied by the explorers, it was cut short\r\n'b'by the ridge of a fantastically-shaped spur, which formed a powerful\r\n'b'support of the central cone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At one o\xe2\x80\x99clock the ascent was continued. They slanted more towards the\r\n'b'southwest and again entered among thick bushes. There under the shade\r\n'b'of the trees fluttered several couples of gallinaceae belonging to the\r\n'b'pheasant species. They were tragopans, ornamented by a pendant skin\r\n'b'which hangs over their throats, and by two small, round horns, planted\r\n'b'behind the eyes. Among these birds, which were about the size of a fowl,\r\n'b'the female was uniformly brown, while the male was gorgeous in his\r\n'b'red plumage, decorated with white spots. Gideon Spilett, with a stone\r\n'b'cleverly and vigorously thrown, killed one of these tragopans, on which\r\n'b'Pencroft, made hungry by the fresh air, had cast greedy eyes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After leaving the region of bushes, the party, assisted by resting on\r\n'b'each other\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders, climbed for about a hundred feet up a steep\r\n'b'acclivity and reached a level place, with very few trees, where the soil\r\n'b'appeared volcanic. It was necessary to ascend by zigzags to make\r\n'b'the slope more easy, for it was very steep, and the footing being\r\n'b'exceedingly precarious required the greatest caution. Neb and Herbert\r\n'b'took the lead, Pencroft the rear, the captain and the reporter between\r\n'b'them. The animals which frequented these heights--and there were\r\n'b'numerous traces of them--must necessarily belong to those races of sure\r\n'b'foot and supple spine, chamois or goat. Several were seen, but this\r\n'b'was not the name Pencroft gave them, for all of a sudden--\xe2\x80\x9cSheep!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\n'b'shouted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All stopped about fifty feet from half-a-dozen animals of a large size,\r\n'b'with strong horns bent back and flattened towards the point, with a\r\n'b'woolly fleece, hidden under long silky hair of a tawny color.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were not ordinary sheep, but a species usually found in the\r\n'b'mountainous regions of the temperate zone, to which Herbert gave the\r\n'b'name of the musmon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave they legs and chops?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, they are sheep!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The animals, motionless among the blocks of basalt, gazed with an\r\n'b'astonished eye, as if they saw human bipeds for the first time. Then\r\n'b'their fears suddenly aroused, they disappeared, bounding over the rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, till we meet again,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, as he watched them, in\r\n'b'such a comical tone that Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Neb\r\n'b'could not help laughing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The ascent was continued. Here and there were traces of lava. Sulphur\r\n'b'springs sometimes stopped their way, and they had to go round them. In\r\n'b'some places the sulphur had formed crystals among other substances, such\r\n'b'as whitish cinders made of an infinity of little feldspar crystals.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In approaching the first plateau formed by the truncating of the lower\r\n'b'cone, the difficulties of the ascent were very great. Towards four\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock the extreme zone of the trees had been passed. There only\r\n'b'remained here and there a few twisted, stunted pines, which must have\r\n'b'had a hard life in resisting at this altitude the high winds from the\r\n'b'open sea. Happily for the engineer and his companions the weather was\r\n'b'beautiful, the atmosphere tranquil; for a high breeze at an elevation of\r\n'b'three thousand feet would have hindered their proceedings. The purity\r\n'b'of the sky at the zenith was felt through the transparent air. A perfect\r\n'b'calm reigned around them. They could not see the sun, then hid by the\r\n'b'vast screen of the upper cone, which masked the half-horizon of the\r\n'b'west, and whose enormous shadow stretching to the shore increased as\r\n'b'the radiant luminary sank in its diurnal course. Vapor--mist rather than\r\n'b'clouds--began to appear in the east, and assume all the prismatic colors\r\n'b'under the influence of the solar rays.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Five hundred feet only separated the explorers from the plateau, which\r\n'b'they wished to reach so as to establish there an encampment for the\r\n'b'night, but these five hundred feet were increased to more than two miles\r\n'b'by the zigzags which they had to describe. The soil, as it were, slid\r\n'b'under their feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The slope often presented such an angle that they slipped when the\r\n'b'stones worn by the air did not give a sufficient support. Evening\r\n'b'came on by degrees, and it was almost night when Cyrus Harding and his\r\n'b'companions, much fatigued by an ascent of seven hours, arrived at\r\n'b'the plateau of the first cone. It was then necessary to prepare an\r\n'b'encampment, and to restore their strength by eating first and sleeping\r\n'b'afterwards. This second stage of the mountain rose on a base of rocks,\r\n'b'among which it would be easy to find a retreat. Fuel was not abundant.\r\n'b'However, a fire could be made by means of the moss and dry brushwood,\r\n'b'which covered certain parts of the plateau. While the sailor was\r\n'b'preparing his hearth with stones which he put to this use, Neb and\r\n'b'Herbert occupied themselves with getting a supply of fuel. They soon\r\n'b'returned with a load of brushwood. The steel was struck, the burnt linen\r\n'b'caught the sparks of flint, and, under Neb\xe2\x80\x99s breath, a crackling fire\r\n'b'showed itself in a few minutes under the shelter of the rocks. Their\r\n'b'object in lighting a fire was only to enable them to withstand the cold\r\n'b'temperature of the night, as it was not employed in cooking the bird,\r\n'b'which Neb kept for the next day. The remains of the capybara and\r\n'b'some dozens of the stone-pine almonds formed their supper. It was not\r\n'b'half-past six when all was finished.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding then thought of exploring in the half-light the large\r\n'b'circular layer which supported the upper cone of the mountain. Before\r\n'b'taking any rest, he wished to know if it was possible to get round the\r\n'b'base of the cone in the case of its sides being too steep and its summit\r\n'b'being inaccessible. This question preoccupied him, for it was possible\r\n'b'that from the way the hat inclined, that is to say, towards the north,\r\n'b'the plateau was not practicable. Also, if the summit of the mountain\r\n'b'could not be reached on one side, and if, on the other, they could not\r\n'b'get round the base of the cone, it would be impossible to survey the\r\n'b'western part of the country, and their object in making the ascent would\r\n'b'in part be altogether unattained.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, accordingly, regardless of fatigue, leaving Pencroft and\r\n'b'Neb to arrange the beds, and Gideon Spilett to note the incidents of the\r\n'b'day, began to follow the edge of the plateau, going towards the north.\r\n'b'Herbert accompanied him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night was beautiful and still, the darkness was not yet deep. Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding and the boy walked near each other, without speaking. In\r\n'b'some places the plateau opened before them, and they passed without\r\n'b'hindrance. In others, obstructed by rocks, there was only a narrow path,\r\n'b'in which two persons could not walk abreast. After a walk of twenty\r\n'b'minutes, Cyrus Harding and Herbert were obliged to stop. From this point\r\n'b'the slope of the two cones became one. No shoulder here separated the\r\n'b'two parts of the mountain. The slope, being inclined almost seventy\r\n'b'degrees, the path became impracticable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But if the engineer and the boy were obliged to give up thoughts of\r\n'b'following a circular direction, in return an opportunity was given for\r\n'b'ascending the cone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, before them opened a deep hollow. It was the rugged mouth\r\n'b'of the crater, by which the eruptive liquid matter had escaped at\r\n'b'the periods when the volcano was still in activity. Hardened lava and\r\n'b'crusted scoria formed a sort of natural staircase of large steps, which\r\n'b'would greatly facilitate the ascent to the summit of the mountain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding took all this in at a glance, and without hesitating, followed\r\n'b'by the lad, he entered the enormous chasm in the midst of an increasing\r\n'b'obscurity.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was still a height of a thousand feet to overcome. Would the\r\n'b'interior acclivities of the crater be practicable? It would soon be\r\n'b'seen. The persevering engineer resolved to continue his ascent until\r\n'b'he was stopped. Happily these acclivities wound up the interior of the\r\n'b'volcano and favored their ascent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the volcano itself, it could not be doubted that it was completely\r\n'b'extinct. No smoke escaped from its sides; not a flame could be seen in\r\n'b'the dark hollows; not a roar, not a mutter, no trembling even issued\r\n'b'from this black well, which perhaps reached far into the bowels of the\r\n'b'earth. The atmosphere inside the crater was filled with no sulphurous\r\n'b'vapor. It was more than the sleep of a volcano; it was its complete\r\n'b'extinction. Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s attempt would succeed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Little by little, Herbert and he climbing up the sides of the interior,\r\n'b'saw the crater widen above their heads. The radius of this circular\r\n'b'portion of the sky, framed by the edge of the cone, increased obviously.\r\n'b'At each step, as it were, that the explorers made, fresh stars entered\r\n'b'the field of their vision. The magnificent constellations of the\r\n'b'southern sky shone resplendently. At the zenith glittered the splendid\r\n'b'Antares in the Scorpion, and not far was Alpha Centauri, which is\r\n'b'believed to be the nearest star to the terrestrial globe. Then, as the\r\n'b'crater widened, appeared Fomalhaut of the Fish, the Southern Triangle,\r\n'b'and lastly, nearly at the Antarctic Pole, the glittering Southern Cross,\r\n'b'which replaces the Polar Star of the Northern Hemisphere.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was nearly eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock when Cyrus Harding and Herbert set foot on\r\n'b'the highest ridge of the mountain at the summit of the cone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was then perfectly dark, and their gaze could not extend over a\r\n'b'radius of two miles. Did the sea surround this unknown land, or was it\r\n'b'connected in the west with some continent of the Pacific? It could not\r\n'b'yet be made out. Towards the west, a cloudy belt, clearly visible at the\r\n'b'horizon, increased the gloom, and the eye could not discover if the sky\r\n'b'and water were blended together in the same circular line.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But at one point of the horizon a vague light suddenly appeared, which\r\n'b'descended slowly in proportion as the cloud mounted to the zenith.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the slender crescent moon, already almost disappearing; but its\r\n'b'light was sufficient to show clearly the horizontal line, then detached\r\n'b'from the cloud, and the engineer could see its reflection trembling for\r\n'b'an instant on a liquid surface. Cyrus Harding seized the lad\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and\r\n'b'in a grave voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAn island!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, at the moment when the lunar crescent disappeared\r\n'b'beneath the waves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 11\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Half an hour later Cyrus Harding and Herbert had returned to the\r\n'b'encampment. The engineer merely told his companions that the land upon\r\n'b'which fate had thrown them was an island, and that the next day they\r\n'b'would consult. Then each settled himself as well as he could to sleep,\r\n'b'and in that rocky hole, at a height of two thousand five hundred feet\r\n'b'above the level of the sea, through a peaceful night, the islanders\r\n'b'enjoyed profound repose.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 30th of March, after a hasty breakfast, which\r\n'b'consisted solely of the roasted tragopan, the engineer wished to climb\r\n'b'again to the summit of the volcano, so as more attentively to survey\r\n'b'the island upon which he and his companions were imprisoned for life\r\n'b'perhaps, should the island be situated at a great distance from any\r\n'b'land, or if it was out of the course of vessels which visited the\r\n'b'archipelagoes of the Pacific Ocean. This time his companions followed\r\n'b'him in the new exploration. They also wished to see the island, on the\r\n'b'productions of which they must depend for the supply of all their wants.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was about seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning when Cyrus Harding, Herbert,\r\n'b'Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Neb quitted the encampment. No one\r\n'b'appeared to be anxious about their situation. They had faith in\r\n'b'themselves, doubtless, but it must be observed that the basis of this\r\n'b'faith was not the same with Harding as with his companions. The engineer\r\n'b'had confidence, because he felt capable of extorting from this wild\r\n'b'country everything necessary for the life of himself and his companions;\r\n'b'the latter feared nothing, just because Cyrus Harding was with them.\r\n'b'Pencroft especially, since the incident of the relighted fire, would\r\n'b'not have despaired for an instant, even if he was on a bare rock, if the\r\n'b'engineer was with him on the rock.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPshaw,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe left Richmond without permission from the\r\n'b'authorities! It will be hard if we don\xe2\x80\x99t manage to get away some day or\r\n'b'other from a place where certainly no one will detain us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding followed the same road as the evening before. They went\r\n'b'round the cone by the plateau which formed the shoulder, to the mouth of\r\n'b'the enormous chasm. The weather was magnificent. The sun rose in a pure\r\n'b'sky and flooded with his rays all the eastern side of the mountain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The crater was reached. It was just what the engineer had made it out to\r\n'b'be in the dark; that is to say, a vast funnel which extended, widening,\r\n'b'to a height of a thousand feet above the plateau. Below the chasm, large\r\n'b'thick streaks of lava wound over the sides of the mountain, and thus\r\n'b'marked the course of the eruptive matter to the lower valleys which\r\n'b'furrowed the northern part of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The interior of the crater, whose inclination did not exceed thirty five\r\n'b'to forty degrees, presented no difficulties nor obstacles to the ascent.\r\n'b'Traces of very ancient lava were noticed, which probably had overflowed\r\n'b'the summit of the cone, before this lateral chasm had opened a new way\r\n'b'to it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the volcanic chimney which established a communication between the\r\n'b'subterranean layers and the crater, its depth could not be calculated\r\n'b'with the eye, for it was lost in obscurity. But there was no doubt as to\r\n'b'the complete extinction of the volcano.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Before eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock Harding and his companions were assembled at the\r\n'b'summit of the crater, on a conical mound which swelled the northern\r\n'b'edge.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe sea, the sea everywhere!\xe2\x80\x9d they cried, as if their lips could not\r\n'b'restrain the words which made islanders of them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sea, indeed, formed an immense circular sheet of water all around\r\n'b'them! Perhaps, on climbing again to the summit of the cone, Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding had had a hope of discovering some coast, some island shore,\r\n'b'which he had not been able to perceive in the dark the evening before.\r\n'b'But nothing appeared on the farthest verge of the horizon, that is to\r\n'b'say over a radius of more than fifty miles. No land in sight. Not a\r\n'b'sail. Over all this immense space the ocean alone was visible--the\r\n'b'island occupied the center of a circumference which appeared to be\r\n'b'infinite.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer and his companions, mute and motionless, surveyed for\r\n'b'some minutes every point of the ocean, examining it to its most extreme\r\n'b'limits. Even Pencroft, who possessed a marvelous power of sight, saw\r\n'b'nothing; and certainly if there had been land at the horizon, if it\r\n'b'appeared only as an indistinct vapor, the sailor would undoubtedly\r\n'b'have found it out, for nature had placed regular telescopes under his\r\n'b'eyebrows.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From the ocean their gaze returned to the island which they commanded\r\n'b'entirely, and the first question was put by Gideon Spilett in these\r\n'b'terms:\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout what size is this island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Truly, it did not appear large in the midst of the immense ocean.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding reflected a few minutes; he attentively observed the\r\n'b'perimeter of the island, taking into consideration the height at which\r\n'b'he was placed; then,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not think I am mistaken in giving to the\r\n'b'shore of the island a circumference of more than a hundred miles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd consequently an area?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is difficult to estimate,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is so\r\n'b'uneven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'If Cyrus Harding was not mistaken in his calculation, the island had\r\n'b'almost the extent of Malta or Zante, in the Mediterranean, but it was at\r\n'b'the same time much more irregular and less rich in capes, promontories,\r\n'b'points, bays, or creeks. Its strange form caught the eye, and when\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, on the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s advice, had drawn the outline, they\r\n'b'found that it resembled some fantastic animal, a monstrous leviathan,\r\n'b'which lay sleeping on the surface of the Pacific.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was in fact the exact shape of the island, which it is of\r\n'b'consequence to know, and a tolerably correct map of it was immediately\r\n'b'drawn by the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The east part of the shore, where the castaways had landed, formed a\r\n'b'wide bay, terminated by a sharp cape, which had been concealed by a high\r\n'b'point from Pencroft on his first exploration. At the northeast two other\r\n'b'capes closed the bay, and between them ran a narrow gulf, which looked\r\n'b'like the half-open jaws of a formidable dog-fish.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From the northeast to the southwest the coast was rounded, like\r\n'b'the flattened cranium of an animal, rising again, forming a sort of\r\n'b'protuberance which did not give any particular shape to this part of the\r\n'b'island, of which the center was occupied by the volcano.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From this point the shore ran pretty regularly north and south, broken\r\n'b'at two-thirds of its perimeter by a narrow creek, from which it ended in\r\n'b'a long tail, similar to the caudal appendage of a gigantic alligator.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This tail formed a regular peninsula, which stretched more than thirty\r\n'b'miles into the sea, reckoning from the cape southeast of the island,\r\n'b'already mentioned; it curled round, making an open roadstead, which\r\n'b'marked out the lower shore of this strangely-formed land.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the narrowest part, that is to say between the Chimneys and the creek\r\n'b'on the western shore, which corresponded to it in latitude, the island\r\n'b'only measured ten miles; but its greatest length, from the jaws at the\r\n'b'northeast to the extremity of the tail of the southwest, was not less\r\n'b'than thirty miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the interior of the island, its general aspect was this, very\r\n'b'woody throughout the southern part from the mountain to the shore, and\r\n'b'arid and sandy in the northern part. Between the volcano and the east\r\n'b'coast Cyrus Harding and his companions were surprised to see a\r\n'b'lake, bordered with green trees, the existence of which they had not\r\n'b'suspected. Seen from this height, the lake appeared to be on the same\r\n'b'level as the ocean, but, on reflection, the engineer explained to his\r\n'b'companions that the altitude of this little sheet of water must be about\r\n'b'three hundred feet, because the plateau, which was its basin, was but a\r\n'b'prolongation of the coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs it a freshwater lake?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it must be fed by the water\r\n'b'which flows from the mountain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI see a little river which runs into it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, pointing out a\r\n'b'narrow stream, which evidently took its source somewhere in the west.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cand since this stream feeds the lake, most\r\n'b'probably on the side near the sea there is an outlet by which the\r\n'b'surplus water escapes. We shall see that on our return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This little winding watercourse and the river already mentioned\r\n'b'constituted the water-system, at least such as it was displayed to the\r\n'b'eyes of the explorers. However, it was possible that under the masses of\r\n'b'trees which covered two-thirds of the island, forming an immense forest,\r\n'b'other rivers ran towards the sea. It might even be inferred that such\r\n'b'was the case, so rich did this region appear in the most magnificent\r\n'b'specimens of the flora of the temperate zones. There was no indication\r\n'b'of running water in the north, though perhaps there might be stagnant\r\n'b'water among the marshes in the northeast; but that was all, in addition\r\n'b'to the downs, sand, and aridity which contrasted so strongly with the\r\n'b'luxuriant vegetation of the rest of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The volcano did not occupy the central part; it rose, on the contrary,\r\n'b'in the northwestern region, and seemed to mark the boundary of the two\r\n'b'zones. At the southwest, at the south, and the southeast, the first part\r\n'b'of the spurs were hidden under masses of verdure. At the north, on the\r\n'b'contrary, one could follow their ramifications, which died away on the\r\n'b'sandy plains. It was on this side that, at the time when the mountain\r\n'b'was in a state of eruption, the discharge had worn away a passage, and\r\n'b'a large heap of lava had spread to the narrow jaw which formed the\r\n'b'northeastern gulf.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions remained an hour at the top of the\r\n'b'mountain. The island was displayed under their eyes, like a plan in\r\n'b'relief with different tints, green for the forests, yellow for the\r\n'b'sand, blue for the water. They viewed it in its tout-ensemble, nothing\r\n'b'remained concealed but the ground hidden by verdure, the hollows of the\r\n'b'valleys, and the interior of the volcanic chasms.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'One important question remained to be solved, and the answer would have\r\n'b'a great effect upon the future of the castaways.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Was the island inhabited?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the reporter who put this question, to which after the close\r\n'b'examination they had just made, the answer seemed to be in the negative.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nowhere could the work of a human hand be perceived. Not a group of\r\n'b'huts, not a solitary cabin, not a fishery on the shore. No smoke curling\r\n'b'in the air betrayed the presence of man. It is true, a distance of\r\n'b'nearly thirty miles separated the observers from the extreme points,\r\n'b'that is, of the tail which extended to the southwest, and it would have\r\n'b'been difficult, even to Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, to discover a habitation there.\r\n'b'Neither could the curtain of verdure, which covered three-quarters\r\n'b'of the island, be raised to see if it did not shelter some straggling\r\n'b'village. But in general the islanders live on the shores of the narrow\r\n'b'spaces which emerge above the waters of the Pacific, and this shore\r\n'b'appeared to be an absolute desert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Until a more complete exploration, it might be admitted that the island\r\n'b'was uninhabited. But was it frequented, at least occasionally, by\r\n'b'the natives of neighboring islands? It was difficult to reply to this\r\n'b'question. No land appeared within a radius of fifty miles. But fifty\r\n'b'miles could be easily crossed, either by Malay proas or by the large\r\n'b'Polynesian canoes. Everything depended on the position of the island,\r\n'b'of its isolation in the Pacific, or of its proximity to archipelagoes.\r\n'b'Would Cyrus Harding be able to find out their latitude and longitude\r\n'b'without instruments? It would be difficult. Since he was in doubt, it\r\n'b'was best to take precautions against a possible descent of neighboring\r\n'b'natives.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The exploration of the island was finished, its shape determined, its\r\n'b'features made out, its extent calculated, the water and mountain systems\r\n'b'ascertained. The disposition of the forests and plains had been marked\r\n'b'in a general way on the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s plan. They had now only to descend\r\n'b'the mountain slopes again, and explore the soil, in the triple point of\r\n'b'view, of its mineral, vegetable, and animal resources.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But before giving his companions the signal for departure, Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'said to them in a calm, grave voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere, my friends, is the small corner of land upon which the hand of\r\n'b'the Almighty has thrown us. We are going to live here; a long time,\r\n'b'perhaps. Perhaps, too, unexpected help will arrive, if some ship passes\r\n'b'by chance. I say by chance, because this is an unimportant island; there\r\n'b'is not even a port in which ships could anchor, and it is to be feared\r\n'b'that it is situated out of the route usually followed, that is to say,\r\n'b'too much to the south for the ships which frequent the archipelagoes of\r\n'b'the Pacific, and too much to the north for those which go to Australia\r\n'b'by doubling Cape Horn. I wish to hide nothing of our position from\r\n'b'you--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are right, my dear Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, with\r\n'b'animation. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have to deal with men. They have confidence in you, and\r\n'b'you can depend upon them. Is it not so, my friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will obey you in everything, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, seizing the\r\n'b'engineer\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy master always, and everywhere!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs for me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cif I ever grumble at work, my name\xe2\x80\x99s not\r\n'b'Jack Pencroft, and if you like, captain, we will make a little America\r\n'b'of this island! We will build towns, we will establish railways, start\r\n'b'telegraphs, and one fine day, when it is quite changed, quite put in\r\n'b'order and quite civilized, we will go and offer it to the government of\r\n'b'the Union. Only, I ask one thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, that we do not consider ourselves castaways, but colonists,\r\n'b'who have come here to settle.\xe2\x80\x9d Harding could not help smiling, and the\r\n'b'sailor\xe2\x80\x99s idea was adopted. He then thanked his companions, and added,\r\n'b'that he would rely on their energy and on the aid of Heaven.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now let us set off to the Chimneys!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne minute, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me it would\r\n'b'be a good thing to give a name to this island, as well as to, the capes,\r\n'b'promontories, and watercourses, which we can see.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the future, that will simplify the\r\n'b'instructions which we shall have to give and follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9calready it is something to be able to say\r\n'b'where one is going, and where one has come from. At least, it looks like\r\n'b'somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Chimneys, for example,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cExactly!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cThat name was the most convenient, and it\r\n'b'came to me quite of myself. Shall we keep the name of the Chimneys for\r\n'b'our first encampment, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Pencroft, since you have so christened it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood! as for the others, that will be easy,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor, who\r\n'b'was in high spirits. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us give them names, as the Robinsons did,\r\n'b'whose story Herbert has often read to me; Providence Bay, Whale Point,\r\n'b'Cape Disappointment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOr, rather, the names of Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cof Mr.\r\n'b'Spilett, of Neb!--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy name!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, showing his sparkling white teeth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cPort Neb, that would do very well! And\r\n'b'Cape Gideon--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI should prefer borrowing names from our country,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cwhich would remind us of America.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for the principal ones,\xe2\x80\x9d then said Cyrus Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cfor those of\r\n'b'the bays and seas, I admit it willingly. We might give to that vast bay\r\n'b'on the east the name of Union Bay, for example; to that large hollow on\r\n'b'the south, Washington Bay; to the mountain upon which we are standing,\r\n'b'that of Mount Franklin; to that lake which is extended under our eyes,\r\n'b'that of Lake Grant; nothing could be better, my friends. These names\r\n'b'will recall our country, and those of the great citizens who have\r\n'b'honored it; but for the rivers, gulfs, capes, and promontories, which we\r\n'b'perceive from the top of this mountain, rather let us choose names which\r\n'b'will recall their particular shape. They will impress themselves better\r\n'b'on our memory, and at the same time will be more practical. The shape of\r\n'b'the island is so strange that we shall not be troubled to imagine\r\n'b'what it resembles. As to the streams which we do not know as yet, in\r\n'b'different parts of the forest which we shall explore later, the creeks\r\n'b'which afterwards will be discovered, we can christen them as we find\r\n'b'them. What do you think, my friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s proposal was unanimously agreed to by his companions. The\r\n'b'island was spread out under their eyes like a map, and they had only to\r\n'b'give names to all its angles and points. Gideon Spilett would write\r\n'b'them down, and the geographical nomenclature of the island would be\r\n'b'definitely adopted. First, they named the two bays and the mountain,\r\n'b'Union Bay, Washington Bay, and Mount Franklin, as the engineer had\r\n'b'suggested.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cto this peninsula at the southwest of the\r\n'b'island, I propose to give the name of Serpentine Peninsula, and that of\r\n'b'Reptile-end to the bent tail which terminates it, for it is just like a\r\n'b'reptile\xe2\x80\x99s tail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAdopted,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, pointing to the other extremity of the island, \xe2\x80\x9clet\r\n'b'us call this gulf which is so singularly like a pair of open jaws, Shark\r\n'b'Gulf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCapital!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand we can complete the resemblance by\r\n'b'naming the two parts of the jaws Mandible Cape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut there are two capes,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can have North Mandible Cape and South\r\n'b'Mandible Cape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey are inscribed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is only the point at the southeastern extremity of the island to\r\n'b'be named,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is, the extremity of Union Bay?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cClaw Cape,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb directly, who also wished to be godfather to some\r\n'b'part of his domain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In truth, Neb had found an excellent name, for this cape was very like\r\n'b'the powerful claw of the fantastic animal which this singularly-shaped\r\n'b'island represented.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft was delighted at the turn things had taken, and their\r\n'b'imaginations soon gave to the river which furnished the settlers with\r\n'b'drinking water and near which the balloon had thrown them, the name of\r\n'b'the Mercy, in true gratitude to Providence. To the islet upon which the\r\n'b'castaways had first landed, the name of Safety Island; to the plateau\r\n'b'which crowned the high granite precipice above the Chimneys, and from\r\n'b'whence the gaze could embrace the whole of the vast bay, the name of\r\n'b'Prospect Heights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Lastly, all the masses of impenetrable wood which covered the Serpentine\r\n'b'Peninsula were named the forests of the Far West.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The nomenclature of the visible and known parts of the island was\r\n'b'thus finished, and later, they would complete it as they made fresh\r\n'b'discoveries.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the points of the compass, the engineer had roughly fixed them by\r\n'b'the height and position of the sun, which placed Union Bay and Prospect\r\n'b'Heights to the east. But the next day, by taking the exact hour of the\r\n'b'rising and setting of the sun, and by marking its position between this\r\n'b'rising and setting, he reckoned to fix the north of the island exactly,\r\n'b'for, in consequence of its situation in the Southern Hemisphere, the\r\n'b'sun, at the precise moment of its culmination, passed in the north and\r\n'b'not in the south, as, in its apparent movement, it seems to do, to those\r\n'b'places situated in the Northern Hemisphere.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Everything was finished, and the settlers had only to descend Mount\r\n'b'Franklin to return to the Chimneys, when Pencroft cried out,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell! we are preciously stupid!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett, who had closed his notebook and risen to\r\n'b'depart.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy! our island! we have forgotten to christen it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert was going to propose to give it the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s name and all his\r\n'b'companions would have applauded him, when Cyrus Harding said simply,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us give it the name of a great citizen, my friend; of him who now\r\n'b'struggles to defend the unity of the American Republic! Let us call it\r\n'b'Lincoln Island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s proposal was replied to by three hurrahs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And that evening, before sleeping, the new colonists talked of their\r\n'b'absent country; they spoke of the terrible war which stained it with\r\n'b'blood; they could not doubt that the South would soon be subdued, and\r\n'b'that the cause of the North, the cause of justice, would triumph, thanks\r\n'b'to Grant, thanks to Lincoln!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now this happened the 30th of March, 1865. They little knew that sixteen\r\n'b'days afterwards a frightful crime would be committed in Washington, and\r\n'b'that on Good Friday Abraham Lincoln would fall by the hand of a fanatic.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 12\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They now began the descent of the mountain. Climbing down the crater,\r\n'b'they went round the cone and reached their encampment of the previous\r\n'b'night. Pencroft thought it must be breakfast-time, and the watches of\r\n'b'the reporter and engineer were therefore consulted to find out the hour.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That of Gideon Spilett had been preserved from the sea-water, as he had\r\n'b'been thrown at once on the sand out of reach of the waves. It was an\r\n'b'instrument of excellent quality, a perfect pocket chronometer, which the\r\n'b'reporter had not forgotten to wind up carefully every day.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s watch, it, of course, had stopped during the time\r\n'b'which he had passed on the downs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer now wound it up, and ascertaining by the height of the sun\r\n'b'that it must be about nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, he put his watch at\r\n'b'that hour.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear Spilett, wait. You have kept the Richmond time, have you\r\n'b'not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Cyrus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cConsequently, your watch is set by the meridian of that town, which is\r\n'b'almost that of Washington?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUndoubtedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, keep it thus. Content yourself with winding it up very,\r\n'b'exactly, but do not touch the hands. This may be of use to us.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will be the good of that?\xe2\x80\x9d thought the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They ate, and so heartily, that the store of game and almonds was\r\n'b'totally exhausted. But Pencroft was not at all uneasy, they would supply\r\n'b'themselves on the way. Top, whose share had been very much to his taste,\r\n'b'would know how to find some fresh game among the brushwood. Moreover,\r\n'b'the sailor thought of simply asking the engineer to manufacture some\r\n'b'powder and one or two fowling-pieces; he supposed there would be no\r\n'b'difficulty in that.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On leaving the plateau, the captain proposed to his companions to return\r\n'b'to the Chimneys by a new way. He wished to reconnoiter Lake Grant, so\r\n'b'magnificently framed in trees. They therefore followed the crest of one\r\n'b'of the spurs, between which the creek that supplied the lake probably\r\n'b'had its source. In talking, the settlers already employed the names\r\n'b'which they had just chosen, which singularly facilitated the exchange\r\n'b'of their ideas. Herbert and Pencroft--the one young and the other very\r\n'b'boyish--were enchanted, and while walking, the sailor said,\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHey, Herbert! how capital it sounds! It will be impossible to lose\r\n'b'ourselves, my boy, since, whether we follow the way to Lake Grant, or\r\n'b'whether we join the Mercy through the woods of the Far West, we shall be\r\n'b'certain to arrive at Prospect Heights, and, consequently, at Union Bay!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It had been agreed, that without forming a compact band, the settlers\r\n'b'should not stray away from each other. It was very certain that the\r\n'b'thick forests of the island were inhabited by dangerous animals, and it\r\n'b'was prudent to be on their guard. In general, Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb\r\n'b'walked first, preceded by Top, who poked his nose into every bush. The\r\n'b'reporter and the engineer went together, Gideon Spilett ready to note\r\n'b'every incident, the engineer silent for the most part, and only stepping\r\n'b'aside to pick up one thing or another, a mineral or vegetable substance,\r\n'b'which he put into his pocket, without making any remark.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can he be picking up?\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cI have looked in vain\r\n'b'for anything that\xe2\x80\x99s worth the trouble of stooping for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock the little band descended the last declivities of\r\n'b'Mount Franklin. As yet the ground was scantily strewn with bushes and\r\n'b'trees. They were walking over yellowish calcinated earth, forming a\r\n'b'plain of nearly a mile long, which extended to the edge of the wood.\r\n'b'Great blocks of that basalt, which, according to Bischof, takes three\r\n'b'hundred and fifty millions of years to cool, strewed the plain, very\r\n'b'confused in some places. However, there were here no traces of lava,\r\n'b'which was spread more particularly over the northern slopes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding expected to reach, without incident, the course of the\r\n'b'creek, which he supposed flowed under the trees at the border of the\r\n'b'plain, when he saw Herbert running hastily back, while Neb and the\r\n'b'sailor were hiding behind the rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, my boy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSmoke,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have seen smoke among the rocks, a hundred\r\n'b'paces from us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMen in this place?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must avoid showing ourselves before knowing with whom we have to\r\n'b'deal,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cI trust that there are no natives on this\r\n'b'island; I dread them more than anything else. Where is Top?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop is on before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t bark?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is strange. However, we must try to call him back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few moments, the engineer, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert had rejoined\r\n'b'their two companions, and like them, they kept out of sight behind the\r\n'b'heaps of basalt.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From thence they clearly saw smoke of a yellowish color rising in the\r\n'b'air.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top was recalled by a slight whistle from his master, and the latter,\r\n'b'signing to his companions to wait for him, glided away among the\r\n'b'rocks. The colonists, motionless, anxiously awaited the result of this\r\n'b'exploration, when a shout from the engineer made them hasten forward.\r\n'b'They soon joined him, and were at once struck with a disagreeable odor\r\n'b'which impregnated the atmosphere.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The odor, easily recognized, was enough for the engineer to guess what\r\n'b'the smoke was which at first, not without cause, had startled him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis fire,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cor rather, this smoke is produced by nature alone.\r\n'b'There is a sulphur spring there, which will cure all our sore throats.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pity that I haven\xe2\x80\x99t got a cold!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers then directed their steps towards the place from which the\r\n'b'smoke escaped. They there saw a sulphur spring which flowed abundantly\r\n'b'between the rocks, and its waters discharged a strong sulphuric acid\r\n'b'odor, after having absorbed the oxygen of the air.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, dipping in his hand, felt the water oily to the touch.\r\n'b'He tasted it and found it rather sweet. As to its temperature, that he\r\n'b'estimated at ninety-five degrees Fahrenheit. Herbert having asked on\r\n'b'what he based this calculation,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIts quite simple, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cfor, in plunging my hand into the\r\n'b'water, I felt no sensation either of heat or cold. Therefore it has the\r\n'b'same temperature as the human body, which is about ninety-five degrees.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sulphur spring not being of any actual use to the settlers, they\r\n'b'proceeded towards the thick border of the forest, which began some\r\n'b'hundred paces off.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There, as they had conjectured, the waters of the stream flowed clear\r\n'b'and limpid between high banks of red earth, the color of which betrayed\r\n'b'the presence of oxide of iron. From this color, the name of Red Creek\r\n'b'was immediately given to the watercourse.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was only a large stream, deep and clear, formed of the mountain\r\n'b'water, which, half river, half torrent, here rippling peacefully over\r\n'b'the sand, there falling against the rocks or dashing down in a cascade,\r\n'b'ran towards the lake, over a distance of a mile and a half, its breadth\r\n'b'varying from thirty to forty feet. Its waters were sweet, and it was\r\n'b'supposed that those of the lake were so also. A fortunate circumstance,\r\n'b'in the event of their finding on its borders a more suitable dwelling\r\n'b'than the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the trees, which some hundred feet downwards shaded the banks of\r\n'b'the creek, they belonged, for the most part, to the species which abound\r\n'b'in the temperate zone of America and Tasmania, and no longer to those\r\n'b'coniferae observed in that portion of the island already explored\r\n'b'to some miles from Prospect Heights. At this time of the year, the\r\n'b'commencement of the month of April, which represents the month of\r\n'b'October, in this hemisphere, that is, the beginning of autumn, they\r\n'b'were still in full leaf. They consisted principally of casuarinas and\r\n'b'eucalypti, some of which next year would yield a sweet manna, similar to\r\n'b'the manna of the East. Clumps of Australian cedars rose on the sloping\r\n'b'banks, which were also covered with the high grass called \xe2\x80\x9ctussac\xe2\x80\x9d in\r\n'b'New Holland; but the cocoanut, so abundant in the archipelagoes of the\r\n'b'Pacific, seemed to be wanting in the island, the latitude, doubtless,\r\n'b'being too low.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pity!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9csuch a useful tree, and which has such\r\n'b'beautiful nuts!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the birds, they swarmed among the scanty branches of the eucalypti\r\n'b'and casuarinas, which did not hinder the display of their wings.\r\n'b'Black, white, or gray cockatoos, paroquets, with plumage of all colors,\r\n'b'kingfishers of a sparkling green and crowned with red, blue lories,\r\n'b'and various other birds appeared on all sides, as through a prism,\r\n'b'fluttering about and producing a deafening clamor. Suddenly, a strange\r\n'b'concert of discordant voices resounded in the midst of a thicket. The\r\n'b'settlers heard successively the song of birds, the cry of quadrupeds,\r\n'b'and a sort of clacking which they might have believed to have escaped\r\n'b'from the lips of a native. Neb and Herbert rushed towards the bush,\r\n'b'forgetting even the most elementary principles of prudence. Happily,\r\n'b'they found there, neither a formidable wild beast nor a dangerous\r\n'b'native, but merely half a dozen mocking and singing birds, known as\r\n'b'mountain pheasants. A few skillful blows from a stick soon put an end to\r\n'b'their concert, and procured excellent food for the evening\xe2\x80\x99s dinner.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert also discovered some magnificent pigeons with bronzed wings,\r\n'b'some superbly crested, others draped in green, like their congeners at\r\n'b'Port-Macquarie; but it was impossible to reach them, or the crows and\r\n'b'magpies which flew away in flocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A charge of small shot would have made great slaughter among these\r\n'b'birds, but the hunters were still limited to sticks and stones, and\r\n'b'these primitive weapons proved very insufficient.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their insufficiency was still more clearly shown when a troop of\r\n'b'quadrupeds, jumping, bounding, making leaps of thirty feet, regular\r\n'b'flying mammiferae, fled over the thickets, so quickly and at such a\r\n'b'height, that one would have thought that they passed from one tree to\r\n'b'another like squirrels.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cKangaroos!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre they good to eat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStewed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9ctheir flesh is equal to the best\r\n'b'venison!--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett had not finished this exciting sentence when the sailor,\r\n'b'followed by Neb and Herbert, darted on the kangaroos tracks. Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding called them back in vain. But it was in vain too for the hunters\r\n'b'to pursue such agile game, which went bounding away like balls. After a\r\n'b'chase of five minutes, they lost their breath, and at the same time all\r\n'b'sight of the creatures, which disappeared in the wood. Top was not more\r\n'b'successful than his masters.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, when the engineer and the reporter had\r\n'b'rejoined them, \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain, you see quite well we can\xe2\x80\x99t get on unless we\r\n'b'make a few guns. Will that be possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we will begin by first\r\n'b'manufacturing some bows and arrows, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt that you will\r\n'b'become as clever in the use of them as the Australian hunters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBows and arrows!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft scornfully. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all very well for\r\n'b'children!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be proud, friend Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cBows and\r\n'b'arrows were sufficient for centuries to stain the earth with blood.\r\n'b'Powder is but a thing of yesterday, and war is as old as the human\r\n'b'race--unhappily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFaith, that\xe2\x80\x99s true, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand I always\r\n'b'speak too quickly. You must excuse me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, Herbert constant to his favorite science, Natural History,\r\n'b'reverted to the kangaroos, saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, we had to deal just now with the species which is most\r\n'b'difficult to catch. They were giants with long gray fur; but if I am not\r\n'b'mistaken, there exist black and red kangaroos, rock kangaroos, and rat\r\n'b'kangaroos, which are more easy to get hold of. It is reckoned that there\r\n'b'are about a dozen species.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHerbert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor sententiously, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is only one species\r\n'b'of kangaroos to me, that is \xe2\x80\x98kangaroo on the spit,\xe2\x80\x99 and it\xe2\x80\x99s just the\r\n'b'one we haven\xe2\x80\x99t got this evening!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They could not help laughing at Master Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s new classification.\r\n'b'The honest sailor did not hide his regret at being reduced for dinner to\r\n'b'the singing pheasants, but fortune once more showed itself obliging to\r\n'b'him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, Top, who felt that his interest was concerned went and ferreted\r\n'b'everywhere with an instinct doubled by a ferocious appetite. It was even\r\n'b'probable that if some piece of game did fall into his clutches, none\r\n'b'would be left for the hunters, if Top was hunting on his own account;\r\n'b'but Neb watched him and he did well.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards three o\xe2\x80\x99clock the dog disappeared in the brushwood and gruntings\r\n'b'showed that he was engaged in a struggle with some animal. Neb rushed\r\n'b'after him, and soon saw Top eagerly devouring a quadruped, which ten\r\n'b'seconds later would have been past recognizing in Top\xe2\x80\x99s stomach. But\r\n'b'fortunately the dog had fallen upon a brood, and besides the victim he\r\n'b'was devouring, two other rodents--the animals in question belonged to\r\n'b'that order--lay strangled on the turf.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb reappeared triumphantly holding one of the rodents in each hand.\r\n'b'Their size exceeded that of a rabbit, their hair was yellow, mingled\r\n'b'with green spots, and they had the merest rudiments of tails.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The citizens of the Union were at no loss for the right name of these\r\n'b'rodents. They were maras, a sort of agouti, a little larger than their\r\n'b'congeners of tropical countries, regular American rabbits, with long\r\n'b'ears, jaws armed on each side with five molars, which distinguish the\r\n'b'agouti.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthe roast has arrived! and now we can go\r\n'b'home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The walk, interrupted for an instant, was resumed. The limpid waters of\r\n'b'the Red Creek flowed under an arch of casuarinas, banksias, and gigantic\r\n'b'gum-trees. Superb lilacs rose to a height of twenty feet. Other\r\n'b'arborescent species, unknown to the young naturalist, bent over the\r\n'b'stream, which could be heard murmuring beneath the bowers of verdure.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile the stream grew much wider, and Cyrus Harding supposed that\r\n'b'they would soon reach its mouth. In fact, on emerging from beneath a\r\n'b'thick clump of beautiful trees, it suddenly appeared before their eyes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The explorers had arrived on the western shore of Lake Grant. The place\r\n'b'was well worth looking at. This extent of water, of a circumference of\r\n'b'nearly seven miles and an area of two hundred and fifty acres, reposed\r\n'b'in a border of diversified trees.
