Towards the east, through a curtain\r\n'b'of verdure, picturesquely raised in some places, sparkled an horizon of\r\n'b'sea. The lake was curved at the north, which contrasted with the sharp\r\n'b'outline of its lower part. Numerous aquatic birds frequented the shores\r\n'b'of this little Ontario, in which the thousand isles of its American\r\n'b'namesake were represented by a rock which emerged from its surface, some\r\n'b'hundred feet from the southern shore. There lived in harmony several\r\n'b'couples of kingfishers perched on a stone, grave, motionless, watching\r\n'b'for fish, then darting down, they plunged in with a sharp cry, and\r\n'b'reappeared with their prey in their beaks. On the shores and on the\r\n'b'islets, strutted wild ducks, pelicans, water-hens, red-beaks, philedons,\r\n'b'furnished with a tongue like a brush, and one or two specimens of the\r\n'b'splendid menura, the tail of which expands gracefully like a lyre.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the water of the lake, it was sweet, limpid, rather dark, and from\r\n'b'certain bubblings, and the concentric circles which crossed each other\r\n'b'on the surface, it could not be doubted that it abounded in fish.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis lake is really beautiful!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cWe could live on\r\n'b'its borders!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will live there!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers, wishing to return to the Chimneys by the shortest way,\r\n'b'descended towards the angle formed on the south by the junction of\r\n'b'the lake\xe2\x80\x99s bank. It was not without difficulty that they broke a path\r\n'b'through the thickets and brushwood which had never been put aside by the\r\n'b'hand of men, and they thus went towards the shore, so as to arrive at\r\n'b'the north of Prospect Heights. Two miles were cleared in this direction,\r\n'b'and then, after they had passed the last curtain of trees, appeared the\r\n'b'plateau, carpeted with thick turf, and beyond that the infinite sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To return to the Chimneys, it was enough to cross the plateau obliquely\r\n'b'for the space of a mile, and then to descend to the elbow formed by\r\n'b'the first detour of the Mercy. But the engineer desired to know how\r\n'b'and where the overplus of the water from the lake escaped, and the\r\n'b'exploration was prolonged under the trees for a mile and a half towards\r\n'b'the north. It was most probable that an overfall existed somewhere, and\r\n'b'doubtless through a cleft in the granite. This lake was only, in short,\r\n'b'an immense center basin, which was filled by degrees by the creek, and\r\n'b'its waters must necessarily pass to the sea by some fall. If it was so,\r\n'b'the engineer thought that it might perhaps be possible to utilize this\r\n'b'fall and borrow its power, actually lost without profit to any one.\r\n'b'They continued then to follow the shores of Lake Grant by climbing the\r\n'b'plateau; but, after having gone a mile in this direction, Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'had not been able to discover the overfall, which, however, must exist\r\n'b'somewhere.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was then half-past four. In order to prepare for dinner it was\r\n'b'necessary that the settlers should return to their dwelling. The little\r\n'b'band retraced their steps, therefore, and by the left bank of the Mercy,\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions arrived at the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The fire was lighted, and Neb and Pencroft, on whom the functions of\r\n'b'cooks naturally devolved, to the one in his quality of Negro, to the\r\n'b'other in that of sailor, quickly prepared some broiled agouti, to which\r\n'b'they did great justice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The repast at length terminated; at the moment when each one was about\r\n'b'to give himself up to sleep, Cyrus Harding drew from his pocket little\r\n'b'specimens of different sorts of minerals, and just said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends, this is iron mineral, this a pyrite, this is clay, this is\r\n'b'lime, and this is coal. Nature gives us these things. It is our business\r\n'b'to make a right use of them. To-morrow we will commence operations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 13\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, captain, where are we going to begin?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft next\r\n'b'morning of the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt the beginning,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And in fact, the settlers were compelled to begin \xe2\x80\x9cat the very\r\n'b'beginning.\xe2\x80\x9d They did not possess even the tools necessary for making\r\n'b'tools, and they were not even in the condition of nature, who, \xe2\x80\x9chaving\r\n'b'time, husbands her strength.\xe2\x80\x9d They had no time, since they had to\r\n'b'provide for the immediate wants of their existence, and though,\r\n'b'profiting by acquired experience, they had nothing to invent, still they\r\n'b'had everything to make; their iron and their steel were as yet only in\r\n'b'the state of minerals, their earthenware in the state of clay, their\r\n'b'linen and their clothes in the state of textile material.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It must be said, however, that the settlers were \xe2\x80\x9cmen\xe2\x80\x9d in the complete\r\n'b'and higher sense of the word. The engineer Harding could not have been\r\n'b'seconded by more intelligent companions, nor with more devotion and\r\n'b'zeal. He had tried them. He knew their abilities.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, a talented reporter, having learned everything so as to\r\n'b'be able to speak of everything, would contribute largely with his head\r\n'b'and hands to the colonization of the island. He would not draw back from\r\n'b'any task: a determined sportsman, he would make a business of what till\r\n'b'then had only been a pleasure to him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, a gallant boy, already remarkably well informed in the natural\r\n'b'sciences, would render greater service to the common cause.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb was devotion personified. Clever, intelligent, indefatigable,\r\n'b'robust, with iron health, he knew a little about the work of the forge,\r\n'b'and could not fail to be very useful in the colony.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Pencroft, he had sailed over every sea, a carpenter in the\r\n'b'dockyards in Brooklyn, assistant tailor in the vessels of the state,\r\n'b'gardener, cultivator, during his holidays, etc., and like all seamen,\r\n'b'fit for anything, he knew how to do everything.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It would have been difficult to unite five men, better fitted to\r\n'b'struggle against fate, more certain to triumph over it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt the beginning,\xe2\x80\x9d Cyrus Harding had said. Now this beginning of which\r\n'b'the engineer spoke was the construction of an apparatus which would\r\n'b'serve to transform the natural substances. The part which heat plays in\r\n'b'these transformations is known. Now fuel, wood or coal, was ready for\r\n'b'immediate use, an oven must be built to use it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this oven for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo make the pottery which we have need of,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd of what shall we make the oven?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWith bricks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the bricks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWith clay. Let us start, my friends. To save trouble, we will establish\r\n'b'our manufactory at the place of production. Neb will bring provisions,\r\n'b'and there will be no lack of fire to cook the food.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if there is a lack of food for want of\r\n'b'instruments for the chase?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh, if we only had a knife!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell! I would soon make a bow and arrows, and then there could be\r\n'b'plenty of game in the larder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a knife, a sharp blade.\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, as if he was speaking\r\n'b'to himself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment his eyes fell upon Top, who was running about on the\r\n'b'shore. Suddenly Harding\xe2\x80\x99s face became animated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop, here,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The dog came at his master\xe2\x80\x99s call. The latter took Top\xe2\x80\x99s head between\r\n'b'his hands, and unfastening the collar which the animal wore round his\r\n'b'neck, he broke it in two, saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere are two knives, Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two hurrahs from the sailor was the reply. Top\xe2\x80\x99s collar was made of a\r\n'b'thin piece of tempered steel. They had only to sharpen it on a piece of\r\n'b'sandstone, then to raise the edge on a finer stone. Now sandstone was\r\n'b'abundant on the beach, and two hours after the stock of tools in the\r\n'b'colony consisted of two sharp blades, which were easily fixed in solid\r\n'b'handles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The production of these their first tools was hailed as a triumph. It\r\n'b'was indeed a valuable result of their labor, and a very opportune one.\r\n'b'They set out.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding proposed that they should return to the western shore of\r\n'b'the lake, where the day before he had noticed the clayey ground of which\r\n'b'he possessed a specimen. They therefore followed the bank of the Mercy,\r\n'b'traversed Prospect Heights, and after a walk of five miles or more they\r\n'b'reached a glade, situated two hundred feet from Lake Grant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the way Herbert had discovered a tree, the branches of which the\r\n'b'Indians of South America employ for making their bows. It was the\r\n'b'crejimba, of the palm family, which does not bear edible fruit. Long\r\n'b'straight branches were cut, the leaves stripped off; it was shaped,\r\n'b'stronger in the middle, more slender at the extremities, and nothing\r\n'b'remained to be done but to find a plant fit to make the bow-string.\r\n'b'This was the \xe2\x80\x9chibiscus heterophyllus,\xe2\x80\x9d which furnishes fibers of such\r\n'b'remarkable tenacity that they have been compared to the tendons of\r\n'b'animals. Pencroft thus obtained bows of tolerable strength, for which he\r\n'b'only wanted arrows. These were easily made with straight stiff branches,\r\n'b'without knots, but the points with which they must be armed, that is\r\n'b'to say, a substance to serve in lieu of iron, could not be met with so\r\n'b'easily. But Pencroft said, that having done his part of the work, chance\r\n'b'would do the rest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers arrived on the ground which had been discovered the day\r\n'b'before. Being composed of the sort of clay which is used for making\r\n'b'bricks and tiles, it was very useful for the work in question. There was\r\n'b'no great difficulty in it. It was enough to scour the clay with sand,\r\n'b'then to mold the bricks and bake them by the heat of a wood fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Generally bricks are formed in molds, but the engineer contented himself\r\n'b'with making them by hand. All that day and the day following were\r\n'b'employed in this work. The clay, soaked in water, was mixed by the feet\r\n'b'and hands of the manipulators, and then divided into pieces of equal\r\n'b'size. A practiced workman can make, without a machine, about ten\r\n'b'thousand bricks in twelve hours; but in their two days work the five\r\n'b'brickmakers on Lincoln Island had not made more than three thousand,\r\n'b'which were ranged near each other, until the time when their complete\r\n'b'desiccation would permit them to be used in building the oven, that is\r\n'b'to say, in three or four days.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was on the 2nd of April that Harding had employed himself in fixing\r\n'b'the orientation of the island, or, in other words, the precise spot\r\n'b'where the sun rose. The day before he had noted exactly the hour when\r\n'b'the sun disappeared beneath the horizon, making allowance for the\r\n'b'refraction. This morning he noted, no less exactly, the hour at which\r\n'b'it reappeared. Between this setting and rising twelve hours, twenty-four\r\n'b'minutes passed. Then, six hours, twelve minutes after its rising, the\r\n'b'sun on this day would exactly pass the meridian and the point of the sky\r\n'b'which it occupied at this moment would be the north. At the said hour,\r\n'b'Cyrus marked this point, and putting in a line with the sun two trees\r\n'b'which would serve him for marks, he thus obtained an invariable meridian\r\n'b'for his ulterior operations.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers employed the two days before the oven was built in\r\n'b'collecting fuel. Branches were cut all round the glade, and they picked\r\n'b'up all the fallen wood under the trees. They were also able to hunt with\r\n'b'greater success, since Pencroft now possessed some dozen arrows armed\r\n'b'with sharp points. It was Top who had furnished these points, by bringing\r\n'b'in a porcupine, rather inferior eating, but of great value, thanks to\r\n'b'the quills with which it bristled. These quills were fixed firmly at the\r\n'b'ends of the arrows, the flight of which was made more certain by some\r\n'b'cockatoos\xe2\x80\x99 feathers. The reporter and Herbert soon became very skilful\r\n'b'archers. Game of all sorts in consequence abounded at the Chimneys,\r\n'b'capybaras, pigeons, agouties, grouse, etc. The greater part of these\r\n'b'animals were killed in the part of the forest on the left bank of the\r\n'b'Mercy, to which they gave the name of Jacamar Wood, in remembrance of\r\n'b'the bird which Pencroft and Herbert had pursued when on their first\r\n'b'exploration.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This game was eaten fresh, but they preserved some capybara hams, by\r\n'b'smoking them above a fire of green wood, after having perfumed them with\r\n'b'sweet-smelling leaves. However, this food, although very strengthening,\r\n'b'was always roast upon roast, and the party would have been delighted\r\n'b'to hear some soup bubbling on the hearth, but they must wait till a pot\r\n'b'could be made, and, consequently, till the oven was built.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During these excursions, which were not extended far from the\r\n'b'brick-field, the hunters could discern the recent passage of animals of\r\n'b'a large size, armed with powerful claws, but they could not recognize\r\n'b'the species. Cyrus Harding advised them to be very careful, as the\r\n'b'forest probably enclosed many dangerous beasts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And he did right. Indeed, Gideon Spilett and Herbert one day saw an\r\n'b'animal which resembled a jaguar. Happily the creature did not attack\r\n'b'them, or they might not have escaped without a severe wound. As soon\r\n'b'as he could get a regular weapon, that is to say, one of the guns which\r\n'b'Pencroft begged for, Gideon Spilett resolved to make desperate war\r\n'b'against the ferocious beasts, and exterminate them from the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The Chimneys during these few days was not made more comfortable, for\r\n'b'the engineer hoped to discover, or build if necessary, a more convenient\r\n'b'dwelling. They contented themselves with spreading moss and dry leaves\r\n'b'on the sand of the passages, and on these primitive couches the tired\r\n'b'workers slept soundly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They also reckoned the days they had passed on Lincoln Island, and from\r\n'b'that time kept a regular account. The 5th of April, which was Wednesday,\r\n'b'was twelve days from the time when the wind threw the castaways on this\r\n'b'shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 6th of April, at daybreak, the engineer and his companions were\r\n'b'collected in the glade, at the place where they were going to perform\r\n'b'the operation of baking the bricks. Naturally this had to be in the open\r\n'b'air, and not in a kiln, or rather, the agglomeration of bricks made an\r\n'b'enormous kiln, which would bake itself. The fuel, made of well-prepared\r\n'b'fagots, was laid on the ground and surrounded with several rows of dried\r\n'b'bricks, which soon formed an enormous cube, to the exterior of which\r\n'b'they contrived air-holes. The work lasted all day, and it was not till\r\n'b'the evening that they set fire to the fagots. No one slept that night,\r\n'b'all watching carefully to keep up the fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The operation lasted forty-eight hours, and succeeded perfectly. It then\r\n'b'became necessary to leave the smoking mass to cool, and during this time\r\n'b'Neb and Pencroft, guided by Cyrus Harding, brought, on a hurdle made of\r\n'b'interlaced branches, loads of carbonate of lime and common stones,\r\n'b'which were very abundant, to the north of the lake. These stones, when\r\n'b'decomposed by heat, made a very strong quicklime, greatly increased by\r\n'b'slacking, at least as pure as if it had been produced by the calcination\r\n'b'of chalk or marble. Mixed with sand the lime made excellent mortar.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The result of these different works was, that, on the 9th of April,\r\n'b'the engineer had at his disposal a quantity of prepared lime and some\r\n'b'thousands of bricks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Without losing an instant, therefore, they began the construction of\r\n'b'a kiln to bake the pottery, which was indispensable for their domestic\r\n'b'use. They succeeded without much difficulty. Five days after, the kiln\r\n'b'was supplied with coal, which the engineer had discovered lying open to\r\n'b'the sky towards the mouth of the Red Creek, and the first smoke escaped\r\n'b'from a chimney twenty feet high. The glade was transformed into a\r\n'b'manufactory, and Pencroft was not far wrong in believing that from this\r\n'b'kiln would issue all the products of modern industry.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meantime what the settlers first manufactured was a common\r\n'b'pottery in which to cook their food. The chief material was clay, to\r\n'b'which Harding added a little lime and quartz. This paste made regular\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cpipe-clay,\xe2\x80\x9d with which they manufactured bowls, cups molded on stones\r\n'b'of a proper size, great jars and pots to hold water, etc. The shape of\r\n'b'these objects was clumsy and defective, but after they had been baked\r\n'b'in a high temperature, the kitchen of the Chimneys was provided with a\r\n'b'number of utensils, as precious to the settlers as the most beautifully\r\n'b'enameled china. We must mention here that Pencroft, desirous to know if\r\n'b'the clay thus prepared was worthy of its name of pipe-clay, made some\r\n'b'large pipes, which he thought charming, but for which, alas! he had no\r\n'b'tobacco, and that was a great privation to Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cBut tobacco\r\n'b'will come, like everything else!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, in a burst of absolute\r\n'b'confidence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This work lasted till the 15th of April, and the time was well employed.\r\n'b'The settlers, having become potters, made nothing but pottery. When\r\n'b'it suited Cyrus Harding to change them into smiths, they would become\r\n'b'smiths. But the next day being Sunday, and also Easter Sunday, all\r\n'b'agreed to sanctify the day by rest. These Americans were religious men,\r\n'b'scrupulous observers of the precepts of the Bible, and their situation\r\n'b'could not but develop sentiments of confidence towards the Author of all\r\n'b'things.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the evening of the 15th of April they returned to the Chimneys,\r\n'b'carrying with them the pottery, the furnace being extinguished until\r\n'b'they could put it to a new use. Their return was marked by a fortunate\r\n'b'incident; the engineer discovered a substance which replaced tinder.\r\n'b'It is known that a spongy, velvety flesh is procured from a certain\r\n'b'mushroom of the genus polyporous. Properly prepared, it is extremely\r\n'b'inflammable, especially when it has been previously saturated with\r\n'b'gunpowder, or boiled in a solution of nitrate or chlorate of potash.\r\n'b'But, till then, they had not found any of these polypores or even any of\r\n'b'the morels which could replace them. On this day, the engineer, seeing\r\n'b'a plant belonging to the wormwood genus, the principal species of which\r\n'b'are absinthe, balm-mint, tarragon, etc., gathered several tufts, and,\r\n'b'presenting them to the sailor, said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Pencroft, this will please you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft looked attentively at the plant, covered with long silky hair,\r\n'b'the leaves being clothed with soft down.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it tobacco?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cit is wormwood; Chinese wormwood to the learned,\r\n'b'but to us it will be tinder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When the wormwood was properly dried it provided them with a very\r\n'b'inflammable substance, especially afterwards when the engineer had\r\n'b'impregnated it with nitrate of potash, of which the island possessed\r\n'b'several beds, and which is in truth saltpeter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists had a good supper that evening. Neb prepared some agouti\r\n'b'soup, a smoked capybara ham, to which was added the boiled tubercules of\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9ccaladium macrorhizum,\xe2\x80\x9d an herbaceous plant of the arum family.\r\n'b'They had an excellent taste, and were very nutritious, being something\r\n'b'similar to the substance which is sold in England under the name of\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPortland sago\xe2\x80\x9d; they were also a good substitute for bread, which the\r\n'b'settlers in Lincoln Island did not yet possess.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When supper was finished, before sleeping, Harding and his companions\r\n'b'went to take the air on the beach. It was eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening;\r\n'b'the night was magnificent. The moon, which had been full five days\r\n'b'before, had not yet risen, but the horizon was already silvered by those\r\n'b'soft, pale shades which might be called the dawn of the moon. At the\r\n'b'southern zenith glittered the circumpolar constellations, and above all\r\n'b'the Southern Cross, which some days before the engineer had greeted on\r\n'b'the summit of Mount Franklin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding gazed for some time at this splendid constellation, which\r\n'b'has at its summit and at its base two stars of the first magnitude, at\r\n'b'its left arm a star of the second, and at its right arm a star of the\r\n'b'third magnitude.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, after some minutes thought--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHerbert,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of the lad, \xe2\x80\x9cis not this the 15th of April?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if I am not mistaken, to-morrow will be one of the four days in\r\n'b'the year in which the real time is identical with average time; that\r\n'b'is to say, my boy, that to-morrow, to within some seconds, the sun will\r\n'b'pass the meridian just at midday by the clocks. If the weather is fine\r\n'b'I think that I shall obtain the longitude of the island with an\r\n'b'approximation of some degrees.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWithout instruments, without sextant?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cAlso, since the night is clear, I will\r\n'b'try, this very evening, to obtain our latitude by calculating the\r\n'b'height of the Southern Cross, that is, from the southern pole above the\r\n'b'horizon. You understand, my friends, that before undertaking the work\r\n'b'of installation in earnest it is not enough to have found out that this\r\n'b'land is an island; we must, as nearly as possible, know at what distance\r\n'b'it is situated, either from the American continent or Australia, or from\r\n'b'the principal archipelagoes of the Pacific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cinstead of building a house it would\r\n'b'be more important to build a boat, if by chance we are not more than a\r\n'b'hundred miles from an inhabited coast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is why,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cI am going to try this evening to\r\n'b'calculate the latitude of Lincoln Island, and to-morrow, at midday, I\r\n'b'will try to calculate the longitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'If the engineer had possessed a sextant, an apparatus with which the\r\n'b'angular distance of objects can be measured with great precision, there\r\n'b'would have been no difficulty in the operation. This evening by the\r\n'b'height of the pole, the next day by the passing of the sun at the\r\n'b'meridian, he would obtain the position of the island. But as they had\r\n'b'not one he would have to supply the deficiency.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding then entered the Chimneys. By the light of the fire he cut two\r\n'b'little flat rulers, which he joined together at one end so as to form\r\n'b'a pair of compasses, whose legs could separate or come together. The\r\n'b'fastening was fixed with a strong acacia thorn which was found in the\r\n'b'wood pile. This instrument finished, the engineer returned to the beach,\r\n'b'but as it was necessary to take the height of the pole from above a\r\n'b'clear horizon, that is, a sea horizon, and as Claw Cape hid the southern\r\n'b'horizon, he was obliged to look for a more suitable station. The best\r\n'b'would evidently have been the shore exposed directly to the south; but\r\n'b'the Mercy would have to be crossed, and that was a difficulty. Harding\r\n'b'resolved, in consequence, to make his observation from Prospect Heights,\r\n'b'taking into consideration its height above the level of the sea--a\r\n'b'height which he intended to calculate next day by a simple process of\r\n'b'elementary geometry.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers, therefore, went to the plateau, ascending the left bank of\r\n'b'the Mercy, and placed themselves on the edge which looked northwest and\r\n'b'southeast, that is, above the curiously-shaped rocks which bordered the\r\n'b'river.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This part of the plateau commanded the heights of the left bank, which\r\n'b'sloped away to the extremity of Claw Cape, and to the southern side of\r\n'b'the island. No obstacle intercepted their gaze, which swept the horizon\r\n'b'in a semi-circle from the cape to Reptile End. To the south the horizon,\r\n'b'lighted by the first rays of the moon, was very clearly defined against\r\n'b'the sky.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment the Southern Cross presented itself to the observer in an\r\n'b'inverted position, the star Alpha marking its base, which is nearer to\r\n'b'the southern pole.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This constellation is not situated as near to the antarctic pole as the\r\n'b'Polar Star is to the arctic pole. The star Alpha is about twenty-seven\r\n'b'degrees from it, but Cyrus Harding knew this and made allowance for\r\n'b'it in his calculation. He took care also to observe the moment when it\r\n'b'passed the meridian below the pole, which would simplify the operation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding pointed one leg of the compasses to the horizon, the\r\n'b'other to Alpha, and the space between the two legs gave him the angular\r\n'b'distance which separated Alpha from the horizon. In order to fix the\r\n'b'angle obtained, he fastened with thorns the two pieces of wood on a\r\n'b'third placed transversely, so that their separation should be properly\r\n'b'maintained.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That done, there was only the angle to calculate by bringing back the\r\n'b'observation to the level of the sea, taking into consideration the\r\n'b'depression of the horizon, which would necessitate measuring the height\r\n'b'of the cliff. The value of this angle would give the height of Alpha,\r\n'b'and consequently that of the pole above the horizon, that is to say, the\r\n'b'latitude of the island, since the latitude of a point of the globe is\r\n'b'always equal to the height of the pole above the horizon of this point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The calculations were left for the next day, and at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock every\r\n'b'one was sleeping soundly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 14\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 16th of April, and Easter Sunday, the settlers issued\r\n'b'from the Chimneys at daybreak, and proceeded to wash their linen. The\r\n'b'engineer intended to manufacture soap as soon as he could procure the\r\n'b'necessary materials--soda or potash, fat or oil. The important question\r\n'b'of renewing their wardrobe would be treated of in the proper time and\r\n'b'place. At any rate their clothes would last at least six months longer,\r\n'b'for they were strong, and could resist the wear of manual labor. But\r\n'b'all would depend on the situation of the island with regard to inhabited\r\n'b'land. This would be settled to-day if the weather permitted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sun rising above a clear horizon, announced a magnificent day, one\r\n'b'of those beautiful autumn days which are like the last farewells of the\r\n'b'warm season.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now necessary to complete the observations of the evening before\r\n'b'by measuring the height of the cliff above the level of the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShall you not need an instrument similar to the one which you used\r\n'b'yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert to the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the latter, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are going to proceed differently,\r\n'b'but in as precise a way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, wishing to learn everything he could, followed the engineer to\r\n'b'the beach. Pencroft, Neb, and the reporter remained behind and occupied\r\n'b'themselves in different ways.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had provided himself with a straight stick, twelve feet\r\n'b'long, which he had measured as exactly as possible by comparing it with\r\n'b'his own height, which he knew to a hair. Herbert carried a plumb-line\r\n'b'which Harding had given him, that is to say, a simple stone fastened\r\n'b'to the end of a flexible fiber. Having reached a spot about twenty feet\r\n'b'from the edge of the beach, and nearly five hundred feet from the cliff,\r\n'b'which rose perpendicularly, Harding thrust the pole two feet into\r\n'b'the sand, and wedging it up carefully, he managed, by means of the\r\n'b'plumb-line, to erect it perpendicularly with the plane of the horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That done, he retired the necessary distance, when, lying on the sand,\r\n'b'his eye glanced at the same time at the top of the pole and the crest of\r\n'b'the cliff. He carefully marked the place with a little stick.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then addressing Herbert--\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know the first principles of geometry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' he asked.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSlightly, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, who did not wish to put himself\r\n'b'forward.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou remember what are the properties of two similar triangles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9ctheir homologous sides are proportional.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy, I have just constructed two similar right-angled\r\n'b'triangles; the first, the smallest, has for its sides the perpendicular\r\n'b'pole, the distance which separates the little stick from the foot of the\r\n'b'pole and my visual ray for hypothenuse; the second has for its sides\r\n'b'the perpendicular cliff, the height of which we wish to measure, the\r\n'b'distance which separates the little stick from the bottom of the\r\n'b'cliff, and my visual ray also forms its hypothenuse, which proves to be\r\n'b'prolongation of that of the first triangle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh, captain, I understand!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cAs the distance from the\r\n'b'stick to the pole is to the distance from the stick to the base of the\r\n'b'cliff, so is the height of the pole to the height of the cliff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJust so, Herbert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cand when we have measured the\r\n'b'two first distances, knowing the height of the pole, we shall only have\r\n'b'a sum in proportion to do, which will give us the height of the cliff,\r\n'b'and will save us the trouble of measuring it directly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The two horizontal distances were found out by means of the pole, whose\r\n'b'length above the sand was exactly ten feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first distance was fifteen feet between the stick and the place\r\n'b'where the pole was thrust into the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The second distance between the stick and the bottom of the cliff was\r\n'b'five hundred feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These measurements finished, Cyrus Harding and the lad returned to the\r\n'b'Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer then took a flat stone which he had brought back from one\r\n'b'of his previous excursions, a sort of slate, on which it was easy\r\n'b'to trace figures with a sharp shell. He then proved the following\r\n'b'proportions:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'          15:500::10:x\r\n'b'\r\n'b'         500 x 10 = 5000\r\n'b'\r\n'b'        5000 / 15 = 333.3\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From which it was proved that the granite cliff measured 333 feet in\r\n'b'height.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding then took the instrument which he had made the evening\r\n'b'before, the space between its two legs giving the angular distance\r\n'b'between the star Alpha and the horizon. He measured, very exactly, the\r\n'b'opening of this angle on a circumference which he divided into 360 equal\r\n'b'parts. Now, this angle by adding to it the twenty-seven degrees which\r\n'b'separated Alpha from the antarctic pole, and by reducing to the level of\r\n'b'the sea the height of the cliff on which the observation had been made,\r\n'b'was found to be fifty-three degrees. These fifty-three degrees being\r\n'b'subtracted from ninety degrees--the distance from the pole to the\r\n'b'equator--there remained thirty-seven degrees. Cyrus Harding concluded,\r\n'b'therefore, that Lincoln Island was situated on the thirty-seventh degree\r\n'b'of the southern latitude, or taking into consideration through the\r\n'b'imperfection of the performance, an error of five degrees, that it must\r\n'b'be situated between the thirty-fifth and the fortieth parallel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was only the longitude to be obtained, and the position of the\r\n'b'island would be determined, The engineer hoped to attempt this the same\r\n'b'day, at twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, at which moment the sun would pass the meridian.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was decided that Sunday should be spent in a walk, or rather an\r\n'b'exploring expedition, to that side of the island between the north of\r\n'b'the lake and Shark Gulf, and if there was time they would push their\r\n'b'discoveries to the northern side of Cape South Mandible. They would\r\n'b'breakfast on the downs, and not return till evening.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At half-past eight the little band was following the edge of the\r\n'b'channel. On the other side, on Safety Islet, numerous birds were gravely\r\n'b'strutting. They were divers, easily recognized by their cry, which much\r\n'b'resembles the braying of a donkey. Pencroft only considered them in\r\n'b'an eatable point of view, and learnt with some satisfaction that their\r\n'b'flesh, though blackish, is not bad food.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Great amphibious creatures could also be seen crawling on the sand;\r\n'b'seals, doubtless, who appeared to have chosen the islet for a place of\r\n'b'refuge. It was impossible to think of those animals in an alimentary\r\n'b'point of view, for their oily flesh is detestable; however, Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding observed them attentively, and without making known his idea, he\r\n'b'announced to his companions that very soon they would pay a visit to the\r\n'b'islet. The beach was strewn with innumerable shells, some of which would\r\n'b'have rejoiced the heart of a conchologist; there were, among others, the\r\n'b'phasianella, the terebratual, etc. But what would be of more use, was\r\n'b'the discovery, by Neb, at low tide, of a large oysterbed among the\r\n'b'rocks, nearly five miles from the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNeb will not have lost his day,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, looking at the\r\n'b'spacious oyster-bed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is really a fortunate discovery,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand as it is\r\n'b'said that each oyster produces yearly from fifty to sixty thousand eggs,\r\n'b'we shall have an inexhaustible supply there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOnly I believe that the oyster is not very nourishing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cThe oyster contains very little nitrogen, and\r\n'b'if a man lived exclusively on them, he would have to eat not less than\r\n'b'fifteen to sixteen dozen a day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCapital!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cWe might swallow dozens and dozens without\r\n'b'exhausting the bed. Shall we take some for breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And without waiting for a reply to this proposal, knowing that it would\r\n'b'be approved of, the sailor and Neb detached a quantity of the molluscs.\r\n'b'They put them in a sort of net of hibiscus fiber, which Neb had\r\n'b'manufactured, and which already contained food; they then continued to\r\n'b'climb the coast between the downs and the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From time to time Harding consulted his watch, so as to be prepared in\r\n'b'time for the solar observation, which had to be made exactly at midday.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All that part of the island was very barren as far as the point\r\n'b'which closed Union Bay, and which had received the name of Cape South\r\n'b'Mandible. Nothing could be seen there but sand and shells, mingled with\r\n'b'debris of lava. A few sea-birds frequented this desolate coast, gulls,\r\n'b'great albatrosses, as well as wild duck, for which Pencroft had a great\r\n'b'fancy. He tried to knock some over with an arrow, but without result,\r\n'b'for they seldom perched, and he could not hit them on the wing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This led the sailor to repeat to the engineer,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, captain, so long as we have not one or two fowling-pieces, we\r\n'b'shall never get anything!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it depends on you.\r\n'b'Procure us some iron for the barrels, steel for the hammers, saltpeter.\r\n'b'coal and sulphur for powder, mercury and nitric acid for the fulminate,\r\n'b'and lead for the shot, and the captain will make us first-rate guns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe might, no doubt, find all these\r\n'b'substances on the island, but a gun is a delicate instrument, and needs\r\n'b'very particular tools. However, we shall see later!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwere we obliged to throw overboard all the\r\n'b'weapons we had with us in the car, all our implements, even our\r\n'b'pocket-knives?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut if we had not thrown them away, Pencroft, the balloon would have\r\n'b'thrown us to the bottom of the sea!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you say is true, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then passing to another idea,--\xe2\x80\x9cThink,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9chow astounded Jonathan\r\n'b'Forster and his companions must have been when, next morning, they found\r\n'b'the place empty, and the machine flown away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am utterly indifferent about knowing what they may have thought,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was all my idea, that!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, with a satisfied air.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA splendid idea, Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\n'b'which has placed us where we are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather be here than in the hands of the Southerners,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\n'b'sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cespecially since the captain has been kind enough to come and\r\n'b'join us again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo would I, truly!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, what do we want?\r\n'b'Nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf that is not--everything!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, laughing and shrugging\r\n'b'his shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, some day or other, we shall find means of going\r\n'b'away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSooner, perhaps, than you imagine, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the engineer,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cif Lincoln Island is but a medium distance from an inhabited island,\r\n'b'or from a continent. We shall know in an hour. I have not a map of the\r\n'b'Pacific, but my memory has preserved a very clear recollection of\r\n'b'its southern part. The latitude which I obtained yesterday placed New\r\n'b'Zealand to the west of Lincoln Island, and the coast of Chile to the\r\n'b'east. But between these two countries, there is a distance of at least\r\n'b'six thousand miles. It has, therefore, to be determined what point in\r\n'b'this great space the island occupies, and this the longitude will give\r\n'b'us presently, with a sufficient approximation, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs not the archipelago of the Pomoutous the nearest point to us in\r\n'b'latitude?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the distance which separates us from\r\n'b'it is more than twelve hundred miles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that way?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb, who followed the conversation with extreme\r\n'b'interest, pointing to the south.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat way, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d added the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cif Lincoln Island is not more than\r\n'b'two or three thousand miles from New Zealand or Chile?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cinstead of building a house we will build\r\n'b'a boat, and Master Pencroft shall be put in command--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell then,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI am quite ready to be captain--as soon\r\n'b'as you can make a craft that\xe2\x80\x99s able to keep at sea!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall do it, if it is necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But while these men, who really hesitated at nothing, were talking,\r\n'b'the hour approached at which the observation was to be made. What Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding was to do to ascertain the passage of the sun at the meridian of\r\n'b'the island, without an instrument of any sort, Herbert could not guess.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The observers were then about six miles from the Chimneys, not far from\r\n'b'that part of the downs in which the engineer had been found after his\r\n'b'enigmatical preservation. They halted at this place and prepared for\r\n'b'breakfast, for it was half-past eleven. Herbert went for some fresh\r\n'b'water from a stream which ran near, and brought it back in a jug, which\r\n'b'Neb had provided.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During these preparations Harding arranged everything for his\r\n'b'astronomical observation. He chose a clear place on the shore, which\r\n'b'the ebbing tide had left perfectly level. This bed of fine sand was as\r\n'b'smooth as ice, not a grain out of place. It was of little importance\r\n'b'whether it was horizontal or not, and it did not matter much whether the\r\n'b'stick six feet high, which was planted there, rose perpendicularly. On\r\n'b'the contrary, the engineer inclined it towards the south, that is to\r\n'b'say, in the direction of the coast opposite to the sun, for it must\r\n'b'not be forgotten that the settlers in Lincoln Island, as the island was\r\n'b'situated in the Southern Hemisphere, saw the radiant planet describe its\r\n'b'diurnal arc above the northern, and not above the southern horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert now understood how the engineer was going to proceed to\r\n'b'ascertain the culmination of the sun, that is to say its passing the\r\n'b'meridian of the island or, in other words, determine due south. It was\r\n'b'by means of the shadow cast on the sand by the stick, a way which, for\r\n'b'want of an instrument, would give him a suitable approach to the result\r\n'b'which he wished to obtain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the moment when this shadow would reach its minimum of length\r\n'b'would be exactly twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and it would be enough to watch the\r\n'b'extremity of the shadow, so as to ascertain the instant when, after\r\n'b'having successively diminished, it began to lengthen. By inclining his\r\n'b'stick to the side opposite to the sun, Cyrus Harding made the shadow\r\n'b'longer, and consequently its modifications would be more easily\r\n'b'ascertained. In fact, the longer the needle of a dial is, the more\r\n'b'easily can the movement of its point be followed. The shadow of the\r\n'b'stick was nothing but the needle of a dial. The moment had come, and\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding knelt on the sand, and with little wooden pegs, which he\r\n'b'stuck into the sand, he began to mark the successive diminutions of the\r\n'b'stick\xe2\x80\x99s shadow. His companions, bending over him, watched the operation\r\n'b'with extreme interest. The reporter held his chronometer in his hand,\r\n'b'ready to tell the hour which it marked when the shadow would be at its\r\n'b'shortest. Moreover, as Cyrus Harding was working on the 16th of April,\r\n'b'the day on which the true and the average time are identical, the hour\r\n'b'given by Gideon Spilett would be the true hour then at Washington, which\r\n'b'would simplify the calculation. Meanwhile as the sun slowly advanced,\r\n'b'the shadow slowly diminished, and when it appeared to Cyrus Harding that\r\n'b'it was beginning to increase, he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat o\xe2\x80\x99clock is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne minute past five,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett directly. They had now\r\n'b'only to calculate the operation. Nothing could be easier. It could be\r\n'b'seen that there existed, in round numbers, a difference of five hours\r\n'b'between the meridian of Washington and that of Lincoln Island, that is\r\n'b'to say, it was midday in Lincoln Island when it was already five o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\n'b'in the evening in Washington. Now the sun, in its apparent movement\r\n'b'round the earth, traverses one degree in four minutes, or fifteen\r\n'b'degrees an hour. Fifteen degrees multiplied by five hours give\r\n'b'seventy-five degrees.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, since Washington is 77deg 3\xe2\x80\x99 11\xe2\x80\x9d as much as to say seventy-seven\r\n'b'degrees counted from the meridian of Greenwich which the Americans\r\n'b'take for their starting-point for longitudes concurrently with the\r\n'b'English--it followed that the island must be situated seventy-seven and\r\n'b'seventy-five degrees west of the meridian of Greenwich, that is to say,\r\n'b'on the hundred and fifty-second degree of west longitude.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding announced this result to his companions, and taking into\r\n'b'consideration errors of observation, as he had done for the latitude, he\r\n'b'believed he could positively affirm that the position of Lincoln Island\r\n'b'was between the thirty-fifth and the thirty-seventh parallel, and\r\n'b'between the hundred and fiftieth and the hundred and fifty-fifth\r\n'b'meridian to the west of the meridian of Greenwich.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The possible fault which he attributed to errors in the observation was,\r\n'b'it may be seen, of five degrees on both sides, which, at sixty miles\r\n'b'to a degree, would give an error of three hundred miles in latitude and\r\n'b'longitude for the exact position.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But this error would not influence the determination which it was\r\n'b'necessary to take. It was very evident that Lincoln Island was at such a\r\n'b'distance from every country or island that it would be too hazardous to\r\n'b'attempt to reach one in a frail boat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, this calculation placed it at least twelve hundred miles from\r\n'b'Tahiti and the islands of the archipelago of the Pomoutous, more than\r\n'b'eighteen hundred miles from New Zealand, and more than four thousand\r\n'b'five hundred miles from the American coast!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And when Cyrus Harding consulted his memory, he could not remember in\r\n'b'any way that such an island occupied, in that part of the Pacific, the\r\n'b'situation assigned to Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 15\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 17th of April, the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s first words were addressed\r\n'b'to Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat shall we do to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the captain pleases,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Till then the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s companions had been brickmakers and potters,\r\n'b'now they were to become metallurgists.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The day before, after breakfast, they had explored as far as the point\r\n'b'of Mandible Cape, seven miles distant from the Chimneys. There, the long\r\n'b'series of downs ended, and the soil had a volcanic appearance. There\r\n'b'were no longer high cliffs as at Prospect Heights, but a strange and\r\n'b'capricious border which surrounded the narrow gulf between the two\r\n'b'capes, formed of mineral matter, thrown up by the volcano. Arrived at\r\n'b'this point the settlers retraced their steps, and at nightfall entered\r\n'b'the Chimneys; but they did not sleep before the question of knowing\r\n'b'whether they could think of leaving Lincoln Island or not was definitely\r\n'b'settled.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The twelve hundred miles which separated the island from the Pomoutous\r\n'b'Island was a considerable distance. A boat could not cross it,\r\n'b'especially at the approach of the bad season. Pencroft had expressly\r\n'b'declared this. Now, to construct a simple boat even with the necessary\r\n'b'tools, was a difficult work, and the colonists not having tools they\r\n'b'must begin by making hammers, axes, adzes, saws, augers, planes, etc.,\r\n'b'which would take some time. It was decided, therefore, that they\r\n'b'would winter at Lincoln Island, and that they would look for a more\r\n'b'comfortable dwelling than the Chimneys, in which to pass the winter\r\n'b'months.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Before anything else could be done it was necessary to make the iron\r\n'b'ore, of which the engineer had observed some traces in the northwest\r\n'b'part of the island, fit for use by converting it either into iron or\r\n'b'into steel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Metals are not generally found in the ground in a pure state. For the\r\n'b'most part they are combined with oxygen or sulphur. Such was the case\r\n'b'with the two specimens which Cyrus Harding had brought back, one of\r\n'b'magnetic iron, not carbonated, the other a pyrite, also called sulphuret\r\n'b'of iron. It was, therefore the first, the oxide of iron, which they must\r\n'b'reduce with coal, that is to say, get rid of the oxygen, to obtain it in\r\n'b'a pure state. This reduction is made by subjecting the ore with coal to\r\n'b'a high temperature, either by the rapid and easy Catalan method,\r\n'b'which has the advantage of transforming the ore into iron in a single\r\n'b'operation, or by the blast furnace, which first smelts the ore, then\r\n'b'changes it into iron, by carrying away the three to four per cent. of\r\n'b'coal, which is combined with it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now Cyrus Harding wanted iron, and he wished to obtain it as soon as\r\n'b'possible. The ore which he had picked up was in itself very pure and\r\n'b'rich. It was the oxydulous iron, which is found in confused masses of a\r\n'b'deep gray color; it gives a black dust, crystallized in the form of the\r\n'b'regular octahedron. Native lodestones consist of this ore, and iron\r\n'b'of the first quality is made in Europe from that with which Sweden and\r\n'b'Norway are so abundantly supplied. Not far from this vein was the vein\r\n'b'of coal already made use of by the settlers. The ingredients for the\r\n'b'manufacture being close together would greatly facilitate the treatment\r\n'b'of the ore. This is the cause of the wealth of the mines in Great\r\n'b'Britain, where the coal aids the manufacture of the metal extracted from\r\n'b'the same soil at the same time as itself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are going to work iron ore?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand for that--something which\r\n'b'will please you--we must begin by having a seal hunt on the islet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA seal hunt!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor, turning towards Gideon Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cAre\r\n'b'seals needed to make iron?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSince Cyrus has said so!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the engineer had already left the Chimneys, and Pencroft prepared\r\n'b'for the seal hunt, without having received any other explanation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, Herbert, Gideon Spilett, Neb, and the sailor were\r\n'b'soon collected on the shore, at a place where the channel left a ford\r\n'b'passable at low tide. The hunters could therefore traverse it without\r\n'b'getting wet higher than the knee.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding then put his foot on the islet for the first, and his companions\r\n'b'for the second time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On their landing some hundreds of penguins looked fearlessly at them.\r\n'b'The hunters, armed with sticks, could have killed them easily, but they\r\n'b'were not guilty of such useless massacre, as it was important not to\r\n'b'frighten the seals, who were lying on the sand several cable lengths\r\n'b'off. They also respected certain innocent-looking birds, whose wings\r\n'b'were reduced to the state of stumps, spread out like fins, ornamented\r\n'b'with feathers of a scaly appearance. The settlers, therefore, prudently\r\n'b'advanced towards the north point, walking over ground riddled with\r\n'b'little holes, which formed nests for the sea-birds. Towards the\r\n'b'extremity of the islet appeared great black heads floating just above\r\n'b'the water, having exactly the appearance of rocks in motion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These were the seals which were to be captured. It was necessary,\r\n'b'however, first to allow them to land, for with their close, short\r\n'b'hair, and their fusiform conformation, being excellent swimmers, it is\r\n'b'difficult to catch them in the sea, while on land their short, webbed\r\n'b'feet prevent their having more than a slow, waddling movement.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft knew the habits of these creatures, and he advised waiting till\r\n'b'they were stretched on the sand, when the sun, before long, would send\r\n'b'them to sleep. They must then manage to cut off their retreat and knock\r\n'b'them on the head.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The hunters, having concealed themselves behind the rocks, waited\r\n'b'silently.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An hour passed before the seals came to play on the sand. They could\r\n'b'count half a dozen. Pencroft and Herbert then went round the point of\r\n'b'the islet, so as to take them in the rear, and cut off their retreat.\r\n'b'During this time Cyrus Harding, Spilett, and Neb, crawling behind the\r\n'b'rocks, glided towards the future scene of combat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All at once the tall figure of the sailor appeared. Pencroft shouted.\r\n'b'The engineer and his two companions threw themselves between the sea and\r\n'b'the seals. Two of the animals soon lay dead on the sand, but the rest\r\n'b'regained the sea in safety.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere are the seals required, captain!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, advancing\r\n'b'towards the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCapital,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will make bellows of them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBellows!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cWell! these are lucky seals!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was, in fact, a blowing-machine, necessary for the treatment of\r\n'b'the ore that the engineer wished to manufacture with the skins of the\r\n'b'amphibious creatures. They were of a medium size, for their length did\r\n'b'not exceed six feet. They resembled a dog about the head.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As it was useless to burden themselves with the weight of both the\r\n'b'animals, Neb and Pencroft resolved to skin them on the spot, while Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding and the reporter continued to explore the islet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor and the Negro cleverly performed the operation, and three\r\n'b'hours afterwards Cyrus Harding had at his disposal two seals\xe2\x80\x99 skins,\r\n'b'which he intended to use in this state, without subjecting them to any\r\n'b'tanning process.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers waited till the tide was again low, and crossing the\r\n'b'channel they entered the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The skins had then to be stretched on a frame of wood and sewn by means\r\n'b'of fibers so as to preserve the air without allowing too much to escape.\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had nothing but the two steel blades from Top\xe2\x80\x99s collar,\r\n'b'and yet he was so clever, and his companions aided him with so much\r\n'b'intelligence, that three days afterwards the little colony\xe2\x80\x99s stock of\r\n'b'tools was augmented by a blowing-machine, destined to inject the air\r\n'b'into the midst of the ore when it should be subjected to heat--an\r\n'b'indispensable condition to the success of the operation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the morning of the 20th of April began the \xe2\x80\x9cmetallic period,\xe2\x80\x9d as the\r\n'b'reporter called it in his notes. The engineer had decided, as has been\r\n'b'said, to operate near the veins both of coal and ore. Now, according to\r\n'b'his observations, these veins were situated at the foot of the northeast\r\n'b'spurs of Mount Franklin, that is to say, a distance of six miles from\r\n'b'their home. It was impossible, therefore, to return every day to the\r\n'b'Chimneys, and it was agreed that the little colony should camp under a\r\n'b'hut of branches, so that the important operation could be followed night\r\n'b'and day.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This settled, they set out in the morning. Neb and Pencroft dragged the\r\n'b'bellows on a hurdle; also a quantity of vegetables and animals, which\r\n'b'they besides could renew on the way.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The road led through Jacamar Wood, which they traversed obliquely from\r\n'b'southeast to northwest, and in the thickest part. It was necessary to\r\n'b'beat a path, which would in the future form the most direct road to\r\n'b'Prospect Heights and Mount Franklin. The trees, belonging to the species\r\n'b'already discovered, were magnificent. Herbert found some new ones, among\r\n'b'others some which Pencroft called \xe2\x80\x9csham leeks\xe2\x80\x9d; for, in spite of their\r\n'b'size, they were of the same liliaceous family as the onion, chive,\r\n'b'shallot, or asparagus. These trees produce ligneous roots which, when\r\n'b'cooked, are excellent; from them, by fermentation, a very agreeable\r\n'b'liquor is made. They therefore made a good store of the roots.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The journey through the wood was long; it lasted the whole day, and so\r\n'b'allowed plenty of time for examining the flora and fauna. Top, who\r\n'b'took special charge of the fauna, ran through the grass and brushwood,\r\n'b'putting up all sorts of game. Herbert and Gideon Spilett killed two\r\n'b'kangaroos with bows and arrows, and also an animal which strongly\r\n'b'resembled both a hedgehog and an ant-eater. It was like the first\r\n'b'because it rolled itself into a ball, and bristled with spines, and the\r\n'b'second because it had sharp claws, a long slender snout which terminated\r\n'b'in a bird\xe2\x80\x99s beak, and an extendible tongue, covered with little thorns\r\n'b'which served to hold the insects.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when it is in the pot,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft naturally, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat will it be\r\n'b'like?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAn excellent piece of beef,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will not ask more from it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this excursion they saw several wild boars, which however, did\r\n'b'not offer to attack the little band, and it appeared as if they would\r\n'b'not meet with any dangerous beasts; when, in a thick part of the wood,\r\n'b'the reporter thought he saw, some paces from him, among the lower\r\n'b'branches of a tree, an animal which he took for a bear, and which he\r\n'b'very tranquilly began to draw. Happily for Gideon Spilett, the animal in\r\n'b'question did not belong to the redoubtable family of the plantigrades.\r\n'b'It was only a koala, better known under the name of the sloth, being\r\n'b'about the size of a large dog, and having stiff hair of a dirty color,\r\n'b'the paws armed with strong claws, which enabled it to climb trees and\r\n'b'feed on the leaves. Having identified the animal, which they did not\r\n'b'disturb, Gideon Spilett erased \xe2\x80\x9cbear\xe2\x80\x9d from the title of his sketch,\r\n'b'putting koala in its place, and the journey was resumed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, Cyrus Harding gave the signal to halt.\r\n'b'They were now outside the forest, at the beginning of the powerful spurs\r\n'b'which supported Mount Franklin towards the west. At a distance of some\r\n'b'hundred feet flowed the Red Creek, and consequently plenty of fresh\r\n'b'water was within their reach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The camp was soon organized. In less than an hour, on the edge of the\r\n'b'forest, among the trees, a hut of branches interlaced with creepers,\r\n'b'and pasted over with clay, offered a tolerable shelter. Their geological\r\n'b'researches were put off till the next day. Supper was prepared, a good\r\n'b'fire blazed before the hut, the roast turned, and at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\r\n'b'while one of the settlers watched to keep up the fire, in case any wild\r\n'b'beasts should prowl in the neighborhood, the others slept soundly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 21st of April, Cyrus Harding accompanied by Herbert,\r\n'b'went to look for the soil of ancient formation, on which he had already\r\n'b'discovered a specimen of ore. They found the vein above ground, near the\r\n'b'source of the creek, at the foot of one of the northeastern spurs. This\r\n'b'ore, very rich in iron, enclosed in its fusible veinstone, was perfectly\r\n'b'suited to the mode of reduction which the engineer intended to employ;\r\n'b'that is, the Catalan method, but simplified, as it is used in\r\n'b'Corsica. In fact, the Catalan method, properly so called, requires the\r\n'b'construction of kilns and crucibles, in which the ore and the coal,\r\n'b'placed in alternate layers, are transformed and reduced, But Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding intended to economize these constructions, and wished simply to\r\n'b'form, with the ore and the coal, a cubic mass, to the center of which he\r\n'b'would direct the wind from his bellows. Doubtless, it was the proceeding\r\n'b'employed by Tubalcain, and the first metallurgists of the inhabited\r\n'b'world. Now that which had succeeded with the grandson of Adam, and which\r\n'b'still yielded good results in countries rich in ore and fuel, could not\r\n'b'but succeed with the settlers in Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The coal, as well as the ore, was collected without trouble on the\r\n'b'surface of the ground. They first broke the ore into little pieces,\r\n'b'and cleansed them with the hand from the impurities which soiled their\r\n'b'surface. Then coal and ore were arranged in heaps and in successive\r\n'b'layers, as the charcoal-burner does with the wood which he wishes to\r\n'b'carbonize. In this way, under the influence of the air projected by the\r\n'b'blowing-machine, the coal would be transformed into carbonic acid, then\r\n'b'into oxide of carbon, its use being to reduce the oxide of iron, that is\r\n'b'to say, to rid it of the oxygen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus the engineer proceeded. The bellows of sealskin, furnished at its\r\n'b'extremity with a nozzle of clay, which had been previously fabricated\r\n'b'in the pottery kiln, was established near the heap of ore. Using the\r\n'b'mechanism which consisted of a frame, cords of fiber and counterpoise,\r\n'b'he threw into the mass an abundance of air, which by raising the\r\n'b'temperature also concurred with the chemical transformation to produce\r\n'b'in time pure iron.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The operation was difficult. All the patience, all the ingenuity of the\r\n'b'settlers was needed; but at last it succeeded, and the result was a lump\r\n'b'of iron, reduced to a spongy state, which it was necessary to shingle\r\n'b'and fagot, that is to say, to forge so as to expel from it the liquefied\r\n'b'veinstone. These amateur smiths had, of course, no hammer; but they were\r\n'b'in no worse a situation than the first metallurgist, and therefore did\r\n'b'what, no doubt, he had to do.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A handle was fixed to the first lump, and was used as a hammer to forge\r\n'b'the second on a granite anvil, and thus they obtained a coarse but\r\n'b'useful metal. At length, after many trials and much fatigue, on the 25th\r\n'b'of April several bars of iron were forged, and transformed into tools,\r\n'b'crowbars, pincers, pickaxes, spades, etc., which Pencroft and Neb\r\n'b'declared to be real jewels. But the metal was not yet in its most\r\n'b'serviceable state, that is, of steel. Now steel is a combination of iron\r\n'b'and coal, which is extracted, either from the liquid ore, by taking from\r\n'b'it the excess of coal, or from the iron by adding to it the coal which\r\n'b'was wanting. The first, obtained by the decarburation of the metal,\r\n'b'gives natural or puddled steel; the second, produced by the carburation\r\n'b'of the iron, gives steel of cementation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the last which Cyrus Harding intended to forge, as he possessed\r\n'b'iron in a pure state. He succeeded by heating the metal with powdered\r\n'b'coal in a crucible which had previously been manufactured from clay\r\n'b'suitable for the purpose.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He then worked this steel, which is malleable both when hot or cold,\r\n'b'with the hammer. Neb and Pencroft, cleverly directed, made hatchets,\r\n'b'which, heated red-hot, and plunged suddenly into cold water, acquired an\r\n'b'excellent temper.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Other instruments, of course roughly fashioned, were also manufactured;\r\n'b'blades for planes, axes, hatchets, pieces of steel to be transformed\r\n'b'into saws, chisels; then iron for spades, pickaxes, hammers, nails,\r\n'b'etc. At last, on the 5th of May, the metallic period ended, the smiths\r\n'b'returned to the Chimneys, and new work would soon authorize them to take\r\n'b'a fresh title.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 16\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the 6th of May, a day which corresponds to the 6th of November in\r\n'b'the countries of the Northern Hemisphere. The sky had been obscured for\r\n'b'some days, and it was of importance to make preparations for the winter.\r\n'b'However, the temperature was not as yet much lower, and a centigrade\r\n'b'thermometer, transported to Lincoln Island, would still have marked an\r\n'b'average of ten to twelve degrees above zero. This was not surprising,\r\n'b'since Lincoln Island, probably situated between the thirty-fifth and\r\n'b'fortieth parallel, would be subject, in the Southern Hemisphere, to\r\n'b'the same climate as Sicily or Greece in the Northern Hemisphere. But as\r\n'b'Greece and Sicily have severe cold, producing snow and ice, so doubtless\r\n'b'would Lincoln Island in the severest part of the winter and it was\r\n'b'advisable to provide against it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In any case if cold did not yet threaten them, the rainy season would\r\n'b'begin, and on this lonely island, exposed to all the fury of the\r\n'b'elements, in mid-ocean, bad weather would be frequent, and probably\r\n'b'terrible. The question of a more comfortable dwelling than the Chimneys\r\n'b'must therefore be seriously considered and promptly resolved on.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, naturally, had some predilection for the retreat which he\r\n'b'had discovered, but he well understood that another must be found. The\r\n'b'Chimneys had been already visited by the sea, under circumstances\r\n'b'which are known, and it would not do to be exposed again to a similar\r\n'b'accident.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d added Cyrus Harding, who this day was talking of these things\r\n'b'with his companions, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have some precautions to take.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? The island is not inhabited,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is probable,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9calthough we have not yet\r\n'b'explored the interior; but if no human beings are found, I fear that\r\n'b'dangerous animals may abound. It is necessary to guard against a\r\n'b'possible attack, so that we shall not be obliged to watch every night,\r\n'b'or to keep up a fire. And then, my friends, we must foresee everything.\r\n'b'We are here in a part of the Pacific often frequented by Malay\r\n'b'pirates--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cat such a distance from land?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cThese pirates are bold sailors as\r\n'b'well as formidable enemies, and we must take measures accordingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will fortify ourselves against savages\r\n'b'with two legs as well as against savages with four. But, captain, will\r\n'b'it not be best to explore every part of the island before undertaking\r\n'b'anything else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be best,\xe2\x80\x9d added Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho knows if we might not find on the opposite side one of the caverns\r\n'b'which we have searched for in vain here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you forget, my friends, that\r\n'b'it will be necessary to establish ourselves in the neighborhood of a\r\n'b'watercourse, and that, from the summit of Mount Franklin, we could not\r\n'b'see towards the west, either stream or river. Here, on the contrary, we\r\n'b'are placed between the Mercy and Lake Grant, an advantage which must not\r\n'b'be neglected. And, besides, this side, looking towards the east, is not\r\n'b'exposed as the other is to the trade-winds, which in this hemisphere\r\n'b'blow from the northwest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9clet us build a house on the edge\r\n'b'of the lake. Neither bricks nor tools are wanting now. After having been\r\n'b'brickmakers, potters, smelters, and smiths, we shall surely know how to\r\n'b'be masons!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my friend; but before coming to any decision we must consider\r\n'b'the matter thoroughly. A natural dwelling would spare us much work,\r\n'b'and would be a surer retreat, for it would be as well defended against\r\n'b'enemies from the interior as those from outside.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we have already\r\n'b'examined all that mass of granite, and there is not a hole, not a\r\n'b'cranny!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not one!\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, if we were able to dig out a\r\n'b'dwelling in that cliff, at a good height, so as to be out of the reach\r\n'b'of harm, that would be capital! I can see that on the front which looks\r\n'b'seaward, five or six rooms--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWith windows to light them!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, laughing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a staircase to climb up to them!\xe2\x80\x9d added Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are laughing,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand why? What is there impossible\r\n'b'in what I propose? Haven\xe2\x80\x99t we got pickaxes and spades? Won\xe2\x80\x99t Captain\r\n'b'Harding be able to make powder to blow up the mine? Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it true,\r\n'b'captain, that you will make powder the very day we want it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding listened to the enthusiastic Pencroft developing his\r\n'b'fanciful projects. To attack this mass of granite, even by a mine, was\r\n'b'Herculean work, and it was really vexing that nature could not help them\r\n'b'at their need. But the engineer did not reply to the sailor except by\r\n'b'proposing to examine the cliff more attentively, from the mouth of the\r\n'b'river to the angle which terminated it on the north.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They went out, therefore, and the exploration was made with extreme\r\n'b'care, over an extent of nearly two miles. But in no place in the bare,\r\n'b'straight cliff, could any cavity be found. The nests of the rock pigeons\r\n'b'which fluttered at its summit were only, in reality, holes bored at the\r\n'b'very top, and on the irregular edge of the granite.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was a provoking circumstance, and as to attacking this cliff, either\r\n'b'with pickaxe or with powder, so as to effect a sufficient excavation, it\r\n'b'was not to be thought of. It so happened that, on all this part of the\r\n'b'shore, Pencroft had discovered the only habitable shelter, that is to\r\n'b'say, the Chimneys, which now had to be abandoned.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The exploration ended, the colonists found themselves at the north angle\r\n'b'of the cliff, where it terminated in long slopes which died away on the\r\n'b'shore. From this place, to its extreme limit in the west, it only formed\r\n'b'a sort of declivity, a thick mass of stones, earth, and sand, bound\r\n'b'together by plants, bushes, and grass inclined at an angle of only\r\n'b'forty-five degrees. Clumps of trees grew on these slopes, which were\r\n'b'also carpeted with thick grass. But the vegetation did not extend\r\n'b'far, and a long, sandy plain, which began at the foot of these slopes,\r\n'b'reached to the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding thought, not without reason, that the overplus of the lake\r\n'b'must overflow on this side. The excess of water furnished by the Red\r\n'b'Creek must also escape by some channel or other. Now the engineer had\r\n'b'not yet found this channel on any part of the shore already explored,\r\n'b'that is to say, from the mouth of the stream on the west of Prospect\r\n'b'Heights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer now proposed to his companions to climb the slope, and to\r\n'b'return to the Chimneys by the heights, while exploring the northern\r\n'b'and eastern shores of the lake. The proposal was accepted, and in a few\r\n'b'minutes Herbert and Neb were on the upper plateau. Cyrus Harding, Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, and Pencroft followed with more sedate steps.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The beautiful sheet of water glittered through the trees under the rays\r\n'b'of the sun. In this direction the country was charming. The eye feasted\r\n'b'on the groups of trees. Some old trunks, bent with age, showed black\r\n'b'against the verdant grass which covered the ground. Crowds of brilliant\r\n'b'cockatoos screamed among the branches, moving prisms, hopping from one\r\n'b'bough to another.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers instead of going directly to the north bank of the lake,\r\n'b'made a circuit round the edge of the plateau, so as to join the mouth\r\n'b'of the creek on its left bank. It was a detour of more than a mile and a\r\n'b'half. Walking was easy, for the trees widely spread, left a considerable\r\n'b'space between them. The fertile zone evidently stopped at this point,\r\n'b'and vegetation would be less vigorous in the part between the course of\r\n'b'the Creek and the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions walked over this new ground with great\r\n'b'care. Bows, arrows, and sticks with sharp iron points were their only\r\n'b'weapons. However, no wild beast showed itself, and it was probable that\r\n'b'these animals frequented rather the thick forests in the south; but the\r\n'b'settlers had the disagreeable surprise of seeing Top stop before a snake\r\n'b'of great size, measuring from fourteen to fifteen feet in length. Neb\r\n'b'killed it by a blow from his stick. Cyrus Harding examined the reptile,\r\n'b'and declared it not venomous, for it belonged to that species of diamond\r\n'b'serpents which the natives of New South Wales rear. But it was possible\r\n'b'that others existed whose bite was mortal such as the deaf vipers with\r\n'b'forked tails, which rise up under the feet, or those winged snakes,\r\n'b'furnished with two ears, which enable them to proceed with great\r\n'b'rapidity. Top, the first moment of surprise over, began a reptile chase\r\n'b'with such eagerness, that they feared for his safety. His master called\r\n'b'him back directly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The mouth of the Red Creek, at the place where it entered into the lake,\r\n'b'was soon reached. The explorers recognized on the opposite shore the\r\n'b'point which they had visited on their descent from Mount Franklin. Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding ascertained that the flow of water into it from the creek was\r\n'b'considerable. Nature must therefore have provided some place for the\r\n'b'escape of the overplus. This doubtless formed a fall, which, if it could\r\n'b'be discovered, would be of great use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, walking apart, but not straying far from each other,\r\n'b'began to skirt the edge of the lake, which was very steep. The water\r\n'b'appeared to be full of fish, and Pencroft resolved to make some\r\n'b'fishing-rods, so as to try and catch some.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The northeast point was first to be doubled. It might have been supposed\r\n'b'that the discharge of water was at this place, for the extremity of the\r\n'b'lake was almost on a level with the edge of the plateau. But no signs of\r\n'b'this were discovered, and the colonists continued to explore the bank,\r\n'b'which, after a slight bend, descended parallel to the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this side the banks were less woody, but clumps of trees, here and\r\n'b'there, added to the picturesqueness of the country. Lake Grant was\r\n'b'viewed from thence in all its extent, and no breath disturbed the\r\n'b'surface of its waters. Top, in beating the bushes, put up flocks of\r\n'b'birds of different kinds, which Gideon Spilett and Herbert saluted with\r\n'b'arrows. One was hit by the lad, and fell into some marshy grass. Top\r\n'b'rushed forward, and brought a beautiful swimming bird, of a slate color,\r\n'b'short beak, very developed frontal plate, and wings edged with white. It\r\n'b'was a \xe2\x80\x9ccoot,\xe2\x80\x9d the size of a large partridge, belonging to the group of\r\n'b'macrodactyls which form the transition between the order of wading birds\r\n'b'and that of palmipeds. Sorry game, in truth, and its flavor is far from\r\n'b'pleasant.
