But Top was not so particular in these things as his masters,\r\n'b'and it was agreed that the coot should be for his supper.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers were now following the eastern bank of the lake, and they\r\n'b'would not be long in reaching the part which they already knew.\r\n'b'The engineer was much surprised at not seeing any indication of the\r\n'b'discharge of water. The reporter and the sailor talked with him, and he\r\n'b'could not conceal his astonishment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment Top, who had been very quiet till then, gave signs of\r\n'b'agitation. The intelligent animal went backwards and forwards on the\r\n'b'shore, stopped suddenly, and looked at the water, one paw raised, as if\r\n'b'he was pointing at some invisible game; then he barked furiously, and\r\n'b'was suddenly silent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions had at first paid any attention\r\n'b'to Top\xe2\x80\x99s behavior; but the dog\xe2\x80\x99s barking soon became so frequent that\r\n'b'the engineer noticed it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is there, Top?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The dog bounded towards his master, seeming to be very uneasy, and then\r\n'b'rushed again towards the bank. Then, all at once, he plunged into the\r\n'b'lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Top!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Cyrus Harding, who did not like his dog to venture\r\n'b'into the treacherous water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s happening down there?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft, examining the surface of\r\n'b'the lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop smells some amphibious creature,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAn alligator, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cAlligators are only met with in\r\n'b'regions less elevated in latitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile Top had returned at his master\xe2\x80\x99s call, and had regained the\r\n'b'shore: but he could not stay quiet; he plunged in among the tall grass,\r\n'b'and guided by instinct, he appeared to follow some invisible being which\r\n'b'was slipping along under the surface of the water. However the water\r\n'b'was calm; not a ripple disturbed its surface. Several times the settlers\r\n'b'stopped on the bank, and observed it attentively. Nothing appeared.\r\n'b'There was some mystery there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer was puzzled.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us pursue this exploration to the end,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Half an hour after they had all arrived at the southeast angle of the\r\n'b'lake, on Prospect Heights. At this point the examination of the banks of\r\n'b'the lake was considered finished, and yet the engineer had not been able\r\n'b'to discover how and where the waters were discharged. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no doubt\r\n'b'this overflow exists,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, \xe2\x80\x9cand since it is not visible it must\r\n'b'go through the granite cliff at the west!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what importance do you attach to knowing that, my dear Cyrus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cConsiderable importance,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cfor if it flows\r\n'b'through the cliff there is probably some cavity, which it would be easy\r\n'b'to render habitable after turning away the water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut is it not possible, captain, that the water flows away at the\r\n'b'bottom of the lake,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand that it reaches the sea by some\r\n'b'subterranean passage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat might be,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand should it be so we shall be\r\n'b'obliged to build our house ourselves, since nature has not done it for\r\n'b'us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists were about to begin to traverse the plateau to return to\r\n'b'the Chimneys, when Top gave new signs of agitation. He barked with fury,\r\n'b'and before his master could restrain him, he had plunged a second time\r\n'b'into the lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All ran towards the bank. The dog was already more than twenty feet off,\r\n'b'and Cyrus was calling him back, when an enormous head emerged from the\r\n'b'water, which did not appear to be deep in that place.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert recognized directly the species of amphibian to which the\r\n'b'tapering head, with large eyes, and adorned with long silky mustaches,\r\n'b'belonged.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA lamantin!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was not a lamantin, but one of that species of the order of\r\n'b'cetaceans, which bear the name of the \xe2\x80\x9cdugong,\xe2\x80\x9d for its nostrils were\r\n'b'open at the upper part of its snout. The enormous animal rushed on the\r\n'b'dog, who tried to escape by returning towards the shore. His master\r\n'b'could do nothing to save him, and before Gideon Spilett or Herbert\r\n'b'thought of bending their bows, Top, seized by the dugong, had\r\n'b'disappeared beneath the water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb, his iron-tipped spear in his hand, wished to go to Top\xe2\x80\x99s help, and\r\n'b'attack the dangerous animal in its own element.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, restraining his courageous servant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, a struggle was going on beneath the water, an inexplicable\r\n'b'struggle, for in his situation Top could not possibly resist; and\r\n'b'judging by the bubbling of the surface it must be also a terrible\r\n'b'struggle, and could not but terminate in the death of the dog! But\r\n'b'suddenly, in the middle of a foaming circle, Top reappeared. Thrown in\r\n'b'the air by some unknown power, he rose ten feet above the surface of the\r\n'b'lake, fell again into the midst of the agitated waters, and then soon\r\n'b'gained the shore, without any severe wounds, miraculously saved.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions could not understand it. What was not\r\n'b'less inexplicable was that the struggle still appeared to be going on.\r\n'b'Doubtless, the dugong, attacked by some powerful animal, after having\r\n'b'released the dog, was fighting on its own account. But it did not last\r\n'b'long. The water became red with blood, and the body of the dugong,\r\n'b'emerging from the sheet of scarlet which spread around, soon stranded on\r\n'b'a little beach at the south angle of the lake. The colonists ran towards\r\n'b'it. The dugong was dead. It was an enormous animal, fifteen or sixteen\r\n'b'feet long, and must have weighed from three to four thousand pounds. At\r\n'b'its neck was a wound, which appeared to have been produced by a sharp\r\n'b'blade.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What could the amphibious creature have been, who, by this terrible\r\n'b'blow had destroyed the formidable dugong? No one could tell, and much\r\n'b'interested in this incident, Harding and his companions returned to the\r\n'b'Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 17\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 7th of May, Harding and Gideon Spilett, leaving Neb to\r\n'b'prepare breakfast, climbed Prospect Heights, while Herbert and Pencroft\r\n'b'ascended by the river, to renew their store of wood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer and the reporter soon reached the little beach on which the\r\n'b'dugong had been stranded. Already flocks of birds had attacked the mass\r\n'b'of flesh, and had to be driven away with stones, for Cyrus wished to\r\n'b'keep the fat for the use of the colony. As to the animal\xe2\x80\x99s flesh\r\n'b'it would furnish excellent food, for in the islands of the Malay\r\n'b'Archipelago and elsewhere, it is especially reserved for the table of\r\n'b'the native princes. But that was Neb\xe2\x80\x99s affair.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment Cyrus Harding had other thoughts. He was much interested\r\n'b'in the incident of the day before. He wished to penetrate the mystery\r\n'b'of that submarine combat, and to ascertain what monster could have given\r\n'b'the dugong so strange a wound. He remained at the edge of the lake,\r\n'b'looking, observing; but nothing appeared under the tranquil waters,\r\n'b'which sparkled in the first rays of the rising sun.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the beach, on which lay the body of the dugong, the water was\r\n'b'tolerably shallow, but from this point the bottom of the lake sloped\r\n'b'gradually, and it was probable that the depth was considerable in the\r\n'b'center. The lake might be considered as a large center basin, which was\r\n'b'filled by the water from the Red Creek.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cthere seems to be nothing suspicious\r\n'b'in this water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand I really do not know\r\n'b'how to account for the incident of yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI acknowledge,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the wound given this creature\r\n'b'is, at least, very strange, and I cannot explain either how Top was\r\n'b'so vigorously cast up out of the water. One could have thought that a\r\n'b'powerful arm hurled him up, and that the same arm with a dagger killed\r\n'b'the dugong!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, who had become thoughtful; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is\r\n'b'something there that I cannot understand. But do you better understand\r\n'b'either, my dear Spilett, in what way I was saved myself--how I was drawn\r\n'b'from the waves, and carried to the downs? No! Is it not true? Now, I\r\n'b'feel sure that there is some mystery there, which, doubtless, we shall\r\n'b'discover some day. Let us observe, but do not dwell on these singular\r\n'b'incidents before our companions. Let us keep our remarks to ourselves,\r\n'b'and continue our work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It will be remembered that the engineer had not as yet been able to\r\n'b'discover the place where the surplus water escaped, but he knew it must\r\n'b'exist somewhere. He was much surprised to see a strong current at this\r\n'b'place. By throwing in some bits of wood he found that it set towards the\r\n'b'southern angle. He followed the current, and arrived at the south point\r\n'b'of the lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was there a sort of depression in the water, as if it was suddenly\r\n'b'lost in some fissure in the ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding listened; placing his ear to the level of the lake, he very\r\n'b'distinctly heard the noise of a subterranean fall.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, rising, \xe2\x80\x9cis the discharge of the water; there,\r\n'b'doubtless, by a passage in the granite cliff, it joins the sea, through\r\n'b'cavities which we can use to our profit. Well, I can find it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer cut a long branch, stripped it of its leaves, and plunging\r\n'b'it into the angle between the two banks, he found that there was a large\r\n'b'hole one foot only beneath the surface of the water. This hole was the\r\n'b'opening so long looked for in vain, and the force of the current was\r\n'b'such that the branch was torn from the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s hands and disappeared.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no doubt about it now,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is the\r\n'b'outlet, and I will lay it open to view!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy lowering the level of the water of the lake three feet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how will you lower the level?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy opening another outlet larger than this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt what place, Cyrus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt the part of the bank nearest the coast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is a mass of granite!\xe2\x80\x9d observed Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cI will blow up the granite, and the\r\n'b'water escaping, will subside, so as to lay bare this opening--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd make a waterfall, by falling on to the beach,\xe2\x80\x9d added the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA fall that we shall make use of!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer hurried away his companion, whose confidence in Harding was\r\n'b'such that he did not doubt the enterprise would succeed. And yet, how\r\n'b'was this granite wall to be opened without powder, and with imperfect\r\n'b'instruments? Was not this work upon which the engineer was so bent above\r\n'b'their strength?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When Harding and the reporter entered the Chimneys, they found Herbert\r\n'b'and Pencroft unloading their raft of wood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe woodmen have just finished, captain.\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, laughing,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cand when you want masons--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMasons,--no, but chemists,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d added the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are going to blow up the island--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBlow up the island?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPart of it, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer. And he made known to them\r\n'b'the result of his observations.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'According to him, a cavity, more or less considerable, must exist in\r\n'b'the mass of granite which supported Prospect Heights, and he intended\r\n'b'to penetrate into it. To do this, the opening through which the water\r\n'b'rushed must first be cleared, and the level lowered by making a larger\r\n'b'outlet. Therefore an explosive substance must be manufactured, which\r\n'b'would make a deep trench in some other part of the shore. This was what\r\n'b'Harding was going to attempt with the minerals which nature placed at\r\n'b'his disposal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is useless to say with what enthusiasm all, especially Pencroft,\r\n'b'received this project. To employ great means, open the granite, create a\r\n'b'cascade, that suited the sailor. And he would just as soon be a chemist\r\n'b'as a mason or bootmaker, since the engineer wanted chemicals. He would\r\n'b'be all that they liked, \xe2\x80\x9ceven a professor of dancing and deportment,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' said he to Neb, if that was ever necessary.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb and Pencroft were first of all told to extract the grease from the\r\n'b'dugong, and to keep the flesh, which was destined for food. Such perfect\r\n'b'confidence had they in the engineer, that they set out directly,\r\n'b'without even asking a question. A few minutes after them, Cyrus Harding,\r\n'b'Herbert, and Gideon Spilett, dragging the hurdle, went towards the vein\r\n'b'of coals, where those shistose pyrites abound which are met with in the\r\n'b'most recent transition soil, and of which Harding had already found a\r\n'b'specimen. All the day being employed in carrying a quantity of these\r\n'b'stones to the Chimneys, by evening they had several tons.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 8th of May, the engineer began his manipulations.\r\n'b'These shistose pyrites being composed principally of coal, flint,\r\n'b'alumina, and sulphuret of iron--the latter in excess--it was necessary\r\n'b'to separate the sulphuret of iron, and transform it into sulphate as\r\n'b'rapidly as possible. The sulphate obtained, the sulphuric acid could\r\n'b'then be extracted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was the object to be attained. Sulphuric acid is one of the agents\r\n'b'the most frequently employed, and the manufacturing importance of a\r\n'b'nation can be measured by the consumption which is made of it. This acid\r\n'b'would later be of great use to the settlers, in the manufacturing of\r\n'b'candles, tanning skins, etc., but this time the engineer reserved it for\r\n'b'another use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding chose, behind the Chimneys, a site where the ground\r\n'b'was perfectly level. On this ground he placed a layer of branches and\r\n'b'chopped wood, on which were piled some pieces of shistose pyrites,\r\n'b'buttressed one against the other, the whole being covered with a thin\r\n'b'layer of pyrites, previously reduced to the size of a nut.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This done, they set fire to the wood, the heat was communicated to the\r\n'b'shist, which soon kindled, since it contains coal and sulphur. Then new\r\n'b'layers of bruised pyrites were arranged so as to form an immense\r\n'b'heap, the exterior of which was covered with earth and grass, several\r\n'b'air-holes being left, as if it was a stack of wood which was to be\r\n'b'carbonized to make charcoal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They then left the transformation to complete itself, and it would\r\n'b'not take less than ten or twelve days for the sulphuret of iron to be\r\n'b'changed to sulphate of iron and the alumina into sulphate of alumina,\r\n'b'two equally soluble substances, the others, flint, burnt coal, and\r\n'b'cinders, not being so.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While this chemical work was going on, Cyrus Harding proceeded with\r\n'b'other operations, which were pursued with more than zeal,--it was\r\n'b'eagerness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb and Pencroft had taken away the fat from the dugong, and placed it\r\n'b'in large earthen pots. It was then necessary to separate the glycerine\r\n'b'from the fat by saponifying it. Now, to obtain this result, it had to\r\n'b'be treated either with soda or lime. In fact, one or other of these\r\n'b'substances, after having attacked the fat, would form a soap by\r\n'b'separating the glycerine, and it was just this glycerine which the\r\n'b'engineer wished to obtain. There was no want of lime, only treatment by\r\n'b'lime would give calcareous soap, insoluble, and consequently useless,\r\n'b'while treatment by soda would furnish, on the contrary, a soluble soap,\r\n'b'which could be put to domestic use. Now, a practical man, like Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding, would rather try to obtain soda. Was this difficult? No; for\r\n'b'marine plants abounded on the shore, glass-wort, ficoides, and all\r\n'b'those fucaceae which form wrack. A large quantity of these plants\r\n'b'was collected, first dried, then burnt in holes in the open air. The\r\n'b'combustion of these plants was kept up for several days, and the result\r\n'b'was a compact gray mass, which has been long known under the name of\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cnatural soda.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This obtained, the engineer treated the fat with soda, which gave both a\r\n'b'soluble soap and that neutral substance, glycerine.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But this was not all. Cyrus Harding still needed, in view of his future\r\n'b'preparation, another substance, nitrate of potash, which is better known\r\n'b'under the name of salt niter, or of saltpeter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding could have manufactured this substance by treating the\r\n'b'carbonate of potash, which would be easily extracted from the cinders of\r\n'b'the vegetables, by azotic acid. But this acid was wanting, and he would\r\n'b'have been in some difficulty, if nature had not happily furnished the\r\n'b'saltpeter, without giving them any other trouble than that of picking it\r\n'b'up. Herbert found a vein of it at the foot of Mount Franklin, and they\r\n'b'had nothing to do but purify this salt.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These different works lasted a week. They were finished before\r\n'b'the transformation of the sulphuret into sulphate of iron had been\r\n'b'accomplished. During the following days the settlers had time to\r\n'b'construct a furnace of bricks of a particular arrangement, to serve for\r\n'b'the distillation of the sulphate or iron when it had been obtained. All\r\n'b'this was finished about the 18th of May, nearly at the time when the\r\n'b'chemical transformation terminated. Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Neb, and\r\n'b'Pencroft, skillfully directed by the engineer, had become most clever\r\n'b'workmen. Before all masters, necessity is the one most listened to, and\r\n'b'who teaches the best.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When the heap of pyrites had been entirely reduced by fire, the result\r\n'b'of the operation, consisting of sulphate of iron, sulphate of alumina,\r\n'b'flint, remains of coal, and cinders was placed in a basinful of water.\r\n'b'They stirred this mixture, let it settle, then decanted it, and obtained\r\n'b'a clear liquid containing in solution sulphate of iron and sulphate of\r\n'b'alumina, the other matters remaining solid, since they are insoluble.\r\n'b'Lastly, this liquid being partly evaporated, crystals of sulphate of\r\n'b'iron were deposited, and the not evaporated liquid, which contained the\r\n'b'sulphate of alumina, was thrown away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had now at his disposal a large quantity of these sulphate\r\n'b'of iron crystals, from which the sulphuric acid had to be extracted. The\r\n'b'making of sulphuric acid is a very expensive manufacture. Considerable\r\n'b'works are necessary--a special set of tools, an apparatus of\r\n'b'platina, leaden chambers, unassailable by the acid, and in which the\r\n'b'transformation is performed, etc. The engineer had none of these at his\r\n'b'disposal, but he knew that, in Bohemia especially, sulphuric acid is\r\n'b'manufactured by very simple means, which have also the advantage of\r\n'b'producing it to a superior degree of concentration. It is thus that the\r\n'b'acid known under the name of Nordhausen acid is made.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To obtain sulphuric acid, Cyrus Harding had only one operation to make,\r\n'b'to calcine the sulphate of iron crystals in a closed vase, so that the\r\n'b'sulphuric acid should distil in vapor, which vapor, by condensation,\r\n'b'would produce the acid.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The crystals were placed in pots, and the heat from the furnace would\r\n'b'distil the sulphuric acid. The operation was successfully completed, and\r\n'b'on the 20th of May, twelve days after commencing it, the engineer\r\n'b'was the possessor of the agent which later he hoped to use in so many\r\n'b'different ways.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now, why did he wish for this agent? Simply to produce azotic acid;\r\n'b'and that was easy, since saltpeter, attacked by sulphuric acid, gives\r\n'b'azotic, or nitric, acid by distillation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But, after all, how was he going to employ this azotic acid? His\r\n'b'companions were still ignorant of this, for he had not informed them of\r\n'b'the result at which he aimed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the engineer had nearly accomplished his purpose, and by a\r\n'b'last operation he would procure the substance which had given so much\r\n'b'trouble.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Taking some azotic acid, he mixed it with glycerine, which had been\r\n'b'previously concentrated by evaporation, subjected to the water-bath, and\r\n'b'he obtained, without even employing a refrigerant mixture, several pints\r\n'b'of an oily yellow mixture.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This last operation Cyrus Harding had made alone, in a retired place, at\r\n'b'a distance from the Chimneys, for he feared the danger of an explosion,\r\n'b'and when he showed a bottle of this liquid to his friends, he contented\r\n'b'himself with saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere is nitro-glycerine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was really this terrible production, of which the explosive power is\r\n'b'perhaps tenfold that of ordinary powder, and which has already caused so\r\n'b'many accidents. However, since a way has been found to transform it into\r\n'b'dynamite, that is to say, to mix with it some solid substance, clay or\r\n'b'sugar, porous enough to hold it, the dangerous liquid has been used\r\n'b'with some security. But dynamite was not yet known at the time when the\r\n'b'settlers worked on Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is it that liquid that is going to blow up our rocks?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\n'b'Pencroft incredulously.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand this nitro-glycerine will\r\n'b'produce so much the more effect, as the granite is extremely hard, and\r\n'b'will oppose a greater resistance to the explosion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when shall we see this, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow, as soon as we have dug a hole for the mine, replied the\r\n'b'engineer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 21st of May, at daybreak, the miners went to the point\r\n'b'which formed the eastern shore of Lake Grant, and was only five hundred\r\n'b'feet from the coast. At this place, the plateau inclined downwards from\r\n'b'the waters, which were only restrained by their granite case. Therefore,\r\n'b'if this case was broken, the water would escape by the opening and form\r\n'b'a stream, which, flowing over the inclined surface of the plateau,\r\n'b'would rush on to the beach. Consequently, the level of the lake would\r\n'b'be greatly lowered, and the opening where the water escaped would be\r\n'b'exposed, which was their final aim.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Under the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s directions, Pencroft, armed with a pickaxe, which\r\n'b'he handled skillfully and vigorously, attacked the granite. The hole was\r\n'b'made on the point of the shore, slanting, so that it should meet a\r\n'b'much lower level than that of the water of the lake. In this way the\r\n'b'explosive force, by scattering the rock, would open a large place for\r\n'b'the water to rush out.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The work took some time, for the engineer, wishing to produce a great\r\n'b'effect, intended to devote not less than seven quarts of nitro-glycerine\r\n'b'to the operation. But Pencroft, relieved by Neb, did so well, that\r\n'b'towards four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, the mine was finished.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now the question of setting fire to the explosive substance was raised.\r\n'b'Generally, nitro-glycerine is ignited by caps of fulminate, which in\r\n'b'bursting cause the explosion. A shock is therefore needed to produce\r\n'b'the explosion, for, simply lighted, this substance would burn without\r\n'b'exploding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding could certainly have fabricated a percussion cap. In\r\n'b'default of fulminate, he could easily obtain a substance similar to\r\n'b'guncotton, since he had azotic acid at his disposal. This substance,\r\n'b'pressed in a cartridge, and introduced among the nitro-glycerine, would\r\n'b'burst by means of a fuse, and cause the explosion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Cyrus Harding knew that nitro-glycerine would explode by a shock.\r\n'b'He resolved to employ this means, and try another way, if this did not\r\n'b'succeed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the blow of a hammer on a few drops of nitro-glycerine, spread\r\n'b'out on a hard surface, was enough to create an explosion. But the\r\n'b'operator could not be there to give the blow, without becoming a victim\r\n'b'to the operation. Harding, therefore, thought of suspending a mass of\r\n'b'iron, weighing several pounds, by means of a fiber, to an upright just\r\n'b'above the mine. Another long fiber, previously impregnated with sulphur,\r\n'b'was attached to the middle of the first, by one end, while the other lay\r\n'b'on the ground several feet distant from the mine. The second fiber being\r\n'b'set on fire, it would burn till it reached the first. This catching\r\n'b'fire in its turn, would break, and the mass of iron would fall on the\r\n'b'nitro-glycerine. This apparatus being then arranged, the engineer, after\r\n'b'having sent his companions to a distance, filled the hole, so that the\r\n'b'nitro-glycerine was on a level with the opening; then he threw a few\r\n'b'drops of it on the surface of the rock, above which the mass of iron was\r\n'b'already suspended.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This done, Harding lit the end of the sulphured fiber, and leaving the\r\n'b'place, he returned with his companions to the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The fiber was intended to burn five and twenty minutes, and, in fact,\r\n'b'five and twenty minutes afterwards a most tremendous explosion was\r\n'b'heard. The island appeared to tremble to its very foundation. Stones\r\n'b'were projected in the air as if by the eruption of a volcano. The shock\r\n'b'produced by the displacing of the air was such, that the rocks of the\r\n'b'Chimneys shook. The settlers, although they were more than two miles\r\n'b'from the mine, were thrown on the ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They rose, climbed the plateau, and ran towards the place where the bank\r\n'b'of the lake must have been shattered by the explosion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A cheer escaped them! A large rent was seen in the granite! A rapid\r\n'b'stream of water rushed foaming across the plateau and dashed down a\r\n'b'height of three hundred feet on to the beach!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 18\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s project had succeeded, but, according to his usual\r\n'b'habit he showed no satisfaction; with closed lips and a fixed look, he\r\n'b'remained motionless. Herbert was in ecstasies, Neb bounded with joy,\r\n'b'Pencroft nodded his great head, murmuring these words,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome, our engineer gets on capitally!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The nitro-glycerine had indeed acted powerfully. The opening which it\r\n'b'had made was so large that the volume of water which escaped through\r\n'b'this new outlet was at least treble that which before passed through the\r\n'b'old one. The result was, that a short time after the operation the level\r\n'b'of the lake would be lowered two feet, or more.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers went to the Chimneys to take some pickaxes, iron-tipped\r\n'b'spears, string made of fibers, flint and steel; they then returned to\r\n'b'the plateau, Top accompanying them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the way the sailor could not help saying to the engineer,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think, captain, that by means of that charming liquid you\r\n'b'have made, one could blow up the whole of our island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWithout any doubt, the island, continents, and the world itself,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is only a question of quantity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen could you not use this nitro-glycerine for loading firearms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft; for it is too explosive a substance. But it would be easy\r\n'b'to make some guncotton, or even ordinary powder, as we have azotic acid,\r\n'b'saltpeter, sulphur, and coal. Unhappily, it is the guns which we have\r\n'b'not got.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cwith a little determination--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft had erased the word \xe2\x80\x9cimpossible\xe2\x80\x9d from the dictionary of Lincoln\r\n'b'Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers, having arrived at Prospect Heights, went immediately\r\n'b'towards that point of the lake near which was the old opening now\r\n'b'uncovered. This outlet had now become practicable, since the water no\r\n'b'longer rushed through it, and it would doubtless be easy to explore the\r\n'b'interior.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few minutes the settlers had reached the lower point of the lake,\r\n'b'and a glance showed them that the object had been attained.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, in the side of the lake, and now above the surface of the\r\n'b'water, appeared the long-looked-for opening. A narrow ridge, left bare\r\n'b'by the retreat of the water, allowed them to approach it. This orifice\r\n'b'was nearly twenty feet in width, but scarcely two in height. It was like\r\n'b'the mouth of a drain at the edge of the pavement, and therefore did\r\n'b'not offer an easy passage to the settlers; but Neb and Pencroft, taking\r\n'b'their pickaxes, soon made it of a suitable height.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer then approached, and found that the sides of the opening,\r\n'b'in its upper part at least, had not a slope of more than from thirty to\r\n'b'thirty-five degrees. It was therefore practicable, and, provided that\r\n'b'the declivity did not increase, it would be easy to descend even to the\r\n'b'level of the sea. If then, as was probable, some vast cavity existed in\r\n'b'the interior of the granite, it might, perhaps, be of great use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, captain, what are we stopping for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor, impatient\r\n'b'to enter the narrow passage. \xe2\x80\x9cYou see Top has got before us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cBut we must see our way. Neb, go and\r\n'b'cut some resinous branches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb and Herbert ran to the edge of the lake, shaded with pines and other\r\n'b'green trees, and soon returned with some branches, which they made\r\n'b'into torches. The torches were lighted with flint and steel, and Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding leading, the settlers ventured into the dark passage, which the\r\n'b'overplus of the lake had formerly filled.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Contrary to what might have been supposed, the diameter of the passage\r\n'b'increased as the explorers proceeded, so that they very soon were able\r\n'b'to stand upright. The granite, worn by the water for an infinite time,\r\n'b'was very slippery, and falls were to be dreaded. But the settlers were\r\n'b'all attached to each other by a cord, as is frequently done in ascending\r\n'b'mountains. Happily some projections of the granite, forming regular\r\n'b'steps, made the descent less perilous. Drops, still hanging from the\r\n'b'rocks, shone here and there under the light of the torches, and\r\n'b'the explorers guessed that the sides were clothed with innumerable\r\n'b'stalactites. The engineer examined this black granite. There was not a\r\n'b'stratum, not a break in it. The mass was compact, and of an extremely\r\n'b'close grain. The passage dated, then, from the very origin of the\r\n'b'island. It was not the water which little by little had hollowed it.\r\n'b'Pluto and not Neptune had bored it with his own hand, and on the wall\r\n'b'traces of an eruptive work could be distinguished, which all the washing\r\n'b'of the water had not been able totally to efface.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers descended very slowly. They could not but feel a certain\r\n'b'awe, in this venturing into these unknown depths, for the first time\r\n'b'visited by human beings. They did not speak, but they thought; and\r\n'b'the thought came to more than one, that some polypus or other\r\n'b'gigantic cephalopod might inhabit the interior cavities, which were in\r\n'b'communication with the sea. However, Top kept at the head of the little\r\n'b'band, and they could rely on the sagacity of the dog, who would not fail\r\n'b'to give the alarm if there was any need for it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After having descended about a hundred feet, following a winding road,\r\n'b'Harding who was walking on before, stopped, and his companions came up\r\n'b'with him. The place where they had halted was wider, so as to form a\r\n'b'cavern of moderate dimensions. Drops of water fell from the vault, but\r\n'b'that did not prove that they oozed through the rock. They were simply\r\n'b'the last traces left by the torrent which had so long thundered through\r\n'b'this cavity, and the air there was pure though slightly damp, but\r\n'b'producing no mephitic exhalation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a very secure\r\n'b'retreat, well hid in the depths of the rock, but it is, however,\r\n'b'uninhabitable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy uninhabitable?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause it is too small and too dark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t we enlarge it, hollow it out, make openings to let in light\r\n'b'and air?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, who now thought nothing impossible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go on with our exploration,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps lower\r\n'b'down, nature will have spared us this labor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe have only gone a third of the way,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNearly a third,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cfor we have descended a hundred feet\r\n'b'from the opening, and it is not impossible that a hundred feet farther\r\n'b'down--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Top?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb, interrupting his master.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They searched the cavern, but the dog was not there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMost likely he has gone on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us join him,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The descent was continued. The engineer carefully observed all the\r\n'b'deviations of the passage, and notwithstanding so many detours, he\r\n'b'could easily have given an account of its general direction, which went\r\n'b'towards the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers had gone some fifty feet farther, when their attention was\r\n'b'attracted by distant sounds which came up from the depths. They stopped\r\n'b'and listened. These sounds, carried through the passage as through an\r\n'b'acoustic tube, came clearly to the ear.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is Top barking!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand our brave dog is barking furiously!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe have our iron-tipped spears,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cKeep on your\r\n'b'guard, and forward!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is becoming more and more interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Gideon Spilett in\r\n'b'the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s ear, who nodded. Harding and his companions rushed to the\r\n'b'help of their dog. Top\xe2\x80\x99s barking became more and more perceptible,\r\n'b'and it seemed strangely fierce. Was he engaged in a struggle with some\r\n'b'animal whose retreat he had disturbed? Without thinking of the danger\r\n'b'to which they might be exposed, the explorers were now impelled by an\r\n'b'irresistible curiosity, and in a few minutes, sixteen feet lower they\r\n'b'rejoined Top.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There the passage ended in a vast and magnificent cavern.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top was running backwards and forwards, barking furiously. Pencroft and\r\n'b'Neb, waving their torches, threw the light into every crevice; and\r\n'b'at the same time, Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert, their spears\r\n'b'raised, were ready for any emergency which might arise. The enormous\r\n'b'cavern was empty. The settlers explored it in every direction. There was\r\n'b'nothing there, not an animal, not a human being; and yet Top continued\r\n'b'to bark. Neither caresses nor threats could make him be silent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere must be a place somewhere, by which the waters of the lake\r\n'b'reached the sea,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand we must take care not to tumble into\r\n'b'a hole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGo, Top, go!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The dog, excited by his master\xe2\x80\x99s words, ran towards the extremity of the\r\n'b'cavern, and there redoubled his barking.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They followed him, and by the light of the torches, perceived the mouth\r\n'b'of a regular well in the granite. It was by this that the water escaped;\r\n'b'and this time it was not an oblique and practicable passage, but a\r\n'b'perpendicular well, into which it was impossible to venture.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The torches were held over the opening: nothing could be seen. Harding\r\n'b'took a lighted branch, and threw it into the abyss. The blazing resin,\r\n'b'whose illuminating power increased still more by the rapidity of its\r\n'b'fall, lighted up the interior of the well, but yet nothing appeared. The\r\n'b'flame then went out with a slight hiss, which showed that it had reached\r\n'b'the water, that is to say, the level of the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, calculating the time employed in its fall, was able to\r\n'b'calculate the depth of the well, which was found to be about ninety\r\n'b'feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The floor of the cavern must thus be situated ninety feet above the\r\n'b'level of the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere is our dwelling,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was occupied by some creature,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, whose\r\n'b'curiosity was not yet satisfied.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the creature, amphibious or otherwise, has made off through this\r\n'b'opening,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand has left the place for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d added the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI should like very much to be Top just\r\n'b'for a quarter of an hour, for he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t bark for nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding looked at his dog, and those of his companions who were\r\n'b'near him might have heard him murmur these words,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I believe that Top knows more than we do about a great many\r\n'b'things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the wishes of the settlers were for the most part satisfied.\r\n'b'Chance, aided by the marvelous sagacity of their leader, had done them\r\n'b'great service. They had now at their disposal a vast cavern, the size\r\n'b'of which could not be properly calculated by the feeble light of their\r\n'b'torches, but it would certainly be easy to divide it into rooms, by\r\n'b'means of brick partitions, or to use it, if not as a house, at least as\r\n'b'a spacious apartment. The water which had left it could not return. The\r\n'b'place was free.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two difficulties remained; firstly, the possibility of lighting this\r\n'b'excavation in the midst of solid rock; secondly, the necessity of\r\n'b'rendering the means of access more easy. It was useless to think of\r\n'b'lighting it from above, because of the enormous thickness of the granite\r\n'b'which composed the ceiling; but perhaps the outer wall next the sea\r\n'b'might be pierced. Cyrus Harding, during the descent, had roughly\r\n'b'calculated its obliqueness, and consequently the length of the passage,\r\n'b'and was therefore led to believe that the outer wall could not be very\r\n'b'thick. If light was thus obtained, so would a means of access, for\r\n'b'it would be as easy to pierce a door as windows, and to establish an\r\n'b'exterior ladder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding made known his ideas to his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, captain, let us set to work!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cI have my\r\n'b'pickaxe, and I shall soon make my way through this wall. Where shall I\r\n'b'strike?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, showing the sturdy sailor a considerable\r\n'b'recess in the side, which would much diminish the thickness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft attacked the granite, and for half an hour, by the light of the\r\n'b'torches, he made the splinters fly around him. Neb relieved him, then\r\n'b'Spilett took Neb\xe2\x80\x99s place.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This work had lasted two hours, and they began to fear that at this spot\r\n'b'the wall would not yield to the pickaxe, when at a last blow given by\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, the instrument, passing through the rock, fell outside.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah! hurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The wall only measured there three feet in thickness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding applied his eye to the aperture, which overlooked the ground\r\n'b'from a height of eighty feet. Before him was extended the sea-coast, the\r\n'b'islet, and beyond the open sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Floods of light entered by this hole, inundating the splendid cavern and\r\n'b'producing a magic effect! On its left side it did not measure more than\r\n'b'thirty feet in height and breadth, but on the right it was enormous, and\r\n'b'its vaulted roof rose to a height of more than eighty feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In some places granite pillars, irregularly disposed, supported the\r\n'b'vaulted roof, as those in the nave of a cathedral, here forming lateral\r\n'b'piers, there elliptical arches, adorned with pointed moldings, losing\r\n'b'themselves in dark bays, amid the fantastic arches of which glimpses\r\n'b'could be caught in the shade, covered with a profusion of projections\r\n'b'formed like so many pendants. This cavern was a picturesque mixture of\r\n'b'all the styles of Byzantine, Roman, or Gothic architecture ever produced\r\n'b'by the hand of man. And yet this was only the work of nature. She alone\r\n'b'had hollowed this fairy Alhambra in a mass of granite.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers were overwhelmed with admiration. Where they had only\r\n'b'expected to find a narrow cavity, they had found a sort of marvelous\r\n'b'palace, and Neb had taken off his hat, as if he had been transported\r\n'b'into a temple!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cries of admiration issued from every mouth. Hurrahs resounded, and the\r\n'b'echo was repeated again and again till it died away in the dark naves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my friends!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen we have lighted the\r\n'b'interior of this place, and have arranged our rooms and storehouses in\r\n'b'the left part, we shall still have this splendid cavern, which we will\r\n'b'make our study and our museum!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we will call it?--\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGranite House,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding; a name which his companions again\r\n'b'saluted with a cheer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The torches were now almost consumed, and as they were obliged to return\r\n'b'by the passage to reach the summit of the plateau, it was decided to put\r\n'b'off the work necessary for the arrangement of their new dwelling till\r\n'b'the next day.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Before departing, Cyrus Harding leaned once more over the dark well,\r\n'b'which descended perpendicularly to the level of the sea. He listened\r\n'b'attentively. No noise was heard, not even that of the water, which the\r\n'b'undulations of the surge must sometimes agitate in its depths. A flaming\r\n'b'branch was again thrown in. The sides of the well were lighted up for an\r\n'b'instant, but as at the first time, nothing suspicious was seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'If some marine monster had been surprised unawares by the retreat of the\r\n'b'water, he would by this time have regained the sea by the subterranean\r\n'b'passage, before the new opening had been offered to him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, the engineer was standing motionless, his eyes fixed on the\r\n'b'gulf, without uttering a word.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor approached him, and touching his arm, \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer, as if he had returned\r\n'b'from the land of dreams.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe torches will soon go out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The little band left the cavern and began to ascend through the dark\r\n'b'passage. Top closed the rear, still growling every now and then. The\r\n'b'ascent was painful enough. The settlers rested a few minutes in the\r\n'b'upper grotto, which made a sort of landing-place halfway up the long\r\n'b'granite staircase. Then they began to climb again.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Soon fresher air was felt. The drops of water, dried by evaporation, no\r\n'b'longer sparkled on the walls. The flaring torches began to grow dim. The\r\n'b'one which Neb carried went out, and if they did not wish to find their\r\n'b'way in the dark, they must hasten.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was done, and a little before four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, at the moment when the\r\n'b'sailor\xe2\x80\x99s torch went out in its turn, Cyrus Harding and his companions\r\n'b'passed out of the passage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 19\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 22nd of May, the arrangement of their new dwelling\r\n'b'was commenced. In fact, the settlers longed to exchange the insufficient\r\n'b'shelter of the Chimneys for this large and healthy retreat, in the midst\r\n'b'of solid rock, and sheltered from the water both of the sea and sky.\r\n'b'Their former dwelling was not, however, to be entirely abandoned, for\r\n'b'the engineer intended to make a manufactory of it for important works.\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s first care was to find out the position of the front of\r\n'b'Granite House from the outside. He went to the beach, and as the\r\n'b'pickaxe when it escaped from the hands of the reporter must have fallen\r\n'b'perpendicularly to the foot of the cliff, the finding it would be\r\n'b'sufficient to show the place where the hole had been pierced in the\r\n'b'granite.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The pickaxe was easily found, and the hole could be seen in a\r\n'b'perpendicular line above the spot where it was stuck in the sand. Some\r\n'b'rock pigeons were already flying in and out of the narrow opening; they\r\n'b'evidently thought that Granite House had been discovered on purpose for\r\n'b'them. It was the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s intention to divide the right portion of the\r\n'b'cavern into several rooms, preceded by an entrance passage, and to light\r\n'b'it by means of five windows and a door, pierced in the front. Pencroft\r\n'b'was much pleased with the five windows, but he could not understand the\r\n'b'use of the door, since the passage offered a natural staircase, through\r\n'b'which it would always be easy to enter Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cif it is easy for us to reach our\r\n'b'dwelling by this passage, it will be equally easy for others besides\r\n'b'us. I mean, on the contrary, to block up that opening, to seal it\r\n'b'hermetically, and, if it is necessary, to completely hide the entrance\r\n'b'by making a dam, and thus causing the water of the lake to rise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how shall we get in?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy an outside ladder,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9ca rope ladder, which,\r\n'b'once drawn up, will render access to our dwelling impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut why so many precautions?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cAs yet we have seen no\r\n'b'dangerous animals. As to our island being inhabited by natives, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n'b'believe it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite sure of that, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer, looking at\r\n'b'the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOf course we shall not be quite sure, till we have explored it in every\r\n'b'direction,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cfor we know only a small portion of it as yet. But\r\n'b'at any rate, if we have no enemies in the interior, they may come from\r\n'b'the exterior, for parts of the Pacific are very dangerous. We must be\r\n'b'provided against every contingency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding spoke wisely; and without making any further objection,\r\n'b'Pencroft prepared to execute his orders.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The front of Granite House was then to be lighted by five windows and a\r\n'b'door, besides a large bay window and some smaller oval ones, which would\r\n'b'admit plenty of light to enter into the marvelous nave which was to be\r\n'b'their chief room. This facade, situated at a height of eighty feet above\r\n'b'the ground, was exposed to the east, and the rising sun saluted it with\r\n'b'its first rays. It was found to be just at that part of the cliff which\r\n'b'was between the projection at the mouth of the Mercy and a perpendicular\r\n'b'line traced above the heap of rocks which formed the Chimneys. Thus\r\n'b'the winds from the northeast would only strike it obliquely, for it was\r\n'b'protected by the projection. Besides, until the window-frames were made,\r\n'b'the engineer meant to close the openings with thick shutters, which\r\n'b'would prevent either wind or rain from entering, and which could be\r\n'b'concealed in need.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first work was to make the openings. This would have taken too long\r\n'b'with the pickaxe alone, and it is known that Harding was an ingenious\r\n'b'man. He had still a quantity of nitro-glycerine at his disposal, and he\r\n'b'employed it usefully. By means of this explosive substance the rock was\r\n'b'broken open at the very places chosen by the engineer. Then, with the\r\n'b'pickaxe and spade, the windows and doors were properly shaped, the\r\n'b'jagged edges were smoothed off, and a few days after the beginning of\r\n'b'the work, Granite House was abundantly lighted by the rising sun,\r\n'b'whose rays penetrated into its most secret recesses. Following the\r\n'b'plan proposed by Cyrus Harding, the space was to be divided into five\r\n'b'compartments looking out on the sea; to the right, an entry with a\r\n'b'door, which would meet the ladder; then a kitchen, thirty feet long; a\r\n'b'dining-room, measuring forty feet; a sleeping-room, of equal size; and\r\n'b'lastly, a \xe2\x80\x9cVisitor\xe2\x80\x99s room,\xe2\x80\x9d petitioned for by Pencroft, and which was\r\n'b'next to the great hall. These rooms, or rather this suite of rooms,\r\n'b'would not occupy all the depth of the cave. There would be also a\r\n'b'corridor and a storehouse, in which their tools, provisions, and stores\r\n'b'would be kept. All the productions of the island, the flora as well as\r\n'b'the fauna, were to be there in the best possible state of preservation,\r\n'b'and completely sheltered from the damp. There was no want of space, so\r\n'b'that each object could be methodically arranged. Besides, the colonists\r\n'b'had still at their disposal the little grotto above the great cavern,\r\n'b'which was like the garret of the new dwelling.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This plan settled, it had only to be put into execution. The miners\r\n'b'became brickmakers again, then the bricks were brought to the foot of\r\n'b'Granite House. Till then, Harding and his companions had only entered\r\n'b'the cavern by the long passage. This mode of communication obliged them\r\n'b'first to climb Prospect Heights, making a detour by the river\xe2\x80\x99s bank,\r\n'b'and then to descend two hundred feet through the passage, having to\r\n'b'climb as far when they wished to return to the plateau. This was a great\r\n'b'loss of time, and was also very fatiguing. Cyrus Harding, therefore,\r\n'b'resolved to proceed without any further delay to the fabrication of\r\n'b'a strong rope ladder, which, once raised, would render Granite House\r\n'b'completely inaccessible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This ladder was manufactured with extreme care, and its uprights, formed\r\n'b'of the twisted fibers of a species of cane, had the strength of a thick\r\n'b'cable. As to the rounds, they were made of a sort of red cedar, with\r\n'b'light, strong branches; and this apparatus was wrought by the masterly\r\n'b'hand of Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Other ropes were made with vegetable fibers, and a sort of crane with a\r\n'b'tackle was fixed at the door. In this way bricks could easily be\r\n'b'raised into Granite House. The transport of the materials being thus\r\n'b'simplified, the arrangement of the interior could begin immediately.\r\n'b'There was no want of lime, and some thousands of bricks were there\r\n'b'ready to be used. The framework of the partitions was soon raised, very\r\n'b'roughly at first, and in a short time, the cave was divided into rooms\r\n'b'and storehouses, according to the plan agreed upon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These different works progressed rapidly under the direction of the\r\n'b'engineer, who himself handled the hammer and the trowel. No labor came\r\n'b'amiss to Cyrus Harding, who thus set an example to his intelligent and\r\n'b'zealous companions. They worked with confidence, even gaily, Pencroft\r\n'b'always having some joke to crack, sometimes carpenter, sometimes\r\n'b'rope-maker, sometimes mason, while he communicated his good humor to\r\n'b'all the members of their little world. His faith in the engineer\r\n'b'was complete; nothing could disturb it. He believed him capable of\r\n'b'undertaking anything and succeeding in everything. The question of boots\r\n'b'and clothes--assuredly a serious question,--that of light during the\r\n'b'winter months, utilizing the fertile parts of the island, transforming\r\n'b'the wild flora into cultivated flora, it all appeared easy to him; Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding helping, everything would be done in time. He dreamed of canals\r\n'b'facilitating the transport of the riches of the ground; workings\r\n'b'of quarries and mines; machines for every industrial manufacture;\r\n'b'railroads; yes, railroads! of which a network would certainly one day\r\n'b'cover Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer let Pencroft talk. He did not put down the aspirations of\r\n'b'this brave heart. He knew how communicable confidence is; he even smiled\r\n'b'to hear him speak, and said nothing of the uneasiness for the future\r\n'b'which he felt. In fact, in that part of the Pacific, out of the course\r\n'b'of vessels, it was to be feared that no help would ever come to them. It\r\n'b'was on themselves, on themselves alone, that the settlers must depend,\r\n'b'for the distance of Lincoln Island from all other land was such, that\r\n'b'to hazard themselves in a boat, of a necessarily inferior construction,\r\n'b'would be a serious and perilous thing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d as the sailor said, \xe2\x80\x9cthey quite took the wind out of the sails of\r\n'b'the Robinsons, for whom everything was done by a miracle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, they were energetic; an energetic man will succeed where an\r\n'b'indolent one would vegetate and inevitably perish.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert distinguished himself in these works. He was intelligent and\r\n'b'active; understanding quickly, he performed well; and Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'became more and more attached to the boy. Herbert had a lively and\r\n'b'reverent love for the engineer. Pencroft saw the close sympathy which\r\n'b'existed between the two, but he was not in the least jealous. Neb\r\n'b'was Neb: he was what he would be always, courage, zeal, devotion,\r\n'b'self-denial personified. He had the same faith in his master that\r\n'b'Pencroft had, but he showed it less vehemently. When the sailor was\r\n'b'enthusiastic, Neb always looked as if he would say, \xe2\x80\x9cNothing could be\r\n'b'more natural.\xe2\x80\x9d Pencroft and he were great friends.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Gideon Spilett, he took part in the common work, and was not less\r\n'b'skilful in it than his companions, which always rather astonished\r\n'b'the sailor. A \xe2\x80\x9cjournalist,\xe2\x80\x9d clever, not only in understanding, but in\r\n'b'performing everything.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The ladder was finally fixed on the 28th of May. There were not less\r\n'b'than a hundred rounds in this perpendicular height of eighty feet.\r\n'b'Harding had been able, fortunately, to divide it in two parts, profiting\r\n'b'by an overhanging of the cliff which made a projection forty feet above\r\n'b'the ground. This projection, carefully leveled by the pickaxe, made a\r\n'b'sort of platform, to which they fixed the first ladder, of which the\r\n'b'oscillation was thus diminished one-half, and a rope permitted it to be\r\n'b'raised to the level of Granite House. As to the second ladder, it was\r\n'b'secured both at its lower part, which rested on the projection, and at\r\n'b'its upper end, which was fastened to the door. In short the ascent had\r\n'b'been made much easier. Besides, Cyrus Harding hoped later to establish\r\n'b'an hydraulic apparatus, which would avoid all fatigue and loss of time,\r\n'b'for the inhabitants of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers soon became habituated to the use of this ladder. They were\r\n'b'light and active, and Pencroft, as a sailor, accustomed to run up\r\n'b'the masts and shrouds, was able to give them lessons. But it was also\r\n'b'necessary to give them to Top. The poor dog, with his four paws, was\r\n'b'not formed for this sort of exercise. But Pencroft was such a zealous\r\n'b'master, that Top ended by properly performing his ascents, and soon\r\n'b'mounted the ladder as readily as his brethren in the circus. It need not\r\n'b'be said that the sailor was proud of his pupil. However, more than once\r\n'b'Pencroft hoisted him on his back, which Top never complained of.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It must be mentioned here, that during these works, which were actively\r\n'b'conducted, for the bad season was approaching, the alimentary question\r\n'b'was not neglected. Every day, the reporter and Herbert, who had been\r\n'b'voted purveyors to the colony, devoted some hours to the chase. As yet,\r\n'b'they only hunted in Jacamar Wood, on the left of the river, because, for\r\n'b'want of a bridge or boat, the Mercy had not yet been crossed. All the\r\n'b'immense woods, to which the name of the Forests of the Far West had been\r\n'b'given, were not explored. They reserved this important excursion for the\r\n'b'first fine days of the next spring. But Jacamar Wood was full of game;\r\n'b'kangaroos and boars abounded, and the hunters\xe2\x80\x99 iron-tipped spears and\r\n'b'bows and arrows did wonders. Besides, Herbert discovered towards the\r\n'b'southwest point of the lagoon a natural warren, a slightly damp meadow,\r\n'b'covered with willows and aromatic herbs which scented the air, such\r\n'b'as thyme, basil, savory, all the sweet-scented species of the labiated\r\n'b'plants, which the rabbits appeared to be particularly fond of.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the reporter observing that since the table was spread for the\r\n'b'rabbits, it was strange that the rabbits themselves should be wanting,\r\n'b'the two sportsmen carefully explored the warren. At any rate, it\r\n'b'produced an abundance of useful plants, and a naturalist would have had\r\n'b'a good opportunity of studying many specimens of the vegetable kingdom.\r\n'b'Herbert gathered several shoots of the basil, rosemary, balm, betony,\r\n'b'etc., which possess different medicinal properties, some pectoral,\r\n'b'astringent, febrifuge, others anti-spasmodic, or anti-rheumatic. When,\r\n'b'afterwards, Pencroft asked the use of this collection of herbs,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor medicine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the lad, \xe2\x80\x9cto treat us when we are ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should we be ill, since there are no doctors in the island?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\n'b'Pencroft quite seriously.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no reply to be made to that, but the lad went on with his\r\n'b'collection all the same, and it was well received at Granite House.\r\n'b'Besides these medicinal herbs, he added a plant known in North America\r\n'b'as \xe2\x80\x9cOswego tea,\xe2\x80\x9d which made an excellent beverage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last, by searching thoroughly, the hunters arrived at the real site\r\n'b'of the warren. There the ground was perforated like a sieve.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere are the burrows!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cso I see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut are they inhabited?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was soon answered. Almost immediately, hundreds of little animals,\r\n'b'similar to rabbits, fled in every direction, with such rapidity that\r\n'b'even Top could not overtake them. Hunters and dog ran in vain; these\r\n'b'rodents escaped them easily. But the reporter resolved not to leave the\r\n'b'place, until he had captured at least half-a-dozen of the quadrupeds.\r\n'b'He wished to stock their larder first, and domesticate those which they\r\n'b'might take later. It would not have been difficult to do this, with a\r\n'b'few snares stretched at the openings of the burrows. But at this moment\r\n'b'they had neither snares, nor anything to make them of. They must,\r\n'b'therefore, be satisfied with visiting each hole, and rummaging in it\r\n'b'with a stick, hoping by dint of patience to do what could not be done in\r\n'b'any other way.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last, after half an hour, four rodents were taken in their holes.\r\n'b'They were similar to their European brethren, and are commonly known by\r\n'b'the name of American rabbits.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This produce of the chase was brought back to Granite House, and figured\r\n'b'at the evening repast. The tenants of the warren were not at all to be\r\n'b'despised, for they were delicious. It was a valuable resource of the\r\n'b'colony, and it appeared to be inexhaustible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 31st of May the partitions were finished. The rooms had now only\r\n'b'to be furnished, and this would be work for the long winter days. A\r\n'b'chimney was established in the first room, which served as a kitchen.\r\n'b'The pipe destined to conduct the smoke outside gave some trouble to\r\n'b'these amateur bricklayers. It appeared simplest to Harding to make it of\r\n'b'brick clay; as creating an outlet for it to the upper plateau was not to\r\n'b'be thought of, a hole was pierced in the granite above the window of\r\n'b'the kitchen, and the pipe met it like that of an iron stove. Perhaps\r\n'b'the winds which blew directly against the facade would make the chimney\r\n'b'smoke, but these winds were rare, and besides, Master Neb, the cook, was\r\n'b'not so very particular about that.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When these interior arrangements were finished, the engineer occupied\r\n'b'himself in blocking up the outlet by the lake, so as to prevent any\r\n'b'access by that way. Masses of rock were rolled to the entrance and\r\n'b'strongly cemented together. Cyrus Harding did not yet realize his plan\r\n'b'of drowning this opening under the waters of the lake, by restoring\r\n'b'them to their former level by means of a dam. He contented himself with\r\n'b'hiding the obstruction with grass and shrubs, which were planted in the\r\n'b'interstices of the rocks, and which next spring would sprout thickly.\r\n'b'However, he used the waterfall so as to lead a small stream of fresh\r\n'b'water to the new dwelling. A little trench, made below their level,\r\n'b'produced this result; and this derivation from a pure and inexhaustible\r\n'b'source yielded twenty-five or thirty gallons a day. There would never be\r\n'b'any want of water at Granite House. At last all was finished, and it was\r\n'b'time, for the bad season was near. Thick shutters closed the windows of\r\n'b'the facade, until the engineer had time to make glass.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett had very artistically arranged on the rocky projections\r\n'b'around the windows plants of different kinds, as well as long streaming\r\n'b'grass, so that the openings were picturesquely framed in green, which\r\n'b'had a pleasing effect.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The inhabitants of this solid, healthy, and secure dwelling, could not\r\n'b'but be charmed with their work. The view from the windows extended over\r\n'b'a boundless horizon, which was closed by the two Mandible Capes on the\r\n'b'north, and Claw Cape on the south. All Union Bay was spread before them.\r\n'b'Yes, our brave settlers had reason to be satisfied, and Pencroft was\r\n'b'lavish in his praise of what he humorously called, \xe2\x80\x9chis apartments on\r\n'b'the fifth floor above the ground!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 20\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The winter season set in with the month of June, which corresponds with\r\n'b'the month of December in the Northern Hemisphere. It began with showers\r\n'b'and squalls, which succeeded each other without intermission. The\r\n'b'tenants of Granite House could appreciate the advantages of a dwelling\r\n'b'which sheltered them from the inclement weather. The Chimneys would have\r\n'b'been quite insufficient to protect them against the rigor of winter, and\r\n'b'it was to be feared that the high tides would make another irruption.\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had taken precautions against this contingency, so as\r\n'b'to preserve as much as possible the forge and furnace which were\r\n'b'established there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the whole of the month of June the time was employed in different\r\n'b'occupations, which excluded neither hunting nor fishing, the larder\r\n'b'being, therefore, abundantly supplied. Pencroft, so soon as he had\r\n'b'leisure, proposed to set some traps, from which he expected great\r\n'b'results. He soon made some snares with creepers, by the aid of which the\r\n'b'warren henceforth every day furnished its quota of rodents. Neb employed\r\n'b'nearly all his time in salting or smoking meat, which insured their\r\n'b'always having plenty of provisions. The question of clothes was now\r\n'b'seriously discussed, the settlers having no other garments than those\r\n'b'they wore when the balloon threw them on the island. These clothes were\r\n'b'warm and good; they had taken great care of them as well as of their\r\n'b'linen, and they were perfectly whole, but they would soon need to be\r\n'b'replaced. Moreover, if the winter was severe, the settlers would suffer\r\n'b'greatly from cold.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this subject the ingenuity of Harding was at fault. They must provide\r\n'b'for their most pressing wants, settle their dwelling, and lay in a\r\n'b'store of food; thus the cold might come upon them before the question\r\n'b'of clothes had been settled. They must therefore make up their minds to\r\n'b'pass this first winter without additional clothing. When the fine season\r\n'b'came round again, they would regularly hunt those musmons which had been\r\n'b'seen on the expedition to Mount Franklin, and the wool once collected,\r\n'b'the engineer would know how to make it into strong warm stuff.... How?\r\n'b'He would consider.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we are free to roast ourselves at Granite House!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere are heaps of fuel, and no reason for sparing it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d added Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cLincoln Island is not situated under\r\n'b'a very high latitude, and probably the winters here are not severe. Did\r\n'b'you not say, Cyrus, that this thirty-fifth parallel corresponded to that\r\n'b'of Spain in the other hemisphere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut some winters in Spain are very\r\n'b'cold! No want of snow and ice; and perhaps Lincoln Island is just as\r\n'b'rigorously tried. However, it is an island, and as such, I hope that\r\n'b'the temperature will be more moderate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the sea, my boy, may be considered as an immense reservoir, in\r\n'b'which is stored the heat of the summer. When winter comes, it restores\r\n'b'this heat, which insures for the regions near the ocean a medium\r\n'b'temperature, less high in summer, but less low in winter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall prove that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to bother\r\n'b'myself about whether it will be cold or not. One thing is certain, that\r\n'b'is that the days are already short, and the evenings long. Suppose we\r\n'b'talk about the question of light.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is easier,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo talk about?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo settle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when shall we begin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow, by having a seal hunt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo make candles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Such was the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s project; and it was quite feasible, since he had\r\n'b'lime and sulphuric acid, while the amphibians of the islet would furnish\r\n'b'the fat necessary for the manufacture.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were now at the 4th of June. It was Whit Sunday and they agreed to\r\n'b'observe this feast. All work was suspended, and prayers were offered\r\n'b'to Heaven. But these prayers were now thanksgivings. The settlers in\r\n'b'Lincoln Island were no longer the miserable castaways thrown on the\r\n'b'islet. They asked for nothing more--they gave thanks. The next day, the\r\n'b'5th of June, in rather uncertain weather, they set out for the islet.\r\n'b'They had to profit by the low tide to cross the Channel, and it was\r\n'b'agreed that they would construct, for this purpose, as well as they\r\n'b'could, a boat which would render communication so much easier, and\r\n'b'would also permit them to ascend the Mercy, at the time of their grand\r\n'b'exploration of the southwest of the island, which was put off till the\r\n'b'first fine days.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The seals were numerous, and the hunters, armed with their iron-tipped\r\n'b'spears, easily killed half-a-dozen. Neb and Pencroft skinned them, and\r\n'b'only brought back to Granite House their fat and skin, this skin being\r\n'b'intended for the manufacture of boots.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The result of the hunt was this: nearly three hundred pounds of fat, all\r\n'b'to be employed in the fabrication of candles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The operation was extremely simple, and if it did not yield absolutely\r\n'b'perfect results, they were at least very useful. Cyrus Harding would\r\n'b'only have had at his disposal sulphuric acid, but by heating this acid\r\n'b'with the neutral fatty bodies he could separate the glycerine; then from\r\n'b'this new combination, he easily separated the olein, the margarin, and\r\n'b'the stearin, by employing boiling water. But to simplify the operation,\r\n'b'he preferred to saponify the fat by means of lime. By this he obtained a\r\n'b'calcareous soap, easy to decompose by sulphuric acid, which precipitated\r\n'b'the lime into the state of sulphate, and liberated the fatty acids.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From these three acids-oleic, margaric, and stearic-the first, being\r\n'b'liquid, was driven out by a sufficient pressure. As to the two others,\r\n'b'they formed the very substance of which the candles were to be molded.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This operation did not last more than four and twenty hours. The wicks,\r\n'b'after several trials, were made of vegetable fibers, and dipped in the\r\n'b'liquefied substance, they formed regular stearic candles, molded by the\r\n'b'hand, which only wanted whiteness and polish. They would not doubtless\r\n'b'have the advantages of the wicks which are impregnated with boracic\r\n'b'acid, and which vitrify as they burn and are entirely consumed, but\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding having manufactured a beautiful pair of snuffers, these\r\n'b'candles would be greatly appreciated during the long evenings in Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this month there was no want of work in the interior of their new\r\n'b'dwelling. The joiners had plenty to do. They improved their tools, which\r\n'b'were very rough, and added others also.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Scissors were made among other things, and the settlers were at last\r\n'b'able to cut their hair, and also to shave, or at least trim their\r\n'b'beards. Herbert had none, Neb but little, but their companions were\r\n'b'bristling in a way which justified the making of the said scissors.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The manufacture of a hand-saw cost infinite trouble, but at last an\r\n'b'instrument was obtained which, when vigorously handled, could divide the\r\n'b'ligneous fibers of the wood. They then made tables, seats, cupboards,\r\n'b'to furnish the principal rooms, and bedsteads, of which all the bedding\r\n'b'consisted of grass mattresses. The kitchen, with its shelves, on which\r\n'b'rested the cooking utensils, its brick stove, looked very well, and Neb\r\n'b'worked away there as earnestly as if he was in a chemist\xe2\x80\x99s laboratory.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the joiners had soon to be replaced by carpenters. In fact, the\r\n'b'waterfall created by the explosion rendered the construction of two\r\n'b'bridges necessary, one on Prospect Heights, the other on the shore. Now\r\n'b'the plateau and the shore were transversely divided by a watercourse,\r\n'b'which had to be crossed to reach the northern part of the island. To\r\n'b'avoid it the colonists had been obliged to make a considerable detour,\r\n'b'by climbing up to the source of the Red Creek. The simplest thing was to\r\n'b'establish on the plateau, and on the shore, two bridges from twenty to\r\n'b'five and twenty feet in length. All the carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s work that was needed\r\n'b'was to clear some trees of their branches: this was a business of some\r\n'b'days. Directly the bridges were established, Neb and Pencroft profited\r\n'b'by them to go to the oyster-bed which had been discovered near the\r\n'b'downs. They dragged with them a sort of rough cart, which replaced the\r\n'b'former inconvenient hurdle, and brought back some thousands of oysters,\r\n'b'which soon increased among the rocks and formed a bed at the mouth of\r\n'b'the Mercy. These molluscs were of excellent quality, and the colonists\r\n'b'consumed some daily.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It has been seen that Lincoln Island, although its inhabitants had as\r\n'b'yet only explored a small portion of it, already contributed to almost\r\n'b'all their wants. It was probable that if they hunted into its most\r\n'b'secret recesses, in all the wooded part between the Mercy and Reptile\r\n'b'Point, they would find new treasures.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers in Lincoln Island had still one privation. There was no\r\n'b'want of meat, nor of vegetable products; those ligneous roots which\r\n'b'they had found, when subjected to fermentation, gave them an acid drink,\r\n'b'which was preferable to cold water; they also made sugar, without canes\r\n'b'or beet-roots, by collecting the liquor which distils from the \xe2\x80\x9cacer\r\n'b'saceharinum,\xe2\x80\x9d a sort of maple-tree, which flourishes in all the temperate\r\n'b'zones, and of which the island possessed a great number; they made\r\n'b'a very agreeable tea by employing the herbs brought from the warren;\r\n'b'lastly, they had an abundance of salt, the only mineral which is used in\r\n'b'food... but bread was wanting.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Perhaps in time the settlers could replace this want by some equivalent,\r\n'b'it was possible that they might find the sago or the breadfruit tree\r\n'b'among the forests of the south, but they had not as yet met with these\r\n'b'precious trees.
