However, Providence came directly to their aid, in an\r\n'b'infinitesimal proportion it is true, but Cyrus Harding, with all his\r\n'b'intelligence, all his ingenuity, would never have been able to produce\r\n'b'that which, by the greatest chance, Herbert one day found in the lining\r\n'b'of his waistcoat, which he was occupied in setting to rights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this day, as it was raining in torrents, the settlers were assembled\r\n'b'in the great hall in Granite House, when the lad cried out all at\r\n'b'once,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook here, captain--A grain of corn!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And he showed his companions a grain--a single grain--which from a hole\r\n'b'in his pocket had got into the lining of his waistcoat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The presence of this grain was explained by the fact that Herbert, when\r\n'b'at Richmond, used to feed some pigeons, of which Pencroft had made him a\r\n'b'present.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA grain of corn?\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, captain; but one, only one!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99re getting on capitally,\r\n'b'upon my word! What shall we make with one grain of corn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will make bread of it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBread, cakes, tarts!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, the bread that this\r\n'b'grain of corn will make won\xe2\x80\x99t choke us very soon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, not attaching much importance to his discovery, was going to\r\n'b'throw away the grain in question; but Harding took it, examined it,\r\n'b'found that it was in good condition, and looking the sailor full in the\r\n'b'face--\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked quietly, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know how many ears one grain\r\n'b'of corn can produce?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne, I suppose!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, surprised at the question.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTen, Pencroft! And do you know how many grains one ear bears?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, upon my word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout eighty!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cThen, if we plant this grain, at\r\n'b'the first crop we shall reap eight hundred grains which at the second\r\n'b'will produce six hundred and forty thousand; at the third, five hundred\r\n'b'and twelve millions; at the fourth, more than four hundred thousands of\r\n'b'millions! There is the proportion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding\xe2\x80\x99s companions listened without answering. These numbers\r\n'b'astonished them. They were exact, however.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9csuch are the arithmetical\r\n'b'progressions of prolific nature; and yet what is this multiplication\r\n'b'of the grain of corn, of which the ear only bears eight hundred grains,\r\n'b'compared to the poppy-plant, which bears thirty-two thousand seeds; to\r\n'b'the tobacco-plant, which produces three hundred and sixty thousand? In\r\n'b'a few years, without the numerous causes of destruction, which arrests\r\n'b'their fecundity, these plants would overrun the earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the engineer had not finished his lecture.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know how many bushels four\r\n'b'hundred thousand millions of grains would make?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cbut what I do know is, that I am nothing\r\n'b'better than a fool!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, they would make more than three millions, at a hundred and thirty\r\n'b'thousand a bushel, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThree millions!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThree millions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn four years?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn four years,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand even in two years, if, as I\r\n'b'hope, in this latitude we can obtain two crops a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that, according to his usual custom, Pencroft could not reply\r\n'b'otherwise than by a tremendous hurrah.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo, Herbert,\xe2\x80\x9d added the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have made a discovery of great\r\n'b'importance to us. Everything, my friends, everything can serve us in the\r\n'b'condition in which we are. Do not forget that, I beg of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, captain, no, we shan\xe2\x80\x99t forget it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cand if ever\r\n'b'I find one of those tobacco-seeds, which multiply by three hundred and\r\n'b'sixty thousand, I assure you I won\xe2\x80\x99t throw it away! And now, what must\r\n'b'we do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must plant this grain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d added Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand with every possible care, for it bears\r\n'b'in itself our future harvests.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cProvided it grows!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt will grow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was the 20th of June. The time was then propitious for sowing this\r\n'b'single precious grain of corn. It was first proposed to plant it in\r\n'b'a pot, but upon reflection it was decided to leave it to nature, and\r\n'b'confide it to the earth. This was done that very day, and it is needless\r\n'b'to add, that every precaution was taken that the experiment might\r\n'b'succeed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The weather having cleared, the settlers climbed the height above\r\n'b'Granite House. There, on the plateau, they chose a spot, well sheltered\r\n'b'from the wind, and exposed to all the heat of the midday sun. The place\r\n'b'was cleared, carefully weeded, and searched for insects and worms;\r\n'b'then a bed of good earth, improved with a little lime, was made; it was\r\n'b'surrounded by a railing; and the grain was buried in the damp earth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Did it not seem as if the settlers were laying the first stone of some\r\n'b'edifice? It recalled to Pencroft the day on which he lighted his only\r\n'b'match, and all the anxiety of the operation. But this time the thing\r\n'b'was more serious. In fact, the castaways would have been always able\r\n'b'to procure fire, in some mode or other, but no human power could supply\r\n'b'another grain of corn, if unfortunately this should be lost!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 21\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From this time Pencroft did not let a single day pass without going to\r\n'b'visit what he gravely called his \xe2\x80\x9ccorn-field.\xe2\x80\x9d And woe to the insects\r\n'b'which dared to venture there! No mercy was shown them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards the end of the month of June, after incessant rain, the weather\r\n'b'became decidedly colder, and on the 29th a Fahrenheit thermometer\r\n'b'would certainly have announced only twenty degrees above zero, that is\r\n'b'considerably below the freezing-point. The next day, the 30th of June,\r\n'b'the day which corresponds to the 31st of December in the northern year,\r\n'b'was a Friday. Neb remarked that the year finished on a bad day, but\r\n'b'Pencroft replied that naturally the next would begin on a good one,\r\n'b'which was better.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At any rate it commenced by very severe cold. Ice accumulated at the\r\n'b'mouth of the Mercy, and it was not long before the whole expanse of the\r\n'b'lake was frozen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers had frequently been obliged to renew their store of wood.\r\n'b'Pencroft also had wisely not waited till the river was frozen, but had\r\n'b'brought enormous rafts of wood to their destination. The current was\r\n'b'an indefatigable moving power, and it was employed in conveying the\r\n'b'floating wood to the moment when the frost enchained it. To the fuel\r\n'b'which was so abundantly supplied by the forest, they added several\r\n'b'cartloads of coal, which had to be brought from the foot of the spurs of\r\n'b'Mount Franklin. The powerful heat of the coal was greatly appreciated in\r\n'b'the low temperature, which on the 4th of July fell to eight degrees of\r\n'b'Fahrenheit, that is, thirteen degrees below zero. A second fireplace had\r\n'b'been established in the dining-room, where they all worked together at\r\n'b'their different avocations. During this period of cold, Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'had great cause to congratulate himself on having brought to Granite\r\n'b'House the little stream of water from Lake Grant. Taken below the frozen\r\n'b'surface, and conducted through the passage, it preserved its fluidity,\r\n'b'and arrived at an interior reservoir which had been hollowed out at the\r\n'b'back part of the storeroom, while the overflow ran through the well to\r\n'b'the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About this time, the weather being extremely dry, the colonists, clothed\r\n'b'as warmly as possible, resolved to devote a day to the exploration of\r\n'b'that part of the island between the Mercy and Claw Cape. It was a wide\r\n'b'extent of marshy land, and they would probably find good sport, for\r\n'b'water-birds ought to swarm there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They reckoned that it would be about eight or nine miles to go there,\r\n'b'and as much to return, so that the whole of the day would be occupied.\r\n'b'As an unknown part of the island was about to be explored, the whole\r\n'b'colony took part in the expedition. Accordingly, on the 5th of July, at\r\n'b'six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, when day had scarcely broken, Cyrus Harding,\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft, armed with spears, snares,\r\n'b'bows and arrows, and provided with provisions, left Granite House,\r\n'b'preceded by Top, who bounded before them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their shortest way was to cross the Mercy on the ice, which then covered\r\n'b'it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d as the engineer justly observed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat could not take the place\r\n'b'of a regular bridge!\xe2\x80\x9d So, the construction of a regular bridge was noted\r\n'b'in the list of future works.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the first time that the settlers had set foot on the right bank\r\n'b'of the Mercy, and ventured into the midst of those gigantic and superb\r\n'b'coniferae now sprinkled over with snow.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But they had not gone half a mile when from a thicket a whole family of\r\n'b'quadrupeds, who had made a home there, disturbed by Top, rushed forth\r\n'b'into the open country.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh! I should say those are foxes!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, when he saw the troop\r\n'b'rapidly decamping.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were foxes, but of a very large size, who uttered a sort of\r\n'b'barking, at which Top seemed to be very much astonished, for he stopped\r\n'b'short in the chase, and gave the swift animals time to disappear.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The dog had reason to be surprised, as he did not know Natural History.\r\n'b'But, by their barking, these foxes, with reddish-gray hair, black tails\r\n'b'terminating in a white tuft, had betrayed their origin. So Herbert\r\n'b'was able, without hesitating, to give them their real name of \xe2\x80\x9cArctic\r\n'b'foxes.\xe2\x80\x9d They are frequently met with in Chile, in the Falkland Islands,\r\n'b'and in all parts of America traversed by the thirtieth and fortieth\r\n'b'parallels. Herbert much regretted that Top had not been able to catch\r\n'b'one of these carnivora.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre they good to eat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft, who only regarded the\r\n'b'representatives of the fauna in the island from one special point of\r\n'b'view.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9cbut zoologists have not yet found out if the\r\n'b'eye of these foxes is diurnal or nocturnal, or whether it is correct to\r\n'b'class them in the genus dog, properly so called.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding could not help smiling on hearing the lad\xe2\x80\x99s reflection, which\r\n'b'showed a thoughtful mind. As to the sailor, from the moment when he\r\n'b'found that the foxes were not classed in the genus eatable, they were\r\n'b'nothing to him. However, when a poultry-yard was established at Granite\r\n'b'House, he observed that it would be best to take some precautions\r\n'b'against a probable visit from these four-legged plunderers, and no one\r\n'b'disputed this.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After having turned the point, the settlers saw a long beach washed by\r\n'b'the open sea. It was then eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning. The sky was very\r\n'b'clear, as it often is after prolonged cold; but warmed by their walk,\r\n'b'neither Harding nor his companions felt the sharpness of the atmosphere\r\n'b'too severely. Besides there was no wind, which made it much more\r\n'b'bearable. A brilliant sun, but without any calorific action, was just\r\n'b'issuing from the ocean. The sea was as tranquil and blue as that of a\r\n'b'Mediterranean gulf, when the sky is clear. Claw Cape, bent in the form\r\n'b'of a yataghan, tapered away nearly four miles to the southeast. To\r\n'b'the left the edge of the marsh was abruptly ended by a little point.\r\n'b'Certainly, in this part of Union Bay, which nothing sheltered from the\r\n'b'open sea, not even a sandbank, ships beaten by the east winds would\r\n'b'have found no shelter. They perceived by the tranquillity of the sea, in\r\n'b'which no shallows troubled the waters, by its uniform color, which was\r\n'b'stained by no yellow shades, by the absence of even a reef, that the\r\n'b'coast was steep and that the ocean there covered a deep abyss. Behind in\r\n'b'the west, but at a distance of four miles, rose the first trees of the\r\n'b'forests of the Far West. They might have believed themselves to be on\r\n'b'the desolate coast of some island in the Antarctic regions which the ice\r\n'b'had invaded. The colonists halted at this place for breakfast. A fire of\r\n'b'brushwood and dried seaweed was lighted, and Neb prepared the breakfast\r\n'b'of cold meat, to which he added some cups of Oswego tea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While eating they looked around them. This part of Lincoln Island was\r\n'b'very sterile, and contrasted with all the western part. The reporter\r\n'b'was thus led to observe that if chance had thrown them at first on the\r\n'b'shore, they would have had but a deplorable idea of their future domain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI believe that we should not have been able to reach it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\n'b'engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the sea is deep, and there is not a rock on which we\r\n'b'could have taken refuge. Before Granite House, at least, there were\r\n'b'sandbanks, an islet, which multiplied our chances of safety. Here,\r\n'b'nothing but the depths!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is singular enough,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this comparatively\r\n'b'small island should present such varied ground. This diversity of\r\n'b'aspect, logically only belongs to continents of a certain extent. One\r\n'b'would really say, that the western part of Lincoln Island, so rich and\r\n'b'so fertile, is washed by the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico, and that\r\n'b'its shores to the north and the southeast extend over a sort of Arctic\r\n'b'sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, my dear Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cI have also\r\n'b'observed this. I think the form and also the nature of this island\r\n'b'strange. It is a summary of all the aspects which a continent presents,\r\n'b'and I should not be surprised if it was a continent formerly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! a continent in the middle of the Pacific?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy should not Australia, New\r\n'b'Ireland, Australasia, united to the archipelagoes of the Pacific, have\r\n'b'once formed a sixth part of the world, as important as Europe or Asia,\r\n'b'as Africa or the two Americas? To my mind, it is quite possible that all\r\n'b'these islands, emerging from this vast ocean, are but the summits of\r\n'b'a continent, now submerged, but which was above the waters at a\r\n'b'prehistoric period.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs the Atlantis was formerly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my boy... if, however, it existed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd would Lincoln Island have been a part of that continent?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\n'b'Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is probable,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand that would sufficiently,\r\n'b'explain the variety of productions which are seen on its surface.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the great number of animals which still inhabit it,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand you furnish me with an\r\n'b'argument to support my theory. It is certain, after what we have seen,\r\n'b'that animals are numerous in this island, and what is more strange, that\r\n'b'the species are extremely varied. There is a reason for that, and to\r\n'b'me it is that Lincoln Island may have formerly been a part of some vast\r\n'b'continent which had gradually sunk below the Pacific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, some fine day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, who did not appear to be entirely\r\n'b'convinced, \xe2\x80\x9cthe rest of this ancient continent may disappear in its\r\n'b'turn, and there will be nothing between America and Asia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cthere will be new continents which millions and\r\n'b'millions of animalculae are building at this moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what are these masons?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCoral insects,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cBy constant work they made the\r\n'b'island of Clermont-Tonnerre, and numerous other coral islands in the\r\n'b'Pacific Ocean. Forty-seven millions of these insects are needed to weigh\r\n'b'a grain, and yet, with the sea-salt they absorb, the solid elements of\r\n'b'water which they assimilate, these animalculae produce limestone, and\r\n'b'this limestone forms enormous submarine erections, of which the hardness\r\n'b'and solidity equal granite. Formerly, at the first periods of creation,\r\n'b'nature employing fire, heaved up the land, but now she entrusts to these\r\n'b'microscopic creatures the task of replacing this agent, of which\r\n'b'the dynamic power in the interior of the globe has evidently\r\n'b'diminished--which is proved by the number of volcanoes on the surface of\r\n'b'the earth, now actually extinct. And I believe that centuries succeeding\r\n'b'to centuries, and insects to insects, this Pacific may one day be\r\n'b'changed into a vast continent, which new generations will inhabit and\r\n'b'civilize in their turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat will take a long time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNature has time for it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what would be the use of new continents?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\n'b'appears to me that the present extent of habitable countries is\r\n'b'sufficient for humanity. Yet nature does nothing uselessly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing uselessly, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut this is\r\n'b'how the necessity of new continents for the future, and exactly on the\r\n'b'tropical zone occupied by the coral islands, may be explained. At least\r\n'b'to me this explanation appears plausible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are listening, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is my idea: philosophers generally admit that some day our globe\r\n'b'will end, or rather that animal and vegetable life will no longer be\r\n'b'possible, because of the intense cold to which it will be subjected.\r\n'b'What they are not agreed upon, is the cause of this cold. Some think\r\n'b'that it will arise from the falling of the temperature, which the\r\n'b'sun will experience after millions of years; others, from the gradual\r\n'b'extinction of the fires in the interior of our globe, which have a\r\n'b'greater influence on it than is generally supposed. I hold to this last\r\n'b'hypothesis, grounding it on the fact that the moon is really a cold\r\n'b'star, which is no longer habitable, although the sun continues to throw\r\n'b'on its surface the same amount of heat. If, then, the moon has become\r\n'b'cold, it is because the interior fires to which, as do all the stars of\r\n'b'the stellar world, it owes its origin, are completely extinct. Lastly,\r\n'b'whatever may be the cause, our globe will become cold some day, but this\r\n'b'cold will only operate gradually. What will happen, then? The temperate\r\n'b'zones, at a more or less distant period, will not be more habitable than\r\n'b'the polar regions now are. Then the population of men, as well as the\r\n'b'animals, will flow towards the latitudes which are more directly under\r\n'b'the solar influence. An immense emigration will take place. Europe,\r\n'b'Central Asia, North America, will gradually be abandoned, as well as\r\n'b'Australasia and the lower parts of South America. The vegetation will\r\n'b'follow the human emigration. The flora will retreat towards the Equator\r\n'b'at the same time as the fauna. The central parts of South America and\r\n'b'Africa will be the continents chiefly inhabited. The Laplanders and the\r\n'b'Samoides will find the climate of the polar regions on the shores of the\r\n'b'Mediterranean. Who can say, that at this period, the equatorial regions\r\n'b'will not be too small, to contain and nourish terrestrial humanity? Now,\r\n'b'may not provident nature, so as to give refuge to all the vegetable\r\n'b'and animal emigration, be at present laying the foundation of a new\r\n'b'continent under the Equator, and may she not have entrusted these\r\n'b'insects with the construction of it? I have often thought of all these\r\n'b'things, my friends, and I seriously believe that the aspect of our\r\n'b'globe will some day be completely changed; that by the raising of new\r\n'b'continents the sea will cover the old, and that, in future ages,\r\n'b'a Columbus will go to discover the islands of Chimborazo, of the\r\n'b'Himalayas, or of Mont Blanc, remains of a submerged America, Asia,\r\n'b'and Europe. Then these new continents will become, in their turn,\r\n'b'uninhabitable; heat will die away, as does the heat from a body when\r\n'b'the soul has left it; and life will disappear from the globe, if not for\r\n'b'ever, at least for a period. Perhaps then, our spheroid will rest--will\r\n'b'be left to death--to revive some day under superior conditions! But\r\n'b'all that, my friends, is the secret of the Author of all things; and\r\n'b'beginning by the work of the insects, I have perhaps let myself be\r\n'b'carried too far, in investigating the secrets of the future.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthese theories are prophecies to me,\r\n'b'and they will be accomplished some day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the secret of God,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll that is well and good,\xe2\x80\x9d then said Pencroft, who had listened with\r\n'b'all his might, \xe2\x80\x9cbut will you tell me, captain, if Lincoln Island has\r\n'b'been made by your insects?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cit is of a purely volcanic origin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen it will disappear some day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is probable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI hope we won\xe2\x80\x99t be here then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, don\xe2\x80\x99t be uneasy, Pencroft; we shall not be here then, as we have no\r\n'b'wish to die here, and hope to get away some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn the meantime,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9clet us establish ourselves\r\n'b'here as if forever. There is no use in doing things by halves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This ended the conversation. Breakfast was finished, the exploration was\r\n'b'continued, and the settlers arrived at the border of the marshy\r\n'b'region. It was a marsh of which the extent, to the rounded coast which\r\n'b'terminated the island at the southeast, was about twenty square miles.\r\n'b'The soil was formed of clayey flint-earth, mingled with vegetable\r\n'b'matter, such as the remains of rushes, reeds, grass, etc. Here and there\r\n'b'beds of grass, thick as a carpet, covered it. In many places icy pools\r\n'b'sparkled in the sun. Neither rain nor any river, increased by a sudden\r\n'b'swelling, could supply these ponds. They therefore naturally concluded\r\n'b'that the marsh was fed by the infiltrations of the soil and it was\r\n'b'really so. It was also to be feared that during the heat miasmas would\r\n'b'arise, which might produce fevers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Above the aquatic plants, on the surface of the stagnant water,\r\n'b'fluttered numbers of birds. Wild duck, teal, snipe lived there in\r\n'b'flocks, and those fearless birds allowed themselves to be easily\r\n'b'approached.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'One shot from a gun would certainly have brought down some dozen of the\r\n'b'birds, they were so close together. The explorers were, however, obliged\r\n'b'to content themselves with bows and arrows. The result was less, but the\r\n'b'silent arrow had the advantage of not frightening the birds, while the\r\n'b'noise of firearms would have dispersed them to all parts of the marsh.\r\n'b'The hunters were satisfied, for this time, with a dozen ducks, which had\r\n'b'white bodies with a band of cinnamon, a green head, wings black, white,\r\n'b'and red, and flattened beak. Herbert called them tadorns. Top helped in\r\n'b'the capture of these birds, whose name was given to this marshy part of\r\n'b'the island. The settlers had here an abundant reserve of aquatic game.\r\n'b'At some future time they meant to explore it more carefully, and it was\r\n'b'probable that some of the birds there might be domesticated, or at least\r\n'b'brought to the shores of the lake, so that they would be more within\r\n'b'their reach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening Cyrus Harding and his companions\r\n'b'retraced their steps to their dwelling by traversing Tadorn\xe2\x80\x99s Fens, and\r\n'b'crossed the Mercy on the ice-bridge.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At eight in the evening they all entered Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 22\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This intense cold lasted till the 15th of August, without, however,\r\n'b'passing the degree of Fahrenheit already mentioned. When the atmosphere\r\n'b'was calm, the low temperature was easily borne, but when the wind blew,\r\n'b'the poor settlers, insufficiently clothed, felt it severely. Pencroft\r\n'b'regretted that Lincoln Island was not the home of a few families of\r\n'b'bears rather than of so many foxes and seals.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBears,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9care generally very well dressed, and I ask no more\r\n'b'than to borrow for the winter the warm cloaks which they have on their\r\n'b'backs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps the bears would not consent to\r\n'b'give you their cloaks, Pencroft. These beasts are not St. Martins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe would make them do it, Neb, we would make them,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft,\r\n'b'in quite an authoritative tone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But these formidable carnivora did not exist in the island, or at any\r\n'b'rate they had not yet shown themselves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, Herbert, Pencroft, and the reporter occupied\r\n'b'themselves with making traps on Prospect Heights and at the border of\r\n'b'the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'According to the sailor, any animal, whatever it was, would be a lawful\r\n'b'prize, and the rodents or carnivora which might get into the new snares\r\n'b'would be well received at Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The traps were besides extremely simple; being pits dug in the ground,\r\n'b'a platform of branches and grass above, which concealed the opening, and\r\n'b'at the bottom some bait, the scent of which would attract animals. It\r\n'b'must be mentioned also, that they had not been dug at random, but\r\n'b'at certain places where numerous footprints showed that quadrupeds\r\n'b'frequented the ground. They were visited every day, and at three\r\n'b'different times, during the first days, specimens of those Antarctic\r\n'b'foxes which they had already seen on the right bank of the Mercy were\r\n'b'found in them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, there are nothing but foxes in this country!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, when\r\n'b'for the third time he drew one of the animals out of the pit. Looking at\r\n'b'it in great disgust, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cbeasts which are good for nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthey are good for something!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo make bait to attract other creatures!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter was right, and the traps were henceforward baited with the\r\n'b'foxes carcasses.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor had also made snares from the long tough fibers of a certain\r\n'b'plant, and they were even more successful than the traps. Rarely a day\r\n'b'passed without some rabbits from the warren being caught. It was always\r\n'b'rabbit, but Neb knew how to vary his sauces and the settlers did not\r\n'b'think of complaining.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, once or twice in the second week of August, the traps supplied\r\n'b'the hunters with other animals more useful than foxes, namely, several\r\n'b'of those small wild boars which had already been seen to the north of\r\n'b'the lake. Pencroft had no need to ask if these beasts were eatable. He\r\n'b'could see that by their resemblance to the pig of America and Europe.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut these are not pigs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert to him, \xe2\x80\x9cI warn you of that,\r\n'b'Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, bending over the trap and drawing out one\r\n'b'of these representatives of the family of sus by the little appendage\r\n'b'which served it as a tail. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me believe that these are pigs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause that pleases me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre you very fond of pig then, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am very fond of pig,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cparticularly of its feet,\r\n'b'and if it had eight instead of four, I should like it twice as much!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the animals in question, they were peccaries belonging to one of\r\n'b'the four species which are included in the family, and they were also of\r\n'b'the species of Tajacu, recognizable by their deep color and the absence\r\n'b'of those long teeth with which the mouths of their congeners are armed.\r\n'b'These peccaries generally live in herds, and it was probable that they\r\n'b'abounded in the woody parts of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At any rate, they were eatable from head to foot, and Pencroft did not\r\n'b'ask more from them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards the 15th of August, the state of the atmosphere was suddenly\r\n'b'moderated by the wind shifting to the northwest. The temperature rose\r\n'b'some degrees, and the accumulated vapor in the air was not long in\r\n'b'resolving into snow. All the island was covered with a sheet of white,\r\n'b'and showed itself to its inhabitants under a new aspect. The snow fell\r\n'b'abundantly for several days, and it soon reached a thickness of two\r\n'b'feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The wind also blew with great violence, and at the height of Granite\r\n'b'House the sea could be heard thundering against the reefs. In some\r\n'b'places, the wind, eddying round the corners, formed the snow into tall\r\n'b'whirling columns, resembling those waterspouts which turn round on their\r\n'b'base, and which vessels attack with a shot from a gun. However, the\r\n'b'storm, coming from the northwest, blew across the island, and the\r\n'b'position of Granite House preserved it from a direct attack.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But in the midst of this snow-storm, as terrible as if it had been\r\n'b'produced in some polar country, neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions\r\n'b'could, notwithstanding their wish for it, venture forth, and they\r\n'b'remained shut up for five days, from the 20th to the 25th of August.\r\n'b'They could hear the tempest raging in Jacamar Wood, which would surely\r\n'b'suffer from it. Many of the trees would no doubt be torn up by the\r\n'b'roots, but Pencroft consoled himself by thinking that he would not have\r\n'b'the trouble of cutting them down.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe wind is turning woodman, let it alone,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Besides, there was no way of stopping it, if they had wished to do so.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'How grateful the inhabitants of Granite House then were to Heaven for\r\n'b'having prepared for them this solid and immovable retreat! Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'had also his legitimate share of thanks, but after all, it was Nature\r\n'b'who had hollowed out this vast cavern, and he had only discovered it.\r\n'b'There all were in safety, and the tempest could not reach them. If\r\n'b'they had constructed a house of bricks and wood on Prospect Heights,\r\n'b'it certainly would not have resisted the fury of this storm. As to\r\n'b'the Chimneys, it must have been absolutely uninhabitable, for the sea,\r\n'b'passing over the islet, would beat furiously against it. But here, in\r\n'b'Granite House, in the middle of a solid mass, over which neither the sea\r\n'b'nor air had any influence, there was nothing to fear.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During these days of seclusion the settlers did not remain inactive.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no want of wood, cut up into planks, in the storeroom, and\r\n'b'little by little they completed their furnishing; constructing the\r\n'b'most solid of tables and chairs, for material was not spared. Neb and\r\n'b'Pencroft were very proud of this rather heavy furniture, which they\r\n'b'would not have changed on any account.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then the carpenters became basket-makers, and they did not succeed badly\r\n'b'in this new manufacture. At the point of the lake which projected to the\r\n'b'north, they had discovered an osier-bed in which grew a large number\r\n'b'of purple osiers. Before the rainy season, Pencroft and Herbert had cut\r\n'b'down these useful shrubs, and their branches, well prepared, could now\r\n'b'be effectively employed. The first attempts were somewhat crude, but\r\n'b'in consequence of the cleverness and intelligence of the workmen,\r\n'b'by consulting, and recalling the models which they had seen, and by\r\n'b'emulating each other, the possessions of the colony were soon increased\r\n'b'by several baskets of different sizes. The storeroom was provided with\r\n'b'them, and in special baskets Neb placed his collection of rhizomes,\r\n'b'stone-pine almonds, etc.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the last week of the month of August the weather moderated again.\r\n'b'The temperature fell a little, and the tempest abated. The colonists\r\n'b'sallied out directly. There was certainly two feet of snow on the shore,\r\n'b'but they were able to walk without much difficulty on the hardened\r\n'b'surface. Cyrus Harding and his companions climbed Prospect Heights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What a change! The woods, which they had left green, especially in the\r\n'b'part at which the firs predominated, had disappeared under a uniform\r\n'b'color. All was white, from the summit of Mount Franklin to the shore,\r\n'b'the forests, the plains, the lake, the river. The waters of the Mercy\r\n'b'flowed under a roof of ice, which, at each rising and ebbing of the\r\n'b'tide, broke up with loud crashes. Numerous birds fluttered over the\r\n'b'frozen surface of the lake. Ducks and snipe, teal and guillemots were\r\n'b'assembled in thousands. The rocks among which the cascade flowed were\r\n'b'bristling with icicles. One might have said that the water escaped by a\r\n'b'monstrous gargoyle, shaped with all the imagination of an artist of the\r\n'b'Renaissance. As to the damage caused by the storm in the forest, that\r\n'b'could not as yet be ascertained; they would have to wait till the snowy\r\n'b'covering was dissipated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Herbert did not miss this opportunity of\r\n'b'going to visit their traps. They did not find them easily, under the\r\n'b'snow with which they were covered. They had also to be careful not to\r\n'b'fall into one or other of them, which would have been both dangerous and\r\n'b'humiliating; to be taken in their own snares! But happily they avoided\r\n'b'this unpleasantness, and found their traps perfectly intact. No animal\r\n'b'had fallen into them, and yet the footprints in the neighborhood were\r\n'b'very numerous, among others, certain very clear marks of claws. Herbert\r\n'b'did not hesitate to affirm that some animal of the feline species had\r\n'b'passed there, which justified the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s opinion that dangerous\r\n'b'beasts existed in Lincoln Island. These animals doubtless generally\r\n'b'lived in the forests of the Far West, but pressed by hunger, they had\r\n'b'ventured as far as Prospect Heights. Perhaps they had smelled out the\r\n'b'inhabitants of Granite House. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, what are these feline creatures?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' asked Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are tigers,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought those\r\n'b'beasts were only found in hot countries?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOn the new continent,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the lad, \xe2\x80\x9cthey are found from Mexico to\r\n'b'the Pampas of Buenos Aires. Now, as Lincoln Island is nearly under the\r\n'b'same latitude as the provinces of La Plata, it is not surprising that\r\n'b'tigers are to be met with in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we must look out for them,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the snow soon disappeared, quickly dissolving under the\r\n'b'influence of the rising temperature. Rain fell, and the sheet of white\r\n'b'soon vanished. Notwithstanding the bad weather, the settlers renewed\r\n'b'their stores of different things, stone-pine almonds, rhizomes, syrup\r\n'b'from the maple-tree, for the vegetable part; rabbits from the warren,\r\n'b'agouties, and kangaroos for the animal part. This necessitated several\r\n'b'excursions into the forest, and they found that a great number of trees\r\n'b'had been blown down by the last hurricane. Pencroft and Neb also pushed\r\n'b'with the cart as far as the vein of coal, and brought back several tons\r\n'b'of fuel. They saw in passing that the pottery kiln had been severely\r\n'b'damaged by the wind, at least six feet of it having been blown off.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the same time as the coal, the store of wood was renewed at Granite\r\n'b'House, and they profited by the current of the Mercy having again become\r\n'b'free, to float down several rafts. They could see that the cold period\r\n'b'was not ended.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A visit was also paid to the Chimneys, and the settlers could not but\r\n'b'congratulate themselves on not having been living there during the\r\n'b'hurricane. The sea had left unquestionable traces of its ravages.\r\n'b'Sweeping over the islet, it had furiously assailed the passages, half\r\n'b'filling them with sand, while thick beds of seaweed covered the rocks.\r\n'b'While Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft hunted or collected wood, Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'and Gideon Spilett busied themselves in putting the Chimneys to rights,\r\n'b'and they found the forge and the bellows almost unhurt, protected as\r\n'b'they had been from the first by the heaps of sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The store of fuel had not been made uselessly. The settlers had not done\r\n'b'with the rigorous cold. It is known that, in the Northern Hemisphere,\r\n'b'the month of February is principally distinguished by rapid fallings of\r\n'b'the temperature. It is the same in the Southern Hemisphere, and the end\r\n'b'of the month of August, which is the February of North America, does not\r\n'b'escape this climatic law.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About the 25th, after another change from snow to rain, the wind shifted\r\n'b'to the southeast, and the cold became, suddenly, very severe. According\r\n'b'to the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s calculation, the mercurial column of a Fahrenheit\r\n'b'thermometer would not have marked less than eight degrees below zero,\r\n'b'and this intense cold, rendered still more painful by a sharp gale,\r\n'b'lasted for several days. The colonists were again shut up in Granite\r\n'b'House, and as it was necessary to hermetically seal all the openings\r\n'b'of the facade, only leaving a narrow passage for renewing the air, the\r\n'b'consumption of candles was considerable. To economize them, the cavern\r\n'b'was often only lighted by the blazing hearths, on which fuel was not\r\n'b'spared. Several times, one or other of the settlers descended to the\r\n'b'beach in the midst of ice which the waves heaped up at each tide, but\r\n'b'they soon climbed up again to Granite House, and it was not without pain\r\n'b'and difficulty that their hands could hold to the rounds of the ladder.\r\n'b'In consequence of the intense cold, their fingers felt as if burned when\r\n'b'they touched the rounds. To occupy the leisure hours, which the tenants\r\n'b'of Granite House now had at their disposal, Cyrus Harding undertook an\r\n'b'operation which could be performed indoors.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'We know that the settlers had no other sugar at their disposal than\r\n'b'the liquid substance which they drew from the maple, by making deep\r\n'b'incisions in the tree. They contented themselves with collecting this\r\n'b'liquor in jars and employing it in this state for different culinary\r\n'b'purposes, and the more so, as on growing old, this liquid began to\r\n'b'become white and to be of a syrupy consistence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But there was something better to be made of it, and one day Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding announced that they were going to turn into refiners.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRefiners!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is rather a warm trade, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery warm,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen it will be seasonable!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This word refining need not awake in the mind thoughts of an elaborate\r\n'b'manufactory with apparatus and numerous workmen. No! to crystallize this\r\n'b'liquor, only an extremely easy operation is required. Placed on the fire\r\n'b'in large earthen pots, it was simply subjected to evaporation, and\r\n'b'soon a scum arose to its surface. As soon as this began to thicken,\r\n'b'Neb carefully removed it with a wooden spatula; this accelerated the\r\n'b'evaporation, and at the same time prevented it from contracting an\r\n'b'empyreumatic flavor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After boiling for several hours on a hot fire, which did as much good to\r\n'b'the operators as the substance operated upon, the latter was transformed\r\n'b'into a thick syrup. This syrup was poured into clay molds, previously\r\n'b'fabricated in the kitchen stove, and to which they had given various\r\n'b'shapes. The next day this syrup had become cold, and formed cakes\r\n'b'and tablets. This was sugar of rather a reddish color, but nearly\r\n'b'transparent and of a delicious taste.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cold continued to the middle of September, and the prisoners in\r\n'b'Granite House began to find their captivity rather tedious. Nearly every\r\n'b'day they attempted sorties which they could not prolong. They constantly\r\n'b'worked at the improvement of their dwelling. They talked while working.\r\n'b'Harding instructed his companions in many things, principally explaining\r\n'b'to them the practical applications of science. The colonists had no\r\n'b'library at their disposal; but the engineer was a book which was always\r\n'b'at hand, always open at the page which one wanted, a book which answered\r\n'b'all their questions, and which they often consulted. The time thus\r\n'b'passed away pleasantly, these brave men not appearing to have any fears\r\n'b'for the future.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, all were anxious to see, if not the fine season, at least the\r\n'b'cessation of the insupportable cold. If only they had been clothed in a\r\n'b'way to meet it, how many excursions they would have attempted, either to\r\n'b'the downs or to Tadorn\xe2\x80\x99s Fens! Game would have been easily approached,\r\n'b'and the chase would certainly have been most productive. But Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding considered it of importance that no one should injure his\r\n'b'health, for he had need of all his hands, and his advice was followed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But it must be said, that the one who was most impatient of this\r\n'b'imprisonment, after Pencroft perhaps, was Top. The faithful dog found\r\n'b'Granite House very narrow. He ran backwards and forwards from one\r\n'b'room to another, showing in his way how weary he was of being shut\r\n'b'up. Harding often remarked that when he approached the dark well which\r\n'b'communicated with the sea, and of which the orifice opened at the back\r\n'b'of the storeroom, Top uttered singular growlings. He ran round and round\r\n'b'this hole, which had been covered with a wooden lid. Sometimes even he\r\n'b'tried to put his paws under the lid, as if he wished to raise it.\r\n'b'He then yelped in a peculiar way, which showed at once anger and\r\n'b'uneasiness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer observed this maneuver several times.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What could there be in this abyss to make such an impression on the\r\n'b'intelligent animal? The well led to the sea, that was certain. Could\r\n'b'narrow passages spread from it through the foundations of the island?\r\n'b'Did some marine monster come from time to time, to breathe at the bottom\r\n'b'of this well? The engineer did not know what to think, and could not\r\n'b'refrain from dreaming of many strange improbabilities. Accustomed to go\r\n'b'far into the regions of scientific reality, he would not allow\r\n'b'himself to be drawn into the regions of the strange and almost of the\r\n'b'supernatural; but yet how to explain why Top, one of those sensible dogs\r\n'b'who never waste their time in barking at the moon, should persist in\r\n'b'trying with scent and hearing to fathom this abyss, if there was nothing\r\n'b'there to cause his uneasiness? Top\xe2\x80\x99s conduct puzzled Cyrus Harding even\r\n'b'more than he cared to acknowledge to himself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At all events, the engineer only communicated his impressions to Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, for he thought it useless to explain to his companions the\r\n'b'suspicions which arose from what perhaps was only Top\xe2\x80\x99s fancy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last the cold ceased. There had been rain, squalls mingled with snow,\r\n'b'hailstorms, gusts of wind, but these inclemencies did not last. The ice\r\n'b'melted, the snow disappeared; the shore, the plateau, the banks of\r\n'b'the Mercy, the forest, again became practicable. This return of spring\r\n'b'delighted the tenants of Granite House, and they soon only passed in it\r\n'b'the hours necessary for eating and sleeping.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They hunted much in the second part of September, which led Pencroft to\r\n'b'again entreat for the firearms, which he asserted had been promised by\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding. The latter, knowing well that without special tools it\r\n'b'would be nearly impossible for him to manufacture a gun which would be\r\n'b'of any use, still drew back and put off the operation to some future\r\n'b'time, observing in his usual dry way, that Herbert and Spilett had\r\n'b'become very skilful archers, so that many sorts of excellent animals,\r\n'b'agouties, kangaroos, capybaras, pigeons, bustards, wild ducks, snipes,\r\n'b'in short, game both with fur and feathers, fell victims to their arrows,\r\n'b'and that, consequently, they could wait. But the obstinate sailor would\r\n'b'listen to nothing of this, and he would give the engineer no peace till\r\n'b'he promised to satisfy his desire. Gideon Spilett, however, supported\r\n'b'Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf, which may be doubted,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe island is inhabited by wild\r\n'b'beasts, we must think how to fight with and exterminate them. A time may\r\n'b'come when this will be our first duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But at this period, it was not the question of firearms which occupied\r\n'b'Harding, but that of clothes. Those which the settlers wore had passed\r\n'b'this winter, but they would not last until next winter. Skins of\r\n'b'carnivora or the wool of ruminants must be procured at any price, and\r\n'b'since there were plenty of musmons, it was agreed to consult on the\r\n'b'means of forming a flock which might be brought up for the use of the\r\n'b'colony. An enclosure for the domestic animals, a poultry-yard for the\r\n'b'birds, in a word to establish a sort of farm in the island, such were\r\n'b'the two important projects for the fine season.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In consequence and in view of these future establishments, it became\r\n'b'of much importance that they should penetrate into all the yet unknown\r\n'b'parts of Lincoln Island, that is to say, through that thick forest which\r\n'b'extended on the right bank of the Mercy, from its mouth to the extremity\r\n'b'of the Serpentine Peninsula, as well as on the whole of its western\r\n'b'side. But this needed settled weather, and a month must pass before this\r\n'b'exploration could be profitably undertaken.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They therefore waited with some impatience, when an incident occurred\r\n'b'which increased the desire the settlers had to visit the whole of their\r\n'b'domain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the 24th of October. On this day, Pencroft had gone to visit his\r\n'b'traps, which he always kept properly baited. In one of them he found\r\n'b'three animals which would be very welcome for the larder. They were a\r\n'b'female peccary and her two young ones.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft then returned to Granite House, enchanted with his capture,\r\n'b'and, as usual, he made a great show of his game.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome, we shall have a grand feast, captain!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you\r\n'b'too, Mr. Spilett, you will eat some!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be very happy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9cbut what is it that I am\r\n'b'going to eat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSuckling-pig.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, indeed, suckling-pig, Pencroft? To hear you, I thought that you\r\n'b'were bringing back a young partridge stuffed with truffles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to say that you turn up your nose\r\n'b'at suckling-pig?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, without showing any enthusiasm; \xe2\x80\x9cprovided\r\n'b'one doesn\xe2\x80\x99t eat too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right, that\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor, who was not pleased\r\n'b'whenever he heard his chase made light of. \xe2\x80\x9cYou like to make objections.\r\n'b'Seven months ago, when we landed on the island, you would have been only\r\n'b'too glad to have met with such game!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cman is never perfect, nor\r\n'b'contented.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope that Neb will distinguish himself. Look\r\n'b'here! These two little peccaries are not more than three months old!\r\n'b'They will be as tender as quails! Come along, Neb, come! I will look\r\n'b'after the cooking myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor, followed by Neb, entered the kitchen, where they were\r\n'b'soon absorbed in their culinary labors.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were allowed to do it in their own way. Neb, therefore, prepared\r\n'b'a magnificent repast--the two little peccaries, kangaroo soup, a smoked\r\n'b'ham, stone-pine almonds, Oswego tea; in fact, all the best that they\r\n'b'had, but among all the dishes figured in the first rank the savory\r\n'b'peccaries.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At five o\xe2\x80\x99clock dinner was served in the dining-room of Granite House.\r\n'b'The kangaroo soup was smoking on the table. They found it excellent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To the soup succeeded the peccaries, which Pencroft insisted on carving\r\n'b'himself, and of which he served out monstrous portions to each of the\r\n'b'guests.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These suckling-pigs were really delicious, and Pencroft was devouring\r\n'b'his share with great gusto, when all at once a cry and an oath escaped\r\n'b'him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe matter? the matter is that I have just broken a tooth!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\n'b'sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, are there pebbles in your peccaries?\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, drawing from his lips the object which\r\n'b'had cost him a grinder--!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was not a pebble--it was a leaden bullet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'PART 2\r\n'b'\r\n'b'ABANDONED\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 1\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now exactly seven months since the balloon voyagers had been\r\n'b'thrown on Lincoln Island. During that time, notwithstanding the\r\n'b'researches they had made, no human being had been discovered. No smoke\r\n'b'even had betrayed the presence of man on the surface of the island. No\r\n'b'vestiges of his handiwork showed that either at an early or at a late\r\n'b'period had man lived there. Not only did it now appear to be uninhabited\r\n'b'by any but themselves, but the colonists were compelled to believe that\r\n'b'it never had been inhabited. And now, all this scaffolding of reasonings\r\n'b'fell before a simple ball of metal, found in the body of an inoffensive\r\n'b'rodent! In fact, this bullet must have issued from a firearm, and who\r\n'b'but a human being could have used such a weapon?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When Pencroft had placed the bullet on the table, his companions looked\r\n'b'at it with intense astonishment. All the consequences likely to result\r\n'b'from this incident, notwithstanding its apparent insignificance,\r\n'b'immediately took possession of their minds. The sudden apparition of a\r\n'b'supernatural being could not have startled them more completely.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding did not hesitate to give utterance to the suggestions\r\n'b'which this fact, at once surprising and unexpected, could not fail to\r\n'b'raise in his mind. He took the bullet, turned it over and over, rolled\r\n'b'it between his finger and thumb; then, turning to Pencroft, he asked,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure that the peccary wounded by this bullet was not more than\r\n'b'three months old?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot more, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was still sucking its mother\r\n'b'when I found it in the trap.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cthat proves that within three months a\r\n'b'gun-shot was fired in Lincoln Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that a bullet,\xe2\x80\x9d added Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwounded, though not\r\n'b'mortally, this little animal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is unquestionable,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand these are the\r\n'b'deductions which must be drawn from this incident: that the island was\r\n'b'inhabited before our arrival, or that men have landed here within three\r\n'b'months. Did these men arrive here voluntarily or involuntarily, by\r\n'b'disembarking on the shore or by being wrecked? This point can only be\r\n'b'cleared up later. As to what they were, Europeans or Malays, enemies or\r\n'b'friends of our race, we cannot possibly guess; and if they still inhabit\r\n'b'the island, or if they have left it, we know not. But these questions\r\n'b'are of too much importance to be allowed to remain long unsettled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo! a hundred times no! a thousand times no!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor,\r\n'b'springing up from the table. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are no other men than ourselves on\r\n'b'Lincoln Island! By my faith! The island isn\xe2\x80\x99t large and if it had been\r\n'b'inhabited, we should have seen some of the inhabitants long before\r\n'b'this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn fact, the contrary would be very astonishing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut it would be much more astonishing, I should think,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the\r\n'b'reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cif this peccary had been born with a bullet in its inside!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb seriously, \xe2\x80\x9cif Pencroft has not had--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook here, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d burst out Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I could have a\r\n'b'bullet in my jaw for five or six months without finding it out?\r\n'b'Where could it be hidden?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, opening his mouth to show the\r\n'b'two-and-thirty teeth with which it was furnished. \xe2\x80\x9cLook well, Neb, and\r\n'b'if you find one hollow tooth in this set, I will let you pull out half a\r\n'b'dozen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNeb\xe2\x80\x99s supposition is certainly inadmissible,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, who,\r\n'b'notwithstanding the gravity of his thoughts, could not restrain a smile.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is certain that a gun has been fired in the island, within three\r\n'b'months at most. But I am inclined to think that the people who landed\r\n'b'on this coast were only here a very short time ago, or that they just\r\n'b'touched here; for if, when we surveyed the island from the summit of\r\n'b'Mount Franklin, it had been inhabited, we should have seen them or we\r\n'b'should have been seen ourselves. It is therefore, probable that within\r\n'b'only a few weeks castaways have been thrown by a storm on some part of\r\n'b'the coast. However that may be, it is of consequence to us to have this\r\n'b'point settled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think that we should act with caution,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSuch is my advice,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is to be feared that\r\n'b'Malay pirates have landed on the island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cwould it not be a good plan, before\r\n'b'setting out, to build a canoe in which we could either ascend the\r\n'b'river, or, if we liked, coast round the inland? It will not do to be\r\n'b'unprovided.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYour idea is good, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we cannot wait\r\n'b'for that. It would take at least a month to build a boat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a real boat,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we do not want one for a\r\n'b'sea voyage, and in five days at the most, I will undertake to construct\r\n'b'a canoe fit to navigate the Mercy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFive days,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cto build a boat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Neb; a boat in the Indian fashion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOf wood?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Negro, looking still unconvinced.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOf wood,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cor rather of bark. I repeat, captain, that\r\n'b'in five days the work will be finished!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn five days, then, be it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut till that time we must be very watchful,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery watchful indeed, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cand I beg you to\r\n'b'confine your hunting excursions to the neighborhood of Granite House.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The dinner ended less gaily than Pencroft had hoped.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So, then, the island was, or had been, inhabited by others than the\r\n'b'settlers. Proved as it was by the incident of the bullet, it was\r\n'b'hereafter an unquestionable fact, and such a discovery could not but\r\n'b'cause great uneasiness among the colonists.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett, before sleeping, conversed long about\r\n'b'the matter. They asked themselves if by chance this incident might not\r\n'b'have some connection with the inexplicable way in which the engineer had\r\n'b'been saved, and the other peculiar circumstances which had struck them\r\n'b'at different times. However, Cyrus Harding, after having discussed the\r\n'b'pros and cons of the question, ended by saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn short, would you like to know my opinion, my dear Spilett?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Cyrus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, it is this: however minutely we explore the island, we\r\n'b'shall find nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day Pencroft set to work. He did not mean to build a boat with\r\n'b'boards and planking, but simply a flat-bottomed canoe, which would be\r\n'b'well suited for navigating the Mercy--above all, for approaching its\r\n'b'source, where the water would naturally be shallow. Pieces of bark,\r\n'b'fastened one to the other, would form a light boat; and in case of\r\n'b'natural obstacles, which would render a portage necessary, it would be\r\n'b'easily carried. Pencroft intended to secure the pieces of bark by means\r\n'b'of nails, to insure the canoe being water-tight.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was first necessary to select the trees which would afford a strong\r\n'b'and supple bark for the work. Now the last storm had brought down a\r\n'b'number of large birch-trees, the bark of which would be perfectly suited\r\n'b'for their purpose. Some of these trees lay on the ground, and they had\r\n'b'only to be barked, which was the most difficult thing of all, owing to\r\n'b'the imperfect tools which the settlers possessed. However, they overcame\r\n'b'all difficulties.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While the sailor, seconded by the engineer, thus occupied himself\r\n'b'without losing an hour, Gideon Spilett and Herbert were not idle.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were made purveyors to the colony. The reporter could not but\r\n'b'admire the boy, who had acquired great skill in handling the bow and\r\n'b'spear. Herbert also showed great courage and much of that presence of\r\n'b'mind which may justly be called \xe2\x80\x9cthe reasoning of bravery.\xe2\x80\x9d These two\r\n'b'companions of the chase, remembering Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s recommendations,\r\n'b'did not go beyond a radius of two miles round Granite House; but\r\n'b'the borders of the forest furnished a sufficient tribute of agoutis,\r\n'b'capybaras, kangaroos, peccaries, etc.; and if the result from the traps\r\n'b'was less than during the cold, still the warren yielded its accustomed\r\n'b'quota, which might have fed all the colony in Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Often during these excursions, Herbert talked with Gideon Spilett on the\r\n'b'incident of the bullet, and the deductions which the engineer drew from\r\n'b'it, and one day--it was the 26th of October--he said--\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Mr. Spilett,\r\n'b'do you not think it very extraordinary that, if any castaways have\r\n'b'landed on the island, they have not yet shown themselves near Granite\r\n'b'House?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery astonishing if they are still here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\n'b'not astonishing at all if they are here no longer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo you think that these people have already quitted the island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' returned Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is more than probable, my boy; for if their stay was prolonged, and\r\n'b'above all, if they were still here, some accident would have at last\r\n'b'betrayed their presence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut if they were able to go away,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the lad, \xe2\x80\x9cthey could not\r\n'b'have been castaways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Herbert; or, at least, they were what might be called provisional\r\n'b'castaways. It is very possible that a storm may have driven them to the\r\n'b'island without destroying their vessel, and that, the storm over, they\r\n'b'went away again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI must acknowledge one thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is that Captain\r\n'b'Harding appears rather to fear than desire the presence of human beings\r\n'b'on our island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn short,\xe2\x80\x9d responded the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cthere are only Malays who frequent\r\n'b'these seas, and those fellows are ruffians which it is best to avoid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not impossible, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat some day or\r\n'b'other we may find traces of their landing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do not say no, my boy. A deserted camp, the ashes of a fire, would\r\n'b'put us on the track, and this is what we will look for in our next\r\n'b'expedition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The day on which the hunters spoke thus, they were in a part of the\r\n'b'forest near the Mercy, remarkable for its beautiful trees. There, among\r\n'b'others, rose, to a height of nearly 200 feet above the ground, some of\r\n'b'those superb coniferae, to which, in New Zealand, the natives give the\r\n'b'name of Kauris.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have an idea, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I were to climb to the\r\n'b'top of one of these kauris, I could survey the country for an immense\r\n'b'distance round.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe idea is good,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9cbut could you climb to the\r\n'b'top of those giants?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI can at least try,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The light and active boy then sprang on the first branches, the\r\n'b'arrangement of which made the ascent of the kauri easy, and in a few\r\n'b'minutes he arrived at the summit, which emerged from the immense plain\r\n'b'of verdure.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From this elevated situation his gaze extended over all the southern\r\n'b'portion of the island, from Claw Cape on the southeast, to Reptile End\r\n'b'on the southwest. To the northwest rose Mount Franklin, which concealed\r\n'b'a great part of the horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Herbert, from the height of his observatory, could examine all the\r\n'b'yet unknown portion of the island, which might have given shelter to the\r\n'b'strangers whose presence they suspected.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The lad looked attentively. There was nothing in sight on the sea, not\r\n'b'a sail, neither on the horizon nor near the island. However, as the bank\r\n'b'of trees hid the shore, it was possible that a vessel, especially if\r\n'b'deprived of her masts, might lie close to the land and thus be invisible\r\n'b'to Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neither in the forests of the Far West was anything to be seen. The wood\r\n'b'formed an impenetrable screen, measuring several square miles, without a\r\n'b'break or an opening. It was impossible even to follow the course of the\r\n'b'Mercy, or to ascertain in what part of the mountain it took its source.\r\n'b'Perhaps other creeks also ran towards the west, but they could not be\r\n'b'seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But at last, if all indication of an encampment escaped Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s sight\r\n'b'could he not even catch a glimpse of smoke, the faintest trace of which\r\n'b'would be easily discernible in the pure atmosphere?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For an instant Herbert thought he could perceive a slight smoke in the\r\n'b'west, but a more attentive examination showed that he was mistaken. He\r\n'b'strained his eyes in every direction, and his sight was excellent. No,\r\n'b'decidedly there was nothing there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert descended to the foot of the kauri, and the two sportsmen\r\n'b'returned to Granite House. There Cyrus Harding listened to the lad\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'account, shook his head and said nothing. It was very evident that\r\n'b'no decided opinion could be pronounced on this question until after a\r\n'b'complete exploration of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two days after--the 28th of October--another incident occurred, for\r\n'b'which an explanation was again required.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While strolling along the shore about two miles from Granite House,\r\n'b'Herbert and Neb were fortunate enough to capture a magnificent specimen\r\n'b'of the order of chelonia. It was a turtle of the species Midas, the\r\n'b'edible green turtle, so called from the color both of its shell and fat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert caught sight of this turtle as it was crawling among the rocks\r\n'b'to reach the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHelp, Neb, help!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb ran up.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fine animal!\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb; \xe2\x80\x9cbut how are we to catch it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is easier, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have only to turn the\r\n'b'turtle on its back, and it cannot possibly get away. Take your spear and\r\n'b'do as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reptile, aware of danger, had retired between its carapace and\r\n'b'plastron. They no longer saw its head or feet, and it was motionless as\r\n'b'a rock.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and Neb then drove their sticks underneath the animal, and by\r\n'b'their united efforts managed without difficulty to turn it on its back.\r\n'b'The turtle, which was three feet in length, would have weighed at least\r\n'b'four hundred pounds.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCapital!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is something which will rejoice friend\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the heart of friend Pencroft could not fail to be rejoiced,\r\n'b'for the flesh of the turtle, which feeds on wrack-grass, is extremely\r\n'b'savory. At this moment the creature\xe2\x80\x99s head could be seen, which was\r\n'b'small, flat, but widened behind by the large temporal fossae hidden\r\n'b'under the long roof.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, what shall we do with our prize?\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t drag it\r\n'b'to Granite House!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLeave it here, since it cannot turn over,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand we\r\n'b'will come back with the cart to fetch it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the best plan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, for greater precaution, Herbert took the trouble, which Neb\r\n'b'deemed superfluous, to wedge up the animal with great stones; after\r\n'b'which the two hunters returned to Granite House, following the beach,\r\n'b'which the tide had left uncovered. Herbert, wishing to surprise\r\n'b'Pencroft, said nothing about the \xe2\x80\x9csuperb specimen of a chelonian\xe2\x80\x9d which\r\n'b'they had turned over on the sand; but, two hours later, he and Neb\r\n'b'returned with the cart to the place where they had left it. The \xe2\x80\x9csuperb\r\n'b'specimen of a chelonian\xe2\x80\x9d was no longer there!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb and Herbert stared at each other first; then they stared about them.\r\n'b'It was just at this spot that the turtle had been left. The lad even\r\n'b'found the stones which he had used, and therefore he was certain of not\r\n'b'being mistaken.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cthese beasts can turn themselves over, then?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, who could not understand it at all,\r\n'b'and was gazing at the stones scattered on the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Pencroft will be disgusted!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Captain Harding will perhaps be very perplexed how to explain this\r\n'b'disappearance,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, who wished to hide his ill-luck, \xe2\x80\x9cwe won\xe2\x80\x99t speak\r\n'b'about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, Neb, we must speak about it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the two, taking the cart, which there was now no use for, returned\r\n'b'to Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at the dockyard, where the engineer and the sailor were working\r\n'b'together, Herbert recounted what had happened.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! the stupids!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cto have let at least fifty meals\r\n'b'escape!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cit wasn\xe2\x80\x99t our fault that the beast got\r\n'b'away; as I tell you, we had turned it over on its back!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen you didn\xe2\x80\x99t turn it over enough!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the obstinate sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot enough!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And he told how he had taken care to wedge up the turtle with stones.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a miracle, then!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI thought, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat turtles, once placed on their\r\n'b'backs, could not regain their feet, especially when they are of a large\r\n'b'size?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen how did it manage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt what distance from the sea did you leave this turtle?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\n'b'the engineer, who, having suspended his work, was reflecting on this\r\n'b'incident.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFifteen feet at the most,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the tide was low at the time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat the turtle could not do on the sand\r\n'b'it might have been able to do in the water. It turned over when the tide\r\n'b'overtook it, and then quietly returned to the deep sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! what stupids we were!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is precisely what I had the honor of telling you before!\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\n'b'the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had given this explanation, which, no doubt, was\r\n'b'admissible. But was he himself convinced of the accuracy of this\r\n'b'explanation? It cannot be said that he was.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 2\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 9th of October the bark canoe was entirely finished. Pencroft\r\n'b'had kept his promise, and a light boat, the shell of which was joined\r\n'b'together by the flexible twigs of the crejimba, had been constructed in\r\n'b'five days. A seat in the stern, a second seat in the middle to preserve\r\n'b'the equilibrium, a third seat in the bows, rowlocks for the two oars, a\r\n'b'scull to steer with, completed the little craft, which was twelve feet\r\n'b'long, and did not weigh more than two hundred pounds. The operation of\r\n'b'launching it was extremely simple. The canoe was carried to the beach\r\n'b'and laid on the sand before Granite House, and the rising tide floated\r\n'b'it. Pencroft, who leaped in directly, maneuvered it with the scull and\r\n'b'declared it to be just the thing for the purpose to which they wished to\r\n'b'put it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor, who did not disdain to celebrate thus his\r\n'b'own triumph. \xe2\x80\x9cWith this we could go round--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe world?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, the island. Some stones for ballast, a mast and a sail, which the\r\n'b'captain will make for us some day, and we shall go splendidly! Well,\r\n'b'captain--and you, Mr. Spilett; and you, Herbert; and you, Neb--aren\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n'b'you coming to try our new vessel? Come along! we must see if it will\r\n'b'carry all five of us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was certainly a trial which ought to be made. Pencroft soon brought\r\n'b'the canoe to the shore by a narrow passage among the rocks, and it was\r\n'b'agreed that they should make a trial of the boat that day by following\r\n'b'the shore as far as the first point at which the rocks of the south\r\n'b'ended.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As they embarked, Neb cried,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut your boat leaks rather, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s nothing, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cthe wood will get seasoned.\r\n'b'In two days there won\xe2\x80\x99t be a single leak, and our boat will have no more\r\n'b'water in her than there is in the stomach of a drunkard. Jump in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were soon all seated, and Pencroft shoved off. The weather was\r\n'b'magnificent, the sea as calm as if its waters were contained within\r\n'b'the narrow limits of a lake. Thus the boat could proceed with as much\r\n'b'security as if it was ascending the tranquil current of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb took one of the oars, Herbert the other, and Pencroft remained in\r\n'b'the stern in order to use the scull.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor first crossed the channel, and steered close to the southern\r\n'b'point of the islet. A light breeze blew from the south. No roughness was\r\n'b'found either in the channel or the green sea. A long swell, which the\r\n'b'canoe scarcely felt, as it was heavily laden, rolled regularly over the\r\n'b'surface of the water. They pulled out about half a mile distant from the\r\n'b'shore, that they might have a good view of Mount Franklin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft afterwards returned towards the mouth of the river. The boat\r\n'b'then skirted the shore, which, extending to the extreme point, hid all\r\n'b'Tadorn\xe2\x80\x99s Fens.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This point, of which the distance was increased by the irregularity of\r\n'b'the coast, was nearly three miles from the Mercy. The settlers resolved\r\n'b'to go to its extremity, and only go beyond it as much as was necessary\r\n'b'to take a rapid survey of the coast as far as Claw Cape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The canoe followed the windings of the shore, avoiding the rocks\r\n'b'which fringed it, and which the rising tide began to cover. The cliff\r\n'b'gradually sloped away from the mouth of the river to the point.
