This was\r\n'b'formed of granite rocks, capriciously distributed, very different from\r\n'b'the cliff at Prospect Heights, and of an extremely wild aspect. It might\r\n'b'have been said that an immense cartload of rocks had been emptied out\r\n'b'there. There was no vegetation on this sharp promontory, which projected\r\n'b'two miles from the forest, and it thus represented a giant\xe2\x80\x99s arm\r\n'b'stretched out from a leafy sleeve.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The canoe, impelled by the two oars, advanced without difficulty. Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, pencil in one hand and notebook in the other, sketched the\r\n'b'coast in bold strokes. Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft chatted, while\r\n'b'examining this part of their domain, which was new to them, and, in\r\n'b'proportion as the canoe proceeded towards the south, the two Mandible\r\n'b'Capes appeared to move, and surround Union Bay more closely.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Cyrus Harding, he did not speak; he simply gazed, and by the\r\n'b'mistrust which his look expressed, it appeared that he was examining\r\n'b'some strange country.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meantime, after a voyage of three-quarters of an hour, the\r\n'b'canoe reached the extremity of the point, and Pencroft was preparing to\r\n'b'return, when Herbert, rising, pointed to a black object, saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I see down there on the beach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All eyes turned towards the point indicated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is something. It looks like part of a\r\n'b'wreck half buried in the sand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI see what it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBarrels, barrels, which perhaps are full,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPull to the shore, Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few strokes of the oar brought the canoe into a little creek, and its\r\n'b'passengers leaped on shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft was not mistaken. Two barrels were there, half buried in the\r\n'b'sand, but still firmly attached to a large chest, which, sustained by\r\n'b'them, had floated to the moment when it stranded on the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere has been a wreck, then, in some part of the island,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\n'b'Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEvidently,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what\xe2\x80\x99s in this chest?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, with very natural\r\n'b'impatience. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s in this chest? It is shut up, and nothing to open it\r\n'b'with! Well, perhaps a stone--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor, raising a heavy block, was about to break in one of the\r\n'b'sides of the chest, when the engineer arrested his hand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ccan you restrain your impatience for one hour\r\n'b'only?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, captain, just think! Perhaps there is everything we want in\r\n'b'there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall find that out, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cbut trust\r\n'b'to me, and do not break the chest, which may be useful to us. We must\r\n'b'convey it to Granite House, where we can open it easily, and without\r\n'b'breaking it. It is quite prepared for a voyage; and since it has floated\r\n'b'here, it may just as well float to the mouth of the river.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, captain, and I was wrong, as usual,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s advice was good. In fact, the canoe probably would not\r\n'b'have been able to contain the articles possibly enclosed in the chest,\r\n'b'which doubtless was heavy, since two empty barrels were required to buoy\r\n'b'it up. It was, therefore, much better to tow it to the beach at Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And now, whence had this chest come? That was the important question.\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions looked attentively around them, and\r\n'b'examined the shore for several hundred steps. No other articles or\r\n'b'pieces of wreck could be found. Herbert and Neb climbed a high rock\r\n'b'to survey the sea, but there was nothing in sight--neither a dismasted\r\n'b'vessel nor a ship under sail.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, there was no doubt that there had been a wreck. Perhaps this\r\n'b'incident was connected with that of the bullet? Perhaps strangers had\r\n'b'landed on another part of the island? Perhaps they were still there?\r\n'b'But the thought which came naturally to the settlers was, that these\r\n'b'strangers could not be Malay pirates, for the chest was evidently of\r\n'b'American or European make.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All the party returned to the chest, which was of an unusually large\r\n'b'size. It was made of oak wood, very carefully closed and covered with\r\n'b'a thick hide, which was secured by copper nails. The two great barrels,\r\n'b'hermetically sealed, but which sounded hollow and empty, were fastened\r\n'b'to its sides by strong ropes, knotted with a skill which Pencroft\r\n'b'directly pronounced sailors alone could exhibit. It appeared to be in a\r\n'b'perfect state of preservation, which was explained by the fact that it\r\n'b'had stranded on a sandy beach, and not among rocks. They had no doubt\r\n'b'whatever, on examining it carefully, that it had not been long in the\r\n'b'water, and that its arrival on this coast was recent. The water did\r\n'b'not appear to have penetrated to the inside, and the articles which it\r\n'b'contained were no doubt uninjured.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was evident that this chest had been thrown overboard from some\r\n'b'dismasted vessel driven towards the island, and that, in the hope\r\n'b'that it would reach the land, where they might afterwards find it,\r\n'b'the passengers had taken the precaution to buoy it up by means of this\r\n'b'floating apparatus.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will tow this chest to Granite House,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere we\r\n'b'can make an inventory of its contents; then, if we discover any of the\r\n'b'survivors from the supposed wreck, we can return it to those to whom it\r\n'b'belongs. If we find no one--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will keep it for ourselves!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cBut what in the world\r\n'b'can there be in it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sea was already approaching the chest, and the high tide would\r\n'b'evidently float it. One of the ropes which fastened the barrels was\r\n'b'partly unlashed and used as a cable to unite the floating apparatus with\r\n'b'the canoe. Pencroft and Neb then dug away the sand with their oars, so\r\n'b'as to facilitate the moving of the chest, towing which the boat soon\r\n'b'began to double the point, to which the name of Flotsam Point was given.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The chest was heavy, and the barrels were scarcely sufficient to keep\r\n'b'it above water. The sailor also feared every instant that it would get\r\n'b'loose and sink to the bottom of the sea. But happily his fears were not\r\n'b'realized, and an hour and a half after they set out--all that time had\r\n'b'been taken up in going a distance of three miles--the boat touched the\r\n'b'beach below Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Canoe and chest were then hauled up on the sands; and as the tide was\r\n'b'then going out, they were soon left high and dry. Neb, hurrying home,\r\n'b'brought back some tools with which to open the chest in such a way that\r\n'b'it might be injured as little as possible, and they proceeded to its\r\n'b'inventory. Pencroft did not try to hide that he was greatly excited.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor began by detaching the two barrels, which, being in good\r\n'b'condition, would of course be of use. Then the locks were forced with a\r\n'b'cold chisel and hammer, and the lid thrown back. A second casing of zinc\r\n'b'lined the interior of the chest, which had been evidently arranged\r\n'b'that the articles which it enclosed might under any circumstances be\r\n'b'sheltered from damp.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, \xe2\x80\x9csuppose it\xe2\x80\x99s jam!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI hope not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf only there was--\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor in a low voice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb, who overheard him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The covering of zinc was torn off and thrown back over the sides of the\r\n'b'chest, and by degrees numerous articles of very varied character were\r\n'b'produced and strewn about on the sand. At each new object Pencroft\r\n'b'uttered fresh hurrahs, Herbert clapped his hands, and Neb danced up and\r\n'b'down. There were books which made Herbert wild with joy, and cooking\r\n'b'utensils which Neb covered with kisses!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In short, the colonists had reason to be extremely satisfied, for this\r\n'b'chest contained tools, weapons, instruments, clothes, books; and this\r\n'b'is the exact list of them as stated in Gideon Spilett\xe2\x80\x99s note-book:\r\n'b'--Tools:--3 knives with several blades, 2 woodmen\xe2\x80\x99s axes, 2 carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'hatchets, 3 planes, 2 adzes, 1 twibil or mattock, 6 chisels, 2 files,\r\n'b'3 hammers, 3 gimlets, 2 augers, 10 bags of nails and screws, 3 saws of\r\n'b'different sizes, 2 boxes of needles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Weapons:--2 flint-lock guns, 2 for percussion caps, 2 breach-loader\r\n'b'carbines, 5 boarding cutlasses, 4 sabers, 2 barrels of powder, each\r\n'b'containing twenty-five pounds; 12 boxes of percussion caps.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Instruments:--1 sextant, 1 double opera-glass, 1 telescope, 1 box of\r\n'b'mathematical instruments, 1 mariner\xe2\x80\x99s compass, 1 Fahrenheit thermometer,\r\n'b'1 aneroid barometer, 1 box containing a photographic apparatus,\r\n'b'object-glass, plates, chemicals, etc.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Clothes:--2 dozen shirts of a peculiar material resembling wool, but\r\n'b'evidently of a vegetable origin; 3 dozen stockings of the same material.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Utensils:--1 iron pot, 6 copper saucepans, 3 iron dishes, 10 metal\r\n'b'plates, 2 kettles, 1 portable stove, 6 table-knives.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Books:--1 Bible, 1 atlas, 1 dictionary of the different Polynesian\r\n'b'idioms, 1 dictionary of natural science, in six volumes; 3 reams of\r\n'b'white paper, 2 books with blank pages.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt must be allowed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, after the inventory had been\r\n'b'made, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the owner of this chest was a practical man! Tools, weapons,\r\n'b'instruments, clothes, utensils, books--nothing is wanting! It might\r\n'b'really be said that he expected to be wrecked, and had prepared for it\r\n'b'beforehand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is wanting, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Cyrus Harding thoughtfully.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for a certainty,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthe vessel which carried this\r\n'b'chest and its owner was not a Malay pirate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUnless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthe owner had been taken prisoner by\r\n'b'pirates--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not admissible,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is more probable\r\n'b'that an American or European vessel has been driven into this quarter,\r\n'b'and that her passengers, wishing to save necessaries at least, prepared\r\n'b'this chest and threw it overboard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs that your opinion, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cthat may have been the case. It\r\n'b'is possible that at the moment, or in expectation of a wreck, they\r\n'b'collected into this chest different articles of the greatest use in\r\n'b'hopes of finding it again on the coast--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEven the photographic box!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor incredulously.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs to that apparatus,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not quite see the use of\r\n'b'it; and a more complete supply of clothes or more abundant ammunition\r\n'b'would have been more valuable to us as well as to any other castaways!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut isn\xe2\x80\x99t there any mark or direction on these instruments, tools, or\r\n'b'books, which would tell us something about them?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That might be ascertained. Each article was carefully examined,\r\n'b'especially the books, instruments and weapons. Neither the weapons nor\r\n'b'the instruments, contrary to the usual custom, bore the name of the\r\n'b'maker; they were, besides, in a perfect state, and did not appear to\r\n'b'have been used. The same peculiarity marked the tools and utensils; all\r\n'b'were new, which proved that the articles had not been taken by chance\r\n'b'and thrown into the chest, but, on the contrary, that the choice of\r\n'b'things had been well considered and arranged with care. This was also\r\n'b'indicated by the second case of metal which had preserved them from\r\n'b'damp, and which could not have been soldered in a moment of haste.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the dictionaries of natural science and Polynesian idioms, both\r\n'b'were English; but they neither bore the name of the publisher nor the\r\n'b'date of publication.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The same with the Bible printed in English, in quarto, remarkable from a\r\n'b'typographic point of view, and which appeared to have been often used.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The atlas was a magnificent work, comprising maps of every country in\r\n'b'the world, and several planispheres arranged upon Mercator\xe2\x80\x99s projection,\r\n'b'and of which the nomenclature was in French--but which also bore neither\r\n'b'date nor name of publisher.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was nothing, therefore, on these different articles by which\r\n'b'they could be traced, and nothing consequently of a nature to show the\r\n'b'nationality of the vessel which must have recently passed these shores.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But, wherever the chest might have come from, it was a treasure to the\r\n'b'settlers on Lincoln Island. Till then, by making use of the productions\r\n'b'of nature, they had created everything for themselves, and, thanks to\r\n'b'their intelligence, they had managed without difficulty. But did it not\r\n'b'appear as if Providence had wished to reward them by sending them these\r\n'b'productions of human industry? Their thanks rose unanimously to Heaven.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, one of them was not quite satisfied: it was Pencroft. It\r\n'b'appeared that the chest did not contain something which he evidently\r\n'b'held in great esteem, for in proportion as they approached the bottom\r\n'b'of the box, his hurrahs diminished in heartiness, and, the inventory\r\n'b'finished, he was heard to mutter these words:--\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all very fine,\r\n'b'but you can see that there is nothing for me in that box!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This led Neb to say,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, friend Pencroft, what more do you expect?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHalf a pound of tobacco,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft seriously, \xe2\x80\x9cand nothing\r\n'b'would have been wanting to complete my happiness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No one could help laughing at this speech of the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the result of this discovery of the chest was, that it was now more\r\n'b'than ever necessary to explore the island thoroughly. It was therefore\r\n'b'agreed that the next morning at break of day, they should set out, by\r\n'b'ascending the Mercy so as to reach the western shore. If any castaways\r\n'b'had landed on the coast, it was to be feared they were without\r\n'b'resources, and it was therefore the more necessary to carry help to them\r\n'b'without delay.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the day the different articles were carried to Granite House,\r\n'b'where they were methodically arranged in the great hall. This day--the\r\n'b'29th of October--happened to be a Sunday, and, before going to bed,\r\n'b'Herbert asked the engineer if he would not read them something from the\r\n'b'Gospel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He took the sacred volume, and was about to open it, when Pencroft\r\n'b'stopped him, saying,--\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain, I am superstitious. Open at random\r\n'b'and read the first verse which, your eye falls upon. We will see if it\r\n'b'applies to our situation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding smiled at the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s idea, and, yielding to his wish, he\r\n'b'opened exactly at a place where the leaves were separated by a marker.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Immediately his eyes were attracted by a cross which, made with a\r\n'b'pencil, was placed against the eighth verse of the seventh chapter of\r\n'b'the Gospel of St. Matthew. He read the verse, which was this:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 3\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 30th of October, all was ready for the proposed\r\n'b'exploring expedition, which recent events had rendered so necessary. In\r\n'b'fact, things had so come about that the settlers in Lincoln Island no\r\n'b'longer needed help for themselves, but were even able to carry it to\r\n'b'others.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was therefore agreed that they should ascend the Mercy as far as\r\n'b'the river was navigable. A great part of the distance would thus be\r\n'b'traversed without fatigue, and the explorers could transport their\r\n'b'provisions and arms to an advanced point in the west of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was necessary to think not only of the things which they should take\r\n'b'with them, but also of those which they might have by chance to bring\r\n'b'back to Granite House. If there had been a wreck on the coast, as was\r\n'b'supposed, there would be many things cast up, which would be lawfully\r\n'b'their prizes. In the event of this, the cart would have been of more use\r\n'b'than the light canoe, but it was heavy and clumsy to drag, and therefore\r\n'b'more difficult to use; this led Pencroft to express his regret that the\r\n'b'chest had not contained, besides \xe2\x80\x9chis halfpound of tobacco,\xe2\x80\x9d a pair\r\n'b'of strong New Jersey horses, which would have been very useful to the\r\n'b'colony!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The provisions, which Neb had already packed up, consisted of a store\r\n'b'of meat and of several gallons of beer, that is to say enough to sustain\r\n'b'them for three days, the time which Harding assigned for the expedition.\r\n'b'They hoped besides to supply themselves on the road, and Neb took care\r\n'b'not to forget the portable stove.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The only tools the settlers took were the two woodmen\xe2\x80\x99s axes, which\r\n'b'they could use to cut a path through the thick forests, as also the\r\n'b'instruments, the telescope and pocket-compass.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For weapons they selected the two flint-lock guns, which were likely\r\n'b'to be more useful to them than the percussion fowling-pieces, the first\r\n'b'only requiring flints which could be easily replaced, and the latter\r\n'b'needing fulminating caps, a frequent use of which would soon exhaust\r\n'b'their limited stock. However, they took also one of the carbines and\r\n'b'some cartridges. As to the powder, of which there was about fifty pounds\r\n'b'in the barrel, a small supply of it had to be taken, but the engineer\r\n'b'hoped to manufacture an explosive substance which would allow them to\r\n'b'husband it. To the firearms were added the five cutlasses well sheathed\r\n'b'in leather, and, thus supplied, the settlers could venture into the vast\r\n'b'forest with some chance of success.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is useless to add that Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb, thus armed, were\r\n'b'at the summit of their happiness, although Cyrus Harding made them\r\n'b'promise not to fire a shot unless it was necessary.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At six in the morning the canoe put off from the shore; all had\r\n'b'embarked, including Top, and they proceeded to the mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The tide had begun to come up half an hour before. For several hours,\r\n'b'therefore, there would be a current, which it was well to profit by, for\r\n'b'later the ebb would make it difficult to ascend the river. The tide was\r\n'b'already strong, for in three days the moon would be full, and it was\r\n'b'enough to keep the boat in the center of the current, where it floated\r\n'b'swiftly along between the high banks without its being necessary\r\n'b'to increase its speed by the aid of the oars. In a few minutes the\r\n'b'explorers arrived at the angle formed by the Mercy and exactly at the\r\n'b'place where, seven months before, Pencroft had made his first raft of\r\n'b'wood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After this sudden angle the river widened and flowed under the shade of\r\n'b'great evergreen firs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The aspect of the banks was magnificent. Cyrus Harding and his\r\n'b'companions could not but admire the lovely effects so easily produced\r\n'b'by nature with water and trees. As they advanced the forest element\r\n'b'diminished. On the right bank of the river grew magnificent specimens of\r\n'b'the ulmaceae tribe, the precious elm, so valuable to builders, and which\r\n'b'withstands well the action of water. Then there were numerous groups\r\n'b'belonging to the same family, among others one in particular, the fruit\r\n'b'of which produces a very useful oil. Further on, Herbert remarked the\r\n'b'lardizabala, a twining shrub which, when bruised in water, furnishes\r\n'b'excellent cordage; and two or three ebony trees of a beautiful black,\r\n'b'crossed with capricious veins.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From time to time, in certain places where the landing was easy, the\r\n'b'canoe was stopped, when Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Pencroft, their\r\n'b'guns in their hands, and preceded by Top, jumped on shore. Without\r\n'b'expecting game, some useful plant might be met with, and the young\r\n'b'naturalist was delighted with discovering a sort of wild spinach,\r\n'b'belonging to the order of chenopodiaceae, and numerous specimens of\r\n'b'cruciferae, belonging to the cabbage tribe, which it would certainly be\r\n'b'possible to cultivate by transplanting. There were cresses, horseradish,\r\n'b'turnips, and lastly, little branching hairy stalks, scarcely more than\r\n'b'three feet high, which produced brownish grains.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know what this plant is?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert of the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTobacco!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, who evidently had never seen his favorite\r\n'b'plant except in the bowl of his pipe.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is not tobacco, it is mustard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMustard be hanged!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if by chance you happen\r\n'b'to come across a tobacco-plant, my boy, pray don\xe2\x80\x99t scorn that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall find it some day!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen that day comes, I do not know what\r\n'b'more will be wanting in our island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These different plants, which had been carefully rooted up, were carried\r\n'b'to the canoe, where Cyrus Harding had remained buried in thought.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft in this manner frequently\r\n'b'disembarked, sometimes on the right bank, sometimes on the left bank of\r\n'b'the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The latter was less abrupt, but the former more wooded. The engineer\r\n'b'ascertained by consulting his pocket-compass that the direction of the\r\n'b'river from the first turn was obviously southwest and northeast, and\r\n'b'nearly straight for a length of about three miles. But it was to be\r\n'b'supposed that this direction changed beyond that point, and that the\r\n'b'Mercy continued to the north-west, towards the spurs of Mount Franklin,\r\n'b'among which the river rose.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During one of these excursions, Gideon Spilett managed to get hold\r\n'b'of two couples of living gallinaceae. They were birds with long, thin\r\n'b'beaks, lengthened necks, short wings, and without any appearance of\r\n'b'a tail. Herbert rightly gave them the name of tinamous, and it\r\n'b'was resolved that they should be the first tenants of their future\r\n'b'poultry-yard.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But till then the guns had not spoken, and the first report which awoke\r\n'b'the echoes of the forest of the Far West was provoked by the appearance\r\n'b'of a beautiful bird, resembling the kingfisher.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI recognize him!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, and it seemed as if his gun went off\r\n'b'by itself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you recognize?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe bird which escaped us on our first excursion, and from which we\r\n'b'gave the name to that part of the forest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA jacamar!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was indeed a jacamar, of which the plumage shines with a metallic\r\n'b'luster. A shot brought it to the ground, and Top carried it to the\r\n'b'canoe. At the same time half a dozen lories were brought down. The lory\r\n'b'is of the size of a pigeon, the plumage dashed with green, part of\r\n'b'the wings crimson, and its crest bordered with white. To the young boy\r\n'b'belonged the honor of this shot, and he was proud enough of it. Lories\r\n'b'are better food than the jacamar, the flesh of which is rather tough,\r\n'b'but it was difficult to persuade Pencroft that he had not killed the\r\n'b'king of eatable birds. It was ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning when the canoe\r\n'b'reached a second angle of the Mercy, nearly five miles from its mouth.\r\n'b'Here a halt was made for breakfast under the shade of some splendid\r\n'b'trees. The river still measured from sixty to seventy feet in breadth,\r\n'b'and its bed from five to six feet in depth. The engineer had observed\r\n'b'that it was increased by numerous affluents, but they were unnavigable,\r\n'b'being simply little streams. As to the forest, including Jacamar Wood,\r\n'b'as well as the forests of the Far West, it extended as far as the eye\r\n'b'could reach. In no place, either in the depths of the forests or under\r\n'b'the trees on the banks of the Mercy, was the presence of man revealed.\r\n'b'The explorers could not discover one suspicious trace. It was evident\r\n'b'that the woodman\xe2\x80\x99s axe had never touched these trees, that the pioneer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'knife had never severed the creepers hanging from one trunk to another\r\n'b'in the midst of tangled brushwood and long grass. If castaways had\r\n'b'landed on the island, they could not have yet quitted the shore, and it\r\n'b'was not in the woods that the survivors of the supposed shipwreck should\r\n'b'be sought.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer therefore manifested some impatience to reach the western\r\n'b'coast of Lincoln Island, which was at least five miles distant according\r\n'b'to his estimation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The voyage was continued, and as the Mercy appeared to flow not towards\r\n'b'the shore, but rather towards Mount Franklin, it was decided that they\r\n'b'should use the boat as long as there was enough water under its keel\r\n'b'to float it. It was both fatigue spared and time gained, for they would\r\n'b'have been obliged to cut a path through the thick wood with their axes.\r\n'b'But soon the flow completely failed them, either the tide was going\r\n'b'down, and it was about the hour, or it could no longer be felt at this\r\n'b'distance from the mouth of the Mercy. They had therefore to make use of\r\n'b'the oars. Herbert and Neb each took one, and Pencroft took the scull.\r\n'b'The forest soon became less dense, the trees grew further apart and\r\n'b'often quite isolated. But the further they were from each other the more\r\n'b'magnificent they appeared, profiting, as they did, by the free, pure air\r\n'b'which circulated around them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What splendid specimens of the flora of this latitude! Certainly\r\n'b'their presence would have been enough for a botanist to name without\r\n'b'hesitation the parallel which traversed Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEucalypti!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were, in fact, those splendid trees, the giants of the\r\n'b'extratropical zone, the congeners of the Australian and New Zealand\r\n'b'eucalyptus, both situated under the same latitude as Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'Some rose to a height of two hundred feet. Their trunks at the base\r\n'b'measured twenty feet in circumference, and their bark was covered by a\r\n'b'network of farrows containing a red, sweet-smelling gum. Nothing is more\r\n'b'wonderful or more singular than those enormous specimens of the order of\r\n'b'the myrtaceae, with their leaves placed vertically and not horizontally,\r\n'b'so that an edge and not a surface looks upwards, the effect being that\r\n'b'the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays penetrate more freely among the trees.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The ground at the foot of the eucalypti was carpeted with grass, and\r\n'b'from the bushes escaped flights of little birds, which glittered in the\r\n'b'sunlight like winged rubies.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThese are something like trees!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb; \xe2\x80\x9cbut are they good for\r\n'b'anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPooh!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course there are vegetable giants as well\r\n'b'as human giants, and they are no good, except to show themselves at\r\n'b'fairs!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think that you are mistaken, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\n'b'that the wood of the eucalyptus has begun to be very advantageously\r\n'b'employed in cabinet-making.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I may add,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the eucalyptus belongs to a family\r\n'b'which comprises many useful members; the guava-tree, from whose fruit\r\n'b'guava jelly is made; the clove-tree, which produces the spice; the\r\n'b'pomegranate-tree, which bears pomegranates; the Eugeacia Cauliflora,\r\n'b'the fruit of which is used in making a tolerable wine; the Ugui myrtle,\r\n'b'which contains an excellent alcoholic liquor; the Caryophyllus myrtle,\r\n'b'of which the bark forms an esteemed cinnamon; the Eugenia Pimenta, from\r\n'b'whence comes Jamaica pepper; the common myrtle, from whose buds and\r\n'b'berries spice is sometimes made; the Eucalyptus manifera, which yields\r\n'b'a sweet sort of manna; the Guinea Eucalyptus, the sap of which is\r\n'b'transformed into beer by fermentation; in short, all those trees known\r\n'b'under the name of gum-trees or iron-bark trees in Australia, belong\r\n'b'to this family of the myrtaceae, which contains forty-six genera and\r\n'b'thirteen hundred species!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The lad was allowed to run on, and he delivered his little botanical\r\n'b'lecture with great animation. Cyrus Harding listened smiling, and\r\n'b'Pencroft with an indescribable feeling of pride.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery good, Herbert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I could swear that all\r\n'b'those useful specimens you have just told us about are none of them\r\n'b'giants like these!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat supports what I said,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cnamely, that these\r\n'b'giants are good for nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere you are wrong, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cthese gigantic\r\n'b'eucalypti, which shelter us, are good for something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo render the countries which they inhabit healthy. Do you know what\r\n'b'they are called in Australia and New Zealand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey are called \xe2\x80\x98fever trees.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause they give fevers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, because they prevent them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood. I must note that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNote it then, my dear Spilett; for it appears proved that the presence\r\n'b'of the eucalyptus is enough to neutralize miasmas. This natural antidote\r\n'b'has been tried in certain countries in the middle of Europe and the\r\n'b'north of Africa where the soil was absolutely unhealthy, and the\r\n'b'sanitary condition of the inhabitants has been gradually ameliorated. No\r\n'b'more intermittent fevers prevail in the regions now covered with forests\r\n'b'of the myrtaceae. This fact is now beyond doubt, and it is a happy\r\n'b'circumstance for us settlers in Lincoln Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh! what an island! What a blessed island!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cI tell\r\n'b'you, it wants nothing--unless it is--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat will come, Pencroft, that will be found,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer;\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cbut now we must continue our voyage and push on as far as the river\r\n'b'will carry our boat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The exploration was therefore continued for another two miles in the\r\n'b'midst of country covered with eucalypti, which predominated in the woods\r\n'b'of this portion of the island. The space which they occupied extended as\r\n'b'far as the eye could reach on each side of the Mercy, which wound along\r\n'b'between high green banks. The bed was often obstructed by long weeds,\r\n'b'and even by pointed rocks, which rendered the navigation very difficult.\r\n'b'The action of the oars was prevented, and Pencroft was obliged to push\r\n'b'with a pole. They found also that the water was becoming shallower\r\n'b'and shallower, and that the canoe must soon stop. The sun was already\r\n'b'sinking towards the horizon, and the trees threw long shadows on the\r\n'b'ground. Cyrus Harding, seeing that he could not hope to reach the\r\n'b'western coast of the island in one journey, resolved to camp at the\r\n'b'place where any further navigation was prevented by want of water. He\r\n'b'calculated that they were still five or six miles from the coast, and\r\n'b'this distance was too great for them to attempt during the night in the\r\n'b'midst of unknown woods.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The boat was pushed on through the forest, which gradually became\r\n'b'thicker again, and appeared also to have more inhabitants; for if the\r\n'b'eyes of the sailor did not deceive him, he thought he saw bands of\r\n'b'monkeys springing among the trees. Sometimes even two or three of these\r\n'b'animals stopped at a little distance from the canoe and gazed at the\r\n'b'settlers without manifesting any terror, as if, seeing men for the first\r\n'b'time, they had not yet learned to fear them. It would have been easy\r\n'b'to bring down one of these quadramani with a gunshot, and Pencroft was\r\n'b'greatly tempted to fire, but Harding opposed so useless a massacre.\r\n'b'This was prudent, for the monkeys, or apes rather, appearing to be very\r\n'b'powerful and extremely active, it was useless to provoke an unnecessary\r\n'b'aggression, and the creatures might, ignorant of the power of the\r\n'b'explorers\xe2\x80\x99 firearms, have attacked them. It is true that the sailor\r\n'b'considered the monkeys from a purely alimentary point of view, for those\r\n'b'animals which are herbivorous make very excellent game; but since they\r\n'b'had an abundant supply of provisions, it was a pity to waste their\r\n'b'ammunition.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the navigation of the Mercy became exceedingly\r\n'b'difficult, for its course was obstructed by aquatic plants and rocks.\r\n'b'The banks rose higher and higher, and already they were approaching the\r\n'b'spurs of Mount Franklin. The source could not be far off, since it was\r\n'b'fed by the water from the southern slopes of the mountain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn a quarter of an hour,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall be obliged to\r\n'b'stop, captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, we will stop, Pencroft, and we will make our encampment for\r\n'b'the night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt what distance are we from Granite House?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout seven miles,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9ctaking into calculation,\r\n'b'however, the detours of the river, which has carried us to the\r\n'b'northwest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShall we go on?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, as long as we can,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow, at break of\r\n'b'day, we will leave the canoe, and in two hours I hope we shall cross the\r\n'b'distance which separates us from the coast, and then we shall have the\r\n'b'whole day in which to explore the shore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGo ahead!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But soon the boat grated on the stony bottom of the river, which was\r\n'b'now not more than twenty feet in breadth. The trees met like a bower\r\n'b'overhead, and caused a half-darkness. They also heard the noise of a\r\n'b'waterfall, which showed that a few hundred feet up the river there was a\r\n'b'natural barrier.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Presently, after a sudden turn of the river, a cascade appeared through\r\n'b'the trees. The canoe again touched the bottom, and in a few minutes it\r\n'b'was moored to a trunk near the right bank.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was nearly five o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The last rays of the sun gleamed through\r\n'b'the thick foliage and glanced on the little waterfall, making the spray\r\n'b'sparkle with all the colors of the rainbow. Beyond that, the Mercy was\r\n'b'lost in the bushwood, where it was fed from some hidden source. The\r\n'b'different streams which flowed into it increased it to a regular river\r\n'b'further down, but here it was simply a shallow, limpid brook.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was agreed to camp here, as the place was charming. The colonists\r\n'b'disembarked, and a fire was soon lighted under a clump of trees, among\r\n'b'the branches of which Cyrus Harding and his companions could, if it was\r\n'b'necessary, take refuge for the night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Supper was quickly devoured, for they were very hungry, and then there\r\n'b'was only sleeping to think of. But, as roarings of rather a suspicious\r\n'b'nature had been heard during the evening, a good fire was made up for\r\n'b'the night, so as to protect the sleepers with its crackling flames. Neb\r\n'b'and Pencroft also watched by turns, and did not spare fuel. They thought\r\n'b'they saw the dark forms of some wild animals prowling round the camp\r\n'b'among the bushes, but the night passed without incident, and the next\r\n'b'day, the 31st of October, at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, all were on\r\n'b'foot, ready for a start.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 4\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was six o\xe2\x80\x99 clock in the morning when the settlers, after a hasty\r\n'b'breakfast, set out to reach by the shortest way, the western coast of\r\n'b'the island. And how long would it take to do this? Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'had said two hours, but of course that depended on the nature of the\r\n'b'obstacles they might meet with. As it was probable that they would have\r\n'b'to cut a path through the grass, shrubs, and creepers, they marched axe\r\n'b'in hand, and with guns also ready, wisely taking warning from the cries\r\n'b'of the wild beasts heard in the night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The exact position of the encampment could be determined by the bearing\r\n'b'of Mount Franklin, and as the volcano arose in the north at a distance\r\n'b'of less than three miles, they had only to go straight towards the\r\n'b'southwest to reach the western coast. They set out, having first\r\n'b'carefully secured the canoe. Pencroft and Neb carried sufficient\r\n'b'provision for the little band for at least two days. It would not thus\r\n'b'be necessary to hunt. The engineer advised his companions to refrain\r\n'b'from firing, that their presence might not be betrayed to any one near\r\n'b'the shore. The first hatchet blows were given among the brushwood in the\r\n'b'midst of some mastic-trees, a little above the cascade; and his compass\r\n'b'in his hand, Cyrus Harding led the way.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The forest here was composed for the most part of trees which had\r\n'b'already been met with near the lake and on Prospect Heights. There\r\n'b'were deodars, Douglas firs, casuarinas, gum trees, eucalypti, hibiscus,\r\n'b'cedars, and other trees, generally of a moderate size, for their number\r\n'b'prevented their growth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Since their departure, the settlers had descended the slopes which\r\n'b'constituted the mountain system of the island, on to a dry soil, but the\r\n'b'luxuriant vegetation of which indicated it to be watered either by some\r\n'b'subterranean marsh or by some stream. However, Cyrus Harding did not\r\n'b'remember having seen, at the time of his excursion to the crater, any\r\n'b'other watercourses but the Red Creek and the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the first part of their excursion, they saw numerous troops of\r\n'b'monkeys who exhibited great astonishment at the sight of men, whose\r\n'b'appearance was so new to them. Gideon Spilett jokingly asked whether\r\n'b'these active and merry quadrupeds did not consider him and his\r\n'b'companions as degenerate brothers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And certainly, pedestrians, hindered at each step by bushes, caught by\r\n'b'creepers, barred by trunks of trees, did not shine beside those supple\r\n'b'animals, who, bounding from branch to branch, were hindered by nothing\r\n'b'on their course. The monkeys were numerous, but happily they did not\r\n'b'manifest any hostile disposition.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Several pigs, agoutis, kangaroos, and other rodents were seen, also two\r\n'b'or three koalas, at which Pencroft longed to have a shot.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou may jump and play just now; we shall have one or\r\n'b'two words to say to you on our way back!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At half-past nine the way was suddenly found to be barred by an unknown\r\n'b'stream, from thirty to forty feet broad, whose rapid current dashed\r\n'b'foaming over the numerous rocks which interrupted its course. This creek\r\n'b'was deep and clear, but it was absolutely unnavigable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are cut off!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is only a stream, and we can easily swim\r\n'b'over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would be the use of that?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cThis creek evidently\r\n'b'runs to the sea. Let us remain on this side and follow the bank, and\r\n'b'I shall be much astonished if it does not lead us very quickly to the\r\n'b'coast. Forward!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne minute,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cThe name of this creek, my friends? Do\r\n'b'not let us leave our geography incomplete.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll right!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cName it, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, addressing the lad.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWill it not be better to wait until we have explored it to its mouth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' answered Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us follow it as fast as we can\r\n'b'without stopping.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStill another minute!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThough hunting is forbidden, fishing is allowed, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\n'b'sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe have no time to lose,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! five minutes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI only ask for five minutes to\r\n'b'use in the interest of our breakfast!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Pencroft, lying down on the bank, plunged his arm into the water,\r\n'b'and soon pulled up several dozen of fine crayfish from among the stones.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThese will be good!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, going to the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s aid.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs I said, there is everything in this island, except tobacco!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' muttered Pencroft with a sigh.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The fishing did not take five minutes, for the crayfish were swarming in\r\n'b'the creek. A bag was filled with the crustaceae, whose shells were of a\r\n'b'cobalt blue. The settlers then pushed on.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They advanced more rapidly and easily along the bank of the river than\r\n'b'in the forest. From time to time they came upon the traces of animals of\r\n'b'a large size who had come to quench their thirst at the stream, but none\r\n'b'were actually seen, and it was evidently not in this part of the forest\r\n'b'that the peccary had received the bullet which had cost Pencroft a\r\n'b'grinder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, considering the rapid current, Harding was led to\r\n'b'suppose that he and his companions were much farther from the western\r\n'b'coast than they had at first supposed. In fact, at this hour, the rising\r\n'b'tide would have turned back the current of the creek, if its mouth had\r\n'b'only been a few miles distant. Now, this effect was not produced, and\r\n'b'the water pursued its natural course. The engineer was much astonished\r\n'b'at this, and frequently consulted his compass, to assure himself that\r\n'b'some turn of the river was not leading them again into the Far West.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the creek gradually widened and its waters became less\r\n'b'tumultuous. The trees on the right bank were as close together as on the\r\n'b'left bank, and it was impossible to distinguish anything beyond them;\r\n'b'but these masses of wood were evidently uninhabited, for Top did not\r\n'b'bark, and the intelligent animal would not have failed to signal the\r\n'b'presence of any stranger in the neighborhood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At half-past ten, to the great surprise of Cyrus Harding, Herbert, who\r\n'b'was a little in front, suddenly stopped and exclaimed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe sea!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few minutes more, the whole western shore of the island lay\r\n'b'extended before the eyes of the settlers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But what a contrast between this and the eastern coast, upon which\r\n'b'chance had first thrown them. No granite cliff, no rocks, not even a\r\n'b'sandy beach. The forest reached the shore, and the tall trees bending\r\n'b'over the water were beaten by the waves. It was not such a shore as is\r\n'b'usually formed by nature, either by extending a vast carpet of sand,\r\n'b'or by grouping masses of rock, but a beautiful border consisting of the\r\n'b'most splendid trees. The bank was raised a little above the level of the\r\n'b'sea, and on this luxuriant soil, supported by a granite base, the fine\r\n'b'forest trees seemed to be as firmly planted as in the interior of the\r\n'b'island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists were then on the shore of an unimportant little harbor,\r\n'b'which would scarcely have contained even two or three fishing-boats. It\r\n'b'served as a neck to the new creek, of which the curious thing was that\r\n'b'its waters, instead of joining the sea by a gentle slope, fell from a\r\n'b'height of more than forty feet, which explained why the rising tide was\r\n'b'not felt up the stream. In fact, the tides of the Pacific, even at\r\n'b'their maximum elevation, could never reach the level of the river, and,\r\n'b'doubtless, millions of years would pass before the water would have worn\r\n'b'away the granite and hollowed a practicable mouth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was settled that the name of Falls River should be given to this\r\n'b'stream. Beyond, towards the north, the forest border was prolonged for\r\n'b'a space of nearly two miles; then the trees became scarcer, and beyond\r\n'b'that again the picturesque heights described a nearly straight line,\r\n'b'which ran north and south. On the contrary, all the part of the shore\r\n'b'between Falls River and Reptile End was a mass of wood, magnificent\r\n'b'trees, some straight, others bent, so that the long sea-swell bathed\r\n'b'their roots. Now, it was this coast, that is, all the Serpentine\r\n'b'Peninsula, that was to be explored, for this part of the shore offered\r\n'b'a refuge to castaways, which the other wild and barren side must have\r\n'b'refused.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The weather was fine and clear, and from a height of a hillock on which\r\n'b'Neb and Pencroft had arranged breakfast, a wide view was obtained. There\r\n'b'was, however, not a sail in sight; nothing could be seen along the shore\r\n'b'as far as the eye could reach. But the engineer would take nothing for\r\n'b'granted until he had explored the coast to the very extremity of the\r\n'b'Serpentine Peninsula.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Breakfast was soon despatched, and at half-past eleven the captain gave\r\n'b'the signal for departure. Instead of proceeding over the summit of a\r\n'b'cliff or along a sandy beach, the settlers were obliged to remain under\r\n'b'cover of the trees so that they might continue on the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The distance which separated Falls River from Reptile End was about\r\n'b'twelve miles. It would have taken the settlers four hours to do this,\r\n'b'on a clear ground and without hurrying themselves; but as it was they\r\n'b'needed double the time, for what with trees to go round, bushes to cut\r\n'b'down, and creepers to chop away, they were impeded at every step, these\r\n'b'obstacles greatly lengthening their journey.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was, however, nothing to show that a shipwreck had taken place\r\n'b'recently. It is true that, as Gideon Spilett observed, any remains of\r\n'b'it might have drifted out to sea, and they must not take it for granted\r\n'b'that because they could find no traces of it, a ship had not been\r\n'b'castaway on the coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter\xe2\x80\x99s argument was just, and besides, the incident of the\r\n'b'bullet proved that a shot must have been fired in Lincoln Island within\r\n'b'three months.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was already five o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and there were still two miles between the\r\n'b'settlers and the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula. It was evident\r\n'b'that after having reached Reptile End, Harding and his companions would\r\n'b'not have time to return before dark to their encampment near the source\r\n'b'of the Mercy. It would therefore be necessary to pass the night on the\r\n'b'promontory. But they had no lack of provisions, which was lucky, for\r\n'b'there were no animals on the shore, though birds, on the contrary,\r\n'b'abound--jacamars, couroucous, tragopans, grouse, lories, parrots,\r\n'b'cockatoos, pheasants, pigeons, and a hundred others. There was not\r\n'b'a tree without a nest, and not a nest which was not full of flapping\r\n'b'wings.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the weary explorers arrived at Reptile End. Here\r\n'b'the seaside forest ended, and the shore resumed the customary appearance\r\n'b'of a coast, with rocks, reefs, and sands. It was possible that something\r\n'b'might be found here, but darkness came on, and the further exploration\r\n'b'had to be put off to the next day.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Herbert hastened on to find a suitable place for their\r\n'b'camp. Among the last trees of the forest of the Far West, the boy found\r\n'b'several thick clumps of bamboos.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a valuable discovery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cValuable?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cI may say, Pencroft, that the bark of the\r\n'b'bamboo, cut into flexible laths, is used for making baskets; that this\r\n'b'bark, mashed into a paste, is used for the manufacture of Chinese paper;\r\n'b'that the stalks furnish, according to their size, canes and pipes\r\n'b'and are used for conducting water; that large bamboos make excellent\r\n'b'material for building, being light and strong, and being never attacked\r\n'b'by insects. I will add that by sawing the bamboo in two at the joint,\r\n'b'keeping for the bottom the part of the transverse film which forms\r\n'b'the joint, useful cups are obtained, which are much in use among the\r\n'b'Chinese. No! you don\xe2\x80\x99t care for that. But--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can tell you, if you are ignorant of it, that in India these\r\n'b'bamboos are eaten like asparagus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAsparagus thirty feet high!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd are they good?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cExcellent,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly it is not the stems of thirty feet\r\n'b'high which are eaten, but the young shoots.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerfect, my boy, perfect!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will also add that the pith of the young stalks, preserved in\r\n'b'vinegar, makes a good pickle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBetter and better, Herbert!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd lastly, that the bamboos exude a sweet liquor which can be made\r\n'b'into a very agreeable drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs that all?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they don\xe2\x80\x99t happen to do for smoking?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my poor Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and the sailor had not to look long for a place in which to pass\r\n'b'the night. The rocks, which must have been violently beaten by the\r\n'b'sea under the influence of the winds of the southwest, presented many\r\n'b'cavities in which shelter could be found against the night air. But just\r\n'b'as they were about to enter one of these caves a loud roaring arrested\r\n'b'them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBack!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cOur guns are only loaded with small shot, and\r\n'b'beasts which can roar as loud as that would care no more for it than for\r\n'b'grains of salt!\xe2\x80\x9d And the sailor, seizing Herbert by the arm, dragged\r\n'b'him behind a rock, just as a magnificent animal showed itself at the\r\n'b'entrance of the cavern.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was a jaguar of a size at least equal to its Asiatic congeners, that\r\n'b'is to say, it measured five feet from the extremity of its head to the\r\n'b'beginning of its tail. The yellow color of its hair was relieved by\r\n'b'streaks and regular oblong spots of black, which contrasted with the\r\n'b'white of its chest. Herbert recognized it as the ferocious rival of\r\n'b'the tiger, as formidable as the puma, which is the rival of the largest\r\n'b'wolf!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The jaguar advanced and gazed around him with blazing eyes, his hair\r\n'b'bristling as if this was not the first time he had scented men.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment the reporter appeared round a rock, and Herbert, thinking\r\n'b'that he had not seen the jaguar, was about to rush towards him, when\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett signed to him to remain where he was. This was not his\r\n'b'first tiger, and advancing to within ten feet of the animal he remained\r\n'b'motionless, his gun to his shoulder, without moving a muscle. The jaguar\r\n'b'collected itself for a spring, but at that moment a shot struck it in\r\n'b'the eyes, and it fell dead.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and Pencroft rushed towards the jaguar. Neb and Harding also ran\r\n'b'up, and they remained for some instants contemplating the animal as it\r\n'b'lay stretched on the ground, thinking that its magnificent skin would be\r\n'b'a great ornament to the hall at Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Mr. Spilett, how I admire and envy you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, in a fit of\r\n'b'very natural enthusiasm.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cyou could have done the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI! with such coolness!--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cImagine to yourself, Herbert, that the jaguar is only a hare, and you\r\n'b'would fire as quietly as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it is not more dangerous than a\r\n'b'hare!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9csince the jaguar has left its abode, I\r\n'b'do not see, my friends, why we should not take possession of it for the\r\n'b'night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut others may come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be enough to light a fire at the entrance of the cavern,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\n'b'the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand no wild beasts will dare to cross the threshold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cInto the jaguar\xe2\x80\x99s house, then!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, dragging after him\r\n'b'the body of the animal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While Neb skinned the jaguar, his companions collected an abundant\r\n'b'supply of dry wood from the forest, which they heaped up at the cave.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, seeing the clump of bamboos, cut a quantity, which he\r\n'b'mingled with the other fuel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This done, they entered the grotto, of which the floor was strewn with\r\n'b'bones, the guns were carefully loaded, in case of a sudden attack, they\r\n'b'had supper, and then just before they lay down to rest, the heap of wood\r\n'b'piled at the entrance was set fire to. Immediately, a regular explosion,\r\n'b'or rather a series of reports, broke the silence! The noise was caused\r\n'b'by the bamboos, which, as the flames reached them, exploded like\r\n'b'fireworks. The noise was enough to terrify even the boldest of wild\r\n'b'beasts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was not the engineer who had invented this way of causing loud\r\n'b'explosions, for, according to Marco Polo, the Tartars have employed it\r\n'b'for many centuries to drive away from their encampments the formidable\r\n'b'wild beasts of Central Asia.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 5\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions slept like innocent marmots in the cave\r\n'b'which the jaguar had so politely left at their disposal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At sunrise all were on the shore at the extremity of the promontory, and\r\n'b'their gaze was directed towards the horizon, of which two-thirds of\r\n'b'the circumference were visible. For the last time the engineer could\r\n'b'ascertain that not a sail nor the wreck of a ship was on the sea, and\r\n'b'even with the telescope nothing suspicious could be discovered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was nothing either on the shore, at least, in the straight line\r\n'b'of three miles which formed the south side of the promontory, for\r\n'b'beyond that, rising ground had the rest of the coast, and even from the\r\n'b'extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula Claw Cape could not be seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The southern coast of the island still remained to be explored. Now\r\n'b'should they undertake it immediately, and devote this day to it?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was not included in their first plan. In fact, when the boat was\r\n'b'abandoned at the sources of the Mercy, it had been agreed that after\r\n'b'having surveyed the west coast, they should go back to it, and return to\r\n'b'Granite House by the Mercy. Harding then thought that the western coast\r\n'b'would have offered refuge, either to a ship in distress, or to a vessel\r\n'b'in her regular course; but now, as he saw that this coast presented no\r\n'b'good anchorage, he wished to seek on the south what they had not been\r\n'b'able to find on the west.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett proposed to continue the exploration, that the question\r\n'b'of the supposed wreck might be completely settled, and he asked at what\r\n'b'distance Claw Cape might be from the extremity of the peninsula.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout thirty miles,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cif we take into\r\n'b'consideration the curvings of the coast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThirty miles!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cThat would be a long day\xe2\x80\x99s march.\r\n'b'Nevertheless, I think that we should return to Granite House by the\r\n'b'south coast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom Claw Cape to Granite House there must be\r\n'b'at least another ten miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMake it forty miles in all,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand do not hesitate\r\n'b'to do it. At least we should survey the unknown shore, and then we shall\r\n'b'not have to begin the exploration again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cBut the boat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe boat has remained by itself for one day at the sources of the\r\n'b'Mercy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett; \xe2\x80\x9cit may just as well stay there two\r\n'b'days! As yet, we have had no reason to think that the island is infested\r\n'b'by thieves!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I remember the history of the turtle, I am\r\n'b'far from confident of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe turtle! the turtle!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you know that the\r\n'b'sea turned it over?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho knows?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,--\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb had evidently something to say, for he opened his mouth to speak and\r\n'b'yet said nothing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want to say, Neb?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf we return by the shore to Claw Cape,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cafter having\r\n'b'doubled the Cape, we shall be stopped--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy the Mercy! of course,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand we shall have neither\r\n'b'bridge nor boat by which to cross.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwith a few floating trunks we shall\r\n'b'have no difficulty in crossing the river.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cit will be useful to construct a bridge if\r\n'b'we wish to have an easy access to the Far West!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA bridge!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, is not the captain the best engineer\r\n'b'in his profession? He will make us a bridge when we want one. As to\r\n'b'transporting you this evening to the other side of the Mercy, and that\r\n'b'without wetting one thread of your clothes, I will take care of that. We\r\n'b'have provisions for another day, and besides we can get plenty of game.\r\n'b'Forward!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter\xe2\x80\x99s proposal, so strongly seconded by the sailor, received\r\n'b'general approbation, for each wished to have their doubts set at rest,\r\n'b'and by returning by Claw Cape the exploration would be ended. But there\r\n'b'was not an hour to lose, for forty miles was a long march, and they\r\n'b'could not hope to reach Granite House before night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning the little band set out. As a precaution\r\n'b'the guns were loaded with ball, and Top, who led the van, received\r\n'b'orders to beat about the edge of the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From the extremity of the promontory which formed the tail of the\r\n'b'peninsula the coast was rounded for a distance of five miles, which\r\n'b'was rapidly passed over, without even the most minute investigations\r\n'b'bringing to light the least trace of any old or recent landings; no\r\n'b'debris, no mark of an encampment, no cinders of a fire, nor even a\r\n'b'footprint!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From the point of the peninsula on which the settlers now were their\r\n'b'gaze could extend along the southwest. Twenty-five miles off the coast\r\n'b'terminated in the Claw Cape, which loomed dimly through the morning\r\n'b'mists, and which, by the phenomenon of the mirage, appeared as if\r\n'b'suspended between land and water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Between the place occupied by the colonists and the other side of the\r\n'b'immense bay, the shore was composed, first, of a tract of low land,\r\n'b'bordered in the background by trees; then the shore became more\r\n'b'irregular, projecting sharp points into the sea, and finally ended in\r\n'b'the black rocks which, accumulated in picturesque disorder, formed Claw\r\n'b'Cape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Such was the development of this part of the island, which the settlers\r\n'b'took in at a glance, while stopping for an instant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf a vessel ran in here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cshe would certainly be lost.\r\n'b'Sandbanks and reefs everywhere! Bad quarters!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut at least something would be left of the ship,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the\r\n'b'reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere might be pieces of wood on the rocks, but nothing on the sands,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' replied the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the sands are still more dangerous than the rocks, for they\r\n'b'swallow up everything that is thrown on them. In a few days the hull of\r\n'b'a ship of several hundred tons would disappear entirely in there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cif a ship has been wrecked on\r\n'b'these banks, is it not astonishing that there is now no trace of her\r\n'b'remaining?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, captain, with the aid of time and tempest. However, it would be\r\n'b'surprising, even in this case, that some of the masts or spars should\r\n'b'not have been thrown on the beach, out of reach of the waves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go on with our search, then,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At one o\xe2\x80\x99clock the colonists arrived at the other side of Washington\r\n'b'Bay, they having now gone a distance of twenty miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They then halted for breakfast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Here began the irregular coast, covered with lines of rocks and\r\n'b'sandbanks. The long sea-swell could be seen breaking over the rocks in\r\n'b'the bay, forming a foamy fringe. From this point to Claw Cape the beach\r\n'b'was very narrow between the edge of the forest and the reefs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Walking was now more difficult, on account of the numerous rocks which\r\n'b'encumbered the beach. The granite cliff also gradually increased in\r\n'b'height, and only the green tops of the trees which crowned it could be\r\n'b'seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After half an hour\xe2\x80\x99s rest, the settlers resumed their journey, and not\r\n'b'a spot among the rocks was left unexamined. Pencroft and Neb even rushed\r\n'b'into the surf whenever any object attracted their attention. But they\r\n'b'found nothing, some curious formations of the rocks having deceived\r\n'b'them. They ascertained, however, that eatable shellfish abounded there,\r\n'b'but these could not be of any great advantage to them until some easy\r\n'b'means of communication had been established between the two banks of the\r\n'b'Mercy, and until the means of transport had been perfected.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nothing therefore which threw any light on the supposed wreck could be\r\n'b'found on this shore, yet an object of any importance, such as the hull\r\n'b'of a ship, would have been seen directly, or any of her masts and spars\r\n'b'would have been washed on shore, just as the chest had been, which was\r\n'b'found twenty miles from here. But there was nothing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards three o\xe2\x80\x99clock Harding and his companions arrived at a snug\r\n'b'little creek. It formed quite a natural harbor, invisible from the sea,\r\n'b'and was entered by a narrow channel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the back of this creek some violent convulsion had torn up the\r\n'b'rocky border, and a cutting, by a gentle slope, gave access to an upper\r\n'b'plateau, which might be situated at least ten miles from Claw Cape, and\r\n'b'consequently four miles in a straight line from Prospect Heights. Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett proposed to his companions that they should make a halt here.\r\n'b'They agreed readily, for their walk had sharpened their appetites;\r\n'b'and although it was not their usual dinner-hour, no one refused to\r\n'b'strengthen himself with a piece of venison. This luncheon would sustain\r\n'b'them until their supper, which they intended to take at Granite House.\r\n'b'In a few minutes the settlers, seated under a clump of fine sea-pines,\r\n'b'were devouring the provisions which Neb produced from his bag.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This spot was raised from fifty to sixty feet above the level of the\r\n'b'sea. The view was very extensive, but beyond the cape it ended in Union\r\n'b'Bay. Neither the islet nor Prospect Heights was visible, and could not\r\n'b'be from thence, for the rising ground and the curtain of trees closed\r\n'b'the northern horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is useless to add that notwithstanding the wide extent of sea which\r\n'b'the explorers could survey, and though the engineer swept the horizon\r\n'b'with his glass, no vessel could be found.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The shore was of course examined with the same care from the edge of the\r\n'b'water to the cliff, and nothing could be discovered even with the aid of\r\n'b'the instrument.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems we must make up our minds to\r\n'b'console ourselves with thinking that no one will come to dispute with us\r\n'b'the possession of Lincoln Island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut the bullet,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cThat was not imaginary, I suppose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHang it, no!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, thinking of his absent tooth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen what conclusion may be drawn?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cthat three months or more ago, a vessel,\r\n'b'either voluntarily or not, came here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! then you admit, Cyrus, that she was swallowed up without leaving\r\n'b'any trace?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear Spilett; but you see that if it is certain that a human\r\n'b'being set foot on the island, it appears no less certain that he has now\r\n'b'left it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, if I understand you right, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthe vessel\r\n'b'has left again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEvidently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we have lost an opportunity to get back to our country?\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI fear so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, since the opportunity is lost, let us go on; it can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\n'b'helped,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, who felt home-sickness for Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But just as they were rising, Top was heard loudly barking; and the dog\r\n'b'issued from the wood, holding in his mouth a rag soiled with mud.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb seized it. It was a piece of strong cloth!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top still barked, and by his going and coming, seemed to invite his\r\n'b'master to follow him into the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow there\xe2\x80\x99s something to explain the bullet!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA castaway!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWounded, perhaps!\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOr dead!\xe2\x80\x9d added the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All ran after the dog, among the tall pines on the border of the forest.\r\n'b'Harding and his companions made ready their firearms, in case of an\r\n'b'emergency.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They advanced some way into the wood, but to their great disappointment,\r\n'b'they as yet saw no signs of any human being having passed that way.\r\n'b'Shrubs and creepers were uninjured, and they had even to cut them away\r\n'b'with the axe, as they had done in the deepest recesses of the forest.\r\n'b'It was difficult to fancy that any human creature had ever passed there,\r\n'b'but yet Top went backward and forward, not like a dog who searches at\r\n'b'random, but like a dog being endowed with a mind, who is following up an\r\n'b'idea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In about seven or eight minutes Top stopped in a glade surrounded with\r\n'b'tall trees. The settlers gazed around them, but saw nothing, neither\r\n'b'under the bushes nor among the trees.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter, Top?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top barked louder, bounding about at the foot of a gigantic pine. All at\r\n'b'once Pencroft shouted,--\xe2\x80\x9cHo, splendid! capital!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe have been looking for a wreck at sea or on land!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell; and here we\xe2\x80\x99ve found one in the air!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor pointed to a great white rag, caught in the top of the\r\n'b'pine, a fallen scrap of which the dog had brought to them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is not a wreck!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? is it--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is all that remains of our airy boat, of our balloon, which has been\r\n'b'caught up aloft there, at the top of that tree!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft was not mistaken, and he gave vent to his feelings in a\r\n'b'tremendous hurrah, adding,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is good cloth! There is what will furnish us with linen for\r\n'b'years. There is what will make us handkerchiefs and shirts! Ha, ha, Mr.\r\n'b'Spilett, what do you say to an island where shirts grow on the trees?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was certainly a lucky circumstance for the settlers in Lincoln Island\r\n'b'that the balloon, after having made its last bound into the air, had\r\n'b'fallen on the island and thus given them the opportunity of finding it\r\n'b'again, whether they kept the case under its present form, or whether\r\n'b'they wished to attempt another escape by it, or whether they usefully\r\n'b'employed the several hundred yards of cotton, which was of fine quality.\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s joy was therefore shared by all.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But it was necessary to bring down the remains of the balloon from\r\n'b'the tree, to place it in security, and this was no slight task. Neb,\r\n'b'Herbert, and the sailor, climbing to the summit of the tree, used all\r\n'b'their skill to disengage the now reduced balloon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The operation lasted two hours, and then not only the case, with its\r\n'b'valve, its springs, its brasswork, lay on the ground, but the net, that\r\n'b'is to say a considerable quantity of ropes and cordage, and the\r\n'b'circle and the anchor. The case, except for the fracture, was in good\r\n'b'condition, only the lower portion being torn.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was a fortune which had fallen from the sky.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll the same, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cif we ever decide to leave\r\n'b'the island, it won\xe2\x80\x99t be in a balloon, will it? These airboats won\xe2\x80\x99t go\r\n'b'where we want them to go, and we have had some experience in that way!\r\n'b'Look here, we will build a craft of some twenty tons, and then we can\r\n'b'make a main-sail, a foresail, and a jib out of that cloth. As to the\r\n'b'rest of it, that will help to dress us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn the meantime, we must put it in a safe place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They certainly could not think of carrying this load of cloth,\r\n'b'ropes, and cordage, to Granite House, for the weight of it was very\r\n'b'considerable, and while waiting for a suitable vehicle in which to\r\n'b'convey it, it was of importance that this treasure should not be left\r\n'b'longer exposed to the mercies of the first storm. The settlers, uniting\r\n'b'their efforts, managed to drag it as far as the shore, where they\r\n'b'discovered a large rocky cavity, which owing to its position could not\r\n'b'be visited either by the wind or rain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe needed a locker, and now we have one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as we\r\n'b'cannot lock it up, it will be prudent to hide the opening. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean\r\n'b'from two-legged thieves, but from those with four paws!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At six o\xe2\x80\x99clock, all was stowed away, and after having given the creek\r\n'b'the very suitable name of \xe2\x80\x9cPort Balloon,\xe2\x80\x9d the settlers pursued their\r\n'b'way along Claw Cape. Pencroft and the engineer talked of the different\r\n'b'projects which it was agreed to put into execution with the briefest\r\n'b'possible delay. It was necessary first of all to throw a bridge over the\r\n'b'Mercy, so as to establish an easy communication with the south of the\r\n'b'island; then the cart must be taken to bring back the balloon, for the\r\n'b'canoe alone could not carry it, then they would build a decked boat, and\r\n'b'Pencroft would rig it as a cutter, and they would be able to undertake\r\n'b'voyages of circumnavigation round the island, etc.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile night came on, and it was already dark when the\r\n'b'settlers reached Flotsam Point, where they had found the precious chest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The distance between Flotsam Point and Granite House was another four\r\n'b'miles, and it was midnight when, after having followed the shore to the\r\n'b'mouth of the Mercy, the settlers arrived at the first angle formed by\r\n'b'the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There the river was eighty feet in breadth, which was awkward to cross,\r\n'b'but as Pencroft had taken upon himself to conquer this difficulty, he\r\n'b'was compelled to do it. The settlers certainly had reason to be pretty\r\n'b'tired. The journey had been long, and the task of getting down the\r\n'b'balloon had not rested either their arms or legs. They were anxious\r\n'b'to reach Granite House to eat and sleep, and if the bridge had been\r\n'b'constructed, in a quarter of an hour they would have been at home.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night was very dark.
