Pencroft prepared to keep his promise by\r\n'b'constructing a sort of raft, on which to make the passage of the Mercy.\r\n'b'He and Neb, armed with axes, chose two trees near the water, and began\r\n'b'to attack them at the base.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Spilett, seated on the bank, waited till their\r\n'b'companions were ready for their help, while Herbert roamed about, though\r\n'b'without going to any distance. All at once, the lad, who had strolled by\r\n'b'the river, came running back, and, pointing up the Mercy, exclaimed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is floating there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft stopped working, and seeing an indistinct object moving through\r\n'b'the gloom,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA canoe!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All approached, and saw to their extreme surprise, a boat floating down\r\n'b'the current.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBoat ahoy!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the sailor, without thinking that perhaps it would\r\n'b'be best to keep silence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No reply. The boat still drifted onward, and it was not more than twelve\r\n'b'feet off, when the sailor exclaimed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is our own boat! she has broken her moorings, and floated down\r\n'b'the current. I must say she has arrived very opportunely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur boat?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft was right. It was indeed the canoe, of which the rope had\r\n'b'undoubtedly broken, and which had come alone from the sources of the\r\n'b'Mercy. It was very important to seize it before the rapid current should\r\n'b'have swept it away out of the mouth of the river, but Neb and Pencroft\r\n'b'cleverly managed this by means of a long pole.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The canoe touched the shore. The engineer leaped in first, and found,\r\n'b'on examining the rope, that it had been really worn through by rubbing\r\n'b'against the rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter to him, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a strange\r\n'b'thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStrange indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Strange or not, it was very fortunate. Herbert, the reporter, Neb, and\r\n'b'Pencroft, embarked in turn. There was no doubt about the rope having\r\n'b'been worn through, but the astonishing part of the affair was, that the\r\n'b'boat should arrive just at the moment when the settlers were there to\r\n'b'seize it on its way, for a quarter of an hour earlier or later it would\r\n'b'have been lost in the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'If they had been living in the time of genii, this incident would\r\n'b'have given them the right to think that the island was haunted by some\r\n'b'supernatural being, who used his power in the service of the castaways!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few strokes of the oar brought the settlers to the mouth of the\r\n'b'Mercy. The canoe was hauled up on the beach near the Chimneys, and all\r\n'b'proceeded towards the ladder of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But at that moment, Top barked angrily, and Neb, who was looking for the\r\n'b'first steps, uttered a cry.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no longer a ladder!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 6\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding stood still, without saying a word. His companions\r\n'b'searched in the darkness on the wall, in case the wind should have\r\n'b'moved the ladder, and on the ground, thinking that it might have fallen\r\n'b'down.... But the ladder had quite disappeared. As to ascertaining if\r\n'b'a squall had blown it on the landing-place, half way up, that was\r\n'b'impossible in the dark.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf it is a joke,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a very stupid one! To come\r\n'b'home and find no staircase to go up to your room by--that\xe2\x80\x99s nothing for\r\n'b'weary men to laugh at.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb could do nothing but cry out \xe2\x80\x9cOh! oh! oh!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI begin to think that very curious things happen in Lincoln Island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCurious?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cnot at all, Pencroft, nothing can be\r\n'b'more natural. Some one has come during our absence, taken possession of\r\n'b'our dwelling and drawn up the ladder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSome one,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cBut who?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho but the hunter who fired the bullet?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if there is any one up there,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, who began to\r\n'b'lose patience, \xe2\x80\x9cI will give them a hail, and they must answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And in a stentorian voice the sailor gave a prolonged \xe2\x80\x9cHalloo!\xe2\x80\x9d which\r\n'b'was echoed again and again from the cliff and rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers listened and they thought they heard a sort of chuckling\r\n'b'laugh, of which they could not guess the origin. But no voice replied to\r\n'b'Pencroft, who in vain repeated his vigorous shouts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was something indeed in this to astonish the most apathetic\r\n'b'of men, and the settlers were not men of that description. In their\r\n'b'situation every incident had its importance, and, certainly, during the\r\n'b'seven months which they had spent on the island, they had not before met\r\n'b'with anything of so surprising a character.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Be that as it may, forgetting their fatigue in the singularity of the\r\n'b'event, they remained below Granite House, not knowing what to think,\r\n'b'not knowing what to do, questioning each other without any hope of\r\n'b'a satisfactory reply, every one starting some supposition each more\r\n'b'unlikely than the last. Neb bewailed himself, much disappointed at not\r\n'b'being able to get into his kitchen, for the provisions which they\r\n'b'had had on their expedition were exhausted, and they had no means of\r\n'b'renewing them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d at last said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is only one thing to be\r\n'b'done at present; wait for day, and then act according to circumstances.\r\n'b'But let us go to the Chimneys. There we shall be under shelter, and if\r\n'b'we cannot eat, we can at least sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut who is it that has played us this cool trick?\xe2\x80\x9d again asked\r\n'b'Pencroft, unable to make up his mind to retire from the spot.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Whoever it was, the only thing practicable was to do as the engineer\r\n'b'proposed, to go to the Chimneys and there wait for day. In the meanwhile\r\n'b'Top was ordered to mount guard below the windows of Granite House, and\r\n'b'when Top received an order he obeyed it without any questioning. The\r\n'b'brave dog therefore remained at the foot of the cliff while his master\r\n'b'with his companions sought a refuge among the rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To say that the settlers, notwithstanding their fatigue, slept well on\r\n'b'the sandy floor of the Chimneys would not be true. It was not only that\r\n'b'they were extremely anxious to find out the cause of what had happened,\r\n'b'whether it was the result of an accident which would be discovered at\r\n'b'the return of day, or whether on the contrary it was the work of a human\r\n'b'being; but they also had very uncomfortable beds. That could not be\r\n'b'helped, however, for in some way or other at that moment their dwelling\r\n'b'was occupied, and they could not possibly enter it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now Granite House was more than their dwelling, it was their warehouse.\r\n'b'There were all the stores belonging to the colony, weapons, instruments,\r\n'b'tools, ammunition, provisions, etc. To think that all that might be\r\n'b'pillaged and that the settlers would have all their work to do over\r\n'b'again, fresh weapons and tools to make, was a serious matter. Their\r\n'b'uneasiness led one or other of them also to go out every few minutes to\r\n'b'see if Top was keeping good watch. Cyrus Harding alone waited with his\r\n'b'habitual patience, although his strong mind was exasperated at being\r\n'b'confronted with such an inexplicable fact, and he was provoked at\r\n'b'himself for allowing a feeling to which he could not give a name, to\r\n'b'gain an influence over him. Gideon Spilett shared his feelings in this\r\n'b'respect, and the two conversed together in whispers of the inexplicable\r\n'b'circumstance which baffled even their intelligence and experience.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a joke,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cit is a trick some one has played us.\r\n'b'Well, I don\xe2\x80\x99t like such jokes, and the joker had better look out for\r\n'b'himself, if he falls into my hands, I can tell him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As soon as the first gleam of light appeared in the east, the colonists,\r\n'b'suitably armed, repaired to the beach under Granite House. The rising\r\n'b'sun now shone on the cliff and they could see the windows, the shutters\r\n'b'of which were closed, through the curtains of foliage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All here was in order; but a cry escaped the colonists when they saw\r\n'b'that the door, which they had closed on their departure, was now wide\r\n'b'open.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Some one had entered Granite House--there could be no more doubt about\r\n'b'that.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The upper ladder, which generally hung from the door to the landing,\r\n'b'was in its place, but the lower ladder was drawn up and raised to\r\n'b'the threshold. It was evident that the intruders had wished to guard\r\n'b'themselves against a surprise.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft hailed again.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No reply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe beggars,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cThere they are sleeping quietly\r\n'b'as if they were in their own house. Hallo there, you pirates, brigands,\r\n'b'robbers, sons of John Bull!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When Pencroft, being a Yankee, treated any one to the epithet of \xe2\x80\x9cson of\r\n'b'John Bull,\xe2\x80\x9d he considered he had reached the last limits of insult.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sun had now completely risen, and the whole facade of Granite House\r\n'b'became illuminated by its rays; but in the interior as well as on the\r\n'b'exterior all was quiet and calm.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers asked if Granite House was inhabited or not, and yet the\r\n'b'position of the ladder was sufficient to show that it was; it was also\r\n'b'certain that the inhabitants, whoever they might be, had not been able\r\n'b'to escape. But how were they to be got at?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert then thought of fastening a cord to an arrow, and shooting the\r\n'b'arrow so that it should pass between the first rounds of the ladder\r\n'b'which hung from the threshold. By means of the cord they would then\r\n'b'be able to draw down the ladder to the ground, and so re-establish the\r\n'b'communication between the beach and Granite House. There was evidently\r\n'b'nothing else to be done, and, with a little skill, this method might\r\n'b'succeed. Very fortunately bows and arrows had been left at the Chimneys,\r\n'b'where they also found a quantity of light hibiscus cord. Pencroft\r\n'b'fastened this to a well-feathered arrow. Then Herbert fixing it to his\r\n'b'bow, took a careful aim for the lower part of the ladder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Neb drew back, so as to see\r\n'b'if anything appeared at the windows. The reporter lifted his gun to his\r\n'b'shoulder and covered the door.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The bow was bent, the arrow flew, taking the cord with it, and passed\r\n'b'between the two last rounds.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The operation had succeeded.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert immediately seized the end of the cord, but, at that moment when\r\n'b'he gave it a pull to bring down the ladder, an arm, thrust suddenly out\r\n'b'between the wall and the door, grasped it and dragged it inside Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe rascals!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cIf a ball can do anything for you,\r\n'b'you shall not have long to wait for it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut who was it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho was it? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was a monkey, a sapajou, an orangoutang, a baboon, a gorilla, a\r\n'b'sagoin. Our dwelling has been invaded by monkeys, who climbed up the\r\n'b'ladder during our absence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, at this moment, as if to bear witness to the truth of the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'words, two or three quadrumana showed themselves at the windows,\r\n'b'from which they had pushed back the shutters, and saluted the real\r\n'b'proprietors of the place with a thousand hideous grimaces.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI knew that it was only a joke,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cbut one of the jokers\r\n'b'shall pay the penalty for the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So saying, the sailor, raising his piece, took a rapid aim at one of the\r\n'b'monkeys and fired. All disappeared, except one who fell mortally wounded\r\n'b'on the beach. This monkey, which was of a large size, evidently belonged\r\n'b'to the first order of the quadrumana. Whether this was a chimpanzee, an\r\n'b'orangoutang, or a gorilla, he took rank among the anthropoid apes, who\r\n'b'are so called from their resemblance to the human race. However, Herbert\r\n'b'declared it to be an orangoutang.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a magnificent beast!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMagnificent, if you like,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cbut still I do not see\r\n'b'how we are to get into our house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHerbert is a good marksman,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand his bow is here.\r\n'b'He can try again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, these apes are so cunning,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cthey won\xe2\x80\x99t show\r\n'b'themselves again at the windows and so we can\xe2\x80\x99t kill them; and when I\r\n'b'think of the mischief they may do in the rooms and storehouse--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave patience,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cthese creatures cannot keep us long\r\n'b'at bay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI shall not be sure of that till I see them down here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\n'b'sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, captain, do you know how many dozens of these fellows\r\n'b'are up there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was difficult to reply to Pencroft, and as for the young boy making\r\n'b'another attempt, that was not easy; for the lower part of the ladder\r\n'b'had been drawn again into the door, and when another pull was given, the\r\n'b'line broke and the ladder remained firm. The case was really perplexing.\r\n'b'Pencroft stormed. There was a comic side to the situation, but he did\r\n'b'not think it funny at all. It was certain that the settlers would end by\r\n'b'reinstating themselves in their domicile and driving out the intruders,\r\n'b'but when and how? this is what they were not able to say.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two hours passed, during which the apes took care not to show\r\n'b'themselves, but they were still there, and three or four times a nose or\r\n'b'a paw was poked out at the door or windows, and was immediately saluted\r\n'b'by a gun-shot.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us hide ourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d at last said the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps the apes\r\n'b'will think we have gone quite away and will show themselves again. Let\r\n'b'Spilett and Herbert conceal themselves behind those rocks and fire on\r\n'b'all that may appear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s orders were obeyed, and while the reporter and the lad,\r\n'b'the best marksmen in the colony, posted themselves in a good position,\r\n'b'but out of the monkeys\xe2\x80\x99 sight, Neb, Pencroft, and Cyrus climbed the\r\n'b'plateau and entered the forest in order to kill some game, for it was\r\n'b'now time for breakfast and they had no provisions remaining.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In half an hour the hunters returned with a few rock pigeons, which they\r\n'b'roasted as well as they could. Not an ape had appeared. Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'and Herbert went to take their share of the breakfast, leaving Top to\r\n'b'watch under the windows. They then, having eaten, returned to their\r\n'b'post.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two hours later, their situation was in no degree improved. The\r\n'b'quadrumana gave no sign of existence, and it might have been supposed\r\n'b'that they had disappeared; but what seemed more probable was that,\r\n'b'terrified by the death of one of their companions, and frightened by the\r\n'b'noise of the firearms, they had retreated to the back part of the house\r\n'b'or probably even into the store-room. And when they thought of\r\n'b'the valuables which this storeroom contained, the patience so much\r\n'b'recommended by the engineer, fast changed into great irritation, and\r\n'b'there certainly was room for it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly it is too bad,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9cand the worst of it is,\r\n'b'there is no way of putting an end to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut we must drive these vagabonds out somehow,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe could soon get the better of them, even if there are twenty of the\r\n'b'rascals; but for that, we must meet them hand to hand. Come now, is\r\n'b'there no way of getting at them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us try to enter Granite House by the old opening at the lake,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand I never thought of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was in reality the only way by which to penetrate into Granite\r\n'b'House so as to fight with and drive out the intruders. The opening was,\r\n'b'it is true, closed up with a wall of cemented stones, which it would be\r\n'b'necessary to sacrifice, but that could easily be rebuilt. Fortunately,\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had not as yet effected his project of hiding this opening\r\n'b'by raising the waters of the lake, for the operation would then have\r\n'b'taken some time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was already past twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when the colonists, well armed and\r\n'b'provided with picks and spades, left the Chimneys, passed beneath the\r\n'b'windows of Granite House, after telling Top to remain at his post, and\r\n'b'began to ascend the left bank of the Mercy, so as to reach Prospect\r\n'b'Heights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But they had not made fifty steps in this direction, when they heard the\r\n'b'dog barking furiously.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And all rushed down the bank again.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at the turning, they saw that the situation had changed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the apes, seized with a sudden panic, from some unknown cause,\r\n'b'were trying to escape. Two or three ran and clambered from one window\r\n'b'to another with the agility of acrobats. They were not even trying to\r\n'b'replace the ladder, by which it would have been easy to descend; perhaps\r\n'b'in their terror they had forgotten this way of escape. The colonists,\r\n'b'now being able to take aim without difficulty, fired. Some, wounded or\r\n'b'killed, fell back into the rooms, uttering piercing cries. The rest,\r\n'b'throwing themselves out, were dashed to pieces in their fall, and in a\r\n'b'few minutes, so far as they knew, there was not a living quadrumana in\r\n'b'Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this moment the ladder was seen to slip over the threshold, then\r\n'b'unroll and fall to the ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHullo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is queer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery strange!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the engineer, leaping first up the ladder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTake care, captain!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps there are still some of\r\n'b'these rascals.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall soon see,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, without stopping however.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All his companions followed him, and in a minute they had arrived at the\r\n'b'threshold. They searched everywhere. There was no one in the rooms nor\r\n'b'in the storehouse, which had been respected by the band of quadrumana.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell now, and the ladder,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cwho can the gentleman\r\n'b'have been who sent us that down?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But at that moment a cry was heard, and a great orang, who had hidden\r\n'b'himself in the passage, rushed into the room, pursued by Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh, the robber!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And hatchet in hand, he was about to cleave the head of the animal, when\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding seized his arm, saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpare him, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPardon this rascal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! it was he who threw us the ladder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the engineer said this in such a peculiar voice that it was\r\n'b'difficult to know whether he spoke seriously or not.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nevertheless, they threw themselves on the orang, who defended himself\r\n'b'gallantly, but was soon overpowered and bound.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what shall we make of him, now we\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\n'b'him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA servant!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The lad was not joking in saying this, for he knew how this intelligent\r\n'b'race could be turned to account.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers then approached the ape and gazed at it attentively. He\r\n'b'belonged to the family of anthropoid apes, of which the facial angle is\r\n'b'not much inferior to that of the Australians and Hottentots. It was an\r\n'b'orangoutang, and as such, had neither the ferocity of the gorilla, nor\r\n'b'the stupidity of the baboon. It is to this family of the anthropoid apes\r\n'b'that so many characteristics belong which prove them to be possessed\r\n'b'of an almost human intelligence. Employed in houses, they can wait at\r\n'b'table, sweep rooms, brush clothes, clean boots, handle a knife, fork,\r\n'b'and spoon properly, and even drink wine... doing everything as well as\r\n'b'the best servant that ever walked upon two legs. Buffon possessed one\r\n'b'of these apes, who served him for a long time as a faithful and zealous\r\n'b'servant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The one which had been seized in the hall of Granite House was a great\r\n'b'fellow, six feet high, with an admirably poportioned frame, a broad\r\n'b'chest, head of a moderate size, the facial angle reaching sixty-five\r\n'b'degrees, round skull, projecting nose, skin covered with soft glossy\r\n'b'hair, in short, a fine specimen of the anthropoids. His eyes, rather\r\n'b'smaller than human eyes, sparkled with intelligence; his white teeth\r\n'b'glittered under his mustache, and he wore a little curly brown beard.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA handsome fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cif we only knew his language, we\r\n'b'could talk to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, master,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, \xe2\x80\x9care you serious? Are we going to take him as a\r\n'b'servant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you must not be\r\n'b'jealous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I hope he will make an excellent servant,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\n'b'appears young, and will be easy to educate, and we shall not be obliged\r\n'b'to use force to subdue him, nor draw his teeth, as is sometimes done. He\r\n'b'will soon grow fond of his masters if they are kind to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they will be,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, who had forgotten all his rancor\r\n'b'against \xe2\x80\x9cthe jokers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, approaching the orang,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, old boy!\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9chow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The orang replied by a little grunt which did not show any anger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou wish to join the colony?\xe2\x80\x9d again asked the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are going to\r\n'b'enter the service of Captain Cyrus Harding?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Another respondent grunt was uttered by the ape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will be satisfied with no other wages than your food?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Third affirmative grunt.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis conversation is slightly monotonous,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cthe best servants are those who\r\n'b'talk the least. And then, no wages, do you hear, my boy? We will give\r\n'b'you no wages at first, but we will double them afterwards if we are\r\n'b'pleased with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus the colony was increased by a new member. As to his name the sailor\r\n'b'begged that in memory of another ape which he had known, he might be\r\n'b'called Jupiter, and Jup for short.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And so, without more ceremony, Master Jup was installed in Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 7\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers in Lincoln Island had now regained their dwelling, without\r\n'b'having been obliged to reach it by the old opening, and were therefore\r\n'b'spared the trouble of mason\xe2\x80\x99s work. It was certainly lucky, that at the\r\n'b'moment they were about to set out to do so, the apes had been seized\r\n'b'with that terror, no less sudden than inexplicable, which had driven\r\n'b'them out of Granite House. Had the animals discovered that they\r\n'b'were about to be attacked from another direction? This was the only\r\n'b'explanation of their sudden retreat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the day the bodies of the apes were carried into the wood, where\r\n'b'they were buried; then the settlers busied themselves in repairing the\r\n'b'disorder caused by the intruders, disorder but not damage, for although\r\n'b'they had turned everything in the rooms topsy-turvy, yet they had broken\r\n'b'nothing. Neb relighted his stove, and the stores in the larder furnished\r\n'b'a substantial repast, to which all did ample justice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Jup was not forgotten, and he ate with relish some stonepine almonds\r\n'b'and rhizome roots, with which he was abundantly supplied. Pencroft had\r\n'b'unfastened his arms, but judged it best to have his legs tied until they\r\n'b'were more sure of his submission.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, before retiring to rest, Harding and his companions seated round\r\n'b'their table, discussed those plans, the execution of which was most\r\n'b'pressing. The most important and most urgent was the establishment of a\r\n'b'bridge over the Mercy, so as to form a communication with the southern\r\n'b'part of the island and Granite House; then the making of an enclosure\r\n'b'for the musmons or other woolly animals which they wished to capture.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These two projects would help to solve the difficulty as to their\r\n'b'clothing, which was now serious. The bridge would render easy the\r\n'b'transport of the balloon case, which would furnish them with linen, and\r\n'b'the inhabitants of the enclosure would yield wool which would supply\r\n'b'them with winter clothes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the enclosure, it was Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s intention to establish it at\r\n'b'the sources of the Red Creek, where the ruminants would find fresh and\r\n'b'abundant pasture. The road between Prospect Heights and the sources of\r\n'b'the stream was already partly beaten, and with a better cart than the\r\n'b'first, the material could be easily conveyed to the spot, especially if\r\n'b'they could manage to capture some animals to draw it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But though there might be no inconvenience in the enclosure being so far\r\n'b'from Granite House, it would not be the same with the poultry-yard, to\r\n'b'which Neb called the attention of the colonists. It was indeed necessary\r\n'b'that the birds should be close within reach of the cook, and no place\r\n'b'appeared more favorable for the establishment of the said poultry-yard\r\n'b'than that portion of the banks of the lake which was close to the old\r\n'b'opening.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Water-birds would prosper there as well as others, and the couple\r\n'b'of tinamous taken in their last excursion would be the first to be\r\n'b'domesticated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 3rd of November, the new works were begun by the\r\n'b'construction of the bridge, and all hands were required for this\r\n'b'important task. Saws, hatchets, and hammers were shouldered by the\r\n'b'settlers, who, now transformed into carpenters, descended to the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There Pencroft observed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose, that during our absence, Master Jup takes it into his head to\r\n'b'draw up the ladder which he so politely returned to us yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us tie its lower end down firmly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was done by means of two stakes securely fixed in the sand. Then\r\n'b'the settlers, ascending the left bank of the Mercy, soon arrived at the\r\n'b'angle formed by the river.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There they halted, in order to ascertain if the bridge could be thrown\r\n'b'across. The place appeared suitable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, from this spot, to Port Balloon, discovered the day before on\r\n'b'the southern coast, there was only a distance of three miles and a\r\n'b'half, and from the bridge to the Port, it would be easy to make a good\r\n'b'cart-road which would render the communication between Granite House and\r\n'b'the south of the island extremely easy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding now imparted to his companions a scheme for completely\r\n'b'isolating Prospect Heights so as to shelter it from the attacks both of\r\n'b'quadrupeds and quadrumana. In this way, Granite House, the Chimneys, the\r\n'b'poultry-yard, and all the upper part of the plateau which was to be used\r\n'b'for cultivation, would be protected against the depredations of animals.\r\n'b'Nothing could be easier than to execute this project, and this is how\r\n'b'the engineer intended to set to work.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The plateau was already defended on three sides by water-courses, either\r\n'b'artificial or natural. On the northwest, by the shores of Lake Grant,\r\n'b'from the entrance of the passage to the breach made in the banks of the\r\n'b'lake for the escape of the water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the north, from this breach to the sea, by the new water-course which\r\n'b'had hollowed out a bed for itself across the plateau and shore, above\r\n'b'and below the fall, and it would be enough to dig the bed of this creek\r\n'b'a little deeper to make it impracticable for animals, on all the eastern\r\n'b'border by the sea itself, from the mouth of the aforesaid creek to the\r\n'b'mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Lastly, on the south, from the mouth to the turn of the Mercy where the\r\n'b'bridge was to be established.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The western border of the plateau now remained between the turn of the\r\n'b'river and the southern angle of the lake, a distance of about a mile,\r\n'b'which was open to all comers. But nothing could be easier than to dig a\r\n'b'broad deep ditch, which could be filled from the lake, and the overflow\r\n'b'of which would throw itself by a rapid fall into the bed of the Mercy.\r\n'b'The level of the lake would, no doubt, be somewhat lowered by this fresh\r\n'b'discharge of its waters, but Cyrus Harding had ascertained that the\r\n'b'volume of water in the Red Creek was considerable enough to allow of the\r\n'b'execution of this project.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo then,\xe2\x80\x9d added the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cProspect Heights will become a regular\r\n'b'island, being surrounded with water on all sides, and only communicating\r\n'b'with the rest of our domain by the bridge which we are about to throw\r\n'b'across the Mercy, the two little bridges already established above and\r\n'b'below the fall; and, lastly, two other little bridges which must be\r\n'b'constructed, one over the canal which I propose to dig, the other across\r\n'b'to the left bank of the Mercy. Now, if these bridges can be raised at\r\n'b'will, Prospect Heights will be guarded from any surprise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The bridge was the most urgent work. Trees were selected, cut down,\r\n'b'stripped of their branches, and cut into beams, joists, and planks. The\r\n'b'end of the bridge which rested on the right bank of the Mercy was to be\r\n'b'firm, but the other end on the left bank was to be movable, so that it\r\n'b'might be raised by means of a counterpoise, as some canal bridges are\r\n'b'managed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was certainly a considerable work, and though it was skillfully\r\n'b'conducted, it took some time, for the Mercy at this place was eighty\r\n'b'feet wide. It was therefore necessary to fix piles in the bed of\r\n'b'the river so as to sustain the floor of the bridge and establish a\r\n'b'pile-driver to act on the tops of these piles, which would thus form two\r\n'b'arches and allow the bridge to support heavy loads.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Happily there was no want of tools with which to shape the wood, nor\r\n'b'of iron-work to make it firm, nor of the ingenuity of a man who had a\r\n'b'marvelous knowledge of the work, nor lastly, the zeal of his companions,\r\n'b'who in seven months had necessarily acquired great skill in the use of\r\n'b'their tools; and it must be said that not the least skilful was Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, who in dexterity almost equaled the sailor himself. \xe2\x80\x9cWho would\r\n'b'ever have expected so much from a newspaper man!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The construction of the Mercy bridge lasted three weeks of regular\r\n'b'hard work. They even breakfasted on the scene of their labors, and the\r\n'b'weather being magnificent, they only returned to Granite House to sleep.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this period it may be stated that Master Jup grew more accustomed\r\n'b'to his new masters, whose movements he always watched with very\r\n'b'inquisitive eyes. However, as a precautionary measure, Pencroft did not\r\n'b'as yet allow him complete liberty, rightly wishing to wait until the\r\n'b'limits of the plateau should be settled by the projected works. Top\r\n'b'and Jup were good friends and played willingly together, but Jup did\r\n'b'everything solemnly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 20th of November the bridge was finished. The movable part,\r\n'b'balanced by the counterpoise, swung easily, and only a slight effort was\r\n'b'needed to raise it; between its hinge and the last cross-bar on which\r\n'b'it rested when closed, there existed a space of twenty feet, which was\r\n'b'sufficiently wide to prevent any animals from crossing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers now began to talk of fetching the balloon-case, which they\r\n'b'were anxious to place in perfect security; but to bring it, it would be\r\n'b'necessary to take a cart to Port Balloon, and consequently, necessary to\r\n'b'beat a road through the dense forests of the Far West. This would take\r\n'b'some time. Also, Neb and Pencroft having gone to examine into the state\r\n'b'of things at Port Balloon, and reported that the stock of cloth would\r\n'b'suffer no damage in the grotto where it was stored, it was decided that\r\n'b'the work at Prospect Heights should not be discontinued.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwill enable us to establish our poultry-yard\r\n'b'under better conditions, since we need have no fear of visits from foxes\r\n'b'nor the attacks of other beasts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d added Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can clear the plateau, and transplant wild plants\r\n'b'to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd prepare our second corn-field!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor with a triumphant\r\n'b'air.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the first corn-field sown with a single grain had prospered\r\n'b'admirably, thanks to Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s care. It had produced the ten ears\r\n'b'foretold by the engineer, and each ear containing eighty grains, the\r\n'b'colony found itself in possession of eight hundred grains, in six\r\n'b'months, which promised a double harvest each year.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These eight hundred grains, except fifty, which were prudently reserved,\r\n'b'were to be sown in a new field, but with no less care than was bestowed\r\n'b'on the single grain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The field was prepared, then surrounded with a strong palisade, high and\r\n'b'pointed, which quadrupeds would have found difficulty in leaping. As to\r\n'b'birds, some scarecrows, due to Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s ingenious brain, were enough\r\n'b'to frighten them. The seven hundred and fifty grains deposited in very\r\n'b'regular furrows were then left for nature to do the rest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 21st of November, Cyrus Harding began to plan the canal which was\r\n'b'to close the plateau on the west, from the south angle of Lake Grant to\r\n'b'the angle of the Mercy. There was there two or three feet of vegetable\r\n'b'earth, and below that granite. It was therefore necessary to manufacture\r\n'b'some more nitro-glycerine, and the nitro-glycerine did its accustomed\r\n'b'work. In less than a fortnight a ditch, twelve feet wide and six deep,\r\n'b'was dug out in the hard ground of the plateau. A new trench was made by\r\n'b'the same means in the rocky border of the lake, forming a small stream,\r\n'b'to which they gave the name of Creek Glycerine, and which was thus an\r\n'b'affluent of the Mercy. As the engineer had predicted, the level of the\r\n'b'lake was lowered, though very slightly. To complete the enclosure the\r\n'b'bed of the stream on the beach was considerably enlarged, and the sand\r\n'b'supported by means of stakes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'By the end of the first fortnight of December these works were finished,\r\n'b'and Prospect Heights--that is to say, a sort of irregular pentagon,\r\n'b'having a perimeter of nearly four miles, surrounded by a liquid\r\n'b'belt--was completely protected from depredators of every description.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the month of December, the heat was very great. In spite of it,\r\n'b'however, the settlers continued their work, and as they were anxious to\r\n'b'possess a poultry-yard they forthwith commenced it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is useless to say that since the enclosing of the plateau had been\r\n'b'completed, Master Jup had been set at liberty. He did not leave his\r\n'b'masters, and evinced no wish to escape. He was a gentle animal, though\r\n'b'very powerful and wonderfully active. He was already taught to make\r\n'b'himself useful by drawing loads of wood and carting away the stones\r\n'b'which were extracted from the bed of Creek Glycerine.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The poultry-yard occupied an area of two hundred square yards, on the\r\n'b'southeastern bank of the lake. It was surrounded by a palisade, and\r\n'b'in it were constructed various shelters for the birds which were to\r\n'b'populate it. These were simply built of branches and divided into\r\n'b'compartments, made ready for the expected guests.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first were the two tinamous, which were not long in having a number\r\n'b'of young ones; they had for companions half a dozen ducks, accustomed to\r\n'b'the borders of the lake. Some belonged to the Chinese species, of which\r\n'b'the wings open like a fan, and which by the brilliancy of their plumage\r\n'b'rival the golden pheasants. A few days afterwards, Herbert snared a\r\n'b'couple of gallinaceae, with spreading tails composed of long feathers,\r\n'b'magnificent alectors, which soon became tame. As to pelicans,\r\n'b'kingfishers, water-hens, they came of themselves to the shores of the\r\n'b'poultry-yard, and this little community, after some disputes, cooing,\r\n'b'screaming, clucking, ended by settling down peacefully, and increased in\r\n'b'encouraging proportion for the future use of the colony.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, wishing to complete his performance, established a\r\n'b'pigeon-house in a corner of the poultry-yard. There he lodged a dozen\r\n'b'of those pigeons which frequented the rocks of the plateau. These birds\r\n'b'soon became accustomed to returning every evening to their new dwelling,\r\n'b'and showed more disposition to domesticate themselves than their\r\n'b'congeners, the wood-pigeons.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Lastly, the time had come for turning the balloon-case to use, by\r\n'b'cutting it up to make shirts and other articles; for as to keeping it in\r\n'b'its present form, and risking themselves in a balloon filled with gas,\r\n'b'above a sea of the limits of which they had no idea, it was not to be\r\n'b'thought of.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was necessary to bring the case to Granite House, and the colonists\r\n'b'employed themselves in rendering their heavy cart lighter and more\r\n'b'manageable. But though they had a vehicle, the moving power was yet to\r\n'b'be found.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But did there not exist in the island some animal which might supply the\r\n'b'place of the horse, ass, or ox? That was the question.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9ca beast of burden would be very useful to\r\n'b'us until the captain has made a steam cart, or even an engine, for some\r\n'b'day we shall have a railroad from Granite House to Port Balloon, with a\r\n'b'branch line to Mount Franklin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'One day, the 23rd of December, Neb and Top were heard shouting and\r\n'b'barking, each apparently trying to see who could make the most noise.\r\n'b'The settlers, who were busy at the Chimneys, ran, fearing some vexatious\r\n'b'incident.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What did they see? Two fine animals of a large size that had imprudently\r\n'b'ventured on the plateau, when the bridges were open. One would have said\r\n'b'they were horses, or at least donkeys, male and female, of a fine shape,\r\n'b'dove-colored, the legs and tail white, striped with black on the head\r\n'b'and neck. They advanced quietly without showing any uneasiness, and\r\n'b'gazed at the men, in whom they could not as yet recognize their future\r\n'b'masters.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThese are onagers!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9canimals something between the zebra\r\n'b'and the quagga!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not donkeys?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause they have not long ears, and their shape is more graceful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDonkeys or horses,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthey are \xe2\x80\x98moving powers,\xe2\x80\x99 as\r\n'b'the captain would say, and as such must be captured!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor, without frightening the animals, crept through the grass\r\n'b'to the bridge over Creek Glycerine, lowered it, and the onagers were\r\n'b'prisoners.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now, should they seize them with violence and master them by force? No.\r\n'b'It was decided that for a few days they should be allowed to roam\r\n'b'freely about the plateau, where there was an abundance of grass, and the\r\n'b'engineer immediately began to prepare a stable near the poultry-yard,\r\n'b'in which the onagers might find food, with a good litter, and shelter\r\n'b'during the night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This done, the movements of the two magnificent creatures were left\r\n'b'entirely free, and the settlers avoided even approaching them so as to\r\n'b'terrify them. Several times, however, the onagers appeared to wish to\r\n'b'leave the plateau, too confined for animals accustomed to the plains\r\n'b'and forests. They were then seen following the water-barrier which\r\n'b'everywhere presented itself before them, uttering short neighs, then\r\n'b'galloping through the grass, and becoming calmer, they would remain\r\n'b'entire hours gazing at the woods, from which they were cut off for ever!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meantime harness of vegetable fiber had been manufactured, and\r\n'b'some days after the capture of the onagers, not only the cart was ready,\r\n'b'but a straight road, or rather a cutting, had been made through the\r\n'b'forests of the Far West, from the angle of the Mercy to Port Balloon.\r\n'b'The cart might then be driven there, and towards the end of December\r\n'b'they tried the onagers for the first time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft had already coaxed the animals to come and eat out of his hand,\r\n'b'and they allowed him to approach without making any difficulty, but once\r\n'b'harnessed they reared and could with difficulty be held in. However, it\r\n'b'was not long before they submitted to this new service, for the onager,\r\n'b'being less refractory than the zebra, is frequently put in harness\r\n'b'in the mountainous regions of Southern Africa, and it has even been\r\n'b'acclimatized in Europe, under zones of a relative coolness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this day all the colony, except Pencroft who walked at the animals\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'heads, mounted the cart, and set out on the road to Port Balloon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Of course they were jolted over the somewhat rough road, but the vehicle\r\n'b'arrived without any accident, and was soon loaded with the case and\r\n'b'rigging of the balloon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock that evening the cart, after passing over the Mercy\r\n'b'bridge, descended the left bank of the river, and stopped on the beach.\r\n'b'The onagers being unharnessed, were thence led to their stable, and\r\n'b'Pencroft before going to sleep gave vent to his feelings in a deep sigh\r\n'b'of satisfaction that awoke all the echoes of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 8\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first week of January was devoted to the manufacture of the linen\r\n'b'garments required by the colony. The needles found in the box were used\r\n'b'by sturdy if not delicate fingers, and we may be sure that what was sewn\r\n'b'was sewn firmly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no lack of thread, thanks to Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s idea of\r\n'b're-employing that which had been already used in the covering of the\r\n'b'balloon. This with admirable patience was all unpicked by Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'and Herbert, for Pencroft had been obliged to give this work up, as it\r\n'b'irritated him beyond measure; but he had no equal in the sewing part\r\n'b'of the business. Indeed, everybody knows that sailors have a remarkable\r\n'b'aptitude for tailoring.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cloth of which the balloon-case was made was then cleaned by means\r\n'b'of soda and potash, obtained by the incineration of plants, in such a\r\n'b'way that the cotton, having got rid of the varnish, resumed its natural\r\n'b'softness and elasticity; then, exposed to the action of the atmosphere,\r\n'b'it soon became perfectly white. Some dozen shirts and sock--the latter\r\n'b'not knitted, of course, but made of cotton--were thus manufactured. What\r\n'b'a comfort it was to the settlers to clothe themselves again in clean\r\n'b'linen, which was doubtless rather rough, but they were not troubled\r\n'b'about that! and then to go to sleep between sheets, which made the\r\n'b'couches at Granite House into quite comfortable beds!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was about this time also that they made boots of seal-leather, which\r\n'b'were greatly needed to replace the shoes and boots brought from America.\r\n'b'We may be sure that these new shoes were large enough and never pinched\r\n'b'the feet of the wearers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'With the beginning of the year 1866 the heat was very great, but\r\n'b'the hunting in the forests did not stand still. Agouties, peccaries,\r\n'b'capybaras, kangaroos, game of all sorts, actually swarmed there, and\r\n'b'Spilett and Herbert were too good marksmen ever to throw away their shot\r\n'b'uselessly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding still recommended them to husband the ammunition, and he\r\n'b'took measures to replace the powder and shot which had been found in\r\n'b'the box, and which he wished to reserve for the future. How did he know\r\n'b'where chance might one day cast his companions and himself in the\r\n'b'event of their leaving their domain? They should, then, prepare for the\r\n'b'unknown future by husbanding their ammunition and by substituting for it\r\n'b'some easily renewable substance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To replace lead, of which Harding had found no traces in the island, he\r\n'b'employed granulated iron, which was easy to manufacture. These bullets,\r\n'b'not having the weight of leaden bullets, were made larger, and each\r\n'b'charge contained less, but the skill of the sportsmen made up this\r\n'b'deficiency. As to powder, Cyrus Harding would have been able to make\r\n'b'that also, for he had at his disposal saltpeter, sulphur, and coal; but\r\n'b'this preparation requires extreme care, and without special tools it is\r\n'b'difficult to produce it of a good quality. Harding preferred, therefore,\r\n'b'to manufacture pyroxyle, that is to say gun-cotton, a substance in which\r\n'b'cotton is not indispensable, as the elementary tissue of vegetables may\r\n'b'be used, and this is found in an almost pure state, not only in cotton,\r\n'b'but in the textile fiber of hemp and flax, in paper, the pith of the\r\n'b'elder, etc. Now, the elder abounded in the island towards the mouth of\r\n'b'Red Creek, and the colonists had already made coffee of the berries of\r\n'b'these shrubs, which belong to the family of the caprifoliaceae.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The only thing to be collected, therefore, was elder-pith, for as to the\r\n'b'other substance necessary for the manufacture of pyroxyle, it was only\r\n'b'fuming azotic acid. Now, Harding having sulphuric acid at his disposal,\r\n'b'had already been easily able to produce azotic acid by attacking the\r\n'b'saltpeter with which nature supplied him. He accordingly resolved to\r\n'b'manufacture and employ pyroxyle, although it has some inconveniences,\r\n'b'that is to say, a great inequality of effect, an excessive\r\n'b'inflammability, since it takes fire at one hundred and seventy\r\n'b'degrees instead of two hundred and forty, and lastly, an instantaneous\r\n'b'deflagration which might damage the firearms. On the other hand, the\r\n'b'advantages of pyroxyle consist in this, that it is not injured by damp,\r\n'b'that it does not make the gun-barrels dirty, and that its force is four\r\n'b'times that of ordinary powder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To make pyroxyle, the cotton must be immersed in the fuming azotic acid\r\n'b'for a quarter of an hour, then washed in cold water and dried. Nothing\r\n'b'could be more simple.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had only at his disposal the ordinary azotic acid and not\r\n'b'the fuming or monohydrate azotic acid, that is to say, acid which emits\r\n'b'white vapors when it comes in contact with damp air; but by substituting\r\n'b'for the latter ordinary azotic acid, mixed, in the proportion of from\r\n'b'three to five volumes of concentrated sulphuric acid, the engineer\r\n'b'obtained the same result. The sportsmen of the island therefore soon\r\n'b'had a perfectly prepared substance, which, employed discreetly, produced\r\n'b'admirable results.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About this time the settlers cleared three acres of the plateau, and\r\n'b'the rest was preserved in a wild state, for the benefit of the onagers.\r\n'b'Several excursions were made into the Jacamar Wood and the forests of\r\n'b'the Far West, and they brought back from thence a large collection of\r\n'b'wild vegetables, spinach, cress, radishes, and turnips, which careful\r\n'b'culture would soon improve, and which would temper the regimen on which\r\n'b'the settlers had till then subsisted. Supplies of wood and coal were\r\n'b'also carted. Each excursion was at the same time a means of improving\r\n'b'the roads, which gradually became smoother under the wheels of the cart.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The rabbit-warren still continued to supply the larder of Granite House.\r\n'b'As fortunately it was situated on the other side of Creek Glycerine,\r\n'b'its inhabitants could not reach the plateau nor ravage the newly-made\r\n'b'plantation. The oyster-bed among the rocks was frequently renewed and\r\n'b'furnished excellent molluscs. Besides that, the fishing, either in\r\n'b'the lake or the Mercy, was very profitable, for Pencroft had made some\r\n'b'lines, armed with iron hooks, with which they frequently caught fine\r\n'b'trout, and a species of fish whose silvery sides were speckled with\r\n'b'yellow, and which were also extremely savory. Master Neb, who was\r\n'b'skilled in the culinary art, knew how to vary agreeably the bill of\r\n'b'fare. Bread alone was wanting at the table of the settlers, and as has\r\n'b'been said, they felt this privation greatly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers hunted too the turtles which frequented the shores of\r\n'b'Cape Mandible. At this place the beach was covered with little mounds,\r\n'b'concealing perfectly spherical turtles\xe2\x80\x99 eggs, with white hard shells,\r\n'b'the albumen of which does not coagulate as that of birds\xe2\x80\x99 eggs. They\r\n'b'were hatched by the sun, and their number was naturally considerable, as\r\n'b'each turtle can lay annually two hundred and fifty.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA regular egg-field,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand we have nothing to\r\n'b'do but to pick them up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But not being contented with simply the produce, they made chase after\r\n'b'the producers, the result of which was that they were able to bring back\r\n'b'to Granite House a dozen of these chelonians, which were really valuable\r\n'b'from an alimentary point of view. The turtle soup, flavored with\r\n'b'aromatic herbs, often gained well-merited praises for its preparer, Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'We must here mention another fortunate circumstance by which new stores\r\n'b'for the winter were laid in. Shoals of salmon entered the Mercy, and\r\n'b'ascended the country for several miles. It was the time at which the\r\n'b'females, going to find suitable places in which to spawn, precede the\r\n'b'males and make a great noise through the fresh water. A thousand of\r\n'b'these fish, which measured about two feet and a half in length, came up\r\n'b'the river, and a large quantity were retained by fixing dams across\r\n'b'the stream. More than a hundred were thus taken, which were salted and\r\n'b'stored for the time when winter, freezing up the streams, would render\r\n'b'fishing impracticable. By this time the intelligent Jup was raised\r\n'b'to the duty of valet. He had been dressed in a jacket, white linen\r\n'b'breeches, and an apron, the pockets of which were his delight. The\r\n'b'clever orang had been marvelously trained by Neb, and any one would have\r\n'b'said that the Negro and the ape understood each other when they talked\r\n'b'together. Jup had besides a real affection for Neb, and Neb returned\r\n'b'it. When his services were not required, either for carrying wood or for\r\n'b'climbing to the top of some tree, Jup passed the greatest part of his\r\n'b'time in the kitchen, where he endeavored to imitate Neb in all that he\r\n'b'saw him do. The black showed the greatest patience and even extreme\r\n'b'zeal in instructing his pupil, and the pupil exhibited remarkable\r\n'b'intelligence in profiting by the lessons he received from his master.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Judge then of the pleasure Master Jup gave to the inhabitants of Granite\r\n'b'House when, without their having had any idea of it, he appeared one\r\n'b'day, napkin on his arm, ready to wait at table. Quick, attentive, he\r\n'b'acquitted himself perfectly, changing the plates, bringing dishes,\r\n'b'pouring out water, all with a gravity which gave intense amusement to\r\n'b'the settlers, and which enraptured Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJup, some soup!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJup, a little agouti!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJup, a plate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJup! Good Jup! Honest Jup!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nothing was heard but that, and Jup without ever being disconcerted,\r\n'b'replied to every one, watched for everything, and he shook his head in a\r\n'b'knowing way when Pencroft, referring to his joke of the first day, said\r\n'b'to him,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly, Jup, your wages must be doubled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is useless to say that the orang was now thoroughly domesticated at\r\n'b'Granite House, and that he often accompanied his masters to the forest\r\n'b'without showing any wish to leave them. It was most amusing to see him\r\n'b'walking with a stick which Pencroft had given him, and which he carried\r\n'b'on his shoulder like a gun. If they wished to gather some fruit from\r\n'b'the summit of a tree, how quickly he climbed for it. If the wheel of the\r\n'b'cart stuck in the mud, with what energy did Jup with a single heave of\r\n'b'his shoulder put it right again.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a jolly fellow he is!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft often. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he was as\r\n'b'mischievous as he is good, there would be no doing anything with him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was towards the end of January the colonists began their labors in\r\n'b'the center of the island. It had been decided that a corral should be\r\n'b'established near the sources of the Red Creek, at the foot of Mount\r\n'b'Franklin, destined to contain the ruminants, whose presence would have\r\n'b'been troublesome at Granite House, and especially for the musmons, who\r\n'b'were to supply the wool for the settlers\xe2\x80\x99 winter garments.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Each morning, the colony, sometimes entire, but more often represented\r\n'b'only by Harding, Herbert, and Pencroft, proceeded to the sources of the\r\n'b'Creek, a distance of not more than five miles, by the newly beaten road\r\n'b'to which the name of Corral Road had been given.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There a site was chosen, at the back of the southern ridge of the\r\n'b'mountain. It was a meadow land, dotted here and there with clumps of\r\n'b'trees, and watered by a little stream, which sprung from the slopes\r\n'b'which closed it in on one side. The grass was fresh, and it was not\r\n'b'too much shaded by the trees which grew about it. This meadow was to\r\n'b'be surrounded by a palisade, high enough to prevent even the most agile\r\n'b'animals from leaping over. This enclosure would be large enough to\r\n'b'contain a hundred musmons and wild goats, with all the young ones they\r\n'b'might produce.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The perimeter of the corral was then traced by the engineer, and\r\n'b'they would then have proceeded to fell the trees necessary for the\r\n'b'construction of the palisade, but as the opening up of the road had\r\n'b'already necessitated the sacrifice of a considerable number, those were\r\n'b'brought and supplied a hundred stakes, which were firmly fixed in the\r\n'b'ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The construction of this corral did not take less than three weeks,\r\n'b'for besides the palisade, Cyrus Harding built large sheds, in which the\r\n'b'animals could take shelter. These buildings had also to be made very\r\n'b'strong, for musmons are powerful animals, and their first fury was to be\r\n'b'feared. The stakes, sharpened at their upper end and hardened by fire,\r\n'b'had been fixed by means of cross-bars, and at regular distances props\r\n'b'assured the solidity of the whole.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The corral finished, a raid had to be made on the pastures frequented\r\n'b'by the ruminants. This was done on the 7th of February, on a beautiful\r\n'b'summer\xe2\x80\x99s day, and every one took part in it. The onagers, already well\r\n'b'trained, were ridden by Spilett and Herbert, and were of great use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The maneuver consisted simply in surrounding the musmons and goats, and\r\n'b'gradually narrowing the circle around them. Cyrus Harding, Pencroft,\r\n'b'Neb, and Jup, posted themselves in different parts of the wood, while\r\n'b'the two cavaliers and Top galloped in a radius of half a mile round the\r\n'b'corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The musmons were very numerous in this part of the island. These fine\r\n'b'animals were as large as deer; their horns were stronger than those of\r\n'b'the ram, and their gray-colored fleece was mixed with long hair.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This hunting day was very fatiguing. Such going and coming, and running\r\n'b'and riding and shouting! Of a hundred musmons which had been surrounded,\r\n'b'more than two-thirds escaped, but at last, thirty of these animals and\r\n'b'ten wild goats were gradually driven back towards the corral, the open\r\n'b'door of which appearing to offer a means of escape, they rushed in and\r\n'b'were prisoners.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In short, the result was satisfactory, and the settlers had no reason to\r\n'b'complain. There was no doubt that the flock would prosper, and that at\r\n'b'no distant time not only wool but hides would be abundant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That evening the hunters returned to Granite House quite exhausted.\r\n'b'However, notwithstanding their fatigue, they returned the next day\r\n'b'to visit the corral. The prisoners had been trying to overthrow the\r\n'b'palisade, but of course had not succeeded, and were not long in becoming\r\n'b'more tranquil.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the month of February, no event of any importance occurred. The\r\n'b'daily labors were pursued methodically, and, as well as improving the\r\n'b'roads to the corral and to Port Balloon, a third was commenced, which,\r\n'b'starting from the enclosure, proceeded towards the western coast. The\r\n'b'yet unknown portion of Lincoln Island was that of the wood-covered\r\n'b'Serpentine Peninsula, which sheltered the wild beasts, from which Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett was so anxious to clear their domain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Before the cold season should appear the most assiduous care was given\r\n'b'to the cultivation of the wild plants which had been transplanted from\r\n'b'the forest to Prospect Heights. Herbert never returned from an excursion\r\n'b'without bringing home some useful vegetable. One day, it was some\r\n'b'specimens of the chicory tribe, the seeds of which by pressure yield an\r\n'b'excellent oil; another, it was some common sorrel, whose antiscorbutic\r\n'b'qualities were not to be despised; then, some of those precious tubers,\r\n'b'which have at all times been cultivated in South America, potatoes, of\r\n'b'which more than two hundred species are now known. The kitchen garden,\r\n'b'now well stocked and carefully defended from the birds, was divided\r\n'b'into small beds, where grew lettuces, kidney potatoes, sorrel, turnips,\r\n'b'radishes, and other coneiferae. The soil on the plateau was particularly\r\n'b'fertile, and it was hoped that the harvests would be abundant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had also a variety of different beverages, and so long as they did\r\n'b'not demand wine, the most hard to please would have had no reason to\r\n'b'complain. To the Oswego tea, and the fermented liquor extracted from the\r\n'b'roots of the dragonnier, Harding had added a regular beer, made from\r\n'b'the young shoots of the spruce-fir, which, after having been boiled\r\n'b'and fermented, made that agreeable drink called by the Anglo-Americans\r\n'b'spring-beer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards the end of the summer, the poultry-yard was possessed of\r\n'b'a couple of fine bustards, which belonged to the houbara species,\r\n'b'characterized by a sort of feathery mantle; a dozen shovelers, whose\r\n'b'upper mandible was prolonged on each side by a membraneous appendage;\r\n'b'and also some magnificent cocks, similar to the Mozambique cocks,\r\n'b'the comb, caruncle, and epidermis being black. So far, everything had\r\n'b'succeeded, thanks to the activity of these courageous and intelligent\r\n'b'men. Nature did much for them, doubtless; but faithful to the great\r\n'b'precept, they made a right use of what a bountiful Providence gave them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After the heat of these warm summer days, in the evening when their work\r\n'b'was finished and the sea-breeze began to blow, they liked to sit on the\r\n'b'edge of Prospect Heights, in a sort of veranda, covered with creepers,\r\n'b'which Neb had made with his own hands. There they talked, they\r\n'b'instructed each other, they made plans, and the rough good-humor of\r\n'b'the sailor always amused this little world, in which the most perfect\r\n'b'harmony had never ceased to reign.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They often spoke of their country, of their dear and great America. What\r\n'b'was the result of the War of Secession? It could not have been greatly\r\n'b'prolonged. Richmond had doubtless soon fallen into the hands of General\r\n'b'Grant. The taking of the capital of the Confederates must have been the\r\n'b'last action of this terrible struggle. Now the North had triumphed in\r\n'b'the good cause, how welcome would have been a newspaper to the exiles in\r\n'b'Lincoln Island! For eleven months all communication between them and the\r\n'b'rest of their fellow-creatures had been interrupted, and in a short time\r\n'b'the 24th of March would arrive, the anniversary of the day on which\r\n'b'the balloon had thrown them on this unknown coast. They were then mere\r\n'b'castaways, not even knowing how they should preserve their miserable\r\n'b'lives from the fury of the elements! And now, thanks to the knowledge of\r\n'b'their captain, and their own intelligence, they were regular colonists,\r\n'b'furnished with arms, tools, and instruments; they had been able to turn\r\n'b'to their profit the animals, plants, and minerals of the island, that is\r\n'b'to say, the three kingdoms of Nature.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Yes; they often talked of all these things and formed still more plans.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Cyrus Harding he was for the most part silent, and listened to\r\n'b'his companions more often than he spoke to them. Sometimes he smiled\r\n'b'at Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s ideas or Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s nonsense, but always and everywhere he\r\n'b'pondered over those inexplicable facts, that strange enigma, of which\r\n'b'the secret still escaped him!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 9\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The weather changed during the first week of March. There had been a\r\n'b'full moon at the commencement of the month, and the heat was excessive.\r\n'b'The atmosphere was felt to be full of electricity, and a period of some\r\n'b'length of tempestuous weather was to be feared.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Indeed, on the 2nd, peals of thunder were heard, the wind blew from the\r\n'b'east, and hail rattled against the facade of Granite House like\r\n'b'volleys of grape-shot. The door and windows were immediately closed,\r\n'b'or everything in the rooms would have been drenched. On seeing these\r\n'b'hailstones, some of which were the size of a pigeon\xe2\x80\x99s egg, Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'first thought was that his cornfield was in serious danger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He directly rushed to his field, where little green heads were already\r\n'b'appearing, and by means of a great cloth, he managed to protect his\r\n'b'crop.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This bad weather lasted a week, during which time the thunder rolled\r\n'b'without cessation in the depths of the sky.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, not having any pressing work out of doors, profited\r\n'b'by the bad weather to work at the interior of Granite House, the\r\n'b'arrangement of which was becoming more complete from day to day. The\r\n'b'engineer made a turning-lathe, with which he turned several articles\r\n'b'both for the toilet and the kitchen, particularly buttons, the want of\r\n'b'which was greatly felt. A gunrack had been made for the firearms, which\r\n'b'were kept with extreme care, and neither tables nor cupboards were left\r\n'b'incomplete. They sawed, they planed, they filed, they turned; and during\r\n'b'the whole of this bad season, nothing was heard but the grinding\r\n'b'of tools or the humming of the turning-lathe which responded to the\r\n'b'growling of the thunder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Master Jup had not been forgotten, and he occupied a room at the back,\r\n'b'near the storeroom, a sort of cabin with a cot always full of good\r\n'b'litter, which perfectly suited his taste.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWith good old Jup there is never any quarreling,\xe2\x80\x9d often repeated\r\n'b'Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cnever any improper reply. What a servant, Neb, what a\r\n'b'servant!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Of course Jup was now well used to service. He brushed their clothes,\r\n'b'he turned the spit, he waited at table, he swept the rooms, he gathered\r\n'b'wood, and he performed another admirable piece of service which\r\n'b'delighted Pencroft--he never went to sleep without first coming to tuck\r\n'b'up the worthy sailor in his bed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the health of the members of the colony, bipeds or bimana,\r\n'b'quadrumana or quadrupeds, it left nothing to be desired. With their life\r\n'b'in the open air, on this salubrious soil, under that temperate zone,\r\n'b'working both with head and hands, they could not suppose that illness\r\n'b'would ever attack them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All were indeed wonderfully well. Herbert had already grown two inches\r\n'b'in the year. His figure was forming and becoming more manly, and he\r\n'b'promised to be an accomplished man, physically as well as morally.\r\n'b'Besides he improved himself during the leisure hours which manual\r\n'b'occupations left to him; he read the books found in the case; and after\r\n'b'the practical lessons which were taught by the very necessity of their\r\n'b'position, he found in the engineer for science, and the reporter for\r\n'b'languages, masters who were delighted to complete his education.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The tempest ended about the 9th of March, but the sky remained covered\r\n'b'with clouds during the whole of this last summer month. The atmosphere,\r\n'b'violently agitated by the electric commotions, could not recover its\r\n'b'former purity, and there was almost invariably rain and fog, except for\r\n'b'three or four fine days on which several excursions were made. About\r\n'b'this time the female onager gave birth to a young one which belonged to\r\n'b'the same sex as its mother, and which throve capitally. In the corral,\r\n'b'the flock of musmons had also increased, and several lambs already\r\n'b'bleated in the sheds, to the great delight of Neb and Herbert, who had\r\n'b'each their favorite among these newcomers. An attempt was also made\r\n'b'for the domestication of the peccaries, which succeeded well. A sty was\r\n'b'constructed under the poultry-yard, and soon contained several young\r\n'b'ones in the way to become civilized, that is to say, to become fat\r\n'b'under Neb\xe2\x80\x99s care. Master Jup, entrusted with carrying them their\r\n'b'daily nourishment, leavings from the kitchen, etc., acquitted himself\r\n'b'conscientiously of his task. He sometimes amused himself at the expense\r\n'b'of his little pensioners by tweaking their tails; but this was mischief,\r\n'b'and not wickedness, for these little twisted tails amused him like a\r\n'b'plaything, and his instinct was that of a child. One day in this month\r\n'b'of March, Pencroft, talking to the engineer, reminded Cyrus Harding of a\r\n'b'promise which the latter had not as yet had time to fulfil.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou once spoke of an apparatus which would take the place of the long\r\n'b'ladders at Granite House, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cwon\xe2\x80\x99t you make it some\r\n'b'day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing will be easier; but is this a really useful thing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, captain. After we have given ourselves necessaries, let us\r\n'b'think a little of luxury. For us it may be luxury, if you like, but\r\n'b'for things it is necessary. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t very convenient to climb up a long\r\n'b'ladder when one is heavily loaded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Pencroft, we will try to please you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have no machine at your disposal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will make one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA steam machine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, a water machine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, indeed, to work his apparatus there was already a natural force\r\n'b'at the disposal of the engineer which could be used without great\r\n'b'difficulty. For this, it was enough to augment the flow of the little\r\n'b'stream which supplied the interior of Granite House with water. The\r\n'b'opening among the stones and grass was then increased, thus producing\r\n'b'a strong fall at the bottom of the passage, the overflow from which\r\n'b'escaped by the inner well. Below this fall the engineer fixed a cylinder\r\n'b'with paddles, which was joined on the exterior with a strong cable\r\n'b'rolled on a wheel, supporting a basket. In this way, by means of a long\r\n'b'rope reaching to the ground, which enabled them to regulate the motive\r\n'b'power, they could rise in the basket to the door of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was on the 17th of March that the lift acted for the first time, and\r\n'b'gave universal satisfaction. Henceforward all the loads, wood, coal,\r\n'b'provisions, and even the settlers themselves, were hoisted by this\r\n'b'simple system, which replaced the primitive ladder, and, as may be\r\n'b'supposed, no one thought of regretting the change. Top particularly was\r\n'b'enchanted with this improvement, for he had not, and never could have\r\n'b'possessed Master Jup\xe2\x80\x99s skill in climbing ladders, and often it was on\r\n'b'Neb\xe2\x80\x99s back, or even on that of the orang that he had been obliged to\r\n'b'make the ascent to Granite House. About this time, too, Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'attempted to manufacture glass, and he at first put the old pottery-kiln\r\n'b'to this new use. There were some difficulties to be encountered; but,\r\n'b'after several fruitless attempts, he succeeded in setting up a glass\r\n'b'manufactory, which Gideon Spilett and Herbert, his usual assistants, did\r\n'b'not leave for several days. As to the substances used in the composition\r\n'b'of glass, they are simply sand, chalk, and soda, either carbonate or\r\n'b'sulphate. Now the beach supplied sand, lime supplied chalk, sea-weeds\r\n'b'supplied soda, pyrites supplied sulphuric acid, and the ground supplied\r\n'b'coal to heat the kiln to the wished-for temperature. Cyrus Harding thus\r\n'b'soon had everything ready for setting to work.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The tool, the manufacture of which presented the most difficulty, was\r\n'b'the pipe of the glass-maker, an iron tube, five or six feet long, which\r\n'b'collects on one end the material in a state of fusion. But by means of\r\n'b'a long, thin piece of iron rolled up like the barrel of a gun, Pencroft\r\n'b'succeeded in making a tube soon ready for use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 28th of March the tube was heated. A hundred parts of sand,\r\n'b'thirty-five of chalk, forty of sulphate of soda, mixed with two or three\r\n'b'parts of powdered coal, composed the substance, which was placed in\r\n'b'crucibles. When the high temperature of the oven had reduced it to a\r\n'b'liquid, or rather a pasty state, Cyrus Harding collected with the tube\r\n'b'a quantity of the paste: he turned it about on a metal plate, previously\r\n'b'arranged, so as to give it a form suitable for blowing, then he passed\r\n'b'the tube to Herbert, telling him to blow at the other extremity.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Herbert, swelling out his cheeks, blew so much and so well into the\r\n'b'tube-taking care to twirl it round at the same time--that his breath\r\n'b'dilated the glassy mass. Other quantities of the substance in a state\r\n'b'of fusion were added to the first, and in a short time the result was a\r\n'b'bubble which measured a foot in diameter. Harding then took the tube\r\n'b'out of Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s hands, and, giving it a pendulous motion, he ended by\r\n'b'lengthening the malleable bubble so as to give it a cylindroconic shape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The blowing operation had given a cylinder of glass terminated by two\r\n'b'hemispheric caps, which were easily detached by means of a sharp iron\r\n'b'dipped in cold water; then, by the same proceeding, this cylinder was\r\n'b'cut lengthways, and after having been rendered malleable by a second\r\n'b'heating, it was extended on a plate and spread out with a wooden roller.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first pane was thus manufactured, and they had only to perform this\r\n'b'operation fifty times to have fifty panes. The windows at Granite House\r\n'b'were soon furnished with panes; not very white, perhaps, but still\r\n'b'sufficiently transparent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to bottles and tumblers, that was only play. They were satisfied with\r\n'b'them, besides, just as they came from the end of the tube. Pencroft had\r\n'b'asked to be allowed to \xe2\x80\x9cblow\xe2\x80\x9d in his turn, and it was great fun for\r\n'b'him; but he blew so hard that his productions took the most ridiculous\r\n'b'shapes, which he admired immensely.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Herbert, while hunting one day, had entered the forest\r\n'b'of the Far West, on the left bank of the Mercy, and, as usual, the\r\n'b'lad was asking a thousand questions of the engineer, who answered them\r\n'b'heartily. Now, as Harding was not a sportsman, and as, on the other\r\n'b'side, Herbert was talking chemistry and natural philosophy, numbers of\r\n'b'kangaroos, capybaras, and agouties came within range, which, however,\r\n'b'escaped the lad\xe2\x80\x99s gun; the consequence was that the day was already\r\n'b'advanced, and the two hunters were in danger of having made a\r\n'b'useless excursion, when Herbert, stopping, and uttering a cry of joy,\r\n'b'exclaimed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Captain Harding, do you see that tree?\xe2\x80\x9d and he pointed to a shrub,\r\n'b'rather than a tree, for it was composed of a single stem, covered with a\r\n'b'scaly bark, which bore leaves streaked with little parallel veins.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is this tree which resembles a little palm?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a \xe2\x80\x98cycas revoluta,\xe2\x80\x99 of which I have a picture in our dictionary\r\n'b'of Natural History!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can\xe2\x80\x99t see any fruit on this shrub!\xe2\x80\x9d observed his companion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9cbut its stem contains a flour with\r\n'b'which nature has provided us all ready ground.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, then, the bread-tree?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the bread-tree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a valuable discovery,\r\n'b'since our wheat harvest is not yet ripe; I hope that you are not\r\n'b'mistaken!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert was not mistaken: he broke the stem of a cycas, which was\r\n'b'composed of a glandulous tissue, containing a quantity of floury pith,\r\n'b'traversed with woody fiber, separated by rings of the same substance,\r\n'b'arranged concentrically. With this fecula was mingled a mucilaginous\r\n'b'juice of disagreeable flavor, but which it would be easy to get rid of\r\n'b'by pressure.
