This cellular substance was regular flour of a superior\r\n'b'quality, extremely nourishing; its exportation was formerly forbidden by\r\n'b'the Japanese laws.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Herbert, after having examined that part of the Far\r\n'b'West where the cycas grew, took their bearings, and returned to Granite\r\n'b'House, where they made known their discovery.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day the settlers went to collect some, and returned to Granite\r\n'b'House with an ample supply of cycas stems. The engineer constructed a\r\n'b'press, with which to extract the mucilaginous juice mingled with the\r\n'b'fecula, and he obtained a large quantity of flour, which Neb soon\r\n'b'transformed into cakes and puddings. This was not quite real wheaten\r\n'b'bread, but it was very like it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now, too, the onager, the goats, and the sheep in the corral furnished\r\n'b'daily the milk necessary to the colony. The cart, or rather a sort of\r\n'b'light carriole which had replaced it, made frequent journeys to the\r\n'b'corral, and when it was Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s turn to go he took Jup, and let him\r\n'b'drive, and Jup, cracking his whip, acquitted himself with his customary\r\n'b'intelligence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Everything prospered, as well in the corral as in Granite House, and\r\n'b'certainly the settlers, if it had not been that they were so far from\r\n'b'their native land, had no reason to complain. They were so well suited\r\n'b'to this life, and were, besides, so accustomed to the island, that they\r\n'b'could not have left its hospitable soil without regret!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And yet so deeply is the love of his country implanted in the heart of\r\n'b'man, that if a ship had unexpectedly come in sight of the island, the\r\n'b'colonists would have made signals, would have attracted her attention,\r\n'b'and would have departed!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the 1st of April, a Sunday, Easter Day, which Harding and his\r\n'b'companions sanctified by rest and prayer. The day was fine, such as an\r\n'b'October day in the Northern Hemisphere might be.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All, towards the evening after dinner, were seated under the veranda\r\n'b'on the edge of Prospect Heights, and they were watching the\r\n'b'darkness creeping up from the horizon. Some cups of the infusion of\r\n'b'elder-berries, which took the place of coffee, had been served by Neb.\r\n'b'They were speaking of the island and of its isolated situation in the\r\n'b'Pacific, which led Gideon Spilett to say,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Cyrus, have you ever, since you possessed the sextant found in\r\n'b'the case, again taken the position of our island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut it would perhaps be a good thing to do it with this instrument,\r\n'b'which is more perfect than that which you before used.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the good?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cThe island is quite comfortable\r\n'b'where it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, who knows,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cwho knows but that we may be\r\n'b'much nearer inhabited land than we think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall know to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand if it had not\r\n'b'been for the occupations which left me no leisure, we should have known\r\n'b'it already.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cThe captain is too good an observer to be\r\n'b'mistaken, and, if it has not moved from its place, the island is just\r\n'b'where he put it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the next day, therefore, by means of the sextant, the engineer made\r\n'b'the necessary observations to verify the position which he had\r\n'b'already obtained, and this was the result of his operation. His first\r\n'b'observation had given him the situation of Lincoln Island,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In west longitude: from 150deg. to 155deg.;\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In south latitude: from 30deg. to 35deg.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The second gave exactly:\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In longitude: 150deg. 30\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In south latitude: 34deg. 57\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So then, notwithstanding the imperfection of his apparatus, Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding had operated with so much skill that his error did not exceed\r\n'b'five degrees.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9csince we possess an atlas as well as a\r\n'b'sextant, let us see, my dear Cyrus, the exact position which Lincoln\r\n'b'Island occupies in the Pacific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert fetched the atlas, and the map of the Pacific was opened, and\r\n'b'the engineer, compass in hand, prepared to determine their position.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Suddenly the compasses stopped, and he exclaimed,\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut an island exists in this part of the Pacific already!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAn island?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTabor Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAn important island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, an islet lost in the Pacific, and which perhaps has never been\r\n'b'visited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we will visit it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, captain. We will build a decked boat, and I will undertake to\r\n'b'steer her. At what distance are we from this Tabor Island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout a hundred and fifty miles to the northeast,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred and fifty miles! And what\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIn\r\n'b'forty-eight hours, with a good wind, we should sight it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, on this reply, it was decided that a vessel should be constructed\r\n'b'in time to be launched towards the month of next October, on the return\r\n'b'of the fine season.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 10\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When Pencroft had once got a plan in his head, he had no peace till it\r\n'b'was executed. Now he wished to visit Tabor Island, and as a boat of a\r\n'b'certain size was necessary for this voyage, he determined to build one.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What wood should he employ? Elm or fir, both of which abounded in the\r\n'b'island? They decided for the fir, as being easy to work, but which\r\n'b'stands water as well as the elm.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These details settled, it was agreed that since the fine season would\r\n'b'not return before six months, Cyrus Harding and Pencroft should work\r\n'b'alone at the boat. Gideon Spilett and Herbert were to continue to\r\n'b'hunt, and neither Neb nor Master Jup, his assistant, were to leave the\r\n'b'domestic duties which had devolved upon them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Directly the trees were chosen, they were felled, stripped of their\r\n'b'branches, and sawn into planks as well as sawyers would have been able\r\n'b'to do it. A week after, in the recess between the Chimneys and the\r\n'b'cliff, a dockyard was prepared, and a keel five-and-thirty feet long,\r\n'b'furnished with a stern-post at the stern and a stem at the bows, lay\r\n'b'along the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding was not working in the dark at this new trade. He knew as\r\n'b'much about ship-building as about nearly everything else, and he had\r\n'b'at first drawn the model of his ship on paper. Besides, he was ably\r\n'b'seconded by Pencroft, who, having worked for several years in a dockyard\r\n'b'in Brooklyn, knew the practical part of the trade. It was not until\r\n'b'after careful calculation and deep thought that the timbers were laid on\r\n'b'the keel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, as may be believed, was all eagerness to carry out his new\r\n'b'enterprise, and would not leave his work for an instant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A single thing had the honor of drawing him, but for one day only, from\r\n'b'his dockyard. This was the second wheat-harvest, which was gathered in\r\n'b'on the 15th of April. It was as much a success as the first, and yielded\r\n'b'the number of grains which had been predicted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFive bushels, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, after having scrupulously\r\n'b'measured his treasure.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFive bushels,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cand a hundred and thirty thousand\r\n'b'grains a bushel will make six hundred and fifty thousand grains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we will sow them all this time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cexcept a\r\n'b'little in reserve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Pencroft, and if the next crop gives a proportionate yield, we\r\n'b'shall have four thousand bushels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd shall we eat bread?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall eat bread.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut we must have a mill.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will make one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The third corn-field was very much larger than the two first, and the\r\n'b'soil, prepared with extreme care, received the precious seed. That done,\r\n'b'Pencroft returned to his work.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this time Spilett and Herbert hunted in the neighborhood, and\r\n'b'they ventured deep into the still unknown parts of the Far West, their\r\n'b'guns loaded with ball, ready for any dangerous emergency. It was a vast\r\n'b'thicket of magnificent trees, crowded together as if pressed for room.\r\n'b'The exploration of these dense masses of wood was difficult in\r\n'b'the extreme, and the reporter never ventured there without the\r\n'b'pocket-compass, for the sun scarcely pierced through the thick foliage\r\n'b'and it would have been very difficult for them to retrace their way.\r\n'b'It naturally happened that game was more rare in those situations where\r\n'b'there was hardly sufficient room to move; two or three large herbivorous\r\n'b'animals were however killed during the last fortnight of April. These\r\n'b'were koalas, specimens of which the settlers had already seen to the\r\n'b'north of the lake, and which stupidly allowed themselves to be killed\r\n'b'among the thick branches of the trees in which they took refuge. Their\r\n'b'skins were brought back to Granite House, and there, by the help of\r\n'b'sulphuric acid, they were subjected to a sort of tanning process which\r\n'b'rendered them capable of being used.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 30th of April, the two sportsmen were in the depth of the Far\r\n'b'West, when the reporter, preceding Herbert a few paces, arrived in\r\n'b'a sort of clearing, into which the trees more sparsely scattered had\r\n'b'permitted a few rays to penetrate. Gideon Spilett was at first surprised\r\n'b'at the odor which exhaled from certain plants with straight stalks,\r\n'b'round and branchy, bearing grape-like clusters of flowers and very small\r\n'b'berries. The reporter broke off one or two of these stalks and returned\r\n'b'to the lad, to whom he said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can this be, Herbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a treasure which will secure\r\n'b'you Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s gratitude forever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs it tobacco?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and though it may not be of the first quality, it is none the less\r\n'b'tobacco!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, good old Pencroft! Won\xe2\x80\x99t he be pleased! But we must not let him\r\n'b'smoke it all, he must give us our share.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh! an idea occurs to me, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t let us\r\n'b'say anything to Pencroft yet; we will prepare these leaves, and one fine\r\n'b'day we will present him with a pipe already filled!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, Herbert, and on that day our worthy companion will have\r\n'b'nothing left to wish for in this world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter and the lad secured a good store of the precious plant, and\r\n'b'then returned to Granite House, where they smuggled it in with as much\r\n'b'precaution as if Pencroft had been the most vigilant and severe of\r\n'b'custom-house officers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Neb were taken into confidence, and the sailor\r\n'b'suspected nothing during the whole time, necessarily somewhat long,\r\n'b'which was required in order to dry the small leaves, chop them up, and\r\n'b'subject them to a certain torrefaction on hot stones. This took two\r\n'b'months; but all these manipulations were successfully carried on unknown\r\n'b'to Pencroft, for, occupied with the construction of his boat, he only\r\n'b'returned to Granite House at the hour of rest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For some days they had observed an enormous animal two or three miles\r\n'b'out in the open sea swimming around Lincoln Island. This was a whale\r\n'b'of the largest size, which apparently belonged to the southern species,\r\n'b'called the \xe2\x80\x9cCape Whale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a lucky chance it would be if we could capture it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\n'b'sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cAh! if we only had a proper boat and a good harpoon, I would\r\n'b'say \xe2\x80\x98After the beast,\xe2\x80\x99 for he would be well worth the trouble of\r\n'b'catching!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cI should much like to watch you\r\n'b'handling a harpoon. It would be very interesting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am astonished,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cto see a whale in this\r\n'b'comparatively high latitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so, Mr. Spilett?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are exactly in that part of\r\n'b'the Pacific which English and American whalemen call the whale field,\r\n'b'and it is here, between New Zealand and South America, that the whales\r\n'b'of the Southern Hemisphere are met with in the greatest numbers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Pencroft returned to his work, not without uttering a sigh of\r\n'b'regret, for every sailor is a born fisherman, and if the pleasure of\r\n'b'fishing is in exact proportion to the size of the animal, one can judge\r\n'b'how a whaler feels in sight of a whale. And if this had only been for\r\n'b'pleasure! But they could not help feeling how valuable such a prize\r\n'b'would have been to the colony, for the oil, fat, and bones would have\r\n'b'been put to many uses.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now it happened that this whale appeared to have no wish to leave the\r\n'b'waters of the island. Therefore, whether from the windows of Granite\r\n'b'House, or from Prospect Heights, Herbert and Gideon Spilett, when they\r\n'b'were not hunting, or Neb, unless presiding over his fires, never left\r\n'b'the telescope, but watched all the animal\xe2\x80\x99s movements. The cetacean,\r\n'b'having entered far into Union Bay, made rapid furrows across it from\r\n'b'Mandible Cape to Claw Cape, propelled by its enormously powerful flukes,\r\n'b'on which it supported itself, and making its way through the water\r\n'b'at the rate little short of twelve knots. Sometimes also it\r\n'b'approached so near to the island that it could be clearly distinguished.\r\n'b'It was the southern whale, which is completely black, the head being\r\n'b'more depressed than that of the northern whale.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They could also see it throwing up from its air-holes to a great\r\n'b'height a cloud of vapor, or of water, for, strange as it may appear,\r\n'b'naturalists and whalers are not agreed on this subject. Is it air or is\r\n'b'it water which is thus driven out? It is generally admitted to be vapor,\r\n'b'which, condensing suddenly by contact with the cold air, falls again as\r\n'b'rain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the presence of this mammifer preoccupied the colonists. It\r\n'b'irritated Pencroft especially, as he could think of nothing else while\r\n'b'at work. He ended by longing for it, like a child for a thing which it\r\n'b'has been denied. At night he talked about it in his sleep, and certainly\r\n'b'if he had had the means of attacking it, if the sloop had been in a fit\r\n'b'state to put to sea, he would not have hesitated to set out in pursuit.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But what the colonists could not do for themselves chance did for them,\r\n'b'and on the 3rd of May shouts from Neb, who had stationed himself at the\r\n'b'kitchen window, announced that the whale was stranded on the beach of\r\n'b'the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and Gideon Spilett, who were just about to set out hunting,\r\n'b'left their guns, Pencroft threw down his ax, and Harding and Neb joining\r\n'b'their companions, all rushed towards the scene of action.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranding had taken place on the beach of Flotsam Point, three miles\r\n'b'from Granite House, and at high tide. It was therefore probable that the\r\n'b'cetacean would not be able to extricate itself easily; at any rate it\r\n'b'was best to hasten, so as to cut off its retreat if necessary. They ran\r\n'b'with pick-axes and iron-tipped poles in their hands, passed over the\r\n'b'Mercy bridge, descended the right bank of the river, along the beach,\r\n'b'and in less than twenty minutes the settlers were close to the enormous\r\n'b'animal, above which flocks of birds already hovered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a monster!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the exclamation was natural, for it was a southern whale, eighty\r\n'b'feet long, a giant of the species, probably not weighing less than a\r\n'b'hundred and fifty thousand pounds!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, the monster thus stranded did not move, nor attempt by\r\n'b'struggling to regain the water while the tide was still high.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was dead, and a harpoon was sticking out of its left side.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere are whalers in these quarters, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'directly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Mr. Spilett, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t prove anything!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhales have been known to go thousands of miles with a harpoon in\r\n'b'the side, and this one might even have been struck in the north of the\r\n'b'Atlantic and come to die in the south of the Pacific, and it would be\r\n'b'nothing astonishing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, having torn the harpoon from the animal\xe2\x80\x99s side, read this\r\n'b'inscription on it:\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'           MARIA STELLA, VINEYARD\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA vessel from the Vineyard! A ship from my country!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Maria Stella!\xe2\x80\x99 A fine whaler, \xe2\x80\x98pon my word; I know her well! Oh, my\r\n'b'friends, a vessel from the Vineyard!--a whaler from the Vineyard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor brandishing the harpoon, repeated, not without emotion,\r\n'b'the name which he loved so well--the name of his birthplace.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But as it could not be expected that the \xe2\x80\x9cMaria Stella\xe2\x80\x9d would come to\r\n'b'reclaim the animal harpooned by her, they resolved to begin cutting it\r\n'b'up before decomposition should commence. The birds, who had watched\r\n'b'this rich prey for several days, had determined to take possession of it\r\n'b'without further delay, and it was necessary to drive them off by firing\r\n'b'at them repeatedly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The whale was a female, and a large quantity of milk was taken from it,\r\n'b'which, according to the opinion of the naturalist Duffenbach, might pass\r\n'b'for cow\xe2\x80\x99s milk, and, indeed, it differs from it neither in taste, color,\r\n'b'nor density.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft had formerly served on board a whaling-ship, and he could\r\n'b'methodically direct the operation of cutting up, a sufficiently\r\n'b'disagreeable operation lasting three days, but from which the settlers\r\n'b'did not flinch, not even Gideon Spilett, who, as the sailor said, would\r\n'b'end by making a \xe2\x80\x9creal good castaway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The blubber, cut in parallel slices of two feet and a half in thickness,\r\n'b'then divided into pieces which might weigh about a thousand pounds each,\r\n'b'was melted down in large earthen pots brought to the spot, for they did\r\n'b'not wish to taint the environs of Granite House, and in this fusion it\r\n'b'lost nearly a third of its weight.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But there was an immense quantity of it; the tongue alone yielded six\r\n'b'thousand pounds of oil, and the lower lip four thousand. Then, besides\r\n'b'the fat, which would insure for a long time a store of stearine and\r\n'b'glycerine, there were still the bones, for which a use could doubtless\r\n'b'be found, although there were neither umbrellas nor stays used at\r\n'b'Granite House. The upper part of the mouth of the cetacean was, indeed,\r\n'b'provided on both sides with eight hundred horny blades, very elastic,\r\n'b'of a fibrous texture, and fringed at the edge like great combs, at which\r\n'b'the teeth, six feet long, served to retain the thousands of animalculae,\r\n'b'little fish, and molluscs, on which the whale fed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The operation finished, to the great satisfaction of the operators, the\r\n'b'remains of the animal were left to the birds, who would soon make every\r\n'b'vestige of it disappear, and their usual daily occupations were resumed\r\n'b'by the inmates of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, before returning to the dockyard, Cyrus Harding conceived\r\n'b'the idea of fabricating certain machines, which greatly excited the\r\n'b'curiosity of his companions. He took a dozen of the whale\xe2\x80\x99s bones, cut\r\n'b'them into six equal parts, and sharpened their ends.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis machine is not my own invention, and it is frequently employed\r\n'b'by the Aleutian hunters in Russian America. You see these bones, my\r\n'b'friends; well, when it freezes, I will bend them, and then wet them\r\n'b'with water till they are entirely covered with ice, which will keep them\r\n'b'bent, and I will strew them on the snow, having previously covered them\r\n'b'with fat. Now, what will happen if a hungry animal swallows one of these\r\n'b'baits? Why, the heat of his stomach will melt the ice, and the bone,\r\n'b'springing straight, will pierce him with its sharp points.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell! I do call that ingenious!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it will spare the powder and shot,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be better than traps!\xe2\x80\x9d added Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile the boat-building progressed, and towards the end of\r\n'b'the month half the planking was completed. It could already be seen that\r\n'b'her shape was excellent, and that she would sail well.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft worked with unparalleled ardor, and only a sturdy frame could\r\n'b'have borne such fatigue; but his companions were preparing in secret a\r\n'b'reward for his labors, and on the 31st of May he was to meet with one of\r\n'b'the greatest joys of his life.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On that day, after dinner, just as he was about to leave the table,\r\n'b'Pencroft felt a hand on his shoulder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the hand of Gideon Spilett, who said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne moment, Master Pencroft, you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t sneak off like that! You\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\n'b'forgotten your dessert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI am going back to my\r\n'b'work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, a cup of coffee, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA pipe, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft jumped up, and his great good-natured face grew pale when he\r\n'b'saw the reporter presenting him with a ready-filled pipe, and Herbert\r\n'b'with a glowing coal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor endeavored to speak, but could not get out a word; so,\r\n'b'seizing the pipe, he carried it to his lips, then applying the coal,\r\n'b'he drew five or six great whiffs. A fragrant blue cloud soon arose, and\r\n'b'from its depths a voice was heard repeating excitedly,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTobacco! real tobacco!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand very good tobacco too!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cO, divine Providence; sacred Author of all things!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing more is now wanting to our island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Pencroft smoked, and smoked, and smoked.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who made this discovery?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked at length. \xe2\x80\x9cYou, Herbert, no\r\n'b'doubt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft, it was Mr. Spilett.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Spilett!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor, seizing the reporter, and clasping\r\n'b'him to his breast with such a squeeze that he had never felt anything\r\n'b'like it before.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, recovering his breath at last, \xe2\x80\x9ca truce for\r\n'b'one moment. You must share your gratitude with Herbert, who recognized\r\n'b'the plant, with Cyrus, who prepared it, and with Neb, who took a great\r\n'b'deal of trouble to keep our secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my friends, I will repay you some day,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cNow\r\n'b'we are friends for life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 11\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Winter arrived with the month of June, which is the December of the\r\n'b'northern zones, and the great business was the making of warm and solid\r\n'b'clothing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The musmons in the corral had been stripped of their wool, and this\r\n'b'precious textile material was now to be transformed into stuff.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Of course Cyrus Harding, having at his disposal neither carders,\r\n'b'combers, polishers, stretchers, twisters, mule-jenny, nor self-acting\r\n'b'machine to spin the wool, nor loom to weave it, was obliged to proceed\r\n'b'in a simpler way, so as to do without spinning and weaving. And indeed\r\n'b'he proposed to make use of the property which the filaments of wool\r\n'b'possess when subjected to a powerful pressure of mixing together, and of\r\n'b'manufacturing by this simple process the material called felt. This felt\r\n'b'could then be obtained by a simple operation which, if it diminished\r\n'b'the flexibility of the stuff, increased its power of retaining heat in\r\n'b'proportion. Now the wool furnished by the musmons was composed of very\r\n'b'short hairs, and was in a good condition to be felted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, aided by his companions, including Pencroft, who was once\r\n'b'more obliged to leave his boat, commenced the preliminary operations,\r\n'b'the subject of which was to rid the wool of that fat and oily substance\r\n'b'with which it is impregnated, and which is called grease. This cleaning\r\n'b'was done in vats filled with water, which was maintained at the\r\n'b'temperature of seventy degrees, and in which the wool was soaked for\r\n'b'four-and-twenty hours; it was then thoroughly washed in baths of soda,\r\n'b'and, when sufficiently dried by pressure, it was in a state to be\r\n'b'compressed, that is to say, to produce a solid material, rough, no\r\n'b'doubt, and such as would have no value in a manufacturing center of\r\n'b'Europe or America, but which would be highly esteemed in the Lincoln\r\n'b'Island markets.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This sort of material must have been known from the most ancient times,\r\n'b'and, in fact, the first woolen stuffs were manufactured by the process\r\n'b'which Harding was now about to employ. Where Harding\xe2\x80\x99s engineering\r\n'b'qualifications now came into play was in the construction of the machine\r\n'b'for pressing the wool; for he knew how to turn ingeniously to profit\r\n'b'the mechanical force, hitherto unused, which the waterfall on the beach\r\n'b'possessed to move a fulling-mill.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nothing could be more rudimentary. The wool was placed in troughs, and\r\n'b'upon it fell in turns heavy wooden mallets; such was the machine in\r\n'b'question, and such it had been for centuries until the time when the\r\n'b'mallets were replaced by cylinders of compression, and the material was\r\n'b'no longer subjected to beating, but to regular rolling.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The operation, ably directed by Cyrus Harding, was a complete success.\r\n'b'The wool, previously impregnated with a solution of soap, intended on\r\n'b'the one hand to facilitate the interlacing, the compression, and the\r\n'b'softening of the wool, and on the other to prevent its diminution by\r\n'b'the beating, issued from the mill in the shape of thick felt cloth. The\r\n'b'roughnesses with which the staple of wool is naturally filled were so\r\n'b'thoroughly entangled and interlaced together that a material was formed\r\n'b'equally suitable either for garments or bedclothes. It was certainly\r\n'b'neither merino, muslin, cashmere, rep, satin, alpaca, cloth, nor\r\n'b'flannel. It was \xe2\x80\x9cLincolnian felt,\xe2\x80\x9d and Lincoln Island possessed yet\r\n'b'another manufacture. The colonists had now warm garments and thick\r\n'b'bedclothes, and they could without fear await the approach of the winter\r\n'b'of 1866-67.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The severe cold began to be felt about the 20th of June, and, to his\r\n'b'great regret, Pencroft was obliged to suspend his boat-building, which\r\n'b'he hoped to finish in time for next spring.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor\xe2\x80\x99s great idea was to make a voyage of discovery to Tabor\r\n'b'Island, although Harding could not approve of a voyage simply for\r\n'b'curiosity\xe2\x80\x99s sake, for there was evidently nothing to be found on this\r\n'b'desert and almost arid rock. A voyage of a hundred and fifty miles in a\r\n'b'comparatively small vessel, over unknown seas, could not but cause him\r\n'b'some anxiety. Suppose that their vessel, once out at sea, should be\r\n'b'unable to reach Tabor Island, and could not return to Lincoln Island,\r\n'b'what would become of her in the midst of the Pacific, so fruitful of\r\n'b'disasters?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding often talked over this project with Pencroft, and he found him\r\n'b'strangely bent upon undertaking this voyage, for which determination he\r\n'b'himself could give no sufficient reason.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer one day to him, \xe2\x80\x9cI must observe, my friend,\r\n'b'that after having said so much, in praise of Lincoln Island, after\r\n'b'having spoken so often of the sorrow you would feel if you were obliged\r\n'b'to forsake it, you are the first to wish to leave it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOnly to leave it for a few days,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9conly for a few\r\n'b'days, captain. Time to go and come back, and see what that islet is\r\n'b'like!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is not nearly as good as Lincoln Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI know that beforehand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen why venture there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo know what is going on in Tabor Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut nothing is going on there; nothing could happen there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho knows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if you are caught in a hurricane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no fear of that in the fine season,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, captain, as we must provide against everything, I shall ask your\r\n'b'permission to take Herbert only with me on this voyage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, placing his hand on the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'shoulder, \xe2\x80\x9cif any misfortune happens to you, or to this lad, whom\r\n'b'chance has made our child, do you think we could ever cease to blame\r\n'b'ourselves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, with unshaken confidence, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\r\n'b'shall not cause you that sorrow. Besides, we will speak further of this\r\n'b'voyage, when the time comes to make it. And I fancy, when you have seen\r\n'b'our tight-rigged little craft, when you have observed how she behaves at\r\n'b'sea, when we sail round our island, for we will do so together--I fancy,\r\n'b'I say, that you will no longer hesitate to let me go. I don\xe2\x80\x99t conceal\r\n'b'from you that your boat will be a masterpiece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSay \xe2\x80\x98our\xe2\x80\x99 boat, at least, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, disarmed for\r\n'b'the moment. The conversation ended thus, to be resumed later on, without\r\n'b'convincing either the sailor or the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first snow fell towards the end of the month of June. The corral had\r\n'b'previously been largely supplied with stores, so that daily visits to\r\n'b'it were not requisite; but it was decided that more than a week should\r\n'b'never be allowed to pass without someone going to it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Traps were again set, and the machines manufactured by Harding were\r\n'b'tried. The bent whalebones, imprisoned in a case of ice, and covered\r\n'b'with a thick outer layer of fat, were placed on the border of the forest\r\n'b'at a spot where animals usually passed on their way to the lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s great satisfaction, this invention, copied from the\r\n'b'Aleutian fishermen, succeeded perfectly. A dozen foxes, a few wild\r\n'b'boars, and even a jaguar, were taken in this way, the animals being\r\n'b'found dead, their stomachs pierced by the unbent bones.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An incident must here be related, not only as interesting in itself, but\r\n'b'because it was the first attempt made by the colonists to communicate\r\n'b'with the rest of mankind.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett had already several times pondered whether to throw into\r\n'b'the sea a letter enclosed in a bottle, which currents might perhaps\r\n'b'carry to an inhabited coast, or to confide it to pigeons.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But how could it be seriously hoped that either pigeons or bottles could\r\n'b'cross the distance of twelve hundred miles which separated the island\r\n'b'from any inhabited land? It would have been pure folly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But on the 30th of June the capture was effected, not without\r\n'b'difficulty, of an albatross, which a shot from Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s gun had\r\n'b'slightly wounded in the foot. It was a magnificent bird, measuring ten\r\n'b'feet from wing to wing, and which could traverse seas as wide as the\r\n'b'Pacific.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert would have liked to keep this superb bird, as its wound would\r\n'b'soon heal, and he thought he could tame it; but Spilett explained to\r\n'b'him that they should not neglect this opportunity of attempting to\r\n'b'communicate by this messenger with the lands of the Pacific; for if the\r\n'b'albatross had come from some inhabited region, there was no doubt but\r\n'b'that it would return there so soon as it was set free.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Perhaps in his heart Gideon Spilett, in whom the journalist sometimes\r\n'b'came to the surface, was not sorry to have the opportunity of sending\r\n'b'forth to take its chance an exciting article relating the adventures\r\n'b'of the settlers in Lincoln Island. What a success for the authorized\r\n'b'reporter of the New York Herald, and for the number which should contain\r\n'b'the article, if it should ever reach the address of its editor, the\r\n'b'Honorable James Bennett!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett then wrote out a concise account, which was placed in a\r\n'b'strong waterproof bag, with an earnest request to whoever might find it\r\n'b'to forward it to the office of the New York Herald. This little bag was\r\n'b'fastened to the neck of the albatross, and not to its foot, for these\r\n'b'birds are in the habit of resting on the surface of the sea; then\r\n'b'liberty was given to this swift courier of the air, and it was not\r\n'b'without some emotion that the colonists watched it disappear in the\r\n'b'misty west.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he going to?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTowards New Zealand,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA good voyage to you,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the sailor, who himself did not expect\r\n'b'any great result from this mode of correspondence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'With the winter, work had been resumed in the interior of Granite House,\r\n'b'mending clothes and different occupations, among others making the sails\r\n'b'for their vessel, which were cut from the inexhaustible balloon-case.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the month of July the cold was intense, but there was no lack of\r\n'b'either wood or coal. Cyrus Harding had established a second fireplace in\r\n'b'the dining-room, and there the long winter evenings were spent. Talking\r\n'b'while they worked, reading when the hands remained idle, the time passed\r\n'b'with profit to all.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was real enjoyment to the settlers when in their room, well lighted\r\n'b'with candles, well warmed with coal, after a good dinner, elderberry\r\n'b'coffee smoking in the cups, the pipes giving forth an odoriferous smoke,\r\n'b'they could hear the storm howling without. Their comfort would have been\r\n'b'complete, if complete comfort could ever exist for those who are far\r\n'b'from their fellow-creatures, and without any means of communication with\r\n'b'them. They often talked of their country, of the friends whom they had\r\n'b'left, of the grandeur of the American Republic, whose influence could\r\n'b'not but increase; and Cyrus Harding, who had been much mixed up with the\r\n'b'affairs of the Union, greatly interested his auditors by his recitals,\r\n'b'his views, and his prognostics.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It chanced one day that Spilett was led to say--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut now, my dear Cyrus, all this industrial and commercial movement\r\n'b'to which you predict a continual advance, does it not run the danger of\r\n'b'being sooner or later completely stopped?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStopped! And by what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy the want of coal, which may justly be called the most precious of\r\n'b'minerals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the most precious indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cand it would\r\n'b'seem that nature wished to prove that it was so by making the diamond,\r\n'b'which is simply pure carbon crystallized.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we burn\r\n'b'diamonds in our stoves in the shape of coal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not deny that some day the\r\n'b'coal will be entirely consumed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! the veins of coal are still considerable, and the hundred\r\n'b'thousand miners who annually extract from them a hundred millions of\r\n'b'hundredweights have not nearly exhausted them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWith the increasing consumption of coal,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\n'b'can be foreseen that the hundred thousand workmen will soon become two\r\n'b'hundred thousand, and that the rate of extraction will be doubled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless; but after the European mines, which will be soon worked more\r\n'b'thoroughly with new machines, the American and Australian mines will for\r\n'b'a long time yet provide for the consumption in trade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor how long a time?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor at least two hundred and fifty or three hundred years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is reassuring for us, but a bad look-out for our\r\n'b'great-grandchildren!\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey will discover something else,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is to be hoped so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cfor without coal there would\r\n'b'be no machinery, and without machinery there would be no railways, no\r\n'b'steamers, no manufactories, nothing of that which is indispensable to\r\n'b'modern civilization!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what will they find?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cCan you guess, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNearly, my friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what will they burn instead of coal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWater,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWater!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwater as fuel for steamers and engines! water\r\n'b'to heat water!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but water decomposed into its primitive elements,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand decomposed doubtless, by electricity, which will then have\r\n'b'become a powerful and manageable force, for all great discoveries, by\r\n'b'some inexplicable laws, appear to agree and become complete at the same\r\n'b'time. Yes, my friends, I believe that water will one day be employed\r\n'b'as fuel, that hydrogen and oxygen which constitute it, used singly or\r\n'b'together, will furnish an inexhaustible source of heat and light, of\r\n'b'an intensity of which coal is not capable. Some day the coalrooms of\r\n'b'steamers and the tenders of locomotives will, instead of coal, be stored\r\n'b'with these two condensed gases, which will burn in the furnaces with\r\n'b'enormous calorific power. There is, therefore, nothing to fear. As long\r\n'b'as the earth is inhabited it will supply the wants of its inhabitants,\r\n'b'and there will be no want of either light or heat as long as the\r\n'b'productions of the vegetable, mineral or animal kingdoms do not fail us.\r\n'b'I believe, then, that when the deposits of coal are exhausted we shall\r\n'b'heat and warm ourselves with water. Water will be the coal of the\r\n'b'future.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to see that,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou were born too soon, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Neb, who only took part in\r\n'b'the discussion by these words.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, it was not Neb\xe2\x80\x99s speech which interrupted the conversation, but\r\n'b'Top\xe2\x80\x99s barking, which broke out again with that strange intonation which\r\n'b'had before perplexed the engineer. At the same time Top began to run\r\n'b'round the mouth of the well, which opened at the extremity of the\r\n'b'interior passage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can Top be barking in that way for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Jup be growling like that?\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact the orang, joining the dog, gave unequivocal signs of agitation,\r\n'b'and, singular to say, the two animals appeared more uneasy than angry.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is evident,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this well is in direct\r\n'b'communication with the sea, and that some marine animal comes from time\r\n'b'to time to breathe at the bottom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s evident,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand there can be no other\r\n'b'explanation to give. Quiet there, Top!\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, turning to the\r\n'b'dog, \xe2\x80\x9cand you, Jup, be off to your room!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The ape and the dog were silent. Jup went off to bed, but Top remained\r\n'b'in the room, and continued to utter low growls at intervals during the\r\n'b'rest of the evening. There was no further talk on the subject, but the\r\n'b'incident, however, clouded the brow of the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the remainder of the month of July there was alternate rain and\r\n'b'frost. The temperature was not so low as during the preceding winter,\r\n'b'and its maximum did not exceed eight degrees Fahrenheit. But although\r\n'b'this winter was less cold, it was more troubled by storms and squalls;\r\n'b'the sea besides often endangered the safety of the Chimneys. At times\r\n'b'it almost seemed as if an under-current raised these monstrous billows\r\n'b'which thundered against the wall of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When the settlers, leaning from their windows, gazed on the huge watery\r\n'b'masses breaking beneath their eyes, they could not but admire the\r\n'b'magnificent spectacle of the ocean in its impotent fury. The waves\r\n'b'rebounded in dazzling foam, the beach entirely disapppearing under the\r\n'b'raging flood, and the cliff appearing to emerge from the sea itself, the\r\n'b'spray rising to a height of more than a hundred feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During these storms it was difficult and even dangerous to venture out,\r\n'b'owing to the frequently falling trees; however, the colonists never\r\n'b'allowed a week to pass without having paid a visit to the corral.\r\n'b'Happily, this enclosure, sheltered by the southeastern spur of Mount\r\n'b'Franklin, did not greatly suffer from the violence of the hurricanes,\r\n'b'which spared its trees, sheds, and palisades; but the poultry-yard on\r\n'b'Prospect Heights, being directly exposed to the gusts of wind from the\r\n'b'east, suffered considerable damage. The pigeon-house was twice unroofed\r\n'b'and the paling blown down. All this required to be remade more solidly\r\n'b'than before, for, as may be clearly seen, Lincoln Island was situated in\r\n'b'one of the most dangerous parts of the Pacific. It really appeared as if\r\n'b'it formed the central point of vast cyclones, which beat it perpetually\r\n'b'as the whip does the top, only here it was the top which was motionless\r\n'b'and the whip which moved. During the first week of the month of August\r\n'b'the weather became more moderate, and the atmosphere recovered the calm\r\n'b'which it appeared to have lost forever. With the calm the cold again\r\n'b'became intense, and the thermometer fell to eight degrees Fahrenheit,\r\n'b'below zero.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 3rd of August an excursion which had been talked of for several\r\n'b'days was made into the southeastern part of the island, towards Tadorn\r\n'b'Marsh. The hunters were tempted by the aquatic game which took up their\r\n'b'winter quarters there. Wild duck, snipe, teal and grebe abounded there,\r\n'b'and it was agreed that a day should be devoted to an expedition against\r\n'b'these birds.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Not only Gideon Spilett and Herbert, but Pencroft and Neb also took part\r\n'b'in this excursion. Cyrus Harding alone, alleging some work as an excuse,\r\n'b'did not join them, but remained at Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The hunters proceeded in the direction of Port Balloon, in order to\r\n'b'reach the marsh, after having promised to be back by the evening. Top\r\n'b'and Jup accompanied them. As soon as they had passed over the Mercy\r\n'b'Bridge, the engineer raised it and returned, intending to put into\r\n'b'execution a project for the performance of which he wished to be alone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now this project was to minutely explore the interior well, the mouth\r\n'b'of which was on a level with the passage of Granite House, and which\r\n'b'communicated with the sea, since it formerly supplied a way to the\r\n'b'waters of the lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Why did Top so often run round this opening? Why did he utter such\r\n'b'strange barks when a sort of uneasiness seemed to draw him towards this\r\n'b'well? Why did Jup join Top in a sort of common anxiety? Had this well\r\n'b'branches besides the communication with the sea? Did it spread towards\r\n'b'other parts of the island? This is what Cyrus Harding wished to know. He\r\n'b'had resolved, therefore, to attempt the exploration of the well during\r\n'b'the absence of his companions, and an opportunity for doing so had now\r\n'b'presented itself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was easy to descend to the bottom of the well by employing the rope\r\n'b'ladder which had not been used since the establishment of the lift. The\r\n'b'engineer drew the ladder to the hole, the diameter of which measured\r\n'b'nearly six feet, and allowed it to unroll itself after having securely\r\n'b'fastened its upper extremity. Then, having lighted a lantern, taken a\r\n'b'revolver, and placed a cutlass in his belt, he began the descent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sides were everywhere entire; but points of rock jutted out here and\r\n'b'there, and by means of these points it would have been quite possible\r\n'b'for an active creature to climb to the mouth of the well.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer remarked this; but although he carefully examined these\r\n'b'points by the light of his lantern, he could find no impression, no\r\n'b'fracture which could give any reason to suppose that they had either\r\n'b'recently or at any former time been used as a staircase. Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'descended deeper, throwing the light of his lantern on all sides.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He saw nothing suspicious.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When the engineer had reached the last rounds he came upon the water,\r\n'b'which was then perfectly calm. Neither at its level nor in any other\r\n'b'part of the well, did any passage open, which could lead to the interior\r\n'b'of the cliff. The wall which Harding struck with the hilt of his cutlass\r\n'b'sounded solid. It was compact granite, through which no living being\r\n'b'could force a way. To arrive at the bottom of the well and then climb\r\n'b'up to its mouth it was necessary to pass through the channel under the\r\n'b'rocky subsoil of the beach, which placed it in communication with the\r\n'b'sea, and this was only possible for marine animals. As to the question\r\n'b'of knowing where this channel ended, at what point of the shore, and at\r\n'b'what depth beneath the water, it could not be answered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then Cyrus Harding, having ended his survey, re-ascended, drew up the\r\n'b'ladder, covered the mouth of the well, and returned thoughtfully to the\r\n'b'diningroom, saying to himself,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have seen nothing, and yet there is something there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 12\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the evening the hunters returned, having enjoyed good sport, and\r\n'b'being literally loaded with game; indeed, they had as much as four men\r\n'b'could possibly carry. Top wore a necklace of teal and Jup wreaths of\r\n'b'snipe round his body.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere, master,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb; \xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s something to employ our time!\r\n'b'Preserved and made into pies we shall have a welcome store! But I must\r\n'b'have some one to help me. I count on you, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cI have the rigging of the vessel to\r\n'b'finish and to look after, and you will have to do without me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, Mr. Herbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI must go to the corral to-morrow, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the lad.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be you then, Mr. Spilett, who will help me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo oblige you, Neb, I will,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I warn you that\r\n'b'if you disclose your recipes to me, I shall publish them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhenever you like, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb; \xe2\x80\x9cwhenever you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And so the next day Gideon Spilett became Neb\xe2\x80\x99s assistant and was\r\n'b'installed in his culinary laboratory. The engineer had previously made\r\n'b'known to him the result of the exploration which he had made the day\r\n'b'before, and on this point the reporter shared Harding\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, that\r\n'b'although he had found nothing, a secret still remained to be discovered!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The frost continued for another week, and the settlers did not leave\r\n'b'Granite House unless to look after the poultry-yard. The dwelling\r\n'b'was filled with appetizing odors, which were emitted from the learned\r\n'b'manipulation of Neb and the reporter. But all the results of the chase\r\n'b'were not made into preserved provisions; and as the game kept perfectly\r\n'b'in the intense cold, wild duck and other fowl were eaten fresh, and\r\n'b'declared superior to all other aquatic birds in the known world.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this week, Pencroft, aided by Herbert, who handled the\r\n'b'sailmaker\xe2\x80\x99s needle with much skill, worked with such energy that the\r\n'b'sails of the vessel were finished. There was no want of cordage. Thanks\r\n'b'to the rigging which had been discovered with the case of the balloon,\r\n'b'the ropes and cables from the net were all of good quality, and the\r\n'b'sailor turned them all to account. To the sails were attached strong\r\n'b'bolt ropes, and there still remained enough from which to make the\r\n'b'halyards, shrouds, and sheets, etc. The blocks were manufactured by\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding under Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s directions by means of the turning lathe.\r\n'b'It therefore happened that the rigging was entirely prepared before the\r\n'b'vessel was finished. Pencroft also manufactured a flag, that flag so\r\n'b'dear to every true American, containing the stars and stripes of their\r\n'b'glorious Union. The colors for it were supplied from certain plants\r\n'b'used in dyeing, and which were very abundant in the island; only to the\r\n'b'thirty-seven stars, representing the thirty-seven States of the Union,\r\n'b'which shine on the American flag, the sailor added a thirty-eighth, the\r\n'b'star of \xe2\x80\x9cthe State of Lincoln,\xe2\x80\x9d for he considered his island as already\r\n'b'united to the great republic. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cit is so already in\r\n'b'heart, if not in deed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meantime, the flag was hoisted at the central window of Granite\r\n'b'House, and the settlers saluted it with three cheers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cold season was now almost at an end, and it appeared as if this\r\n'b'second winter was to pass without any unusual occurrence, when on the\r\n'b'night of the 11th of August, the plateau of Prospect Heights was menaced\r\n'b'with complete destruction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After a busy day the colonists were sleeping soundly, when towards four\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning they were suddenly awakened by Top\xe2\x80\x99s barking.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The dog was not this time barking near the mouth of the well, but at\r\n'b'the threshold of the door, at which he was scratching as if he wished to\r\n'b'burst it open. Jup was also uttering piercing cries.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHello, Top!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, who was the first awake. But the dog continued\r\n'b'to bark more furiously than ever.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And all dressing in haste rushed to the windows, which they opened.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Beneath their eyes was spread a sheet of snow which looked gray in the\r\n'b'dim light. The settlers could see nothing, but they heard a singular\r\n'b'yelping noise away in the darkness. It was evident that the beach had\r\n'b'been invaded by a number of animals which could not be seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are they?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWolves, jaguars, or apes?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey have nearly reached the plateau,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd our poultry-yard,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand our garden!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhere can they have crossed?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey must have crossed the bridge on the shore,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cwhich one of us must have forgotten to close.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cI remember having left it open.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA fine job you have made of it, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is done cannot be undone,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must consult\r\n'b'what it will now be best to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Such were the questions and answers which were rapidly exchanged between\r\n'b'Harding and his companions. It was certain that the bridge had been\r\n'b'crossed, that the shore had been invaded by animals, and that whatever\r\n'b'they might be they could by ascending the left bank of the Mercy reach\r\n'b'Prospect Heights. They must therefore be advanced against quickly and\r\n'b'fought with if necessary.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what are these beasts?\xe2\x80\x9d was asked a second time, as the yelpings\r\n'b'were again heard more loudly than before. These yelps made Herbert\r\n'b'start, and he remembered having heard them before during his first visit\r\n'b'to the sources of the Red Creek.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey are colpeo foxes!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And all arming themselves with hatchets, carbines, and revolvers, threw\r\n'b'themselves into the lift and soon set foot on the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Colpeos are dangerous animals when in great numbers and irritated by\r\n'b'hunger, nevertheless the colonists did not hesitate to throw themselves\r\n'b'into the midst of the troop, and their first shots vividly lighting up\r\n'b'the darkness made their assailants draw back.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The chief thing was to hinder these plunderers from reaching the\r\n'b'plateau, for the garden and the poultry-yard would then have been at\r\n'b'their mercy, and immense, perhaps irreparable mischief, would inevitably\r\n'b'be the result, especially with regard to the corn-field. But as the\r\n'b'invasion of the plateau could only be made by the left bank of the\r\n'b'Mercy, it was sufficient to oppose the colpeos on the narrow bank\r\n'b'between the river and the cliff of granite.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was plain to all, and, by Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s orders, they reached the\r\n'b'spot indicated by him, while the colpeos rushed fiercely through\r\n'b'the gloom. Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft and Neb posted\r\n'b'themselves in impregnable line. Top, his formidable jaws open, preceded\r\n'b'the colonists, and he was followed by Jup, armed with a knotty cudgel,\r\n'b'which he brandished like a club.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night was extremely dark, it was only by the flashes from the\r\n'b'revolvers as each person fired that they could see their assailants, who\r\n'b'were at least a hundred in number, and whose eyes were glowing like hot\r\n'b'coals.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey must not pass!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey shall not pass!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But if they did not pass it was not for want of having attempted it.\r\n'b'Those in the rear pushed on the foremost assailants, and it was an\r\n'b'incessant struggle with revolvers and hatchets. Several colpeos already\r\n'b'lay dead on the ground, but their number did not appear to diminish,\r\n'b'and it might have been supposed that reinforcements were continually\r\n'b'arriving over the bridge.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists were soon obliged to fight at close quarters, not without\r\n'b'receiving some wounds, though happily very slight ones. Herbert had,\r\n'b'with a shot from his revolver, rescued Neb, on whose back a colpeo had\r\n'b'sprung like a tiger cat. Top fought with actual fury, flying at the\r\n'b'throats of the foxes and strangling them instantaneously. Jup wielded\r\n'b'his weapon valiantly, and it was in vain that they endeavored to keep\r\n'b'him in the rear. Endowed doubtless with sight which enabled him to\r\n'b'pierce the obscurity, he was always in the thick of the fight uttering\r\n'b'from time to time--a sharp hissing sound, which was with him the sign of\r\n'b'great rejoicing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At one moment he advanced so far, that by the light from a revolver\r\n'b'he was seen surrounded by five or six large colpeos, with whom he was\r\n'b'coping with great coolness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the struggle was ended at last, and victory was on the side\r\n'b'of the settlers, but not until they had fought for two long hours! The\r\n'b'first signs of the approach of day doubtless determined the retreat of\r\n'b'their assailants, who scampered away towards the North, passing over the\r\n'b'bridge, which Neb ran immediately to raise. When day had sufficiently\r\n'b'lighted up the field of battle, the settlers counted as many as fifty\r\n'b'dead bodies scattered about on the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Jup!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cwhere is Jup?\xe2\x80\x9d Jup had disappeared. His\r\n'b'friend Neb called him, and for the first time Jup did not reply to his\r\n'b'friend\xe2\x80\x99s call.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Everyone set out in search of Jup, trembling lest he should be found\r\n'b'among the slain; they cleared the place of the bodies which stained the\r\n'b'snow with their blood. Jup was found in the midst of a heap of colpeos\r\n'b'whose broken jaws and crushed bodies showed that they had to do with the\r\n'b'terrible club of the intrepid animal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Poor Jup still held in his hand the stump of his broken cudgel, but\r\n'b'deprived of his weapon he had been overpowered by numbers, and his chest\r\n'b'was covered with severe wounds.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe is living,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb, who was bending over him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we will save him,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will nurse him as if he\r\n'b'was one of ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It appeared as if Jup understood, for he leaned his head on Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'shoulder as if to thank him. The sailor was wounded himself, but his\r\n'b'wound was insignificant, as were those of his companions; for thanks to\r\n'b'their firearms they had been almost always able to keep their assailants\r\n'b'at a distance. It was therefore only the orang whose condition was\r\n'b'serious.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Jup, carried by Neb and Pencroft, was placed in the lift, and only a\r\n'b'slight moan now and then escaped his lips. He was gently drawn up to\r\n'b'Granite House. There he was laid on a mattress taken from one of the\r\n'b'beds, and his wounds were bathed with the greatest care. It did not\r\n'b'appear that any vital part had been reached, but Jup was very weak from\r\n'b'loss of blood, and a high fever soon set in after his wounds had been\r\n'b'dressed. He was laid down, strict diet was imposed, \xe2\x80\x9cjust like a real\r\n'b'person,\xe2\x80\x9d as Neb said, and they made him swallow several cups of\r\n'b'a cooling drink, for which the ingredients were supplied from the\r\n'b'vegetable medicine chest of Granite House. Jup was at first restless,\r\n'b'but his breathing gradually became more regular, and he was left\r\n'b'sleeping quietly. From time to time Top, walking on tip-toe, as one\r\n'b'might say, came to visit his friend, and seemed to approve of all the\r\n'b'care that had been taken of him. One of Jup\xe2\x80\x99s hands hung over the side\r\n'b'of his bed, and Top licked it with a sympathizing air.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They employed the day in interring the dead, who were dragged to the\r\n'b'forest of the Far West, and there buried deep.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This attack, which might have had such serious consequences, was a\r\n'b'lesson to the settlers, who from this time never went to bed until one\r\n'b'of their number had made sure that all the bridges were raised, and that\r\n'b'no invasion was possible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, Jup, after having given them serious anxiety for several\r\n'b'days, began to recover. His constitution brought him through, the fever\r\n'b'gradually subsided, and Gideon Spilett, who was a bit of a doctor,\r\n'b'pronounced him quite out of danger. On the 16th of August, Jup began to\r\n'b'eat. Neb made him nice little sweet dishes, which the invalid devoured\r\n'b'with great relish, for if he had a pet failing it was that of being\r\n'b'somewhat of a gourmand, and Neb had never done anything to cure him of\r\n'b'this fault.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Gideon Spilett, who sometimes\r\n'b'expostulated with him for spoiling the ape. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor Jup has no other\r\n'b'pleasure than that of the palate, and I am only too glad to be able to\r\n'b'reward his services in this way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ten days after taking to his bed, on the 21st of August, Master Jup\r\n'b'arose. His wounds were healed, and it was evident that he would not\r\n'b'be long in regaining his usual strength and agility. Like all\r\n'b'convalescents, he was tremendously hungry, and the reporter allowed him\r\n'b'to eat as much as he liked, for he trusted to that instinct, which\r\n'b'is too often wanting in reasoning beings, to keep the orang from any\r\n'b'excess. Neb was delighted to see his pupil\xe2\x80\x99s appetite returning.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEat away, my Jup,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand don\xe2\x80\x99t spare anything; you have shed\r\n'b'your blood for us, and it is the least I can do to make you strong\r\n'b'again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 25th of August Neb\xe2\x80\x99s voice was heard calling to his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain, Mr. Spilett, Mr. Herbert, Pencroft, come! come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, who were together in the dining-room, rose at Neb\xe2\x80\x99s call,\r\n'b'who was then in Jup\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, with a shout of laughter. And what did they see?\r\n'b'Master Jup smoking calmly and seriously, sitting crosslegged like a Turk\r\n'b'at the entrance to Granite House!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy pipe,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cHe has taken my pipe! Hello, my honest Jup,\r\n'b'I make you a present of it! Smoke away, old boy, smoke away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Jup gravely puffed out clouds of smoke which seemed to give him\r\n'b'great satisfaction. Harding did not appear to be much astonished at this\r\n'b'incident, and he cited several examples of tame apes, to whom the use of\r\n'b'tobacco had become quite familiar.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But from this day Master Jup had a pipe of his own, the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'ex-pipe, which was hung in his room near his store of tobacco. He filled\r\n'b'it himself, lighted it with a glowing coal, and appeared to be\r\n'b'the happiest of quadrumana. It may readily be understood that this\r\n'b'similarity of tastes of Jup and Pencroft served to tighten the bonds of\r\n'b'friendship which already existed between the honest ape and the worthy\r\n'b'sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he is really a man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft sometimes to Neb. \xe2\x80\x9cShould\r\n'b'you be surprised to hear him beginning to speak to us some day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy word, no,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat astonishes me is that he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t spoken\r\n'b'to us before, for now he wants nothing but speech!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt would amuse me all the same,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cif some fine day\r\n'b'he said to me, \xe2\x80\x98Suppose we change pipes, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a pity he was born dumb!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'With the month of September the winter ended, and the works were again\r\n'b'eagerly commenced. The building of the vessel advanced rapidly, she was\r\n'b'already completely decked over, and all the inside parts of the hull\r\n'b'were firmly united with ribs bent by means of steam, which answered all\r\n'b'the purposes of a mold.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As there was no want of wood, Pencroft proposed to the engineer to give\r\n'b'a double lining to the hull, to insure the strength of the vessel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding, not knowing what the future might have in store for them,\r\n'b'approved the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s idea of making the craft as strong as possible.\r\n'b'The interior and deck of the vessel was entirely finished towards the\r\n'b'15th of September. For calking the seams they made oakum of dry seaweed,\r\n'b'which was hammered in between the planks; then these seams were covered\r\n'b'with boiling tar, which was obtained in great abundance from the pines\r\n'b'in the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The management of the vessel was very simple. She had from the first\r\n'b'been ballasted with heavy blocks of granite walled up, in a bed of lime,\r\n'b'twelve thousand pounds of which they stowed away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A deck was placed over this ballast, and the interior was divided into\r\n'b'two cabins; two benches extended along them and served also as lockers.\r\n'b'The foot of the mast supported the partition which separated the two\r\n'b'cabins, which were reached by two hatchways let into the deck.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft had no trouble in finding a tree suitable for the mast. He\r\n'b'chose a straight young fir, with no knots, and which he had only to\r\n'b'square at the step, and round off at the top. The ironwork of the mast,\r\n'b'the rudder and the hull had been roughly but strongly forged at the\r\n'b'Chimneys. Lastly, yards, masts, boom, spars, oars, etc., were all\r\n'b'furnished by the first week in October, and it was agreed that a trial\r\n'b'trip should be taken round the island, so as to ascertain how the vessel\r\n'b'would behave at sea, and how far they might depend upon her.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During all this time the necessary works had not been neglected.\r\n'b'The corral was enlarged, for the flock of musmons and goats had been\r\n'b'increased by a number of young ones, who had to be housed and fed. The\r\n'b'colonists had paid visits also to the oyster bed, the warren, the coal\r\n'b'and iron mines, and to the till then unexplored districts of the Far\r\n'b'West forest, which abounded in game. Certain indigenous plants were\r\n'b'discovered, and those fit for immediate use contributed to vary the\r\n'b'vegetable stores of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were a species of ficoide, some similar to those of the Cape, with\r\n'b'eatable fleshy leaves, others bearing seeds containing a sort of flour.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 10th of October the vessel was launched. Pencroft was radiant\r\n'b'with joy, the operation was perfectly successful; the boat completely\r\n'b'rigged, having been pushed on rollers to the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge, was floated\r\n'b'by the rising tide, amid the cheers of the colonists, particularly of\r\n'b'Pencroft, who showed no modesty on this occasion. Besides his importance\r\n'b'was to last beyond the finishing of the vessel, since, after having\r\n'b'built her, he was to command her. The grade of captain was bestowed upon\r\n'b'him with the approbation of all. To satisfy Captain Pencroft, it was now\r\n'b'necessary to give a name to the vessel, and, after many propositions had\r\n'b'been discussed, the votes were all in favor of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d As\r\n'b'soon as the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d had been lifted by the rising tide, it was\r\n'b'seen that she lay evenly in the water, and would be easily navigated.\r\n'b'However, the trial trip was to be made that very day, by an excursion\r\n'b'off the coast. The weather was fine, the breeze fresh, and the sea\r\n'b'smooth, especially towards the south coast, for the wind was blowing\r\n'b'from the northwest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll hands on board,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Pencroft; but breakfast was first\r\n'b'necessary, and it was thought best to take provisions on board, in the\r\n'b'event of their excursion being prolonged until the evening.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding was equally anxious to try the vessel, the model of which\r\n'b'had originated with him, although on the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s advice he had altered\r\n'b'some parts of it, but he did not share Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s confidence in her,\r\n'b'and as the latter had not again spoken of the voyage to Tabor Island,\r\n'b'Harding hoped he had given it up. He would have indeed great reluctance\r\n'b'in letting two or three of his companions venture so far in so small a\r\n'b'boat, which was not of more than fifteen tons\xe2\x80\x99 burden.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At half-past ten everybody was on board, even Top and Jup, and Herbert\r\n'b'weighed the anchor, which was fast in the sand near the mouth of the\r\n'b'Mercy. The sail was hoisted, the Lincolnian flag floated from the\r\n'b'masthead, and the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d steered by Pencroft, stood out to sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The wind blowing out of Union Bay she ran before it, and thus showed her\r\n'b'owners, much to their satisfaction, that she possessed a remarkably fast\r\n'b'pair of heels, according to Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s mode of speaking. After having\r\n'b'doubled Flotsam Point and Claw Cape, the captain kept her close hauled,\r\n'b'so as to sail along the southern coast of the island, when it was found\r\n'b'she sailed admirably within five points of the wind. All hands were\r\n'b'enchanted, they had a good vessel, which, in case of need, would be\r\n'b'of great service to them, and with fine weather and a fresh breeze the\r\n'b'voyage promised to be charming.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft now stood off the shore, three or four miles across from Port\r\n'b'Balloon. The island then appeared in all its extent and under a new\r\n'b'aspect, with the varied panorama of its shore from Claw Cape to Reptile\r\n'b'End, the forests in which dark firs contrasted with the young foliage\r\n'b'of other trees and overlooked the whole, and Mount Franklin whose lofty\r\n'b'head was still whitened with snow.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHow beautiful it is!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, our island is beautiful and good,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cI love it as\r\n'b'I loved my poor mother. It received us poor and destitute, and now what\r\n'b'is wanting to us five fellows who fell on it from the sky?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb; \xe2\x80\x9cnothing, captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the two brave men gave three tremendous cheers in honor of their\r\n'b'island!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During all this time Gideon Spilett, leaning against the mast, sketched\r\n'b'the panorama which was developed before his eyes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding gazed on it in silence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you think of our\r\n'b'vessel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShe appears to behave well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood! And do you think now that she could undertake a voyage of some\r\n'b'extent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat voyage, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne to Tabor Island, for instance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cI think that in any pressing emergency\r\n'b'we need not hesitate to trust ourselves to the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 even for\r\n'b'a longer voyage; but you know I should see you set off to Tabor Island\r\n'b'with great uneasiness, since nothing obliges you to go there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne likes to know one\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor, who was\r\n'b'obstinate in his idea. \xe2\x80\x9cTabor Island is our neighbor, and the only one!\r\n'b'Politeness requires us to go at least to pay a visit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy Jove,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cour friend Pencroft has become very particular\r\n'b'about the proprieties all at once!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not particular about anything at all,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted the sailor, who\r\n'b'was rather vexed by the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s opposition, but who did not wish to\r\n'b'cause him anxiety.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cConsider, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cyou cannot go alone to Tabor\r\n'b'Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne companion will be enough for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEven so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will risk depriving the colony of\r\n'b'Lincoln Island of two settlers out of five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOut of six,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cyou forget Jup.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOut of seven,\xe2\x80\x9d added Neb; \xe2\x80\x9cTop is quite worth another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no risk at all in it, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is possible, Pencroft; but I repeat it is to expose ourselves\r\n'b'uselessly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The obstinate sailor did not reply, and let the conversation drop, quite\r\n'b'determined to resume it again. But he did not suspect that an incident\r\n'b'would come to his aid and change into an act of humanity that which was\r\n'b'at first only a doubtful whim.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After standing off the shore the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d again approached it\r\n'b'in the direction of Port Balloon. It was important to ascertain the\r\n'b'channels between the sandbanks and reefs, that buoys might be laid down\r\n'b'since this little creek was to be the harbor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were not more than half a mile from the coast, and it was necessary\r\n'b'to tack to beat against the wind. The \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was then going at a\r\n'b'very moderate rate, as the breeze, partly intercepted by the high land,\r\n'b'scarcely swelled her sails, and the sea, smooth as glass, was only\r\n'b'rippled now and then by passing gusts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert had stationed himself in the bows that he might indicate the\r\n'b'course to be followed among the channels, when all at once he shouted,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLuff, Pencroft, luff!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9ca rock?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo--wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t quite see. Luff again--right--now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So saying, Herbert, leaning over the side, plunged his arm into the\r\n'b'water, and pulled it out, exclaiming,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA bottle!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He held in his hand a corked bottle which he had just seized a few\r\n'b'cables\xe2\x80\x99 length from the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding took the bottle. Without uttering a single word he drew\r\n'b'the cork, and took from it a damp paper, on which were written these\r\n'b'words:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCastaway....
