Tabor island: 153deg W. long., 37deg 11\xe2\x80\x99 S. lat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 13\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA castaway!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cleft on this Tabor Island not two\r\n'b'hundred miles from us! Ah, Captain Harding, you won\xe2\x80\x99t now oppose my\r\n'b'going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cand you shall set out as soon as\r\n'b'possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer still held in his hand the paper which he had taken from\r\n'b'the bottle. He contemplated it for some instants, then resumed,\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFrom this document, my friends, from the way in which it is worded,\r\n'b'we may conclude this: first, that the castaway on Tabor Island is a man\r\n'b'possessing a considerable knowledge of navigation, since he gives the\r\n'b'latitude and longitude of the island exactly as we ourselves found it,\r\n'b'and to a second of approximation; secondly, that he is either English or\r\n'b'American, as the document is written in the English language.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is perfectly logical,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Spilett; \xe2\x80\x9cand the presence of this\r\n'b'castaway explains the arrival of the case on the shores of our island.\r\n'b'There must have been a wreck, since there is a castaway. As to the\r\n'b'latter, whoever he may be, it is lucky for him that Pencroft thought of\r\n'b'building this boat and of trying her this very day, for a day later and\r\n'b'this bottle might have been broken on the rocks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a fortunate chance that the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 passed exactly where the bottle was still floating!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDoes not this appear strange to you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding of Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears fortunate, that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you see\r\n'b'anything extraordinary in it, captain? The bottle must go somewhere, and\r\n'b'why not here as well as anywhere else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you are right, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cand yet--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to prove that this bottle has\r\n'b'been floating long in the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand the document appears even to\r\n'b'have been recently written. What do you think about it, Cyrus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this conversation Pencroft had not remained inactive. He had put\r\n'b'the vessel about, and the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d all sails set, was running\r\n'b'rapidly towards Claw Cape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Every one was thinking of the castaway on Tabor Island. Should they\r\n'b'be in time to save him? This was a great event in the life of the\r\n'b'colonists! They themselves were but castaways, but it was to be feared\r\n'b'that another might not have been so fortunate, and their duty was to go\r\n'b'to his succor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Claw Cape was doubled, and about four o\xe2\x80\x99clock the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d dropped\r\n'b'her anchor at the mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That same evening the arrangements for the new expedition were made.\r\n'b'It appeared best that Pencroft and Herbert, who knew how to work the\r\n'b'vessel, should undertake the voyage alone. By setting out the next day,\r\n'b'the 10th of October, they would arrive on the 13th, for with the present\r\n'b'wind it would not take more than forty-eight hours to make this passage\r\n'b'of a hundred and fifty miles. One day in the island, three or four to\r\n'b'return, they might hope therefore that on the 17th they would again\r\n'b'reach Lincoln Island. The weather was fine, the barometer was rising,\r\n'b'the wind appeared settled, everything then was in favor of these brave\r\n'b'men whom an act of humanity was taking far from their island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus it had been agreed that Cyrus Harding, Neb, and Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'should remain at Granite House, but an objection was raised, and\r\n'b'Spilett, who had not forgotten his business as reporter to the New York\r\n'b'Herald, having declared that he would go by swimming rather than lose\r\n'b'such an opportunity, he was admitted to take a part in the voyage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The evening was occupied in transporting on board the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' articles of bedding, utensils, arms, ammunition, a compass, provisions\r\n'b'for a week; this being rapidly done, the colonists ascended to Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, the farewells were said,\r\n'b'not without some emotion on both sides, and Pencroft setting sail made\r\n'b'towards Claw Cape, which had to be doubled in order to proceed to the\r\n'b'southwest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was already a quarter of a mile from the coast when\r\n'b'the passengers perceived on the heights of Granite House two men waving\r\n'b'their farewells; they were Cyrus Harding and Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur friends,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is our first separation in\r\n'b'fifteen months.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, the reporter and Herbert waved in return, and Granite House\r\n'b'soon disappeared behind the high rocks of the Cape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the first part of the day the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was still in sight\r\n'b'of the southern coast of Lincoln Island, which soon appeared just like\r\n'b'a green basket, with Mount Franklin rising from the center. The heights,\r\n'b'diminished by distance, did not present an appearance likely to tempt\r\n'b'vessels to touch there. Reptile End was passed in about an hour, though\r\n'b'at a distance of about ten miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this distance it was no longer possible to distinguish anything of\r\n'b'the Western Coast, which stretched away to the ridges of Mount Franklin,\r\n'b'and three hours after the last of Lincoln Island sank below the horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d behaved capitally. Bounding over the waves she\r\n'b'proceeded rapidly on her course. Pencroft had hoisted the foresail, and\r\n'b'steering by the compass followed a rectilinear direction. From time to\r\n'b'time Herbert relieved him at the helm, and the lad\xe2\x80\x99s hand was so firm\r\n'b'that the sailor had not a point to find fault with.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett chatted sometimes with one, sometimes with the other, if\r\n'b'wanted he lent a hand with the ropes, and Captain Pencroft was perfectly\r\n'b'satisfied with his crew.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the evening the crescent moon, which would not be in its first\r\n'b'quarter until the 16th, appeared in the twilight and soon set again. The\r\n'b'night was dark but starry, and the next day again promised to be fine.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft prudently lowered the foresail, not wishing to be caught by\r\n'b'a sudden gust while carrying too much canvas; it was perhaps an\r\n'b'unnecessary precaution on such a calm night, but Pencroft was a prudent\r\n'b'sailor and cannot be blamed for it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter slept part of the night. Pencroft and Herbert took turns\r\n'b'for a spell of two hours each at the helm. The sailor trusted Herbert as\r\n'b'he would himself, and his confidence was justified by the coolness and\r\n'b'judgment of the lad. Pencroft gave him his directions as a commander to\r\n'b'his steersman, and Herbert never allowed the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d to swerve\r\n'b'even a point. The night passed quickly, as did the day of the 12th of\r\n'b'October. A south-easterly direction was strictly maintained. Unless the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d fell in with some unknown current she would come exactly\r\n'b'within sight of Tabor Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the sea over which the vessel was then sailing, it was absolutely\r\n'b'deserted. Now and then a great albatross or frigate bird passed within\r\n'b'gunshot, and Gideon Spilett wondered if it was to one of them that he\r\n'b'had confided his last letter addressed to the New York Herald. These\r\n'b'birds were the only beings that appeared to frequent this part of the\r\n'b'ocean between Tabor and Lincoln Islands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is the time that whalers usually\r\n'b'proceed towards the southern part of the Pacific. Indeed I do not think\r\n'b'there could be a more deserted sea than this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not quite so deserted as all that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are on it. Do you take our vessel for a wreck and us for porpoises?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Pencroft laughed at his joke.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'By the evening, according to calculation, it was thought that the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d had accomplished a distance of a hundred and twenty miles\r\n'b'since her departure from Lincoln Island, that is to say in thirty-six\r\n'b'hours, which would give her a speed of between three and four knots.\r\n'b'The breeze was very slight and might soon drop altogether.\r\n'b'However, it was hoped that the next morning by break of day, if the\r\n'b'calculation had been correct and the course true, they would sight Tabor\r\n'b'Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neither Gideon Spilett, Herbert, nor Pencroft slept that night. In the\r\n'b'expectation of the next day they could not but feel some emotion.\r\n'b'There was so much uncertainty in their enterprise! Were they near Tabor\r\n'b'Island? Was the island still inhabited by the castaway to whose succor\r\n'b'they had come? Who was this man? Would not his presence disturb the\r\n'b'little colony till then so united? Besides, would he be content to\r\n'b'exchange his prison for another? All these questions, which would no\r\n'b'doubt be answered the next day, kept them in suspense, and at the dawn\r\n'b'of day they all fixed their gaze on the western horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLand!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Pencroft at about six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And it was impossible that Pencroft should be mistaken, it was\r\n'b'evident that land was there. Imagine the joy of the little crew of\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d In a few hours they would land on the beach of the\r\n'b'island!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The low coast of Tabor Island, scarcely emerging from the sea, was not\r\n'b'more than fifteen miles distant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The head of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d which was a little to the south of the\r\n'b'island, was set directly towards it, and as the sun mounted in the east,\r\n'b'its rays fell upon one or two headlands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a much less important isle than Lincoln Island,\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\n'b'Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand is probably due like ours to some submarine convulsion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was not more than two miles off,\r\n'b'and Pencroft, while looking for a suitable place at which to land,\r\n'b'proceeded very cautiously through the unknown waters. The whole of the\r\n'b'island could now be surveyed, and on it could be seen groups of gum\r\n'b'and other large trees, of the same species as those growing on Lincoln\r\n'b'Island. But the astonishing thing was that no smoke arose to show that\r\n'b'the island was inhabited, no signal whatever appeared on the shore!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And yet the document was clear enough; there was a castaway, and this\r\n'b'castaway should have been on the watch.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d entered the winding channels among\r\n'b'the reefs, and Pencroft observed every turn with extreme care. He had\r\n'b'put Herbert at the helm, posting himself in the bows, inspecting the\r\n'b'water, while he held the halliard in his hand, ready to lower the sail\r\n'b'at a moment\xe2\x80\x99s notice. Gideon Spilett with his glass eagerly scanned the\r\n'b'shore, though without perceiving anything.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, at about twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock the keel of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d grated\r\n'b'on the bottom. The anchor was let go, the sails furled, and the crew of\r\n'b'the little vessel landed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And there was no reason to doubt that this was Tabor Island, since\r\n'b'according to the most recent charts there was no island in this part of\r\n'b'the Pacific between New Zealand and the American Coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The vessel was securely moored, so that there should be no danger of\r\n'b'her being carried away by the receding tide; then Pencroft and his\r\n'b'companions, well armed, ascended the shore, so as to gain an elevation\r\n'b'of about two hundred and fifty or three hundred feet which rose at a\r\n'b'distance of half a mile.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the summit of that hill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can no doubt obtain a\r\n'b'complete view of the island, which will greatly facilitate our search.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo as to do here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat which Captain Harding did the\r\n'b'very first thing on Lincoln Island, by climbing Mount Franklin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand it is the best plan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While thus talking the explorers had advanced along a clearing\r\n'b'which terminated at the foot of the hill. Flocks of rock-pigeons and\r\n'b'sea-swallows, similar to those of Lincoln Island, fluttered around them.\r\n'b'Under the woods which skirted the glade on the left they could hear the\r\n'b'bushes rustling and see the grass waving, which indicated the presence\r\n'b'of timid animals, but still nothing to show that the island was\r\n'b'inhabited.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at the foot of the hill, Pencroft, Spilett, and Herbert climbed\r\n'b'it in a few minutes, and gazed anxiously round the horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were on an islet, which did not measure more than six miles in\r\n'b'circumference, its shape not much bordered by capes or promontories,\r\n'b'bays or creeks, being a lengthened oval. All around, the lonely sea\r\n'b'extended to the limits of the horizon. No land nor even a sail was in\r\n'b'sight.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This woody islet did not offer the varied aspects of Lincoln Island,\r\n'b'arid and wild in one part, but fertile and rich in the other. On the\r\n'b'contrary this was a uniform mass of verdure, out of which rose two or\r\n'b'three hills of no great height. Obliquely to the oval of the island ran\r\n'b'a stream through a wide meadow falling into the sea on the west by a\r\n'b'narrow mouth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe domain is limited,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Pencroft: \xe2\x80\x9cIt would have been too small for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd moreover,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears to be uninhabited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cnothing here betrays the presence of man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go down,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand search.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor and his two companions returned to the shore, to the place\r\n'b'where they had left the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had decided to make the tour of the island on foot, before\r\n'b'exploring the interior; so that not a spot should escape their\r\n'b'investigations. The beach was easy to follow, and only in some places\r\n'b'was their way barred by large rocks, which, however, they easily passed\r\n'b'round. The explorers proceeded towards the south, disturbing numerous\r\n'b'flocks of sea-birds and herds of seals, which threw themselves into the\r\n'b'sea as soon as they saw the strangers at a distance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThose beasts yonder,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not see men for the\r\n'b'first time. They fear them, therefore they must know them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An hour after their departure they arrived on the southern point of the\r\n'b'islet, terminated by a sharp cape, and proceeded towards the north along\r\n'b'the western coast, equally formed by sand and rocks, the background\r\n'b'bordered with thick woods.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was not a trace of a habitation in any part, not the print of a\r\n'b'human foot on the shore of the island, which after four hours\xe2\x80\x99 walking\r\n'b'had been gone completely round.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was to say the least very extraordinary, and they were compelled to\r\n'b'believe that Tabor Island was not or was no longer inhabited. Perhaps,\r\n'b'after all the document was already several months or several years old,\r\n'b'and it was possible in this case, either that the castaway had been\r\n'b'enabled to return to his country, or that he had died of misery.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, Spilett, and Herbert, forming more or less probable\r\n'b'conjectures, dined rapidly on board the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d so as to be\r\n'b'able to continue their excursion until nightfall. This was done at five\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, at which hour they entered the wood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Numerous animals fled at their approach, being principally, one might\r\n'b'say, only goats and pigs, which were obviously European species.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Doubtless some whaler had landed them on the island, where they had\r\n'b'rapidly increased. Herbert resolved to catch one or two living, and take\r\n'b'them back to Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was no longer doubtful that men at some period or other had visited\r\n'b'this islet, and this became still more evident when paths appeared\r\n'b'trodden through the forest, felled trees, and everywhere traces of the\r\n'b'hand of man; but the trees were becoming rotten, and had been felled\r\n'b'many years ago; the marks of the axe were velveted with moss, and the\r\n'b'grass grew long and thick on the paths, so that it was difficult to find\r\n'b'them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthis not only proves that men have\r\n'b'landed on the island, but also that they lived on it for some time. Now,\r\n'b'who were these men? How many of them remain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe document,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9conly spoke of one castaway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if he is still on the island,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cit is\r\n'b'impossible but that we shall find him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The exploration was continued. The sailor and his companions naturally\r\n'b'followed the route which cut diagonally across the island, and they were\r\n'b'thus obliged to follow the stream which flowed towards the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'If the animals of European origin, if works due to a human hand, showed\r\n'b'incontestably that men had already visited the island, several specimens\r\n'b'of the vegetable kingdom did not prove it less. In some places, in the\r\n'b'midst of clearings, it was evident that the soil had been planted with\r\n'b'culinary plants, at probably the same distant period.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What, then, was Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s joy, when he recognized potatoes, chicory,\r\n'b'sorrel, carrots, cabbages, and turnips, of which it was sufficient to\r\n'b'collect the seed to enrich the soil of Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCapital, jolly!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cThat will suit Neb as well as us.\r\n'b'Even if we do not find the castaway, at least our voyage will not have\r\n'b'been useless, and God will have rewarded us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut to see the state in which we\r\n'b'find these plantations, it is to be feared that the island has not been\r\n'b'inhabited for some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9can inhabitant, whoever he was, could not\r\n'b'have neglected such an important culture!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthe castaway has gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must suppose so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt must then be admitted that the document has already a distant date?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEvidently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that the bottle only arrived at Lincoln Island after having floated\r\n'b'in the sea a long time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cBut night is coming on,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\n'b'think that it will be best to give up the search for the present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go on board, and to-morrow we will begin again,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\n'b'reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was the wisest course, and it was about to be followed when\r\n'b'Herbert, pointing to a confused mass among the trees, exclaimed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA hut!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All three immediately ran towards the dwelling. In the twilight it was\r\n'b'just possible to see that it was built of planks and covered with a\r\n'b'thick tarpaulin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The half-closed door was pushed open by Pencroft, who entered with a\r\n'b'rapid step.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The hut was empty!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 14\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett remained silent in the midst of\r\n'b'the darkness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft shouted loudly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No reply was made.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor then struck a light and set fire to a twig. This lighted for\r\n'b'a minute a small room, which appeared perfectly empty. At the back was\r\n'b'a rude fireplace, with a few cold cinders, supporting an armful of dry\r\n'b'wood. Pencroft threw the blazing twig on it, the wood crackled and gave\r\n'b'forth a bright light.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor and his two companions then perceived a disordered bed, of\r\n'b'which the damp and yellow coverlets proved that it had not been used for\r\n'b'a long time. In the corner of the fireplace were two kettles, covered\r\n'b'with rust, and an overthrown pot. A cupboard, with a few moldy sailor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'clothes; on the table a tin plate and a Bible, eaten away by damp; in a\r\n'b'corner a few tools, a spade, pickaxe, two fowling-pieces, one of which\r\n'b'was broken; on a plank, forming a shelf, stood a barrel of powder, still\r\n'b'untouched, a barrel of shot, and several boxes of caps, all thickly\r\n'b'covered with dust, accumulated, perhaps, by many long years.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no one here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo one,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a long time since this room has been inhabited,\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\n'b'Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a very long time!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d then said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cinstead of returning on board, I\r\n'b'think that it would be well to pass the night in this hut.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand if its owner\r\n'b'returns, well! perhaps he will not be sorry to find the place taken\r\n'b'possession of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe will not return,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, shaking his head.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou think that he has quitted the island?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf he had quitted the island he would have taken away his weapons and\r\n'b'his tools,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know the value which castaways set\r\n'b'on such articles as these the last remains of a wreck. No! no!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated\r\n'b'the sailor, in a tone of conviction; \xe2\x80\x9cno, he has not left the island! If\r\n'b'he had escaped in a boat made by himself, he would still less have left\r\n'b'these indispensable and necessary articles. No! he is on the island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiving?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiving or dead. But if he is dead, I suppose he has not buried himself,\r\n'b'and so we shall at least find his remains!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was then agreed that the night should be passed in the deserted\r\n'b'dwelling, and a store of wood found in a corner was sufficient to warm\r\n'b'it. The door closed, Pencroft, Herbert and Spilett remained there,\r\n'b'seated on a bench, talking little but wondering much. They were in a\r\n'b'frame of mind to imagine anything or expect anything. They listened\r\n'b'eagerly for sounds outside. The door might have opened suddenly, and\r\n'b'a man presented himself to them without their being in the least\r\n'b'surprised, notwithstanding all that the hut revealed of abandonment,\r\n'b'and they had their hands ready to press the hands of this man, this\r\n'b'castaway, this unknown friend, for whom friends were waiting.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But no voice was heard, the door did not open. The hours thus passed\r\n'b'away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'How long the night appeared to the sailor and his companions! Herbert\r\n'b'alone slept for two hours, for at his age sleep is a necessity. They\r\n'b'were all three anxious to continue their exploration of the day before,\r\n'b'and to search the most secret recesses of the islet! The inferences\r\n'b'deduced by Pencroft were perfectly reasonable, and it was nearly certain\r\n'b'that, as the hut was deserted, and the tools, utensils, and weapons were\r\n'b'still there, the owner had succumbed. It was agreed, therefore, that\r\n'b'they should search for his remains, and give them at least Christian\r\n'b'burial.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Day dawned; Pencroft and his companions immediately proceeded to survey\r\n'b'the dwelling. It had certainly been built in a favorable situation,\r\n'b'at the back of a little hill, sheltered by five or six magnificent\r\n'b'gum-trees. Before its front and through the trees the axe had prepared\r\n'b'a wide clearing, which allowed the view to extend to the sea. Beyond a\r\n'b'lawn, surrounded by a wooden fence falling to pieces, was the shore, on\r\n'b'the left of which was the mouth of the stream.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The hut had been built of planks, and it was easy to see that these\r\n'b'planks had been obtained from the hull or deck of a ship. It was\r\n'b'probable that a disabled vessel had been cast on the coast of the\r\n'b'island, that one at least of the crew had been saved, and that by means\r\n'b'of the wreck this man, having tools at his disposal, had built the\r\n'b'dwelling.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And this became still more evident when Gideon Spilett, after having\r\n'b'walked around the hut, saw on a plank, probably one of those which\r\n'b'had formed the armor of the wrecked vessel, these letters already half\r\n'b'effaced:\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'              BR--TAN--A\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBritannia,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, whom the reporter had called; \xe2\x80\x9cit is\r\n'b'a common name for ships, and I could not say if she was English or\r\n'b'American!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt matters very little, Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery little indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand we will save the\r\n'b'survivor of her crew if he is still living, to whatever country he may\r\n'b'belong. But before beginning our search again let us go on board the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A sort of uneasiness had seized Pencroft upon the subject of his vessel.\r\n'b'Should the island be inhabited after all, and should some one have taken\r\n'b'possession of her? But he shrugged his shoulders at such an unreasonable\r\n'b'supposition. At any rate the sailor was not sorry to go to breakfast on\r\n'b'board. The road already trodden was not long, scarcely a mile. They set\r\n'b'out on their walk, gazing into the wood and thickets through which goats\r\n'b'and pigs fled in hundreds.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Twenty minutes after leaving the hut Pencroft and his companions reached\r\n'b'the western coast of the island, and saw the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d held fast by\r\n'b'her anchor, which was buried deep in the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft could not restrain a sigh of satisfaction. After all this\r\n'b'vessel was his child, and it is the right of fathers to be often uneasy\r\n'b'when there is no occasion for it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They returned on board, breakfasted, so that it should not be necessary\r\n'b'to dine until very late; then the repast being ended, the exploration\r\n'b'was continued and conducted with the most minute care. Indeed, it was\r\n'b'very probable that the only inhabitant of the island had perished. It\r\n'b'was therefore more for the traces of a dead than of a living man that\r\n'b'Pencroft and his companions searched. But their searches were vain, and\r\n'b'during the half of that day they sought to no purpose among the thickets\r\n'b'of trees which covered the islet. There was then scarcely any doubt\r\n'b'that, if the castaway was dead, no trace of his body now remained, but\r\n'b'that some wild beast had probably devoured it to the last bone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will set off to-morrow at daybreak,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft to his two\r\n'b'companions, as about two o\xe2\x80\x99clock they were resting for a few minutes\r\n'b'under the shade of a clump of firs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI should think that we might without scruple take the utensils which\r\n'b'belonged to the castaway,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think so, too,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand these arms and tools\r\n'b'will make up the stores of Granite House. The supply of powder and shot\r\n'b'is also most important.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we must not forget to capture a couple or\r\n'b'two of those pigs, of which Lincoln Island is destitute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNor to gather those seeds,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich will give us all the\r\n'b'vegetables of the Old and the New Worlds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen perhaps it would be best,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cto remain a day\r\n'b'longer on Tabor Island, so as to collect all that may be useful to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI will ask you to set off\r\n'b'to-morrow at daybreak. The wind seems to me to be likely to shift to the\r\n'b'west, and after having had a fair wind for coming we shall have a fair\r\n'b'wind for going back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen do not let us lose time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, rising.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t waste time,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cYou, Herbert, go and gather\r\n'b'the seeds, which you know better than we do. While you do that, Mr.\r\n'b'Spilett and I will go and have a pig hunt, and even without Top I hope\r\n'b'we shall manage to catch a few!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert accordingly took the path which led towards the cultivated part\r\n'b'of the islet, while the sailor and the reporter entered the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Many specimens of the porcine race fled before them, and these animals,\r\n'b'which were singularly active, did not appear to be in a humor to allow\r\n'b'themselves to be approached.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, after an hour\xe2\x80\x99s chase, the hunters had just managed to get hold\r\n'b'of a couple lying in a thicket, when cries were heard resounding from\r\n'b'the north part of the island, With the cries were mingled terrible\r\n'b'yells, in which there was nothing human.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Gideon Spilett were at once on their feet, and the pigs\r\n'b'by this movement began to run away, at the moment when the sailor was\r\n'b'getting ready the rope to bind them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s voice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRun!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor and Spilett immediately ran at full speed towards the\r\n'b'spot from whence the cries proceeded.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They did well to hasten, for at a turn of the path near a clearing they\r\n'b'saw the lad thrown on the ground and in the grasp of a savage being,\r\n'b'apparently a gigantic ape, who was about to do him some great harm.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To rush on this monster, throw him on the ground in his turn, snatch\r\n'b'Herbert from him, then bind him securely, was the work of a minute for\r\n'b'Pencroft and Gideon Spilett. The sailor was of Herculean strength, the\r\n'b'reporter also very powerful, and in spite of the monster\xe2\x80\x99s resistance he\r\n'b'was firmly tied so that he could not even move.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not hurt, Herbert?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if this ape had wounded him!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut he is not an ape,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At these words Pencroft and Gideon Spilett looked at the singular being\r\n'b'who lay on the ground. Indeed it was not an ape; it was a human being,\r\n'b'a man. But what a man! A savage in all the horrible acceptation of the\r\n'b'word, and so much the more frightful that he seemed fallen to the lowest\r\n'b'degree of brutishness!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Shaggy hair, untrimmed beard descending to the chest, the body almost\r\n'b'naked except a rag round the waist, wild eyes, enormous hands with\r\n'b'immensely long nails, skin the color of mahogany, feet as hard as if\r\n'b'made of horn, such was the miserable creature who yet had a claim to be\r\n'b'called a man. But it might justly be asked if there were yet a soul in\r\n'b'this body, or if the brute instinct alone survived in it!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite sure that this is a man, or that he has ever been one?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' said Pencroft to the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! there is no doubt about it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen this must be the castaway?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the unfortunate man has no longer\r\n'b'anything human about him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter spoke the truth. It was evident that if the castaway had\r\n'b'ever been a civilized being, solitude had made him a savage, or worse,\r\n'b'perhaps a regular man of the woods. Hoarse sounds issued from his throat\r\n'b'between his teeth, which were sharp as the teeth of a wild beast made to\r\n'b'tear raw flesh.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Memory must have deserted him long before, and for a long time also he\r\n'b'had forgotten how to use his gun and tools, and he no longer knew how to\r\n'b'make a fire! It could be seen that he was active and powerful, but the\r\n'b'physical qualities had been developed in him to the injury of the moral\r\n'b'qualities. Gideon Spilett spoke to him. He did not appear to understand\r\n'b'or even to hear. And yet on looking into his eyes, the reporter thought\r\n'b'he could see that all reason was not extinguished in him. However, the\r\n'b'prisoner did not struggle, nor even attempt to break his bonds. Was he\r\n'b'overwhelmed by the presence of men whose fellow he had once been? Had he\r\n'b'found in some corner of his brain a fleeting remembrance which recalled\r\n'b'him to humanity? If free, would he attempt to fly, or would he remain?\r\n'b'They could not tell, but they did not make the experiment; and after\r\n'b'gazing attentively at the miserable creature,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhoever he may be,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwhoever he may have\r\n'b'been, and whatever he may become, it is our duty to take him with us to\r\n'b'Lincoln Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand perhaps with care we may arouse in him\r\n'b'some gleam of intelligence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe soul does not die,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand it would be a great\r\n'b'satisfaction to rescue one of God\xe2\x80\x99s creatures from brutishness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft shook his head doubtfully.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must try at any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9chumanity commands\r\n'b'us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was indeed their duty as Christians and civilized beings. All three\r\n'b'felt this, and they well knew that Cyrus Harding would approve of their\r\n'b'acting thus.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShall we leave him bound?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he would walk if his feet were unfastened,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us try,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cords which shackled the prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s feet were cut off, but his arms\r\n'b'remained securely fastened. He got up by himself and did not manifest\r\n'b'any desire to run away. His hard eyes darted a piercing glance at the\r\n'b'three men, who walked near him, but nothing denoted that he recollected\r\n'b'being their fellow, or at least having been so. A continual hissing\r\n'b'sound issued from his lips, his aspect was wild, but he did not attempt\r\n'b'to resist.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'By the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s advice the unfortunate man was taken to the hut.\r\n'b'Perhaps the sight of the things that belonged to him would make some\r\n'b'impression on him! Perhaps a spark would be sufficient to revive his\r\n'b'obscured intellect, to rekindle his dulled soul. The dwelling was\r\n'b'not far off. In a few minutes they arrived there, but the prisoner\r\n'b'remembered nothing, and it appeared that he had lost consciousness of\r\n'b'everything.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What could they think of the degree of brutishness into which this\r\n'b'miserable being had fallen, unless that his imprisonment on the islet\r\n'b'dated from a very distant period and after having arrived there a\r\n'b'rational being solitude had reduced him to this condition.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter then thought that perhaps the sight of fire would have\r\n'b'some effect on him, and in a moment one of those beautiful flames, that\r\n'b'attract even animals, blazed up on the hearth. The sight of the flame\r\n'b'seemed at first to fix the attention of the unhappy object, but soon\r\n'b'he turned away and the look of intelligence faded. Evidently there was\r\n'b'nothing to be done, for the time at least, but to take him on board\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d This was done, and he remained there in Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'charge.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and Spilett returned to finish their work; and some hours after\r\n'b'they came back to the shore, carrying the utensils and guns, a store of\r\n'b'vegetables, of seeds, some game, and two couple of pigs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All was embarked, and the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was ready to weigh anchor and\r\n'b'sail with the morning tide.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The prisoner had been placed in the fore-cabin, where he remained quiet,\r\n'b'silent, apparently deaf and dumb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft offered him something to eat, but he pushed away the cooked\r\n'b'meat that was presented to him and which doubtless did not suit him. But\r\n'b'on the sailor showing him one of the ducks which Herbert had killed, he\r\n'b'pounced on it like a wild beast, and devoured it greedily.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou think that he will recover his senses?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\n'b'not impossible that our care will have an effect upon him, for it is\r\n'b'solitude that has made him what he is, and from this time forward he\r\n'b'will be no longer alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe poor man must no doubt have been in this state for a long time,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout what age is he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the lad.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is difficult to say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is impossible to\r\n'b'see his features under the thick beard which covers his face, but he is\r\n'b'no longer young, and I suppose he might be about fifty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave you noticed, Mr. Spilett, how deeply sunk his eyes are?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\n'b'Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Herbert, but I must add that they are more human than one could\r\n'b'expect from his appearance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever, we shall see,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand I am anxious to know\r\n'b'what opinion Captain Harding will have of our savage. We went to look\r\n'b'for a human creature, and we are bringing back a monster! After all, we\r\n'b'did what we could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night passed, and whether the prisoner slept or not could not be\r\n'b'known, but at any rate, although he had been unbound, he did not\r\n'b'move. He was like a wild animal, which appears stunned at first by its\r\n'b'capture, and becomes wild again afterwards.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At daybreak the next morning, the 15th of October, the change of weather\r\n'b'predicted by Pencroft occurred. The wind having shifted to the northwest\r\n'b'favored the return of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d but at the same time it\r\n'b'freshened, which might render navigation more difficult.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning the anchor was weighed. Pencroft took a\r\n'b'reef in the mainsail, and steered towards the north-east, so as to sail\r\n'b'straight for Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first day of the voyage was not marked by any incident. The prisoner\r\n'b'remained quiet in the fore-cabin, and as he had been a sailor it\r\n'b'appeared that the motion of the vessel might produce on him a salutary\r\n'b'reaction. Did some recollection of his former calling return to him?\r\n'b'However that might be, he remained tranquil, astonished rather than\r\n'b'depressed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day the wind increased, blowing more from the north,\r\n'b'consequently in a less favorable direction for the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' Pencroft was soon obliged to sail close-hauled, and without saying\r\n'b'anything about it he began to be uneasy at the state of the sea, which\r\n'b'frequently broke over the bows. Certainly, if the wind did not moderate,\r\n'b'it would take a longer time to reach Lincoln Island than it had taken to\r\n'b'make Tabor Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Indeed, on the morning of the 17th, the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d had been\r\n'b'forty-eight hours at sea, and nothing showed that she was near the\r\n'b'island. It was impossible, besides, to estimate the distance traversed,\r\n'b'or to trust to the reckoning for the direction, as the speed had been\r\n'b'very irregular.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Twenty-four hours after there was yet no land in sight. The wind was\r\n'b'right ahead and the sea very heavy. The sails were close-reefed, and\r\n'b'they tacked frequently. On the 18th, a wave swept completely over the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d; and if the crew had not taken the precaution of lashing\r\n'b'themselves to the deck, they would have been carried away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this occasion Pencroft and his companions, who were occupied with\r\n'b'loosing themselves, received unexpected aid from the prisoner, who\r\n'b'emerged from the hatchway as if his sailor\xe2\x80\x99s instinct had suddenly\r\n'b'returned, broke a piece out of the bulwarks with a spar so as to let\r\n'b'the water which filled the deck escape. Then the vessel being clear, he\r\n'b'descended to his cabin without having uttered a word. Pencroft, Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, and Herbert, greatly astonished, let him proceed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their situation was truly serious, and the sailor had reason to fear\r\n'b'that he was lost on the wide sea without any possibility of recovering\r\n'b'his course.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night was dark and cold. However, about eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the wind\r\n'b'fell, the sea went down, and the speed of the vessel, as she labored\r\n'b'less, greatly increased.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neither Pencroft, Spilett, nor Herbert thought of taking an hour\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'sleep. They kept a sharp look-out, for either Lincoln Island could not\r\n'b'be far distant and would be sighted at daybreak, or the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' carried away by currents, had drifted so much that it would be\r\n'b'impossible to rectify her course. Pencroft, uneasy to the last degree,\r\n'b'yet did not despair, for he had a gallant heart, and grasping the tiller\r\n'b'he anxiously endeavored to pierce the darkness which surrounded them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning he started forward,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA light! a light!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Indeed, a bright light appeared twenty miles to the northeast. Lincoln\r\n'b'Island was there, and this fire, evidently lighted by Cyrus Harding,\r\n'b'showed them the course to be followed. Pencroft, who was bearing too\r\n'b'much to the north, altered his course and steered towards the fire,\r\n'b'which burned brightly above the horizon like a star of the first\r\n'b'magnitude.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 15\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 20th of October, at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning,\r\n'b'after a voyage of four days, the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d gently glided up to the\r\n'b'beach at the mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Neb, who had become very uneasy at the bad weather and\r\n'b'the prolonged absence of their companions, had climbed at daybreak to\r\n'b'the plateau of Prospect Heights, and they had at last caught sight of\r\n'b'the vessel which had been so long in returning.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGod be praised! there they are!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Neb in his joy, he began to dance, to twirl round, clapping his\r\n'b'hands and shouting, \xe2\x80\x9cOh! my master!\xe2\x80\x9d A more touching pantomime than the\r\n'b'finest discourse.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s first idea, on counting the people on the deck of the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d was that Pencroft had not found the castaway of Tabor\r\n'b'Island, or at any rate that the unfortunate man had refused to leave his\r\n'b'island and change one prison for another.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Indeed Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert were alone on the deck of\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The moment the vessel touched, the engineer and Neb were waiting on\r\n'b'the beach, and before the passengers had time to leap on to the sand,\r\n'b'Harding said: \xe2\x80\x9cWe have been very uneasy at your delay, my friends! Did\r\n'b'you meet with any accident?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett; \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary, everything went\r\n'b'wonderfully well. We will tell you all about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cyour search has been unsuccessful,\r\n'b'since you are only three, just as you went!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are four.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou have found the castaway?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have brought him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiving?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he? Who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cor rather he was a man! There, Cyrus,\r\n'b'that is all we can tell you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer was then informed of all that had passed during the voyage,\r\n'b'and under what conditions the search had been conducted; how the only\r\n'b'dwelling in the island had long been abandoned; how at last a castaway\r\n'b'had been captured, who appeared no longer to belong to the human\r\n'b'species.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that\xe2\x80\x99s just the point,\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know if we have\r\n'b'done right to bring him here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly you have, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut the wretched creature has no sense!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is possible at present,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cbut only a few\r\n'b'months ago the wretched creature was a man like you and me. And who\r\n'b'knows what will become of the survivor of us after a long solitude on\r\n'b'this island? It is a great misfortune to be alone, my friends; and it\r\n'b'must be believed that solitude can quickly destroy reason, since you\r\n'b'have found this poor creature in such a state!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat leads you to think that the\r\n'b'brutishness of the unfortunate man began only a few months back?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the document we found had been recently written,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\n'b'engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand the castaway alone can have written it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAlways supposing,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it had not been\r\n'b'written by a companion of this man, since dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is impossible, my dear Spilett.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the document would then have spoken of two castaways,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\n'b'Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand it mentioned only one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert then in a few words related the incidents of the voyage, and\r\n'b'dwelt on the curious fact of the sort of passing gleam in the prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'mind, when for an instant in the height of the storm he had become a\r\n'b'sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Herbert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are right to attach great\r\n'b'importance to this fact. The unfortunate man cannot be incurable, and\r\n'b'despair has made him what he is; but here he will find his fellow-men,\r\n'b'and since there is still a soul in him, this soul we shall save!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The castaway of Tabor Island, to the great pity of the engineer and\r\n'b'the great astonishment of Neb, was then brought from the cabin which he\r\n'b'occupied in the fore part of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d; when once on land he\r\n'b'manifested a wish to run away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Cyrus Harding approaching, placed his hand on his shoulder with a\r\n'b'gesture full of authority, and looked at him with infinite tenderness.\r\n'b'Immediately the unhappy man, submitting to a superior will, gradually\r\n'b'became calm, his eyes fell, his head bent, and he made no more\r\n'b'resistance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPoor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had attentively observed him. To judge by his appearance\r\n'b'this miserable being had no longer anything human about him, and\r\n'b'yet Harding, as had the reporter already, observed in his look an\r\n'b'indefinable trace of intelligence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was decided that the castaway, or rather the stranger as he was\r\n'b'thenceforth termed by his companions, should live in one of the rooms\r\n'b'of Granite House, from which, however, he could not escape. He was led\r\n'b'there without difficulty, and with careful attention, it might, perhaps,\r\n'b'be hoped that some day he would be a companion to the settlers in\r\n'b'Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, during breakfast, which Neb had hastened to prepare,\r\n'b'as the reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft were dying of hunger, heard in\r\n'b'detail all the incidents which had marked the voyage of exploration to\r\n'b'the islet. He agreed with his friends on this point, that the stranger\r\n'b'must be either English or American, the name Britannia leading them\r\n'b'to suppose this, and, besides, through the bushy beard, and under\r\n'b'the shaggy, matted hair, the engineer thought he could recognize the\r\n'b'characteristic features of the Anglo-Saxon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, by the bye,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, addressing Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cyou never\r\n'b'told us how you met this savage, and we know nothing, except that you\r\n'b'would have been strangled, if we had not happened to come up in time to\r\n'b'help you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is rather difficult to say how it\r\n'b'happened. I was, I think, occupied in collecting my plants, when I heard\r\n'b'a noise like an avalanche falling from a very tall tree. I scarcely\r\n'b'had time to look round. This unfortunate man, who was without doubt\r\n'b'concealed in a tree, rushed upon me in less time than I take to tell you\r\n'b'about it, and unless Mr. Spilett and Pencroft--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy boy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cyou ran a great danger, but, perhaps,\r\n'b'without that, the poor creature would have still hidden himself from\r\n'b'your search, and we should not have had a new companion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou hope, then, Cyrus, to succeed in reforming the man?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the\r\n'b'reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Breakfast over, Harding and his companions left Granite House and\r\n'b'returned to the beach. They there occupied themselves in unloading the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d and the engineer, having examined the arms and tools,\r\n'b'saw nothing which could help them to establish the identity of the\r\n'b'stranger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The capture of pigs, made on the islet, was looked upon as being very\r\n'b'profitable to Lincoln Island, and the animals were led to the sty, where\r\n'b'they soon became at home.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The two barrels, containing the powder and shot, as well as the box\r\n'b'of caps, were very welcome. It was agreed to establish a small\r\n'b'powder-magazine, either outside Granite House or in the Upper Cavern,\r\n'b'where there would be no fear of explosion. However, the use of pyroxyle\r\n'b'was to be continued, for this substance giving excellent results, there\r\n'b'was no reason for substituting ordinary powder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When the unloading of the vessel was finished,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI think it would be prudent to put our\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 in a safe place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs she not safe at the mouth of the Mercy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cHalf of the time she is stranded on\r\n'b'the sand, and that works her. She is a famous craft, you see, and she\r\n'b'behaved admirably during the squall which struck us on our return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCould she not float in the river?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt, captain, she could; but there is no shelter there, and in the\r\n'b'east winds, I think that the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 would suffer much from the\r\n'b'surf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, where would you put her, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn Port Balloon,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cThat little creek, shut in by\r\n'b'rocks, seems to me to be just the harbor we want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs it not rather far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPooh! it is not more than three miles from Granite House, and we have a\r\n'b'fine straight road to take us there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo it then, Pencroft, and take your \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 there,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\n'b'the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand yet I would rather have her under our more immediate\r\n'b'protection. When we have time, we must make a little harbor for her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFamous!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cA harbor with a lighthouse, a pier, and\r\n'b'dock! Ah! really with you, captain, everything becomes easy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my brave Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut on condition,\r\n'b'however, that you help me, for you do as much as three men in all our\r\n'b'work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and the sailor then re-embarked on board the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' the anchor was weighed, the sail hoisted, and the wind drove her rapidly\r\n'b'towards Claw Cape. Two hours after, she was reposing on the tranquil\r\n'b'waters of Port Balloon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the first days passed by the stranger in Granite House, had he\r\n'b'already given them reason to think that his savage nature was becoming\r\n'b'tamed? Did a brighter light burn in the depths of that obscured mind? In\r\n'b'short, was the soul returning to the body?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Yes, to a certainty, and to such a degree, that Cyrus Harding and the\r\n'b'reporter wondered if the reason of the unfortunate man had ever been\r\n'b'totally extinguished. At first, accustomed to the open air, to the\r\n'b'unrestrained liberty which he had enjoyed on Tabor Island, the stranger\r\n'b'manifested a sullen fury, and it was feared that he might throw\r\n'b'himself onto the beach, out of one of the windows of Granite House.\r\n'b'But gradually he became calmer, and more freedom was allowed to his\r\n'b'movements.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had reason to hope, and to hope much. Already, forgetting his\r\n'b'carnivorous instincts, the stranger accepted a less bestial nourishment\r\n'b'than that on which he fed on the islet, and cooked meat did not produce\r\n'b'in him the same sentiment of repulsion which he had showed on board\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d Cyrus Harding had profited by a moment when he was\r\n'b'sleeping, to cut his hair and matted beard, which formed a sort of\r\n'b'mane and gave him such a savage aspect. He had also been clothed more\r\n'b'suitably, after having got rid of the rag which covered him. The result\r\n'b'was that, thanks to these attentions, the stranger resumed a more\r\n'b'human appearance, and it even seemed as if his eyes had become milder.\r\n'b'Certainly, when formerly lighted up by intelligence, this man\xe2\x80\x99s face\r\n'b'must have had a sort of beauty.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Every day, Harding imposed on himself the task of passing some hours\r\n'b'in his company. He came and worked near him, and occupied himself in\r\n'b'different things, so as to fix his attention. A spark, indeed, would be\r\n'b'sufficient to reillumine that soul, a recollection crossing that brain\r\n'b'to recall reason. That had been seen, during the storm, on board the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure!\xe2\x80\x9d The engineer did not neglect either to speak aloud, so\r\n'b'as to penetrate at the same time by the organs of hearing and sight the\r\n'b'depths of that torpid intelligence. Sometimes one of his companions,\r\n'b'sometimes another, sometimes all joined him. They spoke most often of\r\n'b'things belonging to the navy, which must interest a sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At times, the stranger gave some slight attention to what was said,\r\n'b'and the settlers were soon convinced that he partly understood them.\r\n'b'Sometimes the expression of his countenance was deeply sorrowful, a\r\n'b'proof that he suffered mentally, for his face could not be mistaken;\r\n'b'but he did not speak, although at different times, however, they almost\r\n'b'thought that words were about to issue from his lips. At all events, the\r\n'b'poor creature was quite quiet and sad!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But was not his calm only apparent? Was not his sadness only the result\r\n'b'of his seclusion? Nothing could yet be ascertained. Seeing only certain\r\n'b'objects and in a limited space, always in contact with the colonists,\r\n'b'to whom he would soon become accustomed, having no desires to satisfy,\r\n'b'better fed, better clothed, it was natural that his physical nature\r\n'b'should gradually improve; but was he penetrated with the sense of a new\r\n'b'life? or rather, to employ a word which would be exactly applicable\r\n'b'to him, was he not becoming tamed, like an animal in company with his\r\n'b'master? This was an important question, which Cyrus Harding was anxious\r\n'b'to answer, and yet he did not wish to treat his invalid roughly! Would\r\n'b'he ever be a convalescent?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'How the engineer observed him every moment! How he was on the watch for\r\n'b'his soul, if one may use the expression! How he was ready to grasp it!\r\n'b'The settlers followed with real sympathy all the phases of the cure\r\n'b'undertaken by Harding. They aided him also in this work of humanity, and\r\n'b'all, except perhaps the incredulous Pencroft, soon shared both his hope\r\n'b'and his faith.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The calm of the stranger was deep, as has been said, and he even showed\r\n'b'a sort of attachment for the engineer, whose influence he evidently\r\n'b'felt. Cyrus Harding resolved then to try him, by transporting him\r\n'b'to another scene, from that ocean which formerly his eyes had been\r\n'b'accustomed to contemplate, to the border of the forest, which might\r\n'b'perhaps recall those where so many years of his life had been passed!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9ccan we hope that he will not escape, if\r\n'b'once set at liberty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe experiment must be tried,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen that fellow is outside, and feels the fresh\r\n'b'air, he will be off as fast as his legs can carry him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think so,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us try,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will try,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was on the 30th of October, and consequently the castaway of Tabor\r\n'b'Island had been a prisoner in Granite House for nine days. It was\r\n'b'warm, and a bright sun darted its rays on the island. Cyrus Harding and\r\n'b'Pencroft went to the room occupied by the stranger, who was found lying\r\n'b'near the window and gazing at the sky.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer to him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger rose immediately. His eyes were fixed on Cyrus Harding, and\r\n'b'he followed him, while the sailor marched behind them, little confident\r\n'b'as to the result of the experiment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at the door, Harding and Pencroft made him take his place in\r\n'b'the lift, while Neb, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett waited for them before\r\n'b'Granite House. The lift descended, and in a few moments all were united\r\n'b'on the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers went a short distance from the stranger, so as to leave him\r\n'b'at liberty.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He then made a few steps toward the sea, and his look brightened with\r\n'b'extreme animation, but he did not make the slightest attempt to escape.\r\n'b'He was gazing at the little waves which, broken by the islet, rippled on\r\n'b'the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is only the sea,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand possibly it does\r\n'b'not inspire him with any wish to escape!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must take him to the plateau, on the border\r\n'b'of the forest. There the experiment will be more conclusive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, he could not run away,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, \xe2\x80\x9csince the bridge is\r\n'b'raised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat isn\xe2\x80\x99t a man to be troubled by a stream like\r\n'b'Creek Glycerine! He could cross it directly, at a single bound!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall soon see,\xe2\x80\x9d Harding contented himself with replying, his eyes\r\n'b'not quitting those of his patient.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The latter was then led towards the mouth of the Mercy, and all climbing\r\n'b'the left bank of the river, reached Prospect Heights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at the spot on which grew the first beautiful trees of the\r\n'b'forest, their foliage slightly agitated by the breeze, the stranger\r\n'b'appeared greedily to drink in the penetrating odor which filled the\r\n'b'atmosphere, and a long sigh escaped from his chest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers kept behind him, ready to seize him if he made any movement\r\n'b'to escape!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, indeed, the poor creature was on the point of springing into the\r\n'b'creek which separated him from the forest, and his legs were bent for an\r\n'b'instant as if for a spring, but almost immediately he stepped back, half\r\n'b'sank down, and a large tear fell from his eyes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have become a man again, for you can\r\n'b'weep!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 16\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Yes! the unfortunate man had wept! Some recollection doubtless had\r\n'b'flashed across his brain, and to use Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s expression, by\r\n'b'those tears he was once more a man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists left him for some time on the plateau, and withdrew\r\n'b'themselves to a short distance, so that he might feel himself free; but\r\n'b'he did not think of profiting by this liberty, and Harding soon brought\r\n'b'him back to Granite House. Two days after this occurrence, the stranger\r\n'b'appeared to wish gradually to mingle with their common life. He\r\n'b'evidently heard and understood, but no less evidently was he strangely\r\n'b'determined not to speak to the colonists; for one evening, Pencroft,\r\n'b'listening at the door of his room, heard these words escape from his\r\n'b'lips:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo! here! I! never!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor reported these words to his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is some painful mystery there!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger had begun to use the laboring tools, and he worked in the\r\n'b'garden. When he stopped in his work, as was often the case, he remained\r\n'b'retired within himself, but on the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s recommendation, they\r\n'b'respected the reserve which he apparently wished to keep. If one of the\r\n'b'settlers approached him, he drew back, and his chest heaved with sobs,\r\n'b'as if overburdened!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Was it remorse that overwhelmed him thus? They were compelled to believe\r\n'b'so, and Gideon Spilett could not help one day making this observation,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf he does not speak it is because he has, I fear, things too serious\r\n'b'to be told!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They must be patient and wait.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few days later, on the 3rd of November, the stranger, working on the\r\n'b'plateau, had stopped, letting his spade drop to the ground, and Harding,\r\n'b'who was observing him from a little distance, saw that tears were again\r\n'b'flowing from his eyes. A sort of irresistible pity led him towards the\r\n'b'unfortunate man, and he touched his arm lightly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger tried to avoid his look, and Cyrus Harding having\r\n'b'endeavored to take his hand, he drew back quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding in a firmer voice, \xe2\x80\x9clook at me, I wish it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger looked at the engineer, and seemed to be under his power,\r\n'b'as a subject under the influence of a mesmerist. He wished to run away.\r\n'b'But then his countenance suddenly underwent a transformation. His eyes\r\n'b'flashed. Words struggled to escape from his lips. He could no longer\r\n'b'contain himself! At last he folded his arms; then, in a hollow\r\n'b'voice,--\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCastaways, like you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, whose emotion was deep. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\n'b'have brought you here, among your fellow-men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy fellow-men!.... I have none!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are in the midst of friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFriends!--for me! friends!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the stranger, hiding his face in\r\n'b'his hands. \xe2\x80\x9cNo--never--leave me! leave me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then he rushed to the side of the plateau which overlooked the sea, and\r\n'b'remained there a long time motionless.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding rejoined his companions and related to them what had just\r\n'b'happened.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! there is some mystery in that man\xe2\x80\x99s life,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cand it appears as if he had only re-entered society by the path of\r\n'b'remorse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what sort of a man we have brought here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe has secrets--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhich we will respect,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Cyrus Harding quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he has\r\n'b'committed any crime, he has most fearfully expiated it, and in our eyes\r\n'b'he is absolved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For two hours the stranger remained alone on the shore, evidently under\r\n'b'the influence of recollections which recalled all his past life--a\r\n'b'melancholy life doubtless--and the colonists, without losing sight of\r\n'b'him, did not attempt to disturb his solitude. However, after two hours,\r\n'b'appearing to have formed a resolution, he came to find Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'His eyes were red with the tears he had shed, but he wept no longer.\r\n'b'His countenance expressed deep humility. He appeared anxious, timorous,\r\n'b'ashamed, and his eyes were constantly fixed on the ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cyour companions and you, are you English?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are Americans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger, and he murmured, \xe2\x80\x9cI prefer that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEnglish,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he hastily.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And as if these few words had been difficult to say, he retreated to the\r\n'b'beach, where he walked up and down between the cascade and the mouth of\r\n'b'the Mercy, in a state of extreme agitation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, passing one moment close to Herbert, he stopped and in a stifled\r\n'b'voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat month?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDecember,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat year?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c1866.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTwelve years! twelve years!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then he left him abruptly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert reported to the colonists the questions and answers which had\r\n'b'been made.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis unfortunate man,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwas no longer\r\n'b'acquainted with either months or years!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand he had been twelve years already on the islet\r\n'b'when we found him there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTwelve years!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cAh! twelve years of solitude, after a\r\n'b'wicked life, perhaps, may well impair a man\xe2\x80\x99s reason!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am induced to think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this man was not wrecked\r\n'b'on Tabor Island, but that in consequence of some crime he was left\r\n'b'there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be right, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand if it is so\r\n'b'it is not impossible that those who left him on the island may return to\r\n'b'fetch him some day!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they will no longer find him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut then,\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthey must return, and--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not let us discuss this question\r\n'b'until we know more about it. I believe that the unhappy man has\r\n'b'suffered, that he has severely expiated his faults, whatever they may\r\n'b'have been, and that the wish to unburden himself stifles him. Do not let\r\n'b'us press him to tell us his history! He will tell it to us doubtless,\r\n'b'and when we know it, we shall see what course it will be best to follow.\r\n'b'He alone besides can tell us, if he has more than a hope, a certainty,\r\n'b'of returning some day to his country, but I doubt it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause that, in the event of his being sure of being delivered at a\r\n'b'certain time, he would have waited the hour of his deliverance and would\r\n'b'not have thrown this document into the sea. No, it is more probable that\r\n'b'he was condemned to die on that islet, and that he never expected to see\r\n'b'his fellow-creatures again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is one thing which I cannot explain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf this man had been left for twelve years on Tabor Island, one may\r\n'b'well suppose that he had been several years already in the wild state in\r\n'b'which we found him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is probable,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt must then be many years since he wrote that document!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d and yet the document appears to have been recently written!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, how do you know that the bottle which enclosed the document\r\n'b'may not have taken several years to come from Tabor Island to Lincoln\r\n'b'Island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not absolutely impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMight it not have been a long time already on the coast of the island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it was still floating. We could not even\r\n'b'suppose that after it had stayed for any length of time on the shore, it\r\n'b'would have been swept off by the sea, for the south coast is all rocks,\r\n'b'and it would certainly have been smashed to pieces there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Cyrus Harding thoughtfully.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cif the document was several years\r\n'b'old, if it had been shut up in that bottle for several years, it would\r\n'b'have been injured by damp. Now, there is nothing of the kind, and it was\r\n'b'found in a perfect state of preservation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor\xe2\x80\x99s reasoning was very just, and pointed out an\r\n'b'incomprehensible fact, for the document appeared to have been recently\r\n'b'written, when the colonists found it in the bottle. Moreover, it gave\r\n'b'the latitude and longitude of Tabor Island correctly, which implied that\r\n'b'its author had a more complete knowledge of hydrography than could be\r\n'b'expected of a common sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is in this, again, something unaccountable,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cbut we will not urge our companion to speak. When he likes, my\r\n'b'friends, then we shall be ready to hear him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the following days the stranger did not speak a word, and did not\r\n'b'once leave the precincts of the plateau. He worked away, without losing\r\n'b'a moment, without taking a minute\xe2\x80\x99s rest, but always in a retired place.\r\n'b'At meal times he never came to Granite House, although invited several\r\n'b'times to do so, but contented himself with eating a few raw vegetables.\r\n'b'At nightfall he did not return to the room assigned to him, but remained\r\n'b'under some clump of trees, or when the weather was bad crouched in some\r\n'b'cleft of the rocks. Thus he lived in the same manner as when he had no\r\n'b'other shelter than the forests of Tabor Island, and as all persuasion\r\n'b'to induce him to improve his life was in vain, the colonists\r\n'b'waited patiently. And the time was near, when, as it seemed, almost\r\n'b'involuntarily urged by his conscience, a terrible confession escaped\r\n'b'him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 10th of November, about eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, as night\r\n'b'was coming on, the stranger appeared unexpectedly before the settlers,\r\n'b'who were assembled under the veranda. His eyes burned strangely, and he\r\n'b'had quite resumed the wild aspect of his worst days.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions were astounded on seeing that, overcome\r\n'b'by some terrible emotion, his teeth chattered like those of a person\r\n'b'in a fever. What was the matter with him? Was the sight of his\r\n'b'fellow-creatures insupportable to him? Was he weary of this return to a\r\n'b'civilized mode of existence? Was he pining for his former savage\r\n'b'life? It appeared so, as soon he was heard to express himself in these\r\n'b'incoherent sentences:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy am I here?.... By what right have you dragged me from my islet?....\r\n'b'Do you think there could be any tie between you and me?.... Do you know\r\n'b'who I am--what I have done--why I was there--alone? And who told\r\n'b'you that I was not abandoned there--that I was not condemned to die\r\n'b'there?.... Do you know my past?....
