How do you know that I have not\r\n'b'stolen, murdered--that I am not a wretch--an accursed being--only fit to\r\n'b'live like a wild beast, far from all--speak--do you know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists listened without interrupting the miserable creature, from\r\n'b'whom these broken confessions escaped, as it were, in spite of himself.\r\n'b'Harding wishing to calm him, approached him, but he hastily drew back.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo! no!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed; \xe2\x80\x9cone word only--am I free?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are free,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, then!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, and fled like a madman.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb, Pencroft, and Herbert ran also towards the edge of the wood--but\r\n'b'they returned alone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must let him alone!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe will never come back!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe will come back,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Many days passed; but Harding--was it a sort of\r\n'b'presentiment?--persisted in the fixed idea that sooner or later the\r\n'b'unhappy man would return.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the last revolt of his wild nature,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich remorse has\r\n'b'touched, and which renewed solitude will terrify.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, works of all sorts were continued, as well on Prospect\r\n'b'Heights as at the corral, where Harding intended to build a farm. It is\r\n'b'unnecessary to say that the seeds collected by Herbert on Tabor\r\n'b'Island had been carefully sown. The plateau thus formed one immense\r\n'b'kitchen-garden, well laid out and carefully tended, so that the arms of\r\n'b'the settlers were never in want of work. There was always something to\r\n'b'be done. As the esculents increased in number, it became necessary to\r\n'b'enlarge the simple beds, which threatened to grow into regular fields\r\n'b'and replace the meadows. But grass abounded in other parts of the\r\n'b'island, and there was no fear of the onagers being obliged to go on\r\n'b'short allowance. It was well worth while, besides, to turn Prospect\r\n'b'Heights into a kitchen-garden, defended by its deep belt of creeks, and\r\n'b'to remove them to the meadows, which had no need of protection against\r\n'b'the depredations of quadrumana and quadrapeds.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 15th of November, the third harvest was gathered in. How\r\n'b'wonderfully had the field increased in extent, since eighteen months\r\n'b'ago, when the first grain of wheat was sown! The second crop of six\r\n'b'hundred thousand grains produced this time four thousand bushels, or\r\n'b'five hundred millions of grains!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colony was rich in corn, for ten bushels alone were sufficient for\r\n'b'sowing every year to produce an ample crop for the food both of men and\r\n'b'beasts. The harvest was completed, and the last fortnight of the month\r\n'b'of November was devoted to the work of converting it into food for man.\r\n'b'In fact, they had corn, but not flour, and the establishment of a mill\r\n'b'was necessary. Cyrus Harding could have utilized the second fall which\r\n'b'flowed into the Mercy to establish his motive power, the first\r\n'b'being already occupied with moving the felting mill, but, after some\r\n'b'consultation, it was decided that a simple windmill should be built on\r\n'b'Prospect Heights. The building of this presented no more difficulty than\r\n'b'the building of the former, and it was moreover certain that there would\r\n'b'be no want of wind on the plateau, exposed as it was to the sea breezes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot to mention,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the windmill will be more lively\r\n'b'and will have a good effect in the landscape!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They set to work by choosing timber for the frame and machinery of the\r\n'b'mill. Some large stones, found at the north of the lake, could be easily\r\n'b'transformed into millstones, and as to the sails, the inexhaustible case\r\n'b'of the balloon furnished the necessary material.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding made his model, and the site of the mill was chosen a\r\n'b'little to the right of the poultry-yard, near the shore of the lake. The\r\n'b'frame was to rest on a pivot supported with strong timbers, so that it\r\n'b'could turn with all the machinery it contained according as the wind\r\n'b'required it. The work advanced rapidly. Neb and Pencroft had become\r\n'b'very skilful carpenters, and had nothing to do but to copy the models\r\n'b'provided by the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Soon a sort of cylindrical box, in shape like a pepper-pot, with a\r\n'b'pointed roof, rose on the spot chosen. The four frames which formed the\r\n'b'sails had been firmly fixed in the center beam, so as to form a certain\r\n'b'angle with it, and secured with iron clamps. As to the different\r\n'b'parts of the internal mechanism, the box destined to contain the two\r\n'b'millstones, the fixed stone and the moving stone, the hopper, a sort of\r\n'b'large square trough, wide at the top, narrow at the bottom, which would\r\n'b'allow the grain to fall on the stones, the oscillating spout intended to\r\n'b'regulate the passing of the grain, and lastly the bolting machine, which\r\n'b'by the operation of sifting, separates the bran from the flour,\r\n'b'were made without difficulty. The tools were good, and the work not\r\n'b'difficult, for in reality, the machinery of a mill is very simple. This\r\n'b'was only a question of time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Every one had worked at the construction of the mill, and on the 1st\r\n'b'of December it was finished. As usual, Pencroft was delighted with his\r\n'b'work, and had no doubt that the apparatus was perfect.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow for a good wind,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand we shall grind our first harvest\r\n'b'splendidly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA good wind, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut not too much,\r\n'b'Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPooh! our mill would only go the faster!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no need for it to go so very fast,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\n'b'is known by experience that the greatest quantity of work is performed\r\n'b'by a mill when the number of turns made by the sails in a minute is six\r\n'b'times the number of feet traversed by the wind in a second. A moderate\r\n'b'breeze, which passes over twenty-four feet to the second, will give\r\n'b'sixteen turns to the sails during a minute, and there is no need of\r\n'b'more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cExactly!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9ca fine breeze is blowing from the northeast,\r\n'b'which will soon do our business for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no reason for delaying the inauguration of the mill, for the\r\n'b'settlers were eager to taste the first piece of bread in Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'On this morning two or three bushels of wheat were ground, and the next\r\n'b'day at breakfast a magnificent loaf, a little heavy perhaps, although\r\n'b'raised with yeast, appeared on the table at Granite House. Every one\r\n'b'munched away at it with a pleasure which may be easily understood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, the stranger had not reappeared. Several times Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett and Herbert searched the forest in the neighborhood of Granite\r\n'b'House, without meeting or finding any trace of him. They became\r\n'b'seriously uneasy at this prolonged absence. Certainly, the former\r\n'b'savage of Tabor island could not be perplexed how to live in the forest,\r\n'b'abounding in game, but was it not to be feared that he had resumed his\r\n'b'habits, and that this freedom would revive in him his wild instincts?\r\n'b'However, Harding, by a sort of presentiment, doubtless, always persisted\r\n'b'in saying that the fugitive would return.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he will return!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated with a confidence which his\r\n'b'companions could not share. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen this unfortunate man was on Tabor\r\n'b'Island, he knew himself to be alone! Here, he knows that fellow-men are\r\n'b'awaiting him! Since he has partially spoken of his past life, the poor\r\n'b'penitent will return to tell the whole, and from that day he will belong\r\n'b'to us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The event justified Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s predictions. On the 3rd of December,\r\n'b'Herbert had left the plateau to go and fish on the southern bank of the\r\n'b'lake. He was unarmed, and till then had never taken any precautions for\r\n'b'defense, as dangerous animals had not shown themselves on that part of\r\n'b'the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, Pencroft and Neb were working in the poultry-yard, while\r\n'b'Harding and the reporter were occupied at the Chimneys in making soda,\r\n'b'the store of soap being exhausted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Suddenly cries resounded,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHelp! help!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and the reporter, being at too great a distance, had not\r\n'b'been able to hear the shouts. Pencroft and Neb, leaving the poultry-yard\r\n'b'in all haste, rushed towards the lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But before then, the stranger, whose presence at this place no one had\r\n'b'suspected, crossed Creek Glycerine, which separated the plateau from the\r\n'b'forest, and bounded up the opposite bank.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert was there face to face with a fierce jaguar, similar to the\r\n'b'one which had been killed on Reptile End. Suddenly surprised, he was\r\n'b'standing with his back against a tree, while the animal gathering itself\r\n'b'together was about to spring.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the stranger, with no other weapon than a knife, rushed on the\r\n'b'formidable animal, who turned to meet this new adversary.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The struggle was short. The stranger possessed immense strength and\r\n'b'activity. He seized the jaguar\xe2\x80\x99s throat with one powerful hand, holding\r\n'b'it as in a vise, without heeding the beast\xe2\x80\x99s claws which tore his flesh,\r\n'b'and with the other he plunged his knife into its heart.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The jaguar fell. The stranger kicked away the body, and was about to\r\n'b'fly at the moment when the settlers arrived on the field of battle, but\r\n'b'Herbert, clinging to him, cried,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no! you shall not go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding advanced towards the stranger, who frowned when he saw him\r\n'b'approaching. The blood flowed from his shoulder under his torn shirt,\r\n'b'but he took no notice of it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have just contracted a debt of\r\n'b'gratitude to you. To save our boy you have risked your life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy life!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the stranger. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that worth? Less than\r\n'b'nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wounded?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is no matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWill you give me your hand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And as Herbert endeavored to seize the hand which had just saved him,\r\n'b'the stranger folded his arms, his chest heaved, his look darkened, and\r\n'b'he appeared to wish to escape, but making a violent effort over himself,\r\n'b'and in an abrupt tone,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cand what do you claim to be to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 history which he thus demanded, and for the first\r\n'b'time. Perhaps this history recounted, he would tell his own.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few words Harding related all that had happened since their\r\n'b'departure from Richmond; how they had managed, and what resources they\r\n'b'now had at their disposal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger listened with extreme attention.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then the engineer told who they all were, Gideon Spilett, Herbert,\r\n'b'Pencroft, Neb, himself, and, he added, that the greatest happiness they\r\n'b'had felt since their arrival in Lincoln Island was on the return of the\r\n'b'vessel from Tabor Island, when they had been able to include among them\r\n'b'a new companion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At these words the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s face flushed, his head sunk on his breast,\r\n'b'and confusion was depicted on his countenance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now that you know us,\xe2\x80\x9d added Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you give us your\r\n'b'hand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger in a hoarse voice; \xe2\x80\x9cno! You are honest men!\r\n'b'And I--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 17\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These last words justified the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 presentiment. There had been\r\n'b'some mournful past, perhaps expiated in the sight of men, but from which\r\n'b'his conscience had not yet absolved him. At any rate the guilty man felt\r\n'b'remorse, he repented, and his new friends would have cordially pressed\r\n'b'the hand which they sought; but he did not feel himself worthy to extend\r\n'b'it to honest men! However, after the scene with the jaguar, he did not\r\n'b'return to the forest, and from that day did not go beyond the enclosure\r\n'b'of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What was the mystery of his life? Would the stranger one day speak of\r\n'b'it? Time alone could show. At any rate, it was agreed that his secret\r\n'b'should never be asked from him, and that they would live with him as if\r\n'b'they suspected nothing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For some days their life continued as before. Cyrus Harding and Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett worked together, sometimes chemists, sometimes experimentalists.\r\n'b'The reporter never left the engineer except to hunt with Herbert, for\r\n'b'it would not have been prudent to allow the lad to ramble alone in the\r\n'b'forest; and it was very necessary to be on their guard. As to Neb\r\n'b'and Pencroft, one day at the stables and poultry-yard, another at the\r\n'b'corral, without reckoning work in Granite House, they were never in want\r\n'b'of employment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger worked alone, and he had resumed his usual life, never\r\n'b'appearing at meals, sleeping under the trees in the plateau, never\r\n'b'mingling with his companions. It really seemed as if the society of\r\n'b'those who had saved him was insupportable to him!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut then,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy did he entreat the help of his\r\n'b'fellow-creatures? Why did he throw that paper into the sea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe will tell us why,\xe2\x80\x9d invariably replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps sooner than you think, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, indeed, the day of confession was near.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 10th of December, a week after his return to Granite House,\r\n'b'Harding saw the stranger approaching, who, in a calm voice and humble\r\n'b'tone, said to him: \xe2\x80\x9cSir, I have a request to make of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cbut first let me ask you a question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At these words the stranger reddened, and was on the point of\r\n'b'withdrawing. Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in the mind of\r\n'b'the guilty man, who doubtless feared that the engineer would interrogate\r\n'b'him on his past life.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding held him back.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cComrade,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are not only your companions but your friends. I\r\n'b'wish you to believe that, and now I will listen to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger pressed his hand over his eyes. He was seized with a\r\n'b'sort of trembling, and remained a few moments without being able to\r\n'b'articulate a word.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he at last, \xe2\x80\x9cI have come to beg you to grant me a favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, four or five miles from here, a corral for your domesticated\r\n'b'animals. These animals need to be taken care of. Will you allow me to\r\n'b'live there with them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding gazed at the unfortunate man for a few moments with a\r\n'b'feeling of deep commiseration; then,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe corral has only stables hardly fit for\r\n'b'animals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be good enough for me, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will not constrain you in anything.\r\n'b'You wish to live at the corral, so be it. You will, however, be always\r\n'b'welcome at Granite House. But since you wish to live at the corral\r\n'b'we will make the necessary arrangements for your being comfortably\r\n'b'established there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind that, I shall do very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding, who always intentionally made use of this\r\n'b'cordial appellation, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must let us judge what it will be best to do\r\n'b'in this respect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger as he withdrew.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer then made known to his companions the proposal which had\r\n'b'been made to him, and it was agreed that they should build a wooden\r\n'b'house at the corral, which they would make as comfortable as possible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That very day the colonists repaired to the corral with the necessary\r\n'b'tools, and a week had not passed before the house was ready to receive\r\n'b'its tenant. It was built about twenty feet from the sheds, and from\r\n'b'there it was easy to overlook the flock of sheep, which then numbered\r\n'b'more than eighty. Some furniture, a bed, table, bench, cupboard, and\r\n'b'chest were manufactured, and a gun, ammunition, and tools were carried\r\n'b'to the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger, however, had seen nothing of his new dwelling, and he\r\n'b'had allowed the settlers to work there without him, while he occupied\r\n'b'himself on the plateau, wishing, doubtless, to put the finishing stroke\r\n'b'to his work. Indeed, thanks to him, all the ground was dug up and ready\r\n'b'to be sowed when the time came.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was on the 20th of December that all the arrangements at the corral\r\n'b'were completed. The engineer announced to the stranger that his dwelling\r\n'b'was ready to receive him, and the latter replied that he would go and\r\n'b'sleep there that very evening.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this evening the colonists were gathered in the diningroom of Granite\r\n'b'House. It was then eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the hour at which their companion was\r\n'b'to leave them. Not wishing to trouble him by their presence, and thus\r\n'b'imposing on him the necessity of saying farewells which might perhaps be\r\n'b'painful to him, they had left him alone and ascended to Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now, they had been talking in the room for a few minutes, when a light\r\n'b'knock was heard at the door. Almost immediately the stranger entered,\r\n'b'and without any preamble,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cbefore I leave you, it is right that you should\r\n'b'know my history. I will tell it you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These simple words profoundly impressed Cyrus Harding and his\r\n'b'companions. The engineer rose.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe ask you nothing, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cit is your right to be\r\n'b'silent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is my duty to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSit down, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I will stand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are ready to hear you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stranger remained standing in a corner of the room, a little in the\r\n'b'shade. He was bareheaded, his arms folded across his chest, and it\r\n'b'was in this posture that in a hoarse voice, speaking like some one\r\n'b'who obliges himself to speak, he gave the following recital, which his\r\n'b'auditors did not once interrupt:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOn the 20th of December, 1854, a steam-yacht, belonging to a Scotch\r\n'b'nobleman, Lord Glenarvan, anchored off Cape Bernouilli, on the western\r\n'b'coast of Australia, in the thirty-seventh parallel. On board this yacht\r\n'b'were Lord Glenarvan and his wife, a major in the English army, a French\r\n'b'geographer, a young girl, and a young boy. These two last were the\r\n'b'children of Captain Grant, whose ship, the \xe2\x80\x98Britannia,\xe2\x80\x99 had been lost,\r\n'b'crew and cargo, a year before. The \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 was commanded by Captain\r\n'b'John Mangles, and manned by a crew of fifteen men.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the reason the yacht at this time lay off the coast of\r\n'b'Australia. Six months before, a bottle, enclosing a document written in\r\n'b'English, German, and French, had been found in the Irish Sea, and picked\r\n'b'up by the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan.\xe2\x80\x99 This document stated in substance that there still\r\n'b'existed three survivors from the wreck of the \xe2\x80\x98Britannia,\xe2\x80\x99 that these\r\n'b'survivors were Captain Grant and two of his men, and that they had found\r\n'b'refuge on some land, of which the document gave the latitude, but of\r\n'b'which the longitude, effaced by the sea, was no longer legible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis latitude was 37deg 11\xe2\x80\x99 south; therefore, the longitude being\r\n'b'unknown, if they followed the thirty-seventh parallel over continents\r\n'b'and seas, they would be certain to reach the spot inhabited by Captain\r\n'b'Grant and his two companions. The English Admiralty having hesitated to\r\n'b'undertake this search, Lord Glenarvan resolved to attempt everything to\r\n'b'find the captain. He communicated with Mary and Robert Grant, who joined\r\n'b'him. The \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 yacht was equipped for the distant voyage, in which\r\n'b'the nobleman\xe2\x80\x99s family and the captain\xe2\x80\x99s children wished to take part,\r\n'b'and the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 leaving Glasgow, proceeded towards the Atlantic,\r\n'b'passed through the Straits of Magellan, and ascended the Pacific as\r\n'b'far as Patagonia, where, according to a previous interpretation of the\r\n'b'document, they supposed that Captain Grant was a prisoner among the\r\n'b'Indians.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 disembarked her passengers on the western coast of\r\n'b'Patagonia, and sailed to pick them up again on the eastern coast at\r\n'b'Cape Corrientes. Lord Glenarvan traversed Patagonia, following the\r\n'b'thirty-seventh parallel, and having found no trace of the captain, he\r\n'b're-embarked on the 13th of November, so as to pursue his search through\r\n'b'the Ocean.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAfter having unsuccessfully visited the islands of Tristan d\xe2\x80\x99Acunha and\r\n'b'Amsterdam, situated in her course, the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 as I have said, arrived\r\n'b'at Cape Bernouilli, on the Australian coast, on the 20th of December,\r\n'b'1854.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was Lord Glenarvan\xe2\x80\x99s intention to traverse Australia as he had\r\n'b'traversed America, and he disembarked. A few miles from the coast was\r\n'b'established a farm, belonging to an Irishman, who offered hospitality to\r\n'b'the travelers. Lord Glenarvan made known to the Irishman the cause\r\n'b'which had brought him to these parts, and asked if he knew whether a\r\n'b'three-masted English vessel, the \xe2\x80\x98Britannia,\xe2\x80\x99 had been lost less than\r\n'b'two years before on the west coast of Australia.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Irishman had never heard of this wreck, but, to the great surprise\r\n'b'of the bystanders, one of his servants came forward and said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98My lord, praise and thank God! If Captain Grant is still living, he is\r\n'b'living on the Australian shores.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Who are you?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lord Glenarvan.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98A Scotchman like yourself, my lord,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the man; \xe2\x80\x98I am one of\r\n'b'Captain Grant\xe2\x80\x99s crew--one of the castaways of the \xe2\x80\x9cBritannia.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis man was called Ayrton. He was, in fact, the boatswain\xe2\x80\x99s mate of\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x98Britannia,\xe2\x80\x99 as his papers showed. But, separated from Captain Grant\r\n'b'at the moment when the ship struck upon the rocks, he had till then\r\n'b'believed that the captain with all his crew had perished, and that he,\r\n'b'Ayrton, was the sole survivor of the \xe2\x80\x98Britannia.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Only,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, \xe2\x80\x98it was not on the west coast, but on the east coast\r\n'b'of Australia that the vessel was lost, and if Captain Grant is still\r\n'b'living, as his document indicates, he is a prisoner among the natives,\r\n'b'and it is on the other coast that he must be looked for.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis man spoke in a frank voice and with a confident look; his words\r\n'b'could not be doubted. The Irishman, in whose service he had been for\r\n'b'more than a year, answered for his trustworthiness. Lord Glenarvan,\r\n'b'therefore, believed in the fidelity of this man and, by his advice,\r\n'b'resolved to cross Australia, following the thirty-seventh parallel. Lord\r\n'b'Glenarvan, his wife, the two children, the major, the Frenchman, Captain\r\n'b'Mangles, and a few sailors composed the little band under the command\r\n'b'of Ayrton, while the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 under charge of the mate, Tom Austin,\r\n'b'proceeded to Melbourne, there to await Lord Glenarvan\xe2\x80\x99s instructions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey set out on the 23rd of December, 1854.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is time to say that Ayrton was a traitor. He was, indeed, the\r\n'b'boatswain\xe2\x80\x99s mate of the \xe2\x80\x98Britannia,\xe2\x80\x99 but, after some dispute with his\r\n'b'captain, he endeavored to incite the crew to mutiny and seize the ship,\r\n'b'and Captain Grant had landed him, on the 8th of April, 1852, on the\r\n'b'west coast of Australia, and then sailed, leaving him there, as was only\r\n'b'just.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore this wretched man knew nothing of the wreck of the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Britannia\xe2\x80\x99; he had just heard of it from Glenarvan\xe2\x80\x99s account. Since his\r\n'b'abandonment, he had become, under the name of Ben Joyce, the leader of\r\n'b'the escaped convicts; and if he boldly maintained that the wreck had\r\n'b'taken place on the east coast, and led Lord Glenarvan to proceed in that\r\n'b'direction, it was that he hoped to separate him from his ship, seize the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 and make the yacht a pirate in the Pacific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Here the stranger stopped for a moment. His voice trembled, but he\r\n'b'continued,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe expedition set out and proceeded across Australia. It was\r\n'b'inevitably unfortunate, since Ayrton, or Ben Joyce, as he may be\r\n'b'called, guided it, sometimes preceded, sometimes followed by his band of\r\n'b'convicts, who had been told what they had to do.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMeanwhile, the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 had been sent to Melbourne for repairs. It was\r\n'b'necessary, then, to get Lord Glenarvan to order her to leave Melbourne\r\n'b'and go to the east coast of Australia, where it would be easy to seize\r\n'b'her. After having led the expedition near enough to the coast, in the\r\n'b'midst of vast forests with no resources, Ayrton obtained a letter, which\r\n'b'he was charged to carry to the mate of the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99--a letter which\r\n'b'ordered the yacht to repair immediately to the east coast, to Twofold\r\n'b'Bay, that is to say a few days\xe2\x80\x99 journey from the place where the\r\n'b'expedition had stopped. It was there that Ayrton had agreed to meet his\r\n'b'accomplices, and two days after gaining possession of the letter, he\r\n'b'arrived at Melbourne.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo far the villain had succeeded in his wicked design. He would be able\r\n'b'to take the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 into Twofold Bay, where it would be easy for the\r\n'b'convicts to seize her, and her crew massacred, Ben Joyce would become\r\n'b'master of the seas. But it pleased God to prevent the accomplishment of\r\n'b'these terrible projects.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton, arrived at Melbourne, delivered the letter to the mate, Tom\r\n'b'Austin, who read it and immediately set sail, but judge of Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s rage\r\n'b'and disappointment, when the next day he found that the mate was taking\r\n'b'the vessel, not to the east coast of Australia, to Twofold Bay, but to\r\n'b'the east coast of New Zealand. He wished to stop him, but Austin showed\r\n'b'him the letter!... And indeed, by a providential error of the French\r\n'b'geographer, who had written the letter, the east coast of New Zealand\r\n'b'was mentioned as the place of destination.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s plans were frustrated! He became outrageous. They put him\r\n'b'in irons. He was then taken to the coast of New Zealand, not knowing\r\n'b'what would become of his accomplices, or what would become of Lord\r\n'b'Glenarvan.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 cruised about on this coast until the 3rd of March. On\r\n'b'that day Ayrton heard the report of guns. The guns on the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 were\r\n'b'being fired, and soon Lord Glenarvan and his companions came on board.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is what had happened.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAfter a thousand hardships, a thousand dangers, Lord Glenarvan had\r\n'b'accomplished his journey, and arrived on the east coast of Australia, at\r\n'b'Twofold Bay. \xe2\x80\x98No \xe2\x80\x9cDuncan!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99 He telegraphed to Melbourne. They answered,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDuncan\xe2\x80\x9d sailed on the 18th instant. Destination unknown.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLord Glenarvan could only arrive at one conclusion; that his honest\r\n'b'yacht had fallen into the hands of Ben Joyce, and had become a pirate\r\n'b'vessel!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever, Lord Glenarvan would not give up. He was a bold and generous\r\n'b'man. He embarked in a merchant vessel, sailed to the west coast of New\r\n'b'Zealand, traversed it along the thirty-seventh parallel, without\r\n'b'finding any trace of Captain Grant; but on the other side, to his\r\n'b'great surprise, and by the will of Heaven, he found the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 under\r\n'b'command of the mate, who had been waiting for him for five weeks!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis was on the 3rd of March, 1855. Lord Glenarvan was now on board the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 but Ayrton was there also. He appeared before the nobleman,\r\n'b'who wished to extract from him all that the villain knew about Captain\r\n'b'Grant. Ayrton refused to speak. Lord Glenarvan then told him, that at\r\n'b'the first port they put into, he would be delivered up to the English\r\n'b'authorities. Ayrton remained mute.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 continued her voyage along the thirty-seventh parallel.\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, Lady Glenarvan undertook to vanquish the resistance of\r\n'b'the ruffian.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt last, her influence prevailed, and Ayrton, in exchange for what he\r\n'b'could tell, proposed that Lord Glenarvan should leave him on some island\r\n'b'in the Pacific, instead of giving him up to the English authorities.\r\n'b'Lord Glenarvan, resolving to do anything to obtain information about\r\n'b'Captain Grant, consented.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton then related all his life, and it was certain that he knew\r\n'b'nothing from the day on which Captain Grant had landed him on the\r\n'b'Australian coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, Lord Glenarvan kept the promise which he had given. The\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 continued her voyage and arrived at Tabor Island. It was there\r\n'b'that Ayrton was to be landed, and it was there also that, by a\r\n'b'veritable miracle, they found Captain Grant and two men, exactly on the\r\n'b'thirty-seventh parallel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe convict, then, went to take their place on this desert islet, and\r\n'b'at the moment he left the yacht these words were pronounced by Lord\r\n'b'Glenarvan:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Here, Ayrton, you will be far from any land, and without any possible\r\n'b'communication with your fellow-creatures. You cannot escape from this\r\n'b'islet on which the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 leaves you. You will be alone, under the eye\r\n'b'of a God who reads the depths of the heart, but you will be neither\r\n'b'lost nor forgotten, as was Captain Grant. Unworthy as you are to be\r\n'b'remembered by men, men will remember you. I know where you are Ayrton,\r\n'b'and I know where to find you. I will never forget it!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 making sail, soon disappeared. This was 18th of\r\n'b'March, 1855.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'     (The events which have just been briefly related are taken\r\n'b'     from a work which some of our readers have no doubt read,\r\n'b'     and which is entitled, \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Grant\xe2\x80\x99s children.\xe2\x80\x9d They will\r\n'b'     remark on this occasion, as well as later, some discrepancy\r\n'b'     in the dates; but later again, they will understand why the\r\n'b'     real dates were not at first given.)\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton was alone, but he had no want of either ammunition, weapons,\r\n'b'tools, or seeds.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt his, the convict\xe2\x80\x99s disposal, was the house built by honest Captain\r\n'b'Grant. He had only to live and expiate in solitude the crimes which he\r\n'b'had committed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, he repented, he was ashamed of his crimes and was very\r\n'b'miserable! He said to himself, that if men came some day to take\r\n'b'him from that islet, he must be worthy to return among them! How he\r\n'b'suffered, that wretched man! How he labored to recover himself by work!\r\n'b'How he prayed to be reformed by prayer! For two years, three years, this\r\n'b'went on, but Ayrton, humbled by solitude, always looking for some ship\r\n'b'to appear on the horizon, asking himself if the time of expiation would\r\n'b'soon be complete, suffered as none other suffered! Oh! how dreadful was\r\n'b'this solitude, to a heart tormented by remorse!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut doubtless Heaven had not sufficiently punished this unhappy man,\r\n'b'for he felt that he was gradually becoming a savage! He felt that\r\n'b'brutishness was gradually gaining on him!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe could not say if it was after two or three years of solitude, but at\r\n'b'last he became the miserable creature you found!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have no need to tell you, gentlemen, that Ayrton, Ben Joyce, and I,\r\n'b'are the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions rose at the end of this account. It\r\n'b'is impossible to say how much they were moved! What misery, grief, and\r\n'b'despair lay revealed before them!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, rising, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have been a great criminal, but\r\n'b'Heaven must certainly think that you have expiated your crimes! That\r\n'b'has been proved by your having been brought again among your\r\n'b'fellow-creatures. Ayrton, you are forgiven! And now you will be our\r\n'b'companion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton drew back.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere is my hand!\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton grasped the hand which Harding extended to him, and great tears\r\n'b'fell from his eyes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWill you live with us?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding, leave me some time longer,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ayrton, \xe2\x80\x9cleave me\r\n'b'alone in the hut in the corral!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs you like, Ayrton,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding. Ayrton was going to\r\n'b'withdraw, when the engineer addressed one more question to him:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne word more, my friend. Since it was your intention to live alone,\r\n'b'why did you throw into the sea the document which put us on your track?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA document?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Ayrton, who did not appear to know what he meant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the document which we found enclosed in a bottle, giving us the\r\n'b'exact position of Tabor Island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton passed his hand over his brow, then after having thought, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n'b'never threw any document into the sea!\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Ayrton, bowing, reached the door and departed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 18\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPoor man!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, who had rushed to the door, but returned,\r\n'b'having seen Ayrton slide down the rope on the lift and disappear in the\r\n'b'darkness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe will come back,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat does that mean? What!\r\n'b'wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it Ayrton who threw that bottle into the sea? Who was it then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Certainly, if ever a question was necessary to be made, it was that one!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was he,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Neb, \xe2\x80\x9conly the unhappy man was half-mad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand he was no longer conscious of what he was\r\n'b'doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt can only be explained in that way, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding\r\n'b'quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cand I understand now how Ayrton was able to point out exactly\r\n'b'the situation of Tabor Island, since the events which had preceded his\r\n'b'being left on the island had made it known to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cif he was not yet a brute when he wrote\r\n'b'that document, and if he threw it into the sea seven or eight years ago,\r\n'b'how is it that the paper has not been injured by damp?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat proves,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Ayrton was deprived of\r\n'b'intelligence at a more recent time than he thinks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOf course it must be so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwithout that the fact\r\n'b'would be unaccountable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUnaccountable indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, who did not appear\r\n'b'desirous to prolong the conversation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut has Ayrton told the truth?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cThe story which he has told is true in\r\n'b'every point. I remember quite well the account in the newspapers of the\r\n'b'yacht expedition undertaken by Lord Glenarvan, and its result.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton has told the truth,\xe2\x80\x9d added Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cDo not doubt it, Pencroft,\r\n'b'for it was painful to him. People tell the truth when they accuse\r\n'b'themselves like that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day--the 21st of December--the colonists descended to the\r\n'b'beach, and having climbed the plateau they found nothing of Ayrton. He\r\n'b'had reached his house in the corral during the night and the settlers\r\n'b'judged it best not to agitate him by their presence. Time would\r\n'b'doubtless perform what sympathy had been unable to accomplish.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, Pencroft, and Neb resumed their ordinary occupations. On this\r\n'b'day the same work brought Harding and the reporter to the workshop at\r\n'b'the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, my dear Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the explanation\r\n'b'you gave yesterday on the subject of the bottle has not satisfied me at\r\n'b'all! How can it be supposed that the unfortunate man was able to write\r\n'b'that document and throw the bottle into the sea without having the\r\n'b'slightest recollection of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNor was it he who threw it in, my dear Spilett.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou think then--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think nothing, I know nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\n'b'content to rank this incident among those which I have not been able to\r\n'b'explain to this day!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthese things are incredible! Your\r\n'b'rescue, the case stranded on the sand, Top\xe2\x80\x99s adventure, and lastly this\r\n'b'bottle... Shall we never have the answer to these enigmas?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, even if I have to penetrate\r\n'b'into the bowels of this island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cChance will perhaps give us the key to this mystery!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cChance! Spilett! I do not believe in chance, any more than I believe in\r\n'b'mysteries in this world. There is a reason for everything unaccountable\r\n'b'which has happened here, and that reason I shall discover. But in the\r\n'b'meantime we must work and observe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The month of January arrived. The year 1867 commenced. The summer\r\n'b'occupations were assiduously continued. During the days which followed,\r\n'b'Herbert and Spilett having gone in the direction of the corral,\r\n'b'ascertained that Ayrton had taken possession of the habitation which\r\n'b'had been prepared for him. He busied himself with the numerous flock\r\n'b'confided to his care, and spared his companions the trouble of coming\r\n'b'every two or three days to visit the corral. Nevertheless, in order not\r\n'b'to leave Ayrton in solitude for too long a time, the settlers often paid\r\n'b'him a visit.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was not unimportant either, in consequence of some suspicions\r\n'b'entertained by the engineer and Gideon Spilett, that this part of\r\n'b'the island should be subject to a surveillance of some sort, and that\r\n'b'Ayrton, if any incident occurred unexpectedly, should not neglect to\r\n'b'inform the inhabitants of Granite House of it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nevertheless it might happen that something would occur which it would\r\n'b'be necessary to bring rapidly to the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge. Independently\r\n'b'of facts bearing on the mystery of Lincoln Island, many others\r\n'b'might happen, which would call for the prompt interference of the\r\n'b'colonists,--such as the sighting of a vessel, a wreck on the western\r\n'b'coast, the possible arrival of pirates, etc.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Therefore Cyrus Harding resolved to put the corral in instantaneous\r\n'b'communication with Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was on the 10th of January that he made known his project to his\r\n'b'companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy! how are you going to manage that, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cDo\r\n'b'you by chance happen to think of establishing a telegraph?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cElectric?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cElectric,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have all the necessary materials\r\n'b'for making a battery, and the most difficult thing will be to stretch\r\n'b'the wires, but by means of a drawplate I think we shall manage it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, after that,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall never despair of\r\n'b'seeing ourselves some day rolling along on a railway!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They then set to work, beginning with the most difficult thing, for, if\r\n'b'they failed in that, it would be useless to manufacture the battery and\r\n'b'other accessories.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The iron of Lincoln Island, as has been said, was of excellent quality,\r\n'b'and consequently very fit for being drawn out. Harding commenced by\r\n'b'manufacturing a drawplate, that is to say, a plate of steel, pierced\r\n'b'with conical holes of different sizes, which would successively bring\r\n'b'the wire to the wished-for tenacity. This piece of steel, after having\r\n'b'been tempered, was fixed in as firm a way as possible in a solid\r\n'b'framework planted in the ground, only a few feet from the great fall,\r\n'b'the motive power of which the engineer intended to utilize. In fact as\r\n'b'the fulling-mill was there, although not then in use, its beam moved\r\n'b'with extreme power would serve to stretch out the wire by rolling it\r\n'b'round itself. It was a delicate operation, and required much care. The\r\n'b'iron, prepared previously in long thin rods, the ends of which were\r\n'b'sharpened with the file, having been introduced into the largest hole of\r\n'b'the drawplate, was drawn out by the beam which wound it round itself,\r\n'b'to a length of twenty-five or thirty feet, then unrolled, and the same\r\n'b'operation was performed successively through the holes of a less size.\r\n'b'Finally, the engineer obtained wires from forty to fifty feet long,\r\n'b'which could be easily fastened together and stretched over the distance\r\n'b'of five miles, which separated the corral from the bounds of Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It did not take more than a few days to perform this work, and indeed\r\n'b'as soon as the machine had been commenced, Cyrus Harding left his\r\n'b'companions to follow the trade of wiredrawers, and occupied himself with\r\n'b'manufacturing his battery.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was necessary to obtain a battery with a constant current. It is\r\n'b'known that the elements of modern batteries are generally composed of\r\n'b'retort coal, zinc, and copper. Copper was absolutely wanting to the\r\n'b'engineer, who, notwithstanding all his researches, had never been able\r\n'b'to find any trace of it in Lincoln Island, and was therefore obliged to\r\n'b'do without it. Retort coal, that is to say, the hard graphite which\r\n'b'is found in the retorts of gas manufactories, after the coal has\r\n'b'been dehydrogenized, could have been obtained, but it would have been\r\n'b'necessary to establish a special apparatus, involving great labor. As\r\n'b'to zinc, it may be remembered that the case found at Flotsam Point was\r\n'b'lined with this metal, which could not be better utilized than for this\r\n'b'purpose.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, after mature consideration, decided to manufacture a\r\n'b'very simple battery, resembling as nearly as possible that invented\r\n'b'by Becquerel in 1820, and in which zinc only is employed. The other\r\n'b'substances, azotic acid and potash, were all at his disposal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The way in which the battery was composed was as follows, and the\r\n'b'results were to be attained by the reaction of acid and potash on each\r\n'b'other. A number of glass bottles were made and filled with azotic acid.\r\n'b'The engineer corked them by means of a stopper through which passed a\r\n'b'glass tube, bored at its lower extremity, and intended to be plunged\r\n'b'into the acid by means of a clay stopper secured by a rag. Into this\r\n'b'tube, through its upper extremity, he poured a solution of potash,\r\n'b'previously obtained by burning and reducing to ashes various plants,\r\n'b'and in this way the acid and potash could act on each other through the\r\n'b'clay.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding then took two slips of zinc, one of which was plunged\r\n'b'into azotic acid, the other into a solution of potash. A current was\r\n'b'immediately produced, which was transmitted from the slip of zinc in the\r\n'b'bottle to that in the tube, and the two slips having been connected by a\r\n'b'metallic wire the slip in the tube became the positive pole, and that in\r\n'b'the bottle the negative pole of the apparatus. Each bottle, therefore,\r\n'b'produced as many currents as united would be sufficient to produce all\r\n'b'the phenomena of the electric telegraph. Such was the ingenious and very\r\n'b'simple apparatus constructed by Cyrus Harding, an apparatus which would\r\n'b'allow them to establish a telegraphic communication between Granite\r\n'b'House and the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 6th of February was commenced the planting along the road to\r\n'b'the corral, of posts furnished with glass insulators, and intended to\r\n'b'support the wire. A few days after, the wire was extended, ready to\r\n'b'produce the electric current at a rate of twenty thousand miles a\r\n'b'second.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two batteries had been manufactured, one for Granite House, the other\r\n'b'for the corral; for if it was necessary the corral should be able to\r\n'b'communicate with Granite House it might also be useful that Granite\r\n'b'House should be able to communicate with the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the receiver and manipulator, they were very simple. At the two\r\n'b'stations the wire was wound round a magnet, that is to say, round a\r\n'b'piece of soft iron surrounded with a wire. The communication was thus\r\n'b'established between the two poles; the current, starting from the\r\n'b'positive pole, traversed the wire, passed through the magnet which was\r\n'b'temporarily magnetized, and returned through the earth to the negative\r\n'b'pole. If the current was interrupted, the magnet immediately became\r\n'b'unmagnetized. It was sufficient to place a plate of soft iron before the\r\n'b'magnet, which, attracted during the passage of the current, would fall\r\n'b'back when the current was interrupted. This movement of the plate thus\r\n'b'obtained, Harding could easily fasten to it a needle arranged on a dial,\r\n'b'bearing the letters of the alphabet, and in this way communicate from\r\n'b'one station to the other.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All was completely arranged by the 12th of February. On this day,\r\n'b'Harding, having sent the current through the wire, asked if all\r\n'b'was going on well at the corral, and received in a few moments a\r\n'b'satisfactory reply from Ayrton. Pencroft was wild with joy, and every\r\n'b'morning and evening he sent a telegram to the corral, which always\r\n'b'received an answer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This mode of communication presented two very real advantages: firstly,\r\n'b'because it enabled them to ascertain that Ayrton was at the corral; and\r\n'b'secondly, that he was thus not left completely isolated. Besides, Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding never allowed a week to pass without going to see him, and\r\n'b'Ayrton came from time to time to Granite House, where he always found a\r\n'b'cordial welcome.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The fine season passed away in the midst of the usual work. The\r\n'b'resources of the colony, particularly in vegetables and corn, increased\r\n'b'from day to day, and the plants brought from Tabor Island had succeeded\r\n'b'perfectly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The plateau of Prospect Heights presented an encouraging aspect. The\r\n'b'fourth harvest had been admirable and it may be supposed that no one\r\n'b'thought of counting whether the four hundred thousand millions of grains\r\n'b'duly appeared in the crop. However, Pencroft had thought of doing so,\r\n'b'but Cyrus Harding having told him that even if he managed to count three\r\n'b'hundred grains a minute, or nine thousand an hour, it would take him\r\n'b'nearly five thousand five-hundred years to finish his task, the honest\r\n'b'sailor considered it best to give up the idea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The weather was splendid, the temperature very warm in the day time, but\r\n'b'in the evening the sea-breezes tempered the heat of the atmosphere and\r\n'b'procured cool nights for the inhabitants of Granite House. There were,\r\n'b'however, a few storms, which, although they were not of long duration,\r\n'b'swept over Lincoln Island with extraordinary fury. The lightning blazed\r\n'b'and the thunder continued to roll for some hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this period the little colony was extremely prosperous.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The tenants of the poultry-yard swarmed, and they lived on the surplus,\r\n'b'but it became necessary to reduce the population to a more moderate\r\n'b'number. The pigs had already produced young, and it may be understood\r\n'b'that their care for these animals absorbed a great part of Neb and\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s time. The onagers, who had two pretty colts, were most often\r\n'b'mounted by Gideon Spilett and Herbert, who had become an excellent rider\r\n'b'under the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s instruction, and they also harnessed them to the\r\n'b'cart either for carrying wood and coal to Granite House, or different\r\n'b'mineral productions required by the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Several expeditions were made about this time into the depths of the Far\r\n'b'West Forests. The explorers could venture there without having anything\r\n'b'to fear from the heat, for the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays scarcely penetrated through\r\n'b'the thick foliage spreading above their heads. They thus visited all the\r\n'b'left bank of the Mercy, along which ran the road from the corral to the\r\n'b'mouth of Falls River.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But in these excursions the settlers took care to be well armed, for\r\n'b'they met with savage wild boars, with which they often had a tussle.\r\n'b'They also, during this season, made fierce war against the jaguars.\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett had vowed a special hatred against them, and his pupil\r\n'b'Herbert seconded him well. Armed as they were, they no longer feared\r\n'b'to meet one of those beasts. Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s courage was superb, and the\r\n'b'reporter\xe2\x80\x99s sang-froid astonishing. Already twenty magnificent skins\r\n'b'ornamented the dining-room of Granite House, and if this continued, the\r\n'b'jaguar race would soon be extinct in the island, the object aimed at by\r\n'b'the hunters.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer sometimes took part in the expeditions made to the unknown\r\n'b'parts of the island, which he surveyed with great attention. It was for\r\n'b'other traces than those of animals that he searched the thickets of the\r\n'b'vast forest, but nothing suspicious ever appeared. Neither Top nor Jup,\r\n'b'who accompanied him, ever betrayed by their behavior that there was\r\n'b'anything strange there, and yet more than once again the dog barked at\r\n'b'the mouth of the well, which the engineer had before explored without\r\n'b'result.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this time Gideon Spilett, aided by Herbert, took several views of\r\n'b'the most picturesque parts of the island, by means of the photographic\r\n'b'apparatus found in the cases, and of which they had not as yet made any\r\n'b'use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This apparatus, provided with a powerful object-glass, was very\r\n'b'complete. Substances necessary for the photographic reproduction,\r\n'b'collodion for preparing the glass plate, nitrate of silver to render it\r\n'b'sensitive, hyposulfate of soda to fix the prints obtained, chloride of\r\n'b'ammonium in which to soak the paper destined to give the positive proof,\r\n'b'acetate of soda and chloride of gold in which to immerse the paper,\r\n'b'nothing was wanting. Even the papers were there, all prepared,\r\n'b'and before laying in the printing-frame upon the negatives, it was\r\n'b'sufficient to soak them for a few minutes in the solution of nitrate of\r\n'b'silver.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter and his assistant became in a short time very skilful\r\n'b'operators, and they obtained fine views of the country, such as the\r\n'b'island, taken from Prospect Heights with Mount Franklin in the distance,\r\n'b'the mouth of the Mercy, so picturesquely framed in high rocks, the glade\r\n'b'and the corral, with the spurs of the mountain in the background, the\r\n'b'curious development of Claw Cape, Flotsam Point, etc.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nor did the photographers forget to take the portraits of all the\r\n'b'inhabitants of the island, leaving out no one.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt multiplies us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor was enchanted to see his own countenance, faithfully\r\n'b'reproduced, ornamenting the walls of Granite House, and he stopped\r\n'b'as willingly before this exhibition as he would have done before the\r\n'b'richest shop-windows in Broadway.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But it must be acknowledged that the most successful portrait was\r\n'b'incontestably that of Master Jup. Master Jup had sat with a gravity not\r\n'b'to be described, and his portrait was lifelike!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe looks as if he was just going to grin!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And if Master Jup had not been satisfied, he would have been very\r\n'b'difficult to please; but he was quite contented and contemplated his own\r\n'b'countenance with a sentimental air which expressed some small amount of\r\n'b'conceit.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The summer heat ended with the month of March. The weather was sometimes\r\n'b'rainy, but still warm. The month of March, which corresponds to the\r\n'b'September of northern latitudes, was not so fine as might have been\r\n'b'hoped. Perhaps it announced an early and rigorous winter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It might have been supposed one morning--the 21 st--that the first snow\r\n'b'had already made its appearance. In fact Herbert looking early from one\r\n'b'of the windows of Granite House, exclaimed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHallo! the islet is covered with snow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSnow at this time?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, joining the boy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their companions were soon beside them, but could only ascertain one\r\n'b'thing, that not only the islet but all the beach below Granite House was\r\n'b'covered with one uniform sheet of white.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt must be snow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOr rather it\xe2\x80\x99s very like it!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut the thermometer marks fifty-eight degrees!\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding gazed at the sheet of white without saying anything, for\r\n'b'he really did not know how to explain this phenomenon, at this time of\r\n'b'year and in such a temperature.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy Jove!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9call our plants will be frozen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor was about to descend, when he was preceded by the nimble\r\n'b'Jup, who slid down to the sand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the orang had not touched the ground, when the snowy sheet arose and\r\n'b'dispersed in the air in such innumerable flakes that the light of the\r\n'b'sun was obscured for some minutes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBirds!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were indeed swarms of sea-birds, with dazzling white plumage.\r\n'b'They had perched by thousands on the islet and on the shore, and they\r\n'b'disappeared in the distance, leaving the colonists amazed as if they\r\n'b'had been present at some transformation scene, in which summer succeeded\r\n'b'winter at the touch of a fairy\xe2\x80\x99s wand. Unfortunately the change had been\r\n'b'so sudden, that neither the reporter nor the lad had been able to bring\r\n'b'down one of these birds, of which they could not recognize the species.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few days after came the 26th of March, the day on which, two years\r\n'b'before, the castaways from the air had been thrown upon Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 19\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Two years already! and for two years the colonists had had no\r\n'b'communication with their fellow-creatures! They were without news from\r\n'b'the civilized world, lost on this island, as completely as if they had\r\n'b'been on the most minute star of the celestial hemisphere!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What was now happening in their country? The picture of their native\r\n'b'land was always before their eyes, the land torn by civil war at the\r\n'b'time they left it, and which the Southern rebellion was perhaps still\r\n'b'staining with blood! It was a great sorrow to them, and they often\r\n'b'talked together of these things, without ever doubting however that\r\n'b'the cause of the North must triumph, for the honor of the American\r\n'b'Confederation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During these two years not a vessel had passed in sight of the island;\r\n'b'or, at least, not a sail had been seen. It was evident that Lincoln\r\n'b'Island was out of the usual track, and also that it was unknown,--as was\r\n'b'besides proved by the maps,--for though there was no port, vessels might\r\n'b'have visited it for the purpose of renewing their store of water. But\r\n'b'the surrounding ocean was deserted as far as the eye could reach, and\r\n'b'the colonists must rely on themselves for regaining their native land.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, one chance of rescue existed, and this chance was discussed\r\n'b'one day on the first week of April, when the colonists were gathered\r\n'b'together in the dining-room of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had been talking of America, of their native country, which they\r\n'b'had so little hope of ever seeing again.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly we have only one way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cone single way for\r\n'b'leaving Lincoln Island, and that is, to build a vessel large enough to\r\n'b'sail several hundred miles. It appears to me, that when one has built a\r\n'b'boat it is just as easy to build a ship!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in which we might go to the Pomoutous,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cjust as\r\n'b'easily as we went to Tabor Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do not say no,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, who had always the casting vote\r\n'b'in maritime questions; \xe2\x80\x9cI do not say no, although it is not exactly the\r\n'b'same thing to make a long as a short voyage! If our little craft had\r\n'b'been caught in any heavy gale of wind during the voyage to Tabor Island,\r\n'b'we should have known that land was at no great distance either way; but\r\n'b'twelve hundred miles is a pretty long way, and the nearest land is at\r\n'b'least that distance!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWould you not, in that case, Pencroft, attempt the adventure?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\n'b'the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will attempt anything that is desired, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\n'b'sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand you know well that I am not a man to flinch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, besides, that we number another sailor amongst us now,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' remarked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf he will consent to come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the reporter; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think that if Lord\r\n'b'Glenarvan\xe2\x80\x99s yacht had appeared at Tabor Island, while he was still\r\n'b'living there, Ayrton would have refused to depart?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou forget, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d then said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Ayrton was not\r\n'b'in possession of his reason during the last years of his stay there. But\r\n'b'that is not the question. The point is to know if we may count among\r\n'b'our chances of being rescued, the return of the Scotch vessel. Now,\r\n'b'Lord Glenarvan promised Ayrton that he would return to take him off from\r\n'b'Tabor Island when he considered that his crimes were expiated, and I\r\n'b'believe that he will return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will add that he will return soon, for\r\n'b'it is twelve years since Ayrton was abandoned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI agree with you that the nobleman will\r\n'b'return, and soon too. But where will he touch? At Tabor Island, and not\r\n'b'at Lincoln Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the more certain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cas Lincoln Island is not\r\n'b'even marked on the map.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe ought to take the\r\n'b'necessary precautions for making our presence and that of Ayrton on\r\n'b'Lincoln Island known at Tabor Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand nothing is easier than to place\r\n'b'in the hut, which was Captain Grant\xe2\x80\x99s and Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s dwelling, a notice\r\n'b'which Lord Glenarvan and his crew cannot help finding, giving the\r\n'b'position of our island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a pity,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we forgot to take that\r\n'b'precaution on our first visit to Tabor Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why should we have done it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cAt that time we did\r\n'b'not know Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s history; we did not know that any one was likely to\r\n'b'come some day to fetch him, and when we did know his history, the season\r\n'b'was too advanced to allow us to return then to Tabor Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cit was too late, and we must put off the voyage\r\n'b'until next spring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut suppose the Scotch yacht comes before that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not probable,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cfor Lord Glenarvan would\r\n'b'not choose the winter season to venture into these seas. Either he has\r\n'b'already returned to Tabor Island, since Ayrton has been with us, that is\r\n'b'to say, during the last five months and has left again; or he will not\r\n'b'come till later, and it will be time enough in the first fine October\r\n'b'days to go to Tabor Island, and leave a notice there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must allow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it will be very unfortunate if the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 has returned to these parts only a few months ago!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI hope that it is not so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand that Heaven has\r\n'b'not deprived us of the best chance which remains to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cthat at any rate we shall know what\r\n'b'we have to depend on when we have been to Tabor Island, for if the yacht\r\n'b'has returned there, they will necessarily have left some traces of their\r\n'b'visit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is evident,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cSo then, my friends, since\r\n'b'we have this chance of returning to our country, we must wait patiently,\r\n'b'and if it is taken from us we shall see what will be best to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cit is well understood that if we\r\n'b'do leave Lincoln Island, it will not be because we were uncomfortable\r\n'b'there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cit will be because we are far\r\n'b'from all that a man holds dearest in the world, his family, his friends,\r\n'b'his native land!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Matters being thus decided, the building of a vessel large enough to\r\n'b'sail either to the Archipelagoes in the north, or to New Zealand in\r\n'b'the west, was no longer talked of, and they busied themselves in their\r\n'b'accustomed occupations, with a view to wintering a third time in Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, it was agreed that before the stormy weather came on, their\r\n'b'little vessel should be employed in making a voyage round the island.\r\n'b'A complete survey of the coast had not yet been made, and the colonists\r\n'b'had but an imperfect idea of the shore to the west and north, from the\r\n'b'mouth of Falls River to the Mandible Capes, as well as of the narrow bay\r\n'b'between them, which opened like a shark\xe2\x80\x99s jaws.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The plan of this excursion was proposed by Pencroft, and Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'fully acquiesced in it, for he himself wished to see this part of his\r\n'b'domain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The weather was variable, but the barometer did not fluctuate by sudden\r\n'b'movements, and they could therefore count on tolerable weather. However,\r\n'b'during the first week of April, after a sudden barometrical fall, a\r\n'b'renewed rise was marked by a heavy gale of wind, lasting five or six\r\n'b'days; then the needle of the instrument remained stationary at a\r\n'b'height of twenty-nine inches and nine-tenths, and the weather appeared\r\n'b'propitious for an excursion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The departure was fixed for the 16th of April, and the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' anchored in Port Balloon, was provisioned for a voyage which might be of\r\n'b'some duration.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding informed Ayrton of the projected expedition, and proposed\r\n'b'that he should take part in it, but Ayrton preferring to remain on\r\n'b'shore, it was decided that he should come to Granite House during the\r\n'b'absence of his companions. Master Jup was ordered to keep him company,\r\n'b'and made no remonstrance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the morning of the 16th of April all the colonists, including Top,\r\n'b'embarked. A fine breeze blew from the south-west, and the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' tacked on leaving Port Balloon so as to reach Reptile End. Of the ninety\r\n'b'miles which the perimeter of the island measured, twenty included the\r\n'b'south coast between the port and the promontory. The wind being right\r\n'b'ahead it was necessary to hug the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It took the whole day to reach the promontory, for the vessel on leaving\r\n'b'port had only two hours of ebb tide and had therefore to make way for\r\n'b'six hours against the flood. It was nightfall before the promontory was\r\n'b'doubled.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor then proposed to the engineer that they should continue\r\n'b'sailing slowly with two reefs in the sail. But Harding preferred to\r\n'b'anchor a few cable-lengths from the shore, so as to survey that part of\r\n'b'the coast during the day. It was agreed also that as they were anxious\r\n'b'for a minute exploration of the coast they should not sail during the\r\n'b'night, but would always, when the weather permitted it, be at anchor\r\n'b'near the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night was passed under the promontory, and the wind having fallen,\r\n'b'nothing disturbed the silence. The passengers, with the exception of the\r\n'b'sailor, scarcely slept as well on board the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d as they would\r\n'b'have done in their rooms at Granite House, but they did sleep however.\r\n'b'Pencroft set sail at break of day, and by going on the larboard tack\r\n'b'they could keep close to the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists knew this beautiful wooded coast, since they had already\r\n'b'explored it on foot, and yet it again excited their admiration. They\r\n'b'coasted along as close in as possible, so as to notice everything,\r\n'b'avoiding always the trunks of trees which floated here and there.\r\n'b'Several times also they anchored, and Gideon Spilett took photographs of\r\n'b'the superb scenery.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About noon the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d arrived at the mouth of Falls River.\r\n'b'Beyond, on the left bank, a few scattered trees appeared, and three\r\n'b'miles further even these dwindled into solitary groups among the western\r\n'b'spurs of the mountain, whose arid ridge sloped down to the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What a contrast between the northern and southern part of the coast!\r\n'b'In proportion as one was woody and fertile so was the other rugged and\r\n'b'barren! It might have been designated as one of those iron coasts, as\r\n'b'they are called in some countries, and its wild confusion appeared to\r\n'b'indicate that a sudden crystallization had been produced in the yet\r\n'b'liquid basalt of some distant geological sea. These stupendous masses\r\n'b'would have terrified the settlers if they had been cast at first on\r\n'b'this part of the island! They had not been able to perceive the sinister\r\n'b'aspect of this shore from the summit of Mount Franklin, for they\r\n'b'overlooked it from too great a height, but viewed from the sea it\r\n'b'presented a wild appearance which could not perhaps be equaled in any\r\n'b'corner of the globe.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d sailed along this coast for the distance of half a\r\n'b'mile. It was easy to see that it was composed of blocks of all sizes,\r\n'b'from twenty to three hundred feet in height, and of all shapes, round\r\n'b'like towers, prismatic like steeples, pyramidal like obelisks, conical\r\n'b'like factory chimneys. An iceberg of the Polar seas could not have been\r\n'b'more capricious in its terrible sublimity! Here, bridges were thrown\r\n'b'from one rock to another; there, arches like those of a wave, into the\r\n'b'depths of which the eye could not penetrate; in one place, large vaulted\r\n'b'excavations presented a monumental aspect; in another, a crowd of\r\n'b'columns, spires, and arches, such as no Gothic cathedral ever\r\n'b'possessed. Every caprice of nature, still more varied than those of the\r\n'b'imagination, appeared on this grand coast, which extended over a length\r\n'b'of eight or nine miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions gazed, with a feeling of surprise\r\n'b'bordering on stupefaction. But, although they remained silent, Top,\r\n'b'not being troubled with feelings of this sort, uttered barks which were\r\n'b'repeated by the thousand echoes of the basaltic cliff. The engineer\r\n'b'even observed that these barks had something strange in them, like those\r\n'b'which the dog had uttered at the mouth of the well in Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go close in,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d sailed as near as possible to the rocky shore.\r\n'b'Perhaps some cave, which it would be advisable to explore, existed\r\n'b'there? But Harding saw nothing, not a cavern, not a cleft which could\r\n'b'serve as a retreat to any being whatever, for the foot of the cliff was\r\n'b'washed by the surf. Soon Top\xe2\x80\x99s barks ceased, and the vessel continued\r\n'b'her course at a few cables-length from the coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the northwest part of the island the shore became again flat and\r\n'b'sandy. A few trees here and there rose above a low, marshy ground, which\r\n'b'the colonists had already surveyed, and in violent contrast to the other\r\n'b'desert shore, life was again manifested by the presence of myriads of\r\n'b'water-fowl. That evening the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d anchored in a small bay\r\n'b'to the north of the island, near the land, such was the depth of water\r\n'b'there. The night passed quietly, for the breeze died away with the last\r\n'b'light of day, and only rose again with the first streaks of dawn.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As it was easy to land, the usual hunters of the colony, that is to say,\r\n'b'Herbert and Gideon Spilett, went for a ramble of two hours or so, and\r\n'b'returned with several strings of wild duck and snipe. Top had\r\n'b'done wonders, and not a bird had been lost, thanks to his zeal and\r\n'b'cleverness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d set sail, and ran\r\n'b'rapidly towards North Mandible Cape, for the wind was right astern and\r\n'b'freshening rapidly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI should not be surprised if a gale came\r\n'b'up from the west. Yesterday the sun set in a very red-looking horizon,\r\n'b'and now, this morning, those mares-tails don\xe2\x80\x99t forbode anything good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These mares-tails are cirrus clouds, scattered in the zenith, their\r\n'b'height from the sea being less than five thousand feet. They look like\r\n'b'light pieces of cotton wool, and their presence usually announces some\r\n'b'sudden change in the weather.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, \xe2\x80\x9clet us carry as much sail as possible, and run\r\n'b'for shelter into Shark Gulf. I think that the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 will be\r\n'b'safe there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand besides, the north coast is merely\r\n'b'sand, very uninteresting to look at.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI shall not be sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cto pass not only to-night\r\n'b'but to-morrow in that bay, which is worth being carefully explored.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think that we shall be obliged to do so, whether we like it or not,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the sky looks very threatening towards the west.\r\n'b'Dirty weather is coming on!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate we have a favorable wind for reaching Cape Mandible,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' observed the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA very fine wind,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we must tack to enter the\r\n'b'gulf, and I should like to see my way clear in these unknown quarters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cQuarters which appear to be filled with rocks,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cif we\r\n'b'judge by what we saw on the south coast of Shark Gulf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cdo as you think best, we will leave it\r\n'b'to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t make your mind uneasy, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall not\r\n'b'expose myself needlessly!
