I would rather a knife were run into my ribs\r\n'b'than a sharp rock into those of my \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That which Pencroft called ribs was the part of his vessel under water,\r\n'b'and he valued it more than his own skin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat o\xe2\x80\x99clock is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTen o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what distance is it to the Cape, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAbout fifteen miles,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of two hours and a half,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand we\r\n'b'shall be off the Cape between twelve and one o\xe2\x80\x99clock. Unluckily, the\r\n'b'tide will be turning at that moment, and will be ebbing out of the gulf.\r\n'b'I am afraid that it will be very difficult to get in, having both wind\r\n'b'and tide against us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the more so that it is a full moon to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\n'b'these April tides are very strong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding, \xe2\x80\x9ccan you not anchor off the Cape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnchor near land, with bad weather coming on!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you thinking of, captain? We should run aground, of a\r\n'b'certainty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will you do then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI shall try to keep in the offing until the flood, that is to say, till\r\n'b'about seven in the evening, and if there is still light enough I will\r\n'b'try to enter the gulf; if not, we must stand off and on during the\r\n'b'night, and we will enter to-morrow at sunrise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs I told you, Pencroft, we will leave it to you,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cif there was only a lighthouse on the coast, it\r\n'b'would be much more convenient for sailors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand this time we shall have no obliging\r\n'b'engineer to light a fire to guide us into port!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, indeed, my dear Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have never thanked you;\r\n'b'but frankly, without that fire we should never have been able--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA fire?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding, much astonished at the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s words.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe mean, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat on board the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'we were very anxious during the few hours before our return, and we\r\n'b'should have passed to windward of the island, if it had not been for the\r\n'b'precaution you took of lighting a fire the night of the 19th of October,\r\n'b'on Prospect Heights.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! That was a lucky idea of mine!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this time,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cunless the idea occurs to\r\n'b'Ayrton, there will be no one to do us that little service!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo! No one!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few minutes after, finding himself alone in the bows of the vessel,\r\n'b'with the reporter, the engineer bent down and whispered,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf there is one thing certain in this world, Spilett, it is that I\r\n'b'never lighted any fire during the night of the 19th of October, neither\r\n'b'on Prospect Heights nor on any other part of the island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 20\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Things happened as Pencroft had predicted, he being seldom mistaken in\r\n'b'his prognostications. The wind rose, and from a fresh breeze it soon\r\n'b'increased to a regular gale; that is to say, it acquired a speed of from\r\n'b'forty to forty-five miles an hour, before which a ship in the open sea\r\n'b'would have run under close-reefed topsails. Now, as it was nearly six\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock when the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d reached the gulf, and as at that\r\n'b'moment the tide turned, it was impossible to enter. They were therefore\r\n'b'compelled to stand off, for even if he had wished to do so, Pencroft\r\n'b'could not have gained the mouth of the Mercy. Hoisting the jib to the\r\n'b'mainmast by way of a storm-sail, he hove to, putting the head of the\r\n'b'vessel towards the land.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Fortunately, although the wind was strong the sea, being sheltered by\r\n'b'the land, did not run very high. They had then little to fear from\r\n'b'the waves, which always endanger small craft. The \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d would\r\n'b'doubtlessly not have capsized, for she was well ballasted, but enormous\r\n'b'masses of water falling on the deck might injure her if her timbers\r\n'b'could not sustain them. Pencroft, as a good sailor, was prepared\r\n'b'for anything. Certainly, he had great confidence in his vessel, but\r\n'b'nevertheless he awaited the return of day with some anxiety.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the night, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett had no opportunity\r\n'b'for talking together, and yet the words pronounced in the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'ear by the engineer were well worth being discussed, together with the\r\n'b'mysterious influence which appeared to reign over Lincoln Island. Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett did not cease from pondering over this new and inexplicable\r\n'b'incident, the appearance of a fire on the coast of the island. The fire\r\n'b'had actually been seen! His companions, Herbert and Pencroft, had seen\r\n'b'it with him! The fire had served to signalize the position of the island\r\n'b'during that dark night, and they had not doubted that it was lighted by\r\n'b'the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s hand; and here was Cyrus Harding expressly declaring that\r\n'b'he had never done anything of the sort! Spilett resolved to recur to\r\n'b'this incident as soon as the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d returned, and to urge Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding to acquaint their companions with these strange facts. Perhaps\r\n'b'it would be decided to make in common a complete investigation of every\r\n'b'part of Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However that might be, on this evening no fire was lighted on these yet\r\n'b'unknown shores, which formed the entrance to the gulf, and the little\r\n'b'vessel stood off during the night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When the first streaks of dawn appeared in the western horizon, the\r\n'b'wind, which had slightly fallen, shifted two points, and enabled\r\n'b'Pencroft to enter the narrow gulf with greater ease. Towards seven\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d weathering the North\r\n'b'Mandible Cape, entered the strait and glided on to the waters, so\r\n'b'strangely enclosed in the frame of lava.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthis bay would make admirable roads, in which a\r\n'b'whole fleet could lie at their ease!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is especially curious,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cis that the gulf\r\n'b'has been formed by two rivers of lava, thrown out by the volcano, and\r\n'b'accumulated by successive eruptions. The result is that the gulf is\r\n'b'completely sheltered on all sides, and I believe that even in the\r\n'b'stormiest weather, the sea here must be as calm as a lake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9csince the wind has only that narrow\r\n'b'entrance between the two capes to get in by, and, besides, the north\r\n'b'cape protects that of the south in a way which would make the entrance\r\n'b'of gusts very difficult. I declare our \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 could stay here\r\n'b'from one end of the year to the other, without even dragging at her\r\n'b'anchor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is rather large for her!\xe2\x80\x9d observed the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell! Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI agree that it is too large\r\n'b'for the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure,\xe2\x80\x99 but if the fleets of the Union were in want of a\r\n'b'harbor in the Pacific, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think they would ever find a better place\r\n'b'than this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are in the shark\xe2\x80\x99s mouth,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Neb, alluding to the form of the\r\n'b'gulf.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRight into its mouth, my honest Neb!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you are not\r\n'b'afraid that it will shut upon us, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mr. Herbert,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cand yet this gulf here doesn\xe2\x80\x99t please\r\n'b'me much! It has a wicked look!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHallo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9chere is Neb turning up his nose at my gulf,\r\n'b'just as I was thinking of presenting it to America!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, at any rate, is the water deep enough?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cfor a\r\n'b'depth sufficient for the keel of the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 would not be enough\r\n'b'for those of our iron-clads.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is easily found out,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the sailor sounded with a long cord, which served him as a\r\n'b'lead-line, and to which was fastened a lump of iron. This cord measured\r\n'b'nearly fifty fathoms, and its entire length was unrolled without finding\r\n'b'any bottom.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cour iron-clads can come here after all!\r\n'b'They would not run aground!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cthis gulf is a regular abyss, but,\r\n'b'taking into consideration the volcanic origin of the island, it is not\r\n'b'astonishing that the sea should offer similar depressions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne would say too,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat these cliffs were perfectly\r\n'b'perpendicular; and I believe that at their foot, even with a line five\r\n'b'or six times longer, Pencroft would not find bottom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is all very well,\xe2\x80\x9d then said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I must point out\r\n'b'to Pencroft that his harbor is wanting in one very important respect!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that, Mr. Spilett?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAn opening, a cutting of some sort, to give access to the interior of\r\n'b'the island. I do not see a spot on which we could land.\xe2\x80\x9d And, in\r\n'b'fact, the steep lava cliffs did not afford a single place suitable for\r\n'b'landing. They formed an insuperable barrier, recalling, but with more\r\n'b'wildness, the fiords of Norway. The \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure,\xe2\x80\x9d coasting as close\r\n'b'as possible along the cliffs, did not discover even a projection which\r\n'b'would allow the passengers to leave the deck.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft consoled himself by saying that with the help of a mine they\r\n'b'could soon open out the cliff when that was necessary, and then, as\r\n'b'there was evidently nothing to be done in the gulf, he steered his\r\n'b'vessel towards the strait and passed out at about two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the\r\n'b'afternoon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, uttering a sigh of satisfaction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'One might really say that the honest Negro did not feel at his ease in\r\n'b'those enormous jaws.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The distance from Mandible Cape to the mouth of the Mercy was not more\r\n'b'than eight miles. The head of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was put towards Granite\r\n'b'House, and a fair wind filling her sails, she ran rapidly along the\r\n'b'coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To the enormous lava rocks succeeded soon those capricious sand dunes,\r\n'b'among which the engineer had been so singularly recovered, and which\r\n'b'seabirds frequented in thousands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Pencroft leaving the point of the islet on his\r\n'b'left, entered the channel which separated it from the coast, and at five\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock the anchor of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was buried in the sand at the\r\n'b'mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists had been absent three days from their dwelling. Ayrton\r\n'b'was waiting for them on the beach, and Jup came joyously to meet them,\r\n'b'giving vent to deep grunts of satisfaction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A complete exploration of the coast of the island had now been made,\r\n'b'and no suspicious appearances had been observed. If any mysterious being\r\n'b'resided on it, it could only be under cover of the impenetrable forest\r\n'b'of the Serpentine Peninsula, to which the colonists had not yet directed\r\n'b'their investigations.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett discussed these things with the engineer, and it was\r\n'b'agreed that they should direct the attention of their companions to the\r\n'b'strange character of certain incidents which had occurred on the island,\r\n'b'and of which the last was the most unaccountable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, Harding, returning to the fact of a fire having been kindled on\r\n'b'the shore by an unknown hand, could not refrain from repeating for the\r\n'b'twentieth time to the reporter,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut are you quite sure of having seen it? Was it not a partial eruption\r\n'b'of the volcano, or perhaps some meteor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cit was certainly a fire lighted by\r\n'b'the hand of man. Besides; question Pencroft and Herbert. They saw it as\r\n'b'I saw it myself, and they will confirm my words.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In consequence, therefore, a few days after, on the 25th of April, in\r\n'b'the evening, when the settlers were all collected on Prospect Heights,\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding began by saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends, I think it my duty to call your attention to certain\r\n'b'incidents which have occurred in the island, on the subject of which I\r\n'b'shall be happy to have your advice. These incidents are, so to speak,\r\n'b'supernatural--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSupernatural!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor, emitting a volume of smoke from\r\n'b'his mouth. \xe2\x80\x9cCan it be possible that our island is supernatural?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft, but mysterious, most certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer;\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cunless you can explain that which Spilett and I have until now failed\r\n'b'to understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak away, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, have you understood,\xe2\x80\x9d then said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9chow was it that\r\n'b'after falling into the sea, I was found a quarter of a mile into the\r\n'b'interior of the island, and that, without my having any consciousness of\r\n'b'my removal there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUnless, being unconscious--\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not admissible,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cBut to continue. Have\r\n'b'you understood how Top was able to discover your retreat five miles from\r\n'b'the cave in which I was lying?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe dog\xe2\x80\x99s instinct--\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSingular instinct!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9csince notwithstanding the\r\n'b'storm of rain and wind which was raging during that night, Top arrived\r\n'b'at the Chimneys, dry and without a speck of mud!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us continue,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you understood how our\r\n'b'dog was so strangely thrown up out of the water of the lake, after his\r\n'b'struggle with the dugong?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo! I confess, not at all,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand the wound which the\r\n'b'dugong had in its side, a wound which seemed to have been made with a\r\n'b'sharp instrument; that can\xe2\x80\x99t be understood, either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us continue again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you understood, my friends,\r\n'b'how that bullet got into the body of the young peccary; how that case\r\n'b'happened to be so fortunately stranded, without there being any trace\r\n'b'of a wreck; how that bottle containing the document presented itself\r\n'b'so opportunely, during our first sea-excursion; how our canoe, having\r\n'b'broken its moorings, floated down the current of the Mercy and rejoined\r\n'b'us at the very moment we needed it; how after the ape invasion the\r\n'b'ladder was so obligingly thrown down from Granite House; and lastly, how\r\n'b'the document, which Ayrton asserts was never written by him, fell into\r\n'b'our hands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As Cyrus Harding thus enumerated, without forgetting one, the singular\r\n'b'incidents which had occurred in the island, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft\r\n'b'stared at each other, not knowing what to reply, for this succession of\r\n'b'incidents, grouped thus for the first time, could not but excite their\r\n'b'surprise to the highest degree.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Pon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft at last, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are right, captain, and it\r\n'b'is difficult to explain all these things!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9ca last fact has just been\r\n'b'added to these, and it is no less incomprehensible than the others!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you were returning from Tabor Island, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\n'b'engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cyou said that a fire appeared on Lincoln Island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are quite certain of having seen this fire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs sure as I see you now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou also, Herbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat fire was blazing like a star of the\r\n'b'first magnitude!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut was it not a star?\xe2\x80\x9d urged the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the sky was covered with thick clouds, and\r\n'b'at any rate a star would not have been so low on the horizon. But Mr.\r\n'b'Spilett saw it as well as we, and he will confirm our words.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will add,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the fire was very bright, and\r\n'b'that it shot up like a sheet of lightning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! exactly,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand it was certainly placed on the\r\n'b'heights of Granite House.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cduring the night of the 19th\r\n'b'of October, neither Neb nor I lighted any fire on the coast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou did not!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, in the height of his astonishment,\r\n'b'not being able to finish his sentence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe did not leave Granite House,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand if a fire\r\n'b'appeared on the coast, it was lighted by another hand than ours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb were stupefied. No illusion could be\r\n'b'possible, and a fire had actually met their eyes during the night of the\r\n'b'19th of October. Yes! they had to acknowledge it, a mystery existed! An\r\n'b'inexplicable influence, evidently favorable to the colonists, but very\r\n'b'irritating to their curiosity, was executed always in the nick of time\r\n'b'on Lincoln Island. Could there be some being hidden in its profoundest\r\n'b'recesses? It was necessary at any cost to ascertain this.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding also reminded his companions of the singular behavior of Top and\r\n'b'Jup when they prowled round the mouth of the well, which placed Granite\r\n'b'House in communication with the sea, and he told them that he had\r\n'b'explored the well, without discovering anything suspicious. The final\r\n'b'resolve taken, in consequence of this conversation, by all the members\r\n'b'of the colony, was that as soon as the fine season returned they would\r\n'b'thoroughly search the whole of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But from that day Pencroft appeared to be anxious. He felt as if the\r\n'b'island which he had made his own personal property belonged to him\r\n'b'entirely no longer, and that he shared it with another master, to\r\n'b'whom, willing or not, he felt subject. Neb and he often talked of those\r\n'b'unaccountable things, and both, their natures inclining them to the\r\n'b'marvelous, were not far from believing that Lincoln Island was under the\r\n'b'dominion of some supernatural power.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, the bad weather came with the month of May, the\r\n'b'November of the northern zones. It appeared that the winter would\r\n'b'be severe and forward. The preparations for the winter season were\r\n'b'therefore commenced without delay.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nevertheless, the colonists were well prepared to meet the winter,\r\n'b'however hard it might be. They had plenty of felt clothing, and the\r\n'b'musmons, very numerous by this time, had furnished an abundance of wool\r\n'b'necessary for the manufacture of this warm material.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is unnecessary to say that Ayrton had been provided with this\r\n'b'comfortable clothing. Cyrus Harding proposed that he should come to\r\n'b'spend the bad season with them in Granite House, where he would be\r\n'b'better lodged than at the corral, and Ayrton promised to do so, as soon\r\n'b'as the last work at the corral was finished. He did this towards the\r\n'b'middle of April. From that time Ayrton shared the common life, and made\r\n'b'himself useful on all occasions; but still humble and sad, he never took\r\n'b'part in the pleasures of his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For the greater part of this, the third winter which the settlers passed\r\n'b'in Lincoln Island, they were confined to Granite House. There were many\r\n'b'violent storms and frightful tempests, which appeared to shake the rocks\r\n'b'to their very foundations. Immense waves threatened to overwhelm the\r\n'b'island, and certainly any vessel anchored near the shore would have\r\n'b'been dashed to pieces. Twice, during one of these hurricanes, the Mercy\r\n'b'swelled to such a degree as to give reason to fear that the bridges\r\n'b'would be swept away, and it was necessary to strengthen those on the\r\n'b'shore, which disappeared under the foaming waters, when the sea beat\r\n'b'against the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It may well be supposed that such storms, comparable to water-spouts in\r\n'b'which were mingled rain and snow, would cause great havoc on the\r\n'b'plateau of Prospect Heights. The mill and the poultry-yard particularly\r\n'b'suffered. The colonists were often obliged to make immediate repairs,\r\n'b'without which the safety of the birds would have been seriously\r\n'b'threatened.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the worst weather, several jaguars and troops of quadrumana\r\n'b'ventured to the edge of the plateau, and it was always to be feared that\r\n'b'the most active and audacious would, urged by hunger, manage to cross\r\n'b'the stream, which besides, when frozen, offered them an easy passage.\r\n'b'Plantations and domestic animals would then have been infallibly\r\n'b'destroyed, without a constant watch, and it was often necessary to\r\n'b'make use of the guns to keep those dangerous visitors at a respectful\r\n'b'distance. Occupation was not wanting to the colonists, for without\r\n'b'reckoning their out-door cares, they had always a thousand plans for the\r\n'b'fitting up of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had also some fine sporting excursions, which were made during the\r\n'b'frost in the vast Tadorn Marsh. Gideon Spilett and Herbert, aided by\r\n'b'Jup and Top, did not miss a shot in the midst of myriads of wild-duck,\r\n'b'snipe, teal, and others. The access to these hunting-grounds was easy;\r\n'b'besides, whether they reached them by the road to Port Balloon, after\r\n'b'having passed the Mercy Bridge, or by turning the rocks from Flotsam\r\n'b'Point, the hunters were never distant from Granite House more than two\r\n'b'or three miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus passed the four winter months, which were really rigorous, that is\r\n'b'to say, June, July, August, and September. But, in short, Granite House\r\n'b'did not suffer much from the inclemency of the weather, and it was\r\n'b'the same with the corral, which, less exposed than the plateau, and\r\n'b'sheltered partly by Mount Franklin, only received the remains of the\r\n'b'hurricanes, already broken by the forests and the high rocks of the\r\n'b'shore. The damages there were consequently of small importance, and the\r\n'b'activity and skill of Ayrton promptly repaired them, when some time in\r\n'b'October he returned to pass a few days in the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this winter, no fresh inexplicable incident occurred. Nothing\r\n'b'strange happened, although Pencroft and Neb were on the watch for the\r\n'b'most insignificant facts to which they attached any mysterious cause.\r\n'b'Top and Jup themselves no longer growled round the well or gave any\r\n'b'signs of uneasiness. It appeared, therefore, as if the series of\r\n'b'supernatural incidents was interrupted, although they often talked of\r\n'b'them during the evenings in Granite House, and they remained thoroughly\r\n'b'resolved that the island should be searched, even in those parts the\r\n'b'most difficult to explore. But an event of the highest importance, and\r\n'b'of which the consequences might be terrible, momentarily diverted from\r\n'b'their projects Cyrus Harding and his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the month of October. The fine season was swiftly returning.\r\n'b'Nature was reviving; and among the evergreen foliage of the coniferae\r\n'b'which formed the border of the wood, already appeared the young leaves\r\n'b'of the banksias, deodars, and other trees.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It may be remembered that Gideon Spilett and Herbert had, at different\r\n'b'times, taken photographic views of Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now, on the 17th of this month of October, towards three o\xe2\x80\x99clock in\r\n'b'the afternoon, Herbert, enticed by the charms of the sky, thought of\r\n'b'reproducing Union Bay, which was opposite to Prospect Heights, from Cape\r\n'b'Mandible to Claw Cape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The horizon was beautifully clear, and the sea, undulating under a soft\r\n'b'breeze, was as calm as the waters of a lake, sparkling here and there\r\n'b'under the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The apparatus had been placed at one of the windows of the dining-room\r\n'b'at Granite House, and consequently overlooked the shore and the bay.\r\n'b'Herbert proceeded as he was accustomed to do, and the negative obtained,\r\n'b'he went away to fix it by means of the chemicals deposited in a dark\r\n'b'nook of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Returning to the bright light, and examining it well, Herbert perceived\r\n'b'on his negative an almost imperceptible little spot on the sea horizon.\r\n'b'He endeavored to make it disappear by reiterated washing, but could not\r\n'b'accomplish it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a flaw in the glass,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And then he had the curiosity to examine this flaw with a strong\r\n'b'magnifier which he unscrewed from one of the telescopes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But he had scarcely looked at it, when he uttered a cry, and the glass\r\n'b'almost fell from his hands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Immediately running to the room in which Cyrus Harding then was, he\r\n'b'extended the negative and magnifier towards the engineer, pointing out\r\n'b'the little spot.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding examined it; then seizing his telescope he rushed to the window.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The telescope, after having slowly swept the horizon, at last stopped on\r\n'b'the looked-for spot, and Cyrus Harding, lowering it, pronounced one word\r\n'b'only,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA vessel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And in fact a vessel was in sight, off Lincoln Island!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'PART 3\r\n'b'\r\n'b'THE SECRET OF THE ISLAND\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 1\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now two years and a half since the castaways from the balloon had\r\n'b'been thrown on Lincoln Island, and during that period there had been no\r\n'b'communication between them and their fellow-creatures. Once the reporter\r\n'b'had attempted to communicate with the inhabited world by confiding to\r\n'b'a bird a letter which contained the secret of their situation, but that\r\n'b'was a chance on which it was impossible to reckon seriously. Ayrton,\r\n'b'alone, under the circumstances which have been related, had come to\r\n'b'join the little colony. Now, suddenly, on this day, the 17th of October,\r\n'b'other men had unexpectedly appeared in sight of the island, on that\r\n'b'deserted sea!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There could be no doubt about it! A vessel was there! But would she\r\n'b'pass on, or would she put into port? In a few hours the colonists would\r\n'b'definitely know what to expect.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Herbert having immediately called Gideon Spilett,\r\n'b'Pencroft, and Neb into the dining-room of Granite House, told them\r\n'b'what had happened. Pencroft, seizing the telescope, rapidly swept the\r\n'b'horizon, and stopping on the indicated point, that is to say, on\r\n'b'that which had made the almost imperceptible spot on the photographic\r\n'b'negative,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m blessed but it is really a vessel!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, in a voice which\r\n'b'did not express any great amount of satisfaction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs she coming here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible to say anything yet,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cfor her rigging\r\n'b'alone is above the horizon, and not a bit of her hull can be seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the lad.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWait,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And for a considerable time the settlers remained silent, given up to\r\n'b'all the thoughts, and the emotions, all the fears, all the hopes, which\r\n'b'were aroused by this incident--the most important which had occurred\r\n'b'since their arrival in Lincoln Island. Certainly, the colonists were not\r\n'b'in the situation of castaways abandoned on a sterile islet, constantly\r\n'b'contending against a cruel nature for their miserable existence, and\r\n'b'incessantly tormented by the longing to return to inhabited countries.\r\n'b'Pencroft and Neb, especially, who felt themselves at once so happy and\r\n'b'so rich, would not have left their island without regret. They were\r\n'b'accustomed, besides, to this new life in the midst of the domain which\r\n'b'their intelligence had as it were civilized. But at any rate this ship\r\n'b'brought news from the world, perhaps even from their native land. It was\r\n'b'bringing fellow-creatures to them, and it may be conceived how deeply\r\n'b'their hearts were moved at the sight!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From time to time Pencroft took the glass and rested himself at the\r\n'b'window. From thence he very attentively examined the vessel, which was\r\n'b'at a distance of twenty miles to the east. The colonists had as yet,\r\n'b'therefore, no means of signalizing their presence. A flag would not have\r\n'b'been perceived; a gun would not have been heard; a fire would not have\r\n'b'been visible. However, it was certain that the island, overtopped by\r\n'b'Mount Franklin, could not escape the notice of the vessel\xe2\x80\x99s lookout. But\r\n'b'why was the ship coming there? Was it simple chance which brought it to\r\n'b'that part of the Pacific, where the maps mentioned no land except Tabor\r\n'b'Island, which itself was out of the route usually followed by vessels\r\n'b'from the Polynesian Archipelagoes, from New Zealand, and from the\r\n'b'American coast? To this question, which each one asked himself, a reply\r\n'b'was suddenly made by Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCan it be the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cDuncan,\xe2\x80\x9d as has been said, was Lord Glenarvan\xe2\x80\x99s yacht, which had\r\n'b'left Ayrton on the islet, and which was to return there someday to fetch\r\n'b'him. Now, the islet was not so far distant from Lincoln Island, but\r\n'b'that a vessel, standing for the one, could pass in sight of the other. A\r\n'b'hundred and fifty miles only separated them in longitude, and seventy in\r\n'b'latitude.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must tell Ayrton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand send for him\r\n'b'immediately. He alone can say if it is the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was the opinion of all, and the reporter, going to the telegraphic\r\n'b'apparatus which placed the corral in communication with Granite House,\r\n'b'sent this telegram:--\xe2\x80\x9cCome with all possible speed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few minutes the bell sounded.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am coming,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then the settlers continued to watch the vessel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf it is the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cAyrton will recognize her\r\n'b'without difficulty, since he sailed on board her for some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if he recognizes her,\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cit will agitate him\r\n'b'exceedingly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding; \xe2\x80\x9cbut now Ayrton is worthy to return on\r\n'b'board the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan,\xe2\x80\x99 and pray Heaven that it is indeed Lord Glenarvan\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'yacht, for I should be suspicious of any other vessel. These are\r\n'b'ill-famed seas, and I have always feared a visit from Malay pirates to\r\n'b'our island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe could defend it,\xe2\x80\x99, cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it would be\r\n'b'better not to have to defend it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA useless observation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cLincoln Island is unknown to\r\n'b'navigators, since it is not marked even on the most recent maps. Do\r\n'b'you think, Cyrus, that that is a sufficient motive for a ship, finding\r\n'b'herself unexpectedly in sight of new land, to try and visit rather than\r\n'b'avoid it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think so too,\xe2\x80\x9d added the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cIt may even be said that it is\r\n'b'the duty of a captain to come and survey any land or island not yet\r\n'b'known, and Lincoln Island is in this position.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9csuppose this vessel comes and anchors there a\r\n'b'few cables-lengths from our island, what shall we do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This sudden question remained at first without any reply. But Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding, after some moments\xe2\x80\x99 thought, replied in the calm tone which was\r\n'b'usual to him,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat we shall do, my friends? What we ought to do is this:--we will\r\n'b'communicate with the ship, we will take our passage on board her, and we\r\n'b'will leave our island, after having taken possession of it in the name\r\n'b'of the United States. Then we will return with any who may wish to\r\n'b'follow us to colonize it definitely, and endow the American Republic\r\n'b'with a useful station in this part of the Pacific Ocean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand that will be no small present\r\n'b'which we shall make to our country! The colonization is already almost\r\n'b'finished; names are given to every part of the island; there is\r\n'b'a natural port, fresh water, roads, a telegraph, a dockyard, and\r\n'b'manufactories; and there will be nothing to be done but to inscribe\r\n'b'Lincoln Island on the maps!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut if anyone seizes it in our absence?\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHang it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cI would rather remain all alone to guard\r\n'b'it: and trust to Pencroft, they shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t steal it from him, like a\r\n'b'watch from the pocket of a swell!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For an hour it was impossible to say with any certainty whether the\r\n'b'vessel was or was not standing towards Lincoln Island. She was\r\n'b'nearer, but in what direction was she sailing? This Pencroft could not\r\n'b'determine. However, as the wind was blowing from the northeast, in all\r\n'b'probability the vessel was sailing on the starboard tack. Besides, the\r\n'b'wind was favorable for bringing her towards the island, and, the sea\r\n'b'being calm, she would not be afraid to approach although the shallows\r\n'b'were not marked on the chart.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards four o\xe2\x80\x99clock--an hour after he had been sent for--Ayrton arrived\r\n'b'at Granite House. He entered the dining-room saying,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt your service, gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding gave him his hand, as was his custom to do, and, leading\r\n'b'him to the window,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have begged you to come here for an important\r\n'b'reason. A ship is in sight of the island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton at first paled slightly, and for a moment his eyes became dim;\r\n'b'then, leaning out the window, he surveyed the horizon, but could see\r\n'b'nothing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTake this telescope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand look carefully, Ayrton, for\r\n'b'it is possible that this ship may be the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 come to these seas for\r\n'b'the purpose of taking you home again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Duncan!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Ayrton. \xe2\x80\x9cAlready?\xe2\x80\x9d This last word escaped\r\n'b'Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s lips as if involuntarily, and his head drooped upon his hands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Did not twelve years\xe2\x80\x99 solitude on a desert island appear to him a\r\n'b'sufficient expiation? Did not the penitent yet feel himself pardoned,\r\n'b'either in his own eyes or in the eyes of others?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cno! it cannot be the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook, Ayrton,\xe2\x80\x9d then said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is necessary that we\r\n'b'should know beforehand what to expect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton took the glass and pointed it in the direction indicated. During\r\n'b'some minutes he examined the horizon without moving, without uttering a\r\n'b'word. Then,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is indeed a vessel,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I do not think she is the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Duncan.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you not think so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99 is a steam-yacht, and I cannot perceive any trace\r\n'b'of smoke either above or near that vessel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps she is simply sailing,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cThe wind is\r\n'b'favorable for the direction which she appears to be taking, and she may\r\n'b'be anxious to economize her coal, being so far from land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible that you may be right, Mr. Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ayrton,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cand that the vessel has extinguished her fires. We must wait until she\r\n'b'is nearer, and then we shall soon know what to expect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So saying, Ayrton sat down in a corner of the room and remained silent.\r\n'b'The colonists again discussed the strange ship, but Ayrton took no\r\n'b'part in the conversation. All were in such a mood that they found it\r\n'b'impossible to continue their work. Gideon Spilett and Pencroft were\r\n'b'particularly nervous, going, coming, not able to remain still in one\r\n'b'place. Herbert felt more curiosity. Neb alone maintained his usual\r\n'b'calm manner. Was not his country that where his master was? As to the\r\n'b'engineer, he remained plunged in deep thought, and in his heart feared\r\n'b'rather than desired the arrival of the ship. In the meanwhile, the\r\n'b'vessel was a little nearer the island. With the aid of the glass, it was\r\n'b'ascertained that she was a brig, and not one of those Malay proas, which\r\n'b'are generally used by the pirates of the Pacific. It was, therefore,\r\n'b'reasonable to believe that the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s apprehensions would not be\r\n'b'justified, and that the presence of this vessel in the vicinity of the\r\n'b'island was fraught with no danger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, after a minute examination, was able positively to affirm that\r\n'b'the vessel was rigged as a brig, and that she was standing obliquely\r\n'b'towards the coast, on the starboard tack, under her topsails and\r\n'b'top-gallant-sails. This was confirmed by Ayrton. But by continuing in\r\n'b'this direction she must soon disappear behind Claw Cape, as the wind\r\n'b'was from the southwest, and to watch her it would be then necessary\r\n'b'to ascend the height of Washington Bay, near Port Balloon--a provoking\r\n'b'circumstance, for it was already five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, and the\r\n'b'twilight would soon make any observation extremely difficult.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall we do when night comes on?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cShall we\r\n'b'light a fire, so as to signal our presence on the coast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was a serious question, and yet, although the engineer still\r\n'b'retained some of his presentiments, it was answered in the affirmative.\r\n'b'During the night the ship might disappear and leave for ever, and, this\r\n'b'ship gone, would another ever return to the waters of Lincoln Island?\r\n'b'Who could foresee what the future would then have in store for the\r\n'b'colonists?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cwe ought to make known to that vessel,\r\n'b'whoever she may be, that the island is inhabited. To neglect the\r\n'b'opportunity which is offered to us might be to create everlasting\r\n'b'regrets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was therefore decided that Neb and Pencroft should go to Port\r\n'b'Balloon, and that there, at nightfall, they should light an immense\r\n'b'fire, the blaze of which would necessarily attract the attention of the\r\n'b'brig.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But at the moment when Neb and the sailor were preparing to leave\r\n'b'Granite House, the vessel suddenly altered her course, and stood\r\n'b'directly for Union Bay. The brig was a good sailer, for she approached\r\n'b'rapidly. Neb and Pencroft put off their departure, therefore, and the\r\n'b'glass was put into Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s hands, that he might ascertain for certain\r\n'b'whether the ship was or was not the \xe2\x80\x9cDuncan.\xe2\x80\x9d The Scotch yacht was also\r\n'b'rigged as a brig. The question was, whether a chimney could be discerned\r\n'b'between the two masts of the vessel, which was now at a distance of only\r\n'b'five miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The horizon was still very clear. The examination was easy, and Ayrton\r\n'b'soon let the glass fall again, saying--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not the \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99! It could not be!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft again brought the brig within the range of the telescope, and\r\n'b'could see that she was of between three and four hundred tons burden,\r\n'b'wonderfully narrow, well-masted, admirably built, and must be a very\r\n'b'rapid sailer. But to what nation did she belong? That was difficult to\r\n'b'say.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d added the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9ca flag is floating from her peak, but I\r\n'b'cannot distinguish the colors of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn half an hour we shall be certain about that,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, it is very evident that the intention of the captain of this\r\n'b'ship is to land, and, consequently, if not today, to-morrow at the\r\n'b'latest, we shall make his acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is best to know whom we have to deal\r\n'b'with, and I shall not be sorry to recognize that fellow\xe2\x80\x99s colors!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, while thus speaking, the sailor never left the glass. The day began\r\n'b'to fade, and with the day the breeze fell also. The brig\xe2\x80\x99s ensign hung\r\n'b'in folds, and it became more and more difficult to observe it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not the American flag,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft from time to time, \xe2\x80\x9cnor the\r\n'b'English, the red of which could be easily seen, nor the French or German\r\n'b'colors, nor the white flag of Russia, nor the yellow of Spain. One would\r\n'b'say it was all one color. Let\xe2\x80\x99s see: in these seas, what do we generally\r\n'b'meet with? The Chilean flag?--but that is tri-color. Brazilian?--it is\r\n'b'green. Japanese?--it is yellow and black, while this--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment the breeze blew out the unknown flag. Ayrton seizing the\r\n'b'telescope which the sailor had put down, put it to his eye, and in a\r\n'b'hoarse voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe black flag!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And indeed the somber bunting was floating from the mast of the brig,\r\n'b'and they had now good reason for considering her to be a suspicious\r\n'b'vessel!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Had the engineer, then, been right in his presentiments? Was this a\r\n'b'pirate vessel? Did she scour the Pacific, competing with the Malay proas\r\n'b'which still infest it? For what had she come to look at the shores of\r\n'b'Lincoln Island? Was it to them an unknown island, ready to become\r\n'b'a magazine for stolen cargoes? Had she come to find on the coast a\r\n'b'sheltered port for the winter months? Was the settlers\xe2\x80\x99 honest domain\r\n'b'destined to be transformed into an infamous refuge--the headquarters of\r\n'b'the piracy of the Pacific?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All these ideas instinctively presented themselves to the colonists\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'imaginations. There was no doubt, besides, of the signification which\r\n'b'must be attached to the color of the hoisted flag. It was that of\r\n'b'pirates! It was that which the \xe2\x80\x9cDuncan\xe2\x80\x9d would have carried, had the\r\n'b'convicts succeeded in their criminal design! No time was lost before\r\n'b'discussing it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps this vessel only wishes to\r\n'b'survey the coast of the island. Perhaps her crew will not land. There is\r\n'b'a chance of it. However that may be, we ought to do everything we can to\r\n'b'hide our presence here. The windmill on Prospect Heights is too easily\r\n'b'seen. Let Ayrton and Neb go and take down the sails. We must also\r\n'b'conceal the windows of Granite House with thick branches. All the fires\r\n'b'must be extinguished, so that nothing may betray the presence of men on\r\n'b'the island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd our vessel?\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cshe is sheltered in Port Balloon, and I defy\r\n'b'any of those rascals there to find her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s orders were immediately executed. Neb and Ayrton\r\n'b'ascended the plateau, and took the necessary precautions to conceal\r\n'b'any indication of a settlement. While they were thus occupied, their\r\n'b'companions went to the border of Jacamar Wood, and brought back a large\r\n'b'quantity of branches and creepers, which would at some distance appear\r\n'b'as natural foliage, and thus disguise the windows in the granite cliff.\r\n'b'At the same time, the ammunition and guns were placed ready so as to be\r\n'b'at hand in case of an unexpected attack.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When all these precautions had been taken,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, and his voice betrayed some emotion, \xe2\x80\x9cif the\r\n'b'wretches endeavor to seize Lincoln Island, we shall defend it--shall we\r\n'b'not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand if necessary we will die to\r\n'b'defend it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer extended his hand to his companions, who pressed it warmly.\r\n'b'Ayrton remained in his corner, not joining the colonists. Perhaps he,\r\n'b'the former convict, still felt himself unworthy to do so!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s mind, and going to\r\n'b'him--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, Ayrton,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat will you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy duty,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He then took up his station near the window and gazed through the\r\n'b'foliage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now half-past seven. The sun had disappeared twenty minutes ago\r\n'b'behind Granite House. Consequently the Eastern horizon was becoming\r\n'b'obscured. In the meanwhile the brig continued to advance towards Union\r\n'b'Bay. She was now not more than two miles off, and exactly opposite the\r\n'b'plateau of Prospect Heights, for after having tacked off Claw Cape, she\r\n'b'had drifted towards the north in the current of the rising tide. One\r\n'b'might have said that at this distance she had already entered the vast\r\n'b'bay, for a straight line drawn from Claw Cape to Cape Mandible would\r\n'b'have rested on her starboard quarter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Was the brig about to penetrate far into the bay? That was the first\r\n'b'question. When once in the bay, would she anchor there? That was the\r\n'b'second. Would she not content herself with only surveying the coast, and\r\n'b'stand out to sea again without landing her crew? They would know this in\r\n'b'an hour. The colonists could do nothing but wait.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had not seen the suspected vessel hoist the black flag\r\n'b'without deep anxiety. Was it not a direct menace against the work which\r\n'b'he and his companions had till now conducted so successfully? Had these\r\n'b'pirates--for the sailors of the brig could be nothing else--already\r\n'b'visited the island, since on approaching it they had hoisted their\r\n'b'colors. Had they formerly invaded it, so that certain unaccountable\r\n'b'peculiarities might be explained in this way? Did there exist in the as\r\n'b'yet unexplored parts some accomplice ready to enter into communication\r\n'b'with them?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To all these questions which he mentally asked himself, Harding knew not\r\n'b'what to reply; but he felt that the safety of the colony could not but\r\n'b'be seriously threatened by the arrival of the brig.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, he and his companions were determined to fight to the last\r\n'b'gasp. It would have been very important to know if the pirates\r\n'b'were numerous and better armed than the colonists. But how was this\r\n'b'information to be obtained?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Night fell. The new moon had disappeared. Profound darkness enveloped\r\n'b'the island and the sea. No light could pierce through the heavy piles\r\n'b'of clouds on the horizon. The wind had died away completely with the\r\n'b'twilight. Not a leaf rustled on the trees, not a ripple murmured on\r\n'b'the shore. Nothing could be seen of the ship, all her lights being\r\n'b'extinguished, and if she was still in sight of the island, her\r\n'b'whereabouts could not be discovered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell! who knows?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps that cursed craft will stand\r\n'b'off during the night, and we shall see nothing of her at daybreak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As if in reply to the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s observation, a bright light flashed in\r\n'b'the darkness, and a cannon-shot was heard.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The vessel was still there and had guns on board.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Six seconds elapsed between the flash and the report.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Therefore the brig was about a mile and a quarter from the coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the same time, the chains were heard rattling through the\r\n'b'hawse-holes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The vessel had just anchored in sight of Granite House!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 2\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no longer any doubt as to the pirates\xe2\x80\x99 intentions. They had\r\n'b'dropped anchor at a short distance from the island, and it was evident\r\n'b'that the next day by means of their boats they purposed to land on the\r\n'b'beach!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions were ready to act, but, determined\r\n'b'though they were, they must not forget to be prudent. Perhaps their\r\n'b'presence might still be concealed in the event of the pirates contenting\r\n'b'themselves with landing on the shore without examining the interior of\r\n'b'the island. It might be, indeed, that their only intention was to obtain\r\n'b'fresh water from the Mercy, and it was not impossible that the bridge,\r\n'b'thrown across a mile and a half from the mouth, and the manufactory at\r\n'b'the Chimneys might escape their notice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But why was that flag hoisted at the brig\xe2\x80\x99s peak? What was that shot\r\n'b'fired for? Pure bravado doubtless, unless it was a sign of the act of\r\n'b'taking possession. Harding knew now that the vessel was well armed. And\r\n'b'what had the colonists of Lincoln Island to reply to the pirates\xe2\x80\x99 guns?\r\n'b'A few muskets only.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9chere we are in an impregnable\r\n'b'position. The enemy cannot discover the mouth of the outlet, now that it\r\n'b'is hidden under reeds and grass, and consequently it would be impossible\r\n'b'for them to penetrate into Granite House.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut our plantations, our poultry-yard, our corral, all, everything!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' exclaimed Pencroft, stamping his foot. \xe2\x80\x9cThey may spoil everything,\r\n'b'destroy everything in a few hours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEverything, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand we have no means of\r\n'b'preventing them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre they numerous? that is the question,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cIf they\r\n'b'are not more than a dozen, we shall be able to stop them, but forty,\r\n'b'fifty, more perhaps!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d then said Ayrton, advancing towards the engineer,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cwill you give me leave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor what, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo go to that vessel to find out the strength of her crew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut Ayrton--\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, hesitating, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will risk your\r\n'b'life--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is more than your duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have more than my duty to do,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWill you go to the ship in the boat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir, but I will swim. A boat would be seen where a man may glide\r\n'b'between wind and water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know that the brig is a mile and a quarter from the shore?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\n'b'Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am a good swimmer, Mr. Herbert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you it is risking your life,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is no matter,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ayrton. \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding, I ask this as a\r\n'b'favor. Perhaps it will be a means of raising me in my own eyes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGo, Ayrton,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, who felt sure that a refusal would\r\n'b'have deeply wounded the former convict, now become an honest man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will accompany you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou mistrust me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ayrton quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then more humbly,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo! no!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Harding with animation, \xe2\x80\x9cno, Ayrton, Pencroft does\r\n'b'not mistrust you. You interpret his words wrongly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI only propose to accompany Ayrton as\r\n'b'far as the islet. It may be, although it is scarcely possible, that one\r\n'b'of these villains has landed, and in that case two men will not be too\r\n'b'many to hinder him from giving the alarm. I will wait for Ayrton on the\r\n'b'islet, and he shall go alone to the vessel, since he has proposed to do\r\n'b'so.\xe2\x80\x9d These things agreed to, Ayrton made preparations for his departure.\r\n'b'His plan was bold, but it might succeed, thanks to the darkness of the\r\n'b'night. Once arrived at the vessel\xe2\x80\x99s side, Ayrton, holding on to the main\r\n'b'chains, might reconnoiter the number and perhaps overhear the intentions\r\n'b'of the pirates.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton and Pencroft, followed by their companions, descended to the\r\n'b'beach. Ayrton undressed and rubbed himself with grease, so as to suffer\r\n'b'less from the temperature of the water, which was still cold. He might,\r\n'b'indeed, be obliged to remain in it for several hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Neb, during this time, had gone to fetch the boat, moored\r\n'b'a few hundred feet higher up, on the bank of the Mercy, and by the time\r\n'b'they returned, Ayrton was ready to start. A coat was thrown over his\r\n'b'shoulders, and the settlers all came round him to press his hand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton then shoved off with Pencroft in the boat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was half-past ten in the evening when the two adventurers disappeared\r\n'b'in the darkness. Their companions returned to wait at the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The channel was easily traversed, and the boat touched the opposite\r\n'b'shore of the islet. This was not done without precaution, for fear lest\r\n'b'the pirates might be roaming about there. But after a careful survey,\r\n'b'it was evident that the islet was deserted. Ayrton then, followed by\r\n'b'Pencroft, crossed it with a rapid step, scaring the birds nestled in the\r\n'b'holes of the rocks; then, without hesitating, he plunged into the sea,\r\n'b'and swam noiselessly in the direction of the ship, in which a few lights\r\n'b'had recently appeared, showing her exact situation. As to Pencroft,\r\n'b'he crouched down in a cleft of the rock, and awaited the return of his\r\n'b'companion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, Ayrton, swimming with a vigorous stroke, glided\r\n'b'through the sheet of water without producing the slightest ripple. His\r\n'b'head just emerged above it and his eyes were fixed on the dark hull of\r\n'b'the brig, from which the lights were reflected in the water. He thought\r\n'b'only of the duty which he had promised to accomplish, and nothing of the\r\n'b'danger which he ran, not only on board the ship, but in the sea, often\r\n'b'frequented by sharks. The current bore him along and he rapidly receded\r\n'b'from the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Half an hour afterwards, Ayrton, without having been either seen or\r\n'b'heard, arrived at the ship and caught hold of the main-chains. He took\r\n'b'breath, then, hoisting himself up, he managed to reach the extremity of\r\n'b'the cutwater. There were drying several pairs of sailors\xe2\x80\x99 trousers. He\r\n'b'put on a pair. Then settling himself firmly, he listened. They were not\r\n'b'sleeping on board the brig. On the contrary, they were talking, singing,\r\n'b'laughing. And these were the sentences, accompanied with oaths, which\r\n'b'principally struck Ayrton:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur brig is a famous acquisition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShe sails well, and merits her name of the \xe2\x80\x98Speedy.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShe would show all the navy of Norfolk a clean pair of heels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah for her captain!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah for Bob Harvey!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What Ayrton felt when he overheard this fragment of conversation may be\r\n'b'understood when it is known that in this Bob Harvey he recognized one\r\n'b'of his old Australian companions, a daring sailor, who had continued his\r\n'b'criminal career. Bob Harvey had seized, on the shores of Norfolk Island\r\n'b'this brig, which was loaded with arms, ammunition, utensils, and tools\r\n'b'of all sorts, destined for one of the Sandwich Islands. All his gang had\r\n'b'gone on board, and pirates after having been convicts, these wretches,\r\n'b'more ferocious than the Malays themselves, scoured the Pacific,\r\n'b'destroying vessels, and massacring their crews.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The convicts spoke loudly, they recounted their deeds, drinking deeply\r\n'b'at the same time, and this is what Ayrton gathered. The actual crew\r\n'b'of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d was composed solely of English prisoners, escaped from\r\n'b'Norfolk Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Here it may be well to explain what this island was. In 29deg 2\xe2\x80\x99 south\r\n'b'latitude, and 165deg 42\xe2\x80\x99 east longitude, to the east of Australia, is\r\n'b'found a little island, six miles in circumference, overlooked by Mount\r\n'b'Pitt, which rises to a height of 1,100 feet above the level of the sea.\r\n'b'This is Norfolk Island, once the seat of an establishment in which were\r\n'b'lodged the most intractable convicts from the English penitentiaries.\r\n'b'They numbered 500, under an iron discipline, threatened with terrible\r\n'b'punishments, and were guarded by 150 soldiers, and 150 employed\r\n'b'under the orders of the governor. It would be difficult to imagine\r\n'b'a collection of greater ruffians. Sometimes,--although very\r\n'b'rarely,--notwithstanding the extreme surveillance of which they were\r\n'b'the object, many managed to escape, and seizing vessels which they\r\n'b'surprised, they infested the Polynesian Archipelagoes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus had Bob Harvey and his companions done. Thus had Ayrton formerly\r\n'b'wished to do. Bob Harvey had seized the brig \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy,\xe2\x80\x9d anchored in sight\r\n'b'of Norfolk Island; the crew had been massacred; and for a year this ship\r\n'b'had scoured the Pacific, under the command of Harvey, now a pirate, and\r\n'b'well known to Ayrton!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The convicts were, for the most part, assembled under the poop; but a\r\n'b'few, stretched on the deck, were talking loudly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The conversation still continued amid shouts and libations. Ayrton\r\n'b'learned that chance alone had brought the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d in sight of Lincoln\r\n'b'Island; Bob Harvey had never yet set foot on it; but, as Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'had conjectured, finding this unknown land in his course, its position\r\n'b'being marked on no chart, he had formed the project of visiting it, and,\r\n'b'if he found it suitable, of making it the brig\xe2\x80\x99s headquarters.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the black flag hoisted at the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d peak, and the gun which\r\n'b'had been fired, in imitation of men-of-war when they lower their\r\n'b'colors, it was pure piratical bravado. It was in no way a signal, and no\r\n'b'communication yet existed between the convicts and Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers\xe2\x80\x99 domain was now menaced with terrible danger. Evidently\r\n'b'the island, with its water, its harbor, its resources of all kinds so\r\n'b'increased in value by the colonists, and the concealment afforded by\r\n'b'Granite House, could not but be convenient for the convicts; in their\r\n'b'hands it would become an excellent place of refuge, and, being unknown,\r\n'b'it would assure them, for a long time perhaps, impunity and security.\r\n'b'Evidently, also, the lives of the settlers would not be respected, and\r\n'b'Bob Harvey and his accomplices\xe2\x80\x99 first care would be to massacre them\r\n'b'without mercy. Harding and his companions had, therefore, not even the\r\n'b'choice of flying and hiding themselves in the island, since the convicts\r\n'b'intended to reside there, and since, in the event of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' departing on an expedition, it was probable that some of the crew would\r\n'b'remain on shore, so as to settle themselves there. Therefore, it\r\n'b'would be necessary to fight, to destroy every one of these scoundrels,\r\n'b'unworthy of pity, and against whom any means would be right. So thought\r\n'b'Ayrton, and he well knew that Cyrus Harding would be of his way of\r\n'b'thinking.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But was resistance and, in the last place, victory possible? That would\r\n'b'depend on the equipment of the brig, and the number of men which she\r\n'b'carried.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This Ayrton resolved to learn at any cost, and as an hour after his\r\n'b'arrival the vociferations had begun to die away, and as a large number\r\n'b'of the convicts were already buried in a drunken sleep, Ayrton did not\r\n'b'hesitate to venture onto the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d deck, which the extinguished\r\n'b'lanterns now left in total darkness. He hoisted himself onto the\r\n'b'cutwater, and by the bowsprit arrived at the forecastle. Then, gliding\r\n'b'among the convicts stretched here and there, he made the round of the\r\n'b'ship, and found that the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d carried four guns, which would throw\r\n'b'shot of from eight to ten pounds in weight. He found also, on touching\r\n'b'them that these guns were breech-loaders. They were therefore, of modern\r\n'b'make, easily used, and of terrible effect.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the men lying on the deck, they were about ten in number, but\r\n'b'it was to be supposed that more were sleeping down below. Besides, by\r\n'b'listening to them, Ayrton had understood that there were fifty on\r\n'b'board. That was a large number for the six settlers of Lincoln Island to\r\n'b'contend with! But now, thanks to Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s devotion, Cyrus Harding would\r\n'b'not be surprised, he would know the strength of his adversaries, and\r\n'b'would make his arrangements accordingly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was nothing more for Ayrton to do but to return, and render to his\r\n'b'companions an account of the mission with which he had charged himself,\r\n'b'and he prepared to regain the bows of the brig, so that he might let\r\n'b'himself down into the water. But to this man, whose wish was, as he had\r\n'b'said, to do more than his duty, there came an heroic thought. This was\r\n'b'to sacrifice his own life, but save the island and the colonists. Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding evidently could not resist fifty ruffians, all well armed, who,\r\n'b'either by penetrating by main force into Granite House, or by starving\r\n'b'out the besieged, could obtain from them what they wanted. And then he\r\n'b'thought of his preservers--those who had made him again a man, and an\r\n'b'honest mm, those to whom he owed all--murdered without pity, their works\r\n'b'destroyed, their island turned into a pirates\xe2\x80\x99 den! He said to himself\r\n'b'that he, Ayrton, was the principal cause of so many disasters, since his\r\n'b'old companion, Bob Harvey, had but realized his own plans, and a\r\n'b'feeling of horror took possession of him. Then he was seized with an\r\n'b'irresistible desire to blow up the brig and with her, all whom she had\r\n'b'on board. He would perish in the explosion, but he would have done his\r\n'b'duty.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton did not hesitate. To reach the powder-room, which is always\r\n'b'situated in the after-part of a vessel, was easy. There would be no want\r\n'b'of powder in a vessel which followed such a trade, and a spark would be\r\n'b'enough to destroy it in an instant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton stole carefully along the between-decks, strewn with numerous\r\n'b'sleepers, overcome more by drunkenness than sleep. A lantern was lighted\r\n'b'at the foot of the mainmast, round which was hung a gun-rack, furnished\r\n'b'with weapons of all sorts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton took a revolver from the rack, and assured himself that it was\r\n'b'loaded and primed. Nothing more was needed to accomplish the work of\r\n'b'destruction. He then glided towards the stern, so as to arrive under the\r\n'b'brig\xe2\x80\x99s poop at the powder-magazine.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was difficult to proceed along the dimly lighted deck without\r\n'b'stumbling over some half-sleeping convict, who retorted by oaths and\r\n'b'kicks. Ayrton was, therefore, more than once obliged to halt. But at\r\n'b'last he arrived at the partition dividing the aftercabin, and found the\r\n'b'door opening into the magazine itself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton, compelled to force it open, set to work. It was a difficult\r\n'b'operation to perform without noise, for he had to break a padlock. But\r\n'b'under his vigorous hand, the padlock broke, and the door was open.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment a hand was laid on Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a tall man, in a harsh voice, who,\r\n'b'standing in the shadow, quickly threw the light of a lantern in Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'face.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton drew back. In the rapid flash of the lantern, he had recognized\r\n'b'his former accomplice, Bob Harvey, who could not have known him, as he\r\n'b'must have thought Ayrton long since dead.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing here?\xe2\x80\x9d again said Bob Harvey, seizing Ayrton by the\r\n'b'waistband.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Ayrton, without replying, wrenched himself from his grasp and\r\n'b'attempted to rush into the magazine. A shot fired into the midst of the\r\n'b'powder-casks, and all would be over!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHelp, lads!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Bob Harvey.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At his shout two or three pirates awoke, jumped up, and, rushing on\r\n'b'Ayrton, endeavored to throw him down. He soon extricated himself from\r\n'b'their grasp. He fired his revolver, and two of the convicts fell, but\r\n'b'a blow from a knife which he could not ward off made a gash in his\r\n'b'shoulder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton perceived that he could no longer hope to carry out his project.\r\n'b'Bob Harvey had reclosed the door of the powder-magazine, and a movement\r\n'b'on the deck indicated a general awakening of the pirates. Ayrton must\r\n'b'reserve himself to fight at the side of Cyrus Harding. There was nothing\r\n'b'for him but flight!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But was flight still possible? It was doubtful, yet Ayrton resolved to\r\n'b'dare everything in order to rejoin his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Four barrels of the revolver were still undischarged. Two were\r\n'b'fired--one, aimed at Bob Harvey, did not wound him, or at any rate\r\n'b'only slightly, and Ayrton, profiting by the momentary retreat of his\r\n'b'adversaries, rushed towards the companion-ladder to gain the deck.\r\n'b'Passing before the lantern, he smashed it with a blow from the butt of\r\n'b'his revolver. A profound darkness ensued, which favored his flight. Two\r\n'b'or three pirates, awakened by the noise, were descending the ladder at\r\n'b'the same moment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A fifth shot from Ayrton laid one low, and the others drew back, not\r\n'b'understanding what was going on. Ayrton was on deck in two bounds, and\r\n'b'three seconds later, having discharged his last barrel in the face of\r\n'b'a pirate who was about to seize him by the throat, he leaped over the\r\n'b'bulwarks into the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton had not made six strokes before shots were splashing around him\r\n'b'like hail.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What were Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, sheltered under a rock on the islet! What\r\n'b'were those of Harding, the reporter, Herbert, and Neb, crouched in the\r\n'b'Chimneys, when they heard the reports on board the brig! They rushed out\r\n'b'on to the beach, and, their guns shouldered, they stood ready to repel\r\n'b'any attack.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had no doubt about it themselves! Ayrton, surprised by the pirates,\r\n'b'had been murdered, and, perhaps, the wretches would profit by the night\r\n'b'to make a descent on the island!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Half an hour was passed in terrible anxiety. The firing had ceased, and\r\n'b'yet neither Ayrton nor Pencroft had reappeared. Was the islet invaded?\r\n'b'Ought they not to fly to the help of Ayrton and Pencroft? But how? The\r\n'b'tide being high at that time, rendered the channel impassable. The boat\r\n'b'was not there! We may imagine the horrible anxiety which took possession\r\n'b'of Harding and his companions!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last, towards half-past twelve, a boat, carrying two men, touched the\r\n'b'beach. It was Ayrton, slightly wounded in the shoulder, and Pencroft,\r\n'b'safe and sound, whom their friends received with open arms.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All immediately took refuge in the Chimneys. There Ayrton recounted all\r\n'b'that had passed, even to his plan for blowing up the brig, which he had\r\n'b'attempted to put into execution.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All hands were extended to Ayrton, who did not conceal from them that\r\n'b'their situation was serious. The pirates had been alarmed. They knew\r\n'b'that Lincoln Island was inhabited. They would land upon it in numbers\r\n'b'and well armed. They would respect nothing. Should the settlers fall\r\n'b'into their hands, they must expect no mercy!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we shall know how to die!\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go in and watch,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave we any chance of escape, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHum! six against fifty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! six! without counting--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus did not reply, but pointed upwards.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 3\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night passed without incident. The colonists were on the qui vive,\r\n'b'and did not leave their post at the Chimneys. The pirates, on their\r\n'b'side, did not appear to have made any attempt to land. Since the last\r\n'b'shots fired at Ayrton not a report, not even a sound, had betrayed the\r\n'b'presence of the brig in the neighborhood of the island. It might have\r\n'b'been fancied that she had weighed anchor, thinking that she had to deal\r\n'b'with her match, and had left the coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But it was no such thing, and when day began to dawn the settlers could\r\n'b'see a confused mass through the morning mist. It was the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThese, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9care the arrangements which\r\n'b'appear to me best to make before the fog completely clears away. It\r\n'b'hides us from the eyes of the pirates, and we can act without attracting\r\n'b'their attention. The most important thing is, that the convicts\r\n'b'should believe that the inhabitants of the island are numerous, and\r\n'b'consequently capable of resisting them. I therefore propose that we\r\n'b'divide into three parties. The first of which shall be posted at the\r\n'b'Chimneys, the second at the mouth of the Mercy. As to the third, I think\r\n'b'it would be best to place it on the islet, so as to prevent, or at all\r\n'b'events delay, any attempt at landing. We have the use of two rifles and\r\n'b'four muskets. Each of us will be armed, and, as we are amply provided\r\n'b'with powder and shot, we need not spare our fire. We have nothing to\r\n'b'fear from the muskets nor even from the guns of the brig. What can they\r\n'b'do against these rocks? And, as we shall not fire from the windows of\r\n'b'Granite House, the pirates will not think of causing irreparable damage\r\n'b'by throwing shell against it. What is to be feared is, the necessity of\r\n'b'meeting hand-to-hand, since the convicts have numbers on their side. We\r\n'b'must therefore try to prevent them from landing, but without discovering\r\n'b'ourselves. Therefore, do not economize the ammunition. Fire often, but\r\n'b'with a sure aim. We have each eight or ten enemies to kill, and they\r\n'b'must be killed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding had clearly represented their situation, although he spoke\r\n'b'in the calmest voice, as if it was a question of directing a piece\r\n'b'of work and not ordering a battle. His companions approved these\r\n'b'arrangements without even uttering a word. There was nothing more to be\r\n'b'done but for each to take his place before the fog should be completely\r\n'b'dissipated. Neb and Pencroft immediately ascended to Granite House and\r\n'b'brought back a sufficient quantity of ammunition. Gideon Spilett and\r\n'b'Ayrton, both very good marksmen, were armed with the two rifles,\r\n'b'which carried nearly a mile.
