The four other muskets were divided among\r\n'b'Harding, Neb, Pencroft, and Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The posts were arranged in the following manner:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Herbert remained in ambush at the Chimneys, thus\r\n'b'commanding the shore to the foot of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett and Neb crouched among the rocks at the mouth of the\r\n'b'Mercy, from which the drawbridges had been raised, so as to prevent any\r\n'b'one from crossing in a boat or landing on the opposite shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to Ayrton and Pencroft, they shoved off in the boat, and prepared to\r\n'b'cross the channel and to take up two separate stations on the islet.\r\n'b'In this way, shots being fired from four different points at once,\r\n'b'the convicts would be led to believe that the island was both largely\r\n'b'peopled and strongly defended.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the event of a landing being effected without their having been able\r\n'b'to prevent it, and also if they saw that they were on the point of being\r\n'b'cut off by the brig\xe2\x80\x99s boat, Ayrton and Pencroft were to return in their\r\n'b'boat to the shore and proceed towards the threatened spot.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Before starting to occupy their posts, the colonists for the last time\r\n'b'wrung each other\xe2\x80\x99s hands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft succeeded in controlling himself sufficiently to suppress his\r\n'b'emotion when he embraced Herbert, his boy! and then they separated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few moments Harding and Herbert on one side, the reporter and Neb\r\n'b'on the other, had disappeared behind the rocks, and five minutes later\r\n'b'Ayrton and Pencroft, having without difficulty crossed the channel,\r\n'b'disembarked on the islet and concealed themselves in the clefts of its\r\n'b'eastern shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'None of them could have been seen, for they themselves could scarcely\r\n'b'distinguish the brig in the fog.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was half-past six in the morning.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Soon the fog began to clear away, and the topmasts of the brig issued\r\n'b'from the vapor. For some minutes great masses rolled over the surface of\r\n'b'the sea, then a breeze sprang up, which rapidly dispelled the mist.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d now appeared in full view, with a spring on her cable, her\r\n'b'head to the north, presenting her larboard side to the island. Just as\r\n'b'Harding had calculated, she was not more than a mile and a quarter from\r\n'b'the coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sinister black flag floated from the peak.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, with his telescope, could see that the four guns on board\r\n'b'were pointed at the island. They were evidently ready to fire at a\r\n'b'moment\xe2\x80\x99s notice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d remained silent. About thirty pirates\r\n'b'could be seen moving on the deck. A few more on the poop; two others\r\n'b'posted in the shrouds, and armed with spyglasses, were attentively\r\n'b'surveying the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Certainly, Bob Harvey and his crew would not be able easily to give an\r\n'b'account of what had happened during the night on board the brig. Had\r\n'b'this half-naked man, who had forced the door of the powder-magazine, and\r\n'b'with whom they had struggled, who had six times discharged his revolver\r\n'b'at them, who had killed one and wounded two others, escaped their shot?\r\n'b'Had he been able to swim to shore? Whence did he come? What had been his\r\n'b'object? Had his design really been to blow up the brig, as Bob Harvey\r\n'b'had thought? All this must be confused enough to the convicts\xe2\x80\x99 minds.\r\n'b'But what they could no longer doubt was that the unknown island before\r\n'b'which the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d had cast anchor was inhabited, and that there was,\r\n'b'perhaps, a numerous colony ready to defend it. And yet no one was to be\r\n'b'seen, neither on the shore, nor on the heights. The beach appeared to be\r\n'b'absolutely deserted. At any rate, there was no trace of dwellings. Had\r\n'b'the inhabitants fled into the interior? Thus probably the pirate captain\r\n'b'reasoned, and doubtless, like a prudent man, he wished to reconnoiter\r\n'b'the locality before he allowed his men to venture there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During an hour and a half, no indication of attack or landing could be\r\n'b'observed on board the brig. Evidently Bob Harvey was hesitating. Even\r\n'b'with his strongest telescopes he could not have perceived one of the\r\n'b'settlers crouched among the rocks. It was not even probable that his\r\n'b'attention had been awakened by the screen of green branches and creepers\r\n'b'hiding the windows of Granite House, and showing rather conspicuously on\r\n'b'the bare rock. Indeed, how could he imagine that a dwelling was hollowed\r\n'b'out, at that height, in the solid granite? From Claw Cape to the\r\n'b'Mandible Capes, in all the extent of Union Bay, there was nothing to\r\n'b'lead him to suppose that the island was or could be inhabited.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, however, the colonists observed a movement on board\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy.\xe2\x80\x9d A boat was lowered, and seven men jumped into her. They\r\n'b'were armed with muskets; one took the yoke-lines, four others the oars,\r\n'b'and the two others, kneeling in the bows, ready to fire, reconnoitered\r\n'b'the island. Their object was no doubt to make an examination but not to\r\n'b'land, for in the latter case they would have come in larger numbers. The\r\n'b'pirates from their look-out could have seen that the coast was sheltered\r\n'b'by an islet, separated from it by a channel half a mile in width.\r\n'b'However, it was soon evident to Cyrus Harding, on observing the\r\n'b'direction followed by the boat, that they would not attempt to penetrate\r\n'b'into the channel, but would land on the islet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Ayrton, each hidden in a narrow cleft of the rock, saw them\r\n'b'coming directly towards them, and waited till they were within range.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The boat advanced with extreme caution. The oars only dipped into the\r\n'b'water at long intervals. It could now be seen that one of the convicts\r\n'b'held a lead-line in his hand, and that he wished to fathom the depth of\r\n'b'the channel hollowed out by the current of the Mercy. This showed that\r\n'b'it was Bob Harvey\xe2\x80\x99s intention to bring his brig as near as possible\r\n'b'to the coast. About thirty pirates, scattered in the rigging, followed\r\n'b'every movement of the boat, and took the bearings of certain landmarks\r\n'b'which would allow them to approach without danger. The boat was not more\r\n'b'than two cables-lengths off the islet when she stopped. The man at the\r\n'b'tiller stood up and looked for the best place at which to land.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment two shots were heard. Smoke curled up from among the\r\n'b'rocks of the islet. The man at the helm and the man with the lead-line\r\n'b'fell backwards into the boat. Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s and Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s balls had struck\r\n'b'them both at the same moment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Almost immediately a louder report was heard, a cloud of smoke issued\r\n'b'from the brig\xe2\x80\x99s side, and a ball, striking the summit of the rock which\r\n'b'sheltered Ayrton and Pencroft, made it fly in splinters, but the two\r\n'b'marksmen remained unhurt.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Horrible imprecations burst from the boat, which immediately continued\r\n'b'its way. The man who had been at the tiller was replaced by one of his\r\n'b'comrades, and the oars were rapidly plunged into the water. However,\r\n'b'instead of returning on board as might have been expected, the boat\r\n'b'coasted along the islet, so as to round its southern point. The pirates\r\n'b'pulled vigorously at their oars that they might get out of range of the\r\n'b'bullets.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They advanced to within five cables-lengths of that part of the\r\n'b'shore terminated by Flotsam Point, and after having rounded it in a\r\n'b'semicircular line, still protected by the brig\xe2\x80\x99s guns, they proceeded\r\n'b'towards the mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their evident intention was to penetrate into the channel, and cut off\r\n'b'the colonists posted on the islet, in such a way, that whatever their\r\n'b'number might be, being placed between the fire from the boat and the\r\n'b'fire from the brig, they would find themselves in a very disadvantageous\r\n'b'position.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A quarter of an hour passed while the boat advanced in this direction.\r\n'b'Absolute silence, perfect calm reigned in the air and on the water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Ayrton, although they knew they ran the risk of being\r\n'b'cut off, had not left their post, both that they did not wish to show\r\n'b'themselves as yet to their assailants, and expose themselves to the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d guns, and that they relied on Neb and Gideon Spilett,\r\n'b'watching at the mouth of the river, and on Cyrus Harding and Herbert, in\r\n'b'ambush among the rocks at the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Twenty minutes after the first shots were fired, the boat was less than\r\n'b'two cables-lengths off the Mercy. As the tide was beginning to rise with\r\n'b'its accustomed violence, caused by the narrowness of the straits, the\r\n'b'pirates were drawn towards the river, and it was only by dint of hard\r\n'b'rowing that they were able to keep in the middle of the channel. But, as\r\n'b'they were passing within good range of the mouth of the Mercy, two balls\r\n'b'saluted them, and two more of their number were laid in the bottom of\r\n'b'the boat. Neb and Spilett had not missed their aim.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The brig immediately sent a second ball on the post betrayed by the\r\n'b'smoke, but without any other result than that of splintering the rock.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The boat now contained only three able men. Carried on by the current,\r\n'b'it shot through the channel with the rapidity of an arrow, passed before\r\n'b'Harding and Herbert, who, not thinking it within range, withheld their\r\n'b'fire, then, rounding the northern point of the islet with the two\r\n'b'remaining oars, they pulled towards the brig.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Hitherto the settlers had nothing to complain of. Their adversaries\r\n'b'had certainly had the worst of it. The latter already counted four men\r\n'b'seriously wounded if not dead; they, on the contrary, unwounded, had not\r\n'b'missed a shot. If the pirates continued to attack them in this way, if\r\n'b'they renewed their attempt to land by means of a boat, they could be\r\n'b'destroyed one by one.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now seen how advantageous the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s arrangements had\r\n'b'been. The pirates would think that they had to deal with numerous and\r\n'b'well-armed adversaries, whom they could not easily get the better of.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Half an hour passed before the boat, having to pull against the current,\r\n'b'could get alongside the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy.\xe2\x80\x9d Frightful cries were heard when they\r\n'b'returned on board with the wounded, and two or three guns were fired\r\n'b'with no results.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But now about a dozen other convicts, maddened with rage, and possibly\r\n'b'by the effect of the evening\xe2\x80\x99s potations, threw themselves into the\r\n'b'boat. A second boat was also lowered, in which eight men took their\r\n'b'places, and while the first pulled straight for the islet, to dislodge\r\n'b'the colonists from thence the second maneuvered so as to force the\r\n'b'entrance of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The situation was evidently becoming very dangerous for Pencroft and\r\n'b'Ayrton, and they saw that they must regain the mainland.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, they waited till the first boat was within range, when two\r\n'b'well-directed balls threw its crew into disorder. Then, Pencroft and\r\n'b'Ayrton, abandoning their posts, under fire from the dozen muskets, ran\r\n'b'across the islet at full speed, jumped into their boat, crossed the\r\n'b'channel at the moment the second boat reached the southern end, and ran\r\n'b'to hide themselves in the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had scarcely rejoined Cyrus Harding and Herbert, before the islet\r\n'b'was overrun with pirates in every direction. Almost at the same moment,\r\n'b'fresh reports resounded from the Mercy station, to which the second boat\r\n'b'was rapidly approaching. Two, out of the eight men who manned her,\r\n'b'were mortally wounded by Gideon Spilett and Neb, and the boat herself,\r\n'b'carried irresistibly onto the reefs, was stove in at the mouth of the\r\n'b'Mercy. But the six survivors, holding their muskets above their heads to\r\n'b'preserve them from contact with the water, managed to land on the right\r\n'b'bank of the river. Then, finding they were exposed to the fire of the\r\n'b'ambush there, they fled in the direction of Flotsam Point, out of range\r\n'b'of the balls.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The actual situation was this: on the islet were a dozen convicts,\r\n'b'of whom some were no doubt wounded, but who had still a boat at their\r\n'b'disposal; on the island were six, but who could not by any possibility\r\n'b'reach Granite House, as they could not cross the river, all the bridges\r\n'b'being raised.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHallo,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft as he rushed into the Chimneys, \xe2\x80\x9challo,\r\n'b'captain! What do you think of it, now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the combat will now take a new\r\n'b'form, for it cannot be supposed that the convicts will be so foolish as\r\n'b'to remain in a position so unfavorable for them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey won\xe2\x80\x99t cross the channel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cAyrton and Mr.\r\n'b'Spilett\xe2\x80\x99s rifles are there to prevent them. You know that they carry\r\n'b'more than a mile!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert; \xe2\x80\x9cbut what can two rifles do against the\r\n'b'brig\xe2\x80\x99s guns?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the brig isn\xe2\x80\x99t in the channel yet, I fancy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut suppose she does come there?\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s impossible, for she would risk running aground and being lost!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ayrton. \xe2\x80\x9cThe convicts might profit by the high\r\n'b'tide to enter the channel, with the risk of grounding at low tide, it\r\n'b'is true; but then, under the fire from her guns, our posts would be no\r\n'b'longer tenable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cConfound them!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cit really seems as if the\r\n'b'blackguards were preparing to weigh anchor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps we shall be obliged to take refuge in Granite House!\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\n'b'Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must wait!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut Mr. Spilett and Neb?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey will know when it is best to rejoin us. Be ready, Ayrton. It is\r\n'b'yours and Spilett\xe2\x80\x99s rifles which must speak now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was only too true. The \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d was beginning to weigh her anchor,\r\n'b'and her intention was evidently to approach the islet. The tide would\r\n'b'be rising for an hour and a half, and the ebb current being already\r\n'b'weakened, it would be easy for the brig to advance. But as to entering\r\n'b'the channel, Pencroft, contrary to Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, could not believe\r\n'b'that she would dare to attempt it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, the pirates who occupied the islet had gradually\r\n'b'advanced to the opposite shore, and were now only separated from the\r\n'b'mainland by the channel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Being armed with muskets alone, they could do no harm to the settlers,\r\n'b'in ambush at the Chimneys and the mouth of the Mercy; but, not knowing\r\n'b'the latter to be supplied with long-range rifles, they on their side did\r\n'b'not believe themselves to be exposed. Quite uncovered, therefore, they\r\n'b'surveyed the islet, and examined the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their illusion was of short duration. Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s and Gideon Spilett\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'rifles then spoke, and no doubt imparted some very disagreeable\r\n'b'intelligence to two of the convicts, for they fell backwards.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then there was a general helter-skelter. The ten others, not even\r\n'b'stopping to pick up their dead or wounded companions, fled to the other\r\n'b'side of the islet, tumbled into the boat which had brought them, and\r\n'b'pulled away with all their strength.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEight less!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cReally, one would have thought that\r\n'b'Mr. Spilett and Ayrton had given the word to fire together!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ayrton, as he reloaded his gun, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is becoming more\r\n'b'serious. The brig is making sail!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe anchor is weighed!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and she is already moving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, they could distinctly hear the creaking of the windlass. The\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d was at first held by her anchor; then, when that had been\r\n'b'raised, she began to drift towards the shore. The wind was blowing\r\n'b'from the sea; the jib and the foretopsail were hoisted, and the vessel\r\n'b'gradually approached the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From the two posts of the Mercy and the Chimneys they watched her\r\n'b'without giving a sign of life, but not without some emotion. What\r\n'b'could be more terrible for the colonists than to be exposed, at a short\r\n'b'distance, to the brig\xe2\x80\x99s guns, without being able to reply with any\r\n'b'effect? How could they then prevent the pirates from landing?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding felt this strongly, and he asked himself what it would\r\n'b'be possible to do. Before long, he would be called upon for his\r\n'b'determination. But what was it to be? To shut themselves up in Granite\r\n'b'House, to be besieged there, to remain there for weeks, for months even,\r\n'b'since they had an abundance of provisions? So far good! But after that?\r\n'b'The pirates would not the less be masters of the island, which they\r\n'b'would ravage at their pleasure, and in time, they would end by having\r\n'b'their revenge on the prisoners in Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, one chance yet remained; it was that Bob Harvey, after all,\r\n'b'would not venture his ship into the channel, and that he would keep\r\n'b'outside the islet. He would be still separated from the coast by half a\r\n'b'mile, and at that distance his shot could not be very destructive.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cBob Harvey will never, if he is a good\r\n'b'seaman, enter that channel! He knows well that it would risk the brig,\r\n'b'if the sea got up ever so little! And what would become of him without\r\n'b'his vessel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile the brig approached the islet, and it could be seen\r\n'b'that she was endeavoring to make the lower end. The breeze was light,\r\n'b'and as the current had then lost much of its force, Bob Harvey had\r\n'b'absolute command over his vessel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The route previously followed by the boats had allowed her to\r\n'b'reconnoiter the channel, and she boldly entered it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The pirate\xe2\x80\x99s design was now only too evident; he wished to bring her\r\n'b'broadside to bear on the Chimneys and from there to reply with shell and\r\n'b'ball to the shot which had till then decimated her crew.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Soon the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d reached the point of the islet; she rounded it with\r\n'b'ease; the mainsail was braced up, and the brig hugging the wind, stood\r\n'b'across the mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe scoundrels! they are coming!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment, Cyrus Harding, Ayrton, the sailor, and Herbert, were\r\n'b'rejoined by Neb and Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter and his companion had judged it best to abandon the post at\r\n'b'the Mercy, from which they could do nothing against the ship, and they\r\n'b'had acted wisely. It was better that the colonists should be together at\r\n'b'the moment when they were about to engage in a decisive action. Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett and Neb had arrived by dodging behind the rocks, though not\r\n'b'without attracting a shower of bullets, which had not, however, reached\r\n'b'them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpilett! Neb!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are not wounded?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9ca few bruises only from the ricochet! But\r\n'b'that cursed brig has entered the channel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand in ten minutes she will have anchored\r\n'b'before Granite House!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave you formed any plan, Cyrus?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must take refuge in Granite House while there is still time, and the\r\n'b'convicts cannot see us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is, my opinion, too,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut once shut up--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must be guided by circumstances,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us be off, then, and make haste!\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWould you not wish, captain, that Ayrton and I should remain here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' asked the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would be the use of that, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cNo. We will\r\n'b'not separate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was not a moment to be lost. The colonists left the Chimneys. A\r\n'b'bend of the cliff prevented them from being seen by those in the brig,\r\n'b'but two or three reports, and the crash of bullets on the rock, told\r\n'b'them that the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d was at no great distance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To spring into the lift, hoist themselves up to the door of Granite\r\n'b'House, where Top and Jup had been shut up since the evening before, to\r\n'b'rush into the large room, was the work of a minute only.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was quite time, for the settlers, through the branches, could see the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy,\xe2\x80\x9d surrounded with smoke, gliding up the channel. The firing was\r\n'b'incessant, and shot from the four guns struck blindly, both on the Mercy\r\n'b'post, although it was not occupied, and on the Chimneys. The rocks were\r\n'b'splintered, and cheers accompanied each discharge. However, they\r\n'b'were hoping that Granite House would be spared, thanks to Harding\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'precaution of concealing the windows when a shot, piercing the door,\r\n'b'penetrated into the passage.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are discovered!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists had not, perhaps, been seen, but it was certain that Bob\r\n'b'Harvey had thought proper to send a ball through the suspected foliage\r\n'b'which concealed that part of the cliff. Soon he redoubled his attack,\r\n'b'when another ball having torn away the leafy screen, disclosed a gaping\r\n'b'aperture in the granite.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists\xe2\x80\x99 situation was desperate. Their retreat was discovered.\r\n'b'They could not oppose any obstacle to these missiles, nor protect the\r\n'b'stone, which flew in splinters around them. There was nothing to be\r\n'b'done but to take refuge in the upper passage of Granite House, and leave\r\n'b'their dwelling to be devastated, when a deep roar was heard, followed by\r\n'b'frightful cries!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions rushed to one of the windows--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The brig, irresistibly raised on a sort of water-spout, had just split\r\n'b'in two, and in less than ten seconds she was swallowed up with all her\r\n'b'criminal crew!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 4\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShe has blown up!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! blown up, just as if Ayrton had set fire to the powder!\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\n'b'Pencroft, throwing himself into the lift together with Neb and the lad.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett, quite stunned by this\r\n'b'unexpected catastrophe.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! this time, we shall know--\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall we know?--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLater! later! Come, Spilett. The main point is that these pirates have\r\n'b'been exterminated!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Cyrus Harding, hurrying away the reporter and Ayrton, joined\r\n'b'Pencroft, Neb, and Herbert on the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nothing could be seen of the brig, not even her masts. After having been\r\n'b'raised by the water-spout, she had fallen on her side, and had sunk in\r\n'b'that position, doubtless in consequence of some enormous leak. But as\r\n'b'in that place the channel was not more than twenty feet in depth, it\r\n'b'was certain that the sides of the submerged brig would reappear at low\r\n'b'water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few things from the wreck floated on the surface of the water, a raft\r\n'b'could be seen consisting of spare spars, coops of poultry with their\r\n'b'occupants still living, boxes and barrels, which gradually came to the\r\n'b'surface, after having escaped through the hatchways, but no pieces of\r\n'b'the wreck appeared, neither planks from the deck, nor timber from the\r\n'b'hull,--which rendered the sudden disappearance of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d perfectly\r\n'b'inexplicable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the two masts, which had been broken and escaped from the\r\n'b'shrouds and stays came up, and with their sails, some furled and the\r\n'b'others spread. But it was not necessary to wait for the tide to bring\r\n'b'up these riches, and Ayrton and Pencroft jumped into the boat with the\r\n'b'intention of towing the pieces of wreck either to the beach or to the\r\n'b'islet. But just as they were shoving off, an observation from Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett arrested them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about those six convicts who disembarked on the right bank of the\r\n'b'Mercy?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, it would not do to forget that the six men whose boat had gone\r\n'b'to pieces on the rocks had landed at Flotsam Point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They looked in that direction. None of the fugitives were visible. It\r\n'b'was probable that, having seen their vessel engulfed in the channel,\r\n'b'they had fled into the interior of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will deal with them later,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cAs they are armed, they\r\n'b'will still be dangerous; but as it is six against six, the chances are\r\n'b'equal. To the most pressing business first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton and Pencroft pulled vigorously towards the wreck.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sea was calm and the tide very high, as there had been a new moon\r\n'b'but two days before. A whole hour at least would elapse before the hull\r\n'b'of the brig could emerge from the water of the channel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton and Pencroft were able to fasten the masts and spars by means of\r\n'b'ropes, the ends of which were carried to the beach. There, by the united\r\n'b'efforts of the settlers the pieces of wreck were hauled up. Then the\r\n'b'boat picked up all that was floating, coops, barrels, and boxes, which\r\n'b'were immediately carried to the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Several bodies floated also. Among them, Ayrton recognized that of\r\n'b'Bob Harvey, which he pointed out to his companion, saying with some\r\n'b'emotion,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is what I have been, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what you are no longer, brave Ayrton!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the sailor warmly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was singular enough that so few bodies floated. Only five or six were\r\n'b'counted, which were already being carried by the current towards the\r\n'b'open sea. Very probably the convicts had not had time to escape, and\r\n'b'the ship lying over on her side, the greater number of them had remained\r\n'b'below. Now the current, by carrying the bodies of these miserable men\r\n'b'out to sea, would spare the colonists the sad task of burying them in\r\n'b'some corner of their island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For two hours, Cyrus Harding and his companions were solely occupied\r\n'b'in hauling up the spars on to the sand, and then in spreading the sails\r\n'b'which were perfectly uninjured, to dry. They spoke little, for they were\r\n'b'absorbed in their work, but what thoughts occupied their minds!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The possession of this brig, or rather all that she contained, was\r\n'b'a perfect mine of wealth. In fact, a ship is like a little world in\r\n'b'miniature, and the stores of the colony would be increased by a large\r\n'b'number of useful articles. It would be, on a large scale, equivalent to\r\n'b'the chest found at Flotsam Point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd besides,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy should it be impossible to refloat\r\n'b'the brig? If she has only a leak, that may be stopped up; a vessel from\r\n'b'three to four hundred tons, why she is a regular ship compared to our\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99! And we could go a long distance in her! We could go\r\n'b'anywhere we liked! Captain Harding, Ayrton and I must examine her! She\r\n'b'would be well worth the trouble!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, if the brig was still fit to navigate, the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 chances\r\n'b'of returning to their native land were singularly increased. But, to\r\n'b'decide this important question, it was necessary to wait until the tide\r\n'b'was quite low, so that every part of the brig\xe2\x80\x99s hull might be examined.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When their treasures had been safely conveyed on shore, Harding and his\r\n'b'companions agreed to devote some minutes to breakfast. They were almost\r\n'b'famished; fortunately, the larder was not far off, and Neb was noted\r\n'b'for being an expeditious cook. They breakfasted, therefore, near the\r\n'b'Chimneys, and during their repast, as may be supposed, nothing was\r\n'b'talked of but the event which had so miraculously saved the colony.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMiraculous is the word,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it must be\r\n'b'acknowledged that those rascals blew up just at the right moment!\r\n'b'Granite House was beginning to be uncomfortable as a habitation!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd can you guess, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9chow it happened, or\r\n'b'what can have occasioned the explosion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Mr. Spilett, nothing is more simple,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cA convict\r\n'b'vessel is not disciplined like a man-of-war! Convicts are not sailors.\r\n'b'Of course the powder-magazine was open, and as they were firing\r\n'b'incessantly, some careless or clumsy fellow just blew up the vessel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat astonishes me is that the\r\n'b'explosion has not produced more effect. The report was not loud, and\r\n'b'besides there are so few planks and timbers torn out. It seems as if the\r\n'b'ship had rather foundered than blown up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDoes that astonish you, my boy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it astonishes me also, Herbert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut when we visit the\r\n'b'hull of the brig, we shall no doubt find the explanation of the matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cyou don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose that the \xe2\x80\x98Speedy\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'simply foundered like a ship which has struck on a rock?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cif there are rocks in the channel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cyou did not look at the right\r\n'b'moment. An instant before she sank, the brig, as I saw perfectly well,\r\n'b'rose on an enormous wave, and fell back on her larboard side. Now, if\r\n'b'she had only struck, she would have sunk quietly and gone to the bottom\r\n'b'like an honest vessel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was just because she was not an honest vessel!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we shall soon see, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall soon see,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I would wager my\r\n'b'head there are no rocks in the channel. Look here, captain, to speak\r\n'b'candidly, do you mean to say that there is anything marvelous in the\r\n'b'occurrence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding did not answer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwhether rock or explosion, you will\r\n'b'agree, Pencroft, that it occurred just in the nick of time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! yes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that is not the question. I ask\r\n'b'Captain Harding if he sees anything supernatural in all this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot say, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is all the answer I\r\n'b'can make.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A reply which did not satisfy Pencroft at all. He stuck to \xe2\x80\x9can\r\n'b'explosion,\xe2\x80\x9d and did not wish to give it up. He would never consent\r\n'b'to admit that in that channel, with its fine sandy bed, just like\r\n'b'the beach, which he had often crossed at low water, there could be an\r\n'b'unknown rock.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And besides, at the time the brig foundered, it was high water, that is\r\n'b'to say, there was enough water to carry the vessel clear over any rocks\r\n'b'which would not be uncovered at low tide. Therefore, there could not\r\n'b'have been a collision. Therefore, the vessel had not struck. So she had\r\n'b'blown up.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And it must be confessed that the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s arguments were reasonable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards half-past one, the colonists embarked in the boat to visit the\r\n'b'wreck. It was to be regretted that the brig\xe2\x80\x99s two boats had not been\r\n'b'saved; but one, as has been said, had gone to pieces at the mouth of the\r\n'b'Mercy, and was absolutely useless; the other had disappeared when the\r\n'b'brig went down, and had not again been seen, having doubtless been\r\n'b'crushed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The hull of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d was just beginning to issue from the water.\r\n'b'The brig was lying right over on her side, for her masts being broken,\r\n'b'pressed down by the weight of the ballast displaced by the shock, the\r\n'b'keel was visible along her whole length. She had been regularly turned\r\n'b'over by the inexplicable but frightful submarine action, which had been\r\n'b'at the same time manifested by an enormous water-spout.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers rowed round the hull, and in proportion as the tide went\r\n'b'down, they could ascertain, if not the cause which had occasioned the\r\n'b'catastrophe, at least the effect produced.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards the bows, on both sides of the keel, seven or eight feet from\r\n'b'the beginning of the stem, the sides of the brig were frightfully torn.\r\n'b'Over a length of at least twenty feet there opened two large leaks,\r\n'b'which would be impossible to stop up. Not only had the copper sheathing\r\n'b'and the planks disappeared, reduced, no doubt, to powder, but also the\r\n'b'ribs, the iron bolts, and treenails which united them. From the entire\r\n'b'length of the hull to the stern the false keel had been separated with\r\n'b'an unaccountable violence, and the keel itself, torn from the carline in\r\n'b'several places, was split in all its length.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve a notion!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this vessel will be difficult\r\n'b'to get afloat again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett to the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthe explosion,\r\n'b'if there has been one, has produced singular effects! It has split the\r\n'b'lower part of the hull, instead of blowing up the deck and topsides!\r\n'b'These great rents appear rather to have been made by a rock than by the\r\n'b'explosion of a powder-magazine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is not a rock in the channel!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cI will admit\r\n'b'anything you like, except the rock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us try to penetrate into the interior of the brig,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\n'b'engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps we shall then know what to think of the cause of her\r\n'b'destruction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was the best thing to be done, and it was agreed, besides, to\r\n'b'take an inventory of all the treasures on board, and to arrange their\r\n'b'preservation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Access to the interior of the brig was now easy. The tide was still\r\n'b'going down and the deck was practicable. The ballast, composed of heavy\r\n'b'masses of iron, had broken through in several places. The noise of the\r\n'b'sea could be heard as it rushed out at the holes in the hull.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions, hatchets in hand, advanced along the\r\n'b'shattered deck. Cases of all sorts encumbered it, and, as they had\r\n'b'been but a very short time in the water, their contents were perhaps\r\n'b'uninjured.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They then busied themselves in placing all this cargo in safety. The\r\n'b'water would not return for several hours, and these hours must be\r\n'b'employed in the most profitable way. Ayrton and Pencroft had, at the\r\n'b'entrance made in the hull, discovered tackle, which would serve to hoist\r\n'b'up the barrels and chests. The boat received them and transported them\r\n'b'to the shore. They took the articles as they came, intending to sort\r\n'b'them afterwards.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At any rate, the settlers saw at once, with extreme satisfaction, that\r\n'b'the brig possessed a very varied cargo--an assortment of all sorts of\r\n'b'articles, utensils, manufactured goods, and tools--such as the ships\r\n'b'which make the great coasting-trade of Polynesia are usually laden with.\r\n'b'It was probable that they would find a little of everything, and they\r\n'b'agreed that it was exactly what was necessary for the colony of Lincoln\r\n'b'Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However--and Cyrus Harding observed it in silent astonishment--not only,\r\n'b'as has been said, had the hull of the brig enormously suffered from the\r\n'b'shock, whatever it was, that had occasioned the catastrophe, but the\r\n'b'interior arrangements had been destroyed, especially towards the bows.\r\n'b'Partitions and stanchions were smashed, as if some tremendous shell had\r\n'b'burst in the interior of the brig. The colonists could easily go fore\r\n'b'and aft, after having removed the cases as they were extricated. They\r\n'b'were not heavy bales, which would have been difficult to remove,\r\n'b'but simple packages, of which the stowage, besides, was no longer\r\n'b'recognizable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists then reached the stern of the brig--the part formerly\r\n'b'surmounted by the poop. It was there that, following Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'directions, they must look for the powder-magazine. Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'thought that it had not exploded; that it was possible some barrels\r\n'b'might be saved, and that the powder, which is usually enclosed in metal\r\n'b'coverings might not have suffered from contact with the water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This, in fact, was just what had happened. They extricated from among\r\n'b'a large number of shot twenty barrels, the insides of which were lined\r\n'b'with copper. Pencroft was convinced by the evidence of his own eyes that\r\n'b'the destruction of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d could not be attributed to an explosion.\r\n'b'That part of the hull in which the magazine was situated was, moreover,\r\n'b'that which had suffered least.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the obstinate sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as to a rock, there is\r\n'b'not one in the channel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, how did it happen?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know, and\r\n'b'nobody knows or ever will know!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Several hours had passed during these researches, and the tide began to\r\n'b'flow. Work must be suspended for the present. There was no fear of the\r\n'b'brig being carried away by the sea, for she was already fixed as firmly\r\n'b'as if moored by her anchors.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They could, therefore, without inconvenience, wait until the next day to\r\n'b'resume operations; but, as to the vessel itself, she was doomed, and it\r\n'b'would be best to hasten to save the remains of her hull, as she would\r\n'b'not be long in disappearing in the quicksands of the channel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening. It had been a hard day\xe2\x80\x99s work\r\n'b'for the men. They ate with good appetite, and notwithstanding their\r\n'b'fatigue, they could not resist, after dinner, their desire of inspecting\r\n'b'the cases which composed the cargo of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Most of them contained clothes, which, as may be believed, was well\r\n'b'received. There were enough to clothe a whole colony--linen for every\r\n'b'one\xe2\x80\x99s use, shoes for every one\xe2\x80\x99s feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are too rich!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cBut what are we going to do with\r\n'b'all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And every moment burst forth the hurrahs of the delighted sailor when he\r\n'b'caught sight of the barrels of gunpowder, firearms and sidearms,\r\n'b'balls of cotton, implements of husbandry, carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s, joiner\xe2\x80\x99s, and\r\n'b'blacksmith\xe2\x80\x99s tools, and boxes of all kinds of seeds, not in the least\r\n'b'injured by their short sojourn in the water. Ah, two years before,\r\n'b'how these things would have been prized! And now, even though the\r\n'b'industrious colonists had provided themselves with tools, these\r\n'b'treasures would find their use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no want of space in the store-rooms of Granite House, but that\r\n'b'daytime would not allow them to stow away the whole. It would not do\r\n'b'also to forget that the six survivors of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d crew had landed\r\n'b'on the island, for they were in all probability scoundrels of the\r\n'b'deepest dye, and it was necessary that the colonists should be on their\r\n'b'guard against them. Although the bridges over the Mercy were raised,\r\n'b'the convicts would not be stopped by a river or a stream and, rendered\r\n'b'desperate, these wretches would be capable of anything.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They would see later what plan it would be best to follow; but in the\r\n'b'meantime it was necessary to mount guard over cases and packages heaped\r\n'b'up near the Chimneys, and thus the settlers employed themselves in turn\r\n'b'during the night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The morning came, however, without the convicts having attempted any\r\n'b'attack. Master Jup and Top, on guard at the foot of Granite House, would\r\n'b'have quickly given the alarm. The three following days--the 19th, 20th,\r\n'b'and 21st of October--were employed in saving everything of value, or of\r\n'b'any use whatever, either from the cargo or rigging of the brig. At low\r\n'b'tide they overhauled the hold--at high tide they stowed away the rescued\r\n'b'articles. A great part of the copper sheathing had been torn from the\r\n'b'hull, which every day sank lower. But before the sand had swallowed the\r\n'b'heavy things which had fallen through the bottom, Ayrton and Pencroft,\r\n'b'diving to the bed of the channel, recovered the chains and anchors of\r\n'b'the brig, the iron of her ballast, and even four guns, which, floated by\r\n'b'means of empty casks, were brought to shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It may be seen that the arsenal of the colony had gained by the\r\n'b'wreck, as well as the storerooms of Granite House. Pencroft, always\r\n'b'enthusiastic in his projects, already spoke of constructing a battery\r\n'b'to command the channel and the mouth of the river. With four guns,\r\n'b'he engaged to prevent any fleet, \xe2\x80\x9chowever powerful it might be,\xe2\x80\x9d from\r\n'b'venturing into the waters of Lincoln Island!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meantime, when nothing remained of the brig but a useless hulk,\r\n'b'bad weather came on, which soon finished her. Cyrus Harding had intended\r\n'b'to blow her up, so as to collect the remains on the shore, but a strong\r\n'b'gale from the northeast and a heavy sea compelled him to economize his\r\n'b'powder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, on the night of the 23rd, the hull entirely broke up, and some\r\n'b'of the wreck was cast up on the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the papers on board, it is useless to say that, although he\r\n'b'carefully searched the lockers of the poop, Harding did not discover\r\n'b'any trace of them. The pirates had evidently destroyed everything that\r\n'b'concerned either the captain or the owners of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy,\xe2\x80\x9d and, as the\r\n'b'name of her port was not painted on her counter, there was nothing which\r\n'b'would tell them her nationality. However, by the shape of her boats\r\n'b'Ayrton and Pencroft believed that the brig was of English build.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A week after the castrophe--or, rather, after the fortunate, though\r\n'b'inexplicable, event to which the colony owed its preservation--nothing\r\n'b'more could be seen of the vessel, even at low tide. The wreck had\r\n'b'disappeared, and Granite House was enriched by nearly all it had\r\n'b'contained.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the mystery which enveloped its strange destruction would\r\n'b'doubtless never have been cleared away if, on the 30th of November, Neb,\r\n'b'strolling on the beach, had not found a piece of a thick iron cylinder,\r\n'b'bearing traces of explosion. The edges of this cylinder were twisted and\r\n'b'broken, as if they had been subjected to the action of some explosive\r\n'b'substance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb brought this piece of metal to his master, who was then occupied\r\n'b'with his companions in the workshop of the Chimneys.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding examined the cylinder attentively, then, turning to\r\n'b'Pencroft,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou persist, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cin maintaining that the \xe2\x80\x98Speedy\xe2\x80\x99 was\r\n'b'not lost in consequence of a collision?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know as well as I do that\r\n'b'there are no rocks in the channel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut suppose she had run against this piece of iron?\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer,\r\n'b'showing the broken cylinder.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, that bit of pipe!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft in a tone of perfect\r\n'b'incredulity.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cyou remember that before she foundered\r\n'b'the brig rose on the summit of a regular waterspout?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, would you like to know what occasioned that waterspout? It was\r\n'b'this,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, holding up the broken tube.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! This cylinder is all that remains of a torpedo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA torpedo!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who put the torpedo there?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Pencroft, who did not like to\r\n'b'yield.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll that I can tell you is, that it was not I,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding;\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cbut it was there, and you have been able to judge of its incomparable\r\n'b'power!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 5\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So, then, all was explained by the submarine explosion of this torpedo.\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding could not be mistaken, as, during the war of the Union,\r\n'b'he had had occasion to try these terrible engines of destruction. It\r\n'b'was under the action of this cylinder, charged with some explosive\r\n'b'substance, nitro-glycerine, picrate, or some other material of the same\r\n'b'nature, that the water of the channel had been raised like a dome, the\r\n'b'bottom of the brig crushed in, and she had sunk instantly, the damage\r\n'b'done to her hull being so considerable that it was impossible to refloat\r\n'b'her. The \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d had not been able to withstand a torpedo that would\r\n'b'have destroyed an ironclad as easily as a fishing-boat!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Yes! all was explained, everything--except the presence of the torpedo\r\n'b'in the waters of the channel!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can no longer be in doubt\r\n'b'as to the presence of a mysterious being, a castaway like us, perhaps,\r\n'b'abandoned on our island, and I say this in order that Ayrton may be\r\n'b'acquainted with all the strange events which have occurred during these\r\n'b'two years. Who this beneficent stranger is, whose intervention has, so\r\n'b'fortunately for us, been manifested on many occasions, I cannot imagine.\r\n'b'What his object can be in acting thus, in concealing himself after\r\n'b'rendering us so many services, I cannot understand: But his services are\r\n'b'not the less real, and are of such a nature that only a man possessed of\r\n'b'prodigious power, could render them. Ayrton is indebted to him as much\r\n'b'as we are, for, if it was the stranger who saved me from the waves after\r\n'b'the fall from the balloon, evidently it was he who wrote the document,\r\n'b'who placed the bottle in the channel, and who has made known to us the\r\n'b'situation of our companion. I will add that it was he who guided that\r\n'b'chest, provided with everything we wanted, and stranded it on Flotsam\r\n'b'Point; that it was he who lighted that fire on the heights of the\r\n'b'island, which permitted you to land; that it was he who fired that\r\n'b'bullet found in the body of the peccary; that it was he who plunged that\r\n'b'torpedo into the channel, which destroyed the brig; in a word, that all\r\n'b'those inexplicable events, for which we could not assign a reason, are\r\n'b'due to this mysterious being. Therefore, whoever he may be, whether\r\n'b'shipwrecked, or exiled on our island, we shall be ungrateful, if we\r\n'b'think ourselves freed from gratitude towards him. We have contracted a\r\n'b'debt, and I hope that we shall one day pay it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right in speaking thus, my dear Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, there is an almost all-powerful being, hidden in some part of the\r\n'b'island, and whose influence has been singularly useful to our colony.\r\n'b'I will add that the unknown appears to possess means of action which\r\n'b'border on the supernatural, if in the events of practical life the\r\n'b'supernatural were recognizable. Is it he who is in secret communication\r\n'b'with us by the well in Granite House, and has he thus a knowledge of all\r\n'b'our plans? Was it he who threw us that bottle, when the vessel made her\r\n'b'first cruise? Was it he who threw Top out of the lake, and killed the\r\n'b'dugong? Was it he, who as everything leads us to believe, saved you from\r\n'b'the waves, and that under circumstances in which any one else would not\r\n'b'have been able to act? If it was he, he possesses a power which renders\r\n'b'him master of the elements.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter\xe2\x80\x99s reasoning was just, and every one felt it to be so.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cif the intervention of a human being is\r\n'b'not more questionable for us, I agree that he has at his disposal means\r\n'b'of action beyond those possessed by humanity. There is a mystery still,\r\n'b'but if we discover the man, the mystery will be discovered also. The\r\n'b'question, then, is, ought we to respect the incognito of this generous\r\n'b'being, or ought we to do everything to find him out? What is your\r\n'b'opinion on the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cis that, whoever he may be, he is a brave\r\n'b'man, and he has my esteem!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that is not an answer, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMaster,\xe2\x80\x9d then said Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cmy idea is, that we may search as long as we\r\n'b'like for this gentleman whom you are talking about, but that we shall\r\n'b'not discover him till he pleases.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not bad, what you say, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am of Neb\xe2\x80\x99s opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that is no reason for\r\n'b'not attempting the adventure. Whether we find this mysterious being or\r\n'b'not, we shall at least have fulfilled our duty towards him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, my boy, give us your opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, turning to\r\n'b'Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, his countenance full of animation, \xe2\x80\x9chow I should\r\n'b'like to thank him, he who saved you first, and who has now saved us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cso would I and all of us. I am\r\n'b'not inquisitive, but I would give one of my eyes to see this individual\r\n'b'face to face! It seems to me that he must be handsome, tall, strong,\r\n'b'with a splendid beard, radiant hair, and that he must be seated on\r\n'b'clouds, a great ball in his hands!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are describing a picture of the\r\n'b'Creator.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that is how I imagine\r\n'b'him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, Ayrton?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ayrton, \xe2\x80\x9cI can give you no better advice in\r\n'b'this matter. Whatever you do will be best; when you wish me to join you\r\n'b'in your researches, I am ready to follow you.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, Ayrton,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I should like a more\r\n'b'direct answer to the question I put to you. You are our companion; you\r\n'b'have already endangered your life several times for us, and you, as\r\n'b'well as the rest, ought to be consulted in the matter of any important\r\n'b'decision. Speak, therefore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ayrton, \xe2\x80\x9cI think that we ought to do\r\n'b'everything to discover this unknown benefactor. Perhaps he is alone.\r\n'b'Perhaps he is suffering. Perhaps he has a life to be renewed. I, too,\r\n'b'as you said, have a debt of gratitude to pay him. It was he, it could be\r\n'b'only he who must have come to Tabor Island, who found there the wretch\r\n'b'you knew, and who made known to you that there was an unfortunate man\r\n'b'there to be saved. Therefore it is, thanks to him, that I have become a\r\n'b'man again. No, I will never forget him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is settled, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will begin our\r\n'b'researches as soon as possible. We will not leave a corner of the island\r\n'b'unexplored. We will search into its most secret recesses, and will\r\n'b'hope that our unknown friend will pardon us in consideration of our\r\n'b'intentions!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For several days the colonists were actively employed in haymaking and\r\n'b'the harvest. Before putting their project of exploring the yet unknown\r\n'b'parts of the island into execution, they wished to get all possible work\r\n'b'finished. It was also the time for collecting the various vegetables\r\n'b'from the Tabor Island plants. All was stowed away, and happily there was\r\n'b'no want of room in Granite House, in which they might have housed all\r\n'b'the treasures of the island. The products of the colony were there,\r\n'b'methodically arranged, and in a safe place, as may be believed,\r\n'b'sheltered as much from animals as from man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no fear of damp in the middle of that thick mass of granite.\r\n'b'Many natural excavations situated in the upper passage were enlarged\r\n'b'either by pick-axe or mine, and Granite House thus became a general\r\n'b'warehouse, containing all the provisions, arms, tools, and spare\r\n'b'utensils--in a word, all the stores of the colony.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the guns obtained from the brig, they were pretty pieces of\r\n'b'ordnance, which, at Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s entreaty, were hoisted by means of tackle\r\n'b'and pulleys, right up into Granite House; embrasures were made between\r\n'b'the windows, and the shining muzzles of the guns could soon be seen\r\n'b'through the granite cliff. From this height they commanded all Union\r\n'b'Bay. It was like a little Gibraltar, and any vessel anchored off the\r\n'b'islet would inevitably be exposed to the fire of this aerial battery.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft one day, it was the 8th of November, \xe2\x80\x9cnow that\r\n'b'our fortifications are finished, it would be a good thing if we tried\r\n'b'the range of our guns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think that is useful?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is more than useful, it is necessary! Without that how are we to\r\n'b'know to what distance we can send one of those pretty shot with which we\r\n'b'are provided?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTry them, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cHowever, I think that in\r\n'b'making the experiment, we ought to employ, not the ordinary powder,\r\n'b'the supply of which, I think, should remain untouched, but the pyroxyle\r\n'b'which will never fail us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCan the cannon support the shock of the pyroxyle?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter,\r\n'b'who was not less anxious than Pencroft to try the artillery of Granite\r\n'b'House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so. However,\xe2\x80\x9d added the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will be prudent.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\n'b'engineer was right in thinking that the guns were of excellent make.\r\n'b'Made of forged steel, and breech-loaders, they ought consequently to be\r\n'b'able to bear a considerable charge, and also have an enormous range.\r\n'b'In fact, as regards practical effect, the transit described by the ball\r\n'b'ought to be as extended as possible, and this tension could only be\r\n'b'obtained under the condition that the projectile should be impelled with\r\n'b'a very great initial velocity.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding to his companions, \xe2\x80\x9cthe initial velocity is in\r\n'b'proportion to the quantity of powder used. In the fabrication of\r\n'b'these pieces, everything depends on employing a metal with the highest\r\n'b'possible power of resistance, and steel is incontestably that metal of\r\n'b'all others which resists the best. I have, therefore, reason to believe\r\n'b'that our guns will bear without risk the expansion of the pyroxyle gas,\r\n'b'and will give excellent results.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall be a great deal more certain of that when we have tried them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' answered Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is unnecessary to say that the four cannons were in perfect order.\r\n'b'Since they had been taken from the water, the sailor had bestowed great\r\n'b'care upon them. How many hours he had spent, in rubbing, greasing, and\r\n'b'polishing them, and in cleaning the mechanism! And now the pieces were\r\n'b'as brilliant as if they had been on board a frigate of the United States\r\n'b'Navy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this day, therefore, in presence of all the members of the colony,\r\n'b'including Master Jup and Top, the four cannon were successively tried.\r\n'b'They were charged with pyroxyle, taking into consideration its explosive\r\n'b'power, which, as has been said, is four times that of ordinary powder:\r\n'b'the projectile to be fired was cylindroconic.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, holding the end of the quick-match, stood ready to fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At Harding\xe2\x80\x99s signal, he fired. The shot, passing over the islet,\r\n'b'fell into the sea at a distance which could not be calculated with\r\n'b'exactitude.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The second gun was pointed at the rocks at the end of Flotsam Point, and\r\n'b'the shot striking a sharp rock nearly three miles from Granite House,\r\n'b'made it fly into splinters. It was Herbert who had pointed this gun and\r\n'b'fired it, and very proud he was of his first shot. Pencroft only was\r\n'b'prouder than he! Such a shot, the honor of which belonged to his dear\r\n'b'boy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The third shot, aimed this time at the downs forming the upper side\r\n'b'of Union Bay, struck the sand at a distance of four miles, then having\r\n'b'ricocheted: was lost in the sea in a cloud of spray.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For the fourth piece Cyrus Harding slightly increased the charge, so\r\n'b'as to try its extreme range. Then, all standing aside for fear of its\r\n'b'bursting, the match was lighted by means of a long cord.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A tremendous report was heard, but the piece had held good, and the\r\n'b'colonists rushing to the windows, saw the shot graze the rocks of\r\n'b'Mandible Cape, nearly five miles from Granite House, and disappear in\r\n'b'Shark Gulf.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, whose cheers might have rivaled the\r\n'b'reports themselves, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you say of our battery? All the pirates in\r\n'b'the Pacific have only to present themselves before Granite House! Not\r\n'b'one can land there now without our permission!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBelieve me, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cit would be better not to\r\n'b'have to make the experiment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat ought to be done with regard to those\r\n'b'six villains who are roaming about the island? Are we to leave them\r\n'b'to overrun our forests, our fields, our plantations? These pirates are\r\n'b'regular jaguars, and it seems to me we ought not to hesitate to treat\r\n'b'them as such! What do you think, Ayrton?\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, turning to his\r\n'b'companion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton hesitated at first to reply, and Cyrus Harding regretted that\r\n'b'Pencroft had so thoughtlessly put this question. And he was much moved\r\n'b'when Ayrton replied in a humble tone,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have been one of those jaguars, Mr. Pencroft. I have no right to\r\n'b'speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And with a slow step he walked away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft understood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a brute I am!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor Ayrton! He has as much right to\r\n'b'speak here as any one!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut his reserve does him honor, and it is\r\n'b'right to respect the feeling which he has about his sad past.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand there is no fear of\r\n'b'my doing so again. I would rather bite my tongue off than cause Ayrton\r\n'b'any pain! But to return to the question. It seems to me that these\r\n'b'ruffians have no right to any pity, and that we ought to rid the island\r\n'b'of them as soon as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs that your opinion, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cQuite my opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd before hunting them mercilessly, you would not wait until they had\r\n'b'committed some fresh act of hostility against us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t what they have done already enough?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft, who did not\r\n'b'understand these scruples.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey may adopt other sentiments!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand perhaps repent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey repent!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor, shrugging his shoulders.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft, think of Ayrton!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, taking the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\n'b'became an honest man again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft looked at his companions one after the other. He had never\r\n'b'thought of his proposal being met with any objection. His rough nature\r\n'b'could not allow that they ought to come to terms with the rascals who\r\n'b'had landed on the island with Bob Harvey\xe2\x80\x99s accomplices, the murderers of\r\n'b'the crew of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy,\xe2\x80\x9d and he looked upon them as wild beasts which\r\n'b'ought to be destroyed without delay and without remorse.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d said be. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody is against me! You wish to be generous to\r\n'b'those villains! Very well; I hope we mayn\xe2\x80\x99t repent it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat danger shall we run,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cif we take care to be always\r\n'b'on our guard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHum!\xe2\x80\x9d observed the reporter, who had not given any decided opinion.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey are six and well armed. If they each lay hid in a corner, and each\r\n'b'fired at one of us, they would soon be masters of the colony!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy have they not done so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt because it was not\r\n'b'their interest to do it. Besides, we are six also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, whom no reasoning could have convinced.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us leave these good people to do what they like, and don\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\n'b'anything more about them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t make yourself out so bad as all that!\r\n'b'Suppose one of these unfortunate men were here before you, within good\r\n'b'range of your guns, you would not fire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI would fire on him as I would on a mad dog, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft\r\n'b'coldly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have always shown much deference to\r\n'b'my advice; will you, in this matter, yield to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will do as you please, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor, who was\r\n'b'not at all convinced.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, wait, and we will not attack them unless we are attacked\r\n'b'first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus their behavior towards the pirates was agreed upon, although\r\n'b'Pencroft augured nothing good from it. They were not to attack them, but\r\n'b'were to be on their guard. After all, the island was large and fertile.\r\n'b'If any sentiment of honesty yet remained in the bottom of their hearts,\r\n'b'these wretches might perhaps be reclaimed. Was it not their interest in\r\n'b'the situation in which they found themselves to begin a new life? At\r\n'b'any rate, for humanity\xe2\x80\x99s sake alone, it would be right to wait. The\r\n'b'colonists would no longer as before, be able to go and come without\r\n'b'fear. Hitherto they had only wild beasts to guard against, and now six\r\n'b'convicts of the worst description, perhaps, were roaming over their\r\n'b'island. It was serious, certainly, and to less brave men, it would have\r\n'b'been security lost! No matter! At present, the colonists had reason on\r\n'b'their side against Pencroft. Would they be right in the future? That\r\n'b'remained to be seen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 6\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the chief business of the colonists was to make that complete\r\n'b'exploration of the island which had been decided upon, and which would\r\n'b'have two objects: to discover the mysterious being whose existence was\r\n'b'now indisputable, and at the same time to find out what had become of\r\n'b'the pirates, what retreat they had chosen, what sort of life they were\r\n'b'leading, and what was to be feared from them. Cyrus Harding wished\r\n'b'to set out without delay; but as the expedition would be of some days\r\n'b'duration, it appeared best to load the cart with different materials and\r\n'b'tools in order to facilitate the organization of the encampments. One\r\n'b'of the onagers, however, having hurt its leg, could not be harnessed\r\n'b'at present, and a few days\xe2\x80\x99 rest was necessary. The departure was,\r\n'b'therefore, put off for a week, until the 20th of November. The month\r\n'b'of November in this latitude corresponds to the month of May in the\r\n'b'northern zones. It was, therefore, the fine season. The sun was entering\r\n'b'the tropic of Capricorn, and gave the longest days in the year. The time\r\n'b'was, therefore, very favorable for the projected expedition, which,\r\n'b'if it did not accomplish its principal object, would at any rate be\r\n'b'fruitful in discoveries, especially of natural productions, since\r\n'b'Harding proposed to explore those dense forests of the Far West, which\r\n'b'stretched to the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the nine days which preceded their departure, it was agreed that\r\n'b'the work on Prospect Heights should be finished off.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Moreover, it was necessary for Ayrton to return to the corral, where the\r\n'b'domesticated animals required his care. It was decided that he should\r\n'b'spend two days there, and return to Granite House after having liberally\r\n'b'supplied the stables.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As he was about to start, Harding asked him if he would not like one\r\n'b'of them to accompany him, observing that the island was less safe than\r\n'b'formerly. Ayrton replied that this was unnecessary, as he was enough\r\n'b'for the work, and that besides he apprehended no danger. If anything\r\n'b'occurred at the corral, or in the neighborhood, he could instantly warn\r\n'b'the colonists by sending a telegram to Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton departed at dawn on the 9th, taking the cart drawn by one onager,\r\n'b'and two hours after, the electric wire announced that he had found all\r\n'b'in order at the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During these two days Harding busied himself in executing a project\r\n'b'which would completely guard Granite House against any surprise. It was\r\n'b'necessary to completely conceal the opening of the old outlet, which\r\n'b'was already walled up and partly hidden under grass and plants, at the\r\n'b'southern angle of Lake Grant. Nothing was easier, since if the level\r\n'b'of the lake was raised two or three feet, the opening would be quite\r\n'b'beneath it. Now, to raise this level they had only to establish a dam at\r\n'b'the two openings made by the lake, and by which were fed Creek Glycerine\r\n'b'and Falls River.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists worked with a will, and the two dams which besides did not\r\n'b'exceed eight feet in width by three in height, were rapidly erected by\r\n'b'means of well-cemented blocks of stone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This work finished, it would have been impossible to guess that at that\r\n'b'part of the lake, there existed a subterranean passage through which the\r\n'b'overflow of the lake formerly escaped.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Of course the little stream which fed the reservoir of Granite House and\r\n'b'worked the lift, had been carefully preserved, and the water could not\r\n'b'fail. The lift once raised, this sure and comfortable retreat would be\r\n'b'safe from any surprise.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This work had been so quickly done, that Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and\r\n'b'Herbert found time to make an expedition to Port Balloon, The sailor was\r\n'b'very anxious to know if the little creek in which the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was\r\n'b'moored, had been visited by the convicts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThese gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed, \xe2\x80\x9clanded on the south coast, and if they\r\n'b'followed the shore, it is to be feared that they may have discovered the\r\n'b'little harbor, and in that case, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give half-a-dollar for our\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s apprehensions were not without foundation, and a visit\r\n'b'to Port Balloon appeared to be very desirable. The sailor and his\r\n'b'companions set off on the 10th of November, after dinner, well armed.\r\n'b'Pencroft, ostentatiously slipping two bullets into each barrel of his\r\n'b'rifle, shook his head in a way which betokened nothing good to any one\r\n'b'who approached too near him, whether \xe2\x80\x9cman or beast,\xe2\x80\x9d as he said. Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett and Herbert also took their guns, and about three o\xe2\x80\x99clock all\r\n'b'three left Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb accompanied them to the turn of the Mercy, and after they had\r\n'b'crossed, he raised the bridge. It was agreed that a gunshot should\r\n'b'announce the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 return, and that at the signal Neb should return\r\n'b'and reestablish the communication between the two banks of the river.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The little band advanced directly along the road which led to the\r\n'b'southern coast of the island. This was only a distance of three miles\r\n'b'and a half, but Gideon Spilett and his companions took two hours to\r\n'b'traverse it. They examined all the border of the road, the thick forest,\r\n'b'as well as Tabor Marsh. They found no trace of the fugitives who, no\r\n'b'doubt, not having yet discovered the number of the colonists, or the\r\n'b'means of defense which they had at their disposal, had gained the less\r\n'b'accessible parts of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Arrived at Port Balloon, Pencroft saw with extreme satisfaction that\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was tranquilly floating in the narrow creek. However,\r\n'b'Port Balloon was so well hidden among high rocks, that it could scarcely\r\n'b'be discovered either from the land or the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthe blackguards have not been there yet. Long\r\n'b'grass suits reptiles best, and evidently we shall find them in the Far\r\n'b'West.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it\xe2\x80\x99s very lucky, for if they had found the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\n'b'Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthey would have gone off in her, and we should have been\r\n'b'prevented from returning to Tabor Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cit will be important to take a\r\n'b'document there which will make known the situation of Lincoln Island,\r\n'b'and Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s new residence, in case the Scotch yacht returns to fetch\r\n'b'him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 is always there, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\n'b'sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cShe and her crew are ready to start at a moment\xe2\x80\x99s notice!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think, Pencroft, that that is a thing to be done after our\r\n'b'exploration of the island is finished. It is possible after all that the\r\n'b'stranger, if we manage to find him, may know as much about Tabor Island\r\n'b'as about Lincoln Island. Do not forget that he is certainly the author\r\n'b'of the document, and he may, perhaps, know how far we may count on the\r\n'b'return of the yacht!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwho in the world can he be? The fellow knows\r\n'b'us and we know nothing about him! If he is a simple castaway, why should\r\n'b'he conceal himself! We are honest men, I suppose, and the society of\r\n'b'honest men isn\xe2\x80\x99t unpleasant to any one. Did he come here voluntarily?\r\n'b'Can he leave the island if he likes? Is he here still? Will he remain\r\n'b'any longer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chatting thus, Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert got on board and\r\n'b'looked about the deck of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure.\xe2\x80\x9d All at once, the sailor\r\n'b'having examined the bitts to which the cable of the anchor was\r\n'b'secured,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHallo,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is queer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe matter is, that it was not I who made this knot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And Pencroft showed a rope which fastened the cable to the bitt itself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, it was not you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo! I can swear to it. This is a reef knot, and I always make a running\r\n'b'bowline.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be mistaken, Pencroft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not mistaken!\xe2\x80\x9d declared the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cMy hand does it so naturally,\r\n'b'and one\xe2\x80\x99s hand is never mistaken!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen can the convicts have been on board?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing about that,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cbut what is certain,\r\n'b'is that some one has weighed the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x99 anchor and dropped it\r\n'b'again! And look here, here is another proof! The cable of the anchor has\r\n'b'been run out, and its service is no longer at the hawse-hole.
