I repeat\r\n'b'that some one has been using our vessel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut if the convicts had used her, they would have pillaged her, or\r\n'b'rather gone off with her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGone off! where to--to Tabor Island?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think,\r\n'b'they would risk themselves in a boat of such small tonnage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must, besides, be sure that they know of the islet,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the\r\n'b'reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHowever that may be,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cas sure as my name is\r\n'b'Bonadventure Pencroft, of the Vineyard, our \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 has sailed\r\n'b'without us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor was positive that neither Gideon Spilett nor Herbert could\r\n'b'dispute his statement. It was evident that the vessel had been moved,\r\n'b'more or less, since Pencroft had brought her to Port Balloon. As to the\r\n'b'sailor, he had not the slightest doubt that the anchor had been raised\r\n'b'and then dropped again. Now, what was the use of these two maneuvers,\r\n'b'unless the vessel had been employed in some expedition?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut how was it we did not see the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 pass in the sight of\r\n'b'the island?\xe2\x80\x9d observed the reporter, who was anxious to bring forward\r\n'b'every possible objection.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthey would only have to start\r\n'b'in the night with a good breeze, and they would be out of sight of the\r\n'b'island in two hours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cI ask again, what object could the\r\n'b'convicts have had in using the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure,\xe2\x80\x99 and why, after they had\r\n'b'made use of her, should they have brought her back to port?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must put that among the\r\n'b'unaccountable things, and not think anything more about it. The chief\r\n'b'thing is that the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 was there, and she is there now. Only,\r\n'b'unfortunately, if the convicts take her a second time, we shall very\r\n'b'likely not find her again in her place!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cwould it not be wisest to bring the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 off to Granite House?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes and no,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cor rather no. The mouth of the Mercy\r\n'b'is a bad place for a vessel, and the sea is heavy there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut by hauling her up on the sand, to the foot of the Chimneys?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps yes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate, since we must leave\r\n'b'Granite House for a long expedition, I think the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 will be\r\n'b'safer here during our absence, and we shall do best to leave her here\r\n'b'until the island is rid of these blackguards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is exactly my opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate in the\r\n'b'event of bad weather, she will not be exposed here as she would be at\r\n'b'the mouth of the Mercy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut suppose the convicts pay her another visit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cnot finding her here, they would not\r\n'b'be long in finding her on the sands of Granite House, and, during our\r\n'b'absence, nothing could hinder them from seizing her! I agree, therefore,\r\n'b'with Mr. Spilett, that she must be left in Port Balloon. But, if on our\r\n'b'return we have not rid the island of those rascals, it will be prudent\r\n'b'to bring our boat to Granite House, until the time when we need not fear\r\n'b'any unpleasant visits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s settled. Let us be off,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett, on their return to Granite House,\r\n'b'told the engineer all that had passed, and the latter approved of their\r\n'b'arrangements both for the present and the future. He also promised the\r\n'b'sailor that he would study that part of the channel situated between the\r\n'b'islet and the coast, so as to ascertain if it would not be possible\r\n'b'to make an artificial harbor there by means of dams. In this way, the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d would be always within reach, under the eyes of the\r\n'b'colonists, and if necessary, under lock and key.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That evening a telegram was sent to Ayrton, requesting him to bring from\r\n'b'the corral a couple of goats, which Neb wished to acclimatize to the\r\n'b'plateau. Singularly enough, Ayrton did not acknowledge the receipt of\r\n'b'the despatch, as he was accustomed to do. This could not but astonish\r\n'b'the engineer. But it might be that Ayrton was not at that moment in the\r\n'b'corral, or even that he was on his way back to Granite House. In fact,\r\n'b'two days had already passed since his departure, and it had been decided\r\n'b'that on the evening of the 10th or at the latest the morning of the\r\n'b'11th, he should return. The colonists waited, therefore, for Ayrton to\r\n'b'appear on Prospect Heights. Neb and Herbert even watched at the bridge\r\n'b'so as to be ready to lower it the moment their companion presented\r\n'b'himself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But up to ten in the evening, there were no signs of Ayrton. It was,\r\n'b'therefore, judged best to send a fresh despatch, requiring an immediate\r\n'b'reply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The bell of the telegraph at Granite House remained mute.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists\xe2\x80\x99 uneasiness was great. What had happened? Was Ayrton no\r\n'b'longer at the corral, or if he was still there, had he no longer control\r\n'b'over his movements? Could they go to the corral in this dark night?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They consulted. Some wished to go, the others to remain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps some accident has happened to the\r\n'b'telegraphic apparatus, so that it works no longer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat may be,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWait till to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible, indeed,\r\n'b'that Ayrton has not received our despatch, or even that we have not\r\n'b'received his.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They waited, of course not without some anxiety.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At dawn of day, the 11th of November, Harding again sent the electric\r\n'b'current along the wire and received no reply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He tried again: the same result.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOff to the corral,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd well armed!\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was immediately decided that Granite House should not be left alone\r\n'b'and that Neb should remain there. After having accompanied his friends\r\n'b'to Creek Glycerine, he raised the bridge; and waiting behind a tree he\r\n'b'watched for the return of either his companions or Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the event of the pirates presenting themselves and attempting to\r\n'b'force the passage, he was to endeavor to stop them by firing on them,\r\n'b'and as a last resource he was to take refuge in Granite House, where,\r\n'b'the lift once raised, he would be in safety.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Pencroft were to repair\r\n'b'to the corral, and if they did not find Ayrton, search the neighboring\r\n'b'woods.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, the engineer and his three companions\r\n'b'had passed Creek Glycerine, and Neb posted himself behind a small mound\r\n'b'crowned by several dragon trees, on the left bank of the stream.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, after leaving the plateau of Prospect Heights,\r\n'b'immediately took the road to the corral. They shouldered their guns,\r\n'b'ready to fire on the slightest hostile demonstration. The two rifles and\r\n'b'the two guns had been loaded with ball.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The wood was thick on each side of the road and might easily have\r\n'b'concealed the convicts, who owing to their weapons would have been\r\n'b'really formidable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists walked rapidly and in silence. Top preceded them,\r\n'b'sometimes running on the road, sometimes taking a ramble into the wood,\r\n'b'but always quiet and not appearing to fear anything unusual. And\r\n'b'they could be sure that the faithful dog would not allow them to be\r\n'b'surprised, but would bark at the least appearance of danger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions followed beside the road the wire which\r\n'b'connected the corral with Granite House. After walking for nearly two\r\n'b'miles, they had not as yet discovered any explanation of the difficulty.\r\n'b'The posts were in good order, the wire regularly extended. However, at\r\n'b'that moment the engineer observed that the wire appeared to be slack,\r\n'b'and on arriving at post No. 74, Herbert, who was in advance stopped,\r\n'b'exclaiming,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe wire is broken!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His companions hurried forward and arrived at the spot where the lad\r\n'b'was standing. The post was rooted up and lying across the path. The\r\n'b'unexpected explanation of the difficulty was here, and it was evident\r\n'b'that the despatches from Granite House had not been received at the\r\n'b'corral, nor those from the corral at Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the wind that blew down this post,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cThe earth has been dug up round its foot,\r\n'b'and it has been torn up by the hand of man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, the wire is broken,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert, showing that the wire had\r\n'b'been snapped.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs the fracture recent?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cit has certainly been done quite lately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo the corral! to the corral!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists were now half way between Granite House and the corral,\r\n'b'having still two miles and a half to go. They pressed forward with\r\n'b'redoubled speed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Indeed, it was to be feared that some serious accident had occurred in\r\n'b'the corral. No doubt, Ayrton might have sent a telegram which had not\r\n'b'arrived, but this was not the reason why his companions were so uneasy,\r\n'b'for, a more unaccountable circumstance, Ayrton, who had promised to\r\n'b'return the evening before, had not reappeared. In short, it was not\r\n'b'without a motive that all communication had been stopped between the\r\n'b'corral and Granite House, and who but the convicts could have any\r\n'b'interest in interrupting this communication?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers hastened on, their hearts oppressed with anxiety. They were\r\n'b'sincerely attached to their new companion. Were they to find him struck\r\n'b'down by the hands of those of whom he was formerly the leader?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Soon they arrived at the place where the road led along the side of the\r\n'b'little stream which flowed from the Red Creek and watered the meadows\r\n'b'of the corral. They then moderated their pace so that they should not\r\n'b'be out of breath at the moment when a struggle might be necessary. Their\r\n'b'guns were in their hands ready cocked. The forest was watched on every\r\n'b'side. Top uttered sullen groans which were rather ominous.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last the palisade appeared through the trees. No trace of any damage\r\n'b'could be seen. The gate was shut as usual. Deep silence reigned in the\r\n'b'corral. Neither the accustomed bleating of the sheep nor Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s voice\r\n'b'could be heard.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us enter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the engineer advanced, while his companions, keeping watch about\r\n'b'twenty paces behind him, were ready to fire at a moment\xe2\x80\x99s notice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding raised the inner latch of the gate and was about to push it\r\n'b'back, when Top barked loudly. A report sounded and was responded to by a\r\n'b'cry of pain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, struck by a bullet, lay stretched on the ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 7\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s cry, Pencroft, letting his gun fall, rushed towards him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey have killed him!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cMy boy! They have killed him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett ran to Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter listened to ascertain if the poor lad\xe2\x80\x99s heart was still\r\n'b'beating.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe lives,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he must be carried--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo Granite House? that is impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cInto the corral, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And he ran round the left corner of the palisade. There he found a\r\n'b'convict, who aiming at him, sent a ball through his hat. In a few\r\n'b'seconds, before he had even time to fire his second barrel, he fell,\r\n'b'struck to the heart by Harding\xe2\x80\x99s dagger, more sure even than his gun.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During this time, Gideon Spilett and the sailor hoisted themselves over\r\n'b'the palisade, leaped into the enclosure, threw down the props which\r\n'b'supported the inner door, ran into the empty house, and soon, poor\r\n'b'Herbert was lying on Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s bed. In a few moments, Harding was by his\r\n'b'side.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On seeing Herbert senseless, the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s grief was terrible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He sobbed, he cried, he tried to beat his head against the wall.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neither the engineer nor the reporter could calm him. They themselves\r\n'b'were choked with emotion. They could not speak.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, they knew that it depended on them to rescue from death the\r\n'b'poor boy who was suffering beneath their eyes. Gideon Spilett had not\r\n'b'passed through the many incidents by which his life had been checkered\r\n'b'without acquiring some slight knowledge of medicine. He knew a little\r\n'b'of everything, and several times he had been obliged to attend to wounds\r\n'b'produced either by a sword-bayonet or shot. Assisted by Cyrus Harding,\r\n'b'he proceeded to render the aid Herbert required.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter was immediately struck by the complete stupor in which\r\n'b'Herbert lay, a stupor owing either to the hemorrhage, or to the shock,\r\n'b'the ball having struck a bone with sufficient force to produce a violent\r\n'b'concussion.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert was deadly pale, and his pulse so feeble that Spilett only felt\r\n'b'it beat at long intervals, as if it was on the point of stopping.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These symptoms were very serious.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s chest was laid bare, and the blood having been stanched with\r\n'b'handkerchiefs, it was bathed with cold water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The contusion, or rather the contused wound appeared,--an oval below the\r\n'b'chest between the third and fourth ribs. It was there that Herbert had\r\n'b'been hit by the bullet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett then turned the poor boy over; as they\r\n'b'did so, he uttered a moan so feeble that they almost thought it was his\r\n'b'last sigh.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herberts back was covered with blood from another contused wound, by\r\n'b'which the ball had immediately escaped.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGod be praised!\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cthe ball is not in the body, and\r\n'b'we shall not have to extract it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut the heart?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe heart has not been touched; if it had been, Herbert would be dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDead!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, with a groan.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor had only heard the last words uttered by the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cno! He is not dead. His pulse\r\n'b'still beats. He has even uttered a moan. But for your boy\xe2\x80\x99s sake, calm\r\n'b'yourself. We have need of all our self-possession.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo not make us lose it, my friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft was silent, but a reaction set in, and great tears rolled down\r\n'b'his cheeks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile, Gideon Spilett endeavored to collect his ideas, and\r\n'b'proceed methodically. After his examination he had no doubt that the\r\n'b'ball, entering in front, between the seventh and eighth ribs, had issued\r\n'b'behind between the third and fourth. But what mischief had the ball\r\n'b'committed in its passage? What important organs had been reached? A\r\n'b'professional surgeon would have had difficulty in determining this at\r\n'b'once, and still more so the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, he knew one thing, this was that he would have to prevent the\r\n'b'inflammatory strangulation of the injured parts, then to contend with\r\n'b'the local inflammation and fever which would result from the wound,\r\n'b'perhaps mortal! Now, what styptics, what antiphlogistics ought to be\r\n'b'employed? By what means could inflammation be prevented?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At any rate, the most important thing was that the two wounds should\r\n'b'be dressed without delay. It did not appear necessary to Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'that a fresh flow of blood should be caused by bathing them in tepid\r\n'b'water, and compressing their lips. The hemorrhage had been very\r\n'b'abundant, and Herbert was already too much enfeebled by the loss of\r\n'b'blood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter, therefore, thought it best to simply bathe the two wounds\r\n'b'with cold water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert was placed on his left side, and was maintained in that\r\n'b'position.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe must not be moved.\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is in the most\r\n'b'favorable position for the wounds in his back and chest to suppurate\r\n'b'easily, and absolute rest is necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! can\xe2\x80\x99t we carry him to Granite House?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll pay the villains off!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sailor, shaking his fist in a\r\n'b'menacing manner.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett had resumed his examination of the wounded boy. Herbert\r\n'b'was still so frightfully pale, that the reporter felt anxious.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not a surgeon. I am in terrible perplexity. You\r\n'b'must aid me with your advice, your experience!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTake courage, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, pressing the\r\n'b'reporter\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x9cJudge coolly. Think only of this: Herbert must be\r\n'b'saved!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These words restored to Gideon Spilett that self-possession which he had\r\n'b'lost in a moment of discouragement on feeling his great responsibility.\r\n'b'He seated himself close to the bed. Cyrus Harding stood near. Pencroft\r\n'b'had torn up his shirt, and was mechanically making lint.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Spilett then explained to Cyrus Harding that he thought he ought first\r\n'b'of all to stop the hemorrhage, but not close the two wounds, or cause\r\n'b'their immediate cicatrization, for there had been internal perforation,\r\n'b'and the suppuration must not be allowed to accumulate in the chest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding approved entirely, and it was decided that the two wounds should\r\n'b'be dressed without attempting to close them by immediate coaptation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And now did the colonists possess an efficacious agent to act against\r\n'b'the inflammation which might occur?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Yes. They had one, for nature had generously lavished it. They had cold\r\n'b'water, that is to say, the most powerful sedative that can be employed\r\n'b'against inflammation of wounds, the most efficacious therapeutic agent\r\n'b'in grave cases, and the one which is now adopted by all physicians.\r\n'b'Cold water has, moreover, the advantage of leaving the wound in absolute\r\n'b'rest, and preserving it from all premature dressing, a considerable\r\n'b'advantage, since it has been found by experience that contact with the\r\n'b'air is dangerous during the first days.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett and Cyrus Harding reasoned thus with their simple good\r\n'b'sense, and they acted as the best surgeon would have done. Compresses\r\n'b'of linen were applied to poor Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s two wounds, and were kept\r\n'b'constantly wet with cold water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor had at first lighted a fire in the hut, which was not wanting\r\n'b'in things necessary for life. Maple sugar, medicinal plants, the same\r\n'b'which the lad had gathered on the banks of Lake Grant, enabled them to\r\n'b'make some refreshing drinks, which they gave him without his taking any\r\n'b'notice of it. His fever was extremely high, and all that day and night\r\n'b'passed without his becoming conscious.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s life hung on a thread, and this thread might break at any\r\n'b'moment. The next day, the 12th of November, the hopes of Harding and his\r\n'b'companions slightly revived. Herbert had come out of his long stupor.\r\n'b'He opened his eyes, he recognized Cyrus Harding, the reporter, and\r\n'b'Pencroft. He uttered two or three words. He did not know what had\r\n'b'happened. They told him, and Spilett begged him to remain perfectly\r\n'b'still, telling him that his life was not in danger, and that his wounds\r\n'b'would heal in a few days. However, Herbert scarcely suffered at all,\r\n'b'and the cold water with which they were constantly bathed, prevented any\r\n'b'inflammation of the wounds. The suppuration was established in a regular\r\n'b'way, the fever did not increase, and it might now be hoped that this\r\n'b'terrible wound would not involve any catastrophe. Pencroft felt the\r\n'b'swelling of his heart gradually subside. He was like a sister of mercy,\r\n'b'like a mother by the bed of her child.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert dozed again, but his sleep appeared more natural.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTell me again that you hope, Mr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me\r\n'b'again that you will save Herbert!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we will save him!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cThe wound is serious,\r\n'b'and, perhaps, even the ball has traversed the lungs, but the perforation\r\n'b'of this organ is not fatal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As may be believed, during the four-and-twenty hours they had been in\r\n'b'the corral, the colonists had no other thought than that of nursing\r\n'b'Herbert. They did not think either of the danger which threatened them\r\n'b'should the convicts return, or of the precautions to be taken for the\r\n'b'future.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But on this day, while Pencroft watched by the sick-bed, Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'and the reporter consulted as to what it would be best to do.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'First of all they examined the corral. There was not a trace of Ayrton.\r\n'b'Had the unhappy man been dragged away by his former accomplices? Had he\r\n'b'resisted, and been overcome in the struggle? This last supposition was\r\n'b'only too probable. Gideon Spilett, at the moment he scaled the palisade,\r\n'b'had clearly seen some one of the convicts running along the southern\r\n'b'spur of Mount Franklin, towards whom Top had sprung. It was one of those\r\n'b'whose object had been so completely defeated by the rocks at the mouth\r\n'b'of the Mercy. Besides, the one killed by Harding, and whose body was\r\n'b'found outside the enclosure, of course belonged to Bob Harvey\xe2\x80\x99s crew.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the corral, it had not suffered any damage. The gates were closed,\r\n'b'and the animals had not been able to disperse in the forest. Nor could\r\n'b'they see traces of any struggle, any devastation, either in the hut,\r\n'b'or in the palisade. The ammunition only, with which Ayrton had been\r\n'b'supplied, had disappeared with him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe unhappy man has been surprised,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand as he was a man\r\n'b'to defend himself, he must have been overpowered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is to be feared!\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cThen, doubtless, the\r\n'b'convicts installed themselves in the corral where they found plenty of\r\n'b'everything, and only fled when they saw us coming. It is very evident,\r\n'b'too, that at this moment Ayrton, whether living or dead, is not here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall have to beat the forest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cand rid the\r\n'b'island of these wretches. Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s presentiments were not mistaken,\r\n'b'when he wished to hunt them as wild beasts. That would have spared us\r\n'b'all these misfortunes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cbut now we have the right to be\r\n'b'merciless!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are obliged to wait some time,\r\n'b'and to remain at the corral until we can carry Herbert without danger to\r\n'b'Granite House.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut Neb?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNeb is in safety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut if, uneasy at our absence, he would venture to come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe must not come!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Cyrus Harding quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe would be\r\n'b'murdered on the road!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very probable, however, that he will attempt to rejoin us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh, if the telegraph still acted, he might be warned! But that is\r\n'b'impossible now! As to leaving Pencroft and Herbert here alone, we could\r\n'b'not do it! Well, I will go alone to Granite House.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no! Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must not expose yourself!\r\n'b'Your courage would be of no avail. The villains are evidently watching\r\n'b'the corral, they are hidden in the thick woods which surround it, and if\r\n'b'you go we shall soon have to regret two misfortunes instead of one!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut Neb?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is now four-and-twenty hours since\r\n'b'he has had any news of us! He will be sure to come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as he will be less on his guard than we should be ourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\n'b'Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9che will be killed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs there really no way of warning him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While the engineer thought, his eyes fell on Top, who, going backwards\r\n'b'and forwards seemed to say,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAm not I here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The animal sprang at his master\xe2\x80\x99s call.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Top will go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, who had understood the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop can go where we cannot! He will carry to Granite House the news of\r\n'b'the corral, and he will bring back to us that from Granite House!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cQuick!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cQuick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Spilett rapidly tore a leaf from his note-book, and wrote these words:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHerbert wounded. We are at the corral. Be on your guard. Do not leave\r\n'b'Granite House. Have the convicts appeared in the neighborhood? Reply by\r\n'b'Top.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This laconic note contained all that Neb ought to know, and at the same\r\n'b'time asked all that the colonists wished to know. It was folded and\r\n'b'fastened to Top\xe2\x80\x99s collar in a conspicuous position.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop, my dog,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, caressing the animal, \xe2\x80\x9cNeb, Top! Neb!\r\n'b'Go, go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top bounded at these words. He understood, he knew what was expected of\r\n'b'him. The road to the corral was familiar to him. In less than an hour he\r\n'b'could clear it, and it might be hoped that where neither Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'nor the reporter could have ventured without danger, Top, running among\r\n'b'the grass or in the wood, would pass unperceived.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer went to the gate of the corral and opened it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNeb, Top! Neb!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the engineer, again pointing in the direction\r\n'b'of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top sprang forwards, then almost immediately disappeared.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe will get there!\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and he will come back, the faithful animal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat o\xe2\x80\x99clock is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn an hour he may be here. We will watch for his return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The gate of the corral was closed. The engineer and the reporter\r\n'b're-entered the house. Herbert was still in a sleep. Pencroft kept the\r\n'b'compresses always wet. Spilett, seeing there was nothing he could do\r\n'b'at that moment, busied himself in preparing some nourishment, while\r\n'b'attentively watching that part of the enclosure against the hill, at\r\n'b'which an attack might be expected.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The settlers awaited Top\xe2\x80\x99s return with much anxiety. A little before\r\n'b'eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Cyrus Harding and the reporter, rifle in hand, were\r\n'b'behind the gate, ready to open it at the first bark of their dog.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They did not doubt that if Top had arrived safely at Granite House, Neb\r\n'b'would have sent him back immediately.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had both been there for about ten minutes, when a report was heard,\r\n'b'followed by repeated barks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer opened the gate, and seeing smoke a hundred feet off in the\r\n'b'wood, he fired in that direction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Almost immediately Top bounded into the corral, and the gate was quickly\r\n'b'shut.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTop, Top!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the engineer, taking the dog\xe2\x80\x99s great honest head\r\n'b'between his hands.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A note was fastened to his neck, and Cyrus Harding read these words,\r\n'b'traced in Neb\xe2\x80\x99s large writing:--\xe2\x80\x9cNo pirates in the neighborhood of\r\n'b'Granite House. I will not stir. Poor Mr. Herbert!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 8\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So the convicts were still there, watching the corral, and determined to\r\n'b'kill the settlers one after the other. There was nothing to be done but\r\n'b'to treat them as wild beasts. But great precautions must be taken, for\r\n'b'just now the wretches had the advantage on their side, seeing, and not\r\n'b'being seen, being able to surprise by the suddenness of their attack,\r\n'b'yet not to be surprised themselves. Harding made arrangements,\r\n'b'therefore, for living in the corral, of which the provisions would last\r\n'b'for a tolerable length of time. Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s house had been provided with\r\n'b'all that was necessary for existence, and the convicts, scared by\r\n'b'the arrival of the settlers, had not had time to pillage it. It was\r\n'b'probable, as Gideon Spilett observed, that things had occurred as\r\n'b'follows:\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The six convicts, disembarking on the island, had followed the southern\r\n'b'shore, and after having traversed the double shore of the Serpentine\r\n'b'Peninsula, not being inclined to venture into the Far West woods, they\r\n'b'had reached the mouth of Falls River. From this point, by following the\r\n'b'right bank of the watercourse, they would arrive at the spurs of Mount\r\n'b'Franklin, among which they would naturally seek a retreat, and they\r\n'b'could not have been long in discovering the corral, then uninhabited.\r\n'b'There they had regularly installed themselves, awaiting the moment\r\n'b'to put their abominable schemes into execution. Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s arrival had\r\n'b'surprised them, but they had managed to overpower the unfortunate man,\r\n'b'and--the rest may be easily imagined!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now, the convicts,--reduced to five, it is true, but well armed,--were\r\n'b'roaming the woods, and to venture there was to expose themselves to\r\n'b'their attacks, which could be neither guarded against nor prevented.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWait! There is nothing else to be done!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen\r\n'b'Herbert is cured, we can organize a general battle of the island, and\r\n'b'have satisfaction of these convicts. That will be the object of our\r\n'b'grand expedition at the same time--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs the search for our mysterious protector,\xe2\x80\x9d added Gideon Spilett,\r\n'b'finishing the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s sentence. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it must be acknowledged, my dear\r\n'b'Cyrus, that this time his protection was wanting at the very moment when\r\n'b'it was most necessary to us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho knows?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat we are not at the end of our trouble yet, my dear Spilett,\r\n'b'and that his powerful intervention may have another opportunity of\r\n'b'exercising itself. But that is not the question now. Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s life\r\n'b'before everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 saddest thought. Several days passed, and the\r\n'b'poor boy\xe2\x80\x99s state was happily no worse. Cold water, always kept at a\r\n'b'suitable temperature, had completely prevented the inflammation of the\r\n'b'wounds. It even seemed to the reporter that this water, being slightly\r\n'b'sulphurous,--which was explained by the neighborhood of the volcano,\r\n'b'had a more direct action on the healing. The suppuration was much\r\n'b'less abundant, and thanks to the incessant care by which he was\r\n'b'surrounded!--Herbert returned to life, and his fever abated. He was\r\n'b'besides subjected to a severe diet, and consequently his weakness was\r\n'b'and would be extreme; but there was no want of refreshing drinks, and\r\n'b'absolute rest was of the greatest benefit to him. Cyrus Harding, Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, and Pencroft had become very skilful in dressing the lad\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'wounds. All the linen in the house had been sacrificed. Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'wounds, covered with compresses and lint, were pressed neither too much\r\n'b'nor too little, so as to cause their cicatrization without effecting any\r\n'b'inflammatory reaction. The reporter used extreme care in the dressing,\r\n'b'knowing well the importance of it, and repeating to his companions that\r\n'b'which most surgeons willingly admit, that it is perhaps rarer to see a\r\n'b'dressing well done than an operation well performed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In ten days, on the 22nd of November, Herbert was considerably better.\r\n'b'He had begun to take some nourishment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The color was returning to his cheeks, and his bright eyes smiled at\r\n'b'his nurses. He talked a little, notwithstanding Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s efforts, who\r\n'b'talked incessantly to prevent him from beginning to speak, and told him\r\n'b'the most improbable stories. Herbert had questioned him on the subject\r\n'b'of Ayrton, whom he was astonished not to see near him, thinking that\r\n'b'he was at the corral. But the sailor, not wishing to distress Herbert,\r\n'b'contented himself by replying that Ayrton had rejoined Neb, so as to\r\n'b'defend Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHumph!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthese pirates! they are gentlemen who have\r\n'b'no right to any consideration! And the captain wanted to win them by\r\n'b'kindness! I\xe2\x80\x99ll send them some kindness, but in the shape of a good\r\n'b'bullet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have they not been seen again?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we shall find them, and when\r\n'b'you are cured we shall see if the cowards who strike us from behind will\r\n'b'dare to meet us face to face!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am still very weak, my poor Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell! your strength will return gradually! What\xe2\x80\x99s a ball through the\r\n'b'chest? Nothing but a joke! I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen many, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think much of\r\n'b'them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last things appeared to be going on well, and if no complication\r\n'b'occurred, Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s recovery might be regarded as certain. But what\r\n'b'would have been the condition of the colonists if his state had been\r\n'b'aggravated,--if, for example, the ball had remained in his body, if his\r\n'b'arm or his leg had had to be amputated?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett more than once, \xe2\x80\x9cI have never thought of such a\r\n'b'contingency without shuddering!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet, if it had been necessary to operate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding one day to\r\n'b'him, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would not have hesitated?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Cyrus!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut thank God that we have been\r\n'b'spared this complication!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As in so many other conjectures, the colonists had appealed to the logic\r\n'b'of that simple good sense of which they had made use so often, and once\r\n'b'more, thanks to their general knowledge, it had succeeded! But might not\r\n'b'a time come when all their science would be at fault? They were alone\r\n'b'on the island. Now, men in all states of society are necessary to each\r\n'b'other. Cyrus Harding knew this well, and sometimes he asked if some\r\n'b'circumstance might not occur which they would be powerless to surmount.\r\n'b'It appeared to him besides, that he and his companions, till then so\r\n'b'fortunate, had entered into an unlucky period. During the two years and\r\n'b'a half which had elapsed since their escape from Richmond, it might\r\n'b'be said that they had had everything their own way. The island had\r\n'b'abundantly supplied them with minerals, vegetables, animals, and as\r\n'b'Nature had constantly loaded them, their science had known how to take\r\n'b'advantage of what she offered them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The wellbeing of the colony was therefore complete. Moreover, in certain\r\n'b'occurrences an inexplicable influence had come to their aid!... But all\r\n'b'that could only be for a time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In short, Cyrus Harding believed that fortune had turned against them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the convicts\xe2\x80\x99 ship had appeared in the waters of the island,\r\n'b'and if the pirates had been, so to speak, miraculously destroyed, six of\r\n'b'them, at least, had escaped the catastrophe. They had disembarked on the\r\n'b'island, and it was almost impossible to get at the five who survived.\r\n'b'Ayrton had no doubt been murdered by these wretches, who possessed\r\n'b'firearms, and at the first use that they had made of them, Herbert had\r\n'b'fallen, wounded almost mortally. Were these the first blows aimed by\r\n'b'adverse fortune at the colonists? This was often asked by Harding. This\r\n'b'was often repeated by the reporter; and it appeared to him also that the\r\n'b'intervention, so strange, yet so efficacious, which till then had served\r\n'b'them so well, had now failed them. Had this mysterious being, whatever\r\n'b'he was, whose existence could not be denied, abandoned the island? Had\r\n'b'he in his turn succumbed?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No reply was possible to these questions. But it must not be imagined\r\n'b'that because Harding and his companions spoke of these things, they were\r\n'b'men to despair. Far from that. They looked their situation in the face,\r\n'b'they analyzed the chances, they prepared themselves for any event, they\r\n'b'stood firm and straight before the future, and if adversity was at last\r\n'b'to strike them, it would find in them men prepared to struggle against\r\n'b'it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 9\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The convalescence of the young invalid was regularly progressing. One\r\n'b'thing only was now to be desired, that his state would allow him to be\r\n'b'brought to Granite House. However well built and supplied the corral\r\n'b'house was, it could not be so comfortable as the healthy granite\r\n'b'dwelling. Besides, it did not offer the same security, and its tenants,\r\n'b'notwithstanding their watchfulness, were here always in fear of some\r\n'b'shot from the convicts. There, on the contrary, in the middle of that\r\n'b'impregnable and inaccessible cliff, they would have nothing to fear, and\r\n'b'any attack on their persons would certainly fail. They therefore waited\r\n'b'impatiently for the moment when Herbert might be moved without danger\r\n'b'from his wound, and they were determined to make this move, although the\r\n'b'communication through Jacamar Wood was very difficult.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had no news from Neb, but were not uneasy on that account. The\r\n'b'courageous Negro, well entrenched in the depths of Granite House, would\r\n'b'not allow himself to be surprised. Top had not been sent again to him,\r\n'b'as it appeared useless to expose the faithful dog to some shot which\r\n'b'might deprive the settlers of their most useful auxiliary.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They waited, therefore, although they were anxious to be reunited at\r\n'b'Granite House. It pained the engineer to see his forces divided, for it\r\n'b'gave great advantage to the pirates. Since Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s disappearance they\r\n'b'were only four against five, for Herbert could not yet be counted, and\r\n'b'this was not the least care of the brave boy, who well understood the\r\n'b'trouble of which he was the cause.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The question of knowing how, in their condition, they were to act\r\n'b'against the pirates, was thoroughly discussed on the 29th of November\r\n'b'by Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Pencroft, at a moment when Herbert\r\n'b'was asleep and could not hear them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, after they had talked of Neb and of the\r\n'b'impossibility of communicating with him, \xe2\x80\x9cI think,--like you, that to\r\n'b'venture on the road to the corral would be to risk receiving a gunshot\r\n'b'without being able to return it. But do you not think that the best\r\n'b'thing to be done now is to openly give chase to these wretches?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is just what I was thinking,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe we\xe2\x80\x99re\r\n'b'not fellows to be afraid of a bullet, and as for me, if Captain Harding\r\n'b'approves, I\xe2\x80\x99m ready to dash into the forest! Why, hang it, one man is\r\n'b'equal to another!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut is he equal to five?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will join Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand both of us, well-armed\r\n'b'and accompanied by Top--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Spilett, and you, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding, \xe2\x80\x9clet us reason\r\n'b'coolly. If the convicts were hid in one spot of the island, if we knew\r\n'b'that spot, and had only to dislodge them, I would undertake a direct\r\n'b'attack; but is there not occasion to fear, on the contrary, that they\r\n'b'are sure to fire the first shot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9ca bullet does not always reach its\r\n'b'mark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat which struck Herbert did not miss, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\n'b'engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, observe that if both of you left the corral I should\r\n'b'remain here alone to defend it. Do you imagine that the convicts will\r\n'b'not see you leave it, that they will not allow you to enter the forest,\r\n'b'and that they will not attack it during your absence, knowing that there\r\n'b'is no one here but a wounded boy and a man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, his chest swelling with\r\n'b'sullen anger. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; they will do all they can to retake the\r\n'b'corral, which they know to be well stored; and alone you could not hold\r\n'b'it against them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if we were only at Granite House!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf we were at Granite House,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cthe case would be\r\n'b'very different. There I should not be afraid to leave Herbert with one,\r\n'b'while the other three went to search the forests of the island. But we\r\n'b'are at the corral, and it is best to stay here until we can leave it\r\n'b'together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s reasoning was unanswerable, and his companions\r\n'b'understood it well.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf only Ayrton was still one of us!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor fellow!\r\n'b'his return to social life will have been but of short duration.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is dead,\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, in a peculiar tone.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hope, then, Pencroft, that the villains have spared him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if they had any interest in doing so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! you suppose that Ayrton finding his old companions, forgetting\r\n'b'all that he owes us--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho knows?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor, who did not hazard this shameful\r\n'b'supposition without hesitating.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, taking the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s arm, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is a wicked\r\n'b'idea of yours, and you will distress me much if you persist in speaking\r\n'b'thus. I will answer for Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s fidelity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I also,\xe2\x80\x9d added the reporter quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, captain, I was wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft; \xe2\x80\x9cit was a wicked\r\n'b'idea indeed that I had, and nothing justifies it. But what can I do? I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\n'b'not in my senses. This imprisonment in the corral wearies me horribly,\r\n'b'and I have never felt so excited as I do now.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBe patient, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cHow long will it be, my\r\n'b'dear Spilett, before you think Herbert may be carried to Granite House?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is difficult to say, Cyrus,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cfor any\r\n'b'imprudence might involve terrible consequences. But his convalescence\r\n'b'is progressing, and if he continues to gain strength, in eight days from\r\n'b'now--well, we shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Eight days! That would put off the return to Granite House until the\r\n'b'first days of December. At this time two months of spring had already\r\n'b'passed. The weather was fine, and the heat began to be great. The\r\n'b'forests of the island were in full leaf, and the time was approaching\r\n'b'when the usual crops ought to be gathered. The return to the plateau of\r\n'b'Prospect Heights would, therefore, be followed by extensive agricultural\r\n'b'labors, interrupted only by the projected expedition through the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It can, therefore, be well understood how injurious this seclusion in\r\n'b'the corral must have been to the colonists.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But if they were compelled to bow before necessity, they did not do so\r\n'b'without impatience.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Once or twice the reporter ventured out into the road and made the\r\n'b'tour of the palisade. Top accompanied him, and Gideon Spilett, his gun\r\n'b'cocked, was ready for any emergency.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He met with no misadventure and found no suspicious traces. His dog\r\n'b'would have warned him of any danger, and, as Top did not bark, it might\r\n'b'be concluded that there was nothing to fear at the moment at least, and\r\n'b'that the convicts were occupied in another part of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, on his second sortie, on the 27th of November, Gideon Spilett,\r\n'b'who had ventured a quarter of a mile into the woods, towards the south\r\n'b'of the mountain, remarked that Top scented something. The dog had no\r\n'b'longer his unconcerned manner; he went backwards and forwards, ferreting\r\n'b'among the grass and bushes as if his smell had revealed some suspicious\r\n'b'object to him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett followed Top, encouraged him, excited him by his voice,\r\n'b'while keeping a sharp look-out, his gun ready to fire, and sheltering\r\n'b'himself behind the trees. It was not probable that Top scented the\r\n'b'presence of man, for in that case, he would have announced it by\r\n'b'half-uttered, sullen, angry barks. Now, as he did not growl, it was\r\n'b'because danger was neither near nor approaching.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nearly five minutes passed thus, Top rummaging, the reporter following\r\n'b'him prudently when, all at once, the dog rushed towards a thick bush,\r\n'b'and drew out a rag.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was a piece of cloth, stained and torn, which Spilett immediately\r\n'b'brought back to the corral. There it was examined by the colonists,\r\n'b'who found that it was a fragment of Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s waistcoat, a piece of that\r\n'b'felt, manufactured solely by the Granite House factory.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cthere has been resistance on the\r\n'b'part of the unfortunate Ayrton. The convicts have dragged him away in\r\n'b'spite of himself! Do you still doubt his honesty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cand I repented of my suspicion a\r\n'b'long time ago! But it seems to me that something may be learned from the\r\n'b'incident.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is that Ayrton was not killed at the corral! That they dragged him\r\n'b'away living, since he has resisted. Therefore, perhaps, he is still\r\n'b'living!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, who remained thoughtful.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was a hope, to which Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s companions could still hold. Indeed,\r\n'b'they had before believed that, surprised in the corral, Ayrton had\r\n'b'fallen by a bullet, as Herbert had fallen. But if the convicts had not\r\n'b'killed him at first, if they had brought him living to another part of\r\n'b'the island, might it not be admitted that he was still their prisoner?\r\n'b'Perhaps, even, one of them had found in Ayrton his old Australian\r\n'b'companion Ben Joyce, the chief of the escaped convicts. And who knows\r\n'b'but that they had conceived the impossible hope of bringing back Ayrton\r\n'b'to themselves? He would have been very useful to them, if they had been\r\n'b'able to make him turn traitor!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This incident was, therefore, favorably interpreted at the corral, and\r\n'b'it no longer appeared impossible that they should find Ayrton again.\r\n'b'On his side, if he was only a prisoner, Ayrton would no doubt do all\r\n'b'he could to escape from the hands of the villains, and this would be a\r\n'b'powerful aid to the settlers!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cif happily Ayrton did manage to\r\n'b'escape, he would go directly to Granite House, for he could not know\r\n'b'of the attempted assassination of which Herbert has been a victim, and\r\n'b'consequently would never think of our being imprisoned in the corral.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I wish that he was there, at Granite House!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\n'b'that we were there, too! For, although the rascals can do nothing to our\r\n'b'house, they may plunder the plateau, our plantations, our poultry-yard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft had become a thorough farmer, heartily attached to his crops.\r\n'b'But it must be said that Herbert was more anxious than any to return\r\n'b'to Granite House, for he knew how much the presence of the settlers\r\n'b'was needed there. And it was he who was keeping them at the corral!\r\n'b'Therefore, one idea occupied his mind--to leave the corral, and when!\r\n'b'He believed he could bear removal to Granite House. He was sure his\r\n'b'strength would return more quickly in his room, with the air and sight\r\n'b'of the sea!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Several times he pressed Gideon Spilett, but the latter, fearing, with\r\n'b'good reason, that Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s wounds, half healed, might reopen on the\r\n'b'way, did not give the order to start.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, something occurred which compelled Cyrus Harding and his\r\n'b'two friends to yield to the lad\xe2\x80\x99s wish, and God alone knew that this\r\n'b'determination might cause them grief and remorse.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the 29th of November, seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening. The three\r\n'b'settlers were talking in Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s room, when they heard Top utter quick\r\n'b'barks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding, Pencroft, and Spilett seized their guns and ran out of the\r\n'b'house. Top, at the foot of the palisade, was jumping, barking, but it\r\n'b'was with pleasure, not anger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSome one is coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not an enemy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNeb, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOr Ayrton?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These words had hardly been exchanged between the engineer and his two\r\n'b'companions when a body leaped over the palisade and fell on the ground\r\n'b'inside the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was Jup, Master Jup in person, to whom Top immediately gave a most\r\n'b'cordial reception.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJup!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNeb has sent him to us,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9che must have some note on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft rushed up to the orang. Certainly if Neb had any important\r\n'b'matter to communicate to his master he could not employ a more sure or\r\n'b'more rapid messenger, who could pass where neither the colonists could,\r\n'b'nor even Top himself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding was not mistaken. At Jup\xe2\x80\x99s neck hung a small bag, and in\r\n'b'this bag was found a little note traced by Neb\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The despair of Harding and his companions may be imagined when they read\r\n'b'these words:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFriday, six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPlateau invaded by convicts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'                             \xe2\x80\x9cNeb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They gazed at each other without uttering a word, then they re-entered\r\n'b'the house. What were they to do? The convicts on Prospect Heights! that\r\n'b'was disaster, devastation, ruin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, on seeing the engineer, the reporter, and Pencroft re-enter,\r\n'b'guessed that their situation was aggravated, and when he saw Jup, he no\r\n'b'longer doubted that some misfortune menaced Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI must go; I can bear the journey. I must\r\n'b'go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett approached Herbert; then, having looked at him,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The question was quickly decided whether Herbert should be carried on a\r\n'b'litter or in the cart which had brought Ayrton to the corral. The motion\r\n'b'of the litter would have been more easy for the wounded lad, but it\r\n'b'would have necessitated two bearers, that is to say, there would have\r\n'b'been two guns less for defense if an attack was made on the road. Would\r\n'b'they not, on the contrary, by employing the cart leave every arm free?\r\n'b'Was it impossible to place the mattress on which Herbert was lying in\r\n'b'it, and to advance with so much care that any jolt should be avoided? It\r\n'b'could be done.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cart was brought. Pencroft harnessed the onager. Cyrus Harding and\r\n'b'the reporter raised Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s mattress and placed it on the bottom of\r\n'b'the cart. The weather was fine. The sun\xe2\x80\x99s bright rays glanced through\r\n'b'the trees.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre the guns ready?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were. The engineer and Pencroft, each armed with a double-barreled\r\n'b'gun, and Gideon Spilett carrying his rifle, had nothing to do but start.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre you comfortable, Herbert?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the lad, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t be uneasy, I shall not die on the\r\n'b'road!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'While speaking thus, it could be seen that the poor boy had called up\r\n'b'all his energy, and by the energy of a powerful will had collected his\r\n'b'failing strength.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer felt his heart sink painfully. He still hesitated to\r\n'b'give the signal for departure; but that would have driven Herbert to\r\n'b'despair--killed him perhaps.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The gate of the corral was opened. Jup and Top, who knew when to be\r\n'b'silent, ran in advance. The cart came out, the gate was reclosed, and\r\n'b'the onager, led by Pencroft, advanced at a slow pace.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Certainly, it would have been safer to have taken a different road than\r\n'b'that which led straight from the corral to Granite House, but the cart\r\n'b'would have met with great difficulties in moving under the trees. It was\r\n'b'necessary, therefore, to follow this way, although it was well known to\r\n'b'the convicts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett walked one on each side of the cart,\r\n'b'ready to answer to any attack. However, it was not probable that the\r\n'b'convicts would have yet left the plateau of Prospect Heights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb\xe2\x80\x99s note had evidently been written and sent as soon as the convicts\r\n'b'had shown themselves there. Now, this note was dated six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in\r\n'b'the morning, and the active orang, accustomed to come frequently to the\r\n'b'corral, had taken scarcely three quarters of an hour to cross the five\r\n'b'miles which separated it from Granite House. They would, therefore, be\r\n'b'safe at that time, and if there was any occasion for firing, it would\r\n'b'probably not be until they were in the neighborhood of Granite House.\r\n'b'However, the colonists kept a strict watch. Top and Jup, the latter\r\n'b'armed with his club, sometimes in front, sometimes beating the wood at\r\n'b'the sides of the road, signalized no danger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cart advanced slowly under Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s guidance. It had left the\r\n'b'corral at half-past seven. An hour after, four out of the five miles\r\n'b'had been cleared, without any incident having occurred. The road was\r\n'b'as deserted as all that part of the Jacamar Wood which lay between the\r\n'b'Mercy and the lake. There was no occasion for any warning. The wood\r\n'b'appeared as deserted as on the day when the colonists first landed on\r\n'b'the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They approached the plateau. Another mile and they would see the bridge\r\n'b'over Creek Glycerine. Cyrus Harding expected to find it in its place;\r\n'b'supposing that the convicts would have crossed it, and that, after\r\n'b'having passed one of the streams which enclosed the plateau, they\r\n'b'would have taken the precaution to lower it again, so as to keep open a\r\n'b'retreat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At length an opening in the trees allowed the sea-horizon to be seen.\r\n'b'But the cart continued its progress, for not one of its defenders\r\n'b'thought of abandoning it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment Pencroft stopped the onager, and in a hoarse voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh! the villains!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And he pointed to a thick smoke rising from the mill, the sheds, and the\r\n'b'buildings at the poultry-yard.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A man was moving about in the midst of the smoke. It was Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His companions uttered a shout. He heard, and ran to meet them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The convicts had left the plateau nearly half-an-hour before, having\r\n'b'devastated it!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Mr. Herbert?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett returned to the cart.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert had lost consciousness!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 10\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Of the convicts, the dangers which menaced Granite House, the ruins\r\n'b'with which the plateau was covered, the colonists thought no longer.\r\n'b'Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s critical state outweighed all other considerations. Would the\r\n'b'removal prove fatal to him by causing some internal injury? The reporter\r\n'b'could not affirm it, but he and his companions almost despaired of\r\n'b'the result. The cart was brought to the bend of the river. There some\r\n'b'branches, disposed as a liner, received the mattress on which lay the\r\n'b'unconscious Herbert. Ten minutes after, Cyrus Harding, Spilett, and\r\n'b'Pencroft were at the foot of the cliff, leaving Neb to take the cart\r\n'b'on to the plateau of Prospect Heights. The lift was put in motion, and\r\n'b'Herbert was soon stretched on his bed in Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What cares were lavished on him to bring him back to life! He smiled for\r\n'b'a moment on finding himself in his room, but could scarcely even murmur\r\n'b'a few words, so great was his weakness. Gideon Spilett examined his\r\n'b'wounds. He feared to find them reopened, having been imperfectly healed.\r\n'b'There was nothing of the sort. From whence, then, came this prostration?\r\n'b'why was Herbert so much worse? The lad then fell into a kind of feverish\r\n'b'sleep, and the reporter and Pencroft remained near the bed. During this\r\n'b'time, Harding told Neb all that had happened at the corral, and Neb\r\n'b'recounted to his master the events of which the plateau had just been\r\n'b'the theater.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was only during the preceding night that the convicts had appeared on\r\n'b'the edge of the forest, at the approaches to Creek Glycerine. Neb, who\r\n'b'was watching near the poultry-yard, had not hesitated to fire at one of\r\n'b'the pirates, who was about to cross the stream; but in the darkness he\r\n'b'could not tell whether the man had been hit or not. At any rate, it was\r\n'b'not enough to frighten away the band, and Neb had only just time to get\r\n'b'up to Granite House, where at least he was in safety.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But what was he to do there? How prevent the devastations with which the\r\n'b'convicts threatened the plateau? Had Neb any means by which to warn\r\n'b'his master? And, besides, in what situation were the inhabitants of the\r\n'b'corral themselves? Cyrus Harding and his companions had left on the 11th\r\n'b'of November, and it was now the 29th. It was, therefore, nineteen days\r\n'b'since Neb had had other news than that brought by Top--disastrous news:\r\n'b'Ayrton disappeared, Herbert severely wounded, the engineer, reporter,\r\n'b'and sailor, as it were, imprisoned in the corral!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What was he to do? asked poor Neb. Personally he had nothing to\r\n'b'fear, for the convicts could not reach him in Granite House. But the\r\n'b'buildings, the plantations, all their arrangements at the mercy of the\r\n'b'pirates! Would it not be best to let Cyrus Harding judge of what he\r\n'b'ought to do, and to warn him, at least, of the danger which threatened\r\n'b'him?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb then thought of employing Jup, and confiding a note to him. He knew\r\n'b'the orang\xe2\x80\x99s great intelligence, which had been often put to the proof.\r\n'b'Jup understood the word corral, which had been frequently pronounced\r\n'b'before him, and it may be remembered, too, that he had often driven\r\n'b'the cart thither in company with Pencroft. Day had not yet dawned. The\r\n'b'active orang would know how to pass unperceived through the woods, of\r\n'b'which the convicts, besides, would think he was a native.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb did not hesitate. He wrote the note, he tied it to Jup\xe2\x80\x99s neck, he\r\n'b'brought the ape to the door of Granite House, from which he let down a\r\n'b'long cord to the ground; then, several times he repeated these words,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJup Jup! corral, corral!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The creature understood, seized the cord, glided rapidly down the beach,\r\n'b'and disappeared in the darkness without the convicts\xe2\x80\x99 attention having\r\n'b'been in the least excited.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou did well, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cbut perhaps in not warning us you\r\n'b'would have done still better!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, in speaking thus, Cyrus Harding thought of Herbert, whose recovery\r\n'b'the removal had so seriously checked.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb ended his account. The convicts had not appeared at all on the\r\n'b'beach. Not knowing the number of the island\xe2\x80\x99s inhabitants, they might\r\n'b'suppose that Granite House was defended by a large party. They must have\r\n'b'remembered that during the attack by the brig numerous shot had been\r\n'b'fired both from the lower and upper rocks, and no doubt they did not\r\n'b'wish to expose themselves. But the plateau of Prospect Heights was\r\n'b'open to them, and not covered by the fire of Granite House. They gave\r\n'b'themselves up, therefore, to their instinct of destruction,--plundering,\r\n'b'burning, devastating everything,--and only retiring half an hour before\r\n'b'the arrival of the colonists, whom they believed still confined in the\r\n'b'corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On their retreat, Neb hurried out. He climbed the plateau at the risk\r\n'b'of being perceived and fired at, tried to extinguish the fire which was\r\n'b'consuming the buildings of the poultry-yard, and had struggled, though\r\n'b'in vain, against it until the cart appeared at the edge of the wood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Such had been these serious events. The presence of the convicts\r\n'b'constituted a permanent source of danger to the settlers in Lincoln\r\n'b'Island, until then so happy, and who might now expect still greater\r\n'b'misfortunes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Spilett remained in Granite House with Herbert and Pencroft, while\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, accompanied by Neb, proceeded to judge for himself of the\r\n'b'extent of the disaster.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was fortunate that the convicts had not advanced to the foot of\r\n'b'Granite House. The workshop at the Chimneys would in that case not\r\n'b'have escaped destruction. But after all, this evil would have been more\r\n'b'easily reparable than the ruins accumulated on the plateau of Prospect\r\n'b'Heights. Harding and Neb proceeded towards the Mercy, and ascended its\r\n'b'left bank without meeting with any trace of the convicts; nor on the\r\n'b'other side of the river, in the depths of the wood, could they perceive\r\n'b'any suspicious indications.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Besides, it might be supposed that in all probability either the\r\n'b'convicts knew of the return of the settlers to Granite House, by having\r\n'b'seen them pass on the road from the corral, or, after the devastation of\r\n'b'the plateau, they had penetrated into Jacamar Wood, following the course\r\n'b'of the Mercy, and were thus ignorant of their return.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the former case, they must have returned towards the corral, now\r\n'b'without defenders, and which contained valuable stores.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the latter, they must have regained their encampment, and would wait\r\n'b'on opportunity to recommence the attack.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was, therefore, possible to prevent them, but any enterprise to clear\r\n'b'the island was now rendered difficult by reason of Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s condition.\r\n'b'Indeed, their whole force would have been barely sufficient to cope with\r\n'b'the convicts, and just now no one could leave Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer and Neb arrived on the plateau. Desolation reigned\r\n'b'everywhere. The fields had been trampled over; the ears of wheat, which\r\n'b'were nearly full-grown, lay on the ground. The other plantations had not\r\n'b'suffered less.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The kitchen-garden was destroyed. Happily, Granite House possessed a\r\n'b'store of seed which would enable them to repair these misfortunes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the wall and buildings of the poultry-yard and the onagers stable,\r\n'b'the fire had destroyed all. A few terrified creatures roamed over the\r\n'b'plateau. The birds, which during the fire had taken refuge on the waters\r\n'b'of the lake, had already returned to their accustomed spot, and were\r\n'b'dabbling on the banks. Everything would have to be reconstructed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s face, which was paler than usual, expressed an internal\r\n'b'anger which he commanded with difficulty, but he did not utter a word.\r\n'b'Once more he looked at his devastated fields, and at the smoke which\r\n'b'still rose from the ruins, then he returned to Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The following days were the saddest of any that the colonists had passed\r\n'b'on the island! Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s weakness visibly increased. It appeared that\r\n'b'a more serious malady, the consequence of the profound physiological\r\n'b'disturbance he had gone through, threatened to declare itself, and\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett feared such an aggravation of his condition that he would\r\n'b'be powerless to fight against it!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, Herbert remained in an almost continuous state of drowsiness,\r\n'b'and symptoms of delirium began to manifest themselves. Refreshing drinks\r\n'b'were the only remedies at the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 disposal. The fever was not\r\n'b'as yet very high, but it soon appeared that it would probably recur at\r\n'b'regular intervals. Gideon Spilett first recognized this on the 6th of\r\n'b'December.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The poor boy, whose fingers, nose, and ears had become extremely\r\n'b'pale, was at first seized with slight shiverings, horripilations, and\r\n'b'tremblings. His pulse was weak and irregular, his skin dry, his thirst\r\n'b'intense. To this soon succeeded a hot fit; his face became flushed; his\r\n'b'skin reddened; his pulse quick; then a profuse perspiration broke out\r\n'b'after which the fever seemed to diminish. The attack had lasted nearly\r\n'b'five hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett had not left Herbert, who, it was only too certain, was\r\n'b'now seized by an intermittent fever, and this fever must be cured at any\r\n'b'cost before it should assume a more serious aspect.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in order to cure it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett to Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwe need a\r\n'b'febrifuge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA febrifuge--\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have neither Peruvian bark,\r\n'b'nor sulphate of quinine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut there are willows on the border of\r\n'b'the lake, and the bark of the willow might, perhaps, prove to be a\r\n'b'substitute for quinine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us try it without losing a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The bark of the willow has, indeed, been justly considered as a\r\n'b'succedaneum for Peruvian bark, as has also that of the horse-chestnut\r\n'b'tree, the leaf of the holly, the snake-root, etc. It was evidently\r\n'b'necessary to make trial of this substance, although not so valuable as\r\n'b'Peruvian bark, and to employ it in its natural state, since they had no\r\n'b'means for extracting its essence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding went himself to cut from the trunk of a species of black\r\n'b'willow, a few pieces of bark; he brought them back to Granite House, and\r\n'b'reduced them to a powder, which was administered that same evening to\r\n'b'Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night passed without any important change. Herbert was somewhat\r\n'b'delirious, but the fever did not reappear in the night, and did not\r\n'b'return either during the following day.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft again began to hope. Gideon Spilett said nothing. It might be\r\n'b'that the fever was not quotidian, but tertian, and that it would return\r\n'b'next day. Therefore, he awaited the next day with the greatest anxiety.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It might have been remarked besides that during this period Herbert\r\n'b'remained utterly prostrate, his head weak and giddy. Another symptom\r\n'b'alarmed the reporter to the highest degree. Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s liver became\r\n'b'congested, and soon a more intense delirium showed that his brain was\r\n'b'also affected.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett was overwhelmed by this new complication. He took the\r\n'b'engineer aside.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a malignant fever,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA malignant fever!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken, Spilett. A\r\n'b'malignant fever does not declare itself spontaneously; its germ must\r\n'b'previously have existed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not mistaken,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cHerbert no doubt contracted\r\n'b'the germ of this fever in the marshes of the island. He has already had\r\n'b'one attack; should a second come on and should we not be able to prevent\r\n'b'a third, he is lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut the willow bark?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is insufficient,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand the third attack of\r\n'b'a malignant fever, which is not arrested by means of quinine, is always\r\n'b'fatal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Fortunately, Pencroft heard nothing of this conversation or he would\r\n'b'have gone mad.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It may be imagined what anxiety the engineer and the reporter suffered\r\n'b'during the day of the 7th of December and the following night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards the middle of the day the second attack came on. The crisis was\r\n'b'terrible. Herbert felt himself sinking. He stretched his arms towards\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, towards Spilett, towards Pencroft. He was so young to\r\n'b'die! The scene was heart-rending. They were obliged to send Pencroft\r\n'b'away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The fit lasted five hours. It was evident that Herbert could not survive\r\n'b'a third.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night was frightful. In his delirium Herbert uttered words which\r\n'b'went to the hearts of his companions. He struggled with the convicts,\r\n'b'he called to Ayrton, he poured forth entreaties to that mysterious\r\n'b'being,--that powerful unknown protector,--whose image was stamped upon\r\n'b'his mind; then he again fell into a deep exhaustion which completely\r\n'b'prostrated him. Several times Gideon Spilett thought that the poor boy\r\n'b'was dead.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 8th of December, was but a succession of the fainting\r\n'b'fits. Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s thin hands clutched the sheets. They had administered\r\n'b'further doses of pounded bark, but the reporter expected no result from\r\n'b'it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf before tomorrow morning we have not given him a more energetic\r\n'b'febrifuge,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cHerbert will be dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Night arrived--the last night, it was too much to be feared, of the\r\n'b'good, brave, intelligent boy, so far in advance of his years, and who\r\n'b'was loved by all as their own child. The only remedy which existed\r\n'b'against this terrible malignant fever, the only specific which could\r\n'b'overcome it, was not to be found in Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the night of the 8th of December, Herbert was seized by a more\r\n'b'violent delirium. His liver was fearfully congested, his brain affected,\r\n'b'and already it was impossible for him to recognize any one.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Would he live until the next day, until that third attack which\r\n'b'must infallibly carry him off? It was not probable. His strength was\r\n'b'exhausted, and in the intervals of fever he lay as one dead.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards three o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning Herbert uttered a piercing cry.\r\n'b'He seemed to be torn by a supreme convulsion. Neb, who was near him,\r\n'b'terrified, ran into the next room where his companions were watching.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top, at that moment, barked in a strange manner.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All rushed in immediately and managed to restrain the dying boy, who was\r\n'b'endeavoring to throw himself out of his bed, while Spilett, taking his\r\n'b'arm, felt his pulse gradually quicken.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was five in the morning. The rays of the rising sun began to shine in\r\n'b'at the windows of Granite House. It promised to be a fine day, and this\r\n'b'day was to be poor Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s last!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A ray glanced on the table placed near the bed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Suddenly Pencroft, uttering a cry, pointed to the table.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On it lay a little oblong box, of which the cover bore these\r\n'b'words:--\xe2\x80\x9cSULPHATE OF QUININE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 11\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett took the box and opened it. It contained nearly two\r\n'b'hundred grains of a white powder, a few particles of which he carried to\r\n'b'his lips. The extreme bitterness of the substance precluded all doubt;\r\n'b'it was certainly the precious extract of quinine, that pre-eminent\r\n'b'antifebrile.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This powder must be administered to Herbert without delay. How it came\r\n'b'there might be discussed later.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSome coffee!\xe2\x80\x9d said Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few moments Neb brought a cup of the warm infusion. Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'threw into it about eighteen grains of quinine, and they succeeded in\r\n'b'making Herbert drink the mixture.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was still time, for the third attack of the malignant fever had\r\n'b'not yet shown itself.
