How they longed to be able to add that it would\r\n'b'not return!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Besides, it must be remarked, the hopes of all had now revived. The\r\n'b'mysterious influence had been again exerted, and in a critical moment,\r\n'b'when they had despaired of it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few hours Herbert was much calmer. The colonists could now discuss\r\n'b'this incident. The intervention of the stranger was more evident than\r\n'b'ever. But how had he been able to penetrate during the night into\r\n'b'Granite House? It was inexplicable, and, in truth, the proceedings of\r\n'b'the genius of the island were not less mysterious than was that genius\r\n'b'himself. During this day the sulphate of quinine was administered to\r\n'b'Herbert every three hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day some improvement in Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s condition was apparent.\r\n'b'Certainly, he was not out of danger, intermittent fevers being subject\r\n'b'to frequent and dangerous relapses, but the most assiduous care was\r\n'b'bestowed on him. And besides, the specific was at hand; nor, doubtless,\r\n'b'was he who had brought it far distant! And the hearts of all were\r\n'b'animated by returning hope.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This hope was not disappointed. Ten days after, on the 20th of December,\r\n'b'Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s convalescence commenced.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He was still weak, and strict diet had been imposed upon him, but no\r\n'b'access of fever supervened. And then, the poor boy submitted with such\r\n'b'docility to all the prescriptions ordered him! He longed so to get well!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft was as a man who has been drawn up from the bottom of an abyss.\r\n'b'Fits of joy approaching delirium seized him. When the time for the third\r\n'b'attack had passed by, he nearly suffocated the reporter in his embrace.\r\n'b'Since then, he always called him Dr. Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The real doctor, however, remained undiscovered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe will find him!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the sailor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Certainly, this man, whoever he was, might expect a somewhat too\r\n'b'energetic embrace from the worthy Pencroft!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The month of December ended, and with it the year 1867, during which\r\n'b'the colonists of Lincoln Island had of late been so severely tried.\r\n'b'They commenced the year 1868 with magnificent weather, great heat, and\r\n'b'a tropical temperature, delightfully cooled by the sea-breeze. Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'recovery progressed, and from his bed, placed near one of the windows of\r\n'b'Granite House, he could inhale the fresh air, charged with ozone, which\r\n'b'could not fail to restore his health. His appetite returned, and what\r\n'b'numberless delicate, savory little dishes Neb prepared for him!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is enough to make one wish to have a fever oneself!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During all this time, the convicts did not once appear in the vicinity\r\n'b'of Granite House. There was no news of Ayrton, and though the engineer\r\n'b'and Herbert still had some hopes of finding him again, their companions\r\n'b'did not doubt but that the unfortunate man had perished. However, this\r\n'b'uncertainty could not last, and when once the lad should have recovered,\r\n'b'the expedition, the result of which must be so important, would be\r\n'b'undertaken. But they would have to wait a month, perhaps, for all\r\n'b'the strength of the colony must be put into requisition to obtain\r\n'b'satisfaction from the convicts.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s convalescence progressed rapidly. The congestion of\r\n'b'the liver had disappeared, and his wounds might be considered completely\r\n'b'healed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the month of January, important work was done on the plateau\r\n'b'of Prospect Heights; but it consisted solely in saving as much as was\r\n'b'possible from the devastated crops, either of corn or vegetables. The\r\n'b'grain and the plants were gathered, so as to provide a new harvest for\r\n'b'the approaching half-season. With regard to rebuilding the poultry-yard,\r\n'b'wall, or stables, Cyrus Harding preferred to wait. While he and his\r\n'b'companions were in pursuit of the convicts, the latter might very\r\n'b'probably pay another visit to the plateau, and it would be useless to\r\n'b'give them an opportunity of recommencing their work of destruction. When\r\n'b'the island should be cleared of these miscreants, they would set about\r\n'b'rebuilding. The young convalescent began to get up in the second week of\r\n'b'January, at first for one hour a day, then two, then three. His strength\r\n'b'visibly returned, so vigorous was his constitution. He was now eighteen\r\n'b'years of age. He was tall, and promised to become a man of noble and\r\n'b'commanding presence. From this time his recovery, while still requiring\r\n'b'care,--and Dr. Spilett was very strict,--made rapid progress. Towards\r\n'b'the end of the month, Herbert was already walking about on Prospect\r\n'b'Heights, and the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He derived, from several sea-baths, which he took in company with\r\n'b'Pencroft and Neb, the greatest possible benefit. Cyrus Harding thought\r\n'b'he might now settle the day for their departure, for which the 15th of\r\n'b'February was fixed. The nights, very clear at this time of year, would\r\n'b'be favorable to the researches they intended to make all over the\r\n'b'island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The necessary preparations for this exploration were now commenced, and\r\n'b'were important, for the colonists had sworn not to return to Granite\r\n'b'House until their twofold object had been achieved; on the one hand, to\r\n'b'exterminate the convicts, and rescue Ayrton, if he was still living; on\r\n'b'the other, to discover who it was that presided so effectually over the\r\n'b'fortunes of the colony.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Of Lincoln Island, the settlers knew thoroughly all the eastern coast\r\n'b'from Claw Cape to the Mandible Capes, the extensive Tadorn Marsh, the\r\n'b'neighborhood of Lake Grant, Jacamar Wood, between the road to the corral\r\n'b'and the Mercy, the courses of the Mercy and Red Creek, and lastly, the\r\n'b'spurs of Mount Franklin, among which the corral had been established.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had explored, though only in an imperfect manner, the vast shore\r\n'b'of Washington Bay from Claw Cape to Reptile End, the woody and marshy\r\n'b'border of the west coast, and the interminable downs, ending at the open\r\n'b'mouth of Shark Gulf. But they had in no way surveyed the woods which\r\n'b'covered the Serpentine Peninsula, all to the right of the Mercy, the\r\n'b'left bank of Falls River, and the wilderness of spurs and valleys which\r\n'b'supported three quarters of the base of Mount Franklin, to the east, the\r\n'b'north, and the west, and where doubtless many secret retreats existed.\r\n'b'Consequently, many millions of acres of the island had still escaped\r\n'b'their investigations.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was, therefore, decided that the expedition should be carried through\r\n'b'the Far West, so as to include all that region situated on the right of\r\n'b'the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It might, perhaps, be better worth while to go direct to the corral,\r\n'b'where it might be supposed that the convicts had again taken refuge,\r\n'b'either to pillage or to establish themselves there. But either the\r\n'b'devastation of the corral would have been an accomplished fact by\r\n'b'this time, and it would be too late to prevent it, or it had been the\r\n'b'convicts\xe2\x80\x99 interest to entrench themselves there, and there would be\r\n'b'still time to go and turn them out on their return.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Therefore, after some discussion, the first plan was adhered to, and the\r\n'b'settlers resolved to proceed through the wood to Reptile End. They would\r\n'b'make their way with their hatchets, and thus lay the first draft of a\r\n'b'road which would place Granite House in communication with the end of\r\n'b'the peninsula for a length of from sixteen to seventeen miles.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cart was in good condition. The onagers, well rested, could go a\r\n'b'long journey. Provisions, camp effects, a portable stove, and various\r\n'b'utensils were packed in the cart, as also weapons and ammunition,\r\n'b'carefully chosen from the now complete arsenal of Granite House. But it\r\n'b'was necessary to remember that the convicts were, perhaps, roaming about\r\n'b'the woods, and that in the midst of these thick forests a shot might\r\n'b'quickly be fired and received. It was therefore resolved that the little\r\n'b'band of settlers should remain together and not separate under any\r\n'b'pretext whatever.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was also decided that no one should remain at Granite House. Top\r\n'b'and Jup themselves were to accompany the expedition; the inaccessible\r\n'b'dwelling needed no guard. The 14th of February, eve of the departure,\r\n'b'was consecrated entirely to repose, and--thanksgiving addressed by the\r\n'b'colonists to the Creator. A place in the cart was reserved for Herbert,\r\n'b'who, though thoroughly convalescent, was still a little weak. The next\r\n'b'morning, at daybreak, Cyrus Harding took the necessary measures to\r\n'b'protect Granite House from any invasion. The ladders, which were\r\n'b'formerly used for the ascent, were brought to the Chimneys and buried\r\n'b'deep in the sand, so that they might be available on the return of the\r\n'b'colonists, for the machinery of the lift had been taken to pieces, and\r\n'b'nothing of the apparatus remained. Pencroft stayed the last in Granite\r\n'b'House in order to finish this work, and he then lowered himself down\r\n'b'by means of a double rope held below, and which, when once hauled down,\r\n'b'left no communication between the upper landing and the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The weather was magnificent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall have a warm day of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, laughing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPooh! Dr. Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall walk under the shade\r\n'b'of the trees and shan\xe2\x80\x99t even see the sun!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cart was waiting on the beach before the Chimneys. The reporter\r\n'b'made Herbert take his place in it during the first hours at least of the\r\n'b'journey, and the lad was obliged to submit to his doctor\xe2\x80\x99s orders.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb placed himself at the onagers\xe2\x80\x99 heads. Cyrus Harding, the reporter,\r\n'b'and the sailor, walked in front. Top bounded joyfully along. Herbert\r\n'b'offered a seat in his vehicle to Jup, who accepted it without ceremony.\r\n'b'The moment for departure had arrived, and the little band set out.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cart first turned the angle of the mouth of the Mercy, then, having\r\n'b'ascended the left bank for a mile, crossed the bridge, at the other side\r\n'b'of which commenced the road to Port Balloon, and there the explorers,\r\n'b'leaving this road on their left, entered the cover of the immense woods\r\n'b'which formed the region of the Far West.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For the first two miles the widely scattered trees allowed the cart to\r\n'b'pass with ease; from time to time it became necessary to cut away a few\r\n'b'creepers and bushes, but no serious obstacle impeded the progress of the\r\n'b'colonists.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The thick foliage of the trees threw a grateful shade on the ground.\r\n'b'Deodars, Douglas firs, casuarinas, banksias, gum-trees, dragon-trees,\r\n'b'and other well-known species, succeeded each other far as the eye could\r\n'b'reach. The feathered tribes of the island were all represented--grouse,\r\n'b'jacamars, pheasants, lories, as well as the chattering cockatoos,\r\n'b'parrots, and paroquets. Agouties, kangaroos, and capybaras fled swiftly\r\n'b'at their approach; and all this reminded the settlers of the first\r\n'b'excursions they had made on their arrival at the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cI notice that these creatures,\r\n'b'both birds and quadrupeds, are more timid than formerly. These woods\r\n'b'have, therefore, been recently traversed by the convicts, and we shall\r\n'b'certainly find some traces of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, in fact, in several places they could distinguish traces, more or\r\n'b'less recent, of the passage of a band of men--here branches broken off\r\n'b'the trees, perhaps to mark out the way; there the ashes of a fire, and\r\n'b'footprints in clayey spots; but nothing which appeared to belong to a\r\n'b'settled encampment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer had recommended his companions to refrain from hunting. The\r\n'b'reports of the firearms might give the alarm to the convicts, who\r\n'b'were, perhaps, roaming through the forest. Moreover, the hunters would\r\n'b'necessarily ramble some distance from the cart, which it was dangerous\r\n'b'to leave unguarded.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the afterpart of the day, when about six miles from Granite House,\r\n'b'their progress became much more difficult. In order to make their way\r\n'b'through some thickets, they were obliged to cut down trees. Before\r\n'b'entering such places Harding was careful to send in Top and Jup, who\r\n'b'faithfully accomplished their commission, and when the dog and orang\r\n'b'returned without giving any warning, there was evidently nothing to\r\n'b'fear, either from convicts or wild beasts, two varieties of the animal\r\n'b'kingdom, whose ferocious instincts placed them on the same level. On the\r\n'b'evening of the first day the colonists encamped about nine miles from\r\n'b'Granite House, on the border of a little stream falling into the Mercy,\r\n'b'and of the existence of which they had till then been ignorant; it\r\n'b'evidently, however, belonged to the hydiographical system to which the\r\n'b'soil owed its astonishing fertility. The settlers made a hearty meal,\r\n'b'for their appetites were sharpened, and measures were then taken that\r\n'b'the night might be passed in safety. If the engineer had had only to\r\n'b'deal with wild beasts, jaguars or others, he would have simply lighted\r\n'b'fires all around his camp, which would have sufficed for its defense;\r\n'b'but the convicts would be rather attracted than terrified by the flames,\r\n'b'and it was, therefore, better to be surrounded by the profound darkness\r\n'b'of night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The watch was, however, carefully organized. Two of the settlers were\r\n'b'to watch together, and every two hours it was agreed that they should\r\n'b'be relieved by their comrades. And so, notwithstanding his wish to the\r\n'b'contrary, Herbert was exempted from guard. Pencroft and Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'in one party, the engineer and Neb in another, mounted guard in turns\r\n'b'over the camp.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night, however, was but of few hours. The darkness was due rather to\r\n'b'the thickness of the foliage than to the disappearance of the sun.\r\n'b'The silence was scarcely disturbed by the howling of jaguars and the\r\n'b'chattering of the monkeys, the latter appearing to particularly irritate\r\n'b'Master Jup. The night passed without incident, and on the next day, the\r\n'b'15th of February, the journey through the forest, tedious rather than\r\n'b'difficult, was continued. This day they could not accomplish more than\r\n'b'six miles, for every moment they were obliged to cut a road with their\r\n'b'hatchets.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Like true settlers, the colonists spared the largest and most beautiful\r\n'b'trees, which would besides have cost immense labor to fell, and the\r\n'b'small ones only were sacrificed, but the result was that the road took a\r\n'b'very winding direction, and lengthened itself by numerous detours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the day Herbert discovered several new specimens not before met\r\n'b'with in the island, such as the tree-fern, with its leaves spread out\r\n'b'like the waters of a fountain, locust-trees, on the long pods of\r\n'b'which the onagers browsed greedily, and which supplied a sweet pulp\r\n'b'of excellent flavor. There, too, the colonists again found groups of\r\n'b'magnificent kauries, their cylindrical trunks, crowded with a cone\r\n'b'of verdure, rising to a height of two hundred feet. These were the\r\n'b'tree-kings of New Zealand, as celebrated as the cedars of Lebanon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the fauna, there was no addition to those species already known to\r\n'b'the hunters. Nevertheless, they saw, though unable to get near them, a\r\n'b'couple of those large birds peculiar to Australia, a sort of cassowary,\r\n'b'called emu, five feet in height, and with brown plumage, which belong\r\n'b'to the tribe of waders. Top darted after them as fast as his four legs\r\n'b'could carry him, but the emus distanced him with ease, so prodigious was\r\n'b'their speed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As to the traces left by the convicts, a few more were discovered. Some\r\n'b'footprints found near an apparently recently extinguished fire were\r\n'b'attentively examined by the settlers. By measuring them one after the\r\n'b'other, according to their length and breadth, the marks of five men\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'feet were easily distinguished. The five convicts had evidently\r\n'b'camped on this spot; but,--and this was the object of so minute an\r\n'b'examination,--a sixth footprint could not be discovered, which in that\r\n'b'case would have been that of Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton was not with them!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand if he was not with them, it was because\r\n'b'the wretches had already murdered him! but then these rascals have not a\r\n'b'den to which they may be tracked like tigers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cit is more probable that they wander at\r\n'b'random, and it is their interest to rove about until the time when they\r\n'b'will be masters of the island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe masters of the island!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cthe masters of the\r\n'b'island!...\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, and his voice was choked, as if his throat was\r\n'b'seized in an iron grasp. Then in a calmer tone, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Captain\r\n'b'Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat the ball is which I have rammed into my gun?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the ball that went through Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s chest, and I promise you it\r\n'b'won\xe2\x80\x99t miss its mark!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But this just retaliation would not bring Ayrton back to life, and from\r\n'b'the examination of the footprints left in the ground, they must, alas!\r\n'b'conclude that all hopes of ever seeing him again must be abandoned.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That evening they encamped fourteen miles from Granite House, and Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding calculated that they could not be more than five miles from\r\n'b'Reptile Point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And indeed, the next day the extremity of the peninsula was reached, and\r\n'b'the whole length of the forest had been traversed; but there was nothing\r\n'b'to indicate the retreat in which the convicts had taken refuge, nor\r\n'b'that, no less secret, which sheltered the mysterious unknown.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 12\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 18th of February, was devoted to the exploration\r\n'b'of all that wooded region forming the shore from Reptile End to Falls\r\n'b'River. The colonists were able to search this forest thoroughly, for, as\r\n'b'it was comprised between the two shores of the Serpentine Peninsula, it\r\n'b'was only from three to four miles in breadth. The trees, both by their\r\n'b'height and their thick foliage, bore witness to the vegetative power of\r\n'b'the soil, more astonishing here than in any other part of the island.\r\n'b'One might have said that a corner from the virgin forests of America or\r\n'b'Africa had been transported into this temperate zone. This led them to\r\n'b'conclude that the superb vegetation found a heat in this soil, damp in\r\n'b'its upper layer, but warmed in the interior by volcanic fires, which\r\n'b'could not belong to a temperate climate. The most frequently occurring\r\n'b'trees were knaries and eucalypti of gigantic dimensions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 object was not simply to admire the magnificent\r\n'b'vegetation. They knew already that in this respect Lincoln Island would\r\n'b'have been worthy to take the first rank in the Canary group, to which\r\n'b'the first name given was that of the Happy Isles. Now, alas! their\r\n'b'island no longer belonged to them entirely; others had taken possession\r\n'b'of it, miscreants polluted its shores, and they must be destroyed to the\r\n'b'last man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No traces were found on the western coast, although they were carefully\r\n'b'sought for. No more footprints, no more broken branches, no more\r\n'b'deserted camps.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis does not surprise me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding to his companions.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe convicts first landed on the island in the neighborhood of Flotsam\r\n'b'Point, and they immediately plunged into the Far West forests, after\r\n'b'crossing Tadorn Marsh. They then followed almost the same route that we\r\n'b'took on leaving Granite House. This explains the traces we found in the\r\n'b'wood. But, arriving on the shore, the convicts saw at once that they\r\n'b'would discover no suitable retreat there, and it was then that, going\r\n'b'northwards again, they came upon the corral.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhere they have perhaps returned,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cfor they would naturally\r\n'b'suppose that our researches would be in that direction. The corral is\r\n'b'only a storehouse to them, and not a definitive encampment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am of Cyrus\xe2\x80\x99 opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand I think that it is\r\n'b'among the spurs of Mount Franklin that the convicts will have made their\r\n'b'lair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen, captain, straight to the corral!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must finish\r\n'b'them off, and till now we have only lost time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cyou forget that we have a reason\r\n'b'for wishing to know if the forests of the Far West do not contain some\r\n'b'habitation. Our exploration has a double object, Pencroft. If, on the\r\n'b'one hand, we have to chastise crime, we have, on the other, an act of\r\n'b'gratitude to perform.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat was well said, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cbut, all the same,\r\n'b'it is my opinion that we shall not find the gentleman until he pleases.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And truly Pencroft only expressed the opinion of all. It was probable\r\n'b'that the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s retreat was not less mysterious than was he himself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'That evening the cart halted at the mouth of Falls River. The camp was\r\n'b'organized as usual, and the customary precautions were taken for the\r\n'b'night. Herbert, become again the healthy and vigorous lad he was before\r\n'b'his illness, derived great benefit from this life in the open air,\r\n'b'between the sea breezes and the vivifying air from the forests. His\r\n'b'place was no longer in the cart, but at the head of the troop.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 19th of February, the colonists, leaving the shore,\r\n'b'where, beyond the mouth, basalts of every shape were so picturesquely\r\n'b'piled up, ascended the river by its left bank. The road had been already\r\n'b'partly cleared in their former excursions made from the corral to the\r\n'b'west coast. The settlers were now about six miles from Mount Franklin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s plan was this:--To minutely survey the valley forming\r\n'b'the bed of the river, and to cautiously approach the neighborhood of the\r\n'b'corral; if the corral was occupied, to seize it by force; if it was not,\r\n'b'to entrench themselves there and make it the center of the operations\r\n'b'which had for their object the exploration of Mount Franklin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This plan was unanimously approved by the colonists, for they were\r\n'b'impatient to regain entire possession of their island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They made their way then along the narrow valley separating two of the\r\n'b'largest spurs of Mount Franklin. The trees, crowded on the river\xe2\x80\x99s bank,\r\n'b'became rare on the upper slopes of the mountain. The ground was hilly\r\n'b'and rough, very suitable for ambushes, and over which they did not\r\n'b'venture without extreme precaution. Top and Jup skirmished on the\r\n'b'flanks, springing right and left through the thick brushwood, and\r\n'b'emulating each other in intelligence and activity. But nothing showed\r\n'b'that the banks of the stream had been recently frequented--nothing\r\n'b'announced either the presence or the proximity of the convicts. Towards\r\n'b'five in the evening the cart stopped nearly 600 feet from the palisade.\r\n'b'A semicircular screen of trees still hid it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was necessary to reconnoiter the corral, in order to ascertain if it\r\n'b'was occupied. To go there openly, in broad daylight, when the convicts\r\n'b'were probably in ambush, would be to expose themselves, as poor Herbert\r\n'b'had done, to the firearms of the ruffians. It was better, then, to wait\r\n'b'until night came on.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, Gideon Spilett wished without further delay to reconnoiter the\r\n'b'approaches to the corral, and Pencroft, who was quite out of patience,\r\n'b'volunteered to accompany him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwait till night. I will not allow\r\n'b'one of you to expose himself in open day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, captain--\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor, little disposed to obey.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI beg of you, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, who vented his anger in another way, by\r\n'b'bestowing on the convicts the worst names in his maritime vocabulary.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists remained, therefore, near the cart, and carefully watched\r\n'b'the neighboring parts of the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Three hours passed thus. The wind had fallen, and absolute silence\r\n'b'reigned under the great trees. The snapping of the smallest twig, a\r\n'b'footstep on the dry leaves, the gliding of a body among the grass, would\r\n'b'have been heard without difficulty. All was quiet. Besides, Top, lying\r\n'b'on the grass, his head stretched out on his paws, gave no sign of\r\n'b'uneasiness. At eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock the day appeared far enough advanced for\r\n'b'the reconnaissance to be made under favorable conditions. Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'declared himself ready to set out accompanied by Pencroft. Cyrus Harding\r\n'b'consented. Top and Jup were to remain with the engineer, Herbert, and\r\n'b'Neb, for a bark or a cry at a wrong moment would give the alarm.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo not be imprudent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding to the reporter and Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\n'b'have not to gain possession of the corral, but only to find out whether\r\n'b'it is occupied or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the two departed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Under the trees, thanks to the thickness of their foliage, the obscurity\r\n'b'rendered any object invisible beyond a radius of from thirty to forty\r\n'b'feet. The reporter and Pencroft, halting at any suspicious sound,\r\n'b'advanced with great caution.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They walked a little distance apart from each other so as to offer a\r\n'b'less mark for a shot. And, to tell the truth, they expected every moment\r\n'b'to hear a report. Five minutes after leaving the cart, Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'and Pencroft arrived at the edge of the wood before the clearing beyond\r\n'b'which rose the palisade.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They stopped. A few straggling beams still fell on the field clear of\r\n'b'trees. Thirty feet distant was the gate of the corral, which appeared\r\n'b'to be closed. This thirty feet, which it was necessary to cross from\r\n'b'the wood to the palisade, constituted the dangerous zone, to borrow\r\n'b'a ballistic term: in fact, one or more bullets fired from behind the\r\n'b'palisade might knock over any one who ventured on to this zone. Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett and the sailor were not men to draw back, but they knew that\r\n'b'any imprudence on their part, of which they would be the first victims,\r\n'b'would fall afterwards on their companions. If they themselves were\r\n'b'killed, what would become of Harding, Neb, and Herbert?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Pencroft, excited at feeling himself so near the corral where he\r\n'b'supposed the convicts had taken refuge, was about to press forward, when\r\n'b'the reporter held him back with a grasp of iron.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn a few minutes it will be quite dark,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Spilett in the\r\n'b'sailor\xe2\x80\x99s ear, \xe2\x80\x9cthen will be the time to act.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, convulsively clasping the butt-end of his gun, restrained his\r\n'b'energies, and waited, swearing to himself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Soon the last of the twilight faded away. Darkness, which seemed as if\r\n'b'it issued from the dense forest, covered the clearing. Mount Franklin\r\n'b'rose like an enormous screen before the western horizon, and night\r\n'b'spread rapidly over all, as it does in regions of low latitudes. Now was\r\n'b'the time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter and Pencroft, since posting themselves on the edge of the\r\n'b'wood, had not once lost sight of the palisade. The corral appeared to\r\n'b'be absolutely deserted. The top of the palisade formed a line, a\r\n'b'little darker than the surrounding shadow, and nothing disturbed its\r\n'b'distinctness. Nevertheless, if the convicts were there, they must have\r\n'b'posted one of their number to guard against any surprise.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Spilett grasped his companion\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and both crept towards the corral,\r\n'b'their guns ready to fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They reached the gate without the darkness being illuminated by a single\r\n'b'ray of light.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft tried to push open the gate, which, as the reporter and he had\r\n'b'supposed, was closed. However, the sailor was able to ascertain that the\r\n'b'outer bars had not been put up. It might, then, be concluded that the\r\n'b'convicts were there in the corral, and that very probably they had\r\n'b'fastened the gate in such a way that it could not be forced open.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett and Pencroft listened.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Not a sound could be heard inside the palisade. The musmons and the\r\n'b'goats, sleeping no doubt in their huts, in no way disturbed the calm of\r\n'b'night.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter and the sailor hearing nothing, asked themselves whether\r\n'b'they had not better scale the palisades and penetrate into the corral.\r\n'b'This would have been contrary to Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s instructions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It is true that the enterprise might succeed, but it might also fail.\r\n'b'Now, if the convicts were suspecting nothing, if they knew nothing of\r\n'b'the expedition against them, if, lastly, there now existed a chance\r\n'b'of surprising them, ought this chance to be lost by inconsiderately\r\n'b'attempting to cross the palisades?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This was not the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s opinion. He thought it better to wait until\r\n'b'all the settlers were collected together before attempting to penetrate\r\n'b'into the corral. One thing was certain, that it was possible to reach\r\n'b'the palisade without being seen, and also that it did not appear to be\r\n'b'guarded. This point settled, there was nothing to be done but to return\r\n'b'to the cart, where they would consult.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft probably agreed with this decision, for he followed the\r\n'b'reporter without making any objection when the latter turned back to the\r\n'b'wood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few minutes the engineer was made acquainted with the state of\r\n'b'affairs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, after a little thought, \xe2\x80\x9cI now have reason to believe\r\n'b'that the convicts are not in the corral.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall soon know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen we have scaled the palisade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo the corral, my friends!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShall we leave the cart in the wood?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cit is our wagon of ammunition and\r\n'b'provisions, and, if necessary, it would serve as an entrenchment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The cart emerged from the wood and began to roll noiselessly towards the\r\n'b'palisade. The darkness was now profound, the silence as complete as\r\n'b'when Pencroft and the reporter crept over the ground. The thick grass\r\n'b'completely muffled their footsteps. The colonists held themselves ready\r\n'b'to fire. Jup, at Pencroft\xe2\x80\x99s orders, kept behind. Neb led Top in a leash,\r\n'b'to prevent him from bounding forward.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The clearing soon came in sight. It was deserted. Without hesitating,\r\n'b'the little band moved towards the palisade. In a short space of time the\r\n'b'dangerous zone was passed. Neb remained at the onagers\xe2\x80\x99 heads to hold\r\n'b'them. The engineer, the reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft, proceeded to\r\n'b'the door, in order to ascertain if it was barricaded inside. It was\r\n'b'open!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer, turning to the sailor and\r\n'b'Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Both were stupefied.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI can swear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this gate was shut just now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists now hesitated. Were the convicts in the corral when\r\n'b'Pencroft and the reporter made their reconnaissance? It could not be\r\n'b'doubted, as the gate then closed could only have been opened by them.\r\n'b'Were they still there, or had one of their number just gone out?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All these questions presented themselves simultaneously to the minds of\r\n'b'the colonists, but how could they be answered?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment, Herbert, who had advanced a few steps into the\r\n'b'enclosure, drew back hurriedly, and seized Harding\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA light!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All five advanced and indeed, through the window fronting them, they saw\r\n'b'glimmering a feeble light. Cyrus Harding made up his mind rapidly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\n'b'is our only chance,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to his companions, \xe2\x80\x9cof finding the convicts\r\n'b'collected in this house, suspecting nothing! They are in our power!\r\n'b'Forward!\xe2\x80\x9d The colonists crossed through the enclosure, holding their\r\n'b'guns ready in their hands. The cart had been left outside under the\r\n'b'charge of Jup and Top, who had been prudently tied to it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, Pencroft, and Gideon Spilett on one side, Herbert and Neb\r\n'b'on the other, going along by the palisade, surveyed the absolutely dark\r\n'b'and deserted corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few moments they were near the closed door of the house.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding signed to his companions not to stir, and approached the window,\r\n'b'then feebly lighted by the inner light.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He gazed into the apartment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the table burned a lantern. Near the table was the bed formerly used\r\n'b'by Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the bed lay the body of a man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Suddenly Cyrus Harding drew back, and in a hoarse voice,--\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\n'b'exclaimed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Immediately the door was forced rather than opened, and the colonists\r\n'b'rushed into the room.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton appeared to be asleep. His countenance showed that he had long\r\n'b'and cruelly suffered. On his wrists and ankles could be seen great\r\n'b'bruises.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding bent over him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the engineer, seizing the arm of the man whom he had\r\n'b'just found again under such unexpected circumstances.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this exclamation Ayrton opened his eyes, and, gazing at Harding, then\r\n'b'at the others,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton! Ayrton!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhere am I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn the house in the corral!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAlone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut they will come back!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ayrton. \xe2\x80\x9cDefend yourselves! defend\r\n'b'yourselves!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And he fell back exhausted.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpilett,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe may be attacked at any moment.\r\n'b'Bring the cart into the corral. Then, barricade the door, and all come\r\n'b'back here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft, Neb, and the reporter hastened to execute the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'orders. There was not a moment to be lost. Perhaps even now the cart was\r\n'b'in the hands of the convicts!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a moment the reporter and his two companions had crossed the corral\r\n'b'and reached the gate of the palisade behind which Top was heard growling\r\n'b'sullenly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, leaving Ayrton for an instant, came out ready to fire.\r\n'b'Herbert was at his side. Both surveyed the crest of the spur overlooking\r\n'b'the corral. If the convicts were lying in ambush there, they might knock\r\n'b'the settlers over one after the other.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment the moon appeared in the east, above the black curtain of\r\n'b'the forest, and a white sheet of light spread over the interior of the\r\n'b'enclosure. The corral, with its clumps of trees, the little stream which\r\n'b'watered it, its wide carpet of grass, was suddenly illuminated. From\r\n'b'the side of the mountain, the house and a part of the palisade stood\r\n'b'out white in the moonlight. On the opposite side towards the door, the\r\n'b'enclosure remained dark. A black mass soon appeared. This was the cart\r\n'b'entering the circle of light, and Cyrus Harding could hear the noise\r\n'b'made by the door, as his companions shut it and fastened the interior\r\n'b'bars.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But, at that moment, Top, breaking loose, began to bark furiously and\r\n'b'rush to the back of the corral, to the right of the house.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBe ready to fire, my friends!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists raised their pieces and waited the moment to fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Top still barked, and Jup, running towards the dog, uttered shrill\r\n'b'cries.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists followed him, and reached the borders of the little\r\n'b'stream, shaded by large trees. And there, in the bright moonlight, what\r\n'b'did they see? Five corpses, stretched on the bank!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They were those of the convicts who, four months previously, had landed\r\n'b'on Lincoln Island!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 13\r\n'b'\r\n'b'How had it happened? who had killed the convicts? Was it Ayrton? No, for\r\n'b'a moment before he was dreading their return.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Ayrton was now in a profound stupor, from which it was no longer\r\n'b'possible to rouse him. After uttering those few words he had again\r\n'b'become unconscious, and had fallen back motionless on the bed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, a prey to a thousand confused thoughts, under the\r\n'b'influence of violent excitement, waited all night, without leaving\r\n'b'Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s house, or returning to the spot where lay the bodies of the\r\n'b'convicts. It was very probable that Ayrton would not be able to throw\r\n'b'any light on the circumstances under which the bodies had been found,\r\n'b'since he himself was not aware that he was in the corral. But at any\r\n'b'rate he would be in a position to give an account of what had taken\r\n'b'place before this terrible execution. The next day Ayrton awoke from his\r\n'b'torpor, and his companions cordially manifested all the joy they felt,\r\n'b'on seeing him again, almost safe and sound, after a hundred and four\r\n'b'days separation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton then in a few words recounted what had happened, or, at least, as\r\n'b'much as he knew.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The day after his arrival at the corral, on the 10th of last November,\r\n'b'at nightfall, he was surprised by the convicts, who had scaled the\r\n'b'palisade. They bound and gagged him; then he was led to a dark cavern,\r\n'b'at the foot of Mount Franklin, where the convicts had taken refuge.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His death had been decided upon, and the next day the convicts were\r\n'b'about to kill him, when one of them recognized him and called him by\r\n'b'the name which he bore in Australia. The wretches had no scruples as to\r\n'b'murdering Ayrton! They spared Ben Joyce!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But from that moment Ayrton was exposed to the importunities of his\r\n'b'former accomplices. They wished him to join them again, and relied upon\r\n'b'his aid to enable them to gain possession of Granite House, to penetrate\r\n'b'into that hitherto inaccessible dwelling, and to become masters of the\r\n'b'island, after murdering the colonists!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton remained firm. The once convict, now repentant and pardoned,\r\n'b'would rather die than betray his companions. Ayrton--bound, gagged, and\r\n'b'closely watched--lived in this cave for four months.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nevertheless the convicts had discovered the corral a short time after\r\n'b'their arrival in the island, and since then they had subsisted on\r\n'b'Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s stores, but did not live at the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 11th of November, two of the villains, surprised by the\r\n'b'colonists\xe2\x80\x99 arrival, fired at Herbert, and one of them returned, boasting\r\n'b'of having killed one of the inhabitants of the island; but he returned\r\n'b'alone. His companion, as is known, fell by Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s dagger.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s anxiety and despair may be imagined when he learned the news of\r\n'b'Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s death. The settlers were now only four, and, as it seemed,\r\n'b'at the mercy of the convicts. After this event, and during all the\r\n'b'time that the colonists, detained by Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s illness, remained in the\r\n'b'corral, the pirates did not leave their cavern, and even after they had\r\n'b'pillaged the plateau of Prospect Heights, they did not think it prudent\r\n'b'to abandon it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The ill-treatment inflicted on Ayrton was now redoubled. His hands and\r\n'b'feet still bore the bloody marks of the cords which bound him day and\r\n'b'night. Every moment he expected to be put to death, nor did it appear\r\n'b'possible that he could escape.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Matters remained thus until the third week of February. The convicts,\r\n'b'still watching for a favorable opportunity, rarely quitted their\r\n'b'retreat, and only made a few hunting excursions, either to the interior\r\n'b'of the island, or the south coast.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton had no further news of his friends, and relinquished all hope\r\n'b'of ever seeing them again. At last, the unfortunate man, weakened\r\n'b'by ill-treatment, fell into a prostration so profound that sight and\r\n'b'hearing failed him. From that moment, that is to say, since the last two\r\n'b'days, he could give no information whatever of what had occurred.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9csince I was imprisoned in that\r\n'b'cavern, how is it that I find myself in the corral?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHow is it that the convicts are lying yonder dead, in the middle of the\r\n'b'enclosure?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDead!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ayrton, half rising from his bed, notwithstanding his\r\n'b'weakness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His companions supported him. He wished to get up, and with their\r\n'b'assistance he did so. They then proceeded together towards the little\r\n'b'stream.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now broad daylight.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There, on the bank, in the position in which they had been stricken\r\n'b'by death in its most instantaneous form, lay the corpses of the five\r\n'b'convicts!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton was astounded. Harding and his companions looked at him without\r\n'b'uttering a word. On a sign from the engineer, Neb and Pencroft examined\r\n'b'the bodies, already stiffened by the cold.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They bore no apparent trace of any wound.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Only, after carefully examining them, Pencroft found on the forehead of\r\n'b'one, on the chest of another, on the back of this one, on the shoulder\r\n'b'of that, a little red spot, a sort of scarcely visible bruise, the cause\r\n'b'of which it was impossible to conjecture.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is there that they have been struck!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut with what weapon?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA weapon, lightning-like in its effects, and of which we have not the\r\n'b'secret!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who has struck the blow?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe avenging power of the island,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9che who brought you\r\n'b'here, Ayrton, whose influence has once more manifested itself, who does\r\n'b'for us all that which we cannot do for ourselves, and who, his will\r\n'b'accomplished, conceals himself from us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us make search for him, then!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we will search for him,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we shall not\r\n'b'discover this powerful being who performs such wonders, until he pleases\r\n'b'to call us to him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This invisible protection, which rendered their own action unavailing,\r\n'b'both irritated and piqued the engineer. The relative inferiority which\r\n'b'it proved was of a nature to wound a haughty spirit. A generosity\r\n'b'evinced in such a manner as to elude all tokens of gratitude, implied a\r\n'b'sort of disdain for those on whom the obligation was conferred, which in\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s eyes marred, in some degree, the worth of the benefit.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us search,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed, \xe2\x80\x9cand God grant that we may some day be\r\n'b'permitted to prove to this haughty protector that he has not to deal\r\n'b'with ungrateful people! What would I not give could we repay him, by\r\n'b'rendering him in our turn, although at the price of our lives, some\r\n'b'signal service!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From this day, the thoughts of the inhabitants of Lincoln Island were\r\n'b'solely occupied with the intended search. Everything incited them to\r\n'b'discover the answer to this enigma, an answer which would only be the\r\n'b'name of a man endowed with a truly inexplicable, and in some degree\r\n'b'superhuman power.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a few minutes, the settlers re-entered the house, where their\r\n'b'influence soon restored to Ayrton his moral and physical energy. Neb\r\n'b'and Pencroft carried the corpses of the convicts into the forest, some\r\n'b'distance from the corral, and buried them deep in the ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton was then made acquainted with the facts which had occurred during\r\n'b'his seclusion. He learned Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s adventures, and through what various\r\n'b'trials the colonists had passed. As to the settlers, they had despaired\r\n'b'of ever seeing Ayrton again, and had been convinced that the convicts\r\n'b'had ruthlessly murdered him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, as he ended his recital, \xe2\x80\x9ca duty remains\r\n'b'for us to perform. Half of our task is accomplished, but although the\r\n'b'convicts are no longer to be feared, it is not owing to ourselves that\r\n'b'we are once more masters of the island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9clet us search all this labyrinth of\r\n'b'the spurs of Mount Franklin. We will not leave a hollow, not a hole\r\n'b'unexplored! Ah! if ever a reporter found himself face to face with a\r\n'b'mystery, it is I who now speak to you, my friends!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we will not return to Granite House until we have found our\r\n'b'benefactor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will do all that it is humanly possible to\r\n'b'do, but I repeat we shall not find him until he himself permits us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShall we stay at the corral?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall stay here,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cProvisions are abundant, and we\r\n'b'are here in the very center of the circle we have to explore. Besides,\r\n'b'if necessary, the cart will take us rapidly to Granite House.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly I have a remark to make.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHere is the fine season getting on, and we must not forget that we have\r\n'b'a voyage to make.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA voyage?\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to Tabor Island,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is necessary to carry a\r\n'b'notice there to point out the position of our island and say that Ayrton\r\n'b'is here in case the Scotch yacht should come to take him off. Who knows\r\n'b'if it is not already too late?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ayrton, \xe2\x80\x9chow do you intend to make this voyage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn the \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ayrton. \xe2\x80\x9cShe no longer exists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 exists no longer!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Pencroft, bounding from\r\n'b'his seat.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ayrton. \xe2\x80\x9cThe convicts discovered her in her little harbor\r\n'b'only eight days ago, they put to sea in her--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, his heart beating.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd not having Bob Harvey to steer her, they ran on the rocks, and the\r\n'b'vessel went to pieces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the villains, the cutthroats, the infamous scoundrels!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed\r\n'b'Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, taking the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s hand, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will build\r\n'b'another \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99--a larger one. We have all the ironwork--all the\r\n'b'rigging of the brig at our disposal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut do you know,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it will take at least five\r\n'b'or six months to build a vessel of from thirty to forty tons?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe can take our time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cand we must give up the\r\n'b'voyage to Tabor Island for this year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure!\xe2\x80\x99 my poor \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, almost\r\n'b'broken-hearted at the destruction of the vessel of which he was so\r\n'b'proud.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The loss of the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d was certainly a thing to be lamented by\r\n'b'the colonists, and it was agreed that this loss should be repaired\r\n'b'as soon as possible. This settled, they now occupied themselves with\r\n'b'bringing their researches to bear on the most secret parts of the\r\n'b'island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The exploration was commenced at daybreak on the 19th of February, and\r\n'b'lasted an entire week. The base of the mountain, with its spurs and\r\n'b'their numberless ramifications, formed a labyrinth of valleys and\r\n'b'elevations. It was evident that there, in the depths of these narrow\r\n'b'gorges, perhaps even in the interior of Mount Franklin itself, was the\r\n'b'proper place to pursue their researches. No part of the island could\r\n'b'have been more suitable to conceal a dwelling whose occupant wished to\r\n'b'remain unknown. But so irregular was the formation of the valleys that\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding was obliged to conduct the exploration in a strictly\r\n'b'methodical manner.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists first visited the valley opening to the south of the\r\n'b'volcano, and which first received the waters of Falls River. There\r\n'b'Ayrton showed them the cavern where the convicts had taken refuge, and\r\n'b'in which he had been imprisoned until his removal to the corral. This\r\n'b'cavern was just as Ayrton had left it. They found there a considerable\r\n'b'quantity of ammunition and provisions, conveyed thither by the convicts\r\n'b'in order to form a reserve.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The whole of the valley bordering on the cave, shaded by fir and\r\n'b'other trees, was thoroughly explored, and on turning the point of the\r\n'b'southwestern spur, the colonists entered a narrower gorge similar to the\r\n'b'picturesque columns of basalt on the coast. Here the trees were fewer.\r\n'b'Stones took the place of grass. Goats and musmons gambolled among the\r\n'b'rocks. Here began the barren part of the island. It could already be\r\n'b'seen that, of the numerous valleys branching off at the base of Mount\r\n'b'Franklin, three only were wooded and rich in pasturage like that of the\r\n'b'corral, which bordered on the west on the Falls River valley, and on the\r\n'b'east on the Red Creek valley. These two streams, which lower down became\r\n'b'rivers by the absorption of several tributaries, were formed by all the\r\n'b'springs of the mountain and thus caused the fertility of its southern\r\n'b'part. As to the Mercy, it was more directly fed from ample springs\r\n'b'concealed under the cover of Jacamar Wood, and it was by springs of\r\n'b'this nature, spreading in a thousand streamlets, that the soil of the\r\n'b'Serpentine Peninsula was watered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Now, of these three well-watered valleys, either might have served as a\r\n'b'retreat to some solitary who would have found there everything necessary\r\n'b'for life. But the settlers had already explored them, and in no part had\r\n'b'they discovered the presence of man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Was it then in the depths of those barren gorges, in the midst of the\r\n'b'piles of rock, in the rugged northern ravines, among the streams of\r\n'b'lava, that this dwelling and its occupant would be found?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The northern part of Mount Franklin was at its base composed solely of\r\n'b'two valleys, wide, not very deep, without any appearance of vegetation,\r\n'b'strewn with masses of rock, paved with lava, and varied with great\r\n'b'blocks of mineral. This region required a long and careful exploration.\r\n'b'It contained a thousand cavities, comfortless no doubt, but perfectly\r\n'b'concealed and difficult of access.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists even visited dark tunnels, dating from the volcanic\r\n'b'period, still black from the passage of the fire, and penetrated into\r\n'b'the depths of the mountain. They traversed these somber galleries,\r\n'b'waving lighted torches; they examined the smallest excavations; they\r\n'b'sounded the shallowest depths, but all was dark and silent. It did\r\n'b'not appear that the foot of man had ever before trodden these ancient\r\n'b'passages, or that his arm had ever displaced one of these blocks, which\r\n'b'remained as the volcano had cast them up above the waters, at the time\r\n'b'of the submersion of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, although these passages appeared to be absolutely deserted, and\r\n'b'the obscurity was complete, Cyrus Harding was obliged to confess that\r\n'b'absolute silence did not reign there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On arriving at the end of one of these gloomy caverns, extending several\r\n'b'hundred feet into the interior of the mountain, he was surprised to hear\r\n'b'a deep rumbling noise, increased in intensity by the sonorousness of the\r\n'b'rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett, who accompanied him, also heard these distant\r\n'b'mutterings, which indicated a revivification of the subterranean fires.\r\n'b'Several times both listened, and they agreed that some chemical process\r\n'b'was taking place in the bowels of the earth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen the volcano is not totally extinct?\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible that since our exploration of the crater,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding, \xe2\x80\x9csome change has occurred. Any volcano, although considered\r\n'b'extinct, may evidently again burst forth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut if an eruption of Mount Franklin occurred,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cwould\r\n'b'there not be some danger to Lincoln Island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cThe crater, that is to\r\n'b'say, the safety-valve, exists, and the overflow of smoke and lava, would\r\n'b'escape, as it did formerly, by this customary outlet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUnless the lava opened a new way for itself towards the fertile parts\r\n'b'of the island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why, my dear Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cshould it not\r\n'b'follow the road naturally traced out for it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, volcanoes are capricious,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNotice,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the inclination of Mount Franklin\r\n'b'favors the flow of water towards the valleys which we are exploring just\r\n'b'now. To turn aside this flow, an earthquake would be necessary to change\r\n'b'the mountain\xe2\x80\x99s center of gravity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut an earthquake is always to be feared at these times,\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAlways,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cespecially when the subterranean forces\r\n'b'begin to awake, as they risk meeting with some obstruction, after a long\r\n'b'rest. Thus, my dear Spilett, an eruption would be a serious thing\r\n'b'for us, and it would be better that the volcano should not have the\r\n'b'slightest desire to wake up. But we could not prevent it, could we? At\r\n'b'any rate, even if it should occur, I do not think Prospect Heights would\r\n'b'be seriously threatened. Between them and the mountain, the ground\r\n'b'is considerably depressed, and if the lava should ever take a course\r\n'b'towards the lake, it would be cast on the downs and the neighboring\r\n'b'parts of Shark Gulf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe have not yet seen any smoke at the top of the mountain, to indicate\r\n'b'an approaching eruption,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cnot a vapor escapes from the crater, for it\r\n'b'was only yesterday that I attentively surveyed the summit. But it\r\n'b'is probable that at the lower part of the chimney, time may have\r\n'b'accumulated rocks, cinders, hardened lava, and that this valve of which\r\n'b'I spoke, may at any time become overcharged. But at the first serious\r\n'b'effort, every obstacle will disappear, and you may be certain, my dear\r\n'b'Spilett, that neither the island, which is the boiler, nor the\r\n'b'volcano, which is the chimney, will burst under the pressure of gas.\r\n'b'Nevertheless, I repeat, it would be better that there should not be an\r\n'b'eruption.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet we are not mistaken,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cMutterings can be\r\n'b'distinctly heard in the very bowels of the volcano!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, again listening attentively. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\r\n'b'can be no doubt of it. A commotion is going on there, of which we can\r\n'b'neither estimate the importance nor the ultimate result.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Spilett, on coming out, rejoined their companions, to\r\n'b'whom they made known the state of affairs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVery well!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cThe volcano wants to play his pranks! Let\r\n'b'him try, if he likes! He will find his master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur good genius, Neb, our good genius, who will shut his mouth for him,\r\n'b'if he so much as pretends to open it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As may be seen, the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s confidence in the tutelary deity of his\r\n'b'island was absolute, and, certainly, the occult power, manifested until\r\n'b'now in so many inexplicable ways, appeared to be unlimited; but also it\r\n'b'knew how to escape the colonists\xe2\x80\x99 most minute researches, for, in\r\n'b'spite of all their efforts, in spite of the more than zeal,--the\r\n'b'obstinacy,--with which they carried on their exploration, the retreat of\r\n'b'the mysterious being could not be discovered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From the 19th to the 20th of February the circle of investigation was\r\n'b'extended to all the northern region of Lincoln Island, whose most secret\r\n'b'nooks were explored. The colonists even went the length of tapping every\r\n'b'rock. The search was extended to the extreme verge of the mountain. It\r\n'b'was explored thus to the very summit of the truncated cone terminating\r\n'b'the first row of rocks, then to the upper ridge of the enormous hat, at\r\n'b'the bottom of which opened the crater.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They did more; they visited the gulf, now extinct, but in whose depths\r\n'b'the rumbling could be distinctly heard. However, no sign of smoke or\r\n'b'vapor, no heating of the rock, indicated an approaching eruption.\r\n'b'But neither there, nor in any other part of Mount Franklin, did the\r\n'b'colonists find any traces of him of whom they were in search.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their investigations were then directed to the downs. They carefully\r\n'b'examined the high lava-cliffs of Shark Gulf from the base to the crest,\r\n'b'although it was extremely difficult to reach even the level of the gulf.\r\n'b'No one!--nothing!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Indeed, in these three words was summed up so much fatigue uselessly\r\n'b'expended, so much energy producing no results, that somewhat of anger\r\n'b'mingled with the discomfiture of Cyrus Harding and his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now time to think of returning, for these researches could not be\r\n'b'prolonged indefinitely. The colonists were certainly right in believing\r\n'b'that the mysterious being did not reside on the surface of the island,\r\n'b'and the wildest fancies haunted their excited imaginations. Pencroft\r\n'b'and Neb, particularly, were not contented with the mystery, but allowed\r\n'b'their imaginations to wander into the domain of the supernatural.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 25th of February the colonists re-entered Granite House, and by\r\n'b'means of the double cord, carried by an arrow to the threshold of the\r\n'b'door, they re-established communication between their habitation and the\r\n'b'ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A month later they commemorated, on the 25th of March, the third\r\n'b'anniversary of their arrival on Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 14\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Three years had passed away since the escape of the prisoners from\r\n'b'Richmond, and how often during those three years had they spoken of\r\n'b'their country, always present in their thoughts!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They had no doubt that the civil war was at an end, and to them it\r\n'b'appeared impossible that the just cause of the North had not triumphed.\r\n'b'But what had been the incidents of this terrible war? How much blood had\r\n'b'it not cost? How many of their friends must have fallen in the struggle?\r\n'b'They often spoke of these things, without as yet being able to foresee\r\n'b'the day when they would be permitted once more to see their country.\r\n'b'To return thither, were it but for a few days, to renew the social link\r\n'b'with the inhabited world, to establish a communication between their\r\n'b'native land and their island, then to pass the longest, perhaps the\r\n'b'best, portion of their existence in this colony, founded by them,\r\n'b'and which would then be dependent on their country, was this a dream\r\n'b'impossible to realize?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There were only two ways of accomplishing it--either a ship must appear\r\n'b'off Lincoln Island, or the colonists must themselves build a vessel\r\n'b'strong enough to sail to the nearest land.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUnless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cour good genius, himself provides us with the\r\n'b'means of returning to our country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And, really, had any one told Pencroft and Neb that a ship of 300 tons\r\n'b'was waiting for them in Shark Gulf or at Port Balloon, they would not\r\n'b'even have made a gesture of surprise. In their state of mind nothing\r\n'b'appeared improbable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Cyrus Harding, less confident, advised them to confine themselves to\r\n'b'fact, and more especially so with regard to the building of a vessel--a\r\n'b'really urgent work, since it was for the purpose of depositing, as\r\n'b'soon as possible, at Tabor Island a document indicating Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s new\r\n'b'residence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As the \xe2\x80\x9cBonadventure\xe2\x80\x9d no longer existed, six months at least would\r\n'b'be required for the construction of a new vessel. Now winter was\r\n'b'approaching, and the voyage would not be made before the following\r\n'b'spring.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe have time to get everything ready for the fine season,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\r\n'b'the engineer, who was consulting with Pencroft about these matters. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n'b'think, therefore, my friend, that since we have to rebuild our vessel\r\n'b'it will be best to give her larger dimensions. The arrival of the Scotch\r\n'b'yacht at Tabor Island is very uncertain. It may even be that, having\r\n'b'arrived several months ago, she has again sailed after having vainly\r\n'b'searched for some trace of Ayrton. Will it not then be best to build\r\n'b'a ship which, if necessary, could take us either to the Polynesian\r\n'b'Archipelago or to New Zealand? What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor; \xe2\x80\x9cI think that you are as\r\n'b'capable of building a large vessel as a small one. Neither the wood nor\r\n'b'the tools are wanting. It is only a question of time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how many months would be required to build a vessel of from 250 to\r\n'b'300 tons?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSeven or eight months at least,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cBut it must not be\r\n'b'forgotten that winter is drawing near, and that in severe frost wood is\r\n'b'difficult to work. We must calculate on several weeks delay, and if our\r\n'b'vessel is ready by next November we may think ourselves very lucky.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cthat will be exactly the most favorable\r\n'b'time for undertaking a voyage of any importance, either to Tabor Island\r\n'b'or to a more distant land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo it will, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cMake out your plans then;\r\n'b'the workmen are ready, and I imagine that Ayrton can lend us a good\r\n'b'helping hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, having been consulted, approved the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s plan,\r\n'b'and it was, indeed, the best thing to be done. It is true that the\r\n'b'construction of a ship of from two to three hundred tons would be great\r\n'b'labor, but the colonists had confidence in themselves, justified by\r\n'b'their previous success.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding then busied himself in drawing the plan of the vessel and\r\n'b'making the model. During this time his companions employed themselves in\r\n'b'felling and carting trees to furnish the ribs, timbers, and planks.\r\n'b'The forest of the Far West supplied the best oaks and elms. They took\r\n'b'advantage of the opening already made on their last excursion to form a\r\n'b'practicable road, which they named the Far West Road, and the trees were\r\n'b'carried to the Chimneys, where the dockyard was established. As to\r\n'b'the road in question, the choice of trees had rendered its direction\r\n'b'somewhat capricious, but at the same time it facilitated the access to a\r\n'b'large part of the Serpentine Peninsula.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was important that the trees should be quickly felled and cut up, for\r\n'b'they could not be used while yet green, and some time was necessary to\r\n'b'allow them to get seasoned. The carpenters, therefore, worked vigorously\r\n'b'during the month of April, which was troubled only by a few equinoctial\r\n'b'gales of some violence. Master Jup aided them dexterously, either by\r\n'b'climbing to the top of a tree to fasten the ropes or by lending his\r\n'b'stout shoulders to carry the lopped trunks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All this timber was piled up under a large shed, built near the\r\n'b'Chimneys, and there awaited the time for use.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The month of April was tolerably fine, as October often is in the\r\n'b'northern zone. At the same time other work was actively continued, and\r\n'b'soon all trace of devastation disappeared from the plateau of\r\n'b'Prospect Heights. The mill was rebuilt, and new buildings rose in the\r\n'b'poultry-yard. It had appeared necessary to enlarge their dimensions,\r\n'b'for the feathered population had increased considerably. The stable\r\n'b'now contained five onagers, four of which were well broken, and allowed\r\n'b'themselves to be either driven or ridden, and a little colt. The colony\r\n'b'now possessed a plow, to which the onagers were yoked like regular\r\n'b'Yorkshire or Kentucky oxen. The colonists divided their work, and their\r\n'b'arms never tired. Then who could have enjoyed better health than these\r\n'b'workers, and what good humor enlivened the evenings in Granite House as\r\n'b'they formed a thousand plans for the future!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'As a matter of course Ayrton shared the common lot in every respect,\r\n'b'and there was no longer any talk of his going to live at the corral.\r\n'b'Nevertheless he was still sad and reserved, and joined more in the work\r\n'b'than in the pleasures of his companions. But he was a valuable workman\r\n'b'at need--strong, skilful, ingenious, intelligent. He was esteemed and\r\n'b'loved by all, and he could not be ignorant of it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the meanwhile the corral was not abandoned. Every other day one of\r\n'b'the settlers, driving the cart or mounted on an onager, went to look\r\n'b'after the flock of musmons and goats and bring back the supply of\r\n'b'milk required by Neb. These excursions at the same time afforded\r\n'b'opportunities for hunting. Therefore Herbert and Gideon Spilett, with\r\n'b'Top in front, traversed more often than their companions the road to\r\n'b'the corral, and with the capital guns which they carried, capybaras,\r\n'b'agouties, kangaroos, and wild pigs for large game, ducks, grouse,\r\n'b'jacamars, and snipe for small game, were never wanting in the house.\r\n'b'The produce of the warren, of the oyster-bed, several turtles which were\r\n'b'taken, excellent salmon which came up the Mercy, vegetables from the\r\n'b'plateau, wild fruit from the forest, were riches upon riches, and Neb,\r\n'b'the head cook, could scarcely by himself store them away.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The telegraphic wire between the corral and Granite House had of course\r\n'b'been repaired, and it was worked whenever one or other of the settlers\r\n'b'was at the corral and found it necessary to spend the night there.\r\n'b'Besides, the island was safe now and no attacks were to be feared, at\r\n'b'any rate from men.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, that which had happened might happen again. A descent of\r\n'b'pirates, or even of escaped convicts, was always to be feared. It was\r\n'b'possible that companions or accomplices of Bob Harvey had been in the\r\n'b'secret of his plans, and might be tempted to imitate him. The colonists,\r\n'b'therefore, were careful to observe the sea around the island, and every\r\n'b'day their telescope covered the horizon enclosed by Union and Washington\r\n'b'Bays. When they went to the corral they examined the sea to the west\r\n'b'with no less attention, and by climbing the spur their gaze extended\r\n'b'over a large section of the western horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nothing suspicious was discerned, but still it was necessary for them to\r\n'b'be on their guard.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer one evening imparted to his friends a plan which he had\r\n'b'conceived for fortifying the corral. It appeared prudent to him to\r\n'b'heighten the palisade and to flank it with a sort of blockhouse, which,\r\n'b'if necessary, the settlers could hold against the enemy. Granite House\r\n'b'might, by its very position, be considered impregnable; therefore the\r\n'b'corral with its buildings, its stores, and the animals it contained,\r\n'b'would always be the object of pirates, whoever they were, who might land\r\n'b'on the island, and should the colonists be obliged to shut themselves\r\n'b'up there they ought also to be able to defend themselves without any\r\n'b'disadvantage. This was a project which might be left for consideration,\r\n'b'and they were, besides, obliged to put off its execution until the next\r\n'b'spring.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'About the 15th of May the keel of the new vessel lay along the dockyard,\r\n'b'and soon the stem and stern-post, mortised at each of its extremities,\r\n'b'rose almost perpendicularly. The keel, of good oak, measured 110 feet\r\n'b'in length, this allowing a width of five-and-twenty feet to the midship\r\n'b'beam. But this was all the carpenters could do before the arrival of the\r\n'b'frosts and bad weather. During the following week they fixed the first\r\n'b'of the stern timbers, but were then obliged to suspend work.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the last days of the month the weather was extremely bad. The\r\n'b'wind blew from the east, sometimes with the violence of a tempest. The\r\n'b'engineer was somewhat uneasy on account of the dockyard shed--which\r\n'b'besides, he could not have established in any other place near to\r\n'b'Granite House--for the islet only imperfectly sheltered the shore from\r\n'b'the fury of the open sea, and in great storms the waves beat against the\r\n'b'very foot of the granite cliff.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But, very fortunately, these fears were not realized. The wind shifted\r\n'b'to the southeast, and there the beach of Granite House was completely\r\n'b'covered by Flotsam Point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Ayrton, the most zealous workmen at the new vessel, pursued\r\n'b'their labor as long as they could. They were not men to mind the wind\r\n'b'tearing at their hair, nor the rain wetting them to the skin, and a blow\r\n'b'from a hammer is worth just as much in bad as in fine weather. But when\r\n'b'a severe frost succeeded this wet period, the wood, its fibers acquiring\r\n'b'the hardness of iron, became extremely difficult to work, and about the\r\n'b'10th of June shipbuilding was obliged to be entirely discontinued.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions had not omitted to observe how severe\r\n'b'was the temperature during the winters of Lincoln Island. The cold was\r\n'b'comparable to that experienced in the States of New England, situated at\r\n'b'almost the same distance from the equator. In the northern hemisphere,\r\n'b'or at any rate in the part occupied by British America and the north of\r\n'b'the United States, this phenomenon is explained by the flat conformation\r\n'b'of the territories bordering on the pole, and on which there is no\r\n'b'intumescence of the soil to oppose any obstacle to the north winds;\r\n'b'here, in Lincoln Island, this explanation would not suffice.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt has even been observed,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Harding one day to his companions,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cthat in equal latitudes the islands and coast regions are less tried by\r\n'b'the cold than inland countries. I have often heard it asserted that the\r\n'b'winters of Lombardy, for example, are not less rigorous than those of\r\n'b'Scotland, which results from the sea restoring during the winter the\r\n'b'heat which it received during the summer. Islands are, therefore, in a\r\n'b'better situation for benefiting by this restitution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut then, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy does Lincoln Island\r\n'b'appear to escape the common law?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is difficult to explain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cHowever, I\r\n'b'should be disposed to conjecture that this peculiarity results from the\r\n'b'situation of the island in the Southern Hemisphere, which, as you know,\r\n'b'my boy, is colder than the Northern Hemisphere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand icebergs are met with in lower latitudes in\r\n'b'the south than in the north of the Pacific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cand when I have been serving on\r\n'b'board whalers I have seen icebergs off Cape Horn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe severe cold experienced in Lincoln Island,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cmay then perhaps be explained by the presence of floes or icebergs\r\n'b'comparatively near to Lincoln Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYour opinion is very admissible indeed, my dear Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand it is evidently to the proximity of icebergs that\r\n'b'we owe our rigorous winters. I would draw your attention also to an\r\n'b'entirely physical cause, which renders the Southern colder than the\r\n'b'Northern Hemisphere.
