In fact, since the sun is nearer to this hemisphere\r\n'b'during the summer, it is necessarily more distant during the winter.\r\n'b'This explains then the excess of temperature in the two seasons, for, if\r\n'b'we find the winters very cold in Lincoln Island, we must not forget that\r\n'b'the summers here, on the contrary, are very hot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut why, if you please, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft, knitting his brows,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cwhy should our hemisphere, as you say, be so badly divided? It isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n'b'just, that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFriend Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cwhether just\r\n'b'or not, we must submit to it, and here lies the reason for this\r\n'b'peculiarity. The earth does not describe a circle around the sun, but\r\n'b'an ellipse, as it must by the laws of rational mechanics. Now, the earth\r\n'b'occupies one of the foci of the ellipse, and so at one point in its\r\n'b'course is at its apogee, that is, at its farthest from the sun, and\r\n'b'at another point it is at its perigee, or nearest to the sun. Now it\r\n'b'happens that it is during the winter of the southern countries that\r\n'b'it is at its most distant point from the sun, and consequently, in a\r\n'b'situation for those regions to feel the greatest cold. Nothing can be\r\n'b'done to prevent that, and men, Pencroft, however learned they may be,\r\n'b'can never change anything of the cosmographical order established by God\r\n'b'Himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d added Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthe world is very learned. What a big book,\r\n'b'captain, might be made with all that is known!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what a much bigger book still with all that is not known!\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\n'b'Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last, for one reason or another, the month of June brought the cold\r\n'b'with its accustomed intensity, and the settlers were often confined to\r\n'b'Granite House. Ah! how wearisome this imprisonment was to them, and more\r\n'b'particularly to Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook here,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Neb one day, \xe2\x80\x9cI would give you by notarial\r\n'b'deed all the estates which will come to me some day, if you were a good\r\n'b'enough fellow to go, no matter where, and subscribe to some newspaper\r\n'b'for me! Decidedly the thing that is most essential to my happiness is\r\n'b'the knowing every morning what has happened the day before in other\r\n'b'places than this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb began to laugh.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Pon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cthe only thing I think about is my daily\r\n'b'work!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The truth was that indoors as well as out there was no want of work.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colony of Lincoln Island was now at its highest point of prosperity,\r\n'b'achieved by three years of continued hard work. The destruction of the\r\n'b'brig had been a new source of riches. Without speaking of the complete\r\n'b'rig which would serve for the vessel now on the stocks, utensils and\r\n'b'tools of all sorts, weapons and ammunition, clothes and instruments,\r\n'b'were now piled in the storerooms of Granite House. It had not even\r\n'b'been necessary to resort again to the manufacture of the coarse felt\r\n'b'materials. Though the colonists had suffered from cold during their\r\n'b'first winter, the bad season might now come without their having any\r\n'b'reason to dread its severity. Linen was plentiful also, and besides,\r\n'b'they kept it with extreme care. From chloride of sodium, which is\r\n'b'nothing else than sea salt, Cyrus Harding easily extracted the soda and\r\n'b'chlorine. The soda, which it was easy to change into carbonate of soda,\r\n'b'and the chlorine, of which he made chloride of lime, were employed for\r\n'b'various domestic purposes, and especially in bleaching linen. Besides,\r\n'b'they did not wash more than four times a year, as was done by families\r\n'b'in the olden times, and it may be added, that Pencroft and Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, while waiting for the postman to bring him his newspaper,\r\n'b'distinguished themselves as washermen.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So passed the winter months, June, July, and August. They were severe,\r\n'b'and the average observations of the thermometer did not give more than\r\n'b'eight degrees of Fahrenheit. It was therefore lower in temperature than\r\n'b'the preceding winter. But then, what splendid fires blazed continually\r\n'b'on the hearths of Granite House, the smoke marking the granite wall with\r\n'b'long, zebra-like streaks! Fuel was not spared, as it grew naturally a\r\n'b'few steps from them. Besides, the chips of the wood destined for the\r\n'b'construction of the ship enabled them to economize the coal, which\r\n'b'required more trouble to transport.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Men and animals were all well. Master Jup was a little chilly, it must\r\n'b'be confessed. This was perhaps his only weakness, and it was necessary\r\n'b'to make him a well-padded dressing-gown. But what a servant he was,\r\n'b'clever, zealous, indefatigable, not indiscreet, not talkative, and\r\n'b'he might have been with reason proposed as a model for all his biped\r\n'b'brothers in the Old and New Worlds!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs for that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen one has four hands at one\xe2\x80\x99s service,\r\n'b'of course one\xe2\x80\x99s work ought to be done so much the better!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And indeed the intelligent creature did it well.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the seven months which had passed since the last researches made\r\n'b'round the mountain, and during the month of September, which brought\r\n'b'back fine weather, nothing was heard of the genius of the island. His\r\n'b'power was not manifested in any way. It is true that it would have\r\n'b'been superfluous, for no incident occurred to put the colonists to any\r\n'b'painful trial.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding even observed that if by chance the communication between\r\n'b'the unknown and the tenants of Granite House had ever been established\r\n'b'through the granite, and if Top\xe2\x80\x99s instinct had as it were felt it, there\r\n'b'was no further sign of it during this period. The dog\xe2\x80\x99s growling\r\n'b'had entirely ceased, as well as the uneasiness of the orang. The two\r\n'b'friends--for they were such--no longer prowled round the opening of the\r\n'b'inner well, nor did they bark or whine in that singular way which from\r\n'b'the first the engineer had noticed. But could he be sure that this was\r\n'b'all that was to be said about this enigma, and that he should never\r\n'b'arrive at a solution? Could he be certain that some conjuncture would\r\n'b'not occur which would bring the mysterious personage on the scene? who\r\n'b'could tell what the future might have in reserve?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last the winter was ended, but an event, the consequences of which\r\n'b'might be serious occurred in the first days of the returning spring.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On the 7th of September, Cyrus Harding, having observed the crater, saw\r\n'b'smoke curling round the summit of the mountain, its first vapors rising\r\n'b'in the air.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 15\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, warned by the engineer, left their work and gazed in\r\n'b'silence at the summit of Mount Franklin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The volcano had awoke, and the vapor had penetrated the mineral layer\r\n'b'heaped at the bottom of the crater. But would the subterranean fires\r\n'b'provoke any violent eruption? This was an event which could not be\r\n'b'foreseen. However, even while admitting the possibility of an eruption,\r\n'b'it was not probable that the whole of Lincoln Island would suffer from\r\n'b'it. The flow of volcanic matter is not always disastrous, and the island\r\n'b'had already undergone this trial, as was shown by the streams of lava\r\n'b'hardened on the northern slopes of the mountain. Besides, from the shape\r\n'b'of the crater--the opening broken in the upper edge--the matter would be\r\n'b'thrown to the side opposite the fertile regions of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, the past did not necessarily answer for the future. Often, at\r\n'b'the summit of volcanoes, the old craters close and new ones open.\r\n'b'This had occurred in the two hemispheres--at Etna, Popocatepetl, at\r\n'b'Orizabaand on the eve of an eruption there is everything to be feared.\r\n'b'In fact, an earthquake--a phenomenon which often accompanies volcanic\r\n'b'eruption--is enough to change the interior arrangement of a mountain,\r\n'b'and to open new outlets for the burning lava.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding explained these things to his companions, and, without\r\n'b'exaggerating the state of things, he told them all the pros and cons.\r\n'b'After all, they could not prevent it. It did not appear likely that\r\n'b'Granite House would be threatened unless the ground was shaken by an\r\n'b'earthquake. But the corral would be in great danger should a new crater\r\n'b'open in the southern side of Mount Franklin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From that day the smoke never disappeared from the top of the mountain,\r\n'b'and it could even be perceived that it increased in height and\r\n'b'thickness, without any flame mingling in its heavy volumes. The\r\n'b'phenomenon was still concentrated in the lower part of the central\r\n'b'crater.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'However, with the fine days work had been continued. The building of the\r\n'b'vessel was hastened as much as possible, and, by means of the waterfall\r\n'b'on the shore, Cyrus Harding managed to establish an hydraulic sawmill,\r\n'b'which rapidly cut up the trunks of trees into planks and joists. The\r\n'b'mechanism of this apparatus was as simple as those used in the rustic\r\n'b'sawmills of Norway. A first horizontal movement to move the piece of\r\n'b'wood, a second vertical movement to move the saw--this was all that was\r\n'b'wanted; and the engineer succeeded by means of a wheel, two cylinders,\r\n'b'and pulleys properly arranged. Towards the end of the month of September\r\n'b'the skeleton of the vessel, which was to be rigged as a schooner, lay\r\n'b'in the dockyard. The ribs were almost entirely completed, and, all the\r\n'b'timbers having been sustained by a provisional band, the shape of the\r\n'b'vessel could already be seen. The schooner, sharp in the bows, very\r\n'b'slender in the after-part, would evidently be suitable for a long\r\n'b'voyage, if wanted; but laying the planking would still take a\r\n'b'considerable time. Very fortunately, the iron work of the pirate brig\r\n'b'had been saved after the explosion. From the planks and injured ribs\r\n'b'Pencroft and Ayrton had extracted the bolts and a large quantity\r\n'b'of copper nails. It was so much work saved for the smiths, but the\r\n'b'carpenters had much to do.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Shipbuilding was interrupted for a week for the harvest, the haymaking,\r\n'b'and the gathering in of the different crops on the plateau. This work\r\n'b'finished, every moment was devoted to finishing the schooner. When night\r\n'b'came the workmen were really quite exhausted. So as not to lose any\r\n'b'time they had changed the hours for their meals; they dined at twelve\r\n'b'o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and only had their supper when daylight failed them. They then\r\n'b'ascended to Granite House, when they were always ready to go to bed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Sometimes, however, when the conversation bore on some interesting\r\n'b'subject the hour for sleep was delayed for a time. The colonists then\r\n'b'spoke of the future, and talked willingly of the changes which a voyage\r\n'b'in the schooner to inhabited lands would make in their situation.\r\n'b'But always, in the midst of these plans, prevailed the thought of a\r\n'b'subsequent return to Lincoln Island. Never would they abandon this\r\n'b'colony, founded with so much labor and with such success, and to which\r\n'b'a communication with America would afford a fresh impetus. Pencroft and\r\n'b'Neb especially hoped to end their days there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHerbert,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will never abandon Lincoln Island?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever, Pencroft, and especially if you make up your mind to stay\r\n'b'there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat was made up long ago, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall expect\r\n'b'you. You will bring me your wife and children, and I shall make jolly\r\n'b'chaps of your youngsters!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s agreed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, laughing and blushing at the same\r\n'b'time.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Pencroft enthusiastically, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will\r\n'b'be still the governor of the island! Ah, how many inhabitants could it\r\n'b'support? Ten thousand at least!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They talked in this way, allowing Pencroft to run on, and at last the\r\n'b'reporter actually started a newspaper--the New Lincoln Herald!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'So is man\xe2\x80\x99s heart. The desire to perform a work which will endure, which\r\n'b'will survive him, is the origin of his superiority over all other living\r\n'b'creatures here below. It is this which has established his dominion, and\r\n'b'this it is which justifies it, over all the world.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After that, who knows if Jup and Top had not themselves their little\r\n'b'dream of the future.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton silently said to himself that he would like to see Lord Glenarvan\r\n'b'again and show himself to all restored.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'One evening, on the 15th of October, the conversation was prolonged\r\n'b'later than usual. It was nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock. Already, long badly concealed\r\n'b'yawns gave warning of the hour of rest, and Pencroft was proceeding\r\n'b'towards his bed, when the electric bell, placed in the dining-room,\r\n'b'suddenly rang.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All were there, Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Ayrton,\r\n'b'Pencroft, Neb. Therefore none of the colonists were at the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding rose. His companions stared at each other, scarcely\r\n'b'believing their ears.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does that mean?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb. \xe2\x80\x9cWas it the devil who rang it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No one answered.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe weather is stormy,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Herbert. \xe2\x80\x9cMight not its influence of\r\n'b'electricity--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert did not finish his phrase. The engineer, towards whom all eyes\r\n'b'were turned, shook his head negatively.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it is a signal, whoever it may\r\n'b'be who has made it, he will renew it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut who do you think it is?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sailor\xe2\x80\x99s sentence was cut short by a new tinkle of the bell.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding went to the apparatus, and sent this question to the corral:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few moments later the needle, moving on the alphabetic dial, gave this\r\n'b'reply to the tenants of Granite House:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome to the corral immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt last!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Yes! At last! The mystery was about to be unveiled. The colonists\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'fatigue had disappeared before the tremendous interest which was about\r\n'b'to urge them to the corral, and all wish for rest had ceased. Without\r\n'b'having uttered a word, in a few moments they had left Granite House,\r\n'b'and were standing on the beach. Jup and Top alone were left behind. They\r\n'b'could do without them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The night was black. The new moon had disappeared at the same time as\r\n'b'the sun. As Herbert had observed, great stormy clouds formed a lowering\r\n'b'and heavy vault, preventing any star rays. A few lightning flashes,\r\n'b'reflections from a distant storm, illuminated the horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was possible that a few hours later the thunder would roll over the\r\n'b'island itself. The night was very threatening.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But however deep the darkness was, it would not prevent them from\r\n'b'finding the familiar road to the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They ascended the left bank of the Mercy, reached the plateau, passed\r\n'b'the bridge over Creek Glycerine, and advanced through the forest.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They walked at a good pace, a prey to the liveliest emotions. There was\r\n'b'no doubt but that they were now going to learn the long-searched-for\r\n'b'answer to the enigma, the name of that mysterious being, so deeply\r\n'b'concerned in their life, so generous in his influence, so powerful\r\n'b'in his action! Must not this stranger have indeed mingled with their\r\n'b'existence, have known the smallest details, have heard all that was said\r\n'b'in Granite House, to have been able always to act in the very nick of\r\n'b'time?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Every one, wrapped up in his own reflections, pressed forward. Under the\r\n'b'arch of trees the darkness was such that even the edge of the road\r\n'b'could not be seen. Not a sound in the forest. Both animals and birds,\r\n'b'influenced by the heaviness of the atmosphere, remained motionless\r\n'b'and silent. Not a breath disturbed the leaves. The footsteps of the\r\n'b'colonists alone resounded on the hardened ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the first quarter of an hour the silence was only interrupted by\r\n'b'this remark from Pencroft:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe ought to have brought a torch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And by this reply from the engineer:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall find one at the corral.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding and his companions had left Granite House at twelve minutes past\r\n'b'nine. At forty-seven minutes past nine they had traversed three out of\r\n'b'the five miles which separated the mouth of the Mercy from the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At that moment sheets of lightning spread over the island and illumined\r\n'b'the dark trees. The flashes dazzled and almost blinded them. Evidently\r\n'b'the storm would not be long in bursting forth.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The flashes gradually became brighter and more rapid. Distant thunder\r\n'b'growled in the sky. The atmosphere was stifling.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists proceeded as if they were urged onwards by some\r\n'b'irresistible force.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock a vivid flash showed them the palisade, and as they\r\n'b'reached the gate the storm burst forth with tremendous fury.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a minute the corral was crossed, and Harding stood before the hut.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Probably the house was occupied by the stranger, since it was from\r\n'b'thence that the telegram had been sent. However, no light shone through\r\n'b'the window.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer knocked at the door.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No answer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding opened the door, and the settlers entered the room, which\r\n'b'was perfectly dark. A light was struck by Neb, and in a few moments the\r\n'b'lantern was lighted and the light thrown into every corner of the room.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no one there. Everything was in the state in which it had been\r\n'b'left.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHave we been deceived by an illusion?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No! that was not possible! The telegram had clearly said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome to the corral immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They approached the table specially devoted to the use of the wire.\r\n'b'Everything was in order--the pile on the box containing it, as well as\r\n'b'all the apparatus.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho came here the last time?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI did, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that was--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFour days ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh! a note!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Herbert, pointing to a paper lying on the table.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this paper were written these words in English:--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFollow the new wire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Harding, who understood that the despatch had not been\r\n'b'sent from the corral, but from the mysterious retreat, communicating\r\n'b'directly with Granite House by means of a supplementary wire joined to\r\n'b'the old one.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neb took the lighted lantern, and all left the corral. The storm\r\n'b'then burst forth with tremendous violence. The interval between each\r\n'b'lightning-flash and each thunder-clap diminished rapidly. The summit\r\n'b'of the volcano, with its plume of vapor, could be seen by occasional\r\n'b'flashes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was no telegraphic communication in any part of the corral between\r\n'b'the house and the palisade; but the engineer, running straight to the\r\n'b'first post, saw by the light of a flash a new wire hanging from the\r\n'b'isolator to the ground.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere it is!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This wire lay along the ground, and was surrounded with an isolating\r\n'b'substance like a submarine cable, so as to assure the free transmission\r\n'b'of the current. It appeared to pass through the wood and the southern\r\n'b'spurs of the mountain, and consequently it ran towards the west.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFollow it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the settlers immediately pressed forward, guided by the wire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The thunder continued to roar with such violence that not a word could\r\n'b'be heard. However, there was no occasion for speaking, but to get\r\n'b'forward as fast as possible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions then climbed the spur rising between\r\n'b'the corral valley and that of Falls River, which they crossed at its\r\n'b'narrowest part. The wire, sometimes stretched over the lower branches\r\n'b'of the trees, sometimes lying on the ground, guided them surely. The\r\n'b'engineer had supposed that the wire would perhaps stop at the bottom of\r\n'b'the valley, and that the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s retreat would be there.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nothing of the sort. They were obliged to ascend the south-western spur,\r\n'b'and re-descend on that arid plateau terminated by the strangely-wild\r\n'b'basalt cliff. From time to time one of the colonists stooped down and\r\n'b'felt for the wire with his hands; but there was now no doubt that the\r\n'b'wire was running directly towards the sea. There, to a certainty, in the\r\n'b'depths of those rocks, was the dwelling so long sought for in vain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sky was literally on fire. Flash succeeded flash. Several struck the\r\n'b'summit of the volcano in the midst of the thick smoke. It appeared there\r\n'b'as if the mountain was vomiting flame. At a few minutes to eleven the\r\n'b'colonists arrived on the high cliff overlooking the ocean to the west.\r\n'b'The wind had risen. The surf roared 500 feet below.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding calculated that they had gone a mile and a half from the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this point the wire entered among the rocks, following the steep side\r\n'b'of a narrow ravine. The settlers followed it at the risk of occasioning\r\n'b'a fall of the slightly-balanced rocks, and being dashed into the sea.\r\n'b'The descent was extremely perilous, but they did not think of the\r\n'b'danger; they were no longer masters of themselves, and an irresistible\r\n'b'attraction drew them towards this mysterious place as the magnet draws\r\n'b'iron.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus they almost unconsciously descended this ravine, which even in\r\n'b'broad daylight would have been considered impracticable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stones rolled and sparkled like fiery balls when they crossed\r\n'b'through the gleams of light. Harding was first--Ayrton last. On they\r\n'b'went, step by step. Now they slid over the slippery rock; then they\r\n'b'struggled to their feet and scrambled on.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At last the wire touched the rocks on the beach. The colonists had\r\n'b'reached the bottom of the basalt cliff.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There appeared a narrow ridge, running horizontally and parallel with\r\n'b'the sea. The settlers followed the wire along it. They had not gone a\r\n'b'hundred paces when the ridge by a moderate incline sloped down to the\r\n'b'level of the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer seized the wire and found that it disappeared beneath the\r\n'b'waves.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His companions were stupefied.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A cry of disappointment, almost a cry of despair, escaped them! Must\r\n'b'they then plunge beneath the water and seek there for some submarine\r\n'b'cavern? In their excited state they would not have hesitated to do it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer stopped them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He led his companions to a hollow in the rocks, and there--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe must wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cThe tide is high. At low water the way will be\r\n'b'open.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what can make you think-\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe would not have called us if the means had been wanting to enable us\r\n'b'to reach him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding spoke in a tone of such thorough conviction that no\r\n'b'objection was raised. His remark, besides, was logical. It was quite\r\n'b'possible that an opening, practicable at low water, though hidden now by\r\n'b'the high tide, opened at the foot of the cliff.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There was some time to wait. The colonists remained silently crouching\r\n'b'in a deep hollow. Rain now began to fall in torrents. The thunder was\r\n'b're-echoed among the rocks with a grand sonorousness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists\xe2\x80\x99 emotion was great. A thousand strange and extraordinary\r\n'b'ideas crossed their brains, and they expected some grand and superhuman\r\n'b'apparition, which alone could come up to the notion they had formed of\r\n'b'the mysterious genius of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At midnight, Harding carrying the lantern, descended to the beach to\r\n'b'reconnoiter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer was not mistaken. The beginning of an immense excavation\r\n'b'could be seen under the water. There the wire, bending at a right angle,\r\n'b'entered the yawning gulf.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding returned to his companions, and said simply,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn an hour the opening will be practicable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is there, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDid you doubt it?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut this cavern must be filled with water to a certain height,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' observed Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEither the cavern will be completely dry,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand in\r\n'b'that case we can traverse it on foot, or it will not be dry, and some\r\n'b'means of transport will be put at our disposal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An hour passed. All climbed down through the rain to the level of the\r\n'b'sea. There was now eight feet of the opening above the water. It was\r\n'b'like the arch of a bridge, under which rushed the foaming water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Leaning forward, the engineer saw a black object floating on the\r\n'b'water. He drew it towards him. It was a boat, moored to some interior\r\n'b'projection of the cave. This boat was iron-plated. Two oars lay at the\r\n'b'bottom.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJump in!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In a moment the settlers were in the boat. Neb and Ayrton took the\r\n'b'oars, Pencroft the rudder. Cyrus Harding in the bows, with the lantern,\r\n'b'lighted the way.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The elliptical roof, under which the boat at first passed, suddenly\r\n'b'rose; but the darkness was too deep, and the light of the lantern too\r\n'b'slight, for either the extent, length, height, or depth of the cave to\r\n'b'be ascertained. Solemn silence reigned in this basaltic cavern. Not a\r\n'b'sound could penetrate into it, even the thunder peals could not pierce\r\n'b'its thick sides.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Such immense caves exist in various parts of the world, natural crypts\r\n'b'dating from the geological epoch of the globe. Some are filled by the\r\n'b'sea; others contain entire lakes in their sides. Such is Fingal\xe2\x80\x99s Cave,\r\n'b'in the island of Staffa, one of the Hebrides; such are the caves of\r\n'b'Morgat, in the bay of Douarnenez, in Brittany, the caves of Bonifacio,\r\n'b'in Corsica, those of Lyse-Fjord, in Norway; such are the immense Mammoth\r\n'b'caverns in Kentucky, 500 feet in height, and more than twenty miles in\r\n'b'length! In many parts of the globe, nature has excavated these caverns,\r\n'b'and preserved them for the admiration of man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Did the cavern which the settlers were now exploring extend to the\r\n'b'center of the island? For a quarter of an hour the boat had been\r\n'b'advancing, making detours, indicated to Pencroft by the engineer in\r\n'b'short sentences, when all at once,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMore to the right!\xe2\x80\x9d he commanded.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The boat, altering its course, came up alongside the right wall. The\r\n'b'engineer wished to see if the wire still ran along the side.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The wire was there fastened to the rock.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the two oars, plunging into the dark waters, urged the boat onwards.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On they went for another quarter of an hour, and a distance of\r\n'b'half-a-mile must have been cleared from the mouth of the cave, when\r\n'b'Harding\xe2\x80\x99s voice was again heard.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The boat stopped, and the colonists perceived a bright light\r\n'b'illuminating the vast cavern, so deeply excavated in the bowels of the\r\n'b'island, of which nothing had ever led them to suspect the existence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At a height of a hundred feet rose the vaulted roof, supported on basalt\r\n'b'shafts. Irregular arches, strange moldings, appeared on the columns\r\n'b'erected by nature in thousands from the first epochs of the formation of\r\n'b'the globe. The basalt pillars, fitted one into the other, measured\r\n'b'from forty to fifty feet in height, and the water, calm in spite of the\r\n'b'tumult outside, washed their base. The brilliant focus of light, pointed\r\n'b'out by the engineer, touched every point of rocks, and flooded the walls\r\n'b'with light.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'By reflection the water reproduced the brilliant sparkles, so that the\r\n'b'boat appeared to be floating between two glittering zones. They could\r\n'b'not be mistaken in the nature of the irradiation thrown from the glowing\r\n'b'nucleus, whose clear rays were shattered by all the angles, all the\r\n'b'projections of the cavern. This light proceeded from an electric source,\r\n'b'and its white color betrayed its origin. It was the sun of this cave,\r\n'b'and it filled it entirely.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At a sign from Cyrus Harding the oars again plunged into the water,\r\n'b'causing a regular shower of gems, and the boat was urged forward towards\r\n'b'the light, which was now not more than half a cable\xe2\x80\x99s length distant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this place the breadth of the sheet of water measured nearly 350\r\n'b'feet, and beyond the dazzling center could be seen an enormous basaltic\r\n'b'wall, blocking up any issue on that side. The cavern widened here\r\n'b'considerably, the sea forming a little lake. But the roof, the side\r\n'b'walls, the end cliff, all the prisms, all the peaks, were flooded with\r\n'b'the electric fluid, so that the brilliancy belonged to them, and as if\r\n'b'the light issued from them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the center of the lake a long cigar-shaped object floated on the\r\n'b'surface of the water, silent, motionless. The brilliancy which issued\r\n'b'from it escaped from its sides as from two kilns heated to a white heat.\r\n'b'This apparatus, similar in shape to an enormous whale, was about 250\r\n'b'feet long, and rose about ten or twelve above the water.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The boat slowly approached it, Cyrus Harding stood up in the bows. He\r\n'b'gazed, a prey to violent excitement. Then, all at once, seizing the\r\n'b'reporter\xe2\x80\x99s arm,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he! It can only be he!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9che!--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, falling back on the seat, he murmured a name which Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'alone could hear.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The reporter evidently knew this name, for it had a wonderful effect\r\n'b'upon him, and he answered in a hoarse voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe! an outlawed man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe!\xe2\x80\x9d said Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s command the boat approached this singular floating\r\n'b'apparatus. The boat touched the left side, from which escaped a ray of\r\n'b'light through a thick glass.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Harding and his companions mounted on the platform. An open hatchway was\r\n'b'there. All darted down the opening.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the bottom of the ladder was a deck, lighted by electricity. At the\r\n'b'end of this deck was a door, which Harding opened.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A richly-ornamented room, quickly traversed by the colonists, was joined\r\n'b'to a library, over which a luminous ceiling shed a flood of light.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At the end of the library a large door, also shut, was opened by the\r\n'b'engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An immense saloon--a sort of museum, in which were heaped up, with\r\n'b'all the treasures of the mineral world, works of art, marvels of\r\n'b'industry--appeared before the eyes of the colonists, who almost thought\r\n'b'themselves suddenly transported into a land of enchantment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Stretched on a rich sofa they saw a man, who did not appear to notice\r\n'b'their presence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then Harding raised his voice, and to the extreme surprise of his\r\n'b'companions, he uttered these words,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Nemo, you asked for us! We are here.--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 16\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At these words the reclining figure rose, and the electric light fell\r\n'b'upon his countenance; a magnificent head, the forehead high, the glance\r\n'b'commanding, beard white, hair abundant and falling over the shoulders.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His hand rested upon the cushion of the divan from which he had just\r\n'b'risen. He appeared perfectly calm. It was evident that his strength had\r\n'b'been gradually undermined by illness, but his voice seemed yet powerful,\r\n'b'as he said in English, and in a tone which evinced extreme surprise,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSir, I have no name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, I know you!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo fixed his penetrating gaze upon the engineer, as though he\r\n'b'were about to annihilate him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then, falling back amid the pillows of the divan,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAfter all, what matters now?\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured; \xe2\x80\x9cI am dying!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding drew near the captain, and Gideon Spilett took his\r\n'b'hand--it was of a feverish heat. Ayrton, Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb\r\n'b'stood respectfully apart in an angle of the magnificent saloon, whose\r\n'b'atmosphere was saturated with the electric fluid.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile Captain Nemo withdrew his hand, and motioned the engineer and\r\n'b'the reporter to be seated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All regarded him with profound emotion. Before them they beheld that\r\n'b'being whom they had styled the \xe2\x80\x9cgenius of the island,\xe2\x80\x9d the powerful\r\n'b'protector whose intervention, in so many circumstances, had been so\r\n'b'efficacious, the benefactor to whom they owed such a debt of gratitude!\r\n'b'Their eyes beheld a man only, and a man at the point of death, where\r\n'b'Pencroft and Neb had expected to find an almost supernatural being!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But how happened it that Cyrus Harding had recognized Captain Nemo? why\r\n'b'had the latter so suddenly risen on hearing this name uttered, a name\r\n'b'which he had believed known to none?--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The captain had resumed his position on the divan, and leaning on his\r\n'b'arm, he regarded the engineer, seated near him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou know the name I formerly bore, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand also that of this wonderful\r\n'b'submarine vessel--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, with a faint smile.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut do you--do you know who I am?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is nevertheless many years since I have held any communication with\r\n'b'the inhabited world; three long years have I passed in the depth of\r\n'b'the sea, the only place where I have found liberty! Who then can have\r\n'b'betrayed my secret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA man who was bound to you by no tie, Captain Nemo, and who,\r\n'b'consequently, cannot be accused of treachery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Frenchman who was cast on board my vessel by chance sixteen years\r\n'b'since?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe and his two companions did not then perish in the maelstrom, in the\r\n'b'midst of which the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus\xe2\x80\x99 was struggling?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey escaped, and a book has appeared under the title of \xe2\x80\x98Twenty\r\n'b'Thousand Leagues Under the Sea,\xe2\x80\x99 which contains your history.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe history of a few months only of my life!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the captain\r\n'b'impetuously.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cbut a few months of that strange\r\n'b'life have sufficed to make you known.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs a great criminal, doubtless!\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Nemo, a haughty smile\r\n'b'curling his lips. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, a rebel, perhaps an outlaw against humanity!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer was silent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not for me to judge you, Captain Nemo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cat any rate as regards your past life. I am, with the rest of the\r\n'b'world, ignorant of the motives which induced you to adopt this strange\r\n'b'mode of existence, and I cannot judge of effects without knowing their\r\n'b'causes; but what I do know is, that a beneficent hand has constantly\r\n'b'protected us since our arrival on Lincoln Island, that we all owe our\r\n'b'lives to a good, generous, and powerful being, and that this being so\r\n'b'powerful, good and generous, Captain Nemo, is yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is I,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the captain simply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer and the reporter rose. Their companions had drawn near, and\r\n'b'the gratitude with which their hearts were charged was about to express\r\n'b'itself in their gestures and words.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo stopped them by a sign, and in a voice which betrayed more\r\n'b'emotion than he doubtless intended to show.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWait till you have heard all,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And the captain, in a few concise sentences, ran over the events of his\r\n'b'life.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His narrative was short, yet he was obliged to summon up his whole\r\n'b'remaining energy to arrive at the end. He was evidently contending\r\n'b'against extreme weakness. Several times Cyrus Harding entreated him to\r\n'b'repose for a while, but he shook his head as a man to whom the morrow\r\n'b'may never come, and when the reporter offered his assistance,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is useless,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cmy hours are numbered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo was an Indian, the Prince Dakkar, son of a rajah of the\r\n'b'then independent territory of Bundelkund. His father sent him, when ten\r\n'b'years of age, to Europe, in order that he might receive an education\r\n'b'in all respects complete, and in the hopes that by his talents and\r\n'b'knowledge he might one day take a leading part in raising his long\r\n'b'degraded and heathen country to a level with the nations of Europe.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'From the age of ten years to that of thirty Prince Dakkar, endowed by\r\n'b'Nature with her richest gifts of intellect, accumulated knowledge of\r\n'b'every kind, and in science, literature, and art his researches were\r\n'b'extensive and profound.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He traveled over the whole of Europe. His rank and fortune caused him to\r\n'b'be everywhere sought after; but the pleasures of the world had for him\r\n'b'no attractions. Though young and possessed of every personal advantage,\r\n'b'he was ever grave--somber even--devoured by an unquenchable thirst for\r\n'b'knowledge, and cherishing in the recesses of his heart the hope that\r\n'b'he might become a great and powerful ruler of a free and enlightened\r\n'b'people.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Still, for long the love of science triumphed over all other feelings.\r\n'b'He became an artist deeply impressed by the marvels of art, a\r\n'b'philosopher to whom no one of the higher sciences was unknown, a\r\n'b'statesman versed in the policy of European courts. To the eyes of those\r\n'b'who observed him superficially he might have passed for one of those\r\n'b'cosmopolitans, curious of knowledge, but disdaining action; one of those\r\n'b'opulent travelers, haughty and cynical, who move incessantly from place\r\n'b'to place, and are of no country.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The history of Captain Nemo has, in fact, been published under the title\r\n'b'of \xe2\x80\x9cTwenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.\xe2\x80\x9d Here, therefore, will apply\r\n'b'the observation already made as to the adventures of Ayrton with regard\r\n'b'to the discrepancy of dates. Readers should therefore refer to the note\r\n'b'already published on this point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This artist, this philosopher, this man was, however, still cherishing\r\n'b'the hope instilled into him from his earliest days.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Prince Dakkar returned to Bundelkund in the year 1849. He married a\r\n'b'noble Indian lady, who was imbued with an ambition not less ardent than\r\n'b'that by which he was inspired. Two children were born to them, whom they\r\n'b'tenderly loved. But domestic happiness did not prevent him from seeking\r\n'b'to carry out the object at which he aimed. He waited an opportunity. At\r\n'b'length, as he vainly fancied, it presented itself.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Instigated by princes equally ambitious and less sagacious and more\r\n'b'unscrupulous than he was, the people of India were persuaded that they\r\n'b'might successfully rise against their English rulers, who had brought\r\n'b'them out of a state of anarchy and constant warfare and misery, and had\r\n'b'established peace and prosperity in their country. Their ignorance and\r\n'b'gross superstition made them the facile tools of their designing chiefs.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In 1857 the great sepoy revolt broke out. Prince Dakkar, under the\r\n'b'belief that he should thereby have the opportunity of attaining the\r\n'b'object of his long-cherished ambition, was easily drawn into it. He\r\n'b'forthwith devoted his talents and wealth to the service of this cause.\r\n'b'He aided it in person; he fought in the front ranks; he risked his life\r\n'b'equally with the humblest of the wretched and misguided fanatics; he was\r\n'b'ten times wounded in twenty engagements, seeking death but finding it\r\n'b'not, but at length the sanguinary rebels were utterly defeated, and the\r\n'b'atrocious mutiny was brought to an end.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Never before had the British power in India been exposed to such danger,\r\n'b'and if, as they had hoped, the sepoys had received assistance from\r\n'b'without, the influence and supremacy in Asia of the United Kingdom would\r\n'b'have been a thing of the past.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The name of Prince Dakkar was at that time well known. He had fought\r\n'b'openly and without concealment. A price was set upon his head, but he\r\n'b'managed to escape from his pursuers.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Civilization never recedes; the law of necessity ever forces it onwards.\r\n'b'The sepoys were vanquished, and the land of the rajahs of old fell again\r\n'b'under the rule of England.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Prince Dakkar, unable to find that death he courted, returned to the\r\n'b'mountain fastnesses of Bundelkund. There, alone in the world, overcome\r\n'b'by disappointment at the destruction of all his vain hopes, a prey\r\n'b'to profound disgust for all human beings, filled with hatred of the\r\n'b'civilized world, he realized the wreck of his fortune, assembled some\r\n'b'score of his most faithful companions, and one day disappeared, leaving\r\n'b'no trace behind.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Where, then, did he seek that liberty denied him upon the inhabited\r\n'b'earth? Under the waves, in the depths of the ocean, where none could\r\n'b'follow.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The warrior became the man of science. Upon a deserted island of the\r\n'b'Pacific he established his dockyard, and there a submarine vessel was\r\n'b'constructed from his designs. By methods which will at some future\r\n'b'day be revealed he had rendered subservient the illimitable forces of\r\n'b'electricity, which, extracted from inexhaustible sources, was employed\r\n'b'for all the requirements of his floating equipage, as a moving,\r\n'b'lighting, and heating agent. The sea, with its countless treasures, its\r\n'b'myriads of fish, its numberless wrecks, its enormous mammalia, and not\r\n'b'only all that nature supplied, but also all that man had lost in its\r\n'b'depths, sufficed for every want of the prince and his crew--and thus was\r\n'b'his most ardent desire accomplished, never again to hold communication\r\n'b'with the earth. He named his submarine vessel the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d called\r\n'b'himself simply Captain Nemo, and disappeared beneath the seas.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During many years this strange being visited every ocean, from pole to\r\n'b'pole. Outcast of the inhabited earth in these unknown worlds he gathered\r\n'b'incalculable treasures. The millions lost in the Bay of Vigo, in 1702,\r\n'b'by the galleons of Spain, furnished him with a mine of inexhaustible\r\n'b'riches which he devoted always, anonymously, in favor of those nations\r\n'b'who fought for the independence of their country.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'  (This refers to the resurrection of the Candiotes, who were, in\r\n'b'   fact, largely assisted by Captain Nemo.)\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For long, however, he had held no communication with his\r\n'b'fellow-creatures, when, during the night of the 6th of November, 1866,\r\n'b'three men were cast on board his vessel. They were a French professor,\r\n'b'his servant, and a Canadian fisherman. These three men had been hurled\r\n'b'overboard by a collision which had taken place between the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' and the United States frigate \xe2\x80\x9cAbraham Lincoln,\xe2\x80\x9d which had chased her.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo learned from this professor that the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d taken now\r\n'b'for a gigantic mammal of the whale species, now for a submarine vessel\r\n'b'carrying a crew of pirates, was sought for in every sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He might have returned these three men to the ocean, from whence chance\r\n'b'had brought them in contact with his mysterious existence. Instead of\r\n'b'doing this he kept them prisoners, and during seven months they were\r\n'b'enabled to behold all the wonders of a voyage of twenty thousand leagues\r\n'b'under the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'One day, the 22nd of June, 1867, these three men, who knew nothing of\r\n'b'the past history of Captain Nemo, succeeded in escaping in one of the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d boats. But as at this time the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d was drawn into\r\n'b'the vortex of the maelstrom, off the coast of Norway, the captain\r\n'b'naturally believed that the fugitives, engulfed in that frightful\r\n'b'whirlpool, found their death at the bottom of the abyss. He was unaware\r\n'b'that the Frenchman and his two companions had been miraculously cast\r\n'b'on shore, that the fishermen of the Lofoten Islands had rendered\r\n'b'them assistance, and that the professor, on his return to France, had\r\n'b'published that work in which seven months of the strange and eventful\r\n'b'navigation of the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d were narrated and exposed to the curiosity\r\n'b'of the public.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'For a long time after this, Captain Nemo continued to live thus,\r\n'b'traversing every sea. But one by one his companions died, and found\r\n'b'their last resting-place in their cemetery of coral, in the bed of the\r\n'b'Pacific. At last Captain Nemo remained the solitary survivor of all\r\n'b'those who had taken refuge with him in the depths of the ocean.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He was now sixty years of age. Although alone, he succeeded in\r\n'b'navigating the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d towards one of those submarine caverns which\r\n'b'had sometimes served him as a harbor.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'One of these ports was hollowed beneath Lincoln Island, and at this\r\n'b'moment furnished an asylum to the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The captain had now remained there six years, navigating the ocean no\r\n'b'longer, but awaiting death, and that moment when he should rejoin his\r\n'b'former companions, when by chance he observed the descent of the balloon\r\n'b'which carried the prisoners of the Confederates. Clad in his diving\r\n'b'dress he was walking beneath the water at a few cables\xe2\x80\x99 length from the\r\n'b'shore of the island, when the engineer had been thrown into the sea.\r\n'b'Moved by a feeling of compassion the captain saved Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His first impulse was to fly from the vicinity of the five castaways;\r\n'b'but his harbor refuge was closed, for in consequence of an elevation of\r\n'b'the basalt, produced by the influence of volcanic action, he could\r\n'b'no longer pass through the entrance of the vault. Though there was\r\n'b'sufficient depth of water to allow a light craft to pass the bar,\r\n'b'there was not enough for the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d whose draught of water was\r\n'b'considerable.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo was compelled, therefore, to remain. He observed these men\r\n'b'thrown without resources upon a desert island, but had no wish to be\r\n'b'himself discovered by them. By degrees he became interested in their\r\n'b'efforts when he saw them honest, energetic, and bound to each other by\r\n'b'the ties of friendship. As if despite his wishes, he penetrated all the\r\n'b'secrets of their existence. By means of the diving dress he could easily\r\n'b'reach the well in the interior of Granite House, and climbing by the\r\n'b'projections of rock to its upper orifice he heard the colonists as they\r\n'b'recounted the past, and studied the present and future. He learned from\r\n'b'them the tremendous conflict of America with America itself, for the\r\n'b'abolition of slavery. Yes, these men were worthy to reconcile Captain\r\n'b'Nemo with that humanity which they represented so nobly in the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo had saved Cyrus Harding. It was he also who had brought\r\n'b'back the dog to the Chimneys, who rescued Top from the waters of the\r\n'b'lake, who caused to fall at Flotsam Point the case containing so many\r\n'b'things useful to the colonists, who conveyed the canoe back into the\r\n'b'stream of the Mercy, who cast the cord from the top of Granite House at\r\n'b'the time of the attack by the baboons, who made known the presence\r\n'b'of Ayrton upon Tabor Island, by means of the document enclosed in the\r\n'b'bottle, who caused the explosion of the brig by the shock of a torpedo\r\n'b'placed at the bottom of the canal, who saved Herbert from certain death\r\n'b'by bringing the sulphate of quinine; and finally, it was he who had\r\n'b'killed the convicts with the electric balls, of which he possessed the\r\n'b'secret, and which he employed in the chase of submarine creatures. Thus\r\n'b'were explained so many apparently supernatural occurrences, and which\r\n'b'all proved the generosity and power of the captain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nevertheless, this noble misanthrope longed to benefit his proteges\r\n'b'still further. There yet remained much useful advice to give them, and,\r\n'b'his heart being softened by the approach of death, he invited, as we are\r\n'b'aware, the colonists of Granite House to visit the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d by means\r\n'b'of a wire which connected it with the corral. Possibly he would not\r\n'b'have done this had he been aware that Cyrus Harding was sufficiently\r\n'b'acquainted with his history to address him by the name of Nemo.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The captain concluded the narrative of his life. Cyrus Harding then\r\n'b'spoke; he recalled all the incidents which had exercised so beneficent\r\n'b'an influence upon the colony, and in the names of his companions and\r\n'b'himself thanked the generous being to whom they owed so much.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But Captain Nemo paid little attention; his mind appeared to be absorbed\r\n'b'by one idea, and without taking the proffered hand of the engineer,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cnow that you know my history, your judgment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In saying this, the captain evidently alluded to an important incident\r\n'b'witnessed by the three strangers thrown on board his vessel, and which\r\n'b'the French professor had related in his work, causing a profound and\r\n'b'terrible sensation. Some days previous to the flight of the professor\r\n'b'and his two companions, the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d being chased by a frigate in the\r\n'b'north of the Atlantic had hurled herself as a ram upon this frigate, and\r\n'b'sunk her without mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding understood the captain\xe2\x80\x99s allusion, and was silent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was an enemy\xe2\x80\x99s frigate,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Captain Nemo, transformed for\r\n'b'an instant into the Prince Dakkar, \xe2\x80\x9can enemy\xe2\x80\x99s frigate! It was she who\r\n'b'attacked me--I was in a narrow and shallow bay--the frigate barred my\r\n'b'way--and I sank her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few moments of silence ensued; then the captain demanded,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat think you of my life, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding extended his hand to the ci-devant prince and replied\r\n'b'gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cSir, your error was in supposing that the past can be\r\n'b'resuscitated, and in contending against inevitable progress. It is one\r\n'b'of those errors which some admire, others blame; which God alone can\r\n'b'judge. He who is mistaken in an action which he sincerely believes to be\r\n'b'right may be an enemy, but retains our esteem. Your error is one that\r\n'b'we may admire, and your name has nothing to fear from the judgment of\r\n'b'history, which does not condemn heroic folly, but its results.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The old man\xe2\x80\x99s breast swelled with emotion, and raising his hand to\r\n'b'heaven,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWas I wrong, or in the right?\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding replied, \xe2\x80\x9cAll great actions return to God, from whom they\r\n'b'are derived. Captain Nemo, we, whom you have succored, shall ever mourn\r\n'b'your loss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert, who had drawn near the captain, fell on his knees and kissed\r\n'b'his hand.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A tear glistened in the eyes of the dying man. \xe2\x80\x9cMy child,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmay\r\n'b'God bless you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 17\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Day had returned. No ray of light penetrated into the profundity of the\r\n'b'cavern. It being high-water, the entrance was closed by the sea. But the\r\n'b'artificial light, which escaped in long streams from the skylights of\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d was as vivid as before, and the sheet of water shone\r\n'b'around the floating vessel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An extreme exhaustion now overcame Captain Nemo, who had fallen back\r\n'b'upon the divan. It was useless to contemplate removing him to Granite\r\n'b'House, for he had expressed his wish to remain in the midst of those\r\n'b'marvels of the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d which millions could not have purchased, and\r\n'b'to wait there for that death which was swiftly approaching.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During a long interval of prostration, which rendered him almost\r\n'b'unconscious, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett attentively observed\r\n'b'the condition of the dying man. It was apparent that his strength was\r\n'b'gradually diminishing. That frame, once so robust, was now but the\r\n'b'fragile tenement of a departing soul. All of life was concentrated in\r\n'b'the heart and head.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer and reporter consulted in whispers. Was it possible to\r\n'b'render any aid to the dying man? Might his life, if not saved, be\r\n'b'prolonged for some days? He himself had said that no remedy could\r\n'b'avail, and he awaited with tranquillity that death which had for him no\r\n'b'terrors.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe can do nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut of what is he dying?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pencroft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLife is simply fading out,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cif we move him into the open air, and\r\n'b'the light of the sun, he might perhaps recover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cit is useless to attempt it.\r\n'b'Besides, Captain Nemo would never consent to leave his vessel. He\r\n'b'has lived for a dozen years on board the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus,\xe2\x80\x99 and on board the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Nautilus\xe2\x80\x99 he desires to die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Without doubt Captain Nemo heard Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s reply, for he raised\r\n'b'himself slightly, and in a voice more feeble, but always intelligible,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall die here--it is my wish; and\r\n'b'therefore I have a request to make of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions had drawn near the divan, and now\r\n'b'arranged the cushions in such a manner as to better support the dying\r\n'b'man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They saw his eyes wander over all the marvels of this saloon, lighted\r\n'b'by the electric rays which fell from the arabesques of the luminous\r\n'b'ceiling. He surveyed, one after the other, the pictures hanging from\r\n'b'the splendid tapestries of the partitions, the chef-d\xe2\x80\x99oeuvres of the\r\n'b'Italian, Flemish, French, and Spanish masters; the statues of marble and\r\n'b'bronze on their pedestals; the magnificent organ, leaning against the\r\n'b'after-partition; the aquarium, in which bloomed the most wonderful\r\n'b'productions of the sea--marine plants, zoophytes, chaplets of pearls\r\n'b'of inestimable value; and, finally, his eyes rested on this device,\r\n'b'inscribed over the pediment of the museum--the motto of the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMobilis in mobile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'His glance seemed to rest fondly for the last time on these masterpieces\r\n'b'of art and of nature, to which he had limited his horizon during a\r\n'b'sojourn of so many years in the abysses of the seas.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding respected the captain\xe2\x80\x99s silence, and waited till he should\r\n'b'speak.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After some minutes, during which, doubtless, he passed in review his\r\n'b'whole life, Captain Nemo turned to the colonists and said,\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou consider yourselves, gentlemen, under some obligations to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain, believe us that we would give our lives to prolong yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPromise, then,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Captain Nemo, \xe2\x80\x9cto carry out my last wishes,\r\n'b'and I shall be repaid for all I have done for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe promise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And by this promise he bound both himself and his companions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cto-morrow I shall be dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert was about to utter an exclamation, but a sign from the captain\r\n'b'arrested him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow I shall die, and I desire no other tomb than the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'It is my grave! All my friends repose in the depths of the ocean; their\r\n'b'resting-place shall be mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'These words were received with profound silence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPay attention to my wishes,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued. \xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus\xe2\x80\x99 is\r\n'b'imprisoned in this grotto, the entrance of which is blocked up; but,\r\n'b'although egress is impossible, the vessel may at least sink in the\r\n'b'abyss, and there bury my remains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists listened reverently to the words of the dying man.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow, after my death, Mr. Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the captain,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cyourself and companions will leave the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus,\xe2\x80\x99 for all the\r\n'b'treasures it contains must perish with me. One token alone will remain\r\n'b'with you of Prince Dakkar, with whose history you are now acquainted.\r\n'b'That coffer yonder contains diamonds of the value of many millions,\r\n'b'most of them mementoes of the time when, husband and father, I thought\r\n'b'happiness possible for me, and a collection of pearls gathered by my\r\n'b'friends and myself in the depths of the ocean. Of this treasure at a\r\n'b'future day, you may make good use. In the hands of such men as yourself\r\n'b'and your comrades, Captain Harding, money will never be a source of\r\n'b'danger. From on high I shall still participate in your enterprises, and\r\n'b'I fear not but that they will prosper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After a few moments\xe2\x80\x99 repose, necessitated by his extreme weakness,\r\n'b'Captain Nemo continued,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow you will take the coffer, you will leave the saloon, of which\r\n'b'you will close the door; then you will ascend on to the deck of the\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Nautilus,\xe2\x80\x99 and you will lower the mainhatch so as entirely to close the\r\n'b'vessel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt shall be done, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood. You will then embark in the canoe which brought you hither; but,\r\n'b'before leaving the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus,\xe2\x80\x99 go to the stern and there open two large\r\n'b'stop-cocks which you will find upon the water-line. The water will\r\n'b'penetrate into the reservoirs, and the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus\xe2\x80\x99 will gradually sink\r\n'b'beneath the water to repose at the bottom of the abyss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And comprehending a gesture of Cyrus Harding, the captain added,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFear nothing! You will but bury a corpse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions ventured to offer any\r\n'b'observation to Captain Nemo. He had expressed his last wishes, and they\r\n'b'had nothing to do but to conform to them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have your promise, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d added Captain Nemo.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The captain thanked the colonists by a sign, and requested them to leave\r\n'b'him for some hours. Gideon Spilett wished to remain near him, in the\r\n'b'event of a crisis coming on, but the dying man refused, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall\r\n'b'live until to-morrow, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All left the saloon, passed through the library and the dining-room, and\r\n'b'arrived forward, in the machine-room where the electrical apparatus was\r\n'b'established, which supplied not only heat and light, but the mechanical\r\n'b'power of the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d was a masterpiece containing masterpieces within itself,\r\n'b'and the engineer was struck with astonishment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists mounted the platform, which rose seven or eight feet above\r\n'b'the water. There they beheld a thick glass lenticular covering, which\r\n'b'protected a kind of large eye, from which flashed forth light. Behind\r\n'b'this eye was apparently a cabin containing the wheels of the rudder, and\r\n'b'in which was stationed the helmsman, when he navigated the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' over the bed of the ocean, which the electric rays would evidently light\r\n'b'up to a considerable distance.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions remained for a time silent, for they\r\n'b'were vividly impressed by what they had just seen and heard, and their\r\n'b'hearts were deeply touched by the thought that he whose arm had so often\r\n'b'aided them, the protector whom they had known but a few hours, was at\r\n'b'the point of death.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Whatever might be the judgment pronounced by posterity upon the events\r\n'b'of this, so to speak, extra-human existence, the character of Prince\r\n'b'Dakkar would ever remain as one of those whose memory time can never\r\n'b'efface.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a man!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible that he can have lived at\r\n'b'the bottom of the sea? And it seems to me that perhaps he has not found\r\n'b'peace there any more than elsewhere!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d observed Ayrton, \xe2\x80\x9cmight have enabled us to leave\r\n'b'Lincoln Island and reach some inhabited country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood Heavens!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cI for one would never risk myself\r\n'b'in such a craft. To sail on the seas, good, but under the seas, never!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI believe, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the navigation of a\r\n'b'submarine vessel such as the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus\xe2\x80\x99 ought to be very easy, and that\r\n'b'we should soon become accustomed to it. There would be no storms, no\r\n'b'lee-shore to fear. At some feet beneath the surface the waters of the\r\n'b'ocean are as calm as those of a lake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat may be,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I prefer a gale of wind on\r\n'b'board a well-found craft. A vessel is built to sail on the sea, and not\r\n'b'beneath it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cit is useless, at any rate as regards\r\n'b'the \xe2\x80\x98Nautilus,\xe2\x80\x99 to discuss the question of submarine vessels. The\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Nautilus\xe2\x80\x99 is not ours, and we have not the right to dispose of it.\r\n'b'Moreover, we could in no case avail ourselves of it. Independently of\r\n'b'the fact that it would be impossible to get it out of this cavern, whose\r\n'b'entrance is now closed by the uprising of the basaltic rocks, Captain\r\n'b'Nemo\xe2\x80\x99s wish is that it shall be buried with him. His wish is our law,\r\n'b'and we will fulfil it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'After a somewhat prolonged conversation, Cyrus Harding and his\r\n'b'companions again descended to the interior of the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus.\xe2\x80\x9d There they\r\n'b'took some refreshment and returned to the saloon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo had somewhat rallied from the prostration which had\r\n'b'overcome him, and his eyes shone with their wonted fire. A faint smile\r\n'b'even curled his lips.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists drew around him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are brave and honest men. You\r\n'b'have devoted yourselves to the common weal. Often have I observed\r\n'b'your conduct. I have esteemed you--I esteem you still! Your hand, Mr.\r\n'b'Harding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding gave his hand to the captain, who clasped it\r\n'b'affectionately.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He resumed,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut enough of myself. I have to speak concerning yourselves, and this\r\n'b'Lincoln Island, upon which you have taken refuge. You now desire to\r\n'b'leave it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo return, captain!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft quickly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo return, Pencroft?\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, with a smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI know, it is\r\n'b'true, your love for this island. You have helped to make it what it now\r\n'b'is, and it seems to you a paradise!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur project, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cis to annex it to the\r\n'b'United States, and to establish for our shipping a port so fortunately\r\n'b'situated in this part of the Pacific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYour thoughts are with your country, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the captain;\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cyour toils are for her prosperity and glory. You are right. One\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'native land!--there should one live! there die! And I die far from all I\r\n'b'loved!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou have some last wish to transmit,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer with emotion,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9csome souvenir to send to those friends you have left in the mountains\r\n'b'of India?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Captain Harding; no friends remain to me! I am the last of my race,\r\n'b'and to all whom I have known I have long been as are the dead.--But\r\n'b'to return to yourselves. Solitude, isolation, are painful things, and\r\n'b'beyond human endurance. I die of having thought it possible to live\r\n'b'alone! You should, therefore, dare all in the attempt to leave Lincoln\r\n'b'Island, and see once more the land of your birth. I am aware that those\r\n'b'wretches have destroyed the vessel you have built.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe propose to construct a vessel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9csufficiently\r\n'b'large to convey us to the nearest land; but if we should succeed, sooner\r\n'b'or later we shall return to Lincoln Island. We are attached to it by too\r\n'b'many recollections ever to forget it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is here that we have known Captain Nemo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is here only that we can make our home!\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here shall I sleep the sleep of eternity, if--\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\n'b'captain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He paused for a moment, and, instead of completing the sentence, said\r\n'b'simply,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Harding, I wish to speak with you--alone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s companions, respecting the wish, retired.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding remained but a few minutes alone with Captain Nemo, and\r\n'b'soon recalled his companions; but he said nothing to them of the private\r\n'b'matters which the dying man had confided to him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett now watched the captain with extreme care. It was evident\r\n'b'that he was no longer sustained by his moral energy, which had lost the\r\n'b'power of reaction against his physical weakness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The day closed without change. The colonists did not quit the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' for a moment. Night arrived, although it was impossible to distinguish\r\n'b'it from day in the cavern.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Captain Nemo suffered no pain, but he was visibly sinking. His noble\r\n'b'features, paled by the approach of death, were perfectly calm. Inaudible\r\n'b'words escaped at intervals from his lips, bearing upon various incidents\r\n'b'of his checkered career. Life was evidently ebbing slowly and his\r\n'b'extremities were already cold.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Once or twice more he spoke to the colonists who stood around him, and\r\n'b'smiled on them with that last smile which continues after death.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At length, shortly after midnight, Captain Nemo by a supreme effort\r\n'b'succeeded in folding his arms across his breast, as if wishing in that\r\n'b'attitude to compose himself for death.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'By one o\xe2\x80\x99clock his glance alone showed signs of life. A dying light\r\n'b'gleamed in those eyes once so brilliant. Then, murmuring the words, \xe2\x80\x9cGod\r\n'b'and my country!\xe2\x80\x9d he quietly expired.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, bending low closed the eyes of him who had once been the\r\n'b'Prince Dakkar, and was now not even Captain Nemo.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert and Pencroft sobbed aloud. Tears fell from Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. Neb\r\n'b'was on his knees by the reporter\xe2\x80\x99s side, motionless as a statue.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then Cyrus Harding, extending his hand over the forehead of the dead,\r\n'b'said solemnly, \xe2\x80\x9cMay his soul be with God!\xe2\x80\x9d Turning to his friends, he\r\n'b'added, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us pray for him whom we have lost!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Some hours later the colonists fulfilled the promise made to the captain\r\n'b'by carrying out his dying wishes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions quitted the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d taking with\r\n'b'them the only memento left them by their benefactor, the coffer which\r\n'b'contained wealth amounting to millions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The marvelous saloon, still flooded with light, had been carefully\r\n'b'closed. The iron door leading on deck was then securely fastened in\r\n'b'such a manner as to prevent even a drop of water from penetrating to the\r\n'b'interior of the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists then descended into the canoe, which was moored to the\r\n'b'side of the submarine vessel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The canoe was now brought around to the stern. There, at the water-line,\r\n'b'were two large stop-cocks communicating with the reservoirs employed in\r\n'b'the submersion of the vessel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The stop-cocks were opened, the reservoirs filled, and the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' slowly sinking, disappeared beneath the surface of the lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But the colonists were yet able to follow its descent through the waves.\r\n'b'The powerful light it gave forth lighted up the translucent water, while\r\n'b'the cavern became gradually obscure. At length this vast effusion of\r\n'b'electric light faded away, and soon after the \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus,\xe2\x80\x9d now the tomb\r\n'b'of Captain Nemo, reposed in its ocean bed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 18\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At break of day the colonists regained in silence the entrance of the\r\n'b'cavern, to which they gave the name of \xe2\x80\x9cDakkar Grotto,\xe2\x80\x9d in memory of\r\n'b'Captain Nemo. It was now low-water, and they passed without difficulty\r\n'b'under the arcade, washed on the right by the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The canoe was left here, carefully protected from the waves. As\r\n'b'additional precaution, Pencroft, Neb, and Ayrton drew it up on a little\r\n'b'beach which bordered one of the sides of the grotto, in a spot where it\r\n'b'could run no risk of harm.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The storm had ceased during the night. The last low mutterings of the\r\n'b'thunder died away in the west. Rain fell no longer, but the sky was yet\r\n'b'obscured by clouds. On the whole, this month of October, the first of\r\n'b'the southern spring, was not ushered in by satisfactory tokens, and the\r\n'b'wind had a tendency to shift from one point of the compass to another,\r\n'b'which rendered it impossible to count upon settled weather.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and his companions, on leaving Dakkar Grotto, had taken\r\n'b'the road to the corral. On their way Neb and Herbert were careful to\r\n'b'preserve the wire which had been laid down by the captain between the\r\n'b'corral and the grotto, and which might at a future time be of service.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists spoke but little on the road. The various incidents of the\r\n'b'night of October 15th had left a profound impression on their minds. The\r\n'b'unknown being whose influence had so effectually protected them, the\r\n'b'man whom their imagination had endowed with supernatural powers, Captain\r\n'b'Nemo, was no more. His \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d and he were buried in the depths of\r\n'b'the abyss. To each one of them their existence seemed even more isolated\r\n'b'than before. They had been accustomed to count upon the intervention of\r\n'b'that power which existed no longer, and Gideon Spilett, and even Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding, could not escape this impression. Thus they maintained a\r\n'b'profound silence during their journey to the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards nine in the morning the colonists arrived at Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It had been agreed that the construction of the vessel should be\r\n'b'actively pushed forward, and Cyrus Harding more than ever devoted his\r\n'b'time and labor to this object. It was impossible to divine what future\r\n'b'lay before them. Evidently the advantage to the colonists would be great\r\n'b'of having at their disposal a substantial vessel, capable of keeping the\r\n'b'sea even in heavy weather, and large enough to attempt, in case of\r\n'b'need, a voyage of some duration. Even if, when their vessel should be\r\n'b'completed, the colonists should not resolve to leave Lincoln Island as\r\n'b'yet, in order to gain either one of the Polynesian Archipelagoes of the\r\n'b'Pacific or the shores of New Zealand, they might at least, sooner or\r\n'b'later, proceed to Tabor Island, to leave there the notice relating to\r\n'b'Ayrton. This was a precaution rendered indispensable by the possibility\r\n'b'of the Scotch yacht reappearing in those seas, and it was of the highest\r\n'b'importance that nothing should be neglected on this point.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The works were then resumed. Cyrus Harding, Pencroft, and Ayrton,\r\n'b'assisted by Neb, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert, except when unavoidably\r\n'b'called off by other necessary occupations, worked without cessation. It\r\n'b'was important that the new vessel should be ready in five months--that\r\n'b'is to say, by the beginning of March--if they wished to visit Tabor\r\n'b'Island before the equinoctial gales rendered the voyage impracticable.\r\n'b'Therefore the carpenters lost not a moment.
