Moreover, it was unnecessary\r\n'b'to manufacture rigging, that of the \xe2\x80\x9cSpeedy\xe2\x80\x9d having been saved entire,\r\n'b'so that the hull only of the vessel needed to be constructed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The end of the year 1868 found them occupied by these important labors,\r\n'b'to the exclusion of almost all others. At the expiration of two months\r\n'b'and a half the ribs had been set up and the first planks adjusted. It\r\n'b'was already evident that the plans made by Cyrus Harding were admirable,\r\n'b'and that the vessel would behave well at sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft brought to the task a devouring energy, and would even grumble\r\n'b'when one or the other abandoned the carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s axe for the gun of the\r\n'b'hunter. It was nevertheless necessary to keep up the stores of Granite\r\n'b'House, in view of the approaching winter. But this did not satisfy\r\n'b'Pencroft. The brave, honest sailor was not content when the workmen were\r\n'b'not at the dockyard. When this happened he grumbled vigorously, and, by\r\n'b'way of venting his feelings, did the work of six men.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The weather was very unfavorable during the whole of the summer season.\r\n'b'For some days the heat was overpowering, and the atmosphere, saturated\r\n'b'with electricity, was only cleared by violent storms. It was rarely that\r\n'b'the distant growling of the thunder could not be heard, like a low but\r\n'b'incessant murmur, such as is produced in the equatorial regions of the\r\n'b'globe.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The 1st of January, 1869, was signalized by a storm of extreme violence,\r\n'b'and the thunder burst several times over the island. Large trees were\r\n'b'struck by the electric fluid and shattered, and among others one of\r\n'b'those gigantic nettle-trees which had shaded the poultry-yard at the\r\n'b'southern extremity of the lake. Had this meteor any relation to the\r\n'b'phenomena going on in the bowels of the earth? Was there any connection\r\n'b'between the commotion of the atmosphere and that of the interior of the\r\n'b'earth? Cyrus Harding was inclined to think that such was the case, for\r\n'b'the development of these storms was attended by the renewal of volcanic\r\n'b'symptoms.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was on the 3rd of January that Herbert, having ascended at daybreak\r\n'b'to the plateau of Prospect Heights to harness one of the onagers,\r\n'b'perceived an enormous hat-shaped cloud rolling from the summit of the\r\n'b'volcano.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Herbert immediately apprised the colonists, who at once joined him in\r\n'b'watching the summit of Mount Franklin.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthose are not vapors this time! It seems to\r\n'b'me that the giant is not content with breathing; he must smoke!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This figure of speech employed by the sailor exactly expressed the\r\n'b'changes going on at the mouth of the volcano. Already for three months\r\n'b'had the crater emitted vapors more or less dense, but which were as yet\r\n'b'produced only by an internal ebullition of mineral substances. But\r\n'b'now the vapors were replaced by a thick smoke, rising in the form of a\r\n'b'grayish column, more than three hundred feet in width at its base, and\r\n'b'which spread like an immense mushroom to a height of from seven to eight\r\n'b'hundred feet above the summit of the mountain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe fire is in the chimney,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we can\xe2\x80\x99t put it out!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe volcano ought to be swept,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Neb, who spoke as if perfectly\r\n'b'serious.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell said, Neb!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, with a shout of laughter; \xe2\x80\x9cand you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\n'b'undertake the job, no doubt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding attentively observed the dense smoke emitted by Mount\r\n'b'Franklin, and even listened, as if expecting to hear some distant\r\n'b'muttering. Then, turning towards his companions, from whom he had gone\r\n'b'somewhat apart, he said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe truth is, my friends, we must not conceal from ourselves that an\r\n'b'important change is going forward. The volcanic substances are no longer\r\n'b'in a state of ebullition, they have caught fire, and we are undoubtedly\r\n'b'menaced by an approaching eruption.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall witness the eruption; and if\r\n'b'it is a good one, we\xe2\x80\x99ll applaud it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t see that we need concern\r\n'b'ourselves further about the matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the ancient track of\r\n'b'the lava is still open; and thanks to this, the crater has hitherto\r\n'b'overflowed towards the north. And yet--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet, as we can derive no advantage from an eruption, it might be\r\n'b'better it should not take place,\xe2\x80\x9d said the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWho knows?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps there may be some valuable\r\n'b'substance in this volcano, which it will spout forth, and which we may\r\n'b'turn to good account!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding shook his head with the air of a man who augured no good\r\n'b'from the phenomenon whose development had been so sudden. He did not\r\n'b'regard so lightly as Pencroft the results of an eruption. If the lava,\r\n'b'in consequence of the position of the crater, did not directly menace\r\n'b'the wooded and cultivated parts of the island, other complications might\r\n'b'present themselves. In fact, eruptions are not unfrequently accompanied\r\n'b'by earthquakes; and an island of the nature of Lincoln Island, formed of\r\n'b'substances so varied, basalt on one side, granite on the other, lava on\r\n'b'the north, rich soil on the south, substances which consequently could\r\n'b'not be firmly attached to each other, would be exposed to the risk\r\n'b'of disintegration. Although, therefore, the spreading of the volcanic\r\n'b'matter might not constitute a serious danger, any movement of the\r\n'b'terrestrial structure which should shake the island might entail the\r\n'b'gravest consequences.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ayrton, who had reclined so as to place his ear\r\n'b'to the ground, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems to me that I can hear a dull, rumbling sound,\r\n'b'like that of a wagon loaded with bars of iron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists listened with the greatest attention, and were convinced\r\n'b'that Ayrton was not mistaken. The rumbling was mingled with a\r\n'b'subterranean roar, which formed a sort of rinforzando, and died slowly\r\n'b'away, as if some violent storm had passed through the profundities of\r\n'b'the globe. But no explosion properly so termed, could be heard. It might\r\n'b'therefore be concluded that the vapors and smoke found a free passage\r\n'b'through the central shaft; and that the safety-valve being sufficiently\r\n'b'large, no convulsion would be produced, no explosion was to be\r\n'b'apprehended.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9care we not going back to work? Let Mount\r\n'b'Franklin smoke, groan, bellow, or spout forth fire and flame as much as\r\n'b'it pleases, that is no reason why we should be idle! Come, Ayrton, Neb,\r\n'b'Herbert, Captain Harding, Mr. Spilett, every one of us must turn to at\r\n'b'our work to-day! We are going to place the keelson, and a dozen pair\r\n'b'of hands would not be too many. Before two months I want our new\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99--for we shall keep the old name, shall we not?--to float\r\n'b'on the waters of Port Balloon! Therefore there is not an hour to lose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All the colonists, their services thus requisitioned by Pencroft,\r\n'b'descended to the dockyard, and proceeded to place the keelson, a thick\r\n'b'mass of wood which forms the lower portion of a ship and unites firmly\r\n'b'the timbers of the hull. It was an arduous undertaking, in which all\r\n'b'took part.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'They continued their labors during the whole of this day, the 3rd of\r\n'b'January, without thinking further of the volcano, which could not,\r\n'b'besides, be seen from the shore of Granite House. But once or twice,\r\n'b'large shadows, veiling the sun, which described its diurnal arc through\r\n'b'an extremely clear sky, indicated that a thick cloud of smoke passed\r\n'b'between its disc and the island. The wind, blowing on the shore, carried\r\n'b'all these vapors to the westward. Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett\r\n'b'remarked these somber appearances, and from time to time discussed\r\n'b'the evident progress of the volcanic phenomena, but their work went\r\n'b'on without interruption. It was, besides, of the first importance from\r\n'b'every point of view, that the vessel should be finished with the least\r\n'b'possible delay. In presence of the eventualities which might arise,\r\n'b'the safety of the colonists would be to a great extent secured by their\r\n'b'ship. Who could tell that it might not prove some day their only refuge?\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In the evening, after supper, Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert\r\n'b'again ascended the plateau of Prospect Heights. It was already dark, and\r\n'b'the obscurity would permit them to ascertain if flames or incandescent\r\n'b'matter thrown up by the volcano were mingled with the vapor and smoke\r\n'b'accumulated at the mouth of the crater.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe crater is on fire!\xe2\x80\x9d said Herbert, who, more active than his\r\n'b'companion, first reached the plateau.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Mount Franklin, distant about six miles, now appeared like a gigantic\r\n'b'torch, around the summit of which turned fuliginous flames. So much\r\n'b'smoke, and possibly scoriae and cinders were mingled with them, that\r\n'b'their light gleamed but faintly amid the gloom of the night. But a kind\r\n'b'of lurid brilliancy spread over the island, against which stood out\r\n'b'confusedly the wooded masses of the heights. Immense whirlwinds of vapor\r\n'b'obscured the sky, through which glimmered a few stars.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe change is rapid!\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not surprising,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the reporter. \xe2\x80\x9cThe reawakening of the\r\n'b'volcano already dates back some time. You may remember, Cyrus, that\r\n'b'the first vapors appeared about the time we searched the sides of the\r\n'b'mountain to discover Captain Nemo\xe2\x80\x99s retreat. It was, if I mistake not,\r\n'b'about the 15th of October.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Herbert, \xe2\x80\x9ctwo months and a half ago!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe subterranean fires have therefore been smoldering for ten weeks,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b' resumed Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cand it is not to be wondered at that they now\r\n'b'break out with such violence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo not you feel a certain vibration of the soil?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gideon Spilett, \xe2\x80\x9cbut there is a great difference between\r\n'b'that and an earthquake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI do not affirm that we are menaced with an earthquake,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cmay God preserve us from that! No; these vibrations are due to\r\n'b'the effervescence of the central fire. The crust of the earth is\r\n'b'simply the shell of a boiler, and you know that such a shell, under the\r\n'b'pressure of steam, vibrates like a sonorous plate. It is this effect\r\n'b'which is being produced at this moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat magnificent flames!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this instant a kind of bouquet of flames shot forth from the crater,\r\n'b'the brilliancy of which was visible even through the vapors. Thousands\r\n'b'of luminous sheets and barbed tongues of fire were cast in various\r\n'b'directions. Some, extending beyond the dome of smoke, dissipated\r\n'b'it, leaving behind an incandescent powder. This was accompanied\r\n'b'by successive explosions, resembling the discharge of a battery of\r\n'b'machine-guns.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, the reporter, and Herbert, after spending an hour on the\r\n'b'plateau of Prospect Heights, again descended to the beach, and returned\r\n'b'to Granite House. The engineer was thoughtful and preoccupied, so much\r\n'b'so, indeed, that Gideon Spilett inquired if he apprehended any immediate\r\n'b'danger, of which the eruption might directly or indirectly be the cause.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and no,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cwould not the greatest\r\n'b'misfortune which could happen to us be an earthquake which would\r\n'b'overturn the island? Now, I do not suppose that this is to be feared,\r\n'b'since the vapors and lava have found a free outlet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cand I do not fear an earthquake in the\r\n'b'sense in which the term is commonly applied to convulsions of the soil\r\n'b'provoked by the expansion of subterranean gases. But other causes may\r\n'b'produce great disasters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHow so, my dear Cyrus?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not certain. I must consider. I must visit the mountain. In a few\r\n'b'days I shall learn more on this point.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Gideon Spilett said no more, and soon, in spite of the explosions of\r\n'b'the volcano, whose intensity increased, and which were repeated by the\r\n'b'echoes of the island, the inhabitants of Granite House were sleeping\r\n'b'soundly.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Three days passed by--the 4th, 5th, and 6th of January. The construction\r\n'b'of the vessel was diligently continued, and without offering further\r\n'b'explanations the engineer pushed forward the work with all his energy.\r\n'b'Mount Franklin was now hooded by a somber cloud of sinister aspect, and,\r\n'b'amid the flames, vomiting forth incandescent rocks, some of which fell\r\n'b'back into the crater itself. This caused Pencroft, who would only look\r\n'b'at the matter in the light of a joke, to exclaim,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh! the giant is playing at cup and ball; he is a conjurer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the substances thrown up fell back again in to the abyss, and\r\n'b'it did not seem that the lava, though swollen by the internal pressure,\r\n'b'had yet risen to the orifice of the crater. At any rate, the opening on\r\n'b'the northeast, which was partly visible, poured out no torrent upon the\r\n'b'northern slope of the mountain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nevertheless, however pressing was the construction of the vessel, other\r\n'b'duties demanded the presence of the colonists on various portions of the\r\n'b'island. Before everything it was necessary to go to the corral, where\r\n'b'the flocks of musmons and goats were enclosed, and replenish the\r\n'b'provision of forage for those animals. It was accordingly arranged that\r\n'b'Ayrton should proceed thither the next day, the 7th of January; and as\r\n'b'he was sufficient for the task, to which he was accustomed, Pencroft and\r\n'b'the rest were somewhat surprised on hearing the engineer say to Ayrton--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs you are going to-morrow to the corral I will accompany you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cour working days will not\r\n'b'be many, and if you go also we shall be two pair of hands short!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall return to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is necessary\r\n'b'that I should go to the corral. I must learn how the eruption is\r\n'b'progressing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe eruption! always the eruption!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pencroft, with an air of\r\n'b'discontent. \xe2\x80\x9cAn important thing, truly, this eruption! I trouble myself\r\n'b'very little about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Whatever might be the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, the expedition projected by the\r\n'b'engineer was settled for the next day. Herbert wished to accompany Cyrus\r\n'b'Harding, but he would not vex Pencroft by his absence.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, at dawn, Cyrus Harding and Ayrton, mounting the cart drawn\r\n'b'by two onagers, took the road to the corral and set off at a round trot.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Above the forest were passing large clouds, to which the crater of Mount\r\n'b'Franklin incessantly added fuliginous matter. These clouds, which rolled\r\n'b'heavily in the air, were evidently composed of heterogeneous substances.\r\n'b'It was not alone from the volcano that they derived their strange\r\n'b'opacity and weight. Scoriae, in a state of dust, like powdered\r\n'b'pumice-stone, and grayish ashes as small as the finest feculae, were\r\n'b'held in suspension in the midst of their thick folds. These ashes are so\r\n'b'fine that they have been observed in the air for whole months. After\r\n'b'the eruption of 1783 in Iceland for upwards of a year the atmosphere was\r\n'b'thus charged with volcanic dust through which the rays of the sun were\r\n'b'only with difficulty discernible.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But more often this pulverized matter falls, and this happened on the\r\n'b'present occasion. Cyrus Harding and Ayrton had scarcely reached the\r\n'b'corral when a sort of black snow like fine gunpowder fell, and instantly\r\n'b'changed the appearance of the soil. Trees, meadows, all disappeared\r\n'b'beneath a covering several inches in depth. But, very fortunately,\r\n'b'the wind blew from the northeast, and the greater part of the cloud\r\n'b'dissolved itself over the sea.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is very singular, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very serious,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cThis powdered pumice-stone,\r\n'b'all this mineral dust, proves how grave is the convulsion going forward\r\n'b'in the lower depths of the volcano.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut can nothing be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, except to note the progress of the phenomenon. Do you,\r\n'b'therefore, Ayrton, occupy yourself with the necessary work at the\r\n'b'corral. In the meantime I will ascend just beyond the source of Red\r\n'b'Creek and examine the condition of the mountain upon its northern\r\n'b'aspect. Then--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Captain Harding?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThen we will pay a visit to Dakkar Grotto. I wish to inspect it. At any\r\n'b'rate I will come back for you in two hours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton then proceeded to enter the corral, and, while awaiting the\r\n'b'engineer\xe2\x80\x99s return, busied himself with the musmons and goats which\r\n'b'seemed to feel a certain uneasiness in presence of these first signs of\r\n'b'an eruption.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile Cyrus Harding ascended the crest of the eastern spur, passed\r\n'b'Red Creek, and arrived at the spot where he and his companions had\r\n'b'discovered a sulphurous spring at the time of their first exploration.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'How changed was everything! Instead of a single column of smoke he\r\n'b'counted thirteen, forced through the soil as if violently propelled by\r\n'b'some piston. It was evident that the crust of the earth was subjected\r\n'b'in this part of the globe to a frightful pressure. The atmosphere was\r\n'b'saturated with gases and carbonic acid, mingled with aqueous vapors.\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding felt the volcanic tufa with which the plain was strewn,\r\n'b'and which was but pulverized cinders hardened into solid blocks by time,\r\n'b'tremble beneath him, but he could discover no traces of fresh lava.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer became more assured of this when he observed all the\r\n'b'northern part of Mount Franklin. Pillars of smoke and flame escaped from\r\n'b'the crater; a hail of scoriae fell on the ground; but no current of\r\n'b'lava burst from the mouth of the volcano, which proved that the volcanic\r\n'b'matter had not yet attained the level of the superior orifice of the\r\n'b'central shaft.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut I would prefer that it were so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cAt\r\n'b'any rate, I should then know that the lava had followed its accustomed\r\n'b'track. Who can say that it may not take a new course? But the danger\r\n'b'does not consist in that! Captain Nemo foresaw it clearly! No, the\r\n'b'danger does not lie there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding advanced towards the enormous causeway whose prolongation\r\n'b'enclosed the narrow Shark Gulf. He could now sufficiently examine on\r\n'b'this side the ancient channels of the lava. There was no doubt in his\r\n'b'mind that the most recent eruption had occurred at a far-distant epoch.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'He then returned by the same way, listening attentively to the\r\n'b'subterranean mutterings which rolled like long-continued thunder,\r\n'b'interrupted by deafening explosions. At nine in the morning he reached\r\n'b'the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton awaited him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe animals are cared for, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood, Ayrton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey seem uneasy, Captain Harding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, instinct speaks through them, and instinct is never deceived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre you ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTake a lamp, Ayrton,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer; \xe2\x80\x9cwe will start at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton did as desired. The onagers, unharnessed, roamed in the corral.\r\n'b'The gate was secured on the outside, and Cyrus Harding, preceding\r\n'b'Ayrton, took the narrow path which led westward to the shore.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The soil they walked upon was choked with the pulverized matter fallen\r\n'b'from the cloud. No quadruped appeared in the woods. Even the birds had\r\n'b'fled. Sometimes a passing breeze raised the covering of ashes, and the\r\n'b'two colonists, enveloped in a whirlwind of dust, lost sight of each\r\n'b'other. They were then careful to cover their eyes and mouths with\r\n'b'handkerchiefs, for they ran the risk of being blinded and suffocated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was impossible for Cyrus Harding and Ayrton, with these impediments,\r\n'b'to make rapid progress. Moreover, the atmosphere was close, as if the\r\n'b'oxygen had been partly burned up, and had become unfit for respiration.\r\n'b'At every hundred paces they were obliged to stop to take breath. It was\r\n'b'therefore past ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock when the engineer and his companion reached\r\n'b'the crest of the enormous mass of rocks of basalt and porphyry which\r\n'b'composed the northwest coast of the island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton and Cyrus Harding commenced the descent of this abrupt declivity,\r\n'b'following almost step for step the difficult path which, during that\r\n'b'stormy night, had led them to Dakkar Grotto. In open day the descent was\r\n'b'less perilous, and, besides, the bed of ashes which covered the polished\r\n'b'surface of the rock enabled them to make their footing more secure.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The ridge at the end of the shore, about forty feet in height, was soon\r\n'b'reached. Cyrus Harding recollected that this elevation gradually sloped\r\n'b'towards the level of the sea. Although the tide was at present low, no\r\n'b'beach could be seen, and the waves, thickened by the volcanic dust, beat\r\n'b'upon the basaltic rocks.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding and Ayrton found without difficulty the entrance to Dakkar\r\n'b'Grotto, and paused for a moment at the last rock before it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe iron boat should be there,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is here, Captain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ayrton, drawing towards him the\r\n'b'fragile craft, which was protected by the arch of the vault.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOn board, Ayrton!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The two colonists stepped into the boat. A slight undulation of the\r\n'b'waves carried it farther under the low arch of the crypt, and there\r\n'b'Ayrton, with the aid of flint and steel, lighted the lamp. He then took\r\n'b'the oars, and the lamp having been placed in the bow of the boat, so\r\n'b'that its rays fell before them, Cyrus Harding took the helm and steered\r\n'b'through the shades of the grotto.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cNautilus\xe2\x80\x9d was there no longer to illuminate the cavern with its\r\n'b'electric light. Possibly it might not yet be extinguished, but no ray\r\n'b'escaped from the depths of the abyss in which reposed all that was\r\n'b'mortal of Captain Nemo.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The light afforded by the lamp, although feeble, nevertheless enabled\r\n'b'the engineer to advance slowly, following the wall of the cavern. A\r\n'b'deathlike silence reigned under the vaulted roof, or at least in the\r\n'b'anterior portion, for soon Cyrus Harding distinctly heard the rumbling\r\n'b'which proceeded from the bowels of the mountain.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat comes from the volcano,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Besides these sounds, the presence of chemical combinations was soon\r\n'b'betrayed by their powerful odor, and the engineer and his companion were\r\n'b'almost suffocated by sulphurous vapors.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is what Captain Nemo feared,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Cyrus Harding, changing\r\n'b'countenance. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must go to the end, notwithstanding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ayrton, bending to his oars and directing the boat\r\n'b'towards the head of the cavern.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Twenty-five minutes after entering the mouth of the grotto the boat\r\n'b'reached the extreme end.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding then, standing up, cast the light of the lamp upon the\r\n'b'walls of the cavern which separated it from the central shaft of the\r\n'b'volcano. What was the thickness of this wall? It might be ten feet or a\r\n'b'hundred feet--it was impossible to say. But the subterranean sounds were\r\n'b'too perceptible to allow of the supposition that it was of any great\r\n'b'thickness.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer, after having explored the wall at a certain height\r\n'b'horizontally, fastened the lamp to the end of an oar, and again surveyed\r\n'b'the basaltic wall at a greater elevation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There, through scarcely visible clefts and joinings, escaped a pungent\r\n'b'vapor, which infected the atmosphere of the cavern. The wall was broken\r\n'b'by large cracks, some of which extended to within two or three feet of\r\n'b'the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding thought for a brief space. Then he said in a low voice,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes! the captain was right! The danger lies there, and a terrible\r\n'b'danger!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Ayrton said not a word, but, upon a sign from Cyrus Harding, resumed the\r\n'b'oars, and half an hour later the engineer and he reached the entrance of\r\n'b'Dakkar Grotto.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 19\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The next day, the 8th day of January, after a day and night passed\r\n'b'at the corral, where they left all in order, Cyrus Harding and Ayrton\r\n'b'arrived at Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer immediately called his companions together, and informed\r\n'b'them of the imminent danger which threatened Lincoln Island, and from\r\n'b'which no human power could deliver them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and his voice betrayed the depth of his emotion,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cour island is not among those which will endure while this earth\r\n'b'endures. It is doomed to more or less speedy destruction, the cause of\r\n'b'which it bears within itself, and from which nothing can save it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists looked at each other, then at the engineer. They did not\r\n'b'clearly comprehend him.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cExplain yourself, Cyrus!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will do so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cor rather I will simply\r\n'b'afford you the explanation which, during our few minutes of private\r\n'b'conversation, was given me by Captain Nemo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Nemo!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the colonists.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and it was the last service he desired to render us before his\r\n'b'death!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe last service!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cthe last service! You will see\r\n'b'that though he is dead he will render us others yet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut what did the captain say?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the reporter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cLincoln Island does\r\n'b'not resemble the other islands of the Pacific, and a fact of which\r\n'b'Captain Nemo has made me cognizant must sooner or later bring about the\r\n'b'subversion of its foundation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense! Lincoln Island, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pencroft, who, in spite\r\n'b'of the respect he felt for Cyrus Harding, could not prevent a gesture of\r\n'b'incredulity.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cListen, Pencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you what Captain\r\n'b'Nemo communicated to me, and which I myself confirmed yesterday, during\r\n'b'the exploration of Dakkar Grotto.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis cavern stretches under the island as far as the volcano, and is\r\n'b'only separated from its central shaft by the wall which terminates it.\r\n'b'Now, this wall is seamed with fissures and clefts which already allow\r\n'b'the sulphurous gases generated in the interior of the volcano to\r\n'b'escape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, his brow suddenly contracting.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I saw that these fissures widen under the internal pressure\r\n'b'from within, that the wall of basalt is gradually giving way and that\r\n'b'after a longer or shorter period it will afford a passage to the waters\r\n'b'of the lake which fill the cavern.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, with an attempt at pleasantry. \xe2\x80\x9cThe sea will\r\n'b'extinguish the volcano, and there will be an end of the matter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot so!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cshould a day arrive when the sea, rushing\r\n'b'through the wall of the cavern, penetrates by the central shaft into the\r\n'b'interior of the island to the boiling lava, Lincoln Island will that day\r\n'b'be blown into the air--just as would happen to the island of Sicily were\r\n'b'the Mediterranean to precipitate itself into Mount Etna.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists made no answer to these significant words of the engineer.\r\n'b'They now understood the danger by which they were menaced.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It may be added that Cyrus Harding had in no way exaggerated the danger\r\n'b'to be apprehended. Many persons have formed an idea that it would be\r\n'b'possible to extinguish volcanoes, which are almost always situated on\r\n'b'the shores of a sea or lake, by opening a passage for the admission of\r\n'b'the water. But they are not aware that this would be to incur the risk\r\n'b'of blowing up a portion of the globe, like a boiler whose steam is\r\n'b'suddenly expanded by intense heat. The water, rushing into a cavity\r\n'b'whose temperature might be estimated at thousands of degrees, would\r\n'b'be converted into steam with a sudden energy which no enclosure could\r\n'b'resist.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was not therefore doubtful that the island, menaced by a frightful\r\n'b'and approaching convulsion, would endure only so long as the wall\r\n'b'of Dakkar Grotto itself should endure. It was not even a question of\r\n'b'months, nor of weeks, but of days; it might be of hours.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first sentiment which the colonists felt was that of profound\r\n'b'sorrow. They thought not so much of the peril which menaced themselves\r\n'b'personally, but of the destruction of the island which had sheltered\r\n'b'them, which they had cultivated, which they loved so well, and had hoped\r\n'b'to render so flourishing. So much effort ineffectually expended, so much\r\n'b'labor lost.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft could not prevent a large tear from rolling down his cheek, nor\r\n'b'did he attempt to conceal it.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Some further conversation now took place. The chances yet in favor of\r\n'b'the colonists were discussed; but finally it was agreed that there was\r\n'b'not an hour to be lost, that the building and fitting of the vessel\r\n'b'should be pushed forward with their utmost energy, and that this was the\r\n'b'sole chance of safety for the inhabitants of Lincoln Island.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'All hands, therefore, set to work on the vessel. What could it avail\r\n'b'to sow, to reap, to hunt, to increase the stores of Granite House?\r\n'b'The contents of the storehouse and outbuildings contained more than\r\n'b'sufficient to provide the ship for a voyage, however long might be its\r\n'b'duration. But it was imperative that the ship should be ready to receive\r\n'b'them before the inevitable catastrophe should arrive.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Their labors were now carried on with feverish ardor. By the 23rd of\r\n'b'January the vessel was half-decked over. Up to this time no change had\r\n'b'taken place on the summit of the volcano. Vapor and smoke mingled with\r\n'b'flames and incandescent stones were thrown up from the crater. But\r\n'b'during the night of the 23rd, in consequence of the lava attaining the\r\n'b'level of the first stratum of the volcano, the hat-shaped cone which\r\n'b'formed over the latter disappeared. A frightful sound was heard. The\r\n'b'colonists at first thought the island was rent asunder, and rushed out\r\n'b'of Granite House.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This occurred about two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The sky appeared on fire. The superior cone, a mass of rock a thousand\r\n'b'feet in height, and weighing thousands of millions of pounds, had\r\n'b'been thrown down upon the island, making it tremble to its foundation.\r\n'b'Fortunately, this cone inclined to the north, and had fallen upon the\r\n'b'plain of sand and tufa stretching between the volcano and the sea. The\r\n'b'aperture of the crater being thus enlarged projected towards the sky a\r\n'b'glare so intense that by the simple effect of reflection the atmosphere\r\n'b'appeared red-hot. At the same time a torrent of lava, bursting from the\r\n'b'new summit, poured out in long cascades, like water escaping from a vase\r\n'b'too full, and a thousand tongues of fire crept over the sides of the\r\n'b'volcano.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe corral! the corral!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ayrton.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was, in fact, towards the corral that the lava was rushing as the\r\n'b'new crater faced the east, and consequently the fertile portions of the\r\n'b'island, the springs of Red Creek and Jacamar Wood, were menaced with\r\n'b'instant destruction.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s cry the colonists rushed to the onagers\xe2\x80\x99 stables. The cart\r\n'b'was at once harnessed. All were possessed by the same thought--to hasten\r\n'b'to the corral and set at liberty the animals it enclosed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Before three in the morning they arrived at the corral. The cries of the\r\n'b'terrified musmons and goats indicated the alarm which possessed them.\r\n'b'Already a torrent of burning matter and liquefied minerals fell from\r\n'b'the side of the mountain upon the meadows as far as the side of the\r\n'b'palisade. The gate was burst open by Ayrton, and the animals, bewildered\r\n'b'with terror, fled in all directions.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An hour afterwards the boiling lava filled the corral, converting into\r\n'b'vapor the water of the little rivulet which ran through it, burning up\r\n'b'the house like dry grass, and leaving not even a post of the palisade to\r\n'b'mark the spot where the corral once stood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'To contend against this disaster would have been folly--nay, madness. In\r\n'b'presence of Nature\xe2\x80\x99s grand convulsions man is powerless.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was now daylight--the 24th of January. Cyrus Harding and his\r\n'b'companions, before returning to Granite House, desired to ascertain the\r\n'b'probable direction this inundation of lava was about to take. The soil\r\n'b'sloped gradually from Mount Franklin to the east coast, and it was to be\r\n'b'feared that, in spite of the thick Jacamar Wood, the torrent would reach\r\n'b'the plateau of Prospect Heights.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe lake will cover us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so!\xe2\x80\x9d was Cyrus Harding\xe2\x80\x99s only reply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists were desirous of reaching the plain upon which the\r\n'b'superior cone of Mount Franklin had fallen, but the lava arrested their\r\n'b'progress. It had followed, on one side, the valley of Red Creek, and\r\n'b'on the other that of Falls River, evaporating those watercourses in its\r\n'b'passage. There was no possibility of crossing the torrent of lava;\r\n'b'on the contrary, the colonists were obliged to retreat before it. The\r\n'b'volcano, without its crown, was no longer recognizable, terminated as it\r\n'b'was by a sort of flat table which replaced the ancient crater. From two\r\n'b'openings in its southern and eastern sides an unceasing flow of lava\r\n'b'poured forth, thus forming two distinct streams. Above the new crater a\r\n'b'cloud of smoke and ashes, mingled with those of the atmosphere, massed\r\n'b'over the island. Loud peals of thunder broke, and could scarcely be\r\n'b'distinguished from the rumblings of the mountain, whose mouth vomited\r\n'b'forth ignited rocks, which, hurled to more than a thousand feet, burst\r\n'b'in the air like shells. Flashes of lightning rivaled in intensity the\r\n'b'volcano\xe2\x80\x99s eruption.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Towards seven in the morning the position was no longer tenable by the\r\n'b'colonists, who accordingly took shelter in the borders of Jacamar Wood.\r\n'b'Not only did the projectiles begin to rain around them, but the lava,\r\n'b'overflowing the bed of Red Creek, threatened to cut off the road to the\r\n'b'corral. The nearest rows of trees caught fire, and their sap, suddenly\r\n'b'transformed into vapor, caused them to explode with loud reports, while\r\n'b'others, less moist, remained unhurt in the midst of the inundation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists had again taken the road to the corral. They proceeded but\r\n'b'slowly, frequently looking back; but, in consequence of the inclination\r\n'b'of the soil, the lava gained rapidly in the east, and as its lower waves\r\n'b'became solidified others, at boiling heat, covered them immediately.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Meanwhile, the principal stream of Red Creek Valley became more and\r\n'b'more menacing. All this portion of the forest was on fire, and enormous\r\n'b'wreaths of smoke rolled over the trees, whose trunks were already\r\n'b'consumed by the lava.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists halted near the lake, about half a mile from the mouth of\r\n'b'Red Creek. A question of life or death was now to be decided.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, accustomed to the consideration of important crises, and\r\n'b'aware that he was addressing men capable of hearing the truth, whatever\r\n'b'it might be, then said,--\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEither the lake will arrest the progress of the lava, and a part of\r\n'b'the island will be preserved from utter destruction, or the stream will\r\n'b'overrun the forests of the Far West, and not a tree or plant will\r\n'b'remain on the surface of the soil. We shall have no prospect but that\r\n'b'of starvation upon these barren rocks--a death which will probably be\r\n'b'anticipated by the explosion of the island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pencroft, folding his arms and stamping his\r\n'b'foot, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use of working any longer on the vessel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPencroft,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must do our duty to the last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'At this instant the river of lava, after having broken a passage through\r\n'b'the noble trees it devoured in its course, reached the borders of the\r\n'b'lake. At this point there was an elevation of the soil which, had it\r\n'b'been greater, might have sufficed to arrest the torrent.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo work!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The engineer\xe2\x80\x99s thought was at once understood. It might be possible to\r\n'b'dam, as it were, the torrent, and thus compel it to pour itself into the\r\n'b'lake.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists hastened to the dockyard. They returned with shovels,\r\n'b'picks, axes, and by means of banking the earth with the aid of fallen\r\n'b'trees they succeeded in a few hours in raising an embankment three feet\r\n'b'high and some hundreds of paces in length. It seemed to them, when\r\n'b'they had finished, as if they had scarcely been working more than a few\r\n'b'minutes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was not a moment too soon. The liquefied substances soon after\r\n'b'reached the bottom of the barrier. The stream of lava swelled like a\r\n'b'river about to overflow its banks, and threatened to demolish the sole\r\n'b'obstacle which could prevent it from overrunning the whole Far West. But\r\n'b'the dam held firm, and after a moment of terrible suspense the torrent\r\n'b'precipitated itself into Grant Lake from a height of twenty feet.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists, without moving or uttering a word, breathlessly regarded\r\n'b'this strife of the two elements.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'What a spectacle was this conflict between water and fire! What pen\r\n'b'could describe the marvelous horror of this scene--what pencil could\r\n'b'depict it? The water hissed as it evaporated by contact with the boiling\r\n'b'lava. The vapor whirled in the air to an immeasurable height, as if\r\n'b'the valves of an immense boiler had been suddenly opened. But, however\r\n'b'considerable might be the volume of water contained in the lake, it must\r\n'b'eventually be absorbed, because it was not replenished, while the stream\r\n'b'of lava, fed from an inexhaustible source, rolled on without ceasing new\r\n'b'waves of incandescent matter.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The first waves of lava which fell in the lake immediately solidified\r\n'b'and accumulated so as speedily to emerge from it. Upon their surface\r\n'b'fell other waves, which in their turn became stone, but a step\r\n'b'nearer the center of the lake. In this manner was formed a pier which\r\n'b'threatened to gradually fill up the lake, which could not overflow, the\r\n'b'water displaced by the lava being evaporated. The hissing of the water\r\n'b'rent the air with a deafening sound, and the vapor, blown by the wind,\r\n'b'fell in rain upon the sea. The pier became longer and longer, and the\r\n'b'blocks of lava piled themselves one on another. Where formerly stretched\r\n'b'the calm waters of the lake now appeared an enormous mass of smoking\r\n'b'rocks, as if an upheaving of the soil had formed immense shoals. Imagine\r\n'b'the waters of the lake aroused by a hurricane, then suddenly solidified\r\n'b'by an intense frost, and some conception may be formed of the aspect of\r\n'b'the lake three hours after the eruption of this irresistible torrent of\r\n'b'lava.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This time water would be vanquished by fire.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Nevertheless it was a fortunate circumstance for the colonists that the\r\n'b'effusion of lava should have been in the direction of Lake Grant. They\r\n'b'had before them some days\xe2\x80\x99 respite. The plateau of Prospect Heights,\r\n'b'Granite House, and the dockyard were for the moment preserved. And these\r\n'b'few days it was necessary to employ in planking and carefully calking\r\n'b'the vessel, and launching her. The colonists would then take refuge on\r\n'b'board the vessel, content to rig her after she should be afloat on the\r\n'b'waters. With the danger of an explosion which threatened to destroy the\r\n'b'island there could be no security on shore. The walls of Granite House,\r\n'b'once so sure a retreat, might at any moment fall in upon them.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the six following days, from the 25th to the 30th of January, the\r\n'b'colonists accomplished as much of the construction of their vessel as\r\n'b'twenty men could have done. They hardly allowed themselves a moment\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n'b'repose, and the glare of the flames which shot from the crater enabled\r\n'b'them to work night and day. The flow of lava continued, but perhaps\r\n'b'less abundantly. This was fortunate, for Lake Grant was almost entirely\r\n'b'choked up, and if more lava should accumulate it would inevitably spread\r\n'b'over the plateau of Prospect Heights, and thence upon the beach.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But if the island was thus partially protected on this side, it was not\r\n'b'so with the western part.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'In fact, the second stream of lava, which had followed the valley of\r\n'b'Falls River, a valley of great extent, the land on both sides of the\r\n'b'creek being flat, met with no obstacle. The burning liquid had then\r\n'b'spread through the forest of the Far West. At this period of the year,\r\n'b'when the trees were dried up by a tropical heat, the forest caught fire\r\n'b'instantaneously, in such a manner that the conflagration extended itself\r\n'b'both by the trunks of the trees and by their higher branches, whose\r\n'b'interlacement favored its progress. It even appeared that the current\r\n'b'of flame spread more rapidly among the summits of the trees than the\r\n'b'current of lava at their bases.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus it happened that the wild animals, jaguars, wild boars, capybaras,\r\n'b'koalas, and game of every kind, mad with terror, had fled to the banks\r\n'b'of the Mercy and to the Tadorn Marsh, beyond the road to Port Balloon.\r\n'b'But the colonists were too much occupied with their task to pay any\r\n'b'attention to even the most formidable of these animals. They had\r\n'b'abandoned Granite House, and would not even take shelter at the\r\n'b'Chimneys, but encamped under a tent, near the mouth of the Mercy.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Each day Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett ascended the plateau of\r\n'b'Prospect Heights. Sometimes Herbert accompanied them, but never\r\n'b'Pencroft, who could not bear to look upon the prospect of the island now\r\n'b'so utterly devastated.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was, in truth, a heart-rending spectacle. All the wooded part of the\r\n'b'island was now completely bare. One single clump of green trees raised\r\n'b'their heads at the extremity of Serpentine Peninsula. Here and there\r\n'b'were a few grotesque blackened and branchless stumps. The side of the\r\n'b'devastated forest was even more barren than Tadorn Marsh. The eruption\r\n'b'of lava had been complete. Where formerly sprang up that charming\r\n'b'verdure, the soil was now nothing but a savage mass of volcanic tufa.\r\n'b'In the valleys of the Falls and Mercy rivers no drop of water now\r\n'b'flowed towards the sea, and should Lake Grant be entirely dried up,\r\n'b'the colonists would have no means of quenching their thirst. But,\r\n'b'fortunately the lava had spared the southern corner of the lake,\r\n'b'containing all that remained of the drinking water of the island.\r\n'b'Towards the northwest stood out the rugged and well-defined outlines of\r\n'b'the sides of the volcano, like a gigantic claw hovering over the island.\r\n'b'What a sad and fearful sight, and how painful to the colonists, who,\r\n'b'from a fertile domain covered with forests, irrigated by watercourses,\r\n'b'and enriched by the produce of their toils, found themselves, as it\r\n'b'were, transported to a desolate rock, upon which, but for their reserves\r\n'b'of provisions, they could not even gather the means of subsistence!\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is enough to break one\xe2\x80\x99s heart!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gideon Spilett, one day.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Spilett,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the engineer. \xe2\x80\x9cMay God grant us the time to\r\n'b'complete this vessel, now our sole refuge!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo not you think, Cyrus, that the violence of the eruption has somewhat\r\n'b'lessened? The volcano still vomits forth lava, but somewhat less\r\n'b'abundantly, if I mistake not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt matters little,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fire is still burning\r\n'b'in the interior of the mountain, and the sea may break in at any moment.\r\n'b'We are in the condition of passengers whose ship is devoured by a\r\n'b'conflagration which they cannot extinguish, and who know that sooner or\r\n'b'later the flames must reach the powder-magazine. To work, Spilett, to\r\n'b'work, and let us not lose an hour!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During eight days more, that is to say until the 7th of February,\r\n'b'the lava continued to flow, but the eruption was confined within the\r\n'b'previous limits. Cyrus Harding feared above all lest the liquefied\r\n'b'matter should overflow the shore, for in that event the dockyard could\r\n'b'not escape. Moreover, about this time the colonists felt in the frame of\r\n'b'the island vibrations which alarmed them to the highest degree.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the 20th of February. Yet another month must elapse before the\r\n'b'vessel would be ready for sea. Would the island hold together till then?\r\n'b'The intention of Pencroft and Cyrus Harding was to launch the vessel\r\n'b'as soon as the hull should be complete. The deck, the upperworks, the\r\n'b'interior woodwork and the rigging might be finished afterwards, but the\r\n'b'essential point was that the colonists should have an assured refuge\r\n'b'away from the island. Perhaps it might be even better to conduct the\r\n'b'vessel to Port Balloon, that is to say, as far as possible from the\r\n'b'center of eruption, for at the mouth of the Mercy, between the islet and\r\n'b'the wall of granite, it would run the risk of being crushed in the event\r\n'b'of any convulsion. All the exertions of the voyagers were therefore\r\n'b'concentrated upon the completion of the hull.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Thus the 3rd of March arrived, and they might calculate upon launching\r\n'b'the vessel in ten days.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Hope revived in the hearts of the colonists, who had, in this fourth\r\n'b'year of their sojourn on Lincoln island, suffered so many trials. Even\r\n'b'Pencroft lost in some measure the somber taciturnity occasioned by\r\n'b'the devastation and ruin of his domain. His hopes, it is true, were\r\n'b'concentrated upon his vessel.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall finish it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the engineer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall finish it,\r\n'b'captain, and it is time, for the season is advancing and the equinox\r\n'b'will soon be here. Well, if necessary, we must put in to Tabor island\r\n'b'to spend the winter. But think of Tabor island after Lincoln Island. Ah,\r\n'b'how unfortunate! Who could have believed it possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLet us get on,\xe2\x80\x9d was the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s invariable reply.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'And they worked away without losing a moment.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMaster,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Neb, a few days later, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think all this could have\r\n'b'happened if Captain Nemo had been still alive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, Neb,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cyrus Harding.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI, for one, don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Pencroft to Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNor I!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Neb seriously.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the first week of March appearances again became menacing.\r\n'b'Thousands of threads like glass, formed of fluid lava, fell like rain\r\n'b'upon the island. The crater was again boiling with lava which overflowed\r\n'b'the back of the volcano. The torrent flowed along the surface of the\r\n'b'hardened tufa, and destroyed the few meager skeletons of trees which had\r\n'b'withstood the first eruption. The stream, flowing this time towards the\r\n'b'southwest shore of Lake Grant, stretched beyond Creek Glycerine, and\r\n'b'invaded the plateau of Prospect Heights. This last blow to the work of\r\n'b'the colonists was terrible. The mill, the buildings of the inner court,\r\n'b'the stables, were all destroyed. The affrighted poultry fled in all\r\n'b'directions. Top and Jup showed signs of the greatest alarm, as if their\r\n'b'instinct warned them of an impending catastrophe. A large number of the\r\n'b'animals of the island had perished in the first eruption. Those which\r\n'b'survived found no refuge but Tadorn Marsh, save a few to which the\r\n'b'plateau of Prospect Heights afforded asylum. But even this last retreat\r\n'b'was now closed to them, and the lava-torrent, flowing over the edge of\r\n'b'the granite wall, began to pour down upon the beach its cataracts of\r\n'b'fire. The sublime horror of this spectacle passed all description.\r\n'b'During the night it could only be compared to a Niagara of molten fluid,\r\n'b'with its incandescent vapors above and its boiling masses below.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists were driven to their last entrenchment, and although the\r\n'b'upper seams of the vessel were not yet calked, they decided to launch\r\n'b'her at once.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Pencroft and Ayrton therefore set about the necessary preparations for\r\n'b'the launching, which was to take place the morning of the next day, the\r\n'b'9th of March.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But during the night of the 8th an enormous column of vapor escaping\r\n'b'from the crater rose with frightful explosions to a height of more than\r\n'b'three thousand feet. The wall of Dakkar Grotto had evidently given way\r\n'b'under the pressure of gases, and the sea, rushing through the central\r\n'b'shaft into the igneous gulf, was at once converted into vapor. But\r\n'b'the crater could not afford a sufficient outlet for this vapor. An\r\n'b'explosion, which might have been heard at a distance of a hundred miles,\r\n'b'shook the air. Fragments of mountains fell into the Pacific, and, in a\r\n'b'few minutes, the ocean rolled over the spot where Lincoln island once\r\n'b'stood.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Chapter 20\r\n'b'\r\n'b'An isolated rock, thirty feet in length, twenty in breadth, scarcely ten\r\n'b'from the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge, such was the only solid point which the waves of\r\n'b'the Pacific had not engulfed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was all that remained of the structure of Granite House! The wall had\r\n'b'fallen headlong and been then shattered to fragments, and a few of the\r\n'b'rocks of the large room were piled one above another to form this point.\r\n'b'All around had disappeared in the abyss; the inferior cone of Mount\r\n'b'Franklin, rent asunder by the explosion; the lava jaws of Shark Gulf,\r\n'b'the plateau of Prospect Heights, Safety Islet, the granite rocks of Port\r\n'b'Balloon, the basalts of Dakkar Grotto, the long Serpentine Peninsula, so\r\n'b'distant nevertheless from the center of the eruption. All that could\r\n'b'now be seen of Lincoln Island was the narrow rock which now served as a\r\n'b'refuge to the six colonists and their dog Top.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The animals had also perished in the catastrophe; the birds, as well\r\n'b'as those representing the fauna of the island--all either crushed or\r\n'b'drowned, and the unfortunate Jup himself had, alas! found his death in\r\n'b'some crevice of the soil.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'If Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft, Neb, and Ayrton\r\n'b'had survived, it was because, assembled under their tent, they had been\r\n'b'hurled into the sea at the instant when the fragments of the island\r\n'b'rained down on every side.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When they reached the surface they could only perceive, at half a\r\n'b'cable\xe2\x80\x99s length, this mass of rocks, towards which they swam and on which\r\n'b'they found footing.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'On this barren rock they had now existed for nine days. A few provisions\r\n'b'taken from the magazine of Granite House before the catastrophe, a\r\n'b'little fresh water from the rain which had fallen in a hollow of the\r\n'b'rock, was all that the unfortunate colonists possessed. Their last hope,\r\n'b'the vessel, had been shattered to pieces. They had no means of quitting\r\n'b'the reef; no fire, nor any means of obtaining it. It seemed that they\r\n'b'must inevitably perish.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'This day, the 18th of March, there remained only provisions for two\r\n'b'days, although they limited their consumption to the bare necessaries\r\n'b'of life. All their science and intelligence could avail them nothing in\r\n'b'their present position. They were in the hand of God.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding was calm, Gideon Spilett more nervous, and Pencroft, a\r\n'b'prey to sullen anger, walked to and fro on the rock. Herbert did not\r\n'b'for a moment quit the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s side, as if demanding from him that\r\n'b'assistance he had no power to give. Neb and Ayrton were resigned to\r\n'b'their fate.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh, what a misfortune! what a misfortune!\xe2\x80\x9d often repeated Pencroft.\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf we had but a walnut-shell to take us to Tabor Island! But we have\r\n'b'nothing, nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Nemo did right to die,\xe2\x80\x9d said Neb.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'During the five ensuing days Cyrus Harding and his unfortunate\r\n'b'companions husbanded their provisions with the most extreme care, eating\r\n'b'only what would prevent them from dying of starvation. Their weakness\r\n'b'was extreme. Herbert and Neb began to show symptoms of delirium.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Under these circumstances was it possible for them to retain even the\r\n'b'shadow of a hope? No! What was their sole remaining chance? That a\r\n'b'vessel should appear in sight of the rock? But they knew only too well\r\n'b'from experience that no ships ever visited this part of the Pacific.\r\n'b'Could they calculate that, by a truly providential coincidence, the\r\n'b'Scotch yacht would arrive precisely at this time in search of Ayrton\r\n'b'at Tabor Island? It was scarcely probable; and, besides, supposing\r\n'b'she should come there, as the colonists had not been able to deposit\r\n'b'a notice pointing out Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s change of abode, the commander of the\r\n'b'yacht, after having explored Tabor Island without results, would again\r\n'b'set sail and return to lower latitudes.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'No! no hope of being saved could be retained, and a horrible death,\r\n'b'death from hunger and thirst, awaited them upon this rock.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Already they were stretched on the rock, inanimate, and no longer\r\n'b'conscious of what passed around them. Ayrton alone, by a supreme effort,\r\n'b'from time to time raised his head, and cast a despairing glance over the\r\n'b'desert ocean.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'But on the morning of the 24th of March Ayrton\xe2\x80\x99s arms were extended\r\n'b'toward a point in the horizon; he raised himself, at first on his knees,\r\n'b'then upright, and his hand seemed to make a signal.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A sail was in sight off the rock. She was evidently not without an\r\n'b'object. The reef was the mark for which she was making in a direct line,\r\n'b'under all steam, and the unfortunate colonists might have made her out\r\n'b'some hours before if they had had the strength to watch the horizon.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Ayrton--and fell back without sign of life.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'When Cyrus Harding and his companions recovered consciousness, thanks to\r\n'b'the attention lavished upon them, they found themselves in the cabin of\r\n'b'a steamer, without being able to comprehend how they had escaped death.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A word from Ayrton explained everything.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Duncan\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cyrus Harding. And raising his hand to Heaven,\r\n'b'he said, \xe2\x80\x9cOh! Almighty God! mercifully hast Thou preserved us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was, in fact, the \xe2\x80\x9cDuncan,\xe2\x80\x9d Lord Glenarvan\xe2\x80\x99s yacht, now commanded by\r\n'b'Robert, son of Captain Grant, who had been despatched to Tabor Island to\r\n'b'find Ayrton, and bring him back to his native land after twelve years of\r\n'b'expiation.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists were not only saved, but already on the way to their\r\n'b'native country.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Grant,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cwho can have suggested to you the\r\n'b'idea, after having left Tabor Island, where you did not find Ayrton, of\r\n'b'coming a hundred miles farther northeast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Harding,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Robert Grant, \xe2\x80\x9cit was in order to find, not\r\n'b'only Ayrton, but yourself and your companions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy companions and myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless, at Lincoln Island.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt Lincoln Island!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed in a breath Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Neb,\r\n'b'and Pencroft, in the highest degree astonished.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHow could you be aware of the existence of Lincoln Island?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired\r\n'b'Cyrus Harding, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not even named in the charts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI knew of it from a document left by you on Tabor Island,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\n'b'Robert Grant.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA document!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Gideon Spilett.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt, and here it is,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Robert Grant, producing a\r\n'b'paper which indicated the longitude and latitude of Lincoln Island, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\n'b'present residence of Ayrton and five American colonists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Captain Nemo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Cyrus Harding, after having read the notice,\r\n'b'and recognized that the handwriting was similar to that of the paper\r\n'b'found at the corral.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pencroft, \xe2\x80\x9cit was then he who took our \xe2\x80\x98Bonadventure\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\n'b'hazarded himself alone to go to Tabor Island!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn order to leave this notice,\xe2\x80\x9d added Herbert.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI was then right in saying,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cthat even after his\r\n'b'death the captain would render us a last service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, in a voice of the profoundest emotion,\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cmay the God of mercy have had pity on the soul of Captain Nemo, our\r\n'b'benefactor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'The colonists uncovered themselves at these last words of Cyrus Harding,\r\n'b'and murmured the name of Captain Nemo.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Then Ayrton, approaching the engineer, said simply, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere should this\r\n'b'coffer be deposited?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'It was the coffer which Ayrton had saved at the risk of his life, at\r\n'b'the very instant that the island had been engulfed, and which he now\r\n'b'faithfully handed to the engineer.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAyrton! Ayrton!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cyrus Harding, deeply touched. Then, addressing\r\n'b'Robert Grant, \xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cyou left behind you a criminal; you find\r\n'b'in his place a man who has become honest by penitence, and whose hand I\r\n'b'am proud to clasp in mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Robert Grant was now made acquainted with the strange history of Captain\r\n'b'Nemo and the colonists of Lincoln Island. Then, observation being taken\r\n'b'of what remained of this shoal, which must henceforward figure on the\r\n'b'charts of the Pacific, the order was given to make all sail.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'A few weeks afterwards the colonists landed in America, and found their\r\n'b'country once more at peace after the terrible conflict in which right\r\n'b'and justice had triumphed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Of the treasures contained in the coffer left by Captain Nemo to the\r\n'b'colonists of Lincoln Island, the larger portion was employed in the\r\n'b'purchase of a vast territory in the State of Iowa. One pearl alone, the\r\n'b'finest, was reserved from the treasure and sent to Lady Glenarvan in the\r\n'b'name of the castaways restored to their country by the \xe2\x80\x9cDuncan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There, upon this domain, the colonists invited to labor, that is to say,\r\n'b'to wealth and happiness, all those to whom they had hoped to offer the\r\n'b'hospitality of Lincoln Island. There was founded a vast colony to\r\n'b'which they gave the name of that island sunk beneath the waters of the\r\n'b'Pacific. A river there was called the Mercy, a mountain took the name\r\n'b'of Mount Franklin, a small lake was named Lake Grant, and the forests\r\n'b'became the forests of the Far West. It might have been an island on\r\n'b'terra firma.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There, under the intelligent hands of the engineer and his companions,\r\n'b'everything prospered. Not one of the former colonists of Lincoln Island\r\n'b'was absent, for they had sworn to live always together. Neb was with his\r\n'b'master; Ayrton was there ready to sacrifice himself for all; Pencroft\r\n'b'was more a farmer than he had ever been a sailor; Herbert, who completed\r\n'b'his studies under the superintendence of Cyrus Harding, and Gideon\r\n'b'Spilett, who founded the New Lincoln Herald, the best-informed journal\r\n'b'in the world.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There Cyrus Harding and his companions received at intervals visits from\r\n'b'Lord and Lady Glenarvan, Captain John Mangles and his wife, the sister\r\n'b'of Robert Grant, Robert Grant himself, Major McNab, and all those who\r\n'b'had taken part in the history both of Captain Grant and Captain Nemo.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'There, to conclude, all were happy, united in the present as they had\r\n'b'been in the past; but never could they forget that island upon which\r\n'b'they had arrived poor and friendless, that island which, during four\r\n'b'years had supplied all their wants, and of which there remained but a\r\n'b'fragment of granite washed by the waves of the Pacific, the tomb of him\r\n'b'who had borne the name of Captain Nemo.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'\r\n'b'End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of The Mysterious Island, by Jules Verne\r\n'b'\r\n'b'*** END OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK THE MYSTERIOUS ISLAND ***\r\n'b'\r\n'b'***** This file should be named 1268-0.txt or 1268-0.zip *****\r\n'b'This and all associated files of various formats will be found in:\r\n'b'        http://www.gutenberg.org/1/2/6/1268/\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Produced by Anthony Matonak, and Trevor Carlson\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Updated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions\r\n'b'will be renamed.\r\n'b'\r\n'b'Creating the works from public domain print editions means that no\r\n'b'one owns a United States copyright in these works, so the Foundation\r\n'b'(and you!) can copy and distribute it in the United States without\r\n'b'permission and without paying copyright royalties.
